title: General Out of Step
description: Senator Stuart Symington, acting chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, has properly ques tioned the dual role of Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. While serving as head of President Nixon's civilian staff, Gen eral Haig also continues to hold the position of Army Vice Chief of Staff.

title: Weis Staff Locked Out In S.I.P.C. TakeOver
description: Employes of Weis Secur ities, Inc., the defunct stock brokerage firm that was put into liquidation late Wednes day, were locked out of their offices yesterday as the Se curities Investor Protection Corporation took over.

title: Miss Frances Dixon Burden Married to Hilaire O'Malley
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More. was the setting here yester day afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Frances Dixon Burden to Hilaire O'Malley. Msgr. James G. Wilders, the pastor, perfOrmed the cere mony, assisted by Dom Hil iary Martin of the Ports mouth Abbey School.

title: Evelyn McKay, Founded Unit to Aid Blind Musicians
description: Evelyn C. McKay, executive director and founder of the Louis Braille Foundation for Blind Musicians, died, apparent ly of a heart attack, in Beth Israel Hospital on Tuesday. She was 74 years old and lived at 23 West 12th Street.

title: GREECE DISMISSES CHIEF OF THE NAVY
description: ATHENS, May 31  Greece's armybacked Government to night dismissed the navy chief amid reports that it was speed ing plans to end the monarchy and set up a republic.

title: Cahill Gains 2 of 7 Points On Tocks Island Proposal
description: Governor Cahill of New Jersey said yesterday that two of his objections to the controversial Tocks Island dam project had been resolved but that five others remained to be met be fore he could approve the pro jest.

title: People in Sports: Pele Keeps Flanks Covered
description: Pele, the world's most fam ous soccer player, leads his Santos of Brazil team against Deportivo Guadalajara of Mexico in Oakland tonight if he didn't forget to pack two pairs of trunks. After he scored three firsthalf goals in a 64 victory over the Baltimore Bays Wednesday night, some of the 24,680 en thusiastic fans mobbed him on the way to the lockerroom and he lost another of his No. 10 jerseys.

title: Yankee Records
description: BATTING

title: Stop the Bombing
description: The Senate acted decisively on behalf of the rule of law in the United States and against further bombing in Indochina with its 63to19 vote to cut off all funds for United States military activity in Cambodia and Laos.

title: ITALIAN DEFEATS ASHE IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, May 31 (AP)Arthur Ashe was eliminated in straight sets and topseeded Stan Smith was fighting to hang on today as rain halted completion of the fourth round of the French open tennis championships.

title: DECISION ON HOUSING IS TOWNS', U.D.C. SAYS
description: RYE, N. Y., May 31An offi cial of the Urban Development Corporation said tonight that the next move in developing lowincome and middleincome housing in northern Westches ter County was up to the re gion's Town Supervisors.

title: RUSK REMEMBERS NO TAPS ON AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  Dean Rusk said today that he could not recall any use of wiretaps during his eight years as Secretary of State on Govern ment personnel or reporters to trace news leaks, a procedure he called rather futile and unwholesome.

title: Brdge: 2 Top Teams Barely Survive SecondRound Reisinger Play
Roundup: Stargell Hits 14th Home Run
description: Earlier this season Willie Stargell, the powerful slugger of the Pittsburgh Pirates, who has been known to make outrageous predictions and then have them come true, said,  . . . If I stay healthy, I could hit 60 home runs this season.

title: She Doesn't Care for Politics But She's Marrying the Mayor
description: FORT LEE, N.J.,What's a nice Jewish Democratic Mayor like Burt Ross doing with the daughter of a Re publican Irish cop? They're getting married, that's what. We are the Bridget and Bernie of Fort Lee, grinned the 30yearold Mayor of what some people call New York's sixth borough, Fort Lee, N.J.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 1, 1973

title: Middle Class in South Jamaica Seems to Be Leaning to Beame
description: Middleclass voters in South Jamaica, Queens, seem to like Controller Abraham D. Beame for Mayor.

title: KEY SOSTRE WITNESS TELLS COURT HE LIED
description: BUFFALO, May 31A perjury indictment will be sought against a principal prosecution witness in the trial of Martin Sostre, who was convicted in 1968 of selling narcotics and sentenced to 30 to 40 years in prison, the District Attorney's office announced today.

title: BYRNE PROMISES TO BAR SUPER PORT
description: NEWARK, May 31Brendan T. Byrne, campaigning here for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, said today that as Governor he would not allow a super port to be built on the Jersey coast for large oil tankers.

title: CHEMICAL PRODUCTS ARE RAISED IN PRICE
description: The Dow Corning Corpora tion announced yesterday in creases of 7 to 10 cents a pound on its total line of hightemper ature coating resins that are used in paints and delivered in drums.

title: Football Transactions
description: MONTREALSigned Cam Innes, center, from University of Windsor and John Adkins, linebacker, from University of Nebraska.

title: Advertising: Revving Up Chevy
description: How would you judge the nation's top car salesman?

title: A Listing of Off Off Broadway Shows
description: It's advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices before going to the show. Most, if not all, thea ters accept Theater Develop ment Fund vouchers.

title: 650 Student Winners Plan Concert Tonight
description: HOLMDEL, May 31Teen agers from seven counties 650 strongare tuning up for their debuts in the New Jer sey high school band and choral festival, scheduled for tomorrow night at the Gar den State Arts Center.

title: Goodrich Pact Reached
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 31 (AP) The United Rubber Workers and B. F. Goodrich Company reached a tentative agreement on a new contract today follow ing allnight negotiations, a company spokesman said. The details of the agreement, which is subject to ratification by union members, were not dis closed. The union struck Good rich plants across the country May 7.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ALBANY, May 31 (AP)The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court dismissed today the attempt of ??ratoga Raceway and Roosevelt Raceway, harness tracks, to block quarterhorse race tracks in Albany and Suffolk Counties. The harness tracks had contended a section of the quarterhorse racing law was discriminatory in allowing quarterhorse tracks to be established in the two counties so long as they were more than 35 miles away from existing tracks. They argued that other tracks in the state were allowed a buffer zone of at least 50 miles.

title: Sackett Promising In a Walzer Debut With the City Ballet
description: George Balanchine's Liebes lieder Walzer is a ballet about people revealing their private passions publicly. As its first performance of the season at the State Theater proved again Tuesday, these closeups of four couples in a 19thcentury bour geois ballroom waltzing away to Brahms can be enjoyed on two levels.

title: An Alternative
description: WASHINGTONIt is not necessary to give credence to the hearsay of John Dean and James McCord to conclude that the Administration is badly wounded. Even if we assume its elected leadership to have been entire ly unaware of the illicit activities and of the subsequent coverup, Mr. Nixon and Mr. Agnew must bear the respon sibility for the actions of their Admin istration  for the men chosen to administer, and for its moral tone.

title: COAST FINANCIER ACCUSED BY S.E.C. OF MASSIVE FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The Securities and Exchange Com mission today charged C. Arn holt Smith, a California finan cier and longtime confidant of President Nixon, with a mas sive fraudulent manipulation de signed to misappropriate the assets of a West Coast conglo merate he heads and a San Diego bank.

title: Alitz Runs Fast 2Mile
description: NANUET, N. Y., May 31 Curt Alitz of Highland Falls High School won the twomile run today in 9 minutes 5.1 sec onds in the Section 9 cham pionships. It was the sixth fastest twomile run by a New York State schoolboy. Alitz has a 9:04.2 clocking on his unbeaten record.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: HALDEMAN DENIES ROLE IN COVERUP; CONFLICT WIDENS
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The conflict between top former White House aides and officials of the Central Intelligence Agency over their roles in the Watergate case widened today.

title: GOODRICH AND UNION IN TENTATIVE PACT
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 31 (AP)A tentative agreement in a 24day United Rubber Work ers strike against the B. F. Goodrich Company calls for wage increases of up to 80.8 cents an hour over three years, the company and the union said today.

title: Major League Baseball Friday, June 1, 1973
description: American League

title: C.I.A. Reportedly Asked F.B.I. Not to Question 2 on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 Central Intelligence Agency of ficials asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation last June not to interview two C.I.A. employes in connection with the Water gate case for fear that they would be exposed, Justice De partment sources said today.

title: Financier Mixes Sports With Politics
description: Ask almost anyone who C. Arnholt Smith is. If he knows  and the chances that he will are very slim  he will prob ably say that he's the guy that owns the San Diego Padres, a somewhat less than successful baseball club.

title: Philadelphia Warden and Aide Stabbed to Death by 2 Inmates
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (UPI)Two Inmates, one a Black Muslim convicted of killing a policeman, stabbed to death the warden and deputy warden of Holmesburg Prison today before being wounded and subdued.

title: Sword Sold for $70,000
description: A 17thcentury Japanese cav alry sword brought a record price of $70,000 at an auction held by the Sotheby Parke Bernet galleries yesterday. The Koto Tachi blade was crafted in 1603 by Suketsugu, one of the finest sword makers of the time, a gallery spokesman said. Sam Someya, a dealer with galleries in London and Tokyo, had the winning bid.

title: Nixon and Pompidou Fail To Resolve Major Issues
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 31The United States and France failed today to narrow significantly the questions that divide them, but their Presidents agreed to a new series of negotiations by subordi nates.

title: White House Says It Is Unable To Talk With Indians on Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The White House has rejected the concept that it can enter into treaty negotiations with Ameri can Indians who are attempting to assert their sovereignty and to dismantle the structure that the Government has built to deal with Indian affairs.

title: SAVAGE REMAINS ON CRITICAL LIST
Mrs. Kate Seelye, Teacher In Lebanon and Turkey
description: SYRACUSE, May 31  Mrs. Kate Chambers Seelye, a for mer teacher at the American Junior College for Girls in Bei rut, Lebanon, and the American College for Girls in Istanbul, Turkey, died today in the Plaza Nursing Home. She was 84 years old and lived at 50 Morn ingside Drive in New York.

title: Banker Here Pleads No Contest To Charge He Hid Political Aid
description: John L. Loeb, an investment banker and philanthropist, pleaded no contest in Federal Court yesterday to three charg es of having disguised cam paign contributions to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's 1972 Presidential race.

title: Senate Unit Investigating Moves Against Radicals
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The Senate Watergate committee is investigating the Justice De partment's campaign against radicals.

title: $5Million and Publisher's Estate Are Left to Yale
description: A $5million endowment and a Mount Kisco, N. Y., estate belonging to the late Eugene Meyer, publisher of The Washington Post, have been donated to Yale Univer sity for study and confer ence use.

title: Speedway Slaughter
description: The slaughter that marked the 1973 Indianapolis automobile race cannot be categorized as accidental deaths. What happened on the infamous speedway has come to be a routine form of homicide. In 57 years of racing in Indianapolis there has not been a single year without a serious accident. Furthermore, the annual mayhem at Indianapolis only encourages it elsewhere. A columnist for the Indianapolis News, after following up the fortunes of all 33 drivers in the 1953 race, reports that in the intervening twenty years fourteen of them died in racing accidents and a fifteenth was paralyzed as a result of an injurynearly a 50 per cent toll.

title: Terrorists in Belfast Kill 2 Men and Wound 9
description: BELFAST, Northern Ire land, Friday, June 1 (AP) Terrorists bombed two tav erns in downtown Belfast last night and sprayed one of them with machinegun fire, the police reported. Two men were killed and at least nine other persons were in jured.

title: PENN, WISCONSIN GAIN I.R.A. FINAL
description: SYRACUSE, May 31  The Pennsylvania and Wisconsin crews won the two heats for varsity eights today as the In tercollegiate Rowing Associa tion championships began. The Red and Blue and the Badgers thus qualified for Saturday's final. The nine other crews will row again tomorrow in the two repechage or second chance heats to determine the field of six.

title: Indian Jet Carrying 65 Crashes South of New Delhi and 48 Die
description: NEW DELHI, May 31 (UPI) An Indian Airlines jet crashed into a residential area while approaching Palam Airport in New Delhi tonight, killing 48 of the 65 people aboard. Two Indian officials were among the dead.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Hours are given In Eastern Daylight Time.

title: Stanley Dancer Picks Up Winning Habit at Yonkers
description: YONKERS, May 31Stan ley Dancer, who two decades ago drove winners regularly at Yonkers Raceway but has been in action here less fre quently the last few seasons is being seen on a regular basis again on the Westches ter County track.

title: San Diego Never Had It So Bad
description: SAN DIEGO, May 31The New York Mets finally found somebody with more trouble than themselves today when they arrived in San Diego limping liketo use a locally unpopular term  a lame duck.

title: 4 Convicted of Slaying Officer In 1972 Holdup of Meat Market
description: Four Brooklyn men on trial for the second time for the murder of a policeman during a 1972 holdup at a Fort Greene meat market were found guilty by a State Supreme Court jury yesterday, and may thus be subject to the death penalty.

title: Spare Power in Hospitals
description: Nearly 90 per cent of the hospitals in the city have standby electric generators ready for use in case of power blackouts, according to the re sults of an inspection by the Health Department. Dr. Joseph A. Cimino, the Commissioner of Health, ordered the survey in anticipation of electric pow er shortages over the summer.

title: Energy Shortage Continues to Perplex Skylab Team
description: HOUSTON, May 31  An energy crisis continued aboard the Skylab station today, but the three astronauts went ahead with medical experi ments and the operation of solar and stellar telescopes.

title: Barbara Martin's Singing Enlivens Juilliard Concert
description: JUILLIARD SCHOOL CONTEMPORARY CHAMBER MUSIC CONCERT, Richard Dufallo conducting. At the Juillard Theater.

title: Trade Board Head Quits
description: MONROE, N. C., May 31 (UPI) Henry Hall Wilson resigned his $115,000ayear post as president of the Chicago Board of Trade today to seek the Sen ate seat now held by Sen. Sam J. Ervin Jr., of North Carolina. Mr. Wilson, 51 years old, is a Democrat and a former legisla tor and official of the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.

title: DRAFT OF SCIENTIST ASSAILED IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, May 31A lead ing Jewish physicist accused the Soviet authorities today of cruel, lawless and totally un humanitarian action in draft ing an ailing son, himself a noted astrophysicist, for service in an Arctic military unit.

title: Miss Carillo Gains Semifinal Of Eastern Tennis Tourney
description: WOODBURY, L. I., May 31 Mary Carillo of Douglaston, Queens, defeated thirdseeded Adria Price of Roslyn Heights, L. I., 26, 63, 64, today to gain the semifinals of the East ern women's hardcourt tennis championships at the Woodbury Country Club.

title: GEST APO ATTITUDE SEEN IN DEAN PAPERS
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., May 31 (AP)Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. says secret papers of the former White House coun sel, John W. Dean 3d, show a Gestapo mentality in the highest levels of the Nixon Ad ministration.

title: 40,000 Attend Fete for Retarded
description: The Central Park Sheep Meadow swarmed yesterday with a combined garden party, carnival and play day for more than 15,000 children and adults who came from institutions and specialedu cation classes to the second annual One to One Festival for the Mentally Retarded.

title: PENN, WISCONSIN GAIN I.R.A. FINAL
description: SYRACUSE, May 31  The Pennsylvania and Wisconsin crews won the two heats for varsity eights today as the In tercollegiate Rowing Associa tion championships began. The Red and Blue and the Badgers thus qualified for Saturday's final. The nine other crews will row again tomorrow in the two repechage or second chance heats to determine the field of six.

title: N.B.C. and Soviet Sign RadioTV Exchange Pact
description: The National Broadcasting Company and the Soviet Union signed an agreement yesterday providing for the future ex change of television and radio programs.

title: Pact on Public TV Control Reached, Ending Dispute
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Public Broadcasting Service approved an agreement yesterday to end their long battle over control of public TV and program de cisionmaking.

title: Judge Blames Mitchell as He Dismisses 11 Cases
description: MIAMI, May 31 (AP)United States District Court Judge Wil liam Mehrtens said today that he had suppressed wiretaps showing overwhelming evi dence of guilt in 11 Federal gambling, narcotics and bribery cases because former Attorney General John N. Mitchell be lieved he could ignore an ex press command of Congress.

title: Democratic Leaders Wield Little Power
description: Once practically invincible in a primary, the five county democratic organizations are now so badly split that they are having little impact in next Monday's citywide Democratic primary.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: KANSAS CITYSigned Zollo Versalles, in fielder, formerly with Sabinas of Mexican League, and assigned hint to Jacksonville farm club.

title: My Gallant Wins, Will Race in Belmont Stakes
description: My Gallant contributed a sparkling performance at Bel mont Park yesterday, and in so doing qualified for the Belmont Stakes. The Kentucky bred 3yearold son of Gallant Man defeated five older horses at a mile and an eighth, racing in front all the way. He scored by 2 lengths over the favored Loud and by another 2 lengths over Whitey II before a crowd of 18,077.

title: SPELLBOUND WINS HACKOFF AT DEVON
description: DEVON, Pa., May 31Spell bound, Peanut Painter and Royal Blue all won green working hunter championships at the Devon horse show to lay  two with consummate ease and one in a hackoff, which is as close as a contest can be.

title: U.S. Seeks to Reassure Israel on Arms Sales to Arabs
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The United States sought to allay Israeli concern today over the major sale of American military equipment to the Arab states on the Persian Gulf, including an impending purchase of ad vanced F4 Phantom fighter bombers by Saudi Arabia.

title: Holtzman Is Felled in Eighth After Holding Yanks to 1 Hit
description: Matty Alou wiped out Ken Holtzman's perfect game and Jim Ray Hart almost wiped out his career. But Holtzman emerged in slightly better shape than his perfect game as the Oakland A's whipped the Yan kees, 60, last night.

title: Most Issues at Lows
WILLIAM H. SPIER, 66, TV PRODUCER IS DEAD
description: WESTON, Conn., May 31 William Hannan Spier, former radio and television director and producer and husband of June Havoc, the actress, who appeared in some of his shows, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 66 years old.

title: Skylab Instruments Detect a Hole in Sun's Upper Atmosphere
description: HOUSTON, May 31  Sky lab instruments have detected an enormous hole in the sun's upper atmosphere, or corona.

title: Red Smith A Stately Pleasure Dome Decreed
description: Faintly seen through overcast, the Empire State Build ing was a pencil stripe against the sky, but at ground level there was an abomination of desolationacres of muck and rubble stretching away to squishy green tidal marshes. We will stand here again, Sonny Werblin had said on an earlier occasion when his speech writer was at the top of his game, and marvel together at what men of determination, goodwill and strong faith can achieve. The good Lord willing, we will transform what is before you today into an area of beauty, excite ment and pleasure for you, your children and generations still to come. This time, though, Sonny was working without a script, ad libbing for a press crew he had invited to come and hear how comfortable and well fed the press would be same day covering races and games on the Hackensack Meadows.

title: U.S. Jury Indicts Two More Companies On Tax Charges in 1969 Cahill Drive
description: NEWARK, May 31  United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern said today that a Federal grand jury had indicted two more corporations on income tax charges as an outgrowth of an investigation of alleged irregularities in the financing of Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign.

title: FREDERICK CORWIN
description: GREENPORT, L. I., May 31 Frederick Langton Corwin, pub lisher of The Suffolk Times, until his retirement in 1969, died Tuesday in the Eastern Suffolk Nursing Home. He was 84 years old.

title: STOCK PRICES DIP ON AMEX AND OTO Inflationary Pressures and Dollar Worries Reflected
Mayor Elevates Career Housing Aide to Golar Post
description: A career professional in the city's housing bureaucracy, who started as an $840ayear Build ings Dtpartment clerk during the Depression, was named by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to become chairman of the Hous ing Authority, which operates the lowrent public housing pro gram here.

title: Wightman Cup Dates Listed
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., May 31 (UPI)The 50th annual Wightman Cup tennis matches between women players from Britain and the United States will be played Aug. 24 to 26 here at Longwood Cricket Club, the home club of Mrs. Hazel Wightman, 86yearold donor of the cup.

title: Pennsy Rejects Rail Plan; Says Vast Aid Is Needed
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) The bankrupt Penn Central Railroad said today it could not continue operations beyond the end of the year without substantial government as sistance.

title: MRS. NORA MELLON
description: Mrs. Nora McMullen Mellon, former wife of the late Andrew W. Mellon, the Pittsburgh fin ancier and art collector who was Secretary of the Treasury from 1921 to 1932, died Tues day in Roosevelt Hospital. She was 94 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: U.S. Studying Blast That Killed Wife and Son of Police Chemist
description: WILLINGBORO, May 31  Federal investigators today studied material found near an explosion here to determine if the blast, which killed the wife and son of a state crime ex pert, yesterday, was caused by a bomb.

title: Bar Group Backs Hogan, Rules Out vanden Heuvel
description: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night gave William J. vanden Heuvel, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan District Attorney, its lowest rating: Not ap proved.

title: WALTER F. ROCKWELL
description: DETROIT, May 31 (UPI) Walter F. Rockwell, industri alist and a pioneer in the auto motive component business, died at his home in Grosse Pointe Farms Tuesday. He was 73 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating Outlook
description: From southern New Jersey to Rhode Island, the most encouraging angling news is probably the amazing influx of northern weakfish in Nar ragansett Bay. For the past several years, weakfish have been appearing in the bay in greater and greater numbers and now the fishing for the species there is better than anyone can remember. The fish are averaging 6 pounds and some over 11 pounds have been caught.

title: Humble Pie Serves Up Fine n Frenzied Rock n Roll
description: Humble Pie headlined a fine and frenzied rocknroll con cert on Tuesday at a packed Madison Square Garden, even if it did end on a sentimental note with Vera Lynn's voice proclaiming, we'll meet again. And the audience members obviously felt the vibrations from the British group because it was on its collective feet early and re mained on them long.

title: Deputy Charged in Slaying
description: ESCANABA, Mich., May 31 (AP)A Delta County sheriff's deputy was charged today with the murder of his wife and two infant sons, county offi cials said. The deputy, Dennis Murphy, was charged after the bodies of his wife and sons were found in the ashes of their burnedout home.

title: MRS. CARPENTER
description: WILMINGTON, Del., May 31 (AP)Mrs. Margaretta Lammot du Pont Carpenter, the mother of R. M. Carpenter Jr., owner of the Philadelphia Phillies baseball team, died today at her home near here. She was 89 years old.

title: Special Phone Number For Election Questions
description: A special telephone num ber, 2679800, has been set up by the city's Board of Elections for New Yorkers with questions about the pri mary election.

title: Banker Here Pleads No Contest To Charge He Hid Political Aid
description: John L. Loeb, an investment banker and philanthropist, pleaded no contest in Federal Court yesterday to three charg es of having disguised cam paign contributions to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's 1972 Presidential race.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ALBANY, May 31 (AP)The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court dismissed today the attempt of Saratoga Raceway and Roosevelt Raceway, harness tracks, to block quarterhorse race tracks in Albany and Suffolk Counties. The harness tracks had contended a section of the quarterhorse racing law was discriminatory in allowing quarterhorse tracks to be established in the two counties so long as they were more than 35 miles away from existing tracks. They argued that other tracks in the state were allowed a buffer zone of at least 50 miles.

title: The Pop Life Yes, Rock Has Lasted
description: Said Dick Clark, who was one of the first disk jockeys to recognize the potency of rock'n'roll: In the nineteen fifties people used to ask me, How long can rock last? For Clark it has lasted 20 years at least1973 is the 20th anniversary of Ameri can Bandstand, the dance record show in which he sprang to fame. And Clark is still running.

title: Farm Prices Climb
description: The Administration's hopes of reducing inflation received a setback yesterday as the Department of Agriculture reported that farm prices, after dipping in April, re sumed their sharp rise in May. Prices received by farm ers in the month to May 15 were up 33 per cent from a year earlier. Details, Page 47.

title: Pact on Public TV Control Reached, Ending Dispute
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Public Broadcasting Service approved an agreement yesterday to end their long battle over control of public TV and program de cisionmaking.

title: Toronto Dominion Bank Raises Prime Lending Rate
description: TORONTO, May 31 (Canadian Press)  The Toronto Dominion Bank announced today it was increasing its prime lending rate onequarter of one per cent to 7 per cent. The increase follows a similar raise an nounced by the Bank of Mont real last weekend.

title: $1,000 Reward Offered In Slaying of IND Clerk
description: The Transport Workers Union is offering a $1,000 reward for information leading to the ar rest and conviction of the rob ber who shot and killed a sub way clerk in Brooklyn after taking $138.

title: Mayor Elevates Career Housing Aide to Golar Post
description: A career professional in the city's housing bureaucracy, who started as an $840ayear Build ings Department clerk during the Depression, was named by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to become chairman of the Hous ing Authority, which operates the lowrent public housing pro gram here.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly to cut off all funds for the Cambodian bombing, go ing further than the House, which has passed a milder restriction. The vote came several hours after the Pentagon announced a reduc tion in bombing missions over Cambodia, partly because Congress had not authorized a requested transfer of defense funds. The two houses versions must now be reconciled before the bill can be sent to the White House. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: U.S. Wrestlers Seek to Break Soviet Stranglehold Tonight
description: In the 21 years that wrestler from the Soviet Union have been competing on an interna tional level, no American team has ever beaten a Soviet team.

title: State Ban on PhosphateDetergent Sales Takes Effect
description: Beginning today, New York State consumers will have to make do mostly with phos phatefree detergents.

title: Egypt Will Press Security Council on Israeli Pullback
description: CAIRO, May 31Diplomatic sources reported today that Egypt would ask the United Nations Security Council next week to bring about swift compliance with its 1967 call for the withdrawal of Israeli forces from occupied Arab ter ritories.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Vietnamese are indeed the political footballs Frances FitzGerald lucidly analyzes them to be in her May 4 OpEd article on the Mylai refugees in Quang Ngai Province.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Tickets matching the num ber above win $50,000. Tick ets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four num bers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

title: Women's Golf Postponed
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 31 (AP)  Lightning and rain caused postponement today of the first round of the $100,000 SealyFaberge Golf Classic. The Ladies Professional Association tournament was also cut from 72 holes to 54 starting tomor row.

title: Treasurer of Oklahoma Indicted in Extortion Case
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, May 31 (UPI)A Federal grand jury in dicted the Oklahoma State Treasurer, Leo Winters, today on charges of extortion, mail fraud and conspiracy to mis apply bank funds.

title: MANILA ENDS CURBS ON MAJOR UTILITIES
description: MANILA, May 31 (UPI) The martiallaw Government of the Philippines has lifted mili tary supervision and control of major waterworks, power, tele phone and railway companies in the latest move to return to normality, it was announced today.

title: New Jersey Sports Seton Hall's Finest
description: SOUTH ORANGE, May 31When Seton Hall Univer sity inducts nine members into its first sports Hall of Fame tomorrow night in the Galleon Room of the Student Center it will mark the culmination of work by a 33man commit tee that started last October.

title: Shaw Festival, in 12th Season, Goes to New $3Million Theater
description: NIAGARAONTHLAKE, On tario, May 28The Shaw Fes tival, which opened 11 years ago in the converted Old Court house here, will inaugurate its 12th summer season June 12 in a new $3million theater dedi cated to Shavian wit and wis dom.

title: Catskill Altitude Up 7 Feet 2 Inches
description: How do you lob over Artis Gilmore? may become the great mystery of the third annual Dewar's Sports Celebrity tennis tournament Monday at Kutsher's Coun try Club in Monticello, N. Y.

title: MRS. OLMSTED DIES; FRENCH RELIEF AIDE
description: Mrs. Margaret Overton Olm stead, long a leader in French relief activities and philanthro pies, died yesterday at her home, 570 Park Avenue. She was 79 years old, the widow of William B. Olmstead Jr. a di rector of the American Viscose Corporation.

title: Profit for 3 Months Is Raised By Gulf &
Rumors on Pompidou's Health A Subject of Gossip in Iceland
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 31  Widespread and recur rent rumors that President Pompidou's health is failing have been a major subject of unofficial talk during the French leader's meeting with President Nixon here.

title: Inheritor of a Great Irish Name
description: DUBLIN, May 31  Al though he is Britishborn and a Protestant, Erskine Ham ilton Childers is the inheritor of one of the great names in Irish Republican politics.

title: Farm Prices Climb
description: The Administration's hopes of reducing inflation received a setback yesterday as the Department of Agriculture reported that farm prices, after dipping in April, re sumed their sharp rise in May. Prices received by farm ers in the month to May 15 were up 33 per cent from a year earlier. Details, Page 47.

title: Soaring Prices for Gold Stir Stockholder Advice
description: With gold prices at record levels, executives of the Inter national Mining Corporation dis covered yesterday that each shareholder knew exactly how he wanted to capitalize on the good fortune.

title: AGNEW SAYS SCANDAL WON'T AFFECT PARTY
description: CLEVELAND, May 31Vice President Agnew told a Repub lican fundraising dinner to night that the Watergate affair would not have a permanent effect on election of Republican candidates.

title: German Controllers Action
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, May 31 (Reuters)The major ity of air traffic controllers at Dsseldorf and Hanover air ports called in sick today, seri ously disrupting domestic air traffic in West Germany. Their action was believed to have been part of a slowdown by the controllers association in support of pay demands.

title: U.S.CHINA GROUP DISCUSSES TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  Normalization of trade between the United States and China cannot be attained until a num ber of political problems divi ding the two sides are solved, William J. Casey, Under Secre tary of State for Economic Af fairs cautioned here today.

title: Aluminum Purchases Set
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (Reuters)  Primary United States aluminum producers have agreed to buy 240,000 more short tons of Government owned surplus stockpile alumi um ingots in the 12 months be ginning this July 1, or double the amount they were obligated to purchase under revised con tracts negotiated last Decem ber.

title: Art Evokes StravinskyDiaghilev Era
description: The exhibition called Stra vinskyDiaghilev, which opened Wednesday evening at the Cordier & Ekstrom Gallery, 980 Madison Ave nue, at 76th Street, is both a dazzling evocation of a legendary era and an affec tionate hommage to two of its principal geniuses.

title: BUCKLEY PUSHES CURB ON ABORTION
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 Senator James L. Buckley and six other Senators introduced today a constitutional amend ment designed to prohibit abor tions except to save the life the mother.

title: Some Perspective on Watergate
description: WASHINGTONIt began slowly and built into a crescendo which has consumed the attention of virtually everyone in Washington and millions of Americans around the country. At first, it was dismissed as a petty bur glary, an isolated incident. Now, it is a raging controversy which has threatened to paralyze the normal machinery of Government.

title: MEETINGS HALTED BY TRUCE GROUP
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 31 (AP)  The Vietnam peacekeeping commission ad journed indefinitely today after a d?? over procedure, sus pending meetings of chiefs of delegations.

title: Surge in First Quarter of Year Is Ended New Orders Drop
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  Manufacturers inventories showed no increase in April after strong growth in the first three months of this year, the Commerce Department report ed today.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: BUFFALOSigned Morris Titanic, loft wing, No. 1 choice in amateur draft.

title: Cox Names Former Hogan Aide to Watergate Staff
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 Thomas F. McBride, a former assistant district attorney in New York and a former Justice Department attorney, was named today to the Watergate investigating staff by Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor.

title: Bridge: 2 Top Teams Barely Survive SecondRound Reisinger Play
ABPLANALP TIED TO YORKERS BANK
description: Robert H. Abplanalp, a close friend of President Nixon, is a principal stockholder in a bank in Yonkers that was one of four new banks to receive Fed eral charters in New York State in 1971.

title: Intercity Truck Tonnage Up 10.5% From 72 Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 The American Trucking. Associ ations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 10.5 per cent above the corres ponding week last year. Truck tonnage was 0.2 per cent above the weekago level.

title: Hockey Transactions NATIONAL LEAGUE
description: BUFFALOSigned Morris Titanic, left wing,

title: Equity Financing
description: A nonregistered secondary offering of 78,500 common shares of CutlerHammer at 29 was made yesterday by the First Boston Corporation. The com pany's stock closed unchanged at 29 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Open Door for Girls
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 31 (UPI)The State High School Athletic Association announced today that girls could compete with boys in seven noncontact ??ports: crosscountry, water ??olo, swimming, gymnastics, ??olf, tennis and track and field.

title: Indy 500 Delays Force Rex Mays Postponement
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 31  Mechanical problems and the rain delays of the Indianapolis 500 have forced postponement of the next race on the United States Auto Club's Champion ship Trail, the Rex Mays 150 at MilwaUkee. The race will be run June 10 instead of next Sunday.

title: WINTED GARDEN
description: It's probably an exaggera tion to say that as David Merrick goes so goes Broad way, but since 1954, when he opened Fanny on a shoe string and a Gstring, he has been the theater's busiest and, on balance, most suc cessful producer.

title: Missing Woman Hunted
description: TUCSON, Ariz., May 31 (AP) More than 50 F.B.I. agents and local law enforcement officers searched a desert area south of here today for the missing daughter of an F.B.I agent. The agency said that Leese Jo Sha ner, 22 years old was probably kidnaped last night. Her father is James Miller.

title: WESTCHESTER SEES BUSES OF FUTURE
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 31  Westchester County officials today displayed models of the bus of the future in the rotunda of the County Office Building. Six floors above, they were grappling with the question of who, if anyone, will be riding them in an increasingly car oriented society.

title: NixonPompidou Banter Settles Question of Ages
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 31 (Reuters)President Nix on and President Pompidou prefaced their policy talks today with a bantering argu ment about who is older.

title: Heredity Backer Scored In Debate on Intelligence
description: The academic, ideological and political debate about the relative importance of heredity and environment in de termining intelligence raged again here yesterday around the person of Richard Herrn stein, a Harvard psychologist.

title: Robert Caldwell, 64, Newsman Indicted on Drug Charges, Dies
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 31 Robert N. Caldwell, assistant editor of The Record, died to day, apparently of a heart attack, in his office here. He was 64 years old and lived at 226 Prospect Street in Ridge wood.

title: House Passes 3 Health Bills Opposed by the White House
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The House passed today, by over whelming margins, three bills likely to cause a serious con frontation between Congress and the Administration on health policy.

title: DETECTIVE INDICTED IN NEW RAPE CAW
description: A 29yearold New York City detective, under suspension in connection with rape charges in Queens and Suffolk County, was indicted here yesterday for alleged attacks on five Man hattan women last fall.

title: Gurney Wants Watergate Panel To Resolve Nixon Issue Quickly
description: WASHINGTON, May 31A Republican member of the Sen ate Watergate committee said today that the panel should move faster and more decisive ly on the question of whether President Nixon played a role in the Watergate scandal.

title: City U. Proposes 1Year Pact; Staff Union Promptly Rejects It
description: Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee of the City University proposed yesterday a oneyear contract, retroactive to last September, for the City University faculty nd staff union, the Profes sional Staff Congress.

title: 20 Families Are Evacuated After 3Alarm Harlem Fire
description: A threealarm fire raced through six floors of a brick tenement in Harlem last night, forcing the evacuation of 20 families. No one was injured.

title: Shutdown of 20 Nuclear Plants As Threat to Life Asked in Suit
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  Ralph Nader and Friends of the Earth, an environmentalist or ganization, asked a Federal court today to close 20 nuclear power stations, contending they pose a threat to life, public health and property.

title: COAST FINANCIER ACCUSED BY S.E.C, OF MASSIVE FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The Securities and Exchange Com mission today charged C. Arn holt Smith, a California finan cier and longtime confidant of President Nixon, with a mas sive fraudulent manipulation de signed to misappropriate the assets of a West Coast conglo merate he heads and a San Diego bank.

title: Weiskopf Cards 65, Leads Kemper Open by a Stroke
Japan's Reserves Off in May
description: TOKYO, May 31 (UPI) Japan's foreign currency re serves dropped by $965million in May to stand at $15.86bil lion, the Finance Ministry an nounced today. The Ministry attributed the decrease to huge loans extended by the Export Import Bank to foreign coun tries and a sharp increase of imports this month.

title: Henry, Scouts Executive For Councils Here, Retires
description: Dan O. Henry, Scout execu tive of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of Ameri ca, is to retire today.

title: ERVIN, MATHIAS PRESS FOR DATA
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 Two members of the Senate, intensifying Congressional de mands for more data from the executive branch, submitted legislation today that would require Government agencies to keep Congress fully and currently informed.

title: GOLDIN OMISSIONS CHARGED BY POSTEL
description: Councilman Robert I. Postel yesterday accused one of his three rivals for the Democratic nomination for Controller, State Senator Harrison J. Goldin, of omissions on forms filed with the state and Federal govern ments.

title: Liquifin Division Offers to Purchase Shares of Ronson
description: Liquifin Aktiengesellschaft, a German wholyowned subsidi ary of Liquigas S.p.A., a large Italian industrial concern, an nounced yesterday it was offer ing to purchase 2.2milion shares of common stock of the Ronson Corporation at $8.50 share, or total price of $18.7 million.

title: SUSPECT IS KILLED IN NARCOTICS CASE
description: Told he was under arrest for trying to sell 18 ounces of cocaine to two Federal under cover agents, a 28yearold man was shot to death in a Queens apartment yesterday when he allegedly pointed a loaded pistol at them.

title: LIBYA'S CHARGES REJECTED BY U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 31  The United States today rejected a Libyan accusa tion that it was attempting to provoke a confrontation with Libya.

title: HIJACKED PLANE RETURNS TO ARUBA
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, May 31 (AP)A hijacked Colombian airliner, under terrorist com mand for more than 30 hours, landed at the Caribbean island of Aruba late tonight for the third time.

title: The Jersey Primaries
description: This is a gubernatorial election year in New Jersey. On Tuesday, the day after primary balloting in New York, voters will go to the polls to pick both the Demo cratic and Republican nominees. Under New Jersey law, a voter can enter either primary irrespective of previous party affiliation.

title: Recordings Indicate Penn Central Delay In Calling Firemen
description: A taped telephone conversa tion between a Fire Department dispatcher and a Penn Central supervisor last Tuesday night indicated that some railroad officials were aware of the fire in the train stalled under Park Avenue but delayed notifying the Fire Department.

title: FASHION TALK Remember Sant' Angelo's Gypsy Dresses? Now He's on the Glamour Trail
description: It's enough to make you mistyeyed over what will go down in the history books as the costume party phase of fashion, That was three or four years ago, when Giorgio di Sant'Angelo rose to prom inence on a wave of gypsy dresses, fringed buckskin and scarves tied every which way.

title: Comments of Haldeman, Ehrlichman and General Cushman on the Watergate and C.I.A. Investigations
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 Following are the text of a statement read by H. R. Haldeman after testifying be fore the Senate Appropria tions Subcommittee on In telligence Operations today, excerpts from a statement presented by John D. Ehr lichman to the subcommittee yesterday and the text of a statement issued today by Gen. Robert E. Cushman Jr.:

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)The Federal Trade Com mission has filed a complaint against the Phillips Petroleum Company accusing the Bartlesville, Okla., concern of anti competitive lease agreements.

title: Radio
description: 8:0510 A.M., WNCN: Etude No. 2 in E flat, Liszt; Harmonious Blacksmith, Handel; Il Secreto di Susanna; Overture, WolfFer rari; Song without Words (Op. 19, No. 6), Mendelssohn; Danse Macabre, SaintSaens; Concertino No. 2 in G. Pergolesi; Prelude and Fugue No. 8 for Orchestra and Cello (from the WellTem pered Clavier), Bach/VillaLobos; Piano Concerto No. 8 in C (K. 246), Mozart.

title: Loews Hotels Expands
description: Loews Hotels announced yes terday the opening of its Loews L'Enfant Plaza hotel in Wash ington, D. C. The new 372 room hotel is situated in one of four office buildings in the L'Enfant Plaza complex, the na tion's largest privately devel oped commercial project.

title: U.S. Reported Optimistic On a Cambodian Truce
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 1The United States believes that the pros pects for a ceasefire in Cam bodia are very sunny, well informed South Vietnamese of ficials said last night.

title: Trade Board Head Quits
description: MONROE, N. C., May 31 (UPI) Henry Hall Wilson resigned his $115,000ayear post as president of the Chicago Board of Trade today to seek the Sen ate seat now held by Sen. Sam J. Ervin Jr., of North Carolina. Mr. Wilson, 51 years old, is a Democrat and a former legisla tor and official of the Kennedy, and Johnson Administrations.

title: Bobick Wins 4th in Row
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., May 31 (AP)Duane Bobick registered has fourth victory in four pro fessional fights with a second round technical knockout of Clyde Brown tonight in their scheduled eightrounder at the Frankfort Sports Center.

title: FUTURES IN GRAIN FIRM LATE IN DAY
description: Grainfutures prices firmed somewhat yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after being in the doldrums the day before.

title: Grand Jury in Queens Delivers New Indictment
description: A grand jury empaneled by the state's special anticor ruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, handed up a sealed indictment yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens.

title: June
description: June always comes as a surprise, for some strange reason. Winter frays away and it is March and early April, pussy willows and redwings and peepers yelping. Something marvelous is about to happen. Leaves begin unfolding from the buds, hepaticas and anemones bloom, grass makes the meadows and the lawns green again. Then it is May, and violets, and apple blossoms, and lilacs. The leaves have begun to cast shade along the rural roads and the suburban streets. May, when all things are new and full of promises.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 2.5 From WeekAgo Level
GOING OUT Guide
description: OPERA BUFFET The Stuyvesant Opera and its Monteverdi Repertory Sing ??s are back for a short run, with a rare work unheard of here for more than 50 years, ??d a postopera buffet ??ack accompanied by wine. It will be done tonight and next Friday at 7 and tomor row at 5:30 at the Church of the Covenant, 310 East 42d Street. The company, which started as a community group five years ago, will perform Pietro Mascagni's Iris, a work in Italian about Japan first produced in Rome in 1898 and done here by the Met, with Enrico Caruso, in 1908. The work dwells on the importance of sun, flowers and the natural beauty of life and is far from Madame Butterfly in plot, although it does not seem to be any more cheerful in its resolu tion. The cast consists of four principals and a chorus of nine singing to piano music; it is, however, fully staged and costumed.

title: Data in Equity Case Pledged by ExAide
description: LOS ANGELES, May 31  Fred Levin, at one time the No. 2 man in the scandalridden Equity Funding Corporation of America, and three other ousted executives, pledged today to co operate fully with the United States attorney here and other law enforcement agencies in vestigating fraudulent opera tions of the bankrupt company.

title: People and Business Peterson Taking Post at Lehman Brothers
description: Peter G. Peterson, former Secretary of Commerce, and most recently President Nix on's roving ambassador of trade, is about to move from Washington to Wall Street. He was named a vice chair man of Lehman Brothers, Inc., and a senior partner of Lehman Brothers, predeces sor of the corporation.

title: 7,300 Are Awarded Degrees at Rutgers In Graduation Rites
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 31A jazz band playing Blues March instead of Pomp and Circumstance and the first six women graduates of Rutgers College highlighted Rutgers University's 207th com mencement day today.

title: Middle Class in South Jamaica Seems to Be Leaning to Beame
description: Middleclass voters in South Jamaica, Queens, seem to like Controller Abraham D. Beame for Mayor.

title: White House Assailed on Its Reorganization Pact With Labor
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 Members of Congress charged the Administration today with seeking to circumvent the law by signing an agreement with labor lobbyists promising to nullify part of a drug enforce ment reorganization plan even before that plan had been voted on in Congress.

title: Turkey With Ham
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an aster isk are followed by a recipe.

title: That Hankering for Fish Was Not Quite Satisfied
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judg ment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable estab lishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN PATH DISPUTE
description: The PATH railway system and Lodge 1330 of the Brother hood of Railway Carmen reached a tentative agreement yesterday on terms for settling the carmen's 61dayold strike that has forced thousands of New Jersey and New York com muters to find alternative means of travel.

title: Dow Index Off by 7.46; 183 Stocks at New Lows
HOUSE MUST ACT
JAMES LUNDY DIES; QUEENS LEADER, 67
description: James A. Lundy, former chairman of the State Public Service Commission and former Borough President of Queens, died May 22 in the Colorado General Hospital in Denver, where he had been living for the last eight months. He was 67 years old and formerly had lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: New Disclosure Law
description: TRENTON, May 31Virtual ly all charges of corruption that have dominated New Jersey's gubernatorial primary election race were born in the shadowy world of campaign fundraising. Both major parties and their state and local candidates tradi tionally raised most of their campaign funds in secret. Partly this was done in an effort to mask the identity of heavy individual and corporate con tributors. And part ly, in the view of some law enforcement authorities, this was done to hide the first in stallment of an apparent quid pro quo arangement that ulti mately sees some heavy con tributors end up with fat state contracts or government favors.

title: EnglishBorn Protestant Is Elected President of the Irish Republic
description: DUBLIN, May 31Erskine Childers, an Englishborn Prot estant, has been elected as President of the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland, final returns should to night.

title: Administration's Hopes of Reducing Inflation Receive Setback
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 The hopes of the nation and of the Administration for re ducing inflation received a set back today as the Department of Agriculture reported that farm prices had resumed their steep rise in May after a dip in April.

title: Nixon and Pompidou Fail To Resolve Major Issues
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 31The United States and France failed today to narrow significantly the questions that divide them, but their Presidents agreed to a new series of negotiations by subordi nates. Meeting for the first time in a year and a half, President Nixon and President Pompidou conferred twice for a total of almost five hours at Reykjavik's Kjarval Art Gallery.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating Outlook
description: From southern New Jersey to Rhode Island, the most encouraging angling news is probably the amazing influx of northern weakfish in Nar ragansett Bay. For the past several years, weakfish have been appearing in the bay in greater and greater numbers and now the fishing for the species there is better than anyone can remember. The fish are averaging 6 pounds and some over 11 pounds have been caught.

title: HALDEMAN DENIES ROLE IN COVERUP; CONFLICT WIDENS
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The conflict between top former White House aides and officials of the Central Intelligence Agency over their roles in the Watergate case widened today.

title: Of Glaciers and Bananas
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May May 31 (UPI)For a rugged, largely desolate island of volcanic origin, Iceland boasts a lot of superlatives, nega tive and positive. Icelanders some 200,000 in 103,000 square mileswill tell you that their island has no trees, no army, no navy, little crime, no unemployment, the highest literacy rate in the world, the world's north ernmost capital, a glacier bigger than any in Europe, and the best salmon fishing anywhere. And then there are homegrown bananas, mid night golf, a million or more sheep and an erupting vol cano on Heimaey, an island off Iceland's southern coast.

title: Pressure Is Resisted
Notes on People Comdr. Bucher Is Leaving Navy
description: Comdr. Lloyd M. Bucher, the former captain of the in telligence ship Pueblo, is re tiring from the Navy today and says he intends to be come a freelance writer. Commander Bucher and the Pueblo crew spent 11 months in a North Korean prison after they and their ship were captured in January, 1968.

title: New Disclosure Law
description: TRENTON, May 31Virtual ly all the charges of corruption that have dominated New Jer sey's gubernatorial primary election race were born in the shadowy world of campaign fundraising. Both major par ties and their state and local candidates traditionally raised most of their campaign funds in secret. Partly this was done in an effort to mask the identity of heavy individual and corporate con tributors. And partly, in the view of some law enforcement authorities, this was done to hide the first installment of an apparent quid pro quo ar rangement that ultimately sees some heavy contributors end up with fat state contracts or government favors.

title: DETECTIVE INDICTED IN NEW RAPE CASES
description: A 29yearold New York City detective, under suspension in connection with rape charges in Queens and Suffolk County, was indicted here yesterday for alleged attacks on five Man hattan women last fall.

title: JAPANTAIWAN TIE CONTINUES STRONG
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 31  The downtown building that housed the Japanese Embassy until last fall, when Tokyo broke relations and recognized Peking instead, is now the headquarters of a Japanese or ganization called the Inter change Association.

title: First Black Takes Post As Police Chief on L.I.
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 31Maybe it was a big deal 21 years ago, when young Tom Scott became the first black policeman in the Village of Hempstead. He recalls a Jackie Robinson situa tion, but doesn't say much more about it.

title: Books of The Times Ghosts of the American Dream
description: At a superficial glance, this remarkable bookan experiment in psychohistory by a young photographer and historianap pears unpromising, if not downright repugnant. At first it seems to be nothing more than a collection of ancient photo grahps of horses, houses and peopleyou can almost smell the dust and rot on them  interspersed with items of bad news from a smalltown Midwestern newspaper. But on closer inspection, a fascination sets in: The photographs start to glow with an eerie otherworldliness, as if their subjects  even the horses  were archetypal phantoms materializing at a sance and imploring us mutely for attention; the news items begin to work on us like a Ripley's Believe It or Not of the macabre and demented.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The old orange reducedfare transit cards for people 65 years of age or older expired yesterday, and new blue or yellow cards are required beginning today. Those who have not received the new cards can get them at any of the city's centers for the elderly, at neighborhood govern ment offices or by calling the City Office for the Aging at 3496600.

title: 2 Share French Golf Lead
description: PARIS, May 31 (AP)John Hlalliwell of England and Christy O'Connor of Ireland each shot 69 today and shared a onestroke lead following the first round of the French open golf tournament. Bernard Gal ??agher of Scotland and Baldo ??ino Dassu of Italy were at 70

title: State Ban on PhosphateDetergent Sales Takes Effect
description: Beginning today, New York State consumers will have to make do mostly with phos phatefree detergents.

title: Blumenthal Invades Beame News Parley
description: Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal yesterday carried his campaign for the Demo cratic mayoral nomination into the headquarters of an oppon ent, Controller Abraham D. Beame, and engaged him in a facetoface exchange at the Controller's own news confer ence.

title: Suit Seeks to Bar Federal Influence on Public TV
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The American Civil Liberties Union and the Network Project filed a lawsuit today aimed at pro hibiting any control or influ ence over what is seen on public television by the White House, The Corporation for Public Broadcasting or the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: New Cast But Same Old Play
description: WASHINGTON, May 31President Nixon has changed the cast of char acters in the Cabinet and the White House staff, but the new men are still working under the same old closed system and perpetuating the poisonous atmosphere of suspicion and secrecy.

title: U.S. Reported Optimistic On a Cambodian Truce
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 1The United States believes that the pros pects for a ceasefire in Cam bodia are very sunny, well informed South Vietnamese of ficials said last night.

title: Bar Group Gives Hogan Highest Rating
description: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night gave William J. vanden Heuvel, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan District Attorney, its lowest rating: Not ap proved.

title: Recordings Indicate Penn Central Delay In Calling Firemen
description: A taped telephone conversa tion between a Fire Department dispatcher and a Penn Central supervisor last Tuesday night indicated that some railroad officials were aware of the fire in the train stalled under Park Avenue but delayed notifying the Fire Department.

title: HOUSE MUST ACT
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The Senate voted today in favor of cutting off all funds for bomb ing in Cambodia. The vote was 63 to 19.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Avis Meets After 8Year Gap; Decline in Stock Is Main Topic
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 31  Avis, Inc., the nation's second largest car rental com pany, emerged today from the conglomerate cocoon of the In ternational Telephone and Tele graph Corporation and held its first annual meeting in eight years.

title: Electrical Device Imports Seen No Security Threat
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) The Office of Emergency Pre paredness said today that it had determined that the im portation of certain high volt age electrical equipment did not threaten national security.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN PATH DISPUTE
description: The PATH railway system and Lodge 1330 of the Brother hood of Railway Carmen reached a tentative agreement yesterday on terms for settling the carmen's 61dayold strike that has forced thousands of New Jersey and New York com muters to find alternative means of travel.

title: POLICE SEEK CLUE IN BOMB MURDER
description: The police searched the run down area around 12th Street in the East Village yesterday for clues to the origin of a pipe bomb that killed a 74yearold widow and injured her male friend Wednesday night.

title: BIG RETAIL CHAINS REPORT SALES UP
description: Consumer buying moved at a fast clip in May according to reports yesterday of sharp sales gains by several of the country's largest retail chains.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Sony to End Production Of DeskTop Calculators
description: The Sony Corporation an nounced yesterday in Tokyo that it would terminate produc tion of desktop calculators at the end of July because of price competition.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Public Utilities Commission granted a $47 million rate increases yesterday to the Public Service Elec tric and Gas Company as an interim relief measure aimed at providing the utility with adequate revenue to finance construction programs.

title: Melville Shoe Will Pay $1.9Million on Tax Audit
description: The Melville Shoe Corpora tion announced yesterday that it had entered into a closing agreement covering the Fed eral income tax audit of Mel ville and its subsidiaries for the years 1964 through 1971. Under the settlement, Melville and its subsidiaries will pay $1,987,391 in additional tax assessments.

title: 2 MORE CONCERNS CITED IN '69 RACE
description: NEWARK, May 31  United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern said today that a Federal grand jury had indicted two more corporations on income tax charges as an outgrowth of an investigation of alleged irregularities in the financing of Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign.

title: Caring About Children
description: In 1846, the State of Massachusetts opened the Lyman School, the first of what proved to be a long line of Amer ican juvenile institutions, reform schools, industrial schools and the like. In 1972, Massachusetts became the first state in the nation to close all such prisons for young peoplein cluding the Lyman School, then still in operation.

title: POLICE SEEK CLUE IN BOMB MURDER
description: The police searched the run down area around 12th Street in the East Village yesterday for clues to the origin of a pipe bomb that killed a 74yearold widow and injured her male friend Wednesday night.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, May 30, 1973

title: 5 RUTGERS AIDES CHOSE DESIGNERS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, May 31 All four of Governor Cahill's appointees to the Rutgers Uni versity board of governors voted earlier this year in favor of giving a contract for design ing a $9million university sports center to a concern in dicted this week for covering up contributions to Governor Cahill's 1969 campaign,

title: E. Evan Reynolds Is Dead; Newspaper Art Director
description: WESTON, Conn., May 31 E. Evan Reynolds, an artist and former art director of The New York WorldTelegram and The Sun, died yesterday in Southside Hospital, Bay Shore, L. I. His age was 68.

title: The Dance
description: In the United States, John Cranko's very considerable reputation is largely based on what might be called his full length spectaculars. His Ro meo and Juliet, for example, or his Eugene Onegin or, for that matter, this season, his Swan Lake  these largescale works have dom inated his American reputa tion. But in Europe he is also known and highly regarded for his shorter pieces. Some of these have, of course, been seen in New York, with both the Stuttgart Ballet and other companies. But, unfortunate ly, they have never received quite the same degree of attention. And some of the best of Cranko is to be seen in his shorter ballets.

title: Long Beach Is Testing Noiseless Electric Bus
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., May 31For the last three days residents of this South Shore city had the opportunity to ride, free of charge, in an electric bus that makes no noise and emits no gasoline fumes.

title: GREECE DISMISSES CHIEF OF THE NAVY
description: ATHENS, May 31  Greece's armybacked Government to night dismissed the navy chief amid reports that it was speed ing plans to end the monarchy and set up a republic.

title: MRS. JOHN L. SENIOR, CIVIC AIDE HERE, DIES
description: Mrs. Maud Cowham Senior, widow of John L. Senior, a cement executive who died in 1946, died yesterday at her home, 640 Park Avenue. She was 88 years old and lived also in Lenox, Mass.

title: McCord Is Writing Book on Watergate For Publisher Here
description: James W. McCord Jr. said yesterday that he had made tentative arrangements with a New York company to publish a book he is writing titled Watergate Sanction.

title: R. H. COCHRANE, LED UNIVERSAL PICTURES
description: NEW ROCHELLE, June 1 Robert H. Cochrane who re tired in 1938 as president of Universal Pictures, Inc., a mo. tion  picture company he helped found in 1906, died yes terday, at the New Rochelle Hospital. He was 94 years old.

title: And Then There Were 6
description: LONDON, June 1 (UPI)The abolition of the Greek monar chy leaves only six thrones in Europe  those of Gustaf VI Adolf in Sweden, Olav V in Norway, Margrethe in Den mark, Juliana in the Nether lands, Baudouin in Belgium and Elizabeth II in Britain.

title: Operation PUSH Gains Strengthin Its Second Year
description: CHICAGO  Operation PUSH, the newest national civil rights organization, shows signs of being a healthy, growing infant as it presses its second year of activties.

title: DELOS SMITH, 68, A SCIENCE EDITOR
description: Delos Smith, science editor of United Press International, died Thursday night of lung cancer in Memorial Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 420 Riverside Drive.

title: 9 Accused of Distributing Hard Drugs in City Slums
description: Eight men and a woman were arrested yesterday on in dictments alleging that they were part of an organized dis tribution of heroin and other hard drugs in slum areas here.

title: U.S. SETS NEW RULES FOR PROCESSED MEAT
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) Consumers will have a choice of three types of frankfurters and other cooked sausages un der new labeling and ingredient requirements announced today by the Agriculture Department. The changes will take effect. Sept. 7.

title: Unused Spy Plan Under F.B.I. Study
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The Federal Bureau of Investigation is looking into the possibility that elements of the Nixon Ad ministration's master plan for domestic intelligence gathering were put into operation despite President Nixon's assurance that the proposal never went into effect.

title: 2,000 in Contributions Are Reported by Forst
description: TRENTON, June 1 (UPI)  Frank A. Forst, a candidate in the Democratic guberna torial primary, today made public his contributions  and said he had received $2,000.

title: StockMarket Prices Slide In Day of Sluggish Trading
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Equity Financing
description: A special offering of 62,000 common shares of Union Fidelity at 5 per share was continued by Jefferies & Co. The company's stock closed at 5, up  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: American Motors Raising Prices an Average of $59
description: DETROIT, June 1 (AP) American Motors Corporation announced today that it was raising prices on its 1973 cars and jeeps an average of $59 starting June 30.

title: In the Suburbs, Little League Is More Than Just a Game
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I.,There are 73 Little League baseball teams in this small Nassau County communityone team

title: 2,300 Workers Strike At Johnson
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, June 1 (UPI)A total of 2,300 pro duction workers struck three Johnson & Johnson plants in this area yesterday after re jecting a contract package including a 27cent hourly wage increase.

title: SpanishSpeaking Citizens Organize National Coalition
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)  The formation of a national organization of Spanishspeak ing Americans was announced today.

title: Plan to Raze Village Jail For a School Is Dropped
description: A plan to demolish the abandoned Women's Detention in the heart of Greenwich Vil lage and to replace it with a $5.3million educational and community facility to be built by the New School for Social Research has collapsed.

title: Francis Giving Up Job As the Rangers'
description: Emile Francis, the architect of the Ranger renaissance that saw the team leap from National Hockey League obscurity has de cided to step down as coach but to retain the general manager's reins of the club he has led to the playoffs the last seven sea sons.

title: HERBERT FLINT
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 1 Herbert Flint, former newspa perman and advertising director of the State National Bank of Connecticut, died Wednesday at his home, 38 River Lane here. His age was 80.

title: Padres Greif Adds 40 Loss to Mets Woes
description: SAN DIEGO, June 1The New York Mets assigned Cleon Jones to the 21day disabled list tonight, lost Bud Harrelson with tendonitis of the shoulder and then dropped a 40 decision to the lastplace San Diego Padres.

title: Atoms Reach First Place
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) Jim Fryatt scored two goals tonight, the last with 10 min utes to play, as the Philadelphia Atoms beat Montreal, 21, to move into first place in the Eastern Division of the North American Soccer League.

title: BailedOut Fliers Saved
description: ROSEBURG, Ore., June 1 (UPI)Two Navy fliers, in cluding one who spent the night dangling by his parachute from a tree, were rescued from a wooded mountainside yester day. Lieut (jg) Mike Martella, 25 years old of Dubois, Pa., and Lieut. Gene Hall, 30, of Fall brook, Calif., were forced to bail out of their twin engine jet Wednesday night while on a training flight from Whidbey Island Naval Air station near Oak Harbor, Wash.

title: Israel Sets Investment Projects
description: JERUSALEM, June 1  Is rael's Finance Minister, Pinhas Sapir, announced today that 40 new joint and independent busi ness ventures involving more than $500million in investment capital had been agreed upon during the Premier's third In ternational: Economic Confer ence held here this week.

title: Pilot Killed
description: TYLER, Tex., June 1 (UPI) A plane carrying 1,082 pounds of air mail and firstclass mail clipped the top of a tree during a landing yesterday and crashed, killing the pilot and burning 700 pounds of the mail. The pilot was Richard Khoury of Longview, Tex.

title: Brezhnev Will Make A TV Address in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)  Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, will make a nationally televised ad dress while in the United States this month for talks with President Nixon, offi cials here said today.

title: Books of The Times Roman Candle on Campus
description: SDS. By Kirkpatrick Sale. 752 pages. Random House. $15.

title: STIFF TEST LOOMS FOR SPEEDY RICK
description: YONKERS, June 1John Patterson Sr.'s Speedy Rick, undefeated in five starts this year, faces his toughest op ponent of the season in tomor row night's $22,500 handicap trot at Yonkers Raceway.

title: MONARCHY ENDED AS GREEK REGIME SETS UP REPUBLIC
description: ATHENS, June 1  Greece's militaryled Government abol lished the monarchy today and proclaimed the country a re public.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MONTREAL, June 1 (AP)The Montreal Canadiens who beat the Chicago Black Hawks in six games to win the National Hockey League championship, placed three men on the N.H.L. allstar first team and one on the second. The Montreal goalie, Ken Dryden, fell two votes short of unanimous 240 from the Professional Hockey Writers Asso ciation. The defenseman, Bobby Orr of the Boston Bruins, got 236 in the balloting announced today.

title: KISSINGER REVEALS HIS CHINA CONTACT
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) Henry A. Kissinger disclosed today that an experienced Chinese diplomat now stationed in Washington was his secret contact during a crucial period prior to President Nixon's journey to China.

title: 158th Bonn Starfighter Loss
description: BONN, June 1 (UPI)A West German F104G Starfighter crashed today shortly after takeoff from an airport near Memmingen, but the pilot eject ed safely, the Defense Ministry said. It was the 158th West German Starfighter lost since the Americandesigned plane was commissioned in 1961.

title: ONE TO ONE BENEFIT FULFILLS PROMISES
description: Surprises, surprisesthat was promised by the disk jockey Don Imus from the Madison Square Garden stage Thursday at the One to One Festival for the Mentally Retarded benefit concert. And surprises the au dience actually got, over and above the billed artists who Were John Denver, who flew in from England especially for the evenings Judy Collins, Bill Withers and Eric Weisberg and Deliverance. Unlike last year's rock benefit, this concert was directed toward the folkies.

title: Freighter Rams Tanker in Narrows, Setting Off Explosions and Fire
description: A freighter sliced through an oilladen tanker in the Narrows early this morning, engulfing both vessels in balls of flame, setting off a series of explosions and sending flames more than 50 feet above the upper road way of the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge.

title: Wine Talk
description: A couple came into the Lutece restaurant one night recently for a quiet dinner, but it must have been a very special meal: They washed it down with a $220 bottle of Chauteau Petrus 1945. Nor is the 1945 Petrus the most expensive bottle in Lutece's cellar. There is an 1890 Chateau Lafite for $310, a 1926 Mouton Rothschild for $240, and a 1929 Chevel Blanc at $250. But ther? is, also a freSh Beaujolais for $8 and an attractive Cte de Beaune 1969 for $10, and as far as Andre SoItner, the owner, is concerned, these are the wines his guests should drink.

title: American BookStratford Takes Bankruptcy Act Step
description: The American BookStratford Press, Inc., a book publisher at 75 Varick Street in New York, filed a petition in Federal Court yesterday for an arrangement with creditors under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The company listed liabili ties of $15,206,000 and assets of $17,035,000.

title: NORTH KOREANS GET A NEW U.N. STATUS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 1  North Korea has re quested and received official observer status at the United Nations European headquarters in Geneva.

title: NO. AMER. SOCCER LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Restaurant Patron Wins on His Refusal To Pay for Steaks
description: The owner of a chemical company who lives on his yacht at the West 79th Street boat basin and habitually eats at better restaurants staged a oneman revolt against inade quate service and won yester day when a restaurant that had brought charges against him failed to appear in court.

title: Top Aides of Nixon Linked To Secret Dairy Donation
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  Long after the White House was accused in a lawsuit of ordering a multimilliondollar rise in the Federal milk price level in return for campaign contributions from the dairy industry, top aides of Presi dent Nixon were still taking secret cash campaign gifts from milk interests, Govern ment investigators said today.

title: BLAST FATAL TO 2 TRACED OUTDOORS
description: WILLINGBORO, June 1 (UPI) The police disclosed today that Wednesday's explosion here that killed two persons occurred outside the house and added that they would consider every theory as to how it had happened.

title: Dave Anderson The House That Blomberg Remodeled
description: In time, The House That Ruth Built may be remem bered as The House That Blomberg Remodeled. Before last night's game, Ron Blomberg was leading the American League with a 400 batting average. He also was leading it in realism. I'm not going to hit 400 for the season, he said. You know that. I know that, But I'm still trying to get a hit every time up. No matter what he hits, his most significant contribution to the New York Yankees is that people are associating baseball with them again. Other topics have been more popular this season. The lifestyle of two lefthanded pitchers predominated for a while. Then the new owners shoved Mike Burke into a closet. But now Ron Blomberg is swinging a big bat. That's what Yankee Stadium always has been all about. His big bat is what the 24yearold first baseman is all about, too. In the dugout, he's always gripping it, swinging it.

title: LEBANESE LEADER AND ARAFAT MEET
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 1 President Suleiman Franjieh of Lebanon met today with Yasir Arafat, the chief Palestinian guerrilla leader, in a gesture of reconciliation following the fighting here last month be tween the army and the guer rillas.

title: Parsons College, $16Million in Debt, Is Forced to Close
description: FAIRFIELD, Iowa, June 1 Parsons College's acting presi dent, Everett Hadley, an nounced today that the college would discontinue operations, because of its $16million debt.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: LINDSAY TO PRESS STATE DRUG PLAN
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that, despite his ob jections to Governor Rocke feller's narcotics program, he had ordered preparation of a coordinated plan in the city to implement it.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: **Fonda la Paloma (Inn of the Dove), 2020 Lemoine Avenue, Fort Lee. (201) 944 9576.

title: Notes on People Two Stars for Woman General
description: Jeanne M. Holm became the first woman twostar general in United States mili tary history as the silver symbols of her new Air Force rank were pinned on her epaulettes at the Pentagon. At the ceremony, the 51 yearold general recalled that she had served in the Army in World War II, then left the service to attend Lewis and Clark College in Port land, Ore. In the Berlin crisis in 1948, General Holm said, she was reactivated: I was between semesters, had noth ing to do anyway and was flat broke. So I went.

title: Events Today
description: Dance

title: Ravelomanantsoa Winner
