description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 1 Three sprinters equaled the world indoor record of 6.8 sec onds for the 70yard dash to night as the professional track tour entered its final weekend before it reaches Madison Square Garden next Wednes day.

title: ExSecurity Agent Is Called Swindler
description: A San Francisco clothing manufacturing company has charged that its former presi dent  who has been ousted from his job  misrepresented himself under an alias as a past military security expert when he was in fact a selfconfessed stock swindler who testified for the Government in the 1970 trial of Angelo De Carlo, a re puted Mafia leader.

title: King, Secluded in Rome, Calls Move a Surprise
description: ROME, June 1King Con stantine II sent word tonight that the Greek military regime's announcement that it had de posed him came as a painful surprise.

title: Desi Arnaz's Father Dies
description: MIAMI, June 1 (AP)Desdi derio Arnaz, father of the en tertainer Desi Arnaz, died yes terday at a hospital here. He was 79 years old. Mr. Arnaz was the Mayor of Santiago de Cuba for 10 years and was a Congressman for Oriente Pro vince. Other survivors include his widow, Anne; a daughter, Connie, and two grandchildren.

title: Two Unions Will Discuss G.E. Offer of 21% Raise
description: Top level negotiators for the General Electric Company and two major unions planned to continue this weekend their dis cussions of a company offer that would provide an estimated pay increase of about 21 per cent over three years.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Muskie's Mother, 82, Dies
description: RUMFORD, Me., June 1  Mrs. Josephine C. Muskie, mother of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, died in her home here Wednes day night. She was 82 years old. During his 1972 campaign for the Presidential nomination, Senator Muskie named his plane after her. Another son and four daughters also sur vive.

title: ExP.O.W.'s to Get Health Counseling For 5Year Period
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) The Pentagon's health chief said today that all returned Vietnam War prisoners would be counseled and watched for five years to avoid the high violent death rates among for mer American P.O.W.'s after World War II and the Korean War.

title: Bill Easing Divorce Law Passed in Rush in Albany
description: Mandatory conciliation under the state's sixyearold liberal ized divorce law would be abolished on July 1 under a bill passed in the closing legisla tive rush and now awaiting Governor Rockefeller's signa ture.

title: OVERSEAS AIRLINES SUES HELLER & CO.
description: MONTEREY, Calif., June 1 A suit asking a total of $380 million for damages from Walter E. Heller & Co. has been filed in California Superior Court here by trustees repre senting the bankruptcy estate of United States Overseas Air lines, Inc.

title: Antiques: Sharp Contrast
description: Two museums have brought to the city two remarkable and disparate views of the decorative arts as they existed in this country just before World War I.

title: Changes in Brokerage Rules Threaten to Reduce Revenues
description: The Wall Street brokerage community struggled in embar rassment yesterday over rule changeseffective next Monday that threaten to drain reve nues from the beleaguered in dustry.

title: U.S. Concern Resisting Argentine Rebels
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 1The Argentine subsidiary of the Otis Elevator Company indicated to day that it would close opera tions here rather than pay $500,000 demanded by leftist guerrillas.

title: Dutch Bank Rate Will Rise To 4% From 4% Monday
description: AMSTERDAM, June 1 (Reu ters)  The Netherlands has raised her bank rate to 4 per cent from 4 per cent, effective Monday, the Dutch central bank said today. The rate had stood at 4 per cent since Nov. 6, 1972.

title: Factory Hours Off in May
Traffic vs. Parks
description: Mayor Lindsay's move to close New York's major parks during the summer to auto traffic between rush hours is certainly designed in itself to add to the amen ities and livability of the city. We wish we could support it with an enthusiasm uncomplicated by other consid erations. Unfortunately other considerations are present, relevant and serious enough to minimize the warmth with which New Yorkers would otherwise greet the plan to rid Central, Prospect and Forest Parks of the fumes, noise and hazards of automobile traffic for much of the day.

title: Barber, After 2 Crew Cuts, Sees End of LongHair Era
description: The Broadway Barbershor on Broadway near 104th Street is an oldfashioned place with a white ceramic tiled floor and a dominating hottowel heater. It has a ro tating barber pole out front and stacks of magazines that go back three and four years.

title: 28 States to Share In Clearing House On Land Schemes
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. June 1 (AP)An offensive against un scrupulous persons in the bil liondollar land sales industry has been announced by George Bernstein, the Federal land sales administrator.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 57950
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500 Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with The first, middle or last three numbers In sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50,

title: Watergate Pressures
description: The Senate's Watergate committee is currently under pressure from various directions.

title: Floods in Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, June 1 (Reuters)Floods that followed torrential rain have left several thousand people homeless along Bangladesh's southern coast.

title: JOHN E. DOCKENDORFF
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 1 John E. Dockendorff, vice president and European direc to?? of the Black Diamond Lines, a freighter company that ceased operations in 1968, died yesterday in Bridgeport Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Easton, Conn.

title: Bride: Two TeenAgers on L.I. Team Help Lead Upset in Reisinger
NIXON, POMPIDOU CONCLUDE TALKS; SOME GAINS SEEN
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 1  The conference between President Nixon and Pres ident Pompidou of France ended today after more than six hours of facetoface meetings that kindled hopes for future prog ress while producing no con crete agreements.

title: Singer Stops Yanks, Irks Houk
Griffith to Continue His Battle for Survival Tonight in 15Round Title Bout Against Monzon
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, June 1Emile Griffith has endured 15 years of punches. Tomoryow night, while for tunes are changing at the roulette wheels here, he will continue his fight for survi val. He says he is fit enough to take the champion's best punch nine times.

title: In the Suburbs, Little League Is More Than Just a Game
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I.,There are 73 Little League baseball teams in this small Nassau County communityone team

title: 400 ExP.O.W.'s Are Given $400,000 Dallas Reception
description: DALLAS, June 1 (AP)More than 400 former prisoners of war were honored at a parade and banquet here today in the largest and most expensive homecoming rally since their return from Vietnam.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: CHICAGORecalled Sucky Dent, shortstop from Iowa farm club in the American Association and placed Brian Downing third baseman, on 21day disabled Iist.

title: MRS. HARRY E. ELMLARK
description: Mrs. Lillian Rosenthal Elm lark, wife of Harry E. Elmlark, president and editor of the Washington Star Syndicate, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived at 190 East 72d Street.

title: FINANCIER DENIES WESTGATE FRAUD
description: SAN DIEGO, June 1C. Arn holt Smith, chairman of West gateCalifornia Corporation, to day described as unfounded charges of fraud involving, mil lions of dollars contained in a Securities and Exchange Com mission civil suit against him, two associates and other con cerns he controls.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Cahill signed into law legislation that spells out the rights and duties of residents and owners of trailer parks. The bill makes it illegal for a park owner to solicit money from mobilehome owners who want to locate on his property and allows owners to sell their trailers without having to remove them from the park. The legislation per mits evictions only for nonpayment of rent, law violations, repeated breaking of park rules, expiration of a lease or the termination of the park for trailer use.

title: 2 Charged With Murders At Philadelphia Prison
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) Two prisoners were charged today with the murders of the warden and deputy warden at Holmesburg Prison here.

title: Bahamians Say Vesco Made Political Gifts That Recipients Now Find Embarrassing
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, June 1 Robert L. Vesco has made ma jor cash contributions and loans in the Bahamas similar to those he made to the Nixon election campaign in the United States and to political figures in Costa Rica, interviews here this week have shown.

title: Waldheim Plans to Reduce Cyprus Force as Economy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 1  Secretary General Waldheim informed the Se curity Council today that he intended to reduce the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus as a neconomy measure.

title: All 23 Aboard Killed As Jetliner Crashes In Northern Brazil
description: SAO LUIS, Brazil, June 1 (UPI)  A Frenchbuilt, me diumrange Caravelle jetliner approaching for a landing crashed and exploded today in this northern Brazilian city. All 23 persons aboard were killed.

title: Long I.A.M. Strike Ends
description: WESTFIELD, Mass., June 1 (AP)The Savage Arms Com pany said today that the six month strike against it had ended and operations will be resumed Monday at its plant here. The contract with the International Association of Machinists provides a 62cent an hour raise for all workers plus extra pay provisions for trades and daywork employes

title: Queens TeenAgers Reach Final in Women's Tennis
description: WOODBURY, L. I., June 1 Two Queens teenagers, 17 yearold Ruta Gerulaitis of Howard Beach and Mary Carillo, 16, of Douglaston, reached the final today of the Eastern women's hardcourt tennis championships at Woodbury Country Club.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The statr of exploratory est drilling into possible oil bearing deposits on the At lantic Outer Continental Shelf has been postponed for at least a year as a result of an order by President Nixon calling for further study of the environmental impact of such exploration.

title: Bill Easing Divorce Law Passed in Rush in Albany
description: Mandatory conciliation under the state's sixyearold liberal ized divorce law would be abolished on July 1 under a bill passed in the closing legisla tive rush and now awaiting Governor Rockefeller's signa ture.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BROOKLYN BASHES If the skies don't open, you'll be able to spend a busy af ternoon tomorrow in and around Prospect Park in Brooklyn.

title: Art: An Extraordinary Installation
description: NEW HAVENUnder the title American Arts and the American Experience, the Yale University Art Gallery has opened an extraordinary new installation of its perma nent collection of American painting, furniture and deco rative arts.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 57950
description: Tickets matching the number win 62,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with The first, middle or last three numbers In sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50,

title: Football Transactions NATIONAL CONFERENCE
description: LOS ANGELESSigned Cullen Bryan?, de fensive back, No. 2 draft choice from Colorado.

title: Paper Urges Resignation
description: MADISON, Wis., June 1 (UPI) The Madison Capital Times called yesterday for the resig nation of President Nixon. The editorial, in its entirety, said: Richard Milhous Nixon should resign the Presidency. Then he won't have the United States Constitution and the Bill of Rights to kick around any more.

title: VALUE OF DOLLAR SLUMPS AS GOLD SOARS IN EUROPE
description: GENEVA, June 1The dollar lost nearly one per cent of its fasteroding value against ma jor European currencies today and the price of gold reached another new high  almost a daily occurrence this week.

title: Colonel Who Deposed a King
description: When Col. George Papado poulos swept himself and his fellow military plotters into office in April, 1967, a visitor made the generous mistake of calling him General.

title: A House Chief Would Delay Raid Ban
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The chairman of the House Appro priations Committee, who will be a key figure when a Senate House conference tries next week to reconcile differing leg islation to curb the bombing in Cambodia, said today that he favored giving the Nixon Ad ministration a litle more time to try to achieve a ceasefire.

title: How China Solved the Drug Problem
description: DETROIT  Another country that once had an addiction problemone that lasted for almost 200 years and involved an incredible 25 per cent of its populationis China.

title: McKinsey & Co. Elects
description: The directors of McKinsey & Co.., the international manage ment consulting firm, yesterday elected Alonzo L. McDonald Jr., 45, as managing director.

title: Paul T. White, Composer, Dies; Conducted Rochester Symphony
description: ROCHESTER, June 1  Paul Taylor White, composer, con ductor, violinist and former teacher at the Eastman School of Music, died yesterday at his home in suburban Henrietta. His age was 77.

title: SUIT IS INSTITUTED AGAINST A. T. & T.
description: A $230million suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and 23 of its affiliates was initiated yes terday in Manhattan Federal Court by six large corporations using the Centrex telephone system.

title: Film in Teaching Machine Aids Retarded
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 A teaching machine or action box, which displays Motion pictures, has been used to advantage by its in ventor, Joan Rosengren Fors dale of, Nyack, N. Y., in schools for retarded chil dren. Mrs. Fors dale was granted Patent 3,735,499 this week on the equipment and her method for timing a subject's comprehension.

title: Charles Pomerantz, 76, Found Cause of Epidemic
description: Charles Pomerantz, a self taught entomologist and pest control specialist who lectured before universities and public health groups, died yesterday in Hallandale, Fla., where he lived. He was vice president of Exterminating Services Cor poration, 60 Madison Avenue. His age was 76.

title: Mrs. Gilda S. Goodmari Remarried Here
description: Mrs. Gilda S. Goodman, widow of Bertram Goodman, was married here yesterday afternoon to Albert Floer sheimer Jr. of Middletown, N.J., corporate secretary and administrative assistant to the president of the Walter Reade Organization, Inc.

title: Sister B. Lillian Phelps, One of Last Shakers, Dies
description: CANTERBURY, N. H., June 1 (AP)Sister B. Lillian Phelps, one of the last five members of the Canterbury Shaker religious community, died yesterday at the age of 96.

title: Soaring Prices Astonish Many At a Wine Sale
description: ATLANTA, June 1Unbelievable, sputtered the wine merchant, exiting from the morning session at Heu blein's fifth National Auction of Rare Wines yesterday. Those guys in there must be buying for the private stocks of kings. Inside the auditorium of the Atlanta Memorial Arts Center, the crowd that had gathered to bid on some 30,000 bottles of European and American wines buzzed with astonishment at the high level of prices offered for an assortment of vintages that only intermittently raced the blood of the experts.

title: Cox Pledges Full Cooperation in Coast Inquiry
description: LOS ANGELES, June 1  Archibald Cox, the special Watergate prosecutor, prom ised today to give full co operation to a Los Angeles grand jury's investigation of the breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist.

title: Mideast Debate at U.N. Delayed Until Wednesday
description: UNITED NATIONS, June 1 (Reuters)A Security Council debate on the Middle East that was originally to start Monday has been rescheduled Wednes day morning, it was announced here tonight.

title: School Principals Upheld On the Right to Be in Union
description: An official of the State Pub lic Employment Relations Board ruled yesterday that New York City school principals were not managerial employes and consequently could continue to belong to a union and have col lectivebargaining rights.

title: Let's Do It
description: WASHINGTON, June 1As people who think there is too much ado about trivia at the Watergate say,. They all do it. Take George Washington. He did it.

title: Miss Paula Goldsborough Is a Bride
description: STOWE, Vt., June 1 Miss Paula Goldsborough, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Herron Goldsbor ough of Shelburne, was mar ried here this afternoon to son of Mr. and Mrs. James Greene Wolcott of Underhill. The Rev. William H. Hollister of Christ Church, Presby terian, performed the cere mony on Mount Mansfield.

title: MAYORS CRITICIZE NIXON URBAN BILL
description: NEW HAVEN, June 1Con tending that Federal urbande velopment grants to the state's 31 major urban centers would be drastically reduced under President Nixon's proposed Bet ter Communities Bill, the Con necticut Conference of Mayors and Municipalities announced today its opposition to the measure. It asked instead for a reliable and adequate fund ing program.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Home Loan Bank Board asked banks and savings and loan associations today not to raise their interest rates on savings deposits as a result of the lapse, almost sure to be temporary, in the Government's authority to put ceilings on these rates.

title: STOCKS OFF AGAIN ON AMEX AND OTC
American League
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: U.S.SOVIET PACT ON FERTILIZER SET
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The United States and the Soviet Union today exchanged formal letters that gave political en dorsement to a recent $8billion, 20year fertilizer deal worked out between the Occidental Pe troleum Corporation and the Soviet Government.

title: ROSE FRANCES STOKES
description: Rose Frances Stokes, an art ist who taught for many years at the Prospect Country Day School in Newark, died Wednes day in Concord, N. H. She was 79 years old and lived at the Austin Nursing Home in Warner, N. H.

title: Vanden Heuvel's Rating by Bar Is Laid to His Lack of Candor
description: The rating by the Associa tion of the Bar of the City of New York of William J. vanden Heuvel as hot approved for the office of District Attorney in Manhattan was based on his lack of candor with the asso ciation and his lack of experi ence in the criminal courts, association sources said yester day.

title: Missouri Sets Truman Day
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., June 1 (AP)The late President Tru man's birth date, May 8, has been declared a state holiday in Missouri, with the signing of a bill by Gov. Christopher S. Bond. That holiday will replace Jefferson's birthday, April 13.

title: F.B.I. Was Given Key for Search in 1969
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The Federal Bureau of Investigation acknowledged today that its agents had investigated the of fices of a Washington radical newspaper without a search warrant in early 1969, but de nied that the action was an illegal breakin as reported yes terday in The New York Times.

title: Their Very Own SST
description: MOSCOWThe Concorde's contro versial development is being closely and sympathetically watched in Russia. There is no question of anyone being opposed to the project here and when Pan American Airways and Trans World Airlines dropped their options in January, the Soviet Gov ernment paper Izvestia compared their action to wrestling, no holds barred.

title: School Bond Issue Voted
description: MASTIC BEACH, LI., June 1 Voters in the William Floyd School District here voted 1,013 to 922 yesterday to approve a $13.8 million bond issue for construction of two elementary schools and a junior high school and for additions to an existing elementary school. The bond issue will raise the tax rate about $2.50 for each $100 of assessed valuation beginning in the 197475 school year. The rate is currently $21.27 for each $100 valuation.

title: DR. HERMAN THEAMAN
description: RYE, N. Y., June 1Dr. Her man Theaman, who had prac ticed dentistry in New York City and in Scarsdale, where he formerly had lived for more than 60 years, died today in Norwalk Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 720 Milton Road.

title: New London Has a 2d Bridge, but No Way to Get to It
description: NEW LONDON, June 1 For five months residents have watched the new span of the Gold Star Memorial Bridge over the Thames River here with mixed amuse ment and concern as the longest and costliest bridge in the state sat idle despite the completion of all but minor construction work.

title: Unused Spy Plan Under F.B.I. Study
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The Federal Bureau of Investigation is looking into the possibility that elements of the Nixon Ad ministration's master plan for domestic intelligence gathering were put into operation despite President Nixon's assurance that the proposal never went into effect.

title: Big Ammunition Dump Near Saigon Hit by Blasts
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1 (Reuters)Explosions ripped through a huge ammu nition dump near here today, killing one soldier and wound ing 13. Unconfirmed reports reports said the blasts were the work of Vietcong sabotage teams.

title: Effect of Senate's Inquiry On Future Trials Studied
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The staff of the Senate Watergate committee is studying the ques ion of how its fullscale airing of the scandal might affect criminal trials growing out of the case.

title: 25 Puerto Rican Artists Show Prints
description: The exhibition Puerto Ri can Prints, sponsored by the Exxon Corporation and the Pratt Graphic Arts Cen ter, now on view at the Exxon Building, 1251 Avenue of the Americas, near 50th Street, has much to recom mend it both for the quality of the work and the cultural opportunity it provides for seeing works by a number of artists who are not readily familiar.

title: The Screen: 'First Position' Arrives:Dance Documentary Is a Study in Depth The Cast Janis Roswick Seen as Aspirant Here
description: Janis Roswick, who has the lead, of sorts, in William Richert's documentary, "First Position," is an 18-year-old New York girl who hopes to become a dancer.She is pretty, a little plump, not noticeably graceful except when dancing, and resolutely middle class.Her public life is the round of "classes" (beginner, advanced beginner, intermediate and upward) that fill the days of any ballet student in this city. Her private life is a happy family outside Manhattan, a shared apartment in town, romantic interests in another student (Daniel Giagni) and an introspective diary in which she keeps account of these important years in her emotional and spiritual development. "My pink stage is slowly becoming deep cranberry red . . ." she writes. She isn't kidding.Janis has in superabundance the capacity for awe at herself that seems the identifying characteristic of bright young people native to New York City.But "First Position" isn't about Janis only. It is also about her boyfriend (not really; they're both too shy), whose life outside the dance includes training to be a clerk-typist in the National Guard. And it's about other students: a clever, ironic man who loses out in Janis's affections, and a talented but insecure boy who finally goes home to Florida to become a bagger in a supermarketafter almost succeeding at ballet school in New York.The school itself (the American Ballet Theater School, though its identity isn't too important) we know mainly through the qualities of some of its teachersthe vigorous Valentina Pereyaslavec, and Leon Danielian, severely crippled by arthritis, who spends most of the movie in a wheelchair. For an image of personal presence, Danielian's taking command over a dance class, even from a wheelchair, will do until something pretty spectacular comes along.From time to time the film cuts to passages from the recent Ballet Theater production of "Petrushka"almost the only formal dancing in the movie."Petrushka" is in costume, but danced in a semi-darkened classroom rather than on stage. Given the ballet and the setting, the effect is chilling and oddly dispirited. This is what we see of success in the film's terms. It isn't glamour; it's more like loneliness and a vague fear.And it is emblematic of what raises "First Position" above the level of sensitive slice-of-life documentaryto provide a vision of what lies just beyond, say, the winning self-assertion of Janis's diary, the classroom discipline, or Danielian's personal bravery. Temporary victories against time, they lead finally to a lovely expression of defeat, and that is how they are understood in this very good movie."First Position" opened this week at the First Avenue Screening Room.

title: Thompson Leads Golf by 2 Shots
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., June 1 They were suggesting that the $200,000 Kemper open golf tour nament be renamed the Wake Forest open. Leonard Thompson, a 200pound North Carolina pro fessional from Lumberton and a Wake Forest alumnus; led by two strokes with a 36hole ag gregate of 132 today.

title: Cambodia Gets. U.S. Copier Gunships
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 1 (AP)Military sources said today that the United States had given the Cam bodian air force a small squad ron of helicopter gunships for close air support of combat troops.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: BOSTONSigned Andre Savard, center, No. 1 choice in amateur draft, to multiyear con tract.

title: Dr. A. T. Schnurer Weds Mrs. McGill
description: BALTIMORE, June 1 Mrs. Christine Wood McGill and Dr. Anthony Teller Schnurer were married here this afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Blum, friends of the couple. Rabbi David Goldstein performed the ceremony.

title: Plan for Nixon Library Reported Moving Ahead
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 1 (AP)  The president of the Richard Nixon Foundation said today that plans to construct a multimilliondollar Nixon li brary and museum were moving ahead despite the Watergate scandal.

title: Caroline S. Tankoos Married
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 1 The marriage of Miss Caroline Scott Tankoos to Marc Swit Brown, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Samuel Brown of Stamford, took place here this afternoon. The Rev. Frederick P. Gehring, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Samuel M. Silver per formed the ceremony in the garden at the home of Mrs. William Granniss Tankoos, mother of the bride.

title: A Former Slave Dead; Age Believed to Be 122
description: DALLAS, June 1 (UPI) David Peterson, believed to have been 122 years old and possibly the oldest living American, died here yester day.

title: M'CRANE IS FREED ON $25,000 BOND
description: NEWARK, June 1Former State Treasurer Joseph M. Mc Crane Jr. was released in $25,000 bond today after plead ing not guilty to taxfraud, charges today, but he was or dered to give detailed reports on any foreign trips he planned.

title: MONARCHY ENDED AS GREEK REGIME SETS UP REPUBLIC
description: ATHENS, June 1  Greece's militaryled Government abol lished the monarchy today and proclaimed the country a re public.

title: Protestants Lead in Ulster's Local Vote
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 1Nearly complete re turns from the election of local councils on Wednesday showed today that the voters of North ern Ireland had split largely along traditional sectarian lines.

title: GOWL, 19, TAKES CROWN AT DEVON
description: DEVON, Pa., June 1Spindle top Solid Gold captured the intermediate jumper stake to day and with it the division championship with 15 points at the Devon horse show.

title: EXMACKELL AIDE INDICTED IN BRIBE
description: The chief rackets investiga tor in Queens for the last six and a half years has been in dicted on charges of extortion, bribe receiving and conspiracy for allegedly taking more than $4,500 in cash and services from the Avis RentACar Sys tem.

title: WCBSTV Poll Puts Beame Ahead in Race
description: A WCBSTV poll complet ed yesterday showed Con troller Abraham D. Beame running ahead of his oppo nents in the Democratic may oral primary, but with a still large undecided vote of 21 per cent.

title: Age Discrimination Laid To CarRental Agencies
description: TRENTON, June 1 (UPI) The New Jersey Public Inter est Research Group, a stu dent organization, charged today that carrental agen cies were refusing autos to people under 21 years of age in violation of state law.

title: I.R.A. BERTH WON BY NORTHEASTERN
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 1  Northeastern's crew, the best in the East this season, showed its class today with a finishing sprint that won a place in the final of the national champion ships on Onondaga Lake tomor row.

title: People and Business Mitsui Elects Ikeda President
description: Yoshizo Ikeda, 62, has been elected president of Mitsui & Co., Ltd., Japan's $20billion international trad ing company, the company's United States subsidiary, Mitsui & Co. (U.S.A.) an nounced yesterday.

title: VALUE OF DOLLAR SLUMPS AS GOLD SOARS IN EUROPE
description: GENEVA, June 1The dollar lost nearly one per cent of its fasteroding value against ma jor European currencies today and the price of gold reached another new high  almost a daily occurrence this week.

title: KAREL VOGL
description: Karel Vogl, a retired director of the Skins Trading Corpora tion here, died May 25 on a visit to Prague. He was 80 years old and lived at 244 West 72nd Street.

title: Stage: Thomas Andros
description: The Circle Theater Com pany is closing its fourth sea son with a musical tragedy of the fifties by Ron Wilcox titled The Tragedy of Thom as Andros. It is playing Thursday through Sunday un til June 17 at 2307 Broad way. A fine outfit is marking time.

title: Gold Bars, Anyone?
description: Back in 1934, in the midst of the Depression, Congress passed a law making it illegal for United States citizens to own gold except for ornamental, artistic, industrial and similar purposes. The idea was to discourage hoard ing and to encourage spending of money on useful goods and services, thereby creating jobs for the unemployed.

title: A Brezhnev Pledge On Jews Reported Given to Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, June 1Leo nid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, was reported today to have told Henry A. Kissinger last month in Moscow that the Soviet Un ion would permit Jews to emi grate at the current rate of 36,000 to 40,000 a year and that the education tax on emi gration would remain sus pended.

title: Harvey Firestone Jr., Director 0f Rubber Company, Dies at 75
description: Son of of the Founded in Building Plants for Synthetic Products

title: CARL B. TEISBERG JR.
description: Carl B. Teisberg Jr., senior assistant manager of the Wal dorfAstoria Hotel, died in Me morial Hospital on Thursday. He was 63 years old.

title: Inquiry Into 72 Grain Trading Shifted
description: WASHINGTON, June 1(AP) The Commodity Exchange Authority confirmed today that it had asked the Justice Department to take over an investigation into allegations of price rigging on the Kan sas City commodity market during last summer's grain sales to the Soviet Union.

title: West Yields to Demands Of OilExporting Lands
description: GENEVA, Saturday, June 2 Western petroleum companies yielded to the price demands of the major oil exporting coun tries early today to end a dis pute that had threatened new production cuts by exporters and intensification of the world's energy crisis.

title: ANTIOCH COLLEGE OPENED BY POLICE
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, June 1Sheriff's deputies and policemen from nearby towns forcibly opened Antioch Col lege this afternoon, 43 days after its classrooms and ad ministrative buildings were locked and barricaded by strik ing students.

title: Campus Notes Grant Made for StudyIncentive Plan
description: Prof. John M. Darley of Princeton University has won a grant of nearly $30,000 to study the effectiveness of a system he uses in his social psychology lecture course to keep students abreast of each week's required reading.

title: NIXON, POMPIDOU CONCLUDE TALKS; SOME GAINS SEEN
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 1  The conference between President Nixon and Pres ident Pompidou of France ended today after more than six hours of facetoface meetings that kindled hopes for future prog ress while producing no con crete agreements.

title: Woods Loses U.S.T.T.F. Title
description: WICHITA, Kan., June 1A?? Feuerbach scored his sixth con sective shotput victory over George Woods tonight and in the process equaled Woods's United States Track and Field federation meet record. Feuer bach, who recently set a world record of 71 feet 7 inches, put the 16pound ball 69 feet 9 inches on his second attempt. He also had three other efforts over 69 feet.

title: RailTon Mileage at Peak
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The Association of American Rail roads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week set a singleweek high of an estimated 17.2 billion ton miles. The previously reported record was an estimated 17.0 billion tonmiles during the week of October 14, 1972. The A.A.R. also reported carload ings in the same week were the highest in two years, to taling 563,101 cars, 5.4 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago.

title: Chicago Bank Adds Unit
description: CHICAGO, June 1 (Reuters) The First National Bank of Chicago said today it had formed an Australian finance company with offices in Syd ney and Melbourne.

title: MRS. LUCILLE MAYO
description: Mrs. Lucille Y. Mayo, di rector of the rehabilitation and social service department of the New York State Work men's Compensation Board, died yesterday in Bronx Leb anon Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived at 1010 East 216th Street, the Bronx.

title: ExSecurity Agent Is Called Swindler
description: A San Francisco clothing manufacturing company has Charged that its former presi dentwho has been ousted from his job  misrepresented himself under an alias as a past military security expert when he was in fact a selfconfessed stock swindler who testified for the Government in the 1970 trial of Angelo De Carlo, a re puted Mafia leader.

title: Dodge Recalls 1,906 Trucks
description: DETROIT, June 1 (AP) The Chrysler Corporation an nounced today that it was re calling 1,906 medium duty Dodge trucks built from 1969 through 1973 because of a pos sible defect that could cause reduced braking power. Chry sler said that the trucks, equipped with dual braking sys tems, might have brake tubes routed so close to the steering column that contact could be possible, causing wear and pos sible failure of a brake hose. Chrysler estimated that 5 per cent of the trucks had the prob lem. It said that it had no re ports of accidents caused by the defect.

title: Iceland Charges Ramming, Heightening Fishing Clash
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 1 The struggle between Britain and Iceland over fishing rights reached a new climax today with a ramming incident off Iceland's southeast coast.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: CONSENT AGREEMENT SETTLES INSIDER SUIT
description: A Nashville father and his son agreed yesterday not to violate Federal securities laws in a courtapproved injunction by consent that settled a law suit by the Securities and Ex change Commission involving insider dealings.

title: Greece Uncrowned
description: The merest remnant of the once glamorous Greek monarchy was indeed an obstacle (as Athens is now saying) to the dubious political evolution envisaged by George Papadopoulos. It got in his way. However absent from the public eye these past years, the fact that the institutions of monarchy even existed at all served as an offstage check to Mr. Papadopoulos' pretensions to national leadership. Whether or not the deposed King Constantine actually conspired in the uprising, the abor tive naval mutiny of last week demonstrated that so long as the monarchy survived, there was a focal point for the opposition.

title: CAHILL APPEALS TO WOMEN VOTERS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 1 Governor Cahill took his cam women for renomination to the women of New Jersey today, dressing the home and family rod the woman's role in making the state a better place in which to live.

title: Candidates Day ExSenator McCarthy Backs Badillo
description: Representative Herman Ba dillo was endorsed yesterday by former Senator Eugene McCar thy, who called him a man deeply committed to the general good of the country, state and city of New York and especially concerned about the problems of the poor and deprived.

title: A Brezhnev Pledge On Jews Reported Given to Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, June 1Leo nid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, was reported today to have told Henry A. Kissinger last month in Moscow that the Soviet Un ion would permit Jews to emi grate at the current rate of 36,000 to 40,000 a year and that the education tax on emi gration would remain sus pended.

title: F.C.C. Rules 2 Groups Can Copy Tapes From Obscenity Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission overruled it, staff and announced today that two organizations could copy a tape of radio shows that were part of an F.C.C. inquiry into broad cast obscenity.

title: Chicago Laborers Strike
description: CHICAGO, June 1 (AP)  More than 15,000 laborers be longing to a dozen building trade locals in Chicago and northeastern Illinois went on strike early today against building contractors. Union of ficials said the major issues in volved work rules and sched uling.

title: 69 BY MARY MILLS LEADS VEGAS GOLF
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 1 (AP)Mary Mills took advan tage of an early starting time today to shoot a fourunderpar 69 for the firstround lead in the raindelayed $100,000 Sealy Faberge women's golf tourney.

title: Budget Deficit Cut Again By EDWIN L. DALE Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  The Government added $3 billion more today to its esti mate of tax collections in the forthcoming fiscal year and correspondingly reduced its estimate of the budget deficit to $2.7billion.

title: ChainStore Sales Show a 20.9% Rise
Briefs on the Arts
description: The American Symphony Orchestra, which gave no concerts during the 197273 season after the retirement of Leopold Stokowski, its founder and music director, will be in business again next season. It will give five Mondayevening concerts at Carnegie Hall and has plans for other activities, including inschool concerts and a three  year American  music project.

title: FUEL SALES EQUITY BACKED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) The Senate voted today to require major gasoline and oil companies to give independent operators equitable treatment in buying gasoline.

title: WIDE INFORMATION DECREED BY S. E. C.
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The Securities and Exchange Com mission ordered all companies today to provide more mean ingful disclosure in prospec tuses and reports on new prod uct lines, their position in the industry and competitive condi tions under which they operate.

title: TV Splashdown Coverage
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) Live television coverage of the splashdown and recovery operations for the Skylab 1 as tronauts later this month was approved today by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: High Rating ls Given For Notes of City
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame announced yesterday that Moody's Investors Service had given its secondhighest rating to $265million in shortterm notes that New York City plans to sell on Tuesday.

title: Skylab Space Walk Is Planned To Release SolarPower Wing
description: HOUSTON, June 1The Sky lab 1 astronauts are expected to make another attempt next week to release a jammed solarpower wing and thus re lieve the orbiting space sta tion's energy shortage.

title: PRISON MAIL CURB IS TARGET OF SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 1A suit has been filed in United States District Court here by 88 Federal inmates seeking to re move all restrictions on pris oner mail.

title: Byrne and De Rose Give Differing Views on Crime
description: NEWARK, June 1Two Dem ocratic contenders for the par ty's nomination for Governor Brendan T. Byrne and State Senator Ralph C. De Rose were talking about Jersey crime yesterday and who is to blame for failure to control it.

title: Budget Deficit Cut Again
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  The Government added $3 billion more today to its esti mate of tax collections in the forthcoming fiscal year and correspondingly reduced its estimate of the budget deficit to $2.7billion.

title: Foreman Reportedly To Defend in Canada
description: George Foreman, the world heavyweight champion, re portedly has decided to de fend his title for the first time in Canada in midJuly. Foreman's opponent, the re port said, would be selected from among four contenders Larry Middleton of Balti more, Oscar Bonavena of Ar gentina, Jurgen Blin, the German champion, and Jose Urtain, the Spanish title holder. The date, site and terms are expected to be announced Monday.

title: Vanden Heuvel's Rating by Bar Is Laid to His `Lack of Candor
description: The rating by the Associa tion of the Bar of the City of New York of William J. vanden Heuvel as not approved for the office of District Attorney in Manhattan was based on his lack of candor with the asso ciation and his lack of experi ence in the criminal courts, association sources said yester day.

title: A Judge Dismisses Suit Over Access ToAllenhurstJetty
description: FREEHOLD, June 1 (UPI) A suit to guarantee fishermen access to an Allenhurst jetty, which was financed in part by almost $350,000 in state funds, was dismissed today by a Su perior Court judge.

title: SOVIET ALLOWS EXIT OF DISSIDENT WRITER
description: LONDON, June 1Andrei Sinyavsky, the Soviet author and critic who, with Yuli Daniel, was the first dissident writer to se sent to prison for his literary work, has received permission to leave the Soviet Union, it was disclosed here to day.

title: Squabbles Mark Race for State Chief Judge
description: The primary fight for the Democratic nomination for Chief Judge of the state has been a blistering one, with the initial lawyerlike veneer of a nonpolitical and dignified race lost in squabbles over bar association pronouncements, campaign spending and even the endorsements from some Queens Democratic district lead ers.

title: Roundup: Red Sox Down A's and Continue to Rise
description: The Boston Red Sox, al most halfway through a nine game home stand in Fenway Park, where they hope to reach the .500 plateau in the wonlost column, continued in the right direction last night. They beat the stum bling Oakland A's, 6.2.

title: Soviet Shadow Over Reykjavik
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 1 The final meeting, in this spring's round of American West European summitry ended today, appropriately, in mid Atlantic.

title: British Bill Rates Decline At Treasury's Weekly Sale
description: LONDON, June 1 (Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of British treasury bills fell to 7.1604 per cent from 7.1959 per cent.

title: A Dream Nears Reality
description: LONDON  When Britain officially joined the European Economic Com munity this year it became necessary to give life to an old idea: providing a direct physical link between the Continent and these, its major off shore islands. The original plan, to construct a carriageway through a tunnel under the English Channel, was first dreamed up in 1802 by a French engineer named Matthieu and submit ted to Napoleon I.

title: Factory Hours Off in May
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The unemployment rate remained at 5 per cent of the work force in May, about where it has been for six months.

title: Politics, Economics and the Gas Tax
description: WASHINGTON, June 1Sev eral of President Nixon's senior economic advisers are reliably reported to favor an increase of at least 5 cents a gallon in the Federal gasoline tax, and maybe even 10 cents. The tax is now 4 cents.

title: Votes in Congress
Spring Madness in Lower Manhattan
description: A park has died in Lower Manhat tan. In a rampage of destruction, it was turned into a construction site in this area where there are lots of construction sites and not enough parks.

title: Colombian Airliner in Argentina On the Fourth Day of Hijacking
description: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Saturday, June. 2 (AP)A Colombian airliner under the command of two exhausted gunmen landed at Buenos Aires Airport early today. They were involved in the longest hijack ing on recordsome 15,000 miles over a fourday period.

title: Greek Monarchy: 7 Alien Crowns in 140 Years
description: Whoever becomes king of Greece had better keep his bag packed.

title: Philadelphia Stores Struck
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) About 500 warehouse work ers for three departmentstore chains went on strike today. Teamster Locals 169 and 115 established picket lines at stores and warehouses of Lits, Strawbridge & Clothier and Gimbels. Officials said the main issues were workrule changes and a proposed night shift.

title: INDICTED OFFICIAL DONATED TO CAHILL
description: TRENTON, June 1 (AP) Governor Cahill had accepted a $1,000 campaign contribution from a former Jackson Town ship Committeeman who has been indicted on charges of ac cepting a bribe, it was disclosed today.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Hour s are given In Eastern Daylight Time.

title: New Jersey Sports Man With Big Stick
description: TEANECK, N. J., June 1Bruce Neville is a diabetic. There is nothing unusual about that. Thousands of Ameri cans are afflicted with the disease and they continue to function as ordinary people.

title: BEAME GETS MOST OF LABOR SUPPORT
description: In a mayoral campaign in which major labor groups have departed from their traditional neutrality in primaries, Con troller Abraham D. Beame has corralled by far the greatest volume of formal union support.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Japan Trade Meeting Set
description: TOKYO, June 1 (Reuters) Secretary of State William P. Rogers will attend the ninth United StatesJapan trade and economic joint committee meet ing in Tokyo on July 6 and 17, the Foreign Ministry announced today. The Ministry said other United States Government offi cials concerned would take part in the Tokyo meeting.

title: Radio
Jazz: Benny and His AllStars Play Basic Goodman
description: Benny Goodman spent his 64th birthday on Wednesday in bed at his home in Green wich, Conn., nursing a back condition that has bothered him for more than 30 years. But on Thursday night, smiling and relaxed, he was up on the stand at the Rainbow Grill with his sextet as he swung into his 65th year to the accompaniment of belated birthday greetings, with a cake whose decorations pro claimed: Happy Birthday Long Live the King!

title: DRUG DEALER GETS LIFE FOR MURDER
description: Vincent Pacelli Jr., already serving a 20year jail term for dealing in narcotics, was sen tenced to life imprisonment yes terday for killing a fashion model who had been scheduled to testify against him at the drug trial.

title: F. R Coudert 3d, Mrs. Dale Hokin Are Wed Here
description: Mrs. Dale Hokin was mar ried here last evening to Frederic Rene Coudert 3d, a member of the international law firm of Coudert Brothers. The Rev. James W. Crawford of the Central Presbyterian Church performed the cere mony at the bride's apart ment.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: McCrane Pleads Not Guilty

title: OKKER SETS BACK SMITH IN TENNIS
description: PARIS, June 1 (AP)Tom Okker of the Netherlands, taking advantage of poor serves by topseeded Stan Smith in the final game, eliminated the American from the French open tennis championship today in a rain  plagued five  set match played over two days.

title: Brooklyn Girl, 9, Is Killed Apparently by Strangulation
description: A 9yearold Brooklyn girl, whose unconscious body was found lying on a stairway in a Coney Island apartment house yesterday, died a few hours later at Coney Island Hospital, apparently a victim of strangu lation.

title: Mills Offers Assurances On TaxShelter Changes
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The chairman and the ranking Re publican member of the House Ways and Means Committee said today that any tighter new rules that are applied to invest ments in tax shelters probably would not be retroactive.

title: JAPAN'S LEFTISTS HOBBLING TANAKA
description: TOKYO, June 1Japan's Op position parties, led by the So cialists and Communists, ap peared this week to have achieved their avowed aim of bringing Premier Kakuei Ta naka's Government to a halt.

title: To Trawlermen, Iceland War Is Hot
description: HULL, England, June 1 The Lord Tedder, a tired and rusty trawler, moved slowly up the Humber River and pulled herself to dockside at 4:30 in the afternoon. She was home again, back after three weeks with 100 tons of fish from controversial waters, a veteran returning

title: GAMBINO'S SLAYER IS GIVEN 15 YEARS
description: The player of Emanuel Gam bine, a nephew of the reputed Mafia boss Carlo Gambino, was sentenced yesterday to 15 years in Federal prison despite a last minute plea that the killing was an accident.

title: JOHN DE MENIL, 69, A PATRON OF ART
description: HOUSTON, June 1John de Mnil, wellknown art patron and collector of art, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived also in Paris and New York.

title: Coast Quintuplets Gaining
description: PORTLAND, Ore., June 1 (UPI)  The Anderson quin tuplets, now five weeks old, are all gaining weight and may be taken home within a few weeks from Bess Kaiser Hos pital. They were born April 26 to Mr. and Mrs. Eric Anderson of Brush Prairie, Wash.

title: 5 RECORDS BROKEN IN COLLEGE TRACK
description: CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ind. (UPI)The world recordholder and Olympic champion, Rod Milburn of Southern University, shattered a meet record today in the 120yard high hurdles in the National Collegiate Athletic Association College Division track championships.

title: U.S. Wrestlers Lose, 119, To Soviet
description: After the speed and dexterity of their lighterclass wrestlers had given them a 95 advan tage with only three matches remaining last night, the Unit ed States wrestling team failed to pick up another point the rest of the way and bowed again to the Soviet Union, 119 at the Felt Forum.

title: 5th Ave. Coach Gets Refund
description: Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., announced yesterday that it had received a Federal in come tax refund of $2.706,898, including interest of $308,898, relating to 1970 and prior years. The amount of refund had been previously reflected in the balance sheet of the company as an asset that had not as yet been collected.

title: Bass Angler Wins $3,500
description: SENECA, S.C., June 1 (UPI) J. L. Collis, a Decatur, Ga., truck driver took the top prize of $3,500 in the Carolina in vitation bass tournament on Lake Keowee today with a total catch of almost 24 pounds. He also won $750 for catching the second largest bass of the threeday tourney.

title: Alderman Claude Holman Of Chicago City Council
description: CHICAGO, June 1 (UPI) Alderman Claude Holman, president pro tem of the Chi cago City Council and a staunch supporter of Mayor Richard J. Daley, was found dead early today in his South Side apartment. He was 69 years old.

title: Cahill's Record on Environment Is a Source of Pride and a Target
description: TRENTON, June 1  His administration's record of legis lation to protect and conserve New Jersey's environment is one of which Governor Cahill is quite proud, one which he speaks of publicly and often, and one on which it would seem he is least vulnerable. But his opponentsDemocrat and Republicanare highly critical of him on this issue nonethe less.

title: EXMACKELL AIDE INDICTED ON BRIBE
description: The chief rackets investiga tor in Queens for the last six and a half years has been in dicted on charges of extortion, bribe receiving and conspiracy for allegedly taking more than $4,500 in cash and services from the Avis RentACar Sys tem.

title: Effect of Senate's Inquiry On Future Trials Studied
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The staff of the Senate Watergate committee is studying the ques tion of how its fullscale airing of the scandal might affect criminal trials growing out of the case.

title: People in Sports: Gabriel Trades Himself From Rams to Eagles
description: Roman Gabriel, the dis gruntled Los Angeles quarter back, who has two years to go on his contract with the Rams but has or thinks he has the right to trade him self, has come to terms with the Philadelphia Eagles, it was announced yesterday. After Gabriel assured Mike McCormack, the Eagles coach, that his sore arm of 72 was a thing of the past, McCormack called Don Klos terman, the Rams general pricetag for Gabriel and, ac cording to McCormack, Klos terman said he hadn't given it any thought but would get back to him. Gabriel had asked to be traded after the Rams acquired the San Diego Hadl.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. California Angels, at yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M. (TelevisionChannel11, 2 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Padres, at San Diego.

title: In Case of Fire . . .
description: The complaint of Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery that Penn Central personnel failed to sound an alarm when fire broke out in the engine of a crowded commuter train on Wednesday constitutes a grave charge of dan gerous negligence. The train was stalled in the tunnel underneath Park Avenue at 76th Street. Smoke was so dense and acrid that it felled 27 firemen. Yet fire officials maintain that the first alarm was sounded more than one hour after the first sign of the fire, and then apparently only by way of a street alarm box.

title: Barber, After 2 Crew Cuts, Sees End of LongHair Era
description: The Broadway Barbershop on Broadway near 104th Street is an oldfashioned place with a white ceramic tiled floor and a dominating hottowel heater. It has a ro tating barber pole out front and stacks of magazines that go back three and four years. Kay Demetriou, who has owned the place for the last 30 years, knows most of his customers by name. During the last few years of long hair and rare barber shop visits this attested to Mr. Demetriou's good mem ory. Now it is less remark able. Mr. Demetriou is seeing his customers much more regularly.

title: SECRETARIAT FAST EVEN IN PRACTICE
description: Secretariat had a workout on the main track at Belmont Park yesterday morning and amazed a handful of knowl edgeable observers with his performance. With his regular rider, Ron Turcotte, steering him, Secretariat stepped a mile in 1:34 4/5, the exact clocking that was made by Linda's Chief in winning the Withers Mile on Wednesday.

title: Officials of Ronson Corp. Oppose Offer by Liquifin to Buy Stock
description: Louis V. Aronson 2d, presi dent of the Ronson Corpora tion, announced yesterday that directors and management of Ronson were opposed to the tender offer announced yester day by Liquifin Aktiengesell schaft, a wholly owned subsid iary of Liquigas, S.p.A., a large Italian industrial concern. Li quifin offered to buy 2.2million shares of the com mon stock of the Ronson Corpora tion at $8.50 a share, or a total price of $18.7 million. Ronson has 4.2million shares outstanding.

title: FUTURES PRICES SHOW WIDE RISE
description: With the exception of wheat and oats, futures prices of farm commodities rose yesterday. Showing increases were soy beans, soybean meal, corn, cat tle, hogs, and pork bellies.

title: Wedding Is Set By Dana Smith
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., June 2Mr. and Mrs. Doug las MacKenzie Smith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dana MacKenzie Smith, to D. Fred erick Day, son of Mrs. Dud ley Minton Day of Upper Montclair and the late Mr. Day. A September wedding is planned.

title: India's Traditional Arranged Marriage Takes a Modern Turn
Oil Drilling Test Off L.I. Delayed by U.S. Agency
description: The United States Geolog ical Survey has postponed the beginning of explora tory, test drilling into po tenttially oilbearing deposits on the Atlantic Outer Con tinental Shelf for at least one year in response to an order from President Nixon requiring further study of the environmental impact of such exploration.

title: A Political Unknown Is Seeking Cahill's Seat
description: TRENTONWho is Michael A. Maglio? He is 59 years old, he is a machinist who lives in Belleville and, along with Governor Cahill and Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., he is seeking the Republican nomination for Governor in Tuesday's primary balloting.

title: The Wrong Security
description: The Government was in jeopardy. My private infor mation removed all doubt. It was with these words and on the basis of such private information that Attorney General A. Mitchell Palmer in 1920 swept aside all constitutional restraints and momentarily took the United States to the brink of totalitarianism.

title: ShapeUp Time for Perennials
description: APERENNIAL flower bor der can be an orderly mosaic of colors and patterns all summer if the gardener pays some at tention to groonling.

title: Contract Ratified, PATH Strike By Carmen Ends After 63 Days
description: Service on the Port Authority TransHudson commuter rail road resumed at 12:01 this morning, the first time since the beginning of the 63day carmen's strike that a PATH train had made the New JerseyNew York run.

title: Symington Presses Challenge on Haig
description: WASHINGTON, June 2Sen ator Stuart Symington has asked the Pentagon for further information about the appoint ment of General Alexander M. Haig Jr. as assistant to the President, saying that he doubts the President has the right to turn the office of the President into a military command with out Congressional authority.

title: Tenant Court In Brooklyn Is Assailed Ina Study
description: A study of LandlordTenant Court in Brooklyn reports the court is a decrepit, badly overcrowded place in which some judges find it degrad ing to serve and in which litigants often leave more be wildered and ignorant of their rights and responsibilities than when they came in.

title: MILADY HANDICAP TO MINSTREL MISS
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 2 (UPI)  Minstrel Miss outran favored Susan's Girl in the $65,000 Milady handicap for fillies and mares at Hollywood Park today and Bill Shoemaker passed the $50million mark in career earnings by finishing third aboard Pallisima.

title: Home Economists Kept Busy
description: MILLTOWN.  Twenty women, eight children and two infants showed up at a church basement here one re cent morning. The women were there to hear two home economists, Carol Kaiser and Margaret Lawson, tell them how to refinish furniture.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, JUNE 3, 1973
description: King Constantine II held a dramatic news conference in the garden of his villa in Rome and said earnestly that he was confident of returning to Greece as guardian of consti tutional liberties. In a statement, in English, that he read to about 100 newsmen, the King said: The real problem lies not in whether Greece should have a democracy with or without a King, but whether she should have a democracy at all, and whether the people of Greece has the right to be master of its fate and to enjoy its freedom. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Program For Elderly A Success At City U.
description: The new program of open enrollment for the elderly at schools in the City Univer sity of New York is working out very well, accosting to City University officials. All senior colleges, and six of eight community colleges, now have students on cam pus, attending regular classes for credit. There have been no dropouts.

title: Greece
description: ATHENSThe first clear sign that the fate of the Greek monarchy had been decided came at noon Friday. The emblem of the crown was hauled down at the army officers cadet school and up went the symbol of the former colonels who seized power here six years agoa phoenix rising from the ashes.

title: Best Seller List
description: FICTION

title: Yale's First Full Class of Women, About to Graduate, Looks Back With Pride and Hope
description: NEW HAVEN, June 2  The first full class of 195 un dergraduate women to join man and God at Yale since the university was founded 272 years ago will graduate Monday. They are looking back on four struggling years with fierce pride, a sense of accomplishment and the hope that it will be easier for the women who will follow them.

title: Saigon Soldiers Openly Abuse Civilians
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2The South Vietnamese soldier in camouflage fatigue uniform stood casually in the middle of Route 1 near Bong Son, a town on the Central Coast, waving his M16 rifle at an approaching truck, Cautious ly the driver backed to a halt and after a brief discussion handed out some money.

title: World News Briefs
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland. June 2 (Reuters)Iceland will give formal notice this month that she wants a revision of the treaty on the stationing of United States troops at the North Atlantic Treaty Organi zation base here, Foreign Min ister Einar Agustsson an nounced today.

title: NEW FLIGHT PLAN SPED FOR SKYLAB
description: HOUSTON, June 2Mission officials were drawing up a revised flight plan today for the Skylab 1 astronauts to use in trying to repair a jammed solarpower wing on the elec tricityshort space station.

title: Aviation Walkout in Canada
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, June 2 (AP)Air Canada machinists at Vancouver Inter national Airport walked out to day for 24 hours. Machinists were also off the job in Ed monton and Calgary, in Alberta. A union spokesman said that employes not directly involved in the action were being al lowed to cross picket lines.

title: Priscilla Van Tassel Is Married
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 2Miss Priscilla Van Tassel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Van Tassel, was married here this after noon to Douglas S. Eakeley, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Scott Eakeley of Westfield, N. J. The ceremony was performed in the Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. William C. Schram.

title: Mailbox: Weekend Fare
description: To the Editor:

title: IB.M.'s Methods
description: WASHINGTONThe time is April, 1964. In Poughkeepsie, N. Y., the International Business Machines Corporation snakes momentous announcementa new line of advanced computers, called the System 360. For the next six years, the System 360 would be the mainstay of I.B.M.'s business. Fortune magazine later called the decision to build the 360 the $5billion gamble.

title: City Council Units List Week's Open Meetings
description: TUESDAYThe Committee on Industrial Development will meet at 10 A.M. on the relocation of residents of the Northside section of Brooklyn to make way for industrial development.

title: Kodak and the Lilliputians
description: Throughout the history of American industry, one of the problems of competing with giants has been the task of overtaking an established image, particularly a trade mark that is almost a generic term.

title: Not a championship season
description: A year ago last September I went to the first Broadway opening of the season, stood outside theater on 45th Street, looked left toward Broad way and right toward Eighth Avenue, and said to myself, out loud, My God, it's a ghost town. I claim no originality for the phrase. I think even my perception may have come late (how many years after the fact?). But the impression, for me, had force, almost finality. This was the center of the theatrical world. And there was no one on the street.

title: Fuel Oil Spills Into River
description: PITTSBURGH, June 2 (AP) About 40,000 gallons of fuel oil poured into the Monongahela River from the United States Steel Corporation's Duquesne Works last night, the Coast Guard said. The slick spread into the Ohio River before be ing contained.

title: Firemen Warned on Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) A Presidential commission on fire problems will recommend tljat Federal funds for aiding local fire departments be with held from departments that dis criminate against minority groups, a commission spokes man said today.

title: KROGH DISPUTED
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 Contrary to assertions in a sworn statement by a former White House aide, Egil Krogh Jr., the Federal Bureau of In vestigation had knowledge in late June, 1971, that the Soviet Government did not possess the Pentagon papers before they were published by The New York Times, according to Justice Department sources.

title: If You Expect James Bond, You're in for a Shock
description: IN return for starring in his final James Bond movie, Diamonds Are Forever, Sean Connery won from United Artists an agreement to fi nance any two movies of his choosing; the only condition was that the movies be brought in for less than $1million each. The Offence (written by John Hopkins, directed by Sidney Lumet) is the first of the films, and it must be one of the most relentlessly bleak and dour movies ever released by a major American studio. Now the problem is finding how to promote it. United Art ists seems to have already given up; the movie recently opened here without warning and closed just as suddenly weeks later.

title: Numismatics
description: TWO developments in the latter part of last month should prove how wrong those col lectors were who sat on their hands and said, What's the use of speaking out. No one will listen.

title: Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTONIn June of 1969, on its last day under the leadership of Chief Justice Earl Warren, the Su preme Court handed down three de cisions that broadened the rights of criminal suspects and correspondingly curbed the practices of law enforce ment officials.

title: New York
description: Hard footsteps follow you home at night. A knife at your throat, a jab in your stomach, your purse or wal let gone and it's over. You're another statistic in the war we could lose the against the criminal.

title: Letters
description: As others hear us

title: The U.S.S.R. and the U.C.C.
description: For some two decades Western writers and publishers have been regretting that the U.S.S.R. has not joined the Universal Copyright Convention, the international agreement which provides authors of the contracting states with equitable protec tion of their literary property in all sig natory countries. Since the preamble of U.C.C. states that the convention is in tended to ensure respect for the rights of the individual and encourage the development of literature, the sciences and the arts . . . and . . . facilitate wider dissemination of works of the human mind and increase international understanding . . . it was widely as sumed that Russian participation would signal a relaxation of repressive policies toward nonconforming writers and a day of thanksgiving in the Soviet Union, as well as in the West where writers would then presumably receive payment in ex portable money for their works published in the U.S.S.R.

title: Costs Cut In Aiding Homeless In Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L. I.In 1971, Nassau was supporting 100 homeless single persons in hotels and motels. Today, there are six or seven.

title: The Nongolden Fleeced
description: PARISThe United States Govern ment has one curious distinction. It is probably the only major democratic regime that exercises complete juris diction particularly with regard to taxation and money mattersover its citizens residing abroad.

title: Tupolev and Concorde: Supersonic Rivals and Allies
description: PARIS, May 31  The world's two supersonic trans ports have sat nose by tail air show at Le Bourget this week, starting a helpmateri valry that could be decisive for commercial aviation.

title: Pope Commemorafes Death of John XXIII
description: ROME, June 2Pope Paul VI today offered a mass in St. Peter's Basilica to mark the 10th anniversary tomor row of the death of his predecessor, Pope John XXIII.

title: Hospital In Hampton To Begin Constructor
description: EASTPORT, L. I.Ground was broken yesterday for the Hamptons Hospital, a $24million, 222bed medical center that will serve some 70,000 people from the Mas ticShirley area to Hampton Bays.

title: Beastly World
description: ACROSS

title: SHABUOTH STARTS TUESDAY EVENING
description: Shabuoth, the Jewish com memoration of the giving of the Ten Commandments, will start at sundown Tuesday with ob servances in temples and syna gogues.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe Wa tergate flurry, as it is called by many here, is providing an early, unanticipated test of the world's new system of largely floating currency ex change rates. The early opin ions, subject to change, are that the first shock is being met well.

title: A Degree After 50 Years
description: LEXINGTON, Va., June 2 (AP) D. Raymond Snively of the Washington and Lee Univer sity's Class of 1923 has justre ceived his degree. He failed a final exam in geology half a century ago, and left school without graduating. The 73 yearold Mr. Snively, a success ful businessman, made up his mind to get a degree at last month's 50th reunion of his old class. He borrowed a geology book, studied at home in Ha gerstown, Md., and took the test again. This time he passed and received a bachelor of sci ence degree.

title: New over
description: There's a showdown coming up at the ClayburnDurant can ning complexa monolith nes tled amid endless reaches of Appalachian kitchen garden. Company president Stull Clay burn (a drunk) wants to carry on with his insensitive wheel ing and dealing. Cousin Jon Clayburn, an idealistic vice president, thinks it's high time the firm became more socially conscious. When an oldtime employe dies  possibly from eating turnip greens treated with an experimental spray Stull and Jon lock horns over company policy.

title: Women Run a Prosperous Banking Business in Bergen
description: RIVER EDGE  Women, says Mrs. Mildred J. Evans, seem to possess the in tuitiveness that some men do not, and they are inclined to a softsell approach to which it is more difficult to say no.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: In the midst of the cur rent furor over improving the nation's private pensior system, one very important fact has been ignored: majority of industrial work ers in this country do not participate in any private pension plan at all. They are entirely dependent upon Social Security benefits for retirement income.

title: Yanks Set Back Angels, 20, As Peterson Outpitches Ryan
description: Skill was the theme of the 20 victory the New York Yankees scored over the Cali fornia Angels at Yankee Sta dium yesterday, a quiet demon stration of finesse for 28,000 people on hand (of whom 14,000 were children admitted under various programs) and a na tional television audience.

title: Safety Squads Offering Free Boating Courses
description: MONTVALENew Jersey is a land of many waters, both fresh and salt. Included are more than 800 lakes and ponds, at least 100 rivers and creeks, 1,400 miles of trout Streams and 125 miles of Atlantic shore.

title: Summer Guest Is First on Grass
description: Summer Guest tried the turf for the first time and she ac quitted herself splendidly at Belmont Park yesterday. The Rokeby Stable representative, the only filly in the race, cap tured the $57,000 Bowling Green Handicap by 1 lengths over Red Reality, with Astray next in the field of nine.

title: Jankunis Jumps 7 Feet To Set P.S.A.L. Mark
description: Bill Jankunis waited five hours to high jump yesterday, had trouble with a blood blister on his left heel, and the cross bar at Downing Stadium had a twoinch sag.

title: Karolaska Glacier, A Great Pyrenees, Is Best in Show
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., June 2 Ch. Karolaska Glacier, a 5year old Great Pyrenees owned by Mrs. Edith K. Smith of Taunton, Mass., and handled by Robert Forsyth of Southbury, Conn., won its seventh best in show yesterday at the 56th annual dog show and obedience trials of the Ladies' Dog Club held at the Stigmatine Seminary. Mrs. Francis V. Crane of Marathon, Fla., judged the final group.

title: WISCONSIN SCORES SWEEP IN ROWING
description: SYRACUSE, June 2It was On Wisconsin over and over again at the national inter collegiate rowing champion ships today. The three Badger eightoared crews  varsity, second varsity and fresh menall were victors and thus completed a sweep for Coach Randy Jablonic's athletes. It was the first sweep of the In tercollegiate Rowing Associa tion regatta since Pennsylva nia's three victories in 1968.

title: School Shopping
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.Tom Fay, the 34yearold prin&ipal of the Donald J. Meyer Elementary School, lounged in an office chair and talked about the kind of year it has been. The subject was of unusual interest because Mr. Fay's school has been involved in a limited experiment with the controversial concept called educational vouchers.

title: Saigon Accuses Communists Of Blasting Ammunition Dump
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2 (Reuters)  The South Vietnamese Government ac cused the Communists today of blowing up one of the coun try's biggest ammunition dumps, which was destroyed in a series of explosions that rocked Saigon yesterday.

title: The Primary Vote: How It Works
description: TRENTONFor the first time in a primary for state officials, New Jersey voters will be able to cast ballots Tuesday for either Democratic or Re publican candidates without declaring their party affiliation until they actually go to the polls.

title: View From Bridge Improved
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 (UPI)Irhe officials of the San Francisco  Oakland Bay Bridge have removed a halfmile of pipe from the top of the bridge's north railing to give motorists a better view as they approach San Francisco. They said that when the bridge was built in 1936, the railing did not block the view. Cars are now de signed lower to the ground.

title: EDMUND J. PICKUP
description: GLEN COVE, L.L, June 1 Edmund J. Pickup, a lawyer in Brooklyn for more than 70 years, died yesterday in Com munity Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived at 34 Pear sail Avenue.

title: Space Firms Turn Talents To Energy Conservation
description: BETHPAGE, L. I.The techniques of manned space flight are finally coming down to earth.

title: Elmont Torah Celebration
description: ELMONT, L. I.It took Rabbi Samuel Rubenstein, a Hebrew scribe in the Bronx, 1,920 hours to two Sepher Torans, parchment scrolls of the Old Testament, for the Elmont Jewish Center.

title: Parsons College Closes; Last Degree Is Awarded
description: FAIRFIELD, Iowa, June 2 (UPI)Parsons College handed out its last degrees and closed its doors today, giving up in a looing battle against its reputa tion and heavy expenses.

title: Sports Today
The Surgeon as an Artist
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I. Nearly a qtarter of a cen tury of travel in this coun try and around the world is reflected in an art show that will ran at the C.W. Post College of Long Island University here through June 20.

title: Clare Boothe Luce
description: HONOLULUThirty  six Presidents have preceded Mr. Nixon. Many of them have made miscalculations, mis judgments and errors. A regrettable number have lied to the people about matters of the gravest concern to the nation. And sometimes these errors and lies have led to national disasters, such as Pearl Harbor, and the Bay of Pigs which Ied the whole world to the brink of nuclear war. Some Presidents have also been involved in unsavory private scandals. Some have made themselves and their families rich through White House connections. And some have been accused, both in the press and on the hustings, of unethical and illegal deeds, such as smearing and sabotaging their political oppo nents, and stealing elections.

title: OffDuty Officer Slain in Bar Holdup
description: A 23yearold offduty police man was shot and killed yes terday morning by one of three men who tried to hold up a bar and grill near Lincoln Center. The robbers escaped.

title: No Time To Get It Over With
description: Vice President Agnew and Senator Ed Gurney of Florida have expressed the wish that all the facts of the Watergate subversion could be rapidly brought out, so that the case might soon be over and the Government could go back to governing as usual. That is neither possible nor desirable, as these two Republicans must know.

title: CRITICS ANSWERED BY YEVTUSHENKO
description: MOSCOW, June 2Yevgeny Yevtushenko, in a recent poem, has retorted to old literary friends who have accused him of seeking political safety at their expense.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Noting that one of his op ponents for the Democratic mayoral nomination had gained most of the formal union sup port, Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal yesterday defended his relationship with organized labor in the city.

title: NEW FEDERALISM PRESSED IN TEXAS
description: FORT WORTH, June 2The regional council of 156 local units of government for this urban region of 2.5million is gearing up to become a fore runner in the new Federalism concept of increasing the power and responsibility of local elected officials.

title: Blacks May Gain More Seats on Council
description: The lineup of City Council candidates in the primary elec tion tomorrow indicates that blacks may gain several seats on the newly reapportioned Council, but that Puerto Ricans are not likely to fare as well.

title: Westchester Voters Focus on CountryExecutive Job
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 2A highstakes political contest in Westchester County reaches a crucial stage Monday, when Re publican voters select a can didate for next fall's County Executive race.

title: MISS EVERT GAINS FRENCH NET FINAL
description: PARIS, June 2 (AP)  The matchup that had been antici pated for, the women's singles final of the rainplagued French open tennis championships be came a reality today when Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia scored semifinal victories.

title: Staten Island
description: The prospect was Inviting: Eleven square miles of land, within New York City, to be redeveloped and five square mues more to be reclaimed from the sea. At a cost of $6.5billion, 420,000 new res idents could be added, in style, to Staten Island's pop ulation of about 300,000.

title: Miss Neale Wed to Naval Officer
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., June 2Miss Patricia Wesley Neale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lewis Neale of Mount Kisco, and Lieut. (jg.) Daniel Good Van Chief Jr., U.S.N.R. were married here this afternoon. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Chief of Esmont, Va.

title: Public Workshops Set On Long Island Sound
