description: Public workshops which will give people an oppor tunity to discuss current is sues about Long Island Sound are being held in conjunction with the Long Island Sound Regional Study.

title: Paul Simon, Alone, Looks Back Briefly But Is on His Way
description: Right through the nineteen sixties it was always Simon AND Garfunkel, together and telling it. And now it was only Paul Simon, whitesuited and guitarcarrying, who walked onstage at Carnegie Hall Fri day, in his first attempt to solo for a New York audience.

title: Marta Heimark Is Wed to Lewis Staples
description: WAYNE, Pa., June 2Miss Marta Elizabeth Heimark, daughter Of Capt. Jacob Vin cent Heimark, U.S,N., retired, and Mrs. Heimark of St. Da vid's, Pa., was married here this afternoon in St. David's Episcopal Church, to Lewis Fillmore Staples, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert inns Staples of Villanova. The Rev. Rich ard W. Hess performed the ceremony.

title: Euratom Buys Uranium, With Processing in U.S.
description: BRUSSELS, June 2 (AP) Furatrom, the Common Mar ket's organization for the peace ful uses of nuclear energy, has announced its first purchase of natural uranium for enrichment in the United States and use in Europe.

title: 16 HITS BY GIANTS DOWN PHIS, 117
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June (AP)Tito Fuentes and Bobbl Bonds ripped three hits apiece today, leading the San Fran cisco Giants to an 117 uphil victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Californians Plan a Forest In Memory of War Dead
description: LOS ANGELES, June 2 (UPI)  A living memorial to the 6,000 Californians killed in Vietnam will rise over the cen turies in the Angeles National Forest.

title: Miss Hoffman Plans Nuptials
description: TUCSON, Ariz., June 2 Prof. and Mrs. Junius Hoff man have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Prudence Hoffman, to Dr. Henry Phelps Gates, son of Mrs. Roland Fisher of South Laguna, Calif., and the late Henry Phelps Gates. A wedding Aug. 25 in Chapel Hill, N. C., is planned.

title: The coming, not of a messiah, but of the messiah
description: For a small mountain of reasons, this book ensnares one of the most extraordinarily daring ideas to in habit an American novel in a num ber of years. For one thing, it is that risky devising, dreamed of only by the Thomas Manns of this world, a serious and vastly conceived fic tion bled out of the theological imagination. For another, it is clearly an American novel  altogether American, despite its Jewish particu larity: it is not so much about the history of the Jews as it is about the idea of the New World as haven. This by itself would not be uncom mona fundamental mythological source of the American literary im agination is precisely this grappling with America as haven, whether only as a ruined and bungled one. But In the Days of Simon Stern posits something else: America as a refuge not simply for the historical ly maimed, but for the messiah him self.

title: Shape of Things to Come
description: Few concepts have been as emotionally held by Amer icans as the belief that a man's right to do what he wants with his own land is permanent, absolute ana hallowed by history. In fact, however, private land has been subjected through the centuries to confiscation, seizure by right of eminent domain, denial of air and subsurface rights and regulation by town zoning boards. Now, in the cogent report of a Federal task force on land use, the very theory of a landlord's right to arbitrary control over his property is challenged and the way paved for its longoverdue modification.

title: W.T. Grant Estate Sold
description: The 12.3acre Connecticut estate of the late W. T. Grant, founder of the department store chain, has been sold to an anonymous buyer for $1,325,000. The price is be lieved to be the highest ever paid for a single residence in the affluent community of Greenwich.

title: TV's Bargain Disks Are They Worth It?
description: DON'T expect the Mills Brothers, former Mon kee Mickey Dolenz, Mitch Miller, Cornel Wilde and Enzo Stuarti to ever be in the same place the same time. Expect, hew ever, to find them appearing backtoback on local tele vision, each the star of a low budget, hardsell commercial hawking a mailorder bargain package of newly pro grammed old recordings. These commercials have con verted local television into the world's largest bargain basement word store.

title: LARSEN SHOWS UP FOR SOVIET CHESS
description: LENINGRAD, June 2Bent Larsen showed up in Leningrad last night, ending fears that he might boycott the interzonal chess tournament, slated to be gin here tomorrow. The Danish grandmaster has not withdrawn the protest he has lodged with Dr. Max Euwe, president of the world chess organization, but he acknowledged that the chance to qualify for a match with the world champion, Bob by Fischer, was too important to forgo.

title: Florida's Accessible Billionaire
description: SINGER ISLAND, Fla.  Surrounded by the clatter of dishes and the cluck of con versation, John D. MacArthur, quite possibly the nation's most accessible billionaire, runs his real estate and in surance empire from a cor ner table in the coffee shop of the Colonnades Hotel here.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Two law firms have leased almost 100,000 square feet of office space in the R.C.A. Building, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. The center said the 20year leases called for an aggregate rent of approxi mately $18.5million.

title: Duran Retains Title, Stops Aussie in 8th
description: PANAMA CITY, June 2 (AP)Roberto Duran of Pan ama retained his World Box ing Association lightweight title tonight by stopping Hec tor Thompson of Australia in the eighth round of a sched uled 15round fight.

title: dh: Robinson Hot in Clutch
description: Frank Robinson of the California Angels, who has been turned into a designated hitter by a series of leg ailments, isn't one of the best hitting dh's, but he has been one of the most productive.

title: Executive Blues
description: Success is to be who I am. It's doing your own thing.

title: Guards Held Hostage
description: CRANSTON, R. I., June 2 (AP)A small group of in mates in the Adult Correction al Institutions held three guards hostage for about half an hour today while protesting prison conditions. The guards were released and received treatment for bruises.

title: WALTER N. GREAZA, ACTOR, 76, IS DEAD
description: Walter N. Greaza, a veteran character actor of stage, radio and television, died Friday in the Kew Gardens (Queens) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Apparel manufacturers have had little use for non woven fabrics other than those used for interlinings. However, this may soon change as a result of recent developments that can ad vance nonwovens to the face of a garment.

title: INDEPENDENT PAPERS URGED AT COLLEGES
description: A national study of the col lege and university press has recommended the financial and administrative separation of student newspapers from their institutions.

title: Health Unit Names Chinese
description: GENEVA, June 2The World Health Organization has an nounced the appointment of Dr. pediatrician, as one of its five Chang Weihsun, a Chinese assistant directors general. Dr. Chang was a resident in pediat rics at New York's Bellevue Hospital and instructor of pedi atrics at the New York Uni versity School of Medicine from 1944 to 1949. He returned to Peking in 1949.

title: India Orders Aviation Inquiry
description: NEW DELHI, June 2 (UPI) India's Minister of Tourism and Civil Aviation, Prince Karan Singh, today ordered a review of the working of navigational and landing aids at India's four international airportsat New Delhi, Bombay, Calcutta and Madras. The action came 48 hours after the crash of an Indian Airlines jet Thursday night near Palam Airport in New Delhi in which 48 people vire killed.

title: Alice in Mondrianland
description: IF you've never heard of the painter Alice Trum bull Mason, you're in good company. Mason, who died in 1971, had a posi tive talent for obscurity: the bare mention of her name occurs in only a few studies of contemporary American art, and the current show of her work at the Whitney Mu seum has come as a surprise to most of the art world.

title: The B.S. Factor
description: The Theory and Technique of Faking It Big in America. By Arthur Herzog. 218 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $6.95.

title: Melissa Ricci Is Wed
description: In the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyte rian Church yesterday after noon, Miss Melissa Ricci, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard V. Ricci of Port Chester, N.Y., became the bride of John McEntire Stew art 3d, son of Mrs. Kingsley Swan Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late John M. Stewart. The Rev. Norman Stanton performed the cere mony.

title: State Turns On Its First Public Television Network
description: TRENTON  New Jersey's first network television sys tem came into being last night, when the state's Pub lic Broadcasting Authority began transmitting live col or telecasts from its two new UHF noncommercial stations in Northern New Jersey.

title: Miss Henning To Be Bride
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 2 The engagement of Miss Patricia Anne Henning to David William Cochran, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Cochran of Osterville, Mass., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Valen tine Henning. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: Turkish Nesting Place Olt Ibis to Be Preserve
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 2 (Reuters)The World Wild life Fund has allocated $250, 000 for the protection of one of the world's rarest birds, the baldheaded ibis, whose only nesting place is the small southeastern Turkish town of Birecik.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Bunch of them oil slickers from down in Houston been by here. They had some sad news. Said, Old Timer that's their idea how you come on as real downhome folks, callin' a man Old Timer, like they seen Gary Cooper do in the Paramount films 35, 40 years ago. They figger, Hell, these people that never been to Houston don't know nothing about oil. They must be plumb ignorant about the way real people talk nowadays, so we'll just nat urally have to talk to 'em real dumb, the way Gary Cooper used do.

title: Lawrence Fahey Weds Diane Davis
description: BAY HEAD, N. J., June 2 Miss Diane Davis, daugh ter of Mrs. Gerald Davis of Bay Head and Morristown, was married here this after noon to Lawrence Cooper Fahey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Wilbroad Fahey of St. Paul. The Rev. Hughes Gar vin and the Rev. James Brewster Arnold, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony in All Saints Epis copal Church.

title: The U.N.Onward and Upward
description: WASHINGTONThe United Nations is suffering from declining interest and support on the part of the United States. Indeed, there is a great danger the United States could be responsible for the unraveling of the U.N. unless we recommit ourselves to making more effective and more efficient.

title: Television
description: ELEVEN months ago, from July 6 through 8, Man hattan was host to a first anniversary Public Access Celebration, an information event pro duced by individuals, video groups, the New York State Council on the Arts, city agencies and Sterling and Teleprompter, the two cable companies holding franchises to service the borough. Despite some publicity and much energy, the event probably went unnoticed by most New Yorkers. That is the problem with public access. Few people know it exists, and still fewer know what it is about.

title: Miss Hewson Will Be Bride Of C. C. Marboe
description: CHESTER, N. J., June 2 Mr. and Mrs. William Beres ford Hewson of Chester and Nantucket, Mass., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Campbell Hewson, to Charles Chostner Marboe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fenton Mar boe of State College, Pa. A late summer wedding is planned.

title: OLDTIME AUTOS AUCTIONED ON L.I.
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., June 2A man raised his hand and the woodtrimmed 1947 Chrysler Town and Country convertible, which only recently had crossed the line from old to antique, was his.

title: Troubled Youngsters Are Now Offered Crisis Homes
description: Mazy Ann, a 17yearold high school junior in a cen tral Bergen County com munity, came to the atten tion of the police when she was the victim of an at tempted rape. It quickly be came apparent to the police that her family situation was totally unsatisfactory.

title: Public Service Directory Is Put Out by Hempstead
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.A new telephone directory of gov ernmental agencies is being offered to the public by the town's Public Information Office here.

title: Diagramless, 19 by 19
P.O.W.'S HAD LIST OF PROHIBITIONS
description: SAN DIEGO, June 2 (AP) The North Vietnamese captors of American servicemen were adamant. No writing on the pri son walls. No noise. No dis courtesy to the guards.

title: The Good Word: To Reviewers, to Review
description: The author chokes as the wheel spins. Somewhere he will be called one of our finest since . .. in his great est yet, and somewhere else he will be called a tasteless baboon but where? If the blow strikes in The Hoboken News, he may be spared in The Times Book Review. His luck either way is capriciously rationed. What he will not be called anywhere is probably what he isour most middling author in his most middling achievement.

title: IDLE DICE WINNER IN DEVON FINALE
description: DEVON, Pa., June 2Idle Dice won the open jumper championship at the Devon horse show tonight in a Frank Merriwell finish before 10,000 spectators.

description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: A Money Machine Attracts Investors
description: Moving up the East Coast from Merida and across the nation from California, the condominium has tip Wed into the metropolitan area and Nettled down for a long stay.

title: SPORTSMEN'S PARK PLANNED IN MAINZ
description: AUGUST, Ma., June 2The International Telephone am Telegraph Corporation has filed plans with the Land Use Regulation Commission to de velop a sportsmen's park in areas in northwestern Maine owned by the, conglomerate.

title: Patricia M. Murtagh Married To Edward T. Byrne, Student
description: Miss Patricia Mary Mur tagh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Murtagh of Long Beach, L. I., and niece of Justice John M. Murtagh, of the State Supreme Court was married here yesterday afternoon to Edward Thomas Byrne. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald T. Byrne of Douglaston, Queens.

title: MARYLAND TAKES LACROSSE CROWN
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 2  The University of Maryland rallied and won the National Collegiate Athletic Association lacrosse championship in over time today, beating Johns Hop kips, 109. The deciding goal came on a 15yard bounceshot in the second extra period by Frank Urso, a freshman of Brentwood, L. I.

title: Gallagher, Fleming Reach Eastern Junior Net Final
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 2Buddy Gallagher of Larchmont, N. Y., and Peter Fleming of Chatham, N. J., reached the final of the East ern junior spring tournament today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Text of Statement by King Constantine Delivered in Rome
description: ROME, June 2Following is the text of King Constan tine's prepared statement read in English:

title: Frelinghuysen: Moderate Republican
description: MORRISTOWN  Alert visitors to the local office of Representative Peter H. B. Frelinghuysen may notice a 19thcentury colorprint hang ing on one wall. Beneath the faded framed portrait, a cap tion proclaims boldly: Hur rah! Hurrah! The country's risen'/ For Henry Clay and Frelinghuysen.

title: Carol Isenberg to Be Wed July 15
description: NEWTON, Mass., June 2 Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Isen berg have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Isenberg, to Eldon R. Clingan, son of Eugene Clingan of El Paso, Tex., and Mrs. John Bennett of Benicia, Calif.

title: Blackshear Is Triple Winner In Jersey School Track Meet
Is Carol Burnett Forever?
description: WHEN a gaggle of writ ers for The Carol Burnett Show won a group award at the Emmy presentations in Holly wood a few weeks ago, one of the funnymen waded to the microphone through a pool of wisecracks and said simply, I'd like to thank the world for Carol Burnett. It was a generous tribute to the nation'sperhaps the world's funniest female clown, a lady for Whom millions of TV viewers regularly give thanks in the form of hefty Nielsens and fanatical loyalty. A Bur nett fan is forever, but is Carol?

title: In praise of Mr. Nixon
description: The Retreat of American Power is the best account yet written of the foreign policy of President Nixon and Henry Kissinger in their first four years together. Henry Brandon, chief American correspondent of the London Sunday Times since 1950, has the ability, enjoyed by few na tive American newspapermen, to win and hold the confidence of American Presidents, Secretaries of State, and other leaders. As early as the Tru man Administration, he was one of the three or four journalists trusted and respected by Secrettiry of State Dean Acheson. Few writers have had Brandon's access to the President and to Henry Kissinger (and few Ad ministrations have had President Nixon's access to Brandon). The re sult is a book organized around a series of revealing and exclusive in terviews. Sometimes his sources are identified and quoted directly. At other times they are anonymous and thus not subject to verification. The overall impression, however, is of unusual authenticity.

title: New I.L.G.W.U. Accord Gives Bonuses to 40,000
description: New agreements reached last week in the women's coat and suit industry include an unus ual feature providing for semi annual work bonuses for the 40,000 covered workers.

title: Weather Station Opened in Queens
description: It reminds me of Dis neyland, Karl Johnannes D en, associate director of the National Weather Service, said one day last week as he stood alongside a brightly colored building just com pleted at Fort Totten, the Government installation oc cupying a small peninsula that juts into Little Neck Bay north of Bayside, Queens.

title: Congress & Cambodia
description: Like a long sea swell that is hardly noticed until it gets close to shore, the yearslong movement to reassert Con gress's powers on war and peace and force the President to get the United States out of Indochinahas crested with gathering speed.

title: Fink's 4th Goal in Two Games Gives Cosmos 11 Tie With Stars
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 2 The New York Cosmos knew what the problem was in to night's 11 tie with the St. Louis Stars at Hofstra Stadium before 5,635 paying fans, but they ad mitted they had no solution to it.

title: POW's
description: Only five days after President Nixon threw a joyous red, white and blue gala banquet to heap honor on the 600 or so men who made it back from enemy prison camps in Indochina, the facade of heroic endurance began to crack.

title: New Jersey
description: TRENTON  There seemed no let up from the charges of corruption that have turned New Jersey's Re publican primary election for Gover nor into a nightmare for the two candidates.

title: Pragmatism to Be Emphasized Ina New Program at Chicago U.
description: CHICAGO, June 2Pragma tism will be emphasized in a new undergraduate liberal arts program that will begin this fall at the University of Chi cago.

title: New State Plan Would Emphasize Mass Transit Over Highways
description: ALBANY, June 2 (AP)The state released a master trans portation plan today that pro jects declining expenditures on rural highways and increased expenditures on urban mass transit.

title: Mating of Zoo's Pandas In 6 Months Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI)Officials of the Na tional Zoo are predicting that the two giant pandas given to the United States last year by China will mate within six months.

title: 2 Hijackers Flee Colombian Airliner in South America With $50,000 Ransom
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 2 (AP) Two masked gunmen who set hijacking records put a mysterious end to their three day odyssey by sneaking off the commandeered Colombian airliner and disappearing in South America today with $50,000.

title: Fulbright Urges Rogers To Review Athens Policy
description: WASHINGTON, June 2Sen ator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Foreign Relations Com mittee, called on Secretary of State William P. Rogers today to take advantage of the aboli tion of the Greek monarchy to order a full review of American policy toward the militaryled Government of Greece.

title: 41 ON TOURIST BUS HURT AT ARLINGTON
description: ARLINGTON, Va., June 2 (AP)At least 41 tourists were injured today when a section of their tourmobile overturned on a hilly curve in Arlington Na tional Cemetery, the United States Park Police said.

title: Muncey, No Longer No. 1, Will Try Harder
description: The question this year in unlimited hydroplanes is: Can Bill Muncey come back? Last year the question was: Can Bill Muncey be stopped? He wasn't much last year winning every race except one in the Atlas Van Lines boat, but this year Muncey was beaten in the opening race at Miami after an extra curricular effort in an outboard had resulted in several broken ribs.

title: the traveler's world
description: IF you are motoring around the coun try and you feel cut off from the homefolks and worried about what is going on back at the office, cry HELPS and Stuckey's will answer. Not with a pecan praline or a chewy nut roll but with the reassurance that no one is trying frantically to reach you or with the telephone number of who ever is trying to find youout there on the Interstates.

title: Lisa Eversley Bennett Is Bride Of McKinley Campbell McAdoo
description: RADNOR, Pa., June 2St. Martin's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Lisa Eversley Bennett, daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth Chew Bennett of Radnor and Edwin Eversley Bennett of Manchester, Vt., to McKinley Campbell McAdoo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Campbell McAdoo of Bryn Mawr. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard Hess.

title: Park Service Will Open Alcatraz to Public This Fall
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 Alcatraz, once referred to as America's Devil's Island, will he opened to the public about Nov. 1 for the first time since it was ceded by Mexico to the United States in 1848, the National Park Service announced here this week.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WEST ORANGE  When Walter Bauman, for 30 years a wholesale jeweler, went into the retail jewelry busi ness six years ago, he did not raise his prices.

title: 4 Mayoral Candidates Score Arab Arms Deal
description: The four Democratic may oral candidates yesterday issued statements critical of a proposed sale of American arms to Kuwait and Saudi Arabia.

title: A Quartet Bridges Generations' Gaps
description: WESTFIELDFifteen cha ruses, each representing chap ters in the MidAtlantic Dis trict of the Society for the Preservation and Encourage ment of Barber Shop Quartet Singing in America, Inc., per formed yesterday at Conven tion Hall in Asbury Park.

title: 2 Car Lovers With Vintage Tastes
description: ROSLYN, L. I.When Don Gilbert and John Linhardt drive through town in one of their eight Cadillacs or the creamcolored Lincoln, pedestrians wave, motorists honk, and oldtimers smile in recognition, for the long, gleaming Caddies date from 1937, to 1948, and the Lin coln, with its lush leather interior, is a '38 model.

title: 2 QUESTIONS OPEN IN ELLSBERG CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, June 2  A Los Angeles County grand jury will open an investigation Tues day into the breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist, and it has two main questions to explore: Who knew about the breakin before and after it happened, and was their conduct criminal?

title: Cards Get a Bad Deal in N. F. L. Schedule
description: Of the six new head coaches in the National Football League, Don Cory ell of the St. Louis Cardinals faces the most difficult in augural season. Coryell comes from the college ranks, San Diego State, with only a skeletal knowledge of the pro personnel. He is of fensive minded, unlike most pro coaches, and in herits herits a team whose prior coach, Bob Hol way was all for defense. Hollway was in the process of restructuring the Cardinal defensive unit and had it torn down but not rebuilt when he was discharged by the owner, Bill Bidwill. Fur thermore, Coryell's Cardinals will be playing what appears to be the most difficult schedule of any of the 26 N.F.L. teams.

title: Hospital for Veterans Is Being Modernized
description: EAST ORANGEThe Vet erans Administration Hospi tal here is undergoing a mod ernization and expansion program that will cost $1.8 million.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
The Passaic Is Proving A Popular Water Tap
description: LITTLE FALLSDespite a Department of the Interior study that listed the Passaic River as one of the nation's 10 mostpolluted tributaries, a growing number of commu nities in four northern coun ties are becoming customers of the Passaic Valley Water Commission, which uses the river for half its water sup ply.

title: DROPOUTS PLAGUE THE AIR ACADEMY
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, June 2The United States Air Force Academy is in trouble.

title: Colleen Kade Wed
description: MANHASSET, L. L, June 2 Miss Colleen Maria Kade, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Brendan Kade, was married here this afternoon to William Francis Murphy 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murphy Jr. of Sands Point. The Rev. Clement Greenan, chaplain at the Canterbury School in New Milford, Conn., performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Pittsburgh Newspaper Pact
description: PITTSBURGH, June 2 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Press Com pany, publishers of the daily and Sunday Pittsburgh Press, and Printing Pressmen's Union No. 9 reached agreement on a new oneyear contract today, averting a threatened strike. A spokesman for the Scripps Howard newspaper said the pact was reached one hour and 20 minutes after a 4:30 P.M. deadline. He said that details of the contract were being withheld. In addition to the Press, the company prints the morning PostGazette.

title: The New York Times Book Review
description: AFTER CLAUDE, by Iris Owens. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $6.95.) Too bad about Harriet's execrable manners, but she is a remarkably neurotic and unforgettable heroine with a selfconscious, lacerating wit.

title: The President of the Live Oak Society Has a Waistline That Measures 35 Feet
description: THE one thing in her young life that Dolores Owen is most proud of is Elemore Morgan. Dolores is a tall, pretty, brunette librarian who wears huge Riviera eyeglasses and a stylish skyblue pants suit, and she abso lutely glows when she talks about Ele more Morgan. And well she might. Do lores is the person most responsible for the fact that Elemore Morgan is still alive.

title: Home Repair Clinic
description: Questions from readers about home repair problems should be addressed to: Home improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N. Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered in this column.

title: Zoning Rule On an Arena Put to Court
description: MOUNT HOLLYA com plex zoning dispute that may determine whether southern New Jersey gets a multi milliondollar sports develop ment is scheduled to come to trial in Superior Court here on June 11.

title: News From Nowhere
description: Americans now get most of their national and inter national news from televi sion, but of the thousands of newsworthy events taking place in the world every day, only a handful can be shown on a halfhour program. How TV journalists select what is to be shown thus determines what the public learns, and there are at least three theories about their selection procedures. The official journalistic theory is that events are selected by their importance. Another theory, popular with the White House before the Watergate scandal, proposes that events are chosen mainly to satisfy the allegedly leftist bias of the TV journalists. A third theory, favored by social scientists, is that network priorities encour age journalists to select those events that can be covered most easily and cheaply and that will attract a large audi ence.

title: U.S. Policy Giving Indians. Job Preference, Is Voided
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 2 (AP)A panel of three Fed eral judges says that Bureau of Indian Affairs policy giving Indian employes preferential treatment violates the United States Civil Rights Act.

title: How Crews Finished
description: VARSITY PAIRS Championship

title: Photo Show to Open on L.I.
description: UNIONDALE, LI.  A crystal clear picture of pho tography todayand of to morrow  awaits enthusi asts at the International Pho to Show, at the Nassau Vet erans Memorial Coliseum next Friday through Sunday.

title: Soaring Prices in Europe Dissuading U. S. Travelers
description: More Americans will fly to Europe this summer than ever before, but reports of soaring prices abroad are apparently keeping many others home this year.

title: HORACE MANN BARNARD SCHOOL
description: The master plan for the renovation of the Horace Mann Barnard School in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. The project, to be com pleted in 1975, will convert the two independ ent boys' schools into a coeducational elementry and secondary school. Wherever possible, existing structures are being renovated and up graded. The only new construction will be a threelevel building overlooking Van Cortlandt Park. Architects are Frost Associates, New York.

title: FRESH AIR CAMP GETS A CATWALK
description: Thanks to $11,000 that the American Conservation Associ ation has invested in a Dutchess County marsh, the birds and animals that live there and the 3,000 Fresh Air Fund campers who visit them will be looking at each other in a new way this summer.

title: May Is Not an R Month, but
description: FORTESCUEJust as gar deners throughout the state have been setting out their seedlings in anticipation of luscious vegetable and flower harvests later on in the year, Delaware Bay oystermen have been hard at work planting oysters and hoping for a continued revival of the oncealmostdead industry.

title: The Bullfight in Spain Is Mainly on the Wane
description: IN RECENT seasons, the matadors of Madrid have frequently enjoyed the sight of the stands erupting in a flurry of white handkerchiefs, a signal of enthusiastic approval urging the presidencia to award the man in the suit of lights an ear or a tail of the slain bull as a trophy of his skill and daring. But the handkerchiefs waved are not usually those of the local aficionados who have cannily seated themselves on the shady side of the bullring; the waving and the Ols ema nate, instead, from the sunny sidefrom the tourists from the Bronx, Bucking hamshire and Berlin who don't know a faena (the matador's performance) from a fandango.

title: Assembly Gets Coastline Bill
description: TRENTONA highly con troversial measure that would give the state the power to create an environmental sanc tuary along New Jersey's undeveloped coastline ap pears headed for more con troversy this Thursday. That is when the Assembly will convene for a oneday spe cial session.

title: Miss Jan Sherwood Is Married To Michael Garvan Cavanagh
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 2  Miss Jan Sherwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Sherwood, was married here this afternoon to Mich ael Garvan Cavanagh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Dun bar Cavanagh of East Nor walk.

title: Sumo Star in Japan Enjoys Namath Status
description: TOKYO, June 2  About 300 years ago, tradition here holds, a sumo wrestler named Akashi performed magnifi cently in the presence of the Japanese Emperor. When the match was over, the Emperor commanded that Akashi be brought before him.

title: Valiant Bret, $4.80, Takes $50,000 Brandywine Pace
description: WILMINGTON, Del., June 2 (AP)The Gray Brothers' Val iant Bret, driven by John Chap man, finished a neck ahead of Otaro Hanover, a 101 shot, and captured the $50,000 Battle of the Brandywine Pace at Brandy wine Raceway tonight.

title: Carrie's War
description: By Nina Bawden. 159 pp. Philadelphia and New York: J. B. Lippincott Company. $4.95. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: The Magic Moment
description: THE pleasure we take in drawing is not the same as the pleasure we feel in the pres ence of most painting and sculpture. No matter how finished or complete a draw ing may be, our response to it is a response to something contingent and not wholly concludedto an impulse that has not yet run its course and yet can never be repeated in quite the same may with quite the same re suits. Whether the draftsman addresses himself to an ob served subject or to an im aginary one, what he offers us is something piecemeal and provisionalwhat T. S. Eliot, in a similar context (in Four Quartets), called a raid on the inarticulate.

title: Abel Begins Final Term As Steelworkers President
description: PITTSBURGH, June 2 (UPI) I. W. Abel was sworn in yesterday for his third and last fouryear term as president of the United Steelworkers of America, pledging continued progress with the cooperation of the industry.

title: HONG KONG IS SPLIT ON DEATH PENALTY
description: HONG KONG, June 2 Pro gressive Western thinking that criminals should receive hu mane treatment has come into conflict here with traditional Chinese philosophy that they should be sternly punished.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: John N. Gish, president of the Gay Activists Alliance of New Jersey, lost a court bid to have a state law allow ing school boards to order psychiatric examinations for teachers declared unconstitutional. Judge Merritt Lane Jr. of Superior Court in Freehold ruled that school boards lack the expertise to decide if a teacher is mentally fit, and therefore can order the examination if they tell the teacher the reason for the order. Mr. Gish, an English and journalism teacher in Paramus since 1965, said his school board had ordered him to go to a psychiatrist only after he became president of the Gay Activists group last year.

title: Ives: American as Miami
description: ACHARLES IVES festival in Miami? The idea has raised eyebrows in the New England area, which considers the composer its prop erty, but the reaction to this should be Why not? Ives, as has been pointed out, is the quintessential American com poser and so belongs to the nation, and Miami was just smart enough to think of a festival in honor of the cen tennial of his birth before any other place did.

title: Coney Is. Residents Aided Rescue Craft
description: Several hundred residents of the Sea Gate section on the western tip of Coney Island waved flashlights and turned on all their house lights early yesterday to warn rescue craft away from dangerous rock for mations off treacherous Nor tons Point as they went to help the crews of two ships involved in the accident.

title: Music in Review
description: The New York Philhar monic's Promenades moved into a new realm of quality and distinction Friday night, when Aaron Copland ap peared as guest conductor and offered a program that was at once entertaining and strong in musical interest.

title: MORE ARE JAILED
description: ATHENS, June 2Four sen ior officers of the armed forces resigned today as the security police continued to arrest sup porters of King Constantine, who was deposed yesterday by the Greek Government.

title: Photography
description: OF all the experimenta tation being done with photosensitized fabric, that of Betty Hahn has amused me most consistently. Unlike the emotional remote ness of Bea Nettles and the intellectual obscurities of Keith Smith, Hahn's cloth pieces are simple, direct, and genuinely charming.

description: Thanks to $11,000 that the American Conservation Associ ation has invested in a Dutchess County marsh, the birds and animals that live there and the 3,000 Fresh Air Fund campers who visit them will be looking at each other in a new way this summer.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Because of Memorial Day, it was a fourday week in Wall Street. But the declines in the stock market were fullsized, and many brokers no doubt felt they might as well have extended their holiday through the whole week.

title: Stamps
description: A fret Communication with each Town will serve to ascertain this matter; and when once it appears beyond Contradiction, that we are united in Senti ments there will be a Con fidence in each other & a plan of Opposition will be easily formed, & executed with Spirit.

title: EDWARD POTTER
description: Edward Potter, a lawyer here for 63 years, died Wednes day in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 610 West 110th Street and hid his office at 20 Vesey Street.

title: Princeton Picks News Chief
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 2 Phillip K. Langan, 33 years old, sports information director at Ithaca College for the last six years, has been named Prince ton University's director of sports information. William C. Stryker, 46, who has held that post for 15 years, is assuming the newlycreated position of director of athletic relations.

title: In each story an impossible wish
description: By Bernard Malamud. 204 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $6.95.

title: My Young Years
description: Arthur Rubinstein, who ad mits to being 87 years old, who has been before the public for 80 of those years, who is one of the great pianists of the day, has delivered himself of half an autobiography. Half, for My Young Years brings his story to a midway point in World War I, when he was a youngster of 30.

title: Soviet Technology
description: MOSCOWHistory repeats itself is a hackneyed phrase, but it is un usually apt when it comes to describ ing the present course of Soviet American economic relations.

title: Chicago Tests Auto Fumes by Computers
description: CHICAGO, June 2Chicago became the first city in the nation yesterday to begin mandatory tests on the ek haust emissions of private motor vehicles.

title: Pro Track Makes Local Debut Wednesday Night
description: More than coincidence is be hind the International Track Association's decision to wind up its first professional track and field tour with a meet in Madison Square Garden Wednesday night.

title: TWINS TOP TIGERS IN 10TH ON HOMER
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 2 (AP)Joe Lis belted his sec ond home run of the season in the bottom of the 10th inning today, lifting the Minnesota Twins to a 32 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: Warning to Drunken Drivers
description: WASHINGTON  Under cover agents may be patrol ing local New Jersey bars and taverns this summer in an attempt to spot potential drunk drivers.

title: Vicki Staunton Is Wed
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 2  Miss Vicki Staunton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack L. Staunton of West port, formerly of New York, and John Giacci, son of Mr. and Mrs. Liberatto Giacci of New Haven, were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Gerald T. Devore in St. Luke's Roman Catholic Chapel. The couple plan to live at Trolley Crossing in Middletown, Conn.

title: BELGRADE TO CURB WORKER OUTFLOW
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 2  Yugoslavia, troubled by economic, social and political ills resulting from the mass migration of workers to the West, has drafted legislation to bring the movement under tight control.

title: Along the Revealing Road to Surabaja
description: The author, a marketing consultant, recently participated in a volunteer as sistance program in which he served as an executive for an Indonesian manu facturer in Surabaja, on the northern coast of Java. Like thousands of others, he commuted to work daily by car from Tretes, a mountain resort 36 miles away. The drive, made early in the morning when all Java seemed to he on the road, took an hour and a quarter about the same amount of time it takes to go the same distance on the Long Island Expressway during rush hour. Indonesia straddles the equator, so the sun and temperature rose early and swiftly.

title: State Quandary: Clean Air vs. the Auto
description: TRENTONState pollution control experts, under Fed eral orders to come up with a plan to achieve healthful air, were studying new pol lution figures last week in an attempt to find a way of cleaning the air without par alyzing New Jersey's trans portation.

title: 2YEAROLD DOG GETS HIS FIRST TOP AWARD
description: HUNTINGDON VALLEY, Pa., June 2A 2yearold miniature schnauzer owned and bred by Loretta and Louis Steinberg of Meadowbrook, a Philadelphia suburb, gained best  in  show honors today at the 47th an nual Huntingdon Valley Ken nel Club show. There were 1,294 dogs entered. It was the dog's first top award.

title: Deborah J. Parker Has Jersey Bridal
description: MORRISVILLE, Pa., June Miss Deborah Jean Parker, daughter of Dr. Paul Parker, a urologist, and Mrs. Parker of Yardley, was married here this afternoon to Richard Sherwood Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles For walk Williams of Chatham, N. J. The Rev. Dr. Clifford G. Pollock performed the ceremony in the First Presby terian Church.

title: Thirtyfive Years
description: West Germany and Czechoslovakia have finally agreed on a treaty to normalize their relations, another pre dictable step in the progress of dtente in Central Europe, and in fact overshadowed by the agreements Bonn had previously reached with Moscow and Warsaw and with the East German regime. But to those of an older generation familiar with the tortured history and travail of the Czech and Slovak peoples these past 35 years, this new BonnPrague accord must stir many bitter memories.

title: Trails Proposed in Denville
description: DENVILLE  Like many towns in Morris County, this one of 15,000 people is di vided into isolated communi ties by highways. A proposal has been made to join it to gether by another type of thoroughfare: a 25mile net work of nature trails.

title: The Kids Learn to Say Horse Before Mom or Dad
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 2  Another school day had ended and the flinty clipclip of hoofs striking pebbles sound ed at Ox Ridge Hunt Club as young riders guided their horses down dirt roadways that led to practice rings or open fields.

title: Thurmond Helps Launching
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., June 2 (UPI)Senator Strom Thur mond, Republican of South Carolina, helped today to launch the nuclear attack sub marine L. Mendel Rivers. He called the ship, named after the late South Carolina Representa tive, who was chairman of the House Armed Services Commit tee, and her sister ships, our most effective weapons to counter the Soviet submarine threat.

title: Badillo, Biaggi, Blumenthal, Beame
description: Even the candidates themselves, enveloped in the clouds of incense burned by their votaries, intoxi cated by the power of their own oratory, adept the art of selfdelusion, have not been able to re main unaware of the pestilential fog that hangs over the city on the eve of the Democratic mayoral primary. This cloaca( odor, compounded of a loss of confidence in government that has made Hellgate a branch office of Watergate, of the threat of con tinuing inflation, of the fear of loss of jobs, of the possibility of new disorders in the streets this sum mer, is unmistakable.

title: Richmond Prison Searched
description: RICHMOND, June 2 (AP) Guards and the state police began a march for weapons and other contraband at the Virginia Penitentiary today. The search was prompted by six stabbings, one fatal, since May 13.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: FARMERS OF IRAN RESISTING CHANGE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 15  Several months ago, 100 Hol stein cows arrived here from the United States as part of an effort by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi to spur cattle produc tion on Iran's farms. Within weeks, 90 per cent of their newborn calves died.

title: I Once Knew An Indian Woman
description: Simplicity isn't easy to find any more and neither is goodness. In this story they are stunningly ex emplified in the Indian woman of the title, Madame Dey.

title: Dismissals of Black Educators Called Result of Desegregation
description: ATLANTA, June 2Several leading education and civil rights organizations charged today that 6,000 black teachers and principals had been dis missed and thousands more had been demoted as 17 Southern and Border states grudgingly desegregated and merged dual school systems.

title: Home Improvement
description: AS warm weather arrives, more and more people will be turning their air conditioners  and this will account for high percentage of the ener gy used by homes and apart ments during the summer months.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO BOMB IN PHNOM PENH AREA
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 2 (UPI)American fighter bombers reportedly struck sus pected rebel positions 20 miles from Phnom Penh today. But the Cambodian command said rebel activity had generally diminished throughout the country.

title: WALL STREET:
description: Wall Street was filled with bulls last December. But among the galloping herd were a couple of skeptics, Edson Gould, and Charles F. O'Hay, who were interviewed at the time on their views.

title: Sally Craig Married
description: ST. PAUL, June 2  Miss Sally Craig and James O. Leet Jr., students at Colorado College, were married here today in the Macalaster United Church (Presbyterian Congregational) by the Rev. Dr. Paul Francis. The parents of the couple are Dr. and Mrs. David M. Craig and Mr. and Mrs. Leet of Rye, N.Y. Dr. Craig is a cardiologist here. Mr. Leet is executive vice president for marketing of Pan American World Air ways in New York.

title: Pennsylvania Asks State Court to Halt Gettysburg Tower
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 2 Pennsylvania's Attorney Gener al has asked the state's Su preme Court to enjoin the com pletion of a commercial obser vation tower overlooking the Civil War battlefield here.

title: Mets Shut Out by Padres Again, 30
description: SAN DIEGO, June 2The San Diego Padres, supposedly in shock over their sale to Washington, shut out the New York Mets for the second game in a row, 30, on the fivehit pitching of Clay Kirby tonight.

title: Ohio Judge Orders Hearing On Limiting of Gas Sales
description: CLEVELAND, June 2A hear ing will be held Thursday in Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court to determine whether there is an energy crisis.

title: Miss Mossien Has Nuptials
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 2 In St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Central Square this morning, Miss Mary Ann Mossien became the bride of Gerald Francis Hemmer. The Rev. John Phelan performed the cere mony, and the bridegroom's cousin, the Rev. John Dillon, celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Gordon Miller Jr. Weds Miss Hallett
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., June 2In the chapel of the Pres byterian ChurchontheGreen here this afternoon, Miss Christine Norris Hallett, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. E. Bruce Hallett, was married to Gordon Ivan Miller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller of Falmouth, Mass. The Rev. Thomas S. Mutch performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John Miller.

title: Future Social Events
Where the Action Isn't
description: GREAT NECK, L. I. Picture this: In ultrafashionable Brooklyn Heights, an 1836 townhouse one block from the water. On the third and fourth floors is a completely renovated apart ment. The lower level of the duplex has a large, square living room with a classic, working example of a fed eral fireplace, three huge bay win dows with a view of all the ships entering or leaving New York City, a high ceiling, architectural moldings and a parquet floor.

title: Watergate Committee Expected To Reassess Witness Schedule
description: WASHINGTON, June 2The Senate Watergate committee, which will resume public hear ings Tuesday after an 11day recess, is expected to meet pri vately beforehand in an effort to reach agreement on its schedule of witnesses.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: The same Professor Smith, contrary to common mod ern perceptions that his laissezfaire economics showed no concern for the working man, said that businessmen complain much about the bad effects of high wages in raising the price, and thereby lessening the sale of their goods, [but] they, say nothing concerning the bad effects of high profits.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: NOEL B. GER SON: (THE) PROD IGAL GENIUS Huge trees put out many branches, and one on which Balzac expected to earn his fortune ... was in the theatre. Victor Hugo's plays had, earned large sums of money and made him financially independent; what Hugo could do, Balzac ... could do.

title: Vanden Heuvel Bids Bar Group Invalidate Low Rating of Him
description: William J. vanden Heuvel called on the officers of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York yester day to invalidate the judgment of the association's executive committee, which gave him its lowest rating, not approved, for the office of Manhattan District Attorney last Thursday.

title: MOSCOW CAUTIONS ON LIBERALIZATION
description: MOSCOW, June 2An au thoritative Soviet commentator warned Russians this week that only naive people could expect close economic relations with the United States to be associated with a relaxation of political controls in the Soviet Union.

title: Horse Shows Crack Down on Drugs
description: DEVON, Pa., June 2The stringent drug rules that have been in effect for the past two years were strengthened even more today by the board of di rectors of the American Horse Shows Association.

title: India to Import More Grain As Hedge Against Drought
description: NEW DELHI, June 2 (Reuters) India has decided to import more grain to build stocks and to combat severe drought in parts of the country, the Minister of State for Food and Agricul ture said yesterday.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
800 McCrane Items Are Sold at Auction
description: RANCOCAS, N.J., June 2 Eight hundred items of house hold furniture, keepsakes and other possessions of Joseph M. McCrane Jr., the former State Treasurer who has been in dicted, were auctioned off today.

title: Trustees Back Antioch's President
description: Amid intimations of disaster for Antioch College, the trus tees of the troubled progressive institution announced yester day their continued but quali fied support for its president, James P. Dixon, and his ad ministration.

title: China Unearths Her Heritage
description: PARIS THE exhibition of Chinese art treasures that opened at the Petit Pa lais on May 8 is im portant not only for the splendor of its contents, but because it is likely to correct some widely held and very mistaken impressions about cultural activity under the People's Republic. Some of the most sensational discov eries such as the Han Dynas ty tombs with their now famous jade suits were made by peasants and sol diers at the height of the Cul tural Revolution between 1966 and 1969 when, to the outside world, it seemed as if the Chinese were not merely neglecting their artistic heri tage but turning it over to the destructive enthusiasm of the Red Guard.

title: Kennedy Says U.S. Aides Block Help for Vietnamese
description: WASHINGTON, June 2Sen ator Edward M. Kennedy, Dem ocrat of Massachusetts, said to day that officials in the United States Embassy in Saigon and in the State Department were blocking efforts to aid children in Vietnam who were victims of the war.

title: New Ranger Coach Taciturn Taskmaster
description: Larry Popein, the new coach of the Rangers, is a taciturn taskmaster who worked his way up through the ranks and now joins one of the National Hockey League's smoothest organiza tions.

title: Narcotics Officials To Hold a Parley
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Hun dreds of policemen, prose cutors and public officials are expected at the fourth annual convention of the New Jersey State Narcotic Enforcement Officers Asso ciation. The fourday session opens tomorrow.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Fun and Money in Fishing
description: When Roland Martin goes fishing, his wife, Mary, rarely complains, not only because she is an ardent angler her self and usually accom panies him, but also because he makes money at it.

title: Bridge
description: Suppose that the author of a comprehensive guide to bidding theory decided, for some strange reason, to begin with the commonest sequences and conclude his masterpiece with bids that might come up once in a bridge lifetime. His penultimate page might have a hand like this:

title: Antioch College
description: Antioch College in Yellow Springs, Ohio, has long been a symbol of academic liberalism. It has encouraged what its president, James P. Dixon, calls creative con flict, and it has calmly absorbed protest demonstrations over issues such as civil rights and the Viet nam war. It has been a leader in encouraging poorer students into higher education with financial aid.

title: Woman Digging Into Brooklyn Past
description: The world of rolling Brook lyn ferries, smoky primitive railroads, thundering preach ers and of visionaries who also had a keen sense of the value of the good Brooklyn earth, is unfolding now before the eyes of Jane Schwarz, an exLife magazine reporter on a trip to the past.

title: Greta Stapf Is Bride Of Douglas Waterman
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., June 2Miss Greta Stapf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Stapf of South Orange and Palm Beach, Fla., was mar ried here this morning to Douglas Lawrence Waterman, son of Warren Waterman of New York and Mrs. Joan Sabin of New York and Palm Beach. Judge E. Donald Stein brugge of Union County per formed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Music
description: GEORGE BERNARD SHAW once described the sound of the cello as resembling a bee buzzing in stone jug, or something like that. Which may have been an indicatibn of how the cello was played in those days (the early 1890's). But G.B.S. never heard Casals, or Feuermann, or Piatigor sky, or Rose, or Fournier, or Nelsova, or Rostropovich. And then, again, G.B.S. frankly admitted that he did not like the cello.

title: Smithsonian and Harvard Plan Astrophysics Center
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 2 (AP)The Smithsonian Institu tion and Harvard University have announced that they will establish a joint Center for As trophysics here to coordinate related research.

title: Helen Parkhurst, 86, Educator Who Devised Dalton Plan, Dies
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn., June 2Helen Parkhurst, educator, author and lecturer, died yes terday in the New Milford Hos pital. She was 86 years old.

title: PUBLIC INTEREST GETS NEW EDITOR
description: Those who like to keep in step with left and right may now consult a footnote in the current (spring) Public Interest.

title: City Council Districts
description: RICHMOND

title: Percy Calls on Nixon to Tell Truth About Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, June 2Sen ator Charles H. Percy chal lenged President Nixon today to tell the nation the whole truth about Watergate and it, allied abuses.

title: The Black Prince
description: Grudging admiration has long been a common response to Iris Murdoch's fiction. Most readers agree that she offers an unusual com pound of pleasures: ingenious story telling, elegant design, the provoca tions of myth and philosophy  so many pleasures, in fact, that it may seem ungrateful to ask for still more. But as Frank Kermode has put it: each of her books contains some where inside, the ghost of a major novel, and some people (although not Mr. Kermode) cannot quite for give her for failing to make the spirit flesh.

title: WINDTEX VICTOR ON JERSEY GRASS
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., June (AP)  Sol Epstein's Windtex and Augustin Stable's Mo Bay scored victories today in the twodivision Camden Handicap on closing day at Garden State Park.

title: It's Not What You Expect
description: If there were a single word to describe It's Not What You Expect, it might be modest. But modest only in the very best sense of that word: restrained, unpre tentious, calm, clear, unconfused. In the young adult genre, this is a rare set of attributes. Norma Klein, author of Mom, the Wolf Man and Me, is not only singularly adept at delineat ing fine female characters but knows she shouldn't impose Categorical Im peratives on her young readers. In deed her novels reveal that life is a mystery and a pretty good one, at that.

title: Alaskan Malamute Finds Place in Sun
description: MONTE CARLOA hardy breed from the frozen North brought waves of bravos and bravos on the sunny shores of the Riviera. It was an Alaskan malamute, a rar ity in this subtropic clime, who captured the hearts of the fanciers and a goodly collection of prizes at the recent Italian, French and Mon egasque dog shows. He was Ch. Glacier's Storm Kloud, C.D., an international champion with titles in the United States, Canada, Mexico and now Monaco, with legs in Italy and France.

title: Diagramless, 21 by 19
description: ACROSS

title: Darkest Before Dawn (Old Wall St. Adage)
description: Only when everything in Wall Street seems gloomiest will the stock market cease fallingor so goes an adage worshiped for years by some of the most sagacious ana lysts in the securities busi ness.

title: Miss Carpenter Bride of R. W. McKay
description: HARRISON, N. Y., June 2 Miss Elizabeth Ann Car penter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis W. Carpenter, was married here this after noon to Robert Woodrow McKay, son of Mr. and Mrs. John McKay of Erlanger, Ky. The Rev. Dr. Harold A. Bosley of Christ Church United Methodist in. Nevi York performed the cere mony at the Carpenter home.

title: Shift of Padres Could Be First in New Expansion
description: Although it isn't official yet, with lease to be settled and specific financing to be arranged, the San Diego Padres are scheduled to move to Washington next season, restoring major league baseball to the nation's capital after a twoyear absence, and giving Washington its first National League entry since 1899.

title: Junior environments
description: No backyard to romp in, no country side to explore, where's a city child go ing to go? Usually the answer is to his room. No wonder that children's rooms have become a center of atten tion. The need for both sleep and play space in city apartments is one reason for the growing popularity of the loft bed. That spacesaving solution has spawned environmental structures. Environmental structures? Yes. These are constructions that hold the bed and desk and counter and closets and storage shelves and drawers and slides and ladders and hiding places and... . They turn a room into an indoor play ground. Architect Douglas White, who enjoys designing these junior environ ments, says, Kids in the country can build a tree house or find a hiding place in the bushes by the creek. Not so for city children. These environ ments turn a conventional room intq a special place that can be identified by the child as totally his.

title: Magee Judge Named
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., June 2 (UPI)  Superior Court Judge William A. Ingram Jr. will pre side over the second murder trial of Ruchell Magee. Judge Ingram was appointed to the bench in Santa Clara County two years ago by Gov. Ronald Reagan. Magee is charged in the August, 1970, Marin County Courthouse shootout in which four persons, including a judge, died. Magee's retrial will start June 29.

title: Negron to Stay at Hunter
description: Hector Negron, a fouryear varsity wrestler at Hunter Col lege, has been named junior varsity wrestling coach for the 197374 season.

title: Are the Plumbers Worse Trouble Than the Leaks?
description: WASHINGTONIn disclosing his 1972 di rective to the Federal Bureau of Investigation to limit its probe of the Watergate breakin, President Nixon cited the need for secrecy for the protection of national security. He was concerned, he explained in his statement of May 23, lest the F.B.I. unwittingly compromise some unrelated operations of the Central Intel ligence Agency. Both in that statement and in his later remarks to American war prison ers at a gala White House dinner, he referred to a specific leak that, he said, seriously com promised the U.S. negotiating position in the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks, SALT.

title: CHANGES ARE DUE AT POLLING SPOTS
description: Trucks moved the last of New York City's 6,985 voting ma chines into polling places last week to prepare for a primary election tomorrow that should, according to the head of the Board of Elections, be reason ably smooth.

title: Investigations
description: WASHINGTONA misleading, rela tive air of calm last week replaced the storm of sensational disclosures in the Watergate scandals. Investiga tors all over Washington paused on high plateau of sworn statements, grand jury testimony and government documentsbut they were clearly re grouping, not retiring, and inexorably they were aiming higher into the Gov ernment in their search for abuses in the electoral process and the exercise of executive power.

title: OFFERS TO TALK
description: WASHINGTON, June 2  John W. Dean 3d has told the chief counsel of the Senate Watergate committee that he met alone and in small groups with President Nixon more than 40 times between late January and early April of this year, sources close to Mr. Dean said today.

title: Oil Spill From Ship Threatens to Close Brooklyn Beaches
description: The Manhattan and Coney Island beaches in Brooklyn are, expected to be closed today as a result of the oil spill from the tanker Esso Brussels, which was rammed by a freighter in the Narrow early yesterday.

title: Pine Hill Express Is Robbed Again
description: WIIIPPANYTwo masked men, each brandishing long barreled revolvers, held up the Pine Hill Express near here yesterday, robbed all the passengers on the train and blew up the Wells Fargo strong box.

title: Perry Belmont Duryea 3d, Son Of Legislator, Weds Miss Ryan
description: HAMDEN, Conn., June 2 Miss Wendy Lee Ryan was married here this afternoon to Perry Belmont Duryea 3d, whose father is Speaker of the New York State Assem bly. The Rev. Thomas R. Mis sett performed the ceremony in the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church.

title: Another American family
Susan Gray Is Fiancee Of Donald Townsend 3d
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 2  The engagement of Miss Susan Nichols Gray to Don ald L. Townsend 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Townsend Jr. of Riverside, has been an nounced by Mr. and Mrs. William Steele Gray Jr., parents of the future bride.

title: Club Helps Ulster Refugees
description: KEARNY,  Judging by the number of patrons in its upstairs barroom, the newly opened Four Provinces Tav ern on Johnson Avenue ap pears to be quite a money maker.

title: Change of Guard  At Crane House
description: MONTCLAIRThe Junior League here is ending a five year assignment at Crane House, where it has been demonstrating 18thcentury cooking to school children, college students and Girl Scouts.

title: TERRORIST IN IRAN KILLS U.S. ADVISER
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 2  A terrorist shot and killed an American military adviser out side his home today and then fled on a motorcycle driven byli a second man, the United States Embassy reported.

title: U.S. to Weigh Quitting International Tennis Unit
description: Should the United States Lawn Tennis Association withdraw from the Interna tional Lawn Tennis Federa tion?

title: News Summary and Index
description: King Constantine II held a dramatic news conference in the garden, of his villa in Rome and said earnestly that he was confident of returning to Greece as guardian of consti tutional liberties. In a statement, in English, that he read to about 100 newsmen, the King said: The real problem lies not in whether Greece should have a democracy with or without a King, but whether she should have a democracy at all, and whether the people of Greece has the right to be master of its fate and to enjoy its freedom. [Page 1, Column 83.

title: Bar Will Pay for Mishap
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 (AP)The owners of a bar here have agreed to pay $1.1million to a man who was injured in an auto accident caused by one of the bar's patrons. The settle ment was made Wednesday on the basis of a 1971 state Su preme Court decision that held bartenders and bar owners re sponsible for injuries caused by intoxicated persons they con tinued to serve. The suit was brought on behalf of Howard Bennett, a 62yearold former history professor, who suffered brain damage when his car was hit by a speeding auto in 1968.

title: This White Southern Music Is Mulatto
description: I NEVER really know what to do about country music. I have always tended to have immediate negative gut reactions to it. Hearing a whole chuckwagonfull in the forties while sit ting min my Ohio grandmother (born In Alabama) on Saturday nights by a big brown radio was a first encounter. Grand Ole Opry. They should have pub lished librettos. I didn't get the point, the words, the gags, the reason for those silly tunes and bawling voices (the fiddling was nice, though).

title: The Region
description: The New York Legislature ended its 197273 session last week in the usual barrage of bills and following the usual marathon final sitting. Jerome Wilson, political editor for WCBSTV News, is in the unusual position of having sat as a state Senator from 1962 to 1966 and having re ported on the Legislature since. In the following article he explains how the final crush comes about.

title: Camera World
description: A threeday photographic show, sponsored by the International Photo Optical Show Association (IPOSA), will be held at the Nassau Coliseum, located in the Mitchell Field complex, Uniondale, L. I. on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. The show will include a vari ety of different events and features, in addition to 60 booths displaying new cam eras, accessories and allied equipment. In all of these exhibits visitors will be en couraged to handle the equipment on display and will be able to receive in structions and have ques tions answered by technical experts.

title: Summit: Affluence, AA Bond Rating
description: SUMMIT  Along Spring field Avenue, in the heart of this city's thriving business district, there are at least a halfdozen banks, a sign that Summit is a commercial cen ter. Away from the district, in the twisting streets that lead off treeladen thorough fares, the homes are modern and well kept, their lawns neat ly trimmed and their frames painted or cov ered with alumi num. The business and resi dential section make it obvi ous to a visitor that this community of 25,000 has the affluence to do what it wants to do.

title: New Life for Tracking Station
description: PALERMOThe 25 frame buildings and 20acre ex panse that constituted a for mer Air Force missiletrack ing station in this Cape May County community have been turned over to a con sortium of collegefaculty scientists for teaching and research purposes.

title: Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELESFour years ago, after losing the Los Angeles mayoral election, Thomas Bradley tried to con sole his supporters. They shared with me, he said, the kind of hope that we could really demonstrate to this city and this nation that the demo cratic process does work, that a man can be judged on the basis of his merit alone.

title: The Nation
description: What was never an affair, what seemed to be a divorce, has finally ended up as a shotgun wedding With a contract providing for arbitra tion  between the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Public Broadcasting Service. If any unnatural acts occur, the unhappy couple will have bureaucratic nightmares.

title: Yes, My Darling Daughters, I'm a Movie Nut
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. MY grandmother spent the happiest moments of her sunset years watching the Lone Ranger on television. That quiet little woman celebrated a long widowhood by wan dering forlornly around the house, humming faint tunes under her breath, waiting for our daily 30minute meetings in front of the TV screen where she encouraged the Masked Rider of the Plains with Get Him! Watch out! Hit him! and other interjec tions that drove me, an intol erant teenager, crazy.

title: Goodbye To the Purple Sage
description: Well, sir, we been chased before, chased real good, too; but we ain't never been chased the way Old Rotgut chased us, his last time out. Old Rotgut was what we called Sagebrush Sheridan, Sheriff of Medicine Creek. My name's Jack, Cactus Jack, and my boys and me are the Pecos Gangreal varmin ty varmints, the Sheriff used to call us. There's Three Finger Doc, Cold Eyed Luke, Memphis Bill, Dalhart Ike and Sanatone Rose (yep, she's one of the boys).

title: TV Mailbag
description: IFLED from the screening of Leni Riefenstahl's Tri umph of the Will, shown by Amos Vogel to his film class at the University of Pennsylvania in which was enrolled. The WCBS Camera Three specials on Miss Riefenstahl, about which Vogel writes in Can We Now Forget the Evil That She Did?, were less immediately terrifying, but they force one to ask whether it is worse to create a totally false world as Miss Riefenstahl did in Triumph for vile propagan distic purposesor to rewrite history, so that our dreadfully hounded Leni might once again gleam blondly and in nocently from atop a moun tain.

title: Travel Notes: Concern With the Environment
description: WHAT does an oilsmudged vaca tioner emerging from the Car ibbean have in common with a tourist who has his pocket picked on the Boardwalk in Atlantic City? According to Travel Industry for the Environment (T.I.E.), an organization recently set up to make the world better place to visit, both vacationers are victims of a deteriorating environ ment, a condition which T.I.E. wants to correct.

title: Philadelphia Editor Retires
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP)  William B. Dickinson, 65 years old, executive editor of The Evening and Sunday Bulle tin, retired this week after 24 years with the newspaper. He was replaced by George R. Packard, 41.

title: Linda Gilmore, John R. Viertel Plan to Marry
description: OMAHA, June 2Mr. and Mrs. Maurice R. Gilmore, for merly of Great Neck, L. I., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Linda Gilmore, to John R. Viertel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Viertel of Stamford, Conn., and Christiansted, St. Croix.

title: MONZON DEFEATS GRIFFITH 2D TIME TO RETAIN CROWN
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, June 2Carlos Monzon of Ar gentina retained his world mid dleweight boxing crown tonight with a close but unanimous 15 round decision over Emile Grif fith of New York.

title: Martin Mull's Fabulous Furniture
description: LAUGHTER and the rock generation have not rubbed elbows very frequently. The heavy social concerns of the mid sixties did not encourage much humor, while the coun terculture blossoming of the late sixties took itself far too seriously to allow laughter to jar the sacred trinity of peacelovedrugs. The music and the vibes were so heavy, man, that the rock crowd forgot how to turn their lips up into a smile unless it was of the vacant, drugglazed variety.

title: DOCTOR MURDERED AFTER BEING LURED
description: WOODBOURNE, N. Y., June 3The only doctor serving this rural Sullivan County town was slain here this afternoon after being lured by an unknown as sailant and shot at close range. His nurse was also shot and critically wounded.

title: TRACK TITLE WON BY NORFOLK STATE
description: CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ind., June 2 (UPI)Steve Riddick, with three firsts, led favored Norfolk State to its first Na tional Collegiate Athletic Asso ciation College division frack and field championship today.

title: Bird Watchers Now Can Dial for Leads to Rare Species
description: TRENTONElectronic de vices have come to the aid of New Jersey bird watchers.

title: ROBERT RADEMACHER
description: Robert Rademacher, manager of the Eighth Street Bookshop, 17 West Eighth, Street, died Friday in his home at the same address. He was 52 years old.

title: New Facilities Are Under Way for the Fire. Island Park. Station at Watch Hill
description: WATCH HILL, Fire Island  An expanded public beach and camping facility, the latest addition to the Fire Island National Seashore, will fie opened here on July 1.

title: DiGregorio Is Married
description: NORTH PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 2 (AP)Ernie DiGregorio, Providence College's allAmeri can who recently signed with the Buffalo Braves of the Na tional Basketball Association, was married today to Susan Gail Percival of Pawtucket, R.I.

title: Dr. Smith to Retire and Return to Pulpit
description: DENVILLEFor 25 years, the Rev. Dr. Eugene L. Smith lived and worked at the top levels of global ecu menism and the missionary.

title: Jeffrey Chavkin Fiance Of Katherine Showe
description: WOODBRIDGE, Conn., June 2 Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Showe have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Katherine Showe, to Jeffrey Stuart Chavkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Chavkin of New York and Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: Jocelyn Grace, E. R. Howe Jr. Plan Nuptials
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 2 The engagement of Miss Jocelyn Grace to Edward Redfield Howe Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Eugene G. Grace Jr. of Chestnut Hill, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Howe of West Hartford, Conn., and Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: TodayNorthern New Jersey Region, S.C.C.A. North American Road Racing championships at Bridgehampton (L. I.) Race Cir cuit; 1 P.M.

title: Child to the Johnstones
description: WILTON, Conn., June 2 A daughter was born May 19 to Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey Olcott Johnstone in the Nor walk Hospital. Mrs. John stone is the former Miss Pa tricia Porter. Her husband is vice preident of Trinity In dustries in Mount Kisco, N. Y., a medical supply com pany and ambulance service. The child, who has been named Carolyn Ann, is a greatgranddaughter the late Chauncey Olcott, the tenor.

title: When Dream House Becomes Reality, It's Time to Dream Anew
description: THE other day I found a pond about a mile from my home in the Cotswold Hills in England's West Country. I'd never imagined there was a pond In the middle of that copse. Thus it has now become my pond precisely because nobody thought to inform me it was there.

title: The World
description: LONDON  A satisfying large num ber of Northern Irishmen turned out to vote in Wednesday's local elections. The first balloting to be held in the province since 1969, it was to be a kind of practice run for the crucial Provincial Assembly elections at the end of June.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The announcement in April by the Department of Defense that it was closing or con solidating 274 military bases sent shock waves through the communities affected.

title: Lower Fares Permitted In 747 Without Lounges
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)The Civil Aeronautics Board ruled yesterday that airliners that do not have cocktail lounges can charge lower rates than planes that do. The board, by a 3to1 vote, said the current energy crisis had shown that there was a need to operate air craft more economically. By removing the lounges, it said, the airliners can squeeze in more passengers.

title: EDWARD J. M'DONALD
description: Edward J. McDonald, a for mer vice president in charge of store operations at Bonwit Teller, Inc., and more recently an executive with the National Shoe Retailers Association, died here Thursday at the age of 70. He lived at the Yale Club.

title: $42,000 Discovered On a Woman Slain In Times Sq. Hotel
description: A 70yearold woman de scribed as a loner who haunted Times Square with all her be longings crammed into two shopping bags was found stabbed to death yesterday afternoon in a ladies' room of the hotel where she had been living for the last three and a half years.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Gene Tenace knelt in the ondeck circle at RiVerfront Stadium in Cincinnati just before he was to step to the plate for his first time at bat in the World Series last October. He should have been studying the pitching style of Gary Nolan of the Reds, but a wayward thought entered his mind, as he found himself somewhat dis tracted by the enormity of the situation. The world watches, he said to himself and even gave it extra em phasis by getting un grammatical. There's full house of 53,000 people here and 60 million more are in front of their television sets. This ain't no N.B.C. game of the week.

title: Moonshine: Big Business in the Backwoods
description: Moonshining, once the province of hillbillies operat ing small stills in the secluded backwoods of the South, is taking on some of the trap pings of big business. The stills are getting bigger, and the illegal distilling of liquor appears to be handled in creasingly by wellorganized, wellheeled entrepreneurs.

title: Susan L. Smith Becomes Bride
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 2  Miss Susan Lee Smith and David Mason Little 3d were married here this afternoon in the Con gregational Church by the Rev. Bruce E. Schundler.

title: Headquarters for Veterans Affairs Opens
description: Determination, enthusiasm and a warm sun brightened opening ceremonies for the Mayors Office for Veteran Action in Brooklyn late last week, but behind their smiles, department officials were clearly troubled by continu ing practical difficulties.

title: PLEDGE IS GIVEN
description: ROME, June 2  King Con stantine II, in a dramatic news conference here 30 hours after he was deposed by the Athens military Government, said to night that he was confident that he would return to Greece.

title: 25 Years Later, It's Secretariat
description: Unless somebody comes up with modern Pegasus between now and next Saturday, Secretariat will go into the 105th Belmont Stakes as an overwhelming favor ite to complete the first Triple Crown in 25 years.

title: City to Initiate a Program Of Strict Traffic Controls
description: A wideranging trafficcontrol program, described as one of the most sweeping of its kind in the city's history, is sched uled to begin here on July 1.

title: A Sharp Drop in Thefts Is Reported at Piers Here
description: The port's sprawling water front is becoming a safer place for the highvalue goods that enter and leave the port in oceangoing containers.

title: CocaCola Aide in Argentina Reported Free for $100,000
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, June 2 (AP)The Argentine man ager of the C6rdoba CocaCola bottling plant was reported to have been freed today after his family had paid about $100,000 in ransom.

title: U.S. AIDES IN CHINA TREADING SOFTLY
description: PEKING, June 2The new American liaison office in Pe king appears to be enjoying the experience of not being at embassy. Lean and low pro file are among the words used to describe this unusual diplo matic presence.

title: Cahill and Sandman Exchange Charges in Jersey Primary Race
description: TRENTON, June 2  New Jersey's bitterly contested Re publican primary electioncam paign for Governor, dominated by charges of corruption and confronted with apparent apa thy on the part of the voters, concluded this weekend wits each of the two major candi dates charging that the nomi nation of the other would wreck the party.

title: Rain Interrupts Tie
description: CARBONDALE, Ill., June (UPI)Rain forced suspension of the National Collegiate Dis trict 4 championship game between Southern Illinois and Minnesota after 11 innings with the score tied 66. The game is scheduled to resume tomorrow.

title: LETTERS
