description: TV Advertising

title: If You Go ...
description: .... to Indonesia, which consists of five large and more than 3,000 small islands, there are a number of attractive routes: across the Pacific via Hawaii and Japan; over the Pole to Tokyo and onward, and by way of Europe, Bangkok and Singapore. In Jakarta, on the island of Java, where most inter national flights land, there are metered cabs to take you for about 61.50 to any of a number of mod em hotels on Jalan Thamrin, the wide principal avenue. My choice of hotel Is the Kartika Plaza. It has filtered water, its own gener ating plant for use during the not infrequent power failures, modern rooms, passable restaurants, a spacious lobby stocked with pe riodicals and a large pool. Rates are about 620 single, $25 double. The nearby InterContinental Hotel Indonesia has more spacious grounds and more shops, but the furnishings are poor, the aircondi tioning compressors jolt you out of bed when they come on, the service is slow, the prices are high and the rooms are generally re served far in advance. Other good, cheaper hotels, centrally located, are the Asoka and the Sempang Metropolitan.

title: Where the Action Is
description: OXFORD, Conn.Can a prisoner of Second Avenue find happiness in a land where there are no allnight delis? Does a pampered New Yorker ever adjust to the absence of cabs and supers?

title: Religion
description: What manner of man was Jesus?

title: Mrs. Cynthia Eischen Remarries
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 2In the Second Congrega tional Church here this after noon, Mrs. Cynthia Gross Eischen, daughter of William A. O. Gross and the late Mrs. Cynthia Conway Gross, was married to James Southwick Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Farwell Brown Jr. of Riverside. The Rev. Dr. Ken neth E. Nye performed the ceremony.

title: Reagan Vetoes I.Q. Bill
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 2 (UPI)Gov. Ronald Reagan ve toed yesterday a bill prohibiting public schools from adminiter ing group intelligence tests. He said that the I.Q. tests were too valuable to eliminate, and that the right to Utilize them should be left up to local school boards.

title: Celebrating a Structure of the Mind
description: SINCE its completion in 1883, the Brooklyn Bridge has been one of the more enduring na tional monuments, a peren nial subject for both the American painter and the American writer. Its struc turethe stalwart granite towers strung with delicate networks of steel cableap pealed to an artist like Joseph Stella, who made it, almost, an emblem of his oeuvre; its symbolismspanning time as well as space, it seemed provided the inspiration for Hart Crane's great American idyll, The Bridge, published in 1930.

title: LIBERIA CLAIMS MAN POSED AS U.S. AGENT
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 29The Liberian Govern ment has arrested a Liberian citizen on charges of having inmersonated an American in telligence agent and of having falsified and sold documents that said the United States was involved in planning coups Mat and political assassina tions in several African coun tries.

title: L.I.R.R. Highballs to Rock Show
description: Friday evening's rock revival show at Madison Square Gar den was the 13th such event Richard Nader has unleashed; on nostalgiahappy New York ers since 1969. As a concert, it had its labored downs and ex hilarating ups. But for some 250 Long Islanders, it func tioned as something of a ca boose, chronologically speaking, to a Rock in Roll Special train that whisked them from Babylon and points west to Pennsylvania Station.

title: Ferguson Brings Back Power to Dodger LineUp
description: LOS ANGELES, June 2  For the first time in a dec ade, the Los Angeles Dodg ers have an apparent fence buster in Joe Ferguson.

title: Mayoral Candidates Press For a Big Vote Tomorrow
description: With voter turnout vi tally important to their for tunes in tomorrow's primary, four Democratic mayoral hope fuls mobilized their campaign workers this weekend to get out big votes in areas where they expect to run well.

title: John Friedman Jr. To Wed Miss Nevin
description: BALDWIN, L. I., June 2 The engagement of Miss Laurie Suzanne Nevin to John M. Friedman Jr., son of Judge John M. Friedman, Town and Village Justice of Scarsdale, N.Y. and Mrs. Friedman, has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Mar shall I. Nevin.

title: Commuting The Trains Are an Old Story
description: It was, even for a railroad with a tradition of travail for its riders, a bad night on the New Haven: Minutes after pulling out of Grand Central Terminal with hundreds of homeward bound commuters last Tuesday, the 5:02 P.M. train for New Haven rattled to a halt in the tunnel beneath Park Avenue, disabled by the failure of its 17yearold locomotive.

title: U.S.SOVIET PACT ON FORCES IS SEE
description: The United States and the Soviet Union are moving to ward agreement on the mutual withdrawal of some ground forces from central Europe, ac cording to authoritative sources in Washington.

title: Parakeets a Threat To Fruit Growers
description: NEW BRUNSWICKWild parakeets are appearing in New Jersey, and they are bad news for farmers, fruit growers and home gardeners.

title: New Breed of Drivers Too Tame, Says Moss
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, June 2The fast cars went faster than ever here today. That meant nothing to Stir ling Moss. There is more money in auto racing now than a decade ago, and that bothers Moss, because he is no longer a driver.

title: MISS BRYANT IS TIED FOR LEAD WITH 143
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 2 (AP)Bonnie Bryant, the only lefthander on the women's pro golf tour, shot a 71 today and was tied with Mrs. Kathy Cor nelius and Sandra Haynie for the secondround lead in the rainshortened $100,000 Sealy Faberge golf tournament. Miss Bryant was four under par through 14 holes but had bogeys on two of the last four holes.

title: FEUERBACH TAKES SHOTPUT AT 711
description: BERKELEY, Calif., June (UPI)The world recordhold er, Al Feuerbach, won his sec ond shotput title in less than 24 hours today at the Kennedy Games with a put of 71 feet 1 inchei, fourth longest in history.

title: Open letter to the next Mayor
description: Dear Sir:

title: State Agency to Build Sewers in Queens
description: The filthy wading pools that are a pox in the Rock aways after every rainfall are expected to become an unhappy memory as the re sult of a new approach to sewer construction.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: As Fellini Sees Rome: A City of Desolation, Fossilized Ruins, and Children
description: WHAT do I think of when I hear the name Rome? More or less, I know. I think of a ruddy face, brown, muddy ground; of a vast tattered sky, like an opera backdrop, with tones of violet, black, and silver. Funereal colors, but all things considered it is a comforting sight. Com forting because Rome, a horizontal city, stretched out, is the ideal platform for fantastic vertical flights. The intellec tuals, the artists, who always live in a state of friction between two differ ent dimensionsreality and fantasy find in Rome the right liberating thrust for their mental activity, with the com fort of an umbilical cord that keeps them solidly anchored.

title: Disability Payment On Pregnancy Held Peril to Coast Plan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 (AP) A Federal court order giv ing women disability payments for pregnancy would break Cali fornia's $420million disability insurance program within a year unless fees are increased, the program director says.

title: Show After Show Keeps Boss Too Busy to Ride
description: DEVON, Pa., June 2Prob ably the busiest horseman in the Delaware Valley never rides a horse these days.

title: High School Papers Termed Lacking in Minorities
description: Charges that there are not enough blacks on the staffs of high school publications and that school administrators cen sor student publications with regard to language and social issues were raised here yester dad at a hearing on high school journalism.

title: Cod War
description: UNITED NATIONSA dramatic es calation of the cod war has focused attention here on an early warning sign of what may well be man's most critical problem: depletion of the re sources needed to support human life.

title: Dr. Harold D. Harvey Dies; Retired Surgeon Was 79
description: PRINCETON, N.J., June 2 Dr. Harold Dortic Harvey, retired surgeon at Presbyterian Hospital of the ColumbiaPres byterian Medical Center in New York, died today at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived at 76 Library Place.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Enjoy the roses; collect some petals in the morning to dry for potpourri. ... Resow where peas have been picked. ... Thin beets, lettuce, summer spinach and chard... Keep tomatoes pruned to two main stems; tie securely to stakes. ... Put house plants outdoors in semishade for summer.

title: Dance
description: AS a dance lover, I vir tually grew up on Swan Lake. A few years later I discovered the mysteries of Rudolph von Laban, Kurt Jooss, Sigurd Leeder and the European school of moderndance. But by then the floodgates of in ternational dance had opened and drenched me. But as a child it was very much those old Tchaikovsky classics that gave me my first instinct about moving to music.

title: Craftsman Makes Business of Hobby
description: Louis Pronsky's wife told him, Louis, you've got to do something. There's no room to walk around the house. So Mr. Pronsky, a lifelong woodworking hobbyist, took his collection of handmade bookends, mirror frames, pedestals, benches, candle sticks and whatall and opened Knoek On Wood, a tiny showcase of a shop at 169 Seventh Avenue, corner of First Street in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: Miss Marina ValmyNikolescu Is Married to John Joonil Limb
description: NEWTON, N. J., June 2 Miss Marina ValmyNikolescu, daughter of Mrs. Henry D. ValmySterian of New York, Frankfurt, West Germany, and Newton, and John Joonil Limb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Son Bon Limb of Seoul, South Korea, were married here this afternoon at Old Ro mantics, the home of the bride's mother.

title: Miss Deming Has Nuptials
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 Miss Rosamond Bennett Dem ing was married here this afternoon to Luis Larraga Rodriguez de Vera, plant manager for the Ralston Purina Company in Madrid. The Rev. James Fenhagen performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Georgetown.

title: U.S. Labor Chief Is Named Here
description: Stephen D. Blum, a former marketing executive, was ap pointed yesterday as regional director of the United States Department of Labor in New York by Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan.

title: Miss McClave, Peter Douglas Plan Nuptials
description: NEW VERNON, N. J., June 2  Miss Patricia Adams McClave, a legal as sistant at the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wicker sham & Taft, plans to be married in August to Peter Roderick Douglas, a student at Harvard Law School.

title: I Knew This Was My Day to Die, Says Heroic Engineer Who Saved His Shipmates
description: Albert Almeida, the chief engineer of the ruined cargo vessel Sea Witch, lay in the crowded ward at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn yesterday, talking of the night of holocaust and heroism in the Narrows.

title: Maurice Dekobra Dies at 88; French Novelist and Journalist
description: PARIS, June 2 (AP)Maurice Dekobra, one of the most suc cessful French novelists be tween the World Wars, died to day. He was 88 years old.

title: The New Plays
description: NASH AT NINE, a musical revue with verses and lyr ics by Ogden Nash and music by Milton Rosen stock, got five favorable reviews (Watt, Watts, Wal ladt, Reidy, Gayer), two mixed (Harris, Sanders) and four unfavorable re views (Barnes, Gottfried, Glover, Bookspan).

title: MESKIII PRAISES STATE'S ASSEMBLY
description: HARTFORD, June 2Wind ing up its business last night, five days ahead of the constitu tional deadline, the Connecticut General Assembly was praised by Gov. Thomas J. Meskill for its efficiency and quickness, and for producing legislation that he called useful and sound.

title: Democrat Wants Inquiry on BreakIn at His Home
description: STATELINE, Nev., June 2 (AP)The Democratic national chairman, Robert S. Strauss, has asked Senate investigators and Federal prosecutors to look into a mysterious ransacking of his Dallas home last July, in light of recent Watergate reve lations, an aide confirmed here tonight.

title: Miriam J. Holmgren, James McCrea 3d Wed
description: CLINTON, N. Y., June 2 Miss Miriam Jane Holmgren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Joseph Holmgren of Pittsford, was married here this noon to James Craig Mc Crea 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McCrea Jr. of Bayport, L. I. The Rev. Joel Tibbetts per formed the Protestant cere mony in the Root Glen of Hamilton.

title: Gardens
description: MANY a gardener is in a hurry to see re sults. This is par ticularly true for hedges for the best way to grow them is to buy three foot plants, cut them almost to the ground as they are planted and await results.

title: Just When You Think You've Figured Vanya Out
description: IT'S nearer 40 than 30 years ago now that, on a visit to London, I bought a ticket for the top of the balcony at a play I hadn't heard of with John Gielgud in A. When the curtain went up on a man and a woman, the man said: Why do you always wear black? And the woman answered: I'm in mourning for my life. I'm unhappy.

title: A Sampling of Portugal in Newark
description: NEWARKIn a city beset by changing neighborhoods, there is one ethnic area that manages to retain its own flavor. And that special Por tuguese flavor permeates the street language, the lifestyle and, quite naturally, the food.

title: Sri Lanka Rules on Dress
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, June 2 The Ministry of Education has ordered women teachers not to wear miniskirts or dresses with low necklines and men teachers not to wear long hair, long beards and sideburns, or drain pipe slacks. Dress must reflect the purity of mind and the un assailable moral standing of the teachers in the eyes of the stu dents under their care, the ministry said.

title: Wohlhuter Moves Up to the Mile And Wins in 3:58.8 at Wichita
description: WICHITA, Kan., June 2  Rick Wohlhuter, who set a world record in the halfmile last Sunday, moved up to the mile tonight and stole the show from Dave Wottle and a stellar field of halfmilers. Wohlhuter triumphed at the United States Track and Field Federation championships in 3 minutes 58.8 seconds, the first sub4 minute performance of his ca reer.

title: Sports Week
description: BASEBALL

title: Englewood Arts Festival Due
description: ENGLEWOOD  Artists, writers, musicians and dancers have joined with the Engle wood City Council and the Art Center of Northern New Jersey in a Festival of the Arts. The threeday event, which is designed to acquaint this community and its neigh boring towns with the work of the many talented people who live in Englewood, will be held next weekend

title: Caress the Perch, Says a Masterful drench Restaurateur
description: ROANNE, France  JeanBaptiste Troisgros is making his nightly entrance into the dining room of the Restaurant Troisgros, of which he Is the founding father; he goodnaturedly known as patron (boss). Monsieur Troisgros is stocky, well dressed, and wears lightlysmoked glasses.

title: TWINS TOP TIGERS IN 10TH ON HOMER
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 2 (AP)Joe Lis belted his sec ond home run of the season in the bottom of the 10th inning today, lifting the Minnesota Twins to a 32 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: Whistle a Tune From Thomas Mann
description: OST of us have seen The Music Man, but how many of us have seen the music Mann? None of us, but that's going to be changed, thanks to Anthony Burgess, British tubber of A Clockwork Orange and the Broadway musical adaptation of Cy rano, and Stephen Schwartz, the composer of Pippin and Godspell. According to Burgess, the two will col laborate on a song and dance movie version of Thomas Mann's 1941 novel The Transposed Head.

title: AsianAmerican Actors Fight for Jobs and Image
description: The Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center has been found guilty of discrimination because it systematically failed or re fused to give equal opportu nity to AsianAmerican ac tors, particularly as evidenced by the regular awarding of Ori ental parts to nonOriental ac tors.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: Blowing Your Own Horn Mr. Silverman is a free lance advertising and public relations consultant.

title: Letters: Shelters For the Young
description: I read with interest Stephen Kinzer's Page 1 article of April 22, Youth in Canada: Drifting Around With the Government's Blessing. The author suggested that it would be well to consider how to adapt the Canadian experience to the United States, and commented on the seeming lack of facilities and encouragement for youth to travel in our country.

title: Bank Official Appointed
description: BOSTON, June 2 (AP)Mel vin B. Miller, publisher of The Bay State Banner, has been ap pointed by the State Banking Commissioner as conservator of Unity Bank and Trust Company, described as a biracial bank for community development in the city's predominantly black Rox bury section, The conservator is responsible for overall man agement of the bank.

title: Kissinger: Life Is Suffering
description: When one thing goes wrong for an Administration, it often happens that things falter or fall apart in other fields as well, and this seems to be what is happening in Washington now. It is not only the Watergate, but the dollar crisis, the energy crisis, the constitutional crisis over bombing Cambodia, and various other things that are now troubling a distracted and partly paralyzed Nixon Adminis tration. There is something eerie about the way Mr. Nixon's fortunes have plunged from spectacular success a few months ago to spectacular diffi culties now, and it recalls the Spenglerian mood of a passage out of Henry Kissinger's Harvard thesis of almost a quarter of a century ago:

title: ISRAELIS ADVANCE WATER DESALTING
description: TEL AVIV, June 2Two new methods of distilling fresh wa ter from the sea have been de signed independently by two Israeli engineering organiza tions. Both methods dispense with the need for the expensive coppernickel alloy tubing that accounts for much of the cost of conventional desalting in stallations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Let this Fresh Meadows veteran have a word about the article Ownership Change Unsettles Fresh Meadows [May 20]. This end of the Frankel family has been in Fresh Meadows for almost 25 years. Most of that time we spent in a 4room apartment, but for the last seven yearssince our daugh ters were marriedwe have been in a 2room patio apartment.

title: Antiwar Group Loses Plea On Trial for '72 Disorders
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., June 2 (AP)A Federal judge has re fused to dismiss an indictment against seven members of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War and a sympathizer accused of conspiring to disrupt the 1972 Republican National Con vention.

title: Chess: Fischer's Next Challenger? Tal Is Still the One to Watch
description: Mikhail Tal's sensational winning streak  83 games without a losswas snapped when he fell prey to brilliant play by 23yearold Yuri Balashov in the match be tween the Soviet Union's first team and young stars.

title: Space
description: It was a strange sensation at first, to give a little hop that normally would carry me 12 inches off the ground, and shoot into the air some 20 to 30 feet, to drift down and land again almost as lightly as a feather. Or to give a great shove against the ground, and soar 60 or 70 feet upward. ... I found it was necessary to cultivate a certain deli cate instinct of balance.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Guards Held Hostage
description: CRANSTON, R. I., June 2 (AP)A small group of in mates in the Adult Correction al Institutions held three guards hostage for about half an hour today while protesting prison conditions. The guards were released and received treatment for bruises.

title: $27Million Open Space Allotment Is Approved
description: TRENTON  The latest appropriation under New Jersey's Green Acres pro gram will be used for such diverse projects as the con version of a Jersey City junk yard into a park and the protection of wildlife in the South Jersey pinelands.

title: A Human Doll, a Tubby Kid, a Hobo Emperor
description: Hare lire some further thoughts on three new films that have little in common ex cept the acetate stock they are printed on:

title: Now women are baring their arms
News of the Rialto
description: PINUPSgorgeous, glam orous girls, draped and undraped, the sort who used to keep the butterandegg men awake back in the days of Zieg feld's Follies, Earl Carroll's Vanities and George White's Scandals  will return to Broadway next sea son.

title: Beyond the Howard Hunt of June 17
description: The listing in Who's Who must surely have been a source of pride to E. Howard Hunt Jr., a man who has spent much of his 54 years in pursuit of power, status and wealth. But today it must be read with a certain irony: Most of the State Department positions in the entry have been exposed as covers for Hunt's career as a C.I.A. agent, a background that relates in part to news that Hunt's address is no longer the White House, but 19th Street, S.E., or Cellblock Four of the grim District of Columbia jail. For his part in the Water gate breakin and bugging, he stands convicted on six counts of conspiracy, and he is serving a pro visional term of 35 years.

title: Court Aide Chides Lawyers on Fees
description: TRENTON  The outgoing administrative director of New Jersey's courts chided the legal profession last week over what has been a sacred subject: their fees.

title: Language Expert Explores the Rich Diction of Caribbean to See How Islanders View Themselves
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 2 Argentine art collectors con cerned about the political and economic uncertainties under the new Peronist Government have increased their sales of European paintings abroad, according to art dealers and collectors here.

title: Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTONAnalogies between human and international relations can be dangerously misleading, but in one respect the two seem similar. What is not said is often as important, though it gets less notice, as what is said. That may be the case with the rhetoric of EastWest relations: it strains memory to recall the last time Washington publicly and polemically referred to Moscow as the center of the international Communist conspir acy or Moscow identified the President a tool of Wall Street.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The funniest thing about GANGWAY by Donald E. West lake and Brian Garfield (Evans, $5.95) is the jacket photograph of the two authors playing poker. (But what the hell is Garfield doing raking in all those chips without even show ing his hand?) One wonders why Westlake, who handles this kind of thing so well, needs a partner to write still another crimefarce. This one is an essay into temps perdu  San Francisco in 1874, where a New York thug joins up with a few assorted types, including a pert dip, in the robbery of the Unit ed States Mint.

title: Susan Pascall Wed to T. P. Reutershan
description: MILLBURN, N. J., June 2 The Wyoming Presbyterian Church was the setting here this evening for the marriage of Miss Susan Ann Pascall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ross M, Pascall of Millburn to Thomas Paul Reutershan. He is the son of Mrs. Paul Reutershan of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., and the late Mr. Reutershan. The Rev. William Russell performed the cere mony.

title: Hall of Science Gets Ready for Summer
description: The Hall of Science at Flushing MeadowsCorona Park is getting ready for the influx of summer visitors, with an emphasis on children.

title: Witness To History
description: At the end of the 1920's the Foreign Service of the United States, dissatisfied with the results of the current practice of transferring its officers frequently and aimlessly from one part of the globe to another, introduced a program of regional specialization. It was a fortunate innovation, for, among other things, it provided the Service with a group of welltrained Russianlanguage spe cialists just at the time when the United States was beginning its new and troubled association with the Soviet Union.

title: REMUND BREAKS SPEEDBOAT MARK
description: WASHINGTON June 2 (AP) Mickey Remund of Palm Desert, Calif., and Gene Whipp of Dayton, Ohio, raced to easy heat victories on the Potomac today in the President's Cup regatta for unlimited hydro planes.

title: WEISKOPF LEADS GOLF BY 2 SHOTS
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., June 2 Tom Weiskopf dashed the hopes of Wake Forest supporters in the $200,000 Kemper open to day when he shot a fourunder par 68 at the Quail Hollow Country Club to take a two stroke lead with a 13underpar 203 for 54 holes.

title: Rich Dictior Of Caribbear Is Explored
description: BASSETERRE, St. Kitts,  Sneakers. In Trinidad they call them wash ikongs. In Guyana they are yachtings, in Barbados pumps, in Jamaica crepes, in St. Vincent soft mash. Here they call them soft walker.

title: HAROLD A. JACKSON
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., June 2 Harold A. Jackson, who op erated a realestate and insur ance business here for many years, died today in Community Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: THE BIG TEN ON BROADWAY
Bontempo Will Step Down As Jersey Democratic Chief
description: FLORHAM PARK, N. J., June 2 (AP)Salvatore A. Bontempo announced today that he would step down as chairman of the Democratic State committee after Tuesday's gubernatorial primary.

title: Remembered Island
description: Ever since man left the caves, an island has been special place. A man on an island became a king with a realm. Invasion was difficult, safety quite easy achieve. The island, in fact, became the model for the medieval castle, with moat and drawbridge. And an island at a river's mouth was special.

title: 7 Dead, 9 Missing in Narrows Ship Crash
description: Seven seamen were dead and nine crew members were missing and presumed dead yesterday after an American cargo ship, outbound in the early morning darkness, impaled her prow amidships of an oilladen Bel gian tanker at anchor in the Narrows of New York Harbor, touching off an inferno of ex plosions and fire.

title: 13 Blocks of Rockaway's Beach Closed by Erosion
description: There may be fewer bathers in the Rockaways this sum mer, not because sand and surr are becoming, less popu lar, but because erosion has forced the closing of 13 blocks of the peninsula's sevenand onehalfznilelong beach.

title: Daring Duo Star on Brooklyn Street
description: Gordon Parks, motionpic ture director of Shaft faint, says he wants stark reality as the backdrop for his new film, The Super Cops. So stark reality is what he has.

title: Harvey Wins Golf at 287
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., June 2 (AP)Bill Harvey of James town, N. C., shot a par 72 today Ito capture the Falstaff Amature Golf Classic with a 287 total.

title: Cynthia Land Bride Of W.C. Humphries
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 2 Miss Cynthia Gay Land, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gay V. Land, was married here this evening to William Charles Humphries, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Hum phries of Philadelphia.

title: Mr. Astaire Should Know
description: SOMETIMES it takes a pair of sharp eyes to catch talent on the wing. I don't mean mine, thank you, I mean Fred Astaire's. I'm told that at the posh special preview of Via Galactica this seasonthe preview was the last posh thing that happened to the poor showMr. Astaire spot ted a youngster named Ralph Carter and remarked on his extraordinary, always perfectly rhythmic, ability.

title: Met Games This Week
What's New At the Movies?
3Day Cultural Salute Opens in Israel Aug. 11
description: A cultural Salute to Is rael, to which celebrities of the world of art, literature, entertainment and science have been invited, will be held in Jerusalem and Cae sarea on Aug. 11, 12 and 13 under the auspices of Israel's Ministry of Culture and Edu cation.

title: One Alternative to Selecting Candidates
description: GLEN RIDGE  While the rest of the country is ab sorbed in a scandal brought on by partisan politics, this Essex County borough is cele brating its 60th year of an apparently workable alter native to selecting candidates for local office.

title: Lobsters, Now Plentiful, Provide Reasonable Dinner Treat
description: The cost of live lobsters has been so high that it was the buying, not the killing and cooking, that took cour age. However, recent weeks have brought some relief for the lobster lover. Lower prices (in some retail mar kets they have dropped by a dollar a pound) now permit more households to welcome the ferocious but succulent crustacean to their tables.

title: How sane men thought a madman would behave
description: Surely, of all the lessons to be learned from the study of history, one of the most important must be how governments, by carefully col lecting military and diplomatic intel ligence, submitting them to intricate analysis by trained specialists and then turning over the results for judgment to responsible politicians and statesmen, do in the end come to make all those damn  fool decisions.

title: OLDFIELD VICTOR IN SHOTPUT AGAIN
description: RICHMOND, June 2Brian Oldfield put the shot 69 feet 4 inches to win the event for the 14th time in 15 competitions at the International Track Asso ciation's final tuneup before the world indoor pro champion ships at Madison SquareGarden next Wednesday. Oldfield raised his tourleading earnings to $9,575.

title: Arizona Regents Act to Allow Abortions
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., June 2 Overriding legislative opposi tion, the Arizona State Board of Regents has voted after three weeks of controversy to permit abortions at the state funded University of Arizona Hospital in Tucson.

title: Amusement Park Plan Disputed in Mt. Olive
description: MOUNT OLIVE TOWN SHIPThis sparsely devel oped Morris County commu nity has found itself involved in what is becoming a famil iar issue in New Jersey sub urbs: urbs: economics vs. environ ment.

title: JEWS AND POLICE CUMIN BROOKLYN
description: A Brooklyn physician was set upon in his car last night when he tried to escort a patient through a crowd of Hasidic Jews gathered for the Sabbath in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn; the police reported.

title: Arts Center: It's Showtime
description: HOLMDEL  The open air Garden State Arts Center, known affectionately to North Jerseyans as Culture in the Mud. will begin its sixth summer season next Saturday. The opening will be a gala benefit starring Lawrence Welk and his Champagne Music televi sion cast of 40.

title: CUBS 2RUN 6TH TOPS BRAVES, 43
description: CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) Jose Cardenal drove in the ty ing run on an infield out and then scored on a wild pitch, lifting the Chicago Cubs to a 43 victory over the Atlanta Braves today.

title: Even the Ideas Die Fast At the Indianapolis 500
description: Nothing in the Indianapolis 500 establishment dies a quicker death than a fresh idea.

title: Mr. Southampton Will Be Honored
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.,  When Southampton College awards its customary honor ary degrees at commence ment exercises next Thursday, William K. Dunwell will share the spotlight with Jean Stafford, Pulitizer Prizewin ning author, and Dr. Hiram Bentley Glass, international ly known geneticist.

title: LARSEN SHOWS UP FOR SOVIET CHESS
description: LENINGRAD, June 2Bent Larsen showed up in Leningrad last night, ending fears that he might boycott the interzonal chess tournament, slated to be gin here tomorrow. The Danish grandmaster has not withdrawn the protest he has lodged with Dr. Max Euwe, president of the world chess organization, but he acknowledged that the chance to qualify for a match with the world champion, Bob by Fischer, was too important to forgo.

title: Revolt Brewing Over Central Park Tennis
description: Up in Central Park, the atmosphere is a bit stormy at the public tennis courts.

title: A reporter, a Senator, the Senator's wife and what might have been
description: When Tom Wicker was a young reporter in Tennessee in the late 1950's, the dominant figure in the state's politics was Senator Estes Kefauver, the towering, mumbling, hand  pumping, whiskey  drinking, coonskincapwearing, trustbusting intellectualindisguise who came so close to capturing the Democratic nomination for President in 1952. When Wicker came to Washington to join The New York Times, for which he is now an associate editor and columnist, he observed the final, unhappy years of Kefauver's life, which ended with his death of a heart attack in the summer of 1963.

title: Canoeist's Body Is Found
description: PORT JERVIS, N. Y., June 2 (AP)The body of Alfred Rein felder, 36 years old, of Great, Neck, L. I., was found in the Delaware River today following a canoeing accident May 18, the state police said. His canoe had overturned near Berryville, in Sullivan County, and his body was found near Sparrowbush, in Orange County. His son and another boy had made to shore following the accident.

title: A TuxedoClad Waiter Turns Out to Be Nixon
description: LANCASTER, Pa., June 2 (AP)Mrs. Linda Smith said yesterday that she had near ly fainted; everything Just went black when she mis took President Nixon for a waiter during the White House reception for repatri ated prisoners of war on May 24. She attended with her husband, Donald G. Smith of nearby Ephrata, who was re leased by the Viet Cong on New Year's Day, 1969.

title: A continuing revolution in the study of myth
description: Claude LviStrauss, widely ac claimed as the father of structural anthropology, is continuing a revo lution in the study of myth which he began in 1955. At that time he discovered in myth an underlying order in what was otherwise con sidered to be total chaos. As a result of his work, myths are no longer understood as the random construc tion of a primitive and backward mentality. Instead they provide the raw material for a systematic analy sis of a theoretically unlimited but nevertheless closed set of plans for arriving at the fundamental struc tures of the unconscious Mind.

title: Article 1  No Title
E.B.A. Grants Franchise To 76ers' Promotion Chief
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., June (AP)  The Eastern Basketball Association granted a franchise today to Rich Iannarella, di rector of promotions for the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: WATERGATE PROTEST PLANNED IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 2  Civil rights and antiwar leaders have joined with the People's Coalition for Peace and Justice and announced plans for a June 16 march from Water gate to justice with the theme funds for life, not death.

title: Miss Elisabeth Donaghy, Curator, Wed
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., June 2 Miss Elizabeth Donaghy, directorcurator of the Daugh ters of the American Revolu tion Museum in Washington, was married here at noon to day to Wendell Douglas Gar rett, who is editor of Antiques, a magazine in New York. The Rev. Donald A. Webster per formed the Episcopal cere mony in the home of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Madiford Pear don Donaghy, parents of the bride. Dr. Donaghy is chair man of the division of neu rological surgery at the Uni versity of Vermont College of Medicine.

title: Elizabeth S. Beare Has Nuptials Here
description: Miss Elizabeth Sanford Beare, daughter of Dr. John Byron Beare and Mrs. Eliza beth Sanford Beare, both of St. Louis, was married here yesterday afternoon to Stan ley Buddington Thomas Jr., who was appointed recently as Acting Assistant Secretary for Human Development in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Pope Paul Names American To Vatican Lay Council
description: ROME, June 2Pope Paul VI has named John W. McDevitt, a highranking member of the Knights of Columbus of the United States, an honorary member of the Vatican adminis tration's advisory council of laymen founded by Pope Pius IX in 1847. Mr. McDevitt lives in New Haven.

title: A Jewish Congregation Gets New Queens Home
description: After 50 years of worship in the cramped quarters of converted private homes, the Kew Gardens Anshe Sholom Jevish Center has come into being at 8452 Abingdon Road.

title: Eight Killed in Car Crash
description: PLAINVIEW, Tex, June 2 (UPI)Eight persons in one car died today in a crash with truck on Interstate Highway 27 three miles south of Plainview in the Texas Panhandle.

title: Recordings
description: COLUMBIA'S announced intention of reissuing its complete Metropoli tan Opera series on the budget Odyssey label, in hon est undoctored mono trans fers, is good news. Not that these recordings necessarily merit the legendary status accorded them on Odyssey's album coverstaken all in all, the performances rarely rise above a fairtomiddling standard of qualitybut they do represent a valid slice of musical history, documenting some of the company's im portant or representative singers during the late forties and early fifties, and each set is bound to revive a host of operagoing memories from those years.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: From Sleep to a Fantasy
description: PATERSON  Alfred Sole, who faces criminal charges of having promoted fornication while making an Xrated movie, started a new film outside his home here the other day. The movie will be called Neighbors, and it will explore the strains end humor of two affluent sub urban couples.

title: Italian Warplanes Collide, Flier Killed, After Parade
description: ROME, June 2Two fighter planes collided and a pilot was killed today as an armed forces parade, celebrating the 27th anniversary of the Italian Re public, was held here.

title: Dystrophy Research Chief Named
description: The appointment of Dr. Melvin L. Moss as director of research development, a new post of the Muscular Dystrophy Association of America, was announced yes terday by Robert Ross, exec trctve director of the vol untary agency.

title: Weis Case Deepens Wall St. Troubles
description: Just when Wall Street bad ly needed customers, capital and confidence, the Weis Se curities case broke into the open  making it all the more difficult for the industry to find all three.

title: Vote Due on Wage Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) A Democratic bill to raise the minimum wage by 60 cents an hour and to extend its coverage to sixmillion lowpaid workers will come to a vote this week in the House, where a similar proposal was killed last year.

title: PETER M. WHITMAN
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., June 3Peter M. Whitman, a vice president of Johnson & Higgins, international insurance brokers, died today in Northern West chester Hospital, Mount Kisco. He was 63 years old and lived at 190 Broad Brook Road and in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Pollution Warning Device  Is Required for 1975 Autos
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency told automakers today to add another device to cars built in 1975 and after: a light or buzzer that will warn drivers when new antipollution devices need repair or maintenance.

title: 3 Rivals for Mayor Focus Their Fire On Beame as Campaign Nears an End
description: Three of the candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomi nation focused their major criticism yesterday on the fourth, Controller Abraham D. Beame, who is thought to be the frontrunner, as a tepid campaign drew to a busy end.

title: RESERVE DISCLOSES REQUEST TO BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The Federal Reserve Board dis closed today that it had asked about 100 foreignowned banks in the. United States to con form voluntarily to new Re serve requirements imposed last month on domestic banks against largedenomination cer tificates of deposit and some other kinds of funds.

title: PRIMARY RIVALS FORESEE DELAYS AT POLLS IN tITY
description: Although the polls will be open seven hours longer than usual, mayoral campaign aides expressed concern yesterday that there would be widespread confusion in today's primary election in the city.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE LIFE TO COME AND OTHER STORIES.

title: JOSEPH M'MULLAN, CARPET COLLECTOR
description: Joseph V. McMullan, an authority on Islamic carpets, of which he had one of the world's most famous collections, died Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 166 East 66th Street.

title: C.I.A. MEMOS SHOW POLITICAL FEARS OVER WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Central Intelligence Agency and high White House officials viewed the investigation in the weeks after the Watergate bug ging in June, 1972, as a poten tial political bombshell and not as a legitimate matter of na tional security, according to a series of highlevel C.I.A. mem orandums.

title: Ruckelshaus, a Political Outsider, Commands Uneasy F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, June 3With William D. Ruckelshaus's self imposed tenure of two months as acting director of the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation barely half over, he finds him self in a perplexing position.

title: National League
SETH HARRISON
description: Seth Harrison, founder and chairman of the REDM Corpora tion, 1457 Broadway, manufac turer of military and electronic components, died Saturday in Long Island Jewish Hospital, Lake Success. He was 55 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

title: CAHILL PUTS TRUST IN VOTER INTUITION
description: HOLMDEL, N. J., June 3 His voice hoarse from campaign oratory, but his spirits high, Governor Cahill greeted 600 visitors to a Polish Day Festi val at the Garden State Art Center today.

title: Ridley First in Stock Race
description: BYRON, Ga., June 3 (AP) Jody Ridley captured the Per matex 200 today, leading the pack for 155 laps of the 200 lap stock car race.

title: John David Griffin, 45, Dies; ExColumnist for Hearst
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 3 (AP)  John David Griffin, a former syndicated column ist for the Hearst chain, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospi tal. His age was 45.

title: Pravda's News of U.S. Doesn't All Fit
description: MOSCOW, June 3  Ivan Ivanovich, the Russian John Doe, settled back with his Sunday papers on this sum mery day to read all about the United States. A confused picture emerged.

title: More Burglaries by Government Operatives Alleged
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The Senate Watergate investigators have been told that Govern ment operatives have commit ted a number of other burgla ries besides the Ellsberg break in, Newsweek magazine reports in its issue that is due on news stands tomorrow.

title: Owner Rides General C To Stamford Show Title
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 3 Mrs. Lucy Danziger, the own er of Cedar Lodge Farms, has owned General C for five years, but today she rode the mount to a championship for the first time.

title: Hanoi Press Agency Says 32 Have Ties to Vietcong
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3 (UPI)The Vietcong's Provi sional Revolutionary Govern ment has established diplomatic relations with 32 nations, Ha noi's press agency said today.

title: Help for Newly Arrived Puerto Ricans
description: Last December 24yearold Victor Cintron, who had been a welder in Fajardo, P.R., came to New York bringing the dream that thousands of Puerto Ricans had before him, of doing better here.

title: John P. Horrigan, Director Of Buffalo Bills' Publicity
description: BUFFALO, June 3 (UPI) John P. Horrigan, vice president in charge of public relations for the Buffalo Bills football team and a former newsman for the United Press, died yesterday at, the Roswell Park Memorial In stitute here. He was 47 years old.

title: DESPONDENT PAIR APPARENT SUICIDE
description: Capt. Edward A. Brudno of the Air Force, who spent more than seven of his 33 years in a North Vietnamese prisonerof war camp, was found dead yes terday in the home of his wife's family in Harrison, N.Y., appar ently a suicide.

title: Old. Indian Site Near Stockton Called Delaware Valley's Best
description: STOCKTON, June 3A Uni versity of Pennsylvania arche ology team joined a dig north of here today at a site termed by an expert the best by far in the Delaware Valley for learning about American Indi ans who lived in the East thousands of years before the arrival of the white man.

title: GROWING MOVEMENT DRAWS CATHOLICS
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 3 (AP)More than 20,000 Roman Catholics attended an annual conference here on charismatic renewal of the churchtwice the attendance last year.

title: Environment Day to Mark First Year of World Effort
description: A year after the United Na tions Stockholm Conference began global environmental collaboration in an avalanche of words, the undertaking is gathering substance, sinew and momentum.

title: PRIMARY RIVALS FORESEE DELAYS AT POLLS IN CITY
description: Although the polls will be open seven hours longer than usual, mayoral campaign aides expressed concern yesterday that there would be widespread confusion in today's primary election in the city.

title: RentRise Prospects
description: With hopeful anticipation in many cases and confusion in most, a million New York City families are wondering these days what their rent bills will look like next Jan uary.

title: Aficionados Hail PuenteLupe Reunion
description: The scheduled climax to the Latin Festival offered Saturday night at Madison Square Gar den was the reunion of Tito Puente and La Lupe, and the occasion was celebrated with all due hammy hysteria. Puente and La Lupe, the selfproclaimed king and queen of Latin soul, had split up several years ago. La Lupe, a Cuban migr, had served as Puente's lead singer, an their reunion provoked some enthusiam at the Garden. One doubts, however, that in the long run La Lupe's manic cavorting suits Puente's slicker style.

title: About 14 Are Killed as Jet Explodes and Hits Town
description: PARIS, June 3The Soviet Union's supersonic airliner ex ploded today while tens of thousands of spectators watched it making a demonstration flight at the international air show.impress spectators. The TU144 had been the center of attrac tion at the air Show since May 23, when it arrived from Mos cow. Experts concluded that in its present version, it had been considerably redesigned.

title: Savage Remains Critical
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 3 Swede Savage of Santa Ana, Calif., remained on the critical list in Methodist Hospital today with burns and fractures suf fered when his car crashed dur ing the Indy 500 last Wednes day, Another injured driver, David (Salt) Walther, was transferred to the university of Michigan burns center at Ann Arbor yesterday.

title: Judith Sutton Married To David Storeygard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 3Miss Judith Ann Sutton and David Normann Storey gard were married here this afternoon in the chapel of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The nondenom inational ceremony was per formed by the Rev. Con stance Parvey.

title: Gottehrer Denies PowerBroker Role in Passage of Bill for Sports Authority
description: During the heated argu ments in the City Council and later in the Legislature, as the bill setting up a New York City sports authority was rushed through, there were charges that the chief beneficiary would be the Madison Square Garden Corporation.

title: Ervin Voices Hope for Windup Of Watergate Hearings in June
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., June 3 (UPI)Senator Sam J. Ervin said that Americans should not have to wait to find out the truth behind the Watergate scandal adding he would hope hearings could be completed this month with testimony by key White House aides.

title: Disney Film Retrospective Is a Cornucopia for Fans
description: A comprehensive retrospec tive of Walt Disney films will be presented at Lincoln Cen ter's Alice Tully Hall beginning July 9 and continuing through Aug. 4.

title: 3 Hasidic Jews Are Arraigned In Clash With Brooklyn Police
description: Three Hasidic Jews, were ar raigned early yesterday morn ing on charges resulting from a clash Saturday night between Jews and the police in front of the Lubovitcher headquar tens and synagogue in Brook lyn.

title: $100,000 GOLF WON BY MRS. CORNELIUS
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 3 (AP)  Mrs. Kathy Cornelius shot par on the first extra hole to defeat Mrs, Judy Rankin in a suddendeath playoff in the SealyFaberge golf tournament today.

title: Convicted Killer Gets Degree at Stockton College
description: POMONA, June 3Matthew J. Sheridan, 24 years old, a convicted killer who has spent the last five years in Borden town Reformatory, today be came the first prison inmate to be graduated from a four year college in New Jersey's history.

title: 37 Major U.S. Cities Had 6% Jobless Rates in May
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI)  The number of major metro politan areas with unemploy ment of 6 per cent or more de clined by one in May to 37, the lowest in 29 months, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Cypriote Killed During Vote
description: PAPHOS, Cyprus, June 3 (AP) A Greek Cypriote was shot dead and two others, one a policeman, were wounded today in a flareup of violence associ ated with elections for a new bishop of Paphos. Officials said more than half the registered electors had voted by midday and added that the final turnout was expected to be more than 75 per cent.

title: Bill on Senate Questioning
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)  Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, says he will introduce a bill tomorrow seeking to have members of the Cabinet and heads of Federal agencies appear in the Senate once a week for questions vol untarily at the invitation of the Senate.

title: P.O.W. Called a Suicide
description: An Air Force captain, freed from a North Vietnamese prison camp last February after seven years in captivity, was found dead yesterday in Harrison, N. Y., apparently a suicide. Pentagon officials said the death of the man, Capt. Edward A. Brudno, was the first suicide among re leased American prisoners of war. Details, Page 7.

title: JOSEPH C. KELLY
description: Joseph C. Kelly, an assistant vice president of the Bank of Commerce, who was active in Catholic philanthropies in Brooklyn, died yesterday in the Long leach (L. I.) Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 270 Jay Street in Brooklyn.

title: NEIGHBORS FIGHT A BOSTON CAMPUS
description: BOSTON, June 3  Members of at least 16 civic groups, con cerned over plans for a new University of Massachusetts campus and fearing the demise of their traditional neighbor hoods, have banded together. Representatives of the new group, the Dorchester United Neighborhood Action, contend that university officials have whitewashed the housing and transportation problems that residents will face from the in flux of students to Vie area.

title: P.O.W. Called a Suicide
description: An Air Force captain, freed from a North Vietnamese prison camp last February after seven years in captivity, was found dead yesterday in Harrison, N. Y., apparently a suicide. Pentagon officials said the death of the man, Capt. Edward A. Brudno, was the first suicide among re leased American prisoners of war. Details, Page 7.

title: Hungary Regrets Pullout
description: VIENNA, June 3 (Reuters) The Hungarian Communist party newspaper, Nepszabadsag, said today that Canada's de cision to leave the International Commission of Control and Supervision in South Vietnam was regrettable but that the departure is not tragic and replacing her will certainly not be difficult. Hungary is a mem ber of the truce group along with Indonesia and Poland.

title: Television
Public Asked to Report Irregularities in Voting
description: NEWARK, June 3  United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern called on the public to day to report to his office any information which indic ates any fraudulent or illegal voting practices in Tuesday's primary elections.

title: Guide
description: TOTTING UP The Nation al Computer Conference and Exposition, an annual phe nomenon for a score of years under the aegis of the Amer ican Federation of Informa tion Processing Societies, makes its New York debut today at the New York Coli seum on Columbus Circle. The first and second floors will be jammed with the latest electronic wizardy, of 215 exhibitors displayed in 600 booths (there are also technical seminars and the like going on at the Hilton and the Americana) from noon to 8 today; from 10 to 6 Tuesday through Thurs day; from 9 to noon Friday.

title: L. V. BADER
description: LE ROY, Kan., June 3 (AP) L. V. Bader, who was.a pitcher in the major leagues, died at his home here yesterday. He was 85 years old.

title: India Welcomes Whitlam
description: NEW DELHI, June 3 (UPI) Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia was welcomed by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today as he began a fourday official visit to India.

title: Youth Fare Follies
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board strains the meaning of egalitarianism with its ruling that the airlines must phase but youthfare discounts because such reductions are discriminatory. The theory that lower charges for young people are unfair to adult passengers ignores the inher ent economic disadvantages of youth: lesser earning power, dependence on parents, exclusion from many job opportunities, etc. Particularly when offered on a standby basis to prevent lowfare travelers from taking seats away from the fullfare ones, the youth fare is simply a reasonable adjustment to the economic facts of life.

title: 2 Masked Gunmen in Ulster Kill Man and Woman in Living Room
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 3Masked gunmen burst into a house in the Protestant Old Park section of Belfast to day and killed a man and a woman.

title: A Saigon Helicopter Is Hit by a Missile, Killing All 6 Aboard
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, June 4 (AP)A South Vietnamese helicopter was shot down yesterday by a Soviet made heatseeking missile north of Tay Ninh, 55 miles north west of Saigon, military sources reported today. All six crew men were killed.

title: LUNOKHOD 2 ENDS MOON OPERATIONS
description: MOSCOW, Monday, June 4 The Soviet Union announced early today that its remotely controlled moon rover had ceased its operations on the lunar surface after four months.

title: Nearly All of Central Park's Trees Suffer From Neglect and Poor Care
description: The Parks Department con cedes that many trees in Central Park are badly ne glected, improperly main tained, foolishly planted and, in some cases, dying unnec essarily.

title: Former Judge Ralph Body Dies; Presided at Trial of Ginzburg
description: EARLVILLE, Pa., June 3 (AP) Former United States District Judge Ralph C. Body, who pre sided at Ralph Ginzburg's ob scenity trial, died last night at his summer cottage here. He was 70 years old.

title: Widening Found of Study By Jury of Retail Pricing
description: PHILADELPHIARoom 209 at 928 Market Street is in the secondfloor rear of a non descript building sandwiched between the United States Court House and a small fast food restaurant. For almost year, 22 grand jurymen and women have been intermittent ly meeting in this room for the most sweeping Federal in vestigation of retail pricing in decades.

title: KenHoward, Actor, Weds Louise Sorel
description: Ken Howard, star of the Broadway musical Seesaw, and Louise Sorel, an actress, were married here yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Guedaliahou Shive. The Rev. Howard R. Moody of the Judson Memo rial Church, (BaptistUnited Church of Christ) performed the ceremony.

title: OOSTERIIIIIS WINS BY SHOT M PARIS
description: PARIS, June 3 (AP)Peter Oosterhuis of Britain captured the French open golf champion ship today by one stroke. He carded a 68 for a 72hole total of 280.

title: Fifth Avenue Is a Fiesta At Puerto Rican Parade
description: The city's Puerto Ricans transformed Fifth Avenue into a pulsing, swirling, packed fiesta yesterday, leaping joy fully into the routine of their annual parade up Fifth Avenue.

title: Peron Planning Return To Argentina June 21
description: MADRID, June 3 (Reuters) Former President Juan D. Pern will end 17 years of exile and return to Argentina on June 21. The decision was announced at an airport news conference here by Jose Lepez Rega, for many years Mr. Pern's private sec retary in Madrid and now Minister of Social Welfare In the new Peronist Government in Argentina.

title: New U.S. Prosecutor
description: Mobsters, corrupt public officials, crooked business men and others whose ac tions have drawn the atten tion of the State Commission of Investigation in recent years have acquired a wary respect for the big, cherubic faced 40yearold chairman of the panel, Paul J. Curran, who is expected to be sworn in today to replace Whitney North Seymour Jr. as United States At torney here.

title: Seaver Wins for Mets, 92
description: SAN DIEGO, June 3Tom Seaver pitched the New York Mets out of their trance today with a 92 victory over the San Diego Padres. In the proc ess the Mets lost two more players through injuries.

title: Profile of Soviet Plane Lost at Paris Show
description: Following are the latest available vital statistics on the Russian TU144 super sonic airliner:

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 4, 1973 TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PANAMA CITY, June 3 (UPI)Roberto (Rocky) Duran, World Boxing Association lightweight champion, who suc cessfully defended his crown last night against Hector Thompson of Australia, will probably make his next title defense here in August, his manager said today. Duran, who scored an eightround knogkout over the fifthranked Thompson, could meet Ken Buchanan of Scotland, Esteban de Jesus of Puerto Rico, or anyone else who decides come to Panama, said Carlos Eleta, Duran's manager.

title: Humor Dilutes Tensions in 103d Precinct
description: Police! police! the boy shouted, my brother gone crazy. The boy ran after a police car that was cruising down a dark street in Queens and when the officers in the car heard him they stopped.

title: Pleased Riders Greet PATH's Return
description: The management leaflets dis tributed yesterday at the sta tions in New York and New Jersey said: Welcome back to PATH!

title: C.I.A. MEMOS SHOW POLITICAL FEARS OVER WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Central Intelligence Agency and high White House officials viewed the investigation in the weeks after the Watergate bug ging in June, 1972, as a poten tial political bombshell and not as a legitimate matter of na tional security, according to a series of highlevel C.I.A. mem orandums.

title: Miss Laura Osterweis Is Married
description: Miss Laura Osterweis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven L. Osterweis of New York and Newtown, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to Angelos Stan gos, son of Mr. and Mrs. Triantafilos Stangos of Thes saloniki, Greece.

title: Clash of Candidates on TV Marks Jersey Race Finale
description: NEWARK, June 3The three major aspirants for the Demo cratic gubernatorial nomination in New Jersey's primary elec tion Tuesday defended their positions on the issues this afternoon in a television debate that included the two lesser known candidates for the office.

title: Bridge: If West Had Led the Deuce Of Spades Instead of the 9...
description: The Old Guard of New York bridge clashed with the Young Guard in the final of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship at the New York Hilton here yesterday. The Old Guard was repre sented by Waldemar Von Zedtwitz, fighting indomit ably against the handicap of deteriorating eyesight, Tobias Stone, Philip Feldesman and Ira Rubin, ably supported by Barbara Brier of Miami and Kyle Larsen of San Fran cisco.

title: Weiskopf Gets 68 for 271 And 3Shot Open Victory
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., June 3When I'm playing my best I think I can beat anyone, and that includes Jack Nicklaus, said Tom Weiskopf after he won the Kemper open by three strokes today with a 68 and a 72hole aggregate of 271, or 17 under par. But that doesn't mean I'll beat Jack the next time I play him.

title: Manila Seeks Sugar Buyers
description: MANILA, June 3 (UPI) President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today the Philippines hope to find new markets for her sugar exports, including China. Traditionally the Philippines has supplied sugar to the United States, and he said the nation would fulfill its quota to America. In a nationwide radio television interview, Mr. Marcos announced: I have just author ized a team to go to Geneva to meet with the World Sugar Con ference members.

title: Miner's Trial Opens Today
description: ERIE, Pa., June 3 (UPI) Jury selection will begin tomor row for the trial of Albert E. Pass, the last of seven persons charged in the slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski, insurgent United Mine Workers leader, his wife and daughter. Mr. Pass, 54, years old, of Middlesboro, Ky., is a former financial secretary for District 19 of the U.M.W.

title: Despite Gloomy Prophecies, U.S. Aid To Area States and Cities is on the Rise
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 Despite cutbacks in certain areas of Federal spending, state officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut report that with the help of general revenue sharing, these states have received a substantial in crease in Federal funds.

title: The Dance
description: An offbeat program was provided Saturday night when Roma, billed as a gyp sy song and dance company from Poznan, Poland, made its American debut at the Fashion Industries High School Auditorium.

title: INQUIRY ON CRASH OF SHIPS TO OPEN
description: A Coast Guard board of in quiry will be convened here today to determine why an out bound American cargo ship turned off course suddenly and knifed into a Belgian tanker at anchor in the Narrows of New York Harbor early Satur day.

title: 2 GOODRICH PLANTS APPROVE NEW PACT
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 3 (AP) Locals of the United Rubber Workers at two of seven B. F. Goodrich Company plants rati fied a tentative contract agree ment today with the company.

title: Justice First
description: WASHINGTON  Great shocks churn up great waves. The shock of Watergate has posed a question fun damental to our system of government: Is the courtroom or the hearing room the best place to arrive at the truth?

title: Red Smith
description: You hardly ever see graduation exercises like these today, or photographs to remember them by. The picture shows David Sarnoff, President of Radio Corporation America; Jim Tierney, secretary of the New York Giants; Owen D. Young of General Electric, a trustee of St. Law rence University; Secretary of the Treasury Ogden Mills, the commencement orator; Dr. Richard Eddy Sykes, presi dent of St. Lawrence and William Harry Terry, the Giants manager and first baseman. Standing tall in his academic robes between Young and Mills, clutching his diploma in a large and calloused fist, Hal Schumacher, The Graduate. The date was June 12, 1933, and it must have been the only time since Doubleday that an en tire major league baseball team traveled all night to see its youngest pitcher become a Bachelor of Science.

title: Sick Elms Stayed Up Too Long
description: Dutch elm disease is a con stant threat to all elms. It is caused by a fungus that is spread by bark beetles and it is incurable. When a tree has the disease, it must be destroyed, preferably before May 1, when the beetles emerge and infect other elms.

title: Accountant Tells of Tactics To Disrupt Muskie's Drive
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 3 (UPI)An accountant who has pleaded guilty to charges of disrupting last year's Demo cratic Presidential primary in Florida says smoke bombs, phony signs and heckling were also used to sabotage the cam paign, according to today's edi tions of The St. Petersburg Times.

title: Sea View Transformed Into Geriatrics Hospital
description: One of the oldest hospitals in the city quietly assumed new identity yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Josephine Baker Speaks As Artist and as Person
description: Josephine Baker celebrated her 67th birthday yesterday with a press conference at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Pravda's News of U.S. Doesn't All Fit
description: MOSCOW, June 3  Ivan Ivanovich, the Russian John Doe, settled back with his Sunday papers on this sum mery day to read all about the United.States. A confused picture emerged.

title: American League
description: Monday, June 4, 1973

title: VEGETABLE PRICES RISE 1C10C HERE
description: Meat prices again remained at their ceilings last week and in some stores some vegetab?? prices increased from 1 to 10 cents a pound, according ?? price reporters of the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

title: MRS. DAVID BLUM
description: Mrs, Evelyn Ferderber Blum, wife of David Blum, a lawyer, died Saturday at the Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived here and in Long Valley, N.J.

title: Notification on Black Lung
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)  The Labor Department said today that it was notifying 8,000 present and former coal mine operators about the re vised black lung benefits pro gram. Federal law requires the operators to begin paying on Jan. 1, 1974, benefits and medi cal costs to miners disabled by black lung disease or to their survivors.

title: Sports Today
Briefs On The Arts
description: The more than 36,000 re cording musicians of the 315, 000member American Feder ation of Musicians will re ceive a total of $7.2million from the Phonograph Record Manufacturers Special Pay ments Fund, according to Hal C. Davis, president of the federation. The musicians are slated to receive the allot ments Sept. 1. All members who have made recordings since 1969 will be included.

title: Western Citrus Farmers Harvest Profits Abroad
description: VAN NUYS, Calif., June 3 Exports, particularly to Com nunist nations, promise to ease a decadeslong dilemma of the Western citrus industry.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: State Justices' President
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., June 3 (AP)Justice Charles Margett, administrative judge of the State Supreme Court in Queens, was installed yesterday as president of the Association of Supreme Court Justices of the State of New York, which is composed of all the Supreme Court justices and retired jus tices.

title: Malave to Box Lampkin On Felt Forum Series Tonight
description: Chu Chu Malave of New York headlines the opening card of the Felt Forum boxing series tonight when he faces Ray Lampkin of Portland, Ore., in a 10round junior welter weight bout.

title: W.B.C. Lists Foreman In Tokyo Bout Sept. 1
description: MEXICO CITY, June 3 (AP)The World Boxing Council authorized yester day a title fight between the world heavyweight cham pion, George Foreman, and Jose (King) Roman of Puerto Rico.

title: Purchasing Agents Find Business Hard to Improve
description: Business was so good in the early months of this year that it is having a hard time getting better, according to the latest survey of purchasing agents by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: FARM BILL STIRS OFFICIAL CONCERN
description: WASHINGTON, June 3Ad ministration officials are ex pressing growing concern about a sleeper provision in the omni bus farm bill pending before the Senatea provision impos ing a permanent system of im port quotas on dairy pioducts.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The police are continuing an intensive search for the killers of an offduty police officer who was shot when he tried to stop an attempted robbery by four men in a West Side bar. The slain patrolman, 23yearold Robert B. Laurenson, a twoyear man on the force, was killed outside Pat's Bar and Grill at 155 Amsterdam Avenue, near 67th Street, where he had gone with two other officers after going off duty shortly before 3 A.M. Saturday.

title: Toros, Stars Win in Soccer; Lancers, Atoms in 00 Tie
description: The Miami Toros and the St. Louis Stars were outplayed in North American Soccer League action yesterday, but they tri umphed over Toronto and Mon treal, respectively while the Rochester Lancers and the Phil adelphia Atoms fought to scoreless tie.

title: Chagall to Visit Soviet First Time Since 1922
description: MOSCOW, June 3 (Reuters) Marc Chagall will return to his native Russia tomorrow for his first visit in over half a century, informed sources said today.

title: MURDER VIEWED AS PROFESSIONAL
description: WOODBOURNE, N. Y., June 3 The Sullivan County District Attorney, Louis B. Scheinman, said today that the murder of Dr. Jos Gil had been a pro fessional job and a spokesman for the state police said it had gangland overtones.

title: OPTIONS STUDIED IN SKYLAB PLIGHT
description: HOUSTON, June 3  Space engineers are studying two other ways of supplying addi tional electricity to the power short Skylab space station, should the astronauts fail in their second attempt to free a jammed solarpower wing.

title: Clark Clifford
description: WASHINGTON  As each new chapter in the Watergate tragedy un folds, I have an increasing sense of grim foreboding as I look at the future. The extent of the damage already sustained, and the worsening of the Administration's posture as further revelations occur, emphasize the fact that this is no time for partisanship. This is the time for Americans to work together to save this country.

title: Four in House Report Other Business Activity
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)A report filed by a citizen's lobbying group says four New Jersey Representa tives maintain active outside financial interests.

title: INTEREST RATES CONTINUE SURGE
description: The credit markets continue to display scant outward indi cation that surging interest rates are likely to be arrested any time soon. A tightened Fed eral Reserve credit policy, bear ing down on what is nothing less than a fullblown economic boom, is producing rates in the shortterm market reminiscent of the peaks seen in 196970, and banks are still bid ding eagerly for money as the mid June taxpayment date for corporations ap proaches.

title: Minnesota Wins in 14th, 76; Gains College World Series
description: CARBONDALE, Ill., June 3 (UPI)Minnesota scored a 76 victory over Southern Illinois in 14 innings to win the Na tional Collegiate District 4 base ball title today.

title: Some Donors to Nixon Campaign Fund Demanding  and Getting  Refunds
description: WASHINGTON, June 3Dis illusioned contributors to Pres ident Nixon's $50million re election campaign fund are complaining that they were misled or betrayed by Mr. Nix on's fund raisers and that their money helped to pay for politi cal crimes. Some are even de mandingand receivingtheir money back.

title: USAC Orders Changes in Wing Span, and Fuel Load for 500Mile Pocono Race
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 3 Acting to improve racing safety and to decrease speed in championship events in the wake of the recent tragedies during the running of the Indianapolis 500, the United States Auto Club yes terday announced major changes in the aerodynamics and fuel loads of champion ship race cars July 1. He said that cars should be modified prior to that to participate in practice runs beginning June 18.

title: At Disaster Site, Talk of Narrow Escapes and Grief for Villagers Who Died
description: GOUSSAINVILLE, France, June 3Tiled roofs were col lapsed and smoke rose from the rubble of little stucco houses in this town near Le Bourget Airport this after noon after the explosion that destroyed the Soviet super sonic airliner.

title: PATIT's Welcome Back! Finds Riders Glad to Be
description: The management leaflets dis tributed yesterday at the sta tions in New York and New Jersey said: Welcome back to PATH!

title: Perry Wins at Road Atlanta
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga., June 3 (AP)  Geoff Perry won the 75mile Kawasaki Dixie National Championship motorcycle road race today at Road Atlanta in a photofinish over Kel Carruthers of San Di ego. Perry, of Santa Fe Springs, Calif., won by less than a foot. Perry was aboard a Suzuki. Car ruthers rode a Yamaha.

title: Billy Graham Calls Crowd In Seoul Largest of Career
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 3 The Rev. Billy Graham left Seoul for Tokyo on his way home today after preaching to what he said was the largest crowd of his career on the last day of his fiveday crusade here.

title: Perry Wins at Road Atlanta
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga., June 3 (AP)  Geoff Perry won the 75mile Kawasaki Dixie National Championship motorcycle road race today at Road Atlanta in a photofinish over Kel Carruthers of San Di ego. Perry, of Santa Fe Springs, Calif., won by less than a foot. Perry was aboard a Suzuki. Car ruthers rode a Yamaha.

title: Soccer Results
description: GERMANAMERICAN LEAGUE

title: 34 Years of Franco Marked
description: MADRID, June 3 (UPI)Sol diers marched and jet fighters roared overhead today in a dis play of armed might marking the 34th anniversary of Gen eralissimo Francisco Franco's defeat of republican forces in the Spanish Civil War.

title: Eleanor Faust Becomes Bride Of John C. Levy
description: Miss Eleanor Faust, man aging editor of The ORT Re porter, and John Corcos Levy, a New York lawyer, were married here at noon yesterday in Temple Shearith Israel (the Spanish and Por tuguese Synagogue). The Rev. Dr. Louis C. Gerstein and Cantor Abraham L. Cardozo officiated.

title: WHIPP HYDRO FIRST IN PRESIDENT'S CUP
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) Gene Whipp of Dayton, Ohio, drove the battered, patchedup Lincoln Thrift to victory today in his first unlimited hydroplane race in the President's Cup regatta on the Potomac River.

title: MRS. JAMES RAWLE 2D
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 3 Mrs. Mary Morris Rawle, who founded and directed a nursery school here for 35 years, died today at her home, Castlefinn Farm. She was 61 years old and the widow of James Rawle 2d, an antiquarian.

title: Pesticide Rule Corrected
description: SEATTLE, June 3 (UPI) A Labor Department official says new Federal pesticide regulations for apple orchards will keep farmworkers out for three days after spraying in stead of the previously an nounced five days. He said published regulations, to take effect June 18, had included an incorrect announcement on farmworker reentry time.

title: Banks Try to Slow Lending
description: The nation's largest banks say, practically without excep tion, that they are making strenuous efforts to slow the pace of their lending to big business. Prime targets for re straint are loans to finance nonproductive mergers, to fi nance companies and to real estate investment trusts.

title: A Man Is Found Hanged In Old Brooklyn Theater
description: A man was found hanged in the abandoned Brooklyn Palace theater in Brownsville last night by firemen who were sum moned to put out a small fire.

title: Jericho, Huntington Play A 6.6 Overtime Tie in Polo
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., June 3 The Jericho and Huntington polo teams played to a 66 overtime tie today at Bethpage State Park. A goal by Mike Gerard with 30 seconds left to play in regulation time over came a 65 deficit for Jericho, and sent the match into a scoreless extra period.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: OCEANPORT, June 3Everything's coming up roses and petunias, geranium's and ivy.

title: Despite Gloomy Prophecies, U.S. Aid To Area States and Cities Is on the Rise
WORLD MR I UNIT HOLDS A REUNION
description: NEWARK, June 3Their step slightly more hesitant and their memories for details dimming, 25 veterans of World War gathered here today for their 56th annual reunion.

title: Greek Opposition Says Abolition of Monarchy Avoids Crucial Question of Democracy or Dictatorship
description: ATHENS, June 3Leaders of the political opposition intensi fied their campaign today against the Greek Government, declaring that the abolition of the monarchy was an illegal act designed to deceive the Greek people and the world.

title: Knits in Combination
description: The liveliest new Kimberly fash ions for fall involve a combination of patterned knits with plain ones. Many of the patterns are on the vest, sweater or shirt that accom pany the nowstandard Kimberly pants suit. Sometimes the pants are patterned.

title: Mrs. Johnson Relates Her Views on Happiness
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 3 (UPI)Speaking at the University of Virginia commencement today, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson stressed individual action and faith in the future as the keys to happiness in later life.

title: Today's Primaries
description: Party primaries are being held throughout New York State and in New York City todayfor administrative reasons this election comes on a Monday instead the usual Tuesday.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Excerpts From Series of Pravda Articles on U.S.
description: MOSCOW, June 3Follow ing are excerpts from a re cent series of articles about the United States written by Boris Strelnikov, Washing ton correspondent of Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, and by Vasily Peskov of Komsomolskaya Pravda, the youth daily:

title: Fleming and Miss Goldman Capture Junior Net Finals
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I. June 3Peter Fleming of Cha tham, N.J., and Barbara Gold man of Fort Lee, N.J., won 18 years' division finals today in the Eastern Lawn Tennis As sociation junior championships at the Port Washington Acad emy.

title: Dance: Fun at Concert
description: There are very few really funny ballets in the interna tional repertory. To be sure, there are those that offer the occasional chuckle, but, at least for this observer, the ones that remain consistently amusing, however many times you see them, can be counted on the thumbs of two hands. They are Fred erick Ashton's A Wedding Bouquet, for Britain's Royal Ballet, and Jerome Robbins's The Concert, which was given last night for the first time this season by New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater. It is sim ple and gorgeous.

title: 15,000 at CoOp City Celebrate Approach of Summer
description: For several hours yester day afternoon, the sounds of music and the smells of eth nic foods permeated the great meadow in CoOp City in the Bronx. About a third of the community's 45,000 residents showed up to celebrate the approach of summer at a fes tival sponsored by the Com munity Life Forum, a coali tion of 312 clubs and cau cuses in the neighborhood.

title: Come Home, Mr. Vesco
description: Robert L. Vesco, former board chairman of Investors Overseas Service, has emerged from seclusion in Costa Rica long enough to tell newsmen that he would not return to the United States unless a special prosecutor were appointed to assure independent, objective handling of the charges against him.

title: Rush To judgment
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The process of repairing this country's institutions from the damage of Watergate has come to an early and extremely seri ous point of crisis. It lies in the con flict between Senator Ervin's commit tee and the special prosecutor, Archi bald Cox.

title: Morocco Gains in Soccer
description: RABAT, Morocco, June 3 (Agence FrancePresse)  Mo rocco defeated Ivory Coast, 41, today in the second leg of their world soccer cup African groups' elimination series at Tetuan, northern Mo rocco.
