The first leg ended in a 111 draw in Abidjan. Morocco thus became the first country to qualify for the fournation African area finals.

title: Advertising: 5 Andys for D. D. B.
description: The first advertising awards of the New York season were distributed Friday by the Ad vertising Club of New York at its 10th annual Andy Awards program, and Doyle Dane Bernbach; Needham, Harper & Steers, and Grey Advertising were the multiple winners.

title: Dissident Antioch Students Vow to Continue Striking
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, June 3 (UPI)  Dissident Anti och College students announced today that they would try to retake campus buildings to morrow and risk arrest for violating a court injunction against their strike that has closed the school since April 20.

title: ISRAEL EXCHANGES 56 P.O.W.'S FOR 3
description: JERUSALEM, June 3Israel released 56 Syrian and Leba nese prisoners of war today in return for three captured Israeli pilots. It was the first mutual exchange of prisoners across Israel's northern fron tiers in three and a half years.

title: PEARSON TAKES MASONDIXON 500
description: DOVER, Del., June 3 (AP) David Pearson lost an eight second lead during a yellow light situation today but re gained command through the final 86 miles and won the MasonDixon 500 stock car race.

title: C. B. Wrightsman Gives N.Y.U. Unit $1Million
description: Charles B. Wrightsman, oil Industrialist, art collector and philanthropist, has donated $1million to the endowment of New York University's In stitute of Fine Arts on his retirement as a trustee. Mr. Wrightsman, former presi dent of Standard Oil of Kan sas, made his donation to as sist in matching a Ford Foun dation grant. This year, the Andrew W. Mellon Founda tion also gave $1million to the Institute of Fine Arts, which occupies the James B. Duke house at 1 East 78th Street. It offers graduate studies in art history.

title: Libya Extends Cultural Revolution to Broadcasting
description: CAIRO, June 3Col. Muam mar elQaddafi, the President of Libya, took his cultural revo lution a big step further last night, in the process creating new obstacles to the merger with Egypt scheduled on Sept. 1.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1973
description: International

title: About 14 Are Killed as Jet Explodes and Hits Town
description: PARIS, June 3The Soviet Union's supersonic airliner ex ploded today while tens of thousands of spectators watched it making a demonstration flight at the international air show.

title: Clash of Candidates on TV Marks Jersey Race Finale
description: NEWARK, June 3The three major aspirants for the Demo, cratic gubernatorial nomination in New Jersey's primary elec tion Tuesday defended their positions on the issues this afternoon in a television debate that included the two lesser known candidates for the office.

title: 60,108 on Bat Day See Yankees Defeat Angels, 32
description: Before the largest Yankee Stadium crowd in three years 60,108 customers of whom 39,272 collected Little League bats by being under 15 years of agethe Yankees concluded a successful home stand yester day by holding off the Califor nia Angels in the ninth inning for a 32 victory.

title: Personal Finance: Obligations on Rental Property
description: Arizona made a bit of le gal history early in May when it became the first state to enact a law based on the Uniform Residential Landlord and Tenant Act.

title: Crash Raises Doubts On Engine Redesign
description: The Russian TU144 super sonic airliner that crashed yes terday incorporated recent major design changes that in creased engine power, length ened the fuselage and raised passenger capacity from 120 to 140.

title: Toros, Stars Win in Soccer; Lancers, Atoms in 00 Tie
description: The Miami Toros and the St. Louis Stars were outplayed in North. American Soccer League action yesterday, but they tri umphed over Toronto and Mon treal, respectively while the Rochester Lancers and the Phil adelphia Atoms fought to a scoreless tie.

title: STEWART EQUALS GRAND PRIX MARK
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, June 3  Jackie Stewart com pleted an errorfree week today when he drove away with an other Monaco Grand Prix title, thus equaling a driving record of his late friend and country man, Jimmy Clark. Clark was killed in 1968 after he had dominated the drivers' scene, scoring 25 Grand Prix victories.

title: Pressure Grows for U.S. Rules on Intrauterine Devices
description: Charges last week that cer tain intrauterine devices are not as safe or effective as their manufacturers contend have created pressures in Congress that may lead ultimately to a longawaited requirement that the birth control devices be cleared for marketing by the Federal Food and Drug Ad ministration.

title: Argentine Guerrillas Free Businessman for $1Million
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 3 (Reuters)Guerrillas who held an Argentine executive hostage for 10 days released him today after his company paid a ran som of $1million.

title: Western Visitors in China Complain About the Inflation There, Too
description: PEKING, June 3Foreigners in China, a land that has purged itself of many of the chronic social scourges, are finding themselves the victims of a scourge that has long plagued the capitalist West inflation.

title: WIRETAP DISPUTE STIRS MIAMI AREA
description: MIAMI, June 3  Recently The Miami News published cartoon depicting a judge talk ing on the telephone in his chambers. The caption read. I'll be home by 6. Goodbye dear. Good night Sheriff Purdy.

title: Nixon Greets Tourists On Return to Capital
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)  President Nixon shook hands with sightseers near the White House today after he returned for a weekend at Camp David, Md.

title: Accident Seen as Major Blow To Soviet Hope for World Sales
description: MOSCOW, June 3The crash of the TU144 airliner in Paris was viewed here as a major blow to the Soviet Union's am bitions to corner at least part of the world's supersonic air line market in the next few years.

title: Taiwan's Economy Booms Despite Political Setbacks
description: KAOHSIUNG, Taiwan  The reduced international status of the Chinese Nationalist Govern ment here has caused no slow down in Taiwan's economic boom.

title: Miss Aschner CoWinner
description: WOODBURY, L. I., June 3 Marilyn Aschner of Holliswood, Queens, and Sue Lackey of Port Washington, L. I., defeat ed Simmy Stockman of Locust Valley, L. I., and Christine Howe of Greenwich, Conn., 64, 63, to win the Eastern wom en's hardcourt doubles tennis championship today at the Woodbury Country Club.

title: Transit Patrolman Shot on Bronx IRT; Passenger Also Hit
description: A transit policeman patrol ing an IRT subway train in the Bronx was shot in the shoulder shortly after midnight this morning as he made his way through the moving train, the police reported.

title: A.M.A. Membership Off
description: CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) The American Medical Associa tion announced today that its 1972 duespaying membership was 155,861, a drop of 338 from 1971. There are about 50, 000 additional members who are not required to pay dues, including physicians who work for the government and those over age 70.

title: ETHER OF KING SEEN AS HIS SPUR
description: ROME, June 3Former Queen Frederika is urging her son, King Constantine II, to fight the military Government of Greece more actively than he has in the last few years, well informed Greeks here say.

title: Paris: Rolf Liebermann at the Opera
description: PARISThe Theatre Na tional de l'Opera has just re opened, after a yearlong in terruption, under the man agement of Rolf Liebermann, whose ability to revive mori bund lyrical stages is well known. He will need all of this ability, for to the prob lems facing the lyric drama all over the worldboth cul turally and eco nomically it ap pears anachro nisticthe Paris Opera adds some specific lo cal headaches. It is a state institution and, as such, has for generations been beset by nepotism, whitecollaritis, routine. Everybody, from propshifter to primadonna, had come to be obsessed with hierarchic advancement, wage increases, working hour decreases and pensions, to the exclusion of such less er concerns as music. This, then, was the Opera's last chance.

title: Strengthening Family Solidarity With a Home Evening Program
description: To many casual observers, the American family of the mid20th century appears headed down the drain in a swirl of divorce, drugs, venereal disease, alcohol, adultery and group sex.

title: College, School Baseball
description: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT

title: WOMAN REMISE IS SLAIN IN HOTEL
description: Nobody can tell you much about her because she was a real loner, said a desk clerk at the Times Square Motor Ho tel, where an eccentric 70year old resident was found stabbed to death in a fourthfloor lava tory Saturday afternoon.

title: JEWISH SEMINARY HAS GRADUATION
description: Continuing prosecution of wartime Nazi criminals is a moral issue on which humanity must take a stand, Simon Wiesenthal, head of the Jewish Documentation Center in Vien na, told an audience of 600 at the commencement dinner of the Hebrew Union College Jewish Institute of Religion last night at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Sales Rose 1.6% in May At 7 City Department Stores
description: Seven of New York City's largest department stores re corded a minimal gain in sales in May, averaging 1.6 per cent over the yearago month, ac cording to a monthly survey by The New York Times.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: SEYMOUR URGES BREAKUP OF F.B.I.
description: Less than 48 hours after he resigned as United States At torney for the Southern District of New York, Whitney North Seymour Jr. proposed yesterday the breaking up of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Vietnam Veterans, Honored in Dallas, Salute the People
description: DALLAS, June 3 (UPI)A cheering crowd expressed ap preciation to the servicemen who fought in Vietnam. The servicemen reciprocated by praising the crowd.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Plane Crash Off Atlantic City Kills

title: Nixon Offers 4 Plans To Share More Revenues
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 In addition to general rev enue sharing, the Nixon Ad ministration has made four special revenuesharing pro posals on manpower pro grams, education, urban de velopment and law enforce ment.

title: Consumers Advised to Use Protection of the Law; Bank Is Alerting Stores to CreditCard Swindlers
description: EDISON, June 3The trou ble with too many consum ers is, that they don't know enough about existing laws for their own protection, Leonard R. Busch, a New Brunswick lawyer told a daylong conference on con sumer concerns at the Mid dlesex Community College here last week. Mr. Busch, who worked for VIS TA as a legal services lawyer for one year be fore going into private prac tice, did not exempt his fel low lawyers who, he said, have also failed to keep pace.

title: BARRETT WENDELL, CHICAGO BANKER, 92
description: Barrett Wendell, who headed the Chicago office of the Lee Higginson Corporation, invest ment bankers, from 1941 to 1956, died yesterday in Lake Forest (Ill.) Hospital. He was 92 years old and lived in Chicago and formerly in Hamilton, Mass.

title: Dance: Three Programs
description: A cluster of three dance programs over the weekend explored the imaginative use of props, sheer movement and an unusual space. The most completely realized of the three was Memories, Dreams and Reflections, an enjoyable program of dances created by Micki Goodman at Dance Theater Workshop Saturday evening that in cluded new and repertory works.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Before the Democrats begin to sali vate in contemplation of the 1976 Presidential elections, I suggest that they recall the historical ability of Republican administrations to ride out the most sordid of past scandals in volving the Executive Branch of the Government.

title: Jericho, Huntington Play A 66 Overtime Tie in Polo
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., June 3 The Jericho and Huntington polo teams played to a 66 overtime tie today at Bethpage State Park. A goal by Mike Gerard with 30 seconds left to play in regulation time over came a 6.5 deficit for Jericho, and sent the match into a scoreless extra period.

title: South Dakota Senator Seeks CrudeOil Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) Senator James Abourezk, Democrat of South Dakota, charged today that major oil companies had artificially con trived an oil and gasoline shortage by deliberately with holding crude oil supplies from Middle West independent re fineries.

title: Dr. G. Peter Jessel Weds Miss Seegal
description: BRIDGEPORT, Com, June 3Miss Rhonda Lynn Seegal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Seegal of Stratford, was married here this after noon to Dr. G. Peter Jesse!, son of Mrs. Julius Seligman of Forest Hills, Queens, New York, and the late Dr. Wal ter Jessel.

title: At Disaster Site, There Is Talk of Escapes and Grief for Villagers Who Died
description: GOUSSAINVILLE, France, June 3Tiled roofs were col lapsed and smoke rose from the rubble of little stucco houses in this town near Le Bourget Airport this after noon after the explosion that destroyed the Soviet super sonic airliner.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Roundup: Alter 178 Games, Hegan Makes an Error at First Base
description: The rap against Mike Hegan has always been, good field, not hit. It has been the major reason the Oakland A's are the fourth American League team he has played for since he came up with the Yankees at the tailend of the 1964 season.

title: McCloskey to Ask House To Weigh Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, June 3Rep resentative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., Republican of California, announced today that he would ask the House of Representa tives to consider whether Presi dent Nixon should be im peached for obstruction of justice.

title: New Executor Is Named For Long Estate by Judgel
description: BOWLING GREEN, Mo., June 3 (UPI)Judge J. Overton Fry disclosed over the weekend that he had named James G. Rittenbaum executor and trustee of the estate of the late former Senator Edward V. Long.

title: Fischer's Friends Wonder if He'll Play Chess Again
description: Friends of Bobby Fischer, the chess champion of the world, are beginning to wonder if he will ever play again.

title: ERNEST A. GSELL
description: NEWARK, June 3  Ernest A. Gsell, president of the Textile Trimming and Finishing Corpo ration, died here yesterday. He was 74 years old and lived in West Orange.

title: Andrea Siegel Interne's Bride
description: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., June 3Miss Andrea Leigh Siegel and Dr. Joseph Feinberg were married here this morning in Temple Beth Israel by Rabbi Richard Messing.

title: Point Park College in Pittsburgh, Beset by Money Woes, Fails to Meet Monthly Payroll
description: PITTSBURGH, June 3Beset by financial problems, Point Park College failed last week to meet its $253,000 monthly payroll for 445 employes.

title: Transcripts of Excerpts From the C.I.A. Memorandums About the Watergate Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 3Following are excerpts from nine memorandums and a note of transmittal by Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters, deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and a memorandum by James R. Schlesinger, Director of Central Intelligence, that were supplied last month to a Senate Appropriations subcom mittee in connection with its investigation of the Watergate case. The excerpts were transcribed by The New York Times from photocopies of the original docu ments. The first is a covering note apparently provided to the subcommittee prior to General Walters's testi mony last month. The excerpts appear in chronological order.

title: Mrs. Court Takes Title In France for 5th Time
description: PARIS, June 3 (AP)  Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia captured her fifth French ten nis championship as she posted a 67, 76, 64 victory today over 18yearold Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Partial Observers
description: Canada's decision to withdraw its ceasefire observers from Vietnam is understandable, but regrettable. The great Canadian contribution in Vietnam these past months has been an activist determination to contribute as much as poisible to help end the fighting. But, as the chief Canadian delegate put it: We came here to super vise a ceasefire. In fact what we have been doing is observing a war.

title: Gaither Ending Career
description: TALLAHASEE, Fla., June 3 (UPI)Alonzo Smith (Jake) Gaither, football coach at Flor ida A. and M. for 25 years and a legendary figure in black col lege athletics, will retire as ath letic director Aug. 31, the school announced today. Gaither coached the Rattlers to more than 200 football victories over a quarter of a century. He over came cancer and blindness dur ing his long career and became athletic director after stepping down coach in 1969.

title: Petersen Faces an Inquiry On His Waier gate Actions
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The Watergate special prosecu tion team has decided to investigate the conduct of Henry E. Petersen, the Assistant Attorney General who supervised the Watergate inquiry for nearly a year and was placed in sole charge by President Nixon in midApril.

title: Informant Against Mafia in State Flees U.S. Guards After Cover Is Exposed
description: Gerald Martin Zelmanowitz, a confessed bond thief who has furnished pivotal testimony for the Government in two New Jersey Mafia trials, last week eluded United States marshals who had been pro tecting him from possible un derworld reprisals, a Justice De partment source said yester day.

title: KISSINGER IS TAKING ZIEGLER TO PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 Henry A. Kissinger will be ac companied by Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, when he flies to Paris tomorrow to resume talks with Mr. Tho's deputy, Tho, Hanoi's thief negotiator, on strengthening the Vietnam cease  fire agreement, the White House said today.

title: Harvard Exam Rescheduled; Students Had Advance Word
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 4 (AP)Students taking market ing at the Harvard Graduate School of Business will have to face another final examination this fall.

title: Dibbs Wins in Berlin
description: BERLIN, June 4 (UPI)  Eddie Dibbs of Miami beat Pat Hombergen of Belgium, 60, 67, 60, 64, in the first round of the West Berlin international tennis tournament today. George (Butch) Seewagen, the Co lumbia University coach, ous ted Hans Engert of Germany, 75, 76, 61.

title: DR. JOSEPH R. RIDLON
description: GORHAM, Me., June 4Dr. Joseph R. Ridlon, medical di rector of the United States Pub lic Health Service from 1934 until he retired in 1946, died Saturday in the Maine Medical Center in Portland. Dr. Ridlon was 91 years old.

title: ExU.M.W. Head to Testify In Yablonski Murder Trial
description: ERIE, Pa., June 4 (UPI) W. A. Boyle, deposed president of the United Mine Workers, his successor and a convicted union official were named today as prosecution witnesses in the trial of Albert E. Pass, a former union officer charged in the 1969 slaying of Joseph A. Ya blonski, a union reformer, and is wife and daughter.

title: The Primary
description: Mayor

title: DRIVER WHO RAMMED AN AIRLINER IS FREED
description: ST. LOUIS, June 4 (UPI) Charges were dropped today against David Hanley, a busi nessman who rammed his car into the nose gear of a jetliner last June 24 in an effort to halt the plan from being hijaceked.

title: STOCKS OFF AGAIN ON AMEX AND OTC
ABBOTT PAIGE MILLS, WASHINGTONLAWYER
description: WASHINGTON, June 4Ab bott Paige Mills, for 53 years lawyer here, died yesterday in the Washington Hospital Cen ter of burns suffered the pre vious Sunday. He was 83 years old.

title: Maryland Team Voted No. 1 In Final Lacrosse Standing
description: Maryland, unsurprisingly, was named the No. 1 lacrosse team in the nation yesterday in the season's coaches' poll. The vote was unanimous.

title: Upstate Mayoralty Race
description: HUDSON, N. Y., June 4 (AP)Former Mayor Samuel T. Wheeler defeated the incum bent, Mayor Elmer R. Sheffer, in today's primary election for the Republican nomination to the city hall post. Mr. Sheffer announced that he would run as an independent in November. Mr. Wheeler, who was Mayor in the nineteensixties, will also face Thomas Shriver, a Demo crat, in the general election.

title: Kuwait Stresses Defense
description: KUWAIT, June 4 Kuwait, the wealthiest of the Persian Gulf oil sheikdoms, said today that the $500million in arms that she is arranging to pur chase from the West was not for use against anybody but for her own defense. Official sources said that the arms would be used to protect the nation's enormous oil re sources.

title: Karpov Is Quickly Becoming Chess: A Man for All Seasonings
description: How strong is Anatoly Kar pov?

title: Overhauling Aid
description: Committees in both houses of Congress have moved in recent weeks to revise drastically President Nixon's for eign assistance program, which Chairman J. W. Fulbright of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has already dismissed as a relic of the past.

title: Bridge:
description: A remarkable veteran who won his first title a half cen tury ago, before contract bridge was invented, added another to his long list of tournament successes during the weekend at the New York Hilton. Waldemar Von Zedtwitz, at the age of 77, captained the winning team in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, which he first won in 1937.

title: D.A. IS EASY VICTOR
description: Manhattan's Mr. District At torney, Frank S. Hogan, yes terdav overcame the first chal lengein his 32year reign aid easily defeated William J. van den Heuvel in the Democratic primary.

title: COLUMBIA IS BALKED IN BID TO MRS. THANH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 (AP)A South Vietna mese Government spokesman said today that Columbia Uni versity should forward its in vitation for a teaching chair for Mrs. Ngo Ba Thanh either to North Vietnam or the Viet cong because she would soon be released to the Communists.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Review Denied in Flag Defiling

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES RISE TO A RECORD
description: Continuing to show spec tacular price advances, the July soybean contract yesterday jumped 80 cents a bushel to a record of $12.12 a bushel. By contrast the low for this de livery was $3.27 about a year ago.

title: RAIL TAX DEDUCTION BARRED BY COURT
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)  The Supreme Court ruled today, by 62, that a railroad was not entitled to a tax deduc tion for dpereciation of Govern mentfinanced facilities.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Pilot's Remains Found In Vietnam After 8 Years
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 (AP)A United States military team has found the re mains of an American pilot whose plane crashed eight years ago in South Vietnam, a United States Embassy source reported today.

title: Today Is Environment Day
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) President Nixon proclaimed tomorrow as World Environ ment Day in the nation and called on Americans today to conduct appropriate observ ances to stress their concern for a better environment in which to live.

title: Man Sought in Slaying Is Apprehended Upstate
description: ROCHESTER, June 4 (AP) The police said, a man wanted in Pennsylvania on a murder charge was captured in subur ban Greece today after a high speed chase. Identified as John Delmar Taylor, 26 years old, of Meadville, Pa., the man was said to be wanted on murder and robbery charges in the death Friday night of Arthur G. Stolz, 55, of Cochranton, Pa.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Advertising: 71 Clios Distributed
description: The people who make TV commercials, always eager for recognition by their flocked last ngiht in their versions of formal wear to Philharmonic Hall in Lincoln Center for the 14th annual Clio Awards, the most osten tatious display in New York advertising circles.

title: Nixon Moves Vex Urban Coalition
description: WASHINGTON, June 4  A coalition of black and white rich and poor, young and old that met here last week was reminiscent of the civil rights days of the sixties, goingthrougt all the motions except joining hands and singing We Shall Overcome.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN THE DAYS OF SIMON STERN. By Arthur A. Cohen. 464 pages. Random House. $8.95.What is the novelist's imagination to seize uponespecially if it belongs to an American Jew, torn, as it must apparently be, between the ancient demands of tradi tion and the modem pressures of assimila tion? Saul Bellow's imagination doesn't seize, it sociolo gizes. Philip Roth's cracks Jokes, tears of laughter dis torting its Visions. Herman Wolin comes to attention, salutes the Ameri can flag. Allen Ginsberg's howls. And now, into this company steps the imagination of Arthur A. Cohen, and in his new novel, In the Days of Simon Stern, he attempts noth ing less than to embrace the an cient tradition, transplant it whole into the new world, and thusastonishinglypersuades us that the newish novelist's imagination need not be torn at all. For consider God's serv ant, Simon Stern, the charming charismatic hero of Mr. cohen's second novel (his first was The Carpenter Years, a somewhat thin book in which the author, previously a theologian, learned the babysteps of fic tionwriting).

title: COLLECTOR PLANS MAJOR ART SALE
description: Robert C. Scull, the art pa tron and taxi excutive, will sell 50 paintings and sculpture, next fall from his private col lection in what might be on of the most important auctions of contemporary art this year, it was learned yesterday The liVoxIcs, which are by lead. ing American abstract expres sionists and pop artists, are ex pected to bring between $2 million and $2.5million. They will be sold by Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: Beame vs. Badillo
description: With a quarter century of active governmental service behind him, City Controller Abraham Beame campaigned hard on the issue of experience and confidence.

title: Equity Financing
description: Corporations continue to acquire their own shares. Yesterday, the Pillsbury Company an nounced plans to purchase 40,000 shares (of 5,408, 909 outstanding) on the open market. Tiffany In dustries, a farmequipment and furniture concern that should not be confused with Tiffany & Co., authorized the purchase of 50,000 shares. Ambas sador Group, an insurance holding company, plans to buy 50,000 of its shares.

title: Flight to Glory Wins Part Of Opening Stake at Liberty
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 4The largest weekday crowd ever to attend an opening day was on hand at Liberty Bell today for the opening of the 78day springsummer session. A crowd of 10,431 saw Oak Crest Farm's Flight to Glory Win the first division of the featured Senti nel Stakes and Patricia Blass's Annihilate Em take the second half.

title: RAND REVALUED 5% AGAINST THE DOLLAR
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, June 4 (Reuters)The South African rand has been revalued by about 5 per cent against the dollar, effective tomorrow, Finance Minister Nicolaas Die derichs said today.

title: Parkchester Becoming a Condominium
description: One section of Parkchester, the largest rental apartment complex in the country, has of ficially become a condominium.

title: PATH Back, but to 19% Fewer Riders
description: Commuters who returned to the Port Authority TransHud son trains yesterday after a 63day strike found a warm welcome at the end of the line, but not all the commuters went back.

title: U. of Mass. Buys Mss. Of Dubois
description: The collection of papers, correspondence and unpub lished manuscripts of Wil liam E. B. DuBois, America's foremost black scholar, has been purchased from his widow by the University of Massachusetts for $150,000.Dr. DuBois, the first black man to receive a Ph.D. from Harvard Universityin 1895 wrote in 1903 that the problem of the 20th century is the problem of the color line  the relation of the darker to the lighter races of men in Asia and Africa, in America and the islands of the sea.

title: GUILTY PLEA IS 3D IN 4 SEASONS CASE
description: Jack L. Clark, former chair man and president of Four Sea sons Nursing Centers of America, Inc., pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy to de fraud investors, purchasers of debentures and a lender of the nursing home chain.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 5, 1973 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Apartheid 10:30 A.M.

title: 2,806 Awarded Degrees at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, June 4Yale University won a gamble with the weather today and then went on to award 2,806 bach elor and graduate degrees, a record in its 272d commence ment exercises.

title: Skylab May Be Visible Here at Dawn Tomorrow
description: The Skylab spacecraft, carrying its three astronaut passengers, is scheduled to fly directly over New York City at dawn tomorrow and, weather permitting, will be visible as a bright, starlike object moving from south west to northeast.

title: Chou Domands an End T o U.S. Cambodia Role
description: PEKING, June 4 (Reuters) Premier Chou Enlai of China demanded tonight that the Uni ted States stop, bombing Cam bodia and otherwise end its military activity there. Mr. Chou said that no, interference in Indochina, under whatever pretext and in whatever form, would be tolerated.

title: 25% of Eligibles Expected to Vote in Jersey Today
description: TRENTON, June 4  With three of four eligible voters expected to stay home, New Jersey Democrats and Repub licans will choose party nomi nees tomorrow for Governor and all 120 legislative seats.

title: Pentagon Reports 10,000 Died In War of Noncombat Causes
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) The Defense Department re ports that 10,303 American servicemen died of noncombat causes in Vietnam, in addition to the 45,958 men who were combat casualties.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Canadian Consul Gen eral in New York, Bruce Rankin, will present the Outer Critics Circle acting award for 1973 to Christopher Plummer for his performance in Cy rano. The awards dinner will be held Friday at Sardi's restaurant.

title: Helicopter Crash Kills 3
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., June 4 (AP)Three Army helicopter crewmen were killed when their helicopter crashed near their helicopter crashed near Oak Grove airport south of here yesterday. The dead men were identified by the Army as Danny Richard Little, 26 years old, of Duncanville, Tex.; Gary Elliot, 26, of Fort Worth and Lawrence Powell 26, of Dallas.

title: Traffic Is Kept Out of 3 Major Parks, And Things Go Well, for the Most Part
description: Central Park, Prospect Park in Brooklyn and Forest Park in Queens were closed to auto traffic from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. yesterday, the first day of a program that extends the weekend closings and that will run through Sept. 15.

title: Bronx Zoo's Lazybones Frolic at Twilight Show
description: Because of the diurnal work habits of professional zoo keepers and the effects of a tight budget, the right hour when the last straggling visitor must be ushered out of the Bronx Zoo at 5:30 is the very time when much of the zoo starts to come alive.

title: Jackson Says Nixon Isn't Tough Enough In Soviet Dealings
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson accused the Nixon Administra tion yesterday of not being tough enough in its negotia tions wtih the Soviet Union.

title: Israel's Diamond Sales Up
description: TEL AVIV, June 4 (AP) Israel's diamond industry sold more than $53.3million in pol ished diamonds last month, officials said today. It was the largest sales month in the in dustry's history.

title: Judge Orders 4 at Weis Not to. Break Securities Laws
description: Federal Judge Murray I. Gurfein signed yesterday an order permanently prohibiting four executives and one former officer of Weis Securities, the brokerage house put into liquidation last week, from vio lating Federal securities laws.

title: NixonDean Talks on Case Conceded by White House
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The White House acknowledged today that President Nixon con ferred frequently this year with John W. Dean 3d about the Watergate scandal but said that logs detailing the time and place of such conferences would not be turned over to investigators.

title: Israeli Court Forbids Visit To U.S. by Rabbi Kahane
description: TEL AVIV, June 4An Israeli court today forbade Rabbi Meir Kahane from flying to the United States lest he organize disturbances there during the forthcoming visit by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Commu nist party leader.

title: Court Voids Racing Dates Of Figure in Kerner Case
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 4 (AP)  The Illinois Supreme Court ruled today that 1973 racing dates awarded to Wil liam S. Miller, former state rac ing board chairman, were void.

title: STEEL OUTPUT DIPS 2.1% FROM WEEKAGO
description: Steel production for the week ended Saturday dropped by 2.1 per cent from the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yester day.

title: Freight Cars Are Ordered
description: The nation's railroads or dered 14,006 freight cars in April, the highest monthly total since April, 1969. As of May 1, the order backlog of new cars was 36,527, as compared with 26,535 a month earlier

title: 2D PLACE IS CLOSE
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame ran first in the Demo cratic mayoral primary yester day, but fell short of 40 per cent of the vote and faces a runoff against Representative Herman Badillo on June 26.

title: Shultz Calls Dollar's Weakness a Puzzling Matter
description: WASHINGTON, June 4Sec retary of the Treasury George P. Shultz indicated today that he saw no good reason for the dollar and the stock market to be as weak as they are.

title: Reds Beat Mets, 5 to 0
description: CINCINNATI, June 4The bleak world of the New York Mets grew even bleaker tonight when Bud Harrelson was in jured while they were suffering their third shutout in four games.

title: Steingut and Wagner Win Council Primary Contests
description: Robert F. Wagner Jr., the 29 yearold son of the former Mayor, won the Democratic nomination for Manhattan Councilman at Large last night and Robert S. Steingut, the 27 yearold son of the Assembly minority leader, was a victor in the Brooklyn Councilman at Large contest.

title: Move to Subpoena N ixon Termed a Legal Delusion
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 A law professor at an Eastern university, after an extended explanation of the legal and constitutional uncertainties in any move to subpoena the President, ended with a dis satisfied sigh.

title: Igho Kornblueh, Internist, Rehabilitation Specialist
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 4 Dr. Igho H. Kornblueh, an in ternist and a specialist in physi cal medicine and rehabilitation, died here Saturday at the age of 73.

title: OFFICIALS AT ODDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 Archibald Cox, the special pros ecutor in the Watergate investi gation, asked the select Senate committee today for a delay of one to three months in its hear ings in the matter.

title: Dubuffet's Paintings Take Stage Roles
32 Hurt as Bus Flips Over After Crash in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP) Thirtytwo persons were in jured this morning, four seri ously, when a bus collided with a car and plunged down a 30 foot embankment, city police men said.

title: Dincay Wins His 8th Race In 3 Days on Coast Track
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June AP)Laffit Pincay Jr. won his eighth race in three days yes terday when he rode Crimson Saint to a length victory and track record in the $33,500 Vfeteor Handicap at Hollywood ??.

title: Kosygin Leaves for Prague
description: MOSCOW, June 4 (Reuters) the Soviet Premier, Alexei N. Kosygin, left here today for Prague at the head of a delega tion to the 27th session of the Council of Comecon, the Soviet bloc's economic grouping. The session opens tomorrow.

title: Again the D.A.
description: Nomination by the Democrats of Frank S. Hogan for District Attorney of Manhattan guarantees that this respected prosecutor will have fourparty support in November for reelection to a ninth fouryear term. This assurance represents deserved recognition of the splen did standards of fairness, integrity and freedom from politics that Mr. Hogan has made a hallmark of his office.

title: Economic Nominee Gary Leonard Seevers
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 In nominating Gary Leonard Seevers for one of the three seats on the Council of Eco nomic Advisers today, Presi dent Nixon chose a doctor of agricultural economics with a knowledge of both theory and the long end of a pitch fork. Mr. Seevers, who is to join Herbert Stein and Marina Whit man on the au gust panel, has served on the council as a staff aide for three years. The nomination, believed to be the first promotion of an aide to the council, also re flects pressure on the Nixon Administration to deal with higher food prices.

title: Paul Curran Sworn In As New U.S. Attorney
description: Paul J. Curran was sworn in as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York yesterday in a pri vate ceremony performed by Chief District Judge David N. Edelstein.

title: TUTWIER GAINS IN BRITISH GOLF
description: PORTHCAWL, Wales, June 4 (AP)Ed Tutwiler, a former United States Walker Cup star and Ireland's Joe Carr led the advance today as the Britisih Amateur golf championship opened with Frank (One Round) Strafaci of Miami liv ing up to his nickname by los ing in the first round for the 23d year.

title: RED CROSS PUTS RESERVES AT ZERO
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 4 (UPI) An unprecedented demand for its services has depleted American Red Cross disaster re serve funds to absolute zero, the organization's national chairman said today.

title: A.A.A. Checking Gas Sugply Along Major Travel Routes
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) The American Automobile Association said today it had begun a weekly survey of hun dreds of gasoline service sta tions along major travel routes to try to gauge more precisely the fuelsupply situation for motorists.

title: 2 Generations Fiddling Under One Roof
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., There they were, 13 boys and girls, all but two of them 4 or 5 years old (one was 3, one was 7), sawing away on undersized violins at the Anne Frank Montessori School here.

title: DR. ABEL A. HANSON OF COLUMBIA DEAD
description: Dr. Abel A. Hanson, professor emeritus of higher education at Teachers College, Columbia University, and former general secretary of the college and ex ecutive officer of its develop ment program, died yesterday in a hospital in Asheville, N. C. IHe was 69 years old and lived in Flat Rock, N. C.

title: Contract on Containers Signed by Interpool, Ltd.
description: Interpool, Ltd., said yester day that it had agreed to supply Sovinflot, the Soviet Union maritime agency, with about 5,000 20foot equivalent containers over a threeyear period in what is believed to be the largest container contract signed with the agency.

title: TUTWILER GAINS IN BRITISH GOLF
description: PORTHCAWL, Wales, June 4 (AP)Ed Tutwiler, a former United States Walker Cup star, and Ireland's Joe Carr led the advance today as the British Amateur golf championships opened with Frank (One Round) Strafaci of Miami liv ing up to his nickname by los ing in the first round for the 23d year.

title: Kuwait Stresses Defense
description: KUWAIT, June 4 Kuwait, the wealthiest of the Persian Gulf oil sheikdoms, said today that the $500million in arms that she is arranging to pur chase from the West was not for use against anybody but for her own defense. Official sources said that the arms would be used to protect the nation's enormous oil re sources.

title: WILLIAM J. DICKSON, PERSONNEL EXPERT
description: William J. Dickson, retired assistant manager for personnel research at the Western Elec tric Company, died Saturday in Strathpeffer, Scotland, on a va cation trip. He was 69 years old and lived at 10 Parkview Ter race, Summit, N.J.

title: Judges Give Vote to Residents Of Bronx Without Party Ties
description: Dozens of people in the South Bronx who had no party affilia tion were permitted to vote yesterday by order of judges there according to the Board of Elections.

title: NixonDean Talks on Case Conceded by White House
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The White House acknowledged today that President Nixon con ferred frequently this year with John W. Dean 3d about the Watergate scandal but said that logs detailing the time and place of such conferences would not be turned over to investigators.

title: A Cultural Renaissance Sweeps Korea
description: SEOUL, South KoreaWe have wonderful traditional music, Kang Kyung Hee said solemnly. It is not in ferior to Western music, and in some ways it is better.

title: A Wharfside Fixture in Village Ends Role as City School Ship
description: The Liberty ship John. W. Brown, a Greenwich Village waterfront fixture for several years, is the bestpreserved American specimen of a spe cies of ships rapidly ap proaching extinction.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Although the common snap ping turtle is not a thing of beauty, its meat makes a tasty base for a hearty soup.

title: John N. Inglima Dies at 49; Senior Engineer at Con Ed
description: John N. Inglima, a senior engineer in the nuclear bureau of Consolidated Edison, died of a brain tumor on Sunday in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 49 years old and lived at 1 Sherman Square.

title: MRS. W. WATERFALL
description: Mrs. Fern Riley Waterfall, wife of Wallace Waterfall, acoustical engineer and secre tary of the American Institute of Physics, died Friday in Bangor, Me., of injuries suf fered in an automobile acci dent. She was 72 years old and lived at 6 Mereston Terrace, Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Texts of Cox and Ervin Views on Watergate Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 Following are the texts of a letter from Archibald Cox, special prosecutor in the Wa tergate case, to Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Senate committee investigat ing Watergate, and of a statement by Senator Ervin replying to the letter:

title: CHANDLER QUITS GTR AND GEOTEK POSTS
description: Otis Chandler, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, an nounced yesterday that he had resigned as a director of the GTR Management Company and its subsidiary, GeoTek Re sources Fund, Inc., two con cerns that operated a large oil drilling investment program.

title: U. of Mass. Buys Mss. Of DuBois
description: The collection of papers, correspondence and unpub lished manuscripts of Wil liam E. B. DuBois, America's foremost black scholar, has been purchased from his widow by the University of Massachusetts for $150,000.

title: MAINE UPHOLDS LAW ON OILSPILL COSTS
description: PORTLAND, Me., June 4  The Maine Supreme Court to day declared constitutional Maine's 1970 coastal convey ance law, which levies a tax of onehalf cent a barrel on oil shipped over Maine waters.

title: High Court Affirms Ruling On Samoa Oil Conspiracy
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) The Supreme Court ruled today that the Standard Oil Company of California illegally conspired to monopolize the sale of petroleum products in American Samoa.

title: Envoy Voices Concern
description: WASHINGTON, June 4Is rael has opened a major cam paign to persuade the Nixon Administration to drop its ten tative plans to sell Saudi Ara bia 24 to 30 F4 Phantom jet bombers.

title: Coffee Board to Meet
description: LONDON, June 4 (AP)The executive board of the Inter national Coffee Organization will meet June 12 to 14 to map out details of an extended coffee agreement, the organi zation announced today.

title: VETRANO VICTOR IN VESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 4 County Clerk Edward N. Ve trano, the official party choice, tonight won the Republican pri mary contest for Westchester County Executive.

title: CHESS INTERZONAL OPENS IN LENINGRAD
description: LENINGRAD, June 4Six games were fought to conclu sions yesterday in the opening round of the Interzonal Tour nament here.

title: Dr. Gordon D. Hoople, Specialist In Rehabilitation of Deaf, Is Dead
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 4 Dr. Gordon D. Hoople, a special ist in diseases of the ear, pro fessor emeritus of otolaryngol ogy at Syracuse University Col lege of Medicine and former chairman of the university's board of trustees, died today in Crouse Memorial Hospital. His age was 78.

title: ANTIOCH STRIKERS PUT UP NEW BARS
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, June 4More than 100 sheriff's deputies and policemen re turned to the Antioch College campus today to reopen build ings and tear down barricades reconstructed by striking stu dents since Friday.

title: 12,000 Wet Chinese Watch As U.S. Swim Tour Opens
description: HONG KONG, June 4 (AP) A team of top American swim mers opened a threeweek ex hibition tour today before 12,000 people who sat in open stands through a downpour in Canton, China.

title: Police Chief Accused of Lax Inquiry a Suicide at Saranac Lake
description: SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., June 4Police Chief William Wal lace, who was accused by the State Commission of Investiga tion last month of conducting a lax inquiry into the theft of parking fines from the Village Court, committed suicide this afternoon in his home, authori ties said.

title: Pie in the Sky
description: AMHERST, Mass.The spectacular problems of the $2.5billion Skylab mission and the failure of the first three SovietSalyut space stations may have dealt a death blow to manned space flight. The enormous expense, the high risk, the muchballyhooed and grossly exaggerated claims about the pertinence of manned earth orbital flights to the quality of life on earth are creating an everwidening credi bility gap between the public interest and a vested interest inherited from the space race of the nineteensixties.

title: Strike Surcease
description: A timetested maxim in labor rela tions is that the better things are, the worse they are. In less Aesopian terms, that means a period of expan sive economic boom, with prices and profits soaring and jobs plentiful, is one in which to expect unions to strike for outsize pay increases.

title: AREA SENIORS NAMED NATIONAL SCHOLARS
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 Eight young people from the New York area were among 121 high school smiors named today as 1973 Presidential Scholars by President Nixon.

title: At Alice Cooper's Show, Tunes Don't Get in Way of the Action
description: A full Madison Square Gar den bayed, howled and stamped feetall to persuade Alice Cooper to do an encore on Sun day. The commotion was ig nored. In truth, it would have been hard for the rock group to follow a climax where the Nixonlookalike Richard M. Dix on was manhandled by the group in front of the American flag while Kate Smith's familiar voice loudly proclaimed God Bless America.

title: Patrolman Slays Prison Escapee Armed With Knife
description: JERSEY CITY, June 4 (UPI) An escapee from the Annan dale Reformatory, failing to heed warnings to halt, was fatally shot by a Jersey City patrolman today after he was seen running from a house while brandish a knife, authorities said.

title: The Last Days of a Genuine Trattoria
description: The automobile and the housewrecker, those partners in urban debilitation, are about to claim another New York land mark.

title: Tornado Lifts Freight Cars; 2 Die as Winds Fell Tree
description: WAYNE CENTER, Ohio, June 4 (AP)  The State High way Patrol said a tornado lifted up a section of a moving Penn Central freight train yesterday and slammed it into another parked on a siding near here.

title: Dorticos Leaves Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 4 (UPI)President Osvaldo Dor ticos Torrado of Cuba ended a fiveday state visit to Chile to day and left for Lima to visit Gen. Juan Velasco Alvarado, the Peruvian chief executive, before returning to Havana.

title: GOLDIN DEFEATS 3
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame took first place in the Democratic mayoral primary yesterday but fell short of 40. per cent of the total vote and thus faced a runoff June 26 against Representative Herman Badillo, who finished second.

title: Roundup: Maddox Shows Giants How to Choke Up
description: The fact that Garry Mad dox is choking up more this year is helping to keep the San Francisco Giants alive and it certainly helped them in their 72 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates last night.

title: Long Beach Democrats Win in Council Primary
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., June 4 Five nominees of the regular Democratic organization won a primary contest for City Coun cil today, defeating a single in surgent, Harvey Weisenberg,

title: A Day to Observe
description: In a calendar punctuated by artificial days pro claimed by every level of government, World Environ ment Day is exceptional. So designated by the last Assembly of the United Nations, June 5 is worth observ ing both as an antidote to the pessimism of those who think ecological disaster is inevitable and as a spur those who are actively working to head it off.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: High Schools Try To Ease Boredom Of the Final Term
description: High school teachers call it senioritis. The seniors themselves call it a drag. Some parentsand educators are beginning to call it scandal.

title: Sihanouk Peace Plan Offers Cambodia Officials Amnesty
description: ALGIERS, June 4 (Reuters) Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the exiled Cambodian leader, to day promised a general amnesty for what he called the traitors of Phnom Penh as part of peace proposals he has made to the United States.

title: AMMAN TO SETTLE JORDAN'S EAST BANK
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 4 (AP) The Jordanian Government has started work on a $100 million plan to resettle farmers, some of them Palestinian refu ges, in the warravaged Jordan River Valley.

title: Yankee Records
description: BATTING

title: Nursing Home Plan Voted One Day Prior to Hearing
description: Acting a day before the case was listed publicly as up for discussion and decision, the city's Board of Standards and Appeals has approved con struction of the final stage of a controversial 720bed nursing home complex in the Bronx, setting off community charges of irregularities and conflict of interest.

title: OldTimers' Night Brings Su Mac Lad, 18, Back to Yonkers
description: YONKERS, June 4Su Mac Lad, the grand old gelding of Harness racing, returns to Yonkers Raceway Wednesday for an oldtimers' night appearance. Surrie, per haps the most popular trotter ever tocompete in New York, is now 18 years old and enjoys retirement at Stanley Dancer's Egyptian Acres farm in New Egypt, N. J.

title: Mrs. Johnson Opens Drive For Funds to LBJ Library
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson an nounced today the formation of The Friends of the LBJ Library to raise funds for the library and the LBJ School of Public Affairs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: What if the ultimate judgment is that the President must be removed from his office? Does it follow that Mr. Agnew must succeed him? Perhaps it is worth noting that there is, in fact, no clear precedent for this situ ation.

title: 3 Borough Chiefs Capture Races for Renomination
description: The incumbent Borough Pres idents of Brooklyn, the Bronx and Richmond won nomination as Democratic candidates for reelection by decisive majori ties yesterday. There were no contests in Manhattan and Queens for Borough Presidents.

title: Notes on People
description: Marlon Brando and Marla Schneider, stars of Last Tango in Paris, were con victed on obscenity charges Bologna, Italy, and given suspended sentences of two months in jail and $50 fines. The court also ordered that the film be banned in Italy starting today.

title: City Takes the Primary Casually
description: The city took its primary elections in stride last night. The Hare Krishnas chanted and sold incense on 45th Street. At McGlade and Ward, a tavern near 86th on Columbus Avenue, a dozen patitns watched Satchel Paige providing commentary on the BostonKansas City game on television.

title: RIVALS DWINDLE FOR SECRETARIAT
description: The task is being made easier for Secretariat to win the Triple Crown. Unless there are some surprise entrants from pre viously unproclaimed horses, the Meadow Stable colt will have only three rivals in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

title: Music: Kaufman's Modern Song Cycle
description: Poems of Van Doren Yield Inspiration

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Views on Senate Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 Archibald Cox, special prose cutor in the Watergate case, presented today a series of arguments for delaying the Senate Watergate hearings.

title: Circus Helper Crushed to Death By Elephant He Was Handling
description: TENAFLY, June 4  A 45 yearold circus laborer was picked up and thrown to the ground twice yesterday before being crushed to death by an elephant he was handling after a performance on Roosevelt Common.

title: Prices of Stocks Tumble In a Slow Trading Session
description: Stock prices continue to move down yesterday in slow trading, with the DowJones in dustrial average closing at its lowest level in almost 18 months.

title: Democrat to Head Drug Abuse Office, Succeeding Jaffe
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) President Nixon accepted the resignation today of Dr. Jerome H. Jaffe as director of the Spe cial Action Office for Drug Abuse, Prevention and nomi nated Dr. Robert L. DuPont, head of a District of Columbia drug treatment program, to suc ceed him.

title: A Group in London Plans Deal for 95 Offices
description: The Lloyds Bank Group of London, which last week an nounced plans to dissolve its ties to the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said yesterday that it was having discussions with World Airways, Inc., about the possible acquisition of the First Western Bank & Trust Company of Los Angeles.

title: RICHARDSON BARS SECURITY AS ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, June 4  Elliot L. Richardson, the new Attorney General, said today that he did not believe the publication of the Pentagon papers was a sufficient justifica tion for the establishment of a special White House unit to investigate security leaks, or for some of the tactics it em ployed.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Sweaters and sequins. That's the swing of the fashion pendulum for fall. If you have to make a choice, pick sweaters. They'll take you anywhere that sequins willand they look a lot more up to date.

title: New Jersey Primary
description: Voters in New Jersey go to the polls from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. today to nominate a Democratic and a Republican candidate for Governor. Under New Jersey's electoral laws any voter can participate in either party's primary balloting regardless of previous party registration.

title: Petersen Faces an Inquiry On His Watergate Actions
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The Watergate special prosecu tion team has decided to investigate the conduct of Henry E. Petersen, the Assistant Attorney General who supervised the Watergate inquiry for nearly a year and was placed in sole charge by President Nixon in midApril

title: Drug Charges Shake the Record Industry
description: A Federal grand jury in New ark has questioned a former assistant to Clive J. Davis, de posed president of Columbia Records, in connection with an interstate drug investigation, sources close to the case said yesterday.

title: Sylvania Forms New Group
description: GTE Sylvania, Inc., yesterday announced creation of a sixth operating group to expand ac tivities in the electrical equip ment field. Raymond N. Ander son was named senior vice president to head the new group. Sylvania is a subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation.

title: MOSCOW BACKS NEW ECONOMISTS
description: MOSCOW, June 4The So viet leadership, after long hesi tation, came down squarely today on the side of modern, Western  oriented economists who are seeking to break with Stalinist planning practices to insure a slower, but more bal anced and orderly, growth of the Soviet economy.

title: DOLLAR PLUNGES; GOLD, IN EUROPE, SOARS TO $123.75
description: PARIS, June 4The dollar today took its biggest oneday plunge in recent months, fall ing 1 and 2 per cent against leading European currencies, and the price of gold soared by more than $6 an ounce to an other new high.

title: Composer Tells of Artistic Battle in Soviet
description: VIENNA, May 31  Andrei Volkonskyhe makes no use of his title, Prince  one of the Soviet Union's most advanced and therefore least played com posers, as well as a noted harp sichordist, pianist and conduc tor, arrived here a few days ago as a refugee from Moscow.

title: Business Briefs
description: PITTSBURGH, June 4 (UPI)The Gulf Oil Corporation and companies of the Royal DutchShell Group announced today a joint venture in the international nuclear power Industry. The 5050 partnership is intended to own and operate the business now conducted by Gulf linergy and Environmental Systems, Gulf's Californiabased nuclear power division.

title: Security Analysts Elect
description: Peter J. De Angelis has been elected president of the New York Society of Security Ana lysts. He is senior vice president and chairman of the Investment policy and strategy committee of Hornblower & WeeksHemp hill Noyes, Inc.

title: Monmouth ppens Amid Optimism
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., June 4 Monmouth Park opened the 28th and longest season in its modern era of thoroughbred racing today.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: MRS. OTTO DE WESTFELT
description: Mrs. Margaret Rangeley de Westfelt, who was an assistant program director of the na tional headquarters of the Girl Scouts at her retirement in 1960, died Saturday in New Haven Hospital. A former desi dent of Douglaston, Queens, she had been living in New Haven since the death in 1970 of her husband, Otto G. J. P. de Westfelt, an engineer.

title: Cost of Gubernatorial Bids Likely to Total $1.5Million
description: TRENTON, June 4  The candidates for nomination for Governor in tomorrow's primary election report that they expect their campaign bills to total about $1.5million.

title: Philharmonic Plans Nine June Concerts Throughout the City
description: The New York Philharmonic will split into two 50member orchestras and present nine Neighborhood Concerts in six days throughout the city this month. The concerts will be conducted by James De Preist and David Zinman.

title: Jury in Rockland Indicts 11 Persons As Alleged Gamblers
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., June 4 Eleven persons were charged today with gambling in indict ments handed up by a special grand jury investigating organ ized crime and corruption among some officials in Rock land County.

title: JAMES K. SMALL
description: SUMMIT, N. J., June 4 James K. Small, who retired in 1966 as director of the patents division of Esso Research and Engineering Company, died Sat turday in Springfield. He was 68 years old and lived here.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Every so often at the coronation yesterday of Larry Popein as the coach of the New York Rangers, the obses sion quietly intruded on the ceremony.

title: Critics Urge Cuts In Authors' Royalty To Buoy Theaters
description: The question of what theatrical unions can do to en courage Broadway production activity was the subject of dis cussion at the latest luncheon meeting of the Drama Desk, the association of New York critics, editors and reporters, held at Sardi's Belasco Room.

title: BARUCH GRADUATES GET WORD ON WORDS
description: Marya Mannes, the writer, urged the graduating class of Baruch College yesterday to help cleanse the English lan guage so it would enlighten rather than spread the kind of deception, evasion and down right dishonesty that has led to Watergate and other forms of rottenness eroding our society.

title: D.A. WINS EASILY Will Be Unopposed in Fall for 9th Term in Prosecutor's Post
description: Manhattan's Mr. District At torney, Frank S. Hogan, yes terday overcame the first chal lenge in his 32year reign and easily defeated William J. van den Heuvel in the Democratic primary:

title: Chicago Area Construction Halts in Laborers Dispute
description: CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) Major construction halted in an eightcounty area around Chi cago today as contractors coun tered a laborers' strike with the threat of a lockout.

title: MT. SINAI INVESTS A NEW PROFESSOR
description: A reduction in the excessive number of surgeons and surg ical specialists and education of the Medical profession and the public to accept well trained paramedical personnel were among proposals ad vanced yesterday by Dr. S. David Pomrinse, who was in vested at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine as its first professor of administrative medicine.

title: COURT BACKS FEES TO AID RACE SUITS
description: WASHNGTON, June 4In a move to encourage school de segregation lawsuits, the Su preme Court ruled today that the lawyers who prosecute such cases successfully are en titled to fees paid by govern mental agencies under all but special circumstances.

title: Hart Calls for More Competition in Data Industry
description: Senator Philip A. Hart called yesterday for reorganization of the data processing and com munications industry to in crease competition. He spoke at the first National Computer Conference, held in the New York Hilton.

title: Michigan Consolidated Plans Offshore Gas Exploration
description: DETROIT, June 4 (UPI)The American Natural Gas Produc tion Company and the Michi ganWisconsin Pipe Line Com pany, both affiliates of Michi gan Consolidated Gas, an nounced plans today to begin natural gas exploration offshore from Texas and in the Rocky Mountains.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Carrying judicial complaints about low pay and bad work ing conditions a step further, Judge Fred G. Moritt in Brooklyn cut his robes to knee length because he got tired of dragging all the filth and garbage around with him. Judge Moritt, the senior Civil Court judge of the bor ough, decried overcrowded, unsightly and unsanitary con ditions at his courthouse. This place is a hellhole, he protested. People get their first impression of American justice here. And what they see is enough to make them sick.

title: Informant Against Mafia Flees Government Guards
description: Gerald Martin Zelmanowitz a confessed bond thief who has furnished pivotal testi mony for the Government in two New Jersey Mafia trials last week eluded United States marshals who had been pro tecting him from possible un derworld reprisals, a Justice De partment source said yesterday.

title: People and Business
description: Frank J. Pizzitola, in a sur prise move, has resigned as president and director of the Jim Walter Corporation to come to New York City as a general partner of Lazard Freres & Co.

title: Prof. Erwin Stengel Dies; World Authority on Suicide
description: SHEFFIELD, England, June 4 (Reuters)Prof. Erwin Stengel, acknowledged as the world's leading authority on suicide, died here during the weekend.

title: COLLEGES WARNED OF NEW PRESSURE
description: A report made public here yesterday by the Carnegie Com mission on Higher Education concludes that the nation's colleges and universities have entered a period in which they will face increasing pressure from students and teachers to takes sides in major social and political controversies.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Minor league affiliates do not produce all of the talent for major league baseball teams. Senior leagues, sometimes referred to as semipro circuits, also funnel players to the big time.

title: Air Canada Strike
description: MONTREAL, June 4 (AP) Air Canada machinists walked off the job at Montreal Inter national Airport today, forcing cancellation of 15 flights. It was their second 24hour strike to back contract demands.

title: High Schools Try To Ease Boredom Of the Final Term
description: High school teachers call it senioritis. The seniors themselves call it a drag. Some parentsand educators are beginning to call it scandal.

title: TU144 Crash is Expected To Delay Supersonic Era
description: Aviation experts generally agreed yesterday that plans for introducing the era of super sonic air travel had been set back by the crash of the Soviet Tupolev144 at the Paris air show on Sunday.

title: With Hijackings Curbed, F.A.A. May Relax Airport Screenings
description: The Federal Aviation Admin istration, following five months without a hijacking in this country, is studying the possi bility of ending the mandatory electronicscreening of all air line passengers and searches of all carryon luggage.

title: Circus Helper Crushed to Death By Elephant He Was Handling
description: TENAFLY, June 4  A 45 yearold circus laborer was picked up and thrown to the ground twice yesterday before being crushed to death by an elephant he was handling after a performance on Roosevelt Common.

title: Marchi Has the Day Off And Ponders the Election
description: State Senator John J. Marchi said yesterday that he was, eager for the start of the post primary part of the mayoral campaign and that, as the Re publican canadidate, he would have at least $1.5million to spend in his election effort, considerably more than he spent in a losing mayoral cam paign four years ago.

title: Amateur Skeptics Rile Pro Trackmen With Hints of Rigged World Records
description: Skepticism and envy, once the elements of training room warfare, have begun to surface for the first time among ath letes competing on the rival professional and amateur track and field circuits.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Youths Attack at Least 3 Bicyclists in Central Park
description: Within less than 24 hours last weekend, at least three Central Park bicyclists were attacked by youths who knocked them to the ground, made off with their bicycles or tried to, and in one case left a victim with serious knift wounds.

title: How Much Security Is Enough?
description: WASHINGTON, June 4A crucial question that sooner or later must be raised in the Watergate matter is to what extent a President may commit criminal acts in order to protect what he believes to be the national se curity.

title: Canada's G.N.P. Rises 4.4%
description: OTTAWA, June 4 (Reuters) Canada's, seasonally adjusted gross national product rose 4.4 per cent in the first quarter of 1973 from a year ago to $12.6 billion, Statistics Canada re ported today. It said the gain was mainly due to price in creases. The G.N.P., in volume terms, was up 2.9 per cent, the same as in the final 1972 quar ter, the agency said.

title: Equity Trustee Confident on Recovery
description: LOS ANGELES, June 4The trustee of the Equity Funding Corporation of America said to day that he was confident that the bankrupt company could be rehabilitated. Robert M. Loeffler stated at a hearing conducted by Federal District Judge Harry Pregerson that he did not contemplate any rec ommendation of liquidation.

title: Minh Bids Saigon End Curbs on Critics
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 (AP)A former South Vietnamese President today proposed the scrapping of all laws oppressive to nonCom munist opponents of the Saigon Government. He also called for the immediate release of all po litical prisoners.

title: Envoy Voices Concern
description: WASHINGTON, June 4Is rael has opened a major cam paign to persuade the Nixon Administration to drop its ten tative plans to sell Saudi Ara bia 24 to 30 F4 Phantom jet bombers.

title: City College Admits 62 Into 6Year M.D. Program
description: City College has admitted 62 students for a program that will integrate the first two years of medical school into the undergraduate curriculum, enabling them to earn medical degrees in six years instead of the usual eight.

title: Insurance Commissioners Plan Surveillance Study
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The National Association of Insur ance Commissioners, watchdog of the insurance industry, vowed at its annual meeting here to day to eliminate surveillance techniques that failed to un cover the mammoth insurance scandals at the Equity Funding Corporation of America.

title: Air Force Making Deep Study Of Suicide by Indochina P.O.W.
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 4The Air Force began in investiga tion today into the death of Capt. Edward A, Brudno, the first apparent suicide of a for mer captive in the war in Indo china.

title: Nastase, Pilic Reach French Tennis Final
description: PARIS, June 4 (AP) Ilie Nastase, using spin shots and lobs, defeated Tom Gorman, 63 64, 61, today and reached the final of the $135,000 French open tennis championships.

title: New Fighting Ends A Lull in Cambodia; B52's Are Active
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 4  A week of relative calm was broken today by fighting around two provin cial capitals and the loss of two Government positions else where.

title: Food Costs Up Steadily
description: The average cost of feeding a family of two adults and two children in New York City rose in the week of May 24 to May 30 by 73 cents, from $51.62 for the week of May 17 to May 23, to $52.35, the Consumer Affairs Department reported yesterday.

title: JAMES ANDERSON
description: James Anderson, a retired partner in the international public accounting fin of Has kins & Sells, died Sunday at his home in Pinehurst, N. C. His age was 81.

title: Hockey Transactions.
description: WORLD ASSOCIATION

title: MICTHELL LINKED TO PLOTTERS' All
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP John N. Mitchell, former At torney General, reportedly has told Senate investigators that he approved payments to the Watergate conspirators after their arrest to avoid embarrass ment to President Nixon's re election campaign.

title: Intertype Gets Contract
description: The HarrisIntertype Corpo ration said yesterday that it had received a $38.3million Navy contract for computer controlled testing systems for equipment used on jet fighters and other carrierbased aircraft.

title: Donald Starr, 67, Editor With The Chicago Tribune
description: CHICAGO, June 4 (UPI) Donald Starr, retired assistant managing editor of The Chicago Tribune, died today in Wash ington. He was 67 years old.

title: Refugees Sent Home By Saigon Regret It
description: HOAI TAN, South Viet namAfter a year as refu gees, the people of this dev astated central Vietnam vil lage returned home recently under Government prodding. But now they wish they had stayed in their safe if squalid refugee camp.

title: Barber, Irwin, Sifford Also SetVenturi, Brewer Fail
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 4 (UPI)Sam Snead, who has never won a United States Open, and Fred Marti led quali fying for the Open today with threeunderpar 139's.

title: 2.65 Million Shares of Store Chain Sought at $16 Each
description: Loews Corporation announced yesterday that It was making an offer to buy 2.65 million shares of the common stock of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., a depart ment store chain, at $16 a share. If these shares are tendered, Loews will have accumulated, with shares already owned, a total of 4,307,000 shares, or slightly more than half of the 8.5 mil lion shares out standing. The offer caused a delayed opening of Gimbel, stock on the New York Stock Ex change. It closed yesterday at 15, up 2 from last Friday's close of 12.

title: Stage: Mike Nichols's Uncle Vanya
description: The difficulty with many allstar productions of clas sics is simply that on occa sion the stars get in your eyes and you can scarcely see the classic. It is much to Mike Nichols's credit that this does not happen in his staging of Uncle Vanya, which opened last night at the Circle in the Square Joseph E. Levine Theater. Al though at the preview I at tended there were plenty of histrionic sparks, the play it self was never lost sight of.

title: People in Sports: Foreman Gives Japan a First With His Title Defense
description: When George Foreman makes the first defense of his title against Joe (King) Ro man in Tokyo on Sept. 1, it will be the first heavyweight championship fight staged in Japan.

title: With Hijackings Curbed, F.A.A. May Relax Airport Screenings
description: The Federal Aviation Admin istration, following five months without a hijacking in this country, is studying the possi bility of ending the mandatory electronicscreening of all air line passengers and searches of all carryon luggage.

title: SPACE WALK SET TO REPAIR SKYLAB
description: HOUSTON, June 4 Space agency officials, concluding that the potential gain out weighed the risks, approved plans today for the Skylab 1 astronauts to take a space walk to attempt to deploy stuck solarpower wing on their orbiting space station.

title: The Sounds of Midnight
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The Brain was acting up again. It had been hap pening more often lately. Hey, said the Brain, wake Did you see that guy from Hermie's Bonanza New Car Sales?

title: BILL ON BOMBING HELD UP IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, June 4Be cause of Congressional absen teeism, the appointment of a SenateHouse conference com mittee to reconcile bills curbing funds for bombing in Cambodia was delayed today by at least a day.

title: EGGERT OF BRONX NEARS JUDGESHIP
description: Although nine Civil Court judges are scheduled to be elected this fall, there were primary contests yesterday for only four of these positions in the Bronx, Manhattan and Staten Island.

title: MOSCOW BACKS NEW ECONOMISTS
description: MOSCOW, June 4The So viet leadership, after long hesi tation, came down squarely today on the side of modern, Western  oriented economists who are seeking to break with Stalinist planning practices to insure a slower, but more bal anced and orderly, growth of the Soviet economy.

title: BANKERS EXPECT PRIME RATE RISE
description: The upward surge of short term money costs in the open market is likely to force an increase in the prime lending rate of the nation's largest banks to 7 per cent from 7 per cent within the next two or three days, informed bank ers said yesterday.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Climb at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 Yields on United States Treas ury bills soared In the Gov ernment's weekly competitive sale today of these short term securities.

title: DEMOCRATS URGE INFLATION CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The Senate Democratic Caucus unanimously adopted today a policy resolution calling for a 90day freeze on wages and salaries, prices, profits, rents and consumer interest rates.

title: DR. JOHN HANFORD
description: Dr. John Munn Hanford, a re tired attending surgeon of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center and former associate professor of clinical surgery at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia Univer sity, died Saturday at his sum mer home in Scottsville, N. Y. He was 91 years old and lived at 70 East 96th Street.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TORMENT Walk along Grand Street, a broad and, on a sunny day, even pleasantly bustling throughfare. When you come to the corner of Pitt Street, raise your eyes to the side of the Henry Street Playhouse on the northeast corner and you will be quite shaken by a large mural100 feet long, 50 feet high.

title: SHIPCRASH PANEL VISITS 2 VESSELS
description: A Coast Guard inquiry into the ramming early Saturday of an oil tanker by a cargo ship here was postponed for one day yesterday to allow officials time to visit the two ships.

title: OFFICIALS AT ODDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 4  Archibald Cox, the special pros ecutor in the Watergate investi gation, asked the select Senate committee today for a delay of one to three months in its hear ings in the matter.

title: Revere Copper Increases Price of Fabricated Items
description: Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., said yesterday that it had increased its published list prices for fabricated copper and copperalloy products by cent a pound, effective imme

title: VETRANO VICTOR IN WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 4 County Clerk Edward N. Ve trano, the official party choice, tonight won the Republican pri mary contest for Westchester County Executive.

title: Greenberg Tennis Racquet Booms Like Bat
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 4Tennis, the great equalizer between old men and young weinen, became the great tantalizer today when 12 superstars of other sports met in the Dewar's celebrity tournament at Kutsher's Country Club.

title: SYRIANS CHARGE, ISRAELI TORTURE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 4 The Syrian Army officers and soldiers who were released yesterday by Israel said they had been subjected to physical and psychological torture dur ing their captivity, the Damas cus radio said today.

title: Weinstein and Fuchsberg Lead 4Way Judge Race
description: With more than twothirds of the vote in, Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein and Jacob D. Fuchsberg were battling this morning for the lead in the Democratic primary for chief judge of the state.

title: Former Liddy Aide Linked To Perjury to Protect Him
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 In depositions filed in a civil suit arising from the Water gate affair, coworkers of Sally Jackson Harmony have dis closed that she told them she perjured herself to protect her former boss, Q. Gordon Liddy, a convicted Watergate con spirator.

title: Skylab Tests Check Weightlessness Effect
description: Elaborate clinical experi ments are being conductec aboard the Skylab in earth orbit with three subjects, including a physician, and with experi mental equipment ranging from a bloodseparating centrifuge tc devices capable of weighing ob jects in a weightless environ ment.

title: Two Gunmen Die, Officer Is Hit In Brooklyn Tenement Shootout
description: A police officer was wounded and two gunmen were killed late last night in a shootout on Pitkin Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: Independent Files Suit to Nullify Today's Gubernatorial Primary.
description: TRENTON, June 4A New ark resident who says he wants to run for Governor as an in dependent in the November general election challenged the constitutionality of tomorrow's New Jersey primary in a suit filed today in State Superior Court of Mercer County.

title: Yanks Intent on Getting A Reliable 5th Starter
description: The New York Yankees beaded west yesterday for a 13game fourcity tour, mak ing no secret of their desire to acquire another starting pitcher, somehow, some where.

title: Lampkin Knocks Out Malave With Left. Hook in Eighth Round
description: Chu Chu Malave, a parttime actor and the darling of box ing's mod set, was knocked out last night by one punch, a left hook, at the 16second mark of the eighth round in the Felt Forum.

title: $100,000 in Paintings Stolen From Building
description: Burglars during the week end stole $100,000 worth of art objects, mainly contem porary oil paintings, from the officefurniture showroom of Samuel Lakow and Son, Inc., in the former Golet town house at 20 Beaver Street in the financial district.

title: 25% of Eligibles Expected To Vote in Jersey Today
description: TRENTON, June 5  With three of four eligible voters expected to stay home, New Jersey Democrats and Repub licans will choose party nomi nees tomorrow for Governor and all 120 legislative seats.

title: RATES AGAIN RISE ON SHORTTERMS
description: Shortterm interest rates continued to soar to new peaks yesterday as tighter credit pol icy countered a surging econ omy and its voracious demands for money.

title: GOVI LUCEY AWLS NIXON TO RESIGN
