description: The Manhattan District At torney's office was given until July 11 by Criminal Court Judge Bernard Moldow yesterday to move on the case of James Layne, who is accused of trying to sell his infant daughter, Kim Cruz, or the charges will be dismissed. Being sought as a witness is the woman who notified the transit police at the IRT 125th Street subway station on April 28 that a man was trying to sell the baby.

title: ... and Mr. Hoover
description: On New Year's Day 1970, President Nixon telephoned J. Edgar Hoover, then director of the Federal Bureau Investigation, to congratulate him on his 75th birthday. Later in the day, Mr. Nixon let it be known that there were no plans for Mr. Hoover's retirement.

title: Jesse Gray Jr. Sentenced
description: Jesse Gray Jr., 23 years old, son of the Harlem Assembly man, was sentenced to 12 years in prison yesterday as a sub stantial dealer in narcotics in Harlem by a judge in the spe cial narcotics part of State Supreme Court.

title: Islanders Bag a Touted Defenseman, 19
description: The most highly acclaimed young defenseman since Bob by Orr calmly smoked his meerschaum pipe yesterday and spoke of the joys of be ing able to lose yourself in New York, while his mother sat nearby and wondered whether he would be able to take care of himself.

title: Brazil Frees 2 U.S. Boats Seized for Fishing Violation
description: BRASILIA, June 6 (UPI)  Two American shrimp boats de tained last week for fishing Brazilian shrimp banks without proper documentation have been released, officials here) said today.

title: Grand Central Is Favored Over a 3d Ave. Terminal
description: WASHINGTON, June 6The Federal Government has direct ed New York State to consider expanding and modernizing Grand Central Terminal before building a $341million railroad and subway terminal under neath Third Avenue between 48th and 53d Streets.

title: Haig to Quit Army to Hold Haldeman Post as Civilian
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 President Nixon named for mer Secretary of Defense Mel yin R. Laird as his chief do mestic adviser today in an ef fort to shore up the Adminis tration during the Watergate crisis.

title: MRS. LYMAN A. BLISS
description: BELLPORT, L. I., June 6  Mrs. Katharine Park  Lewis Bliss, the wife of Lyman A. Bliss, who retired in 1966 as president of the Union Carbide Nuclear Company, died yester day at her home here.

title: PRO TRACK DRAM 15,501 TO GARDEN
description: Lee Evans gambled and won $6,500, Henry Hines almost leaped out of the longjump pit and Kipchoge Keino outran a flat Jim Ryun in the first pro fessional track and field meet at Madison Square Garden last tight.

title: APARTMENT OWNERS LOSE TENANTS' SUIT
description: The Court of Appeals in Al bany ruled unanimously yester day that a Manhattan apart ment's owners resorted to flagrant misrepresentation in getting tenants to agree to make it a cooperative.

title: Strait of Colliding Ships
description: LONDON (AP)Surveys by Britain's National Physics Labo ratory showed that during 1958 1971 there was an average of about one collision a month in the crowded Dover Strait sepa rating Britain from France.

title: Haig to Quit Army to Hold Haldeman Post as Civilian
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 President Nixon named for mer Secretary of Defense Mel via R. Laird as his chief do mestic adviser today in an of fort; to shore up the Adminis tration during the Watergate crisis.

title: Navy Man Given 3 Months In Strike on Minesweeper
description: MANILA, June 7A special courtmartial at Subic Naval Base, 80 miles northwest of here, today sentenced an Amer ican Navy man to three months at hard labor for having re fused to obey orders during a minesweeping operation off North Vietnam in March.

title: Will We Pay More, Enjoy It Less When the Fulton Market Moves?
description: Progress is swift but bureaucracy is slow. So the Fulton Fish Market has two more years to die.

title: Josephine Baker Sings, Talks, Dances and Captivates
description: Josephine Baker knows how to make an entrance. The Americanborn singer and dancer, who celebrated her 67th birthday on Sunday, brought a full house at Car negie Hall to its feet cheering and applauding Tuesday eve ning merely by stepping into a spotlight wearing a spangled bodystocking that left no doubt about the slim, trim, youthful lines of her figure, topped by an outrageously towering headdress of fla mingocolored plumes that was as tall as she was her self (My Eiffel Tower, she called it).

title: Body of Boy, 12, Is Found On Bronx Subway Tracks
description: The body of a 12yearold boy was found yesterday after noon on the tracks of the IRT Seventh Avenue subway line, 2,000 feet south of the East 149th Street station at Third Avenue, in the South Bronx. The police said he had appar ently been hit by a train.

title: BROKERAGE HOUSES IN CLEVELAND MERGE
description: CLEVELAND, June 6Agree ment in principle to merge the two largest Clevelandbased in vestment banking and broker age firms, Prescott, Merrill, Turben & Co., and Ball, Burge & Kraus was announced here today.

title: Dollar Rallies in Europe; Plea for Support Refused
description: PARIS, June 6Secretary of the Treasury George P. Schultz and Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chair man of the Federal Reserve Board, rejected today pleas for United States intervention to support the weakened dollar. The American currency, mean while, rallied on foreign ex change markets.

title: Rikers Inmate Found Hanged, 9th City Jail Suicide This Year
description: A 36yearold man serving a ninemonth sentence for crimi nal trespass hanged himself yesterday in his cell at the Correctional Institution for Men on Rikers Island.

title: Phnom Penh's Only Link to Sea Cut for 9 Hours by Communists
description: ANG SNUOL, Cambodia, June 6Phnom Penh's only over land link to the sea was cut here for nine hours today by Communist forces and there were signs that an important battle was imminent as thousands of refugees poured toward the capital.

title: Anthologist Sees Verse Getting Worse
description: In choosing poems for The New Oxford Book of English Verse, Dame Helen Gardner had no trouble with the mon uments: sonnets by Shake speare, satire by Pope, odes by Keats and narrative by Tennyson. But what about warhorses, strong in the memory, weak in the ribs, such as Abou Ben Adhem and If?

title: Sihanouk Aide Bids Australia Arrange Parley With Lon Nol
description: CANBERRA, Australia, June 6 (Reuters)Australia has been asked to arrange discussions between Prince Norodom Siha nouk and President Lon Nol aimed at forming a new gov ernment for wartorn Cam bodia, it was disclosed today.

title: George F. Getty 2d, Oldest Son Of Oil Billionaire, Dies on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6 George F. Getty 2d, son of the oil billionaire John Paul Getty, died of a cerebral hemorrhage at Queen of Angels Hospital here this afternoon at the age of 48.

title: Chinese Trade Gets Top Billing
description: The invitation said black tie and $25 a ticket and cocktails to start, which might have made the Chinese Film Festival premiere held last night at the Festival Theater on West 57th Street seem like just another charity benefit.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: 2 IN RUNOFF PLAN SOME TV DEBATES
description: Joint news conferences would be held by the two may oral candidates in the Demo cratic runofflimited to one subject and sure to get free time on televisionunder a pro posal yesterday by aides to Representative Herman Badillo that Controller Abraham D. Beame's team agreed to take under advisement.

title: Economic Mecca on Scotland's Firth of Forth
description: KIRKCALDY, Scotland, June 6John Kay, a burly former miner who is provost of this town on the Firth of Forth, stood on the flower banked stage and told his audience of econo mists, officials and townsmen:

title: Fire Evacuates Academy
description: ANDOVER, Mass., June 6 (AP)A general alarm fire broke out early today in a dormitory at Abbot Academy, an exclusive private girls' school, forcing evacuation of 108 girls. Fire officials said the blaze was confined to a smok ing room on the first floor of the East Wing of Draper Hall, a fourstory, brick dormitory.

title: Fashion Crowd Lets Its Hair Down at Plaza Party
description: There were any number of women gotten up as Zelda Fitzgerald the other night in front of the Plaza. But they weren't about to risk their rented 1920's finery by ca vorting in the Pulitzer foun tain; even though it had been cleared of its normal flotilla of paper cups and Good Hum or wrappers.

title: Yankees Win, 52
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., June 6 Amid reports that the Yankees were close to a deal that could strengthen their staggering pitching staff, Steve Kline came through tonight with successful test of his puzzling arm.

title: SMITH, NASTASE SCORE IN TENNIS
description: ROME, June 6 (AP)  Top seeded Stan Smith beat Fran cois Jauffret of France 62, 76, today and moved into the fourth round of the $135,000 Italian open tennis champion ships.

title: U.S. Decides Against Appeal Of Dismissal of Ellsberg Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  The Federal Government of ficially dropped today its effort to prosecute Dr. Daniel Ells berg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. for stealing and copying the Pentagon papers.

title: Governors Elect Shapp
description: STATELINE, Nev., June 6 (AP)Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania has been elected chairman of the MidAtlantic Governor's Conference. Mr. Shapp, who is attending the na tional Governors Conference here, succeeds Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey as chair man.

title: Dance: Louis Falco's Avenue Has Premiere Here
description: Avenue is the name of a dance work by Louis Falco given its premiere Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall. It preserves Mr. Falco's reputa tion, acquired within the last three years, as a young withit choreographer, and there was a young withit audience at the opening of the runthrough Sunday by the Louis Falco Dance Com pany.

title: U.S. and Saigon Boycott Vietcong's Anniversary
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 6 (AP)American and South Vietnamese officials boycotted a party tonight marking the fourth anni versary of the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government.

title: 3,000 Policemen Attend Funeral Services On L. I. of an Officer Slain in Bar Holdup
description: Police Officer Robert B. Laurenson, who was fatally wounded when he tried to thwart a holdup near Lincoln Center early Saturday morn ing, was buried behind his fami ly's church in Elmont, L. I., yesterday, a dozen gravestones away from another young New York City policeman, Lawrence Stefane, who was slain three years ago.

title: DCL REPORTS DROP IN SALES AND PROFIT
description: A drop in earnings and rev enues for the first quarter was reported yesterday by DCL, Inc., which through its wholly owned subsidiary, the Diebold Company, buys electronic data processing equipment for lease to others.

title: F.T.C. Petroleum Inquiry to End by July
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)  Lewis A. Engman chairman of the Federal Trade Commis sion, said that the yearlong in vestigation of the petroleum in dustry by his agency will be completed no later than July 1.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 7, 1973

title: JAVITS CITES DANGER IN DOLLAR SELLING
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) Senator Jacob K. Javits, Re publican of New York, said to day that those selling the dollar to buy gold may well wake up tomorrow with a speculative hangover.

title: Air Control System Ordered
description: Combustion Engineering, Inc., announced yesterday receipt of an order valued at more than $8million to supply an air qual ity control system for the Southwestern Public Service Company of Amarillo, Texas.

title: Spanish Fly Shot Down
description: Billed as The Original Vice Spice, Imitation Spanish Fly, safe, good tasting and creating a greater awareness, it cost $5 for a bottle of 24 capsules. But alas, Assistant Attorney General Stephen Mindell found it is only paprika. And yester day in State Supreme Court he obtained an injunction to pre vent the sale of this phony aphrodisiac in the S & li Book store, at 251 West 42d Street an adult bookstore.

title: People in Sports: To Chew and Eschew
description: A small plastic vial that pharmacists use to dispense pills in plain view on a shelf in the office of Bobby Win Ides, the manager of the Cali fornia Angels. When asked about it, he said: Oh that; it's not for any pills, it's only for some mouthwash I like to use after I finish chewing to bacco. No, I don't have an ulcer. If I had to take Maalox or any other stuff, I'd quit.

title: Miss Blalock Ban Ends; Golfer Will Get Purses
description: SUTTON, Mass., June 6 (AP)  Jane Blitlock, who countered a oneyear suspen sion by the Ladies Profession al Golf Association with a $5million Federal suit in 1972, said today the formal ban had been lifted and she now was entitled legally to all the money she won on the women's pro golf tour.

title: 3Day Hearing on City Budget Opens
description: Business and civic organiza tions called yesterday for cuts in Mayor Lindsay's proposed $10.6billion expense budget for 197374 while community groups pressed for more funds for local projects.

title: Texts of Documents Relating to Domestic Intelligence  Gathering Plan in 1970
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 The following are the texts of recommendations for in creased domestic intelligence gathering made to President Nixon in July, 1970, by an interagency Government committee; an analysis of the committee's report and of strategy to be used to secure Hoover; cooperation of J. Edgar Hoover; and a decision memorandum reflecting President Nixon's approval of the committee's recom mendations. The President later rescinded his approval after the plan was opposed by Mr. Hoover.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Ethel Kennedy, her children and Senator and Mrs. Edward M. Kennedy prayed at the grave of Sen ator Robert F. Kennedy yes terday in Arlington National Cemetery, The Kennedys stayed near the grave, which is marked with a simple cross, for a halfhour, begin ning at 7 A.M., on the fifth anniversary of the Senator's assassination in Los Angeles.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
description: Today, June 7

title: Dollar Rallies in Europe; Plea for Support Refused
description: PARIS, June 6Secretary of the Treasury George P. Schultz and Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chair man of the Federal Reserve Board, rejected today pleas for United States intervention to support the weakened dollar. The American currency, mean while, rallied on foreign ex change markets.

title: DDay Flag Returned To Village in France
description: STE.  MERE  EGLISE, France, June 6 (AP)  The first American flag to fly over France during the early hours of DDay, June 6, 1944, was returned to Ste.Mere Eglise today to mark the 29th anniversary of the allied land ings.

title: Options Exchange Traded 34,559 Contracts in May
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said yesterday that trading volume in May totaled 34,559 contracts, or options on 3,455,900 shares.

title: Mets Opera Variety Bow To Phils Harmonic Team
description: The New York Philharmonic beat the Metropolitan Opera in softball, 17 to 7, in Central Park yesterday. The Philhar monic hero was Michael Gil bert, who hit two home runs and ordinarily plays a violin. He hit them off Mitch Adl rich, who some of the time pitches with a cigarette in his mouth and ordinarily sings in the chorus.

title: Excerpts From Testimony at Inquiry by Senate Committee Into Watergate Case

title: Theater: Air of Unreality
description: In Lee Kalcheim's The, Boy Who Came to Leave, which opened last night at the Astor Place Theater, two young men inhabit a loft apartment. Paul lives there; Jonathan is becoming a per manent guest.

title: Transsexual Statistics
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 6 (UPI)A bill establishing a separate statistical category for persons who have had their sex changed has been approved by the state Senate Health Com mittee. Dr. Forest Ludden of the state Public Health Depart ment said curently persons who have had sex change operations are nothing to the state.

title: U.S. MISSILE SOLD TO 3 MORE IN NATO
description: BRUSSELS, June 6Britain, West Germany and Belgium agreed today to buy Lance surface tosurface missiles from the United States.

title: Port Agency Balks at Shifting TV Antennas to Top of Trade Center
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has asked the Federal Communi cations Commission to deter mine whether New York City's television stations should be allowed to shift their antennas from the Em pire State Building to the top of the authority's World Trade Center.

title: Meadowlands Engineers Plead Guilty on Deduction
description: NEWARK, June 6A Penn sylvania engineering concern that has a design contract for the proposed $268million Meadowlands sports develop ment pleaded guilty today to charges of illegally deducting political contributions to Gov ernor Cahill's firstterm cam paign on its 1968 and 1969 cor porate incometax returns.

title: TV Review
description: With summer television so far dominated by Watergate and dreary reruns, the Na tional Broadcasting Company had the right idea last night at 7:30 with a new marine life series called Inner Space.

title: Fighting Is Reported in Central Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 7 (AP)A se ries of shelling and infantry attacks was reported along the central coast yesterday, and the Saigon command and the Viet cong blamed each other for the continued fighting in the Me kong Delta.

title: Warning Signals...
description: With hindsight, it is apparent that I should have given more heed to the warning signals I received along the way about a Watergate coverup, and less to the reassurances, President Nixon stated on May 22. Note worthy among White House pronouncements on Water gate, this is a statement that is growing ever truer the disclosures mount.

title: Mental Health Parley Sees Sex Film
description: NEWARK, June 6An audi ence that included a veritable who's who in New Jersey men tal health circles was told to day that sex was still the num ber one taboo in this country.

title: Stock Prices Off at Close As Early Advance Falters
description: The stock market failed to sustain an early advance yes terday and finished slightly lower in slower trading.

title: An Adam Smith Sampler
description: The great work of Adam Smithlogician, philosopher, econo mistwas a twovolume treatise entitled An Inquiry Into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations, published in 1776. The following excerpts reflect the wide range of his thinking and, in some instances, its pertinence today:

title: Iraq Capsizal Kills 20
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 6 (Reu ters)Twenty people, most of them women and children, were drowned in the Tigris River in northern Iraq today when their ferryboat capsized, the official news agency reported.

title: Governor's Office Scrutinizes Lomenzo Job With Metromedia
description: Governor Rockefeller's office has begun an inquiry into the recent assumption by Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo of director's post on the board of Metromedia, Inc.

Erickson, a former Deputy Attorney General, gave an account today of the hurried transfer of files of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation from the Securities and Exchange Commission to the Justice De partment last October that, was totally at variance with an account given the same Congressional subcommittee by William J. Casey, a former S.E.C. chairman.

title: Youth Killed Near Manila
description: MANILA, June 6 (UPI)  A 17yearold New Jersey youth was killed Saturday when his motorcycle collided with a dump truck inside the Subic Bay Naval Base, 50 miles north west of here, Navy authorities reported today. The youth was identified as Ronald D. Kassab, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. Kassab of 219 Reading Ave nue, Barrington, N. J.

title: Books of The Times

title: EXTEAMSTER AIDE ORDERED CLEARED
description: A Federal District Court Judge in Brooklyn yesterday overturned the conviction of Harry Davidoff, former secre tarytreasurer of a teamsters local, who had been found guilty of violating the Taft Hartley Act.

title: Immunity Granted in Trial Over Sabotage of Carrier
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 (UPI)Immunity was granted today to the prosecution's balky chief witness in the trial of sailor accused of sabotaging the carrier U.S.S. Ranger, clearing the way for the witness's tes timony about the defendant's alleged admission of guilt.

title: Nixon Speaks Tomorrow At University in Florida
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI)President Nixon will deliver the commencement address Friday at 10:30 A.M. at Florida Technological Uni versity in Orlando, the White House announced today.

title: Excursion Is Adventure As Boat Survives Mishap
description: The excursion boat Bay Belle, carrying 1,338 high school stu dents, went aground for a short time yesterday morning off Ex ecution Rock, an island with a lighthouse in Long Island Sound.

title: DEAN IS ACCUSED ON BARKER TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 6A White House lawyer sought to persuade an official of Presi dent Nixon's political organiza tion to resist testifying at a Miami trial related to the Watergate affair, it was report ed in Senate hearings today.

title: S. E. C. QUESTIONS STOCK FEE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  The Securities and Exchange Commission indicated today that it had serious questions about some aspects of the in crease in commission charges on stock transactions that has been proposed by the New York Stock Exchange.

title: G.O.P. Quorum Call Halts McCloskey's Impeachment Speech
description: WASHINGTON, June 6An effort by Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., Republican of California, to open a tem pered discussion of the pos sible impeachment of President Nixon was halted tonight by a technical tumult on the floor of the House of Representatives.

title: Hoover Balked Nixon Aide on Security Plan in 1970
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 Tom Charles Huston, then junior man on the White House staff, set out three years ago to conquer the late J. Edgar Hoover as only a 29yearold newcomer to Washington would have tried.

title: National League
description: Thursday, June 7, 1973

title: Nixon Unit Donation To Agnew Backers Not Listed as Such
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 6 (AP)The chairman of Mary land's Republican party said to day that organizers of a 1972 fundraising event honoring Vice President Agnew hid for nearly a year a $49,900 con tribution from the national Committee for the Reelection of the President.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The 30th annual Carey Thomas Awards for distinc tion in publishing were presented yesterday to Atlan ticLittle, Brown, George Braziller, Inc., and the Yale University Press.

title: Stein Wins Hochster Golf With 145 at Quaker Ridge
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 6 Doug Stein of the Glen Oaks Club won the 40th annual Will iam R. Hochster amateur golf tournament today with a 36 hole total of 145.

title: Million at English Derby
description: EPSOM, England, June 6 (AP)Morston, 251 outsider, won the English Derby today with a thundering break through in the final furlong before a record crowd es timated at one million.

title: SINAI CRASH STUDY NOTES CONFUSION
description: As for myself, I prefer to turn back immediately. The Libyan Arab Airlines Boeing 727 jetliner did not turn back, and 24 minutes after one of its crewmen uttered these words, the plane was scattered in flames over the Sinai desert.

title: Moscow Will Pay Damages To Paris for TU144 Crash
description: MOSCOW, June 6 (UPI)The Soviet Union will pay France for damage caused by Sunday's (crash of a supersonic TU144 airliner near Le Bourget air port, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: DOCUMENTS SHOW NIXON APPROVED PARTLY ILLEGAL '70 SECURITY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  President Nixon approved a plan for expanded domestic in telligence gathering in July, 1970, after being cautioned that parts of it were clearly illegal and involved serious risks to his Administration if the operations were ever dis covered, according to White House documents.

title: Mets Obtain Hodges, an Untried Catcher
description: The Mets straggled back to New York last night after a disastrous trip and braced themselves for the same teams that had just mauled them nine times in 12 games in the West.

title: Maddox Attends Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) Former Gov. Lester G. Mad dox of Georgia sat in on the Senate Watergate hearings to day as a guest of Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Georgia Democrat, ho is a member of the committee.

title: ZAPATA OFFERED 200MILLION DEAL
description: The Zapata Corporation, which through subsidiaries is engaged in offshore drilling of oil and gas wells, announced yesterday that it had been of fered about $200million in cash and secured shortterm notes for its international bulk ship ping operation, the Zapata Naess Shipping Company, Ltd. The buyer was not identified by Za pata. The price, according to Za pata would be substantially more than its investment in the subsidiary, which through a group of companies controls an oceangoing fleet of 41 ships. The ships carry crude oil and dry bulk raw material's such as coal, iron ore, bauxite and phosphate rock.

title: MRS. ARTHUR SMITH
description: GREENPORT, L. I., June 6  Mrs. Sada Smith, a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution and founder of the Shelter Island chapter, died to day in Eastern Long Island Hos pital. Her age was 89. She was the widow of Arthur Smith.

title: TRIPLE JUMP MARK IS SET BY LIVERS
description: Ron Livers, a 5foot8inch, 134pound senior from Norris. town (Pa.) High, posted the best schoolboy triple jump it the nation this year when he did 51 feet 7 inches yester. day.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Motorists who have been speeding through the toll lanes at the city's bridges and tunnels without paying are now to be faced with new obstaclesstriped gates similar to those used at railroad crossings. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that the gates had been installed on the Triborough and VerrazanoNarrows Bridges and that it expected to install them within the next few weeks at the Throgs Neck, BronxWhitestone and Henry Hudson Bridges, the Midtown and Brooklyn Battery Tunnels and the Cross Bay and Marine Parkway Bridges.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York Philharmon ic beat the Metropolitan Opera in softball yesterday, 17 to 7, in Central Park. The Philharmonic's hero was Michael Gilbert, who hit two homers and ordinarily plays a violin. Gilbert hit the homers off Mitch Aldrich, who some of the time pitches with a cigarette in his mouth and ordinarily sings in the Met chorus. It was the Phil harmonic's fifth straight vic tory, some of their other con quests being Indianapolis and Detroit Symphonies and the Juilliard School of Music.

title: Pugs Make Their Mark In German Show Rings
description: MONTE CARLOAlthough Mrs. Susan Blalack started her pug kennel only three years ago, it now is the second largest on the con tinent. In that comparatively short time, she has had eight international champions.

title: Roundup: Giants' Goodson Earning Respect as Hitter
description: Just a couple of days ago, Ed Goodson was complaining that he got no respect in the San Francisco lineup and then last night he added credence to his growing repu tation as a hitter by provid ing the lead run with a sixth inning single in the Giants' 97 victory over the Pirates in Pittsburgh.

title: Chinese Foreign Minister Begins 5Day Visit to Britain
description: LONDON, June 6 (UPI) Foreign Minister Chi Pengfei of China began a fiveday offi cial visit to Britain today.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (Reuters)The Nixon Admin istration, in a further effort to control inflation and sta bilize prices, announced today that it would resume sales tomorrow of surplus stockpile tin after five years.

title: ExAddicts Sue Postal Service Over Denial of Jobs as Clerks
description: Two former heroin addicts who say they have shaken the drug habit sued the Postal Service yesterday, charging that their Constitutional rights had been violated when they were denied jobs as clerk/car riers.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ORANGE June 6The athletic feats of Monte Irvin are remembered well by many residents of this city, where Irvin was a foursport star before becoming a professional baseball player.

title: TWO ENGLISH STARS BOW IN WALES GOLF
description: PORHCAWL, Wales, June 6 (AP)It was a disastrous day for the English at the British amateur golf championship to day as Trevor Homer, the de fending champion, bowed out in the second round and Mike Bonallack, a fivetime winner, withdrew with an injury.

title: Lindsay Offers New Plan To Get the Madison Mall
description: Mayor Lindsay will make an other attempt to bring off the Madison Mall. A slightly re vised version of the plan has been presented to the Board of Estimate, and it is sched uled for a vote on June 21. Details will be disclosed by the Mayor at a news conference Monday.

title: YearRound Classes Due At Tenafly High School
description: TRENTON, June 6Tenafly has become the first New Jer sey school district in more than 20 years to adopt a yearround curriculum.

title: Consumer Credit Showed Slower Advance in April
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  Both total consumer credit and consumerinstallment cred it slowed their rapid growth in April, the Federal Reserve Board Board reported today.

title: Cambodian Royalty Attempting to Lead Ordinary Lives
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 6The royal family of Cambodia, disgraced and under close confinement by a hostile revolutionary Government for three years, has cautiously be gun its reentry into the prob lems of daily life in a city at war.

title: Indochina: The Moral Difficulties
description: BANGKOK, ThailandWhile Europe basks in the sun of dtente and, in the United States, people breathe more easily after the rapprochement with the People's Republic of China and im proved Soviet relationsdevelopments which led to the halt of hostilities in Vietnam  Thailand still remains bogged down, neckdeep, in the cold war quagmire because of a massive American military presence and un warranted use of Thai territory for war operations in Indochina.

President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles put the heaviest pressure on the British to call the invasion off. But the Prime Minister, Sir Anthony Eden, said his Government would not take orders from its great ally.

description: WASHINGTON, June 6 President Nixon lost a key round in his fight against infla tion tonight as the House voted to increase the Minimum wage for nearly 35 million workers to $2.20 an hour within a year and to extend coverage for the first time to about a million house hold servants.

Petty Officer Constantine Ko stakis went to police head quarters in uniform today and later told that his request had been granted.

title: The Next Stage

description: YONKERS, June 6 Yon kers Raceway weaved a web of nostalgia tonight, present ed a free scratch sheet to each customer that produced an early $32.60 for $2 winner and presented the fabled, re tiredtrotter Su Mac Lad in a colorful oldtimers night pro gram that proved a whopping success.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Police Officer Robert B. Laurenson, fatally wounded when he tried to thwart a holdup in a bar near Lincoln Center in Manhattan last Saturday, was buried yesterday in the graveyard of his family's church in Elmont, L. I.

title: British Businessman Seized By Argentine Kidnappers
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 6A wealthy Britishborn business man was kidnapped today by four unidentified men outside his home in the northwestern, suburb of Hurlingham, about 20 miles from the Argentine capital.

title: JOSEPH MANN, 79, IMPRESARIO, DEAD
description: Joseph Mann, manager since 1914 of the Peoples' Symphony Concerts, died yesterday of cancer at the Dewitt Nursing Home. He was 79 years old and lived at the Mayflower Hotel, 15 Central Park West.

title: Ethiopian Fundamentalists Under Fire, Pray in Secret
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 1  Two collegeage couples, moving carefully near the teeming central market here, entered a small house one recent evening, locked the doors and shuttered the win dows.

title: SENATORS RESIST DOMESTIC AID CUT
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  The Senate Finance Committee unanimously approved legisla tion today to block Administra tion efforts to reduce drastical ly Federal aid to such programs as day care and aid to the elderly.

description: WEST POINT, N. Y., June 6James J. Pelosi was grad uated from the United States Military Academy here today, more than a year and a half after he was officially si lenced by his fellow cadets.

title: African Group Opens Drive
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Afri care, an organization that seeks to improve health care in rural Africa, began a national fund raising drive today with the announcement of a ninenation benefit tour in Africa by singer Robert A. Flack.

title: 3 in Pleasure Boat Missing After Crash With Barge in the Delaware
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP)Three men were miss ing and believed to have drowned after their 18foot pleasure boat and a barge collided late yesterday in the Delaware River.

title: Stage: Canadians Excel in She Stoops to Conquer
description: STRATFORD, Ontario, June 6What is it that makes Goldsmith's She Stoops to Conquer one of the most delicious of comedies? This year it celebrates its 200th anniversary, and the Strat ford company, by way of homage perhaps, has brought last season's production back into the repertory. It was a wise move, for it shows the company at its best.

title: Screen: 'Elvis on Tour':Performer Is Pictured On and Off Stage The Cast
description: A natural spin-off of the rock concert tour is the rock concert tour film, at which Pierre Adidge and Robert Abel ("Mad Dogs and Englishmen," "Let The Good Times Roll") are such experienced hands that I suspect they were inhibited by the magnitude of their latest subject, Elvis Presley. Or perhapsdare I say?his minitude.The movie is called "Elvis on Tour" and it purports to be an intimate portrait of Elvis as he revealed himself on recent tours, while performing onstage and while getting on and off airplanes, on and off buses, and in and out of limousines. Strip away the storybook myth andlothere is a storybook myth underneath: a nice, clean-cut, multimillionaire pop idol who is, offstage, hard-working and friendly and something less than a riveting personality.The essential blandness of the offstage Elvis has the effect of diminishing the impact of what we see of the onstage performances, which are presented with a lot of fancily photographed and edited split-screen frills that ultimately suggest that Elvis is much duller to watch than to hear.Whether this is his fault or the fault of the moviemakers, I don't know. It is quite apparent that Mr. Adidge and Mr. Abel are treating him with the kind of respect that French television used to reserve for the formal appearances of De Gaulle. The camera never catches him in a truly candid moment. Close-ups do not reveal anything but, rather, they enshrine an ideal, like an official photograph of a President or a Pope.Compared with "Mad Dogs and Englishmen," which chronicled the American concert tour of Joe Cocker in a way that reflected Cocker's tumultuous talent, "Elvis on Tour" seems almost stately. Elvis himself looks vaguely ill at ease in his baby blue (or scarlet), rhinestone-studded Batman costume, not really formidable enough to be announced (as the film does) with the first several bars of "Thus Spake Zarathustra."The film opened yesterday at the East 59th Street Twin 2 Theater and other theaters.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, THURSDAY, JUNE. 7, 1973
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Just down the corridor from the na tionally televised Watergate hearings, another Senate corn mittee listened today to ap peals from several Senators for reforms in the Federal election laws to prevent future Water gates.

title: Prices of Commodities Decline; Reports of Controls Are Factor
description: Commodity futures prices generaly declined yesterday, reacting to more reports that the Government planned firm steps such as price controls and export embargoes to deal with inflation.

title: Kissinger and Tho Resume Talks in Paris
description: PARIS, June 6Henry A. Kissinger and Le Due Tho of North Vietnam resumed their private talks today on how to enforce the Vietnam peace agreement signed Jan. 27.

title: A ChineseAmerican Judge Expected in State in Fall
description: New York State is expected to get its first ChineseAmeri can judge when the election for the Civil Court in Manhat tan is held in November.

title: 28,000 Tons of Cod
description: Another clash between British trawlers and an Ice landic patrol vessel last week underscores the dangers in a deepening dispute between two NATO allies.

title: 38 Food Handlers Cited on Violations Of City Health Code
description: Thirtyeight restaurants and other food establishments are on the Health Department's latest list of places found to have violated the city's Health Code.

title: Sham Gets Belmont Entrymate
description: Secretariat is by all odds the horse to beat in the Bel mont Stakes on Saturday, and Frank (Pancho) Martin is almost obsessive in his de termination to conquer the Meadow Stable colt. Martin trains Sham, the colt who finished second to Secretariat in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, and up until yesterday Martin was satis fied to go it alone against Secretariat.

title: Afghanistan Modernizing Hesitantly
description: KABUL, AfghanistanThe other morning a handful of donkeys followed by a camel and half a dozen cars began moving, suddenly and inexplicably, through a red light on Djadi Maiwand, a busy main street in down town Kabul. An angry police officer chased one of the donkeys and began hitting the animal with a stick, tying up traffic and creating a hornhonking tangle.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 6 (UPI)Bookmakers and the Totalizator Agency Board paid out thousands of dollars today on the wrong horse because of a mixup of saddle cloths. Manhattan Lady was signaled as having finished second at Canterbury race track and paid $84 to place. But Manhattan Lady had really finished last and her stablemate, Fairy Slipper, wearing Manhattan Lady's saddle cloth, finished second. Later, both horses were disqualified, but T.A.B. offices were paying out on the wrong horse until early this evening.

title: Lindsay Offers New Plan To Get the Madison Mall
description: Mayor Lindsay will make an other attempt to bring off the Madison Mall. A slightly re vised version of the plan has been presented to the Board of Estimate, and it is sched uled for a vote on June 21. Details will be disclosed by the Mayor at a news conference Monday.

title: Youth, 18, Gets 15 Years For, Attempted Murder
description: An 18yearold Bronx youth who pleaded guilty to attempt ed murder, robbery and assault of a 53yearold storekeeper in Brooklyn last August was sen tenced yesterday to 15 years in prison by State Supreme Court Justice Harry J. Donnelly.

title: Skilled Presidential Assistant
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  Melvin Robert Laird, named as counselor to the President for domestic affairs, spoke today to reporters at the White House and the key element he brings to that troubled center of executive power was quickly apparent.

title: Old Team
description: In his choice of Melvin Laird, former Secretary of Defense and veteran Congressman from Wisconsin, as the new head of his domestic policy staff, President Nixon has selected a man with the political skills and experience which the former occupant of that postJohn Ehrlichmanconspicuously lacked. The appointment has evoked a predictably favorable reaction on Capitol Hill and from Republican party activists.

title: SheepShearing in Midtown Draws a Large, Cheering Crowd
description: BAA BAA, BAA BAA... protested the shaggy, white faced ewe yesterday as Robert Taylor, a Biblical: looking sheep shearer, yanked her from a red Volkswagen truck and then coaxed her down the stairs to the sunken plaza of the new McGrawHill building.

title: Rhode Island Abortion Law Held to Be Unconstitutional
description: BOSTON, June 6 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit upheld to day that a lower court opinion that a strict law curbing abor tions enacted in Rhode Island in March was unconstitutional. It declined to extend a stay to permit further appeal.

title: Astronauts Ready for Repair Walk
description: HOUSTON, June 6The Sky lab 1 astronauts were prepared tonight for a daring space ad venture tomorrow  a space walk in which they will try to release a stuck solarpower wing on their orbiting space station.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Wisconsin Public Service Corporation yes terday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commsson in connection with an offering of 900, 000 shares of common stock through Merrill Lynch and Robert W. Baird & Co. The utility's stock closed at 16, up  on the New York Stock Ex change.

title: Swedish Wife Awaits 3d Child,M. D. Degree
description: STOCKHOLM, June 6  The big question in the Er hardt household nowadays is which will come firstthe third child or Mrs. Erhardt's M.D. degree.

title: ITALY'S TOP PARTY SEEN SHIFTING LEFT
description: ROME, June 6The Chris tian Democratic party, Italy's dominant but disunited political force, today opened a national convention in a search for sta bility that is expected to bring about a shift to the left.

title: BOMB PLOT LAID TO EXBALLPLAYER
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6 (UPI)  Gerald Priddy, 53 years old, a onetune baseball player who landed with a World Series1 team his first year in the ma jors, was charged today with attempted extortion of $250,000 on threat of setting off bombs on a luxury cruise liner.

title: Terminal to Cut Hours
description: Grand Central Terminal will close from 1:30 A.M. to 5:30 AM, starting July 2. Thirty four trains will be dropped and seven stations discon tinued. The Federal Govern ment directed New York State to consider expanding the terminal before building a railroadsubway terminal under Third Avenue. Page 49.

title: SERIES OF MISHAPS BESET FREIGHTER
description: Coast Guard officials said yesterday that the American Export Lines freighter that; rammed a Belgian oil tanker: early Saturday morning in the Narrows after losing control of its steering mechanism had been plagued by mishaps since she was built in 1968.

title: Dr. George B. Burch, 70, Tufts Authority on India
description: BELMONT, Mass., June 6 Dr. George B. Burch, professor emeritus of philosophy at Tufts University and an authority on India and Hindu thought, died Monday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

title: Upstate Campus to Become A Retirement Community
description: SYRACUS, June 6 (AP)The 88acre Manlius campus of the ManliusPebble Hill School has been sold to a realstate de velopment concern for conver sion into a retirement commu nity.

title: Australia Asks Revision on U.S. Bases
description: NEW DELHI, June 6Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia said here today that he had requested modification of the 1963 agreement with the United States under which American military installations are maintained on his coun try's Northwest Cape.

title: Moorer Lauds the Military At West Point Graduation
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., June Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told 939 graduating ca dets at the United States Mili tary Academy here today that peace could not be achieved by good will and wishful thinking alone, but that a strong military must continue to provide a credible deter rent to war.

title: PRICES OF BONDS RALLY FOR 2D DAY
description: Bond prices rallied for the second straight session yester day, with the market embracing any news report that could be interpreted as leading to less inflation, such as tighter eco nomic controls, and mostly ignoring those that clouded such hopes.

title: Silent Agony Ends for Cadet at Point
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., June 6James J. Pelosi was grad uated from the United States Military Academy here today, more than a year and a half after he was officially si lenced by his fellow cadets.

title: American League
description: Thurday, June 7, 1973

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NOON TUNE If the welkin is ringing middays over in Brooklyn, you can trace it to Borough Hall, that borough hub consisting of the park, the ball itself and an altogether downtown ambi ance. Every weekday, from noon to 2, there is a Boro ?? Happening, a longrun ?? variety program sched ?? through Sept. 15.

title: Nicklaus Changes Strategy for Open Drills
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., June 6 Can the strategy Jack Nick laus is using help him win next week's United States Open? Only twice in Big Jack's suc cessful professional career has he decided to compete in a golf tournament the week prior to the Open, the game's premier test.

title: City Considering Burning Trash in Con Ed's Boilers
description: The Lindsay administration, after years of searching for a solution to one of its most per sistent problems, has decided that the most promising way of getting rid of the city's gar bage is to burn it in Consoli dated Edison Company boilers.

title: AMEX SHARES UP IN QUIET TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthe counter market rose yesterday In quiet trading.

title: Astronauts Free Skylab's Power Wing
description: HOUSTON, Friday, June 8 The fixit crew of Skylab I pulled off the first major repair job in space yesterday when, in a daring space walk, they managed to deploy a stuck solarpower wing on their or biting space station.

title: MobLinked Conduits Get Subpoenas in Payola Case
description: A Federal grand jury in Newark has subpoenaed offi cers of nonexistent trucking companies, limousine services, airline ticket agencies and other concerns that allegedly were links for payoffs from record companies to Mafia fig ures, sources close to the case said yesterday.

title: Jim Cullum, Clarinetist Who Started Jazz Band
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 7 (AP)Jim Cullum Sr., who founded the Happy Jazz Band here, died today of lung cancer. He was 59 years old.

title: Sports Ticket Scalpers Get Millions, State Says
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday disclosed sixmonthold investigation of In alleged multimilliondollar clack market in the most oughtafter hot sports tick ?? in town, including those or Knickerbocker, Ranger, Gi ?? and Jet games.

title: BIG BOARD SEEKS TO RESCIND RULE
description: WASHINGTON, June 7The New York Stock Exchange took steps today to curb the impact of rule changes that threaten to drain sorelyneeded revenues from its member firms.

title: Rate of Monetary Growth Advanced Sharply in May
description: Monetary expansion acceler ated markedly during May for the second month in a row, the Federal Reserve disclosed yesterday.

title: CAHILL WITHHOLDS SANDMAN BACKING
description: TRENTON, June 7Governor Cahill refused today to en dorse Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s Republican candidacy for Governor.

title: HALDEMAN DENIES A KEY ROLE IN '70
description: WASHINGTON, June 7H. R. Haldeman told a House sub committee today that he was merely the conduit between President Nixon and drafters of 1970 plans for expanded do mestic intelligence gathering.

title: DEATH OF GETTY SON IS LINKED TO DRUGS
description: LOS ANGELES, June 7 (Reu ters)The Los Angeles County coroner's office ruled today that George F. Getty 2d, the 48yearold eldest son of John Paul Getty, the oil billionaire died here yesterday from an overdose of barbiturates and alcohol.

title: Brooklyn Policeman Accused of Running A Betting Business
description: A police sergeant in Brook lyn was arrested yesterday and charged with moonlighting as one of the operators of a $30, 000aweek bookmaking busi ness.

title: Arbitrator Denies $8Million For Residuals to TV Union
description: An impartial arbitrator has denied more than $8million in claims for replay payments made by the American Federa tion of Television and Radio Artists against the three tele vision networks and several producers.

title: Trustees of Lehigh Valley Ask Court to End Service
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 7 The Federal Railroad Adminis tration and the Department of Transportation joined with the trustees of the bankrupt Lehigh Valley Railroad here today in asking a Federal disrict court to fix a date for the cessation of railroad operations of the 1,021mile carrier. But the Inter state Commerce Commission, which would have to author ize train discontinuance, asked the court to deny the petition of the trustees, who have sug gested Oct. 1 as a tentative liquidation date.

title: U.S. Defends Honor Panel At West Point in Suit Here
description: The Federal Government as serted yesterday that if the Cadet Honor Committee at West Point were forced by the courts to comply with the re quirements of due process of law, the Honor Code as it now exists would effectively be de stroyed.

title: HALDEMANSfATES WATERGATE DOUBT DISTURBED NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  President Nixon urged his aides, both before and after the election last Nov. 7, to clear up the Watergate case and ease public doubts, according to H. R. Haldeman, former White House chief of staff.

title: EDUCATION BUDGET AIRED AT HEARING
description: Chinese parents speaking in their native dialect, teachers of the deaf using sign language, and mothers of handicapped children pleaded for more edu cational funds yesterday during budget hearings by the Board of Estimate and the City Coun cil Finance Committee.

title: Amex Seats Sold at $37,500, Up $9,500 From Last Sale
description: Three seats on the American Stock Exchange were sold for $37,500 each yesterday, up $9,500 each from the last sale May 28.

title: 611 of 1,034 Pass Examination For Admission to the State Bar
description: ALBANY, June 7The State Board of Law Examiners an nounced today the names of 611 applicants who passed the examination given last March 13 and 14 for admission to the bar.

title: Excerpts From Transcript of Testimony Before Senate's Watergate Committee
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 Following are excerpts from a transcript of testimony in the eighth day of hearings on the Watergate case today be fore the Senate Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

title: Cahill Vetoes Bill Requiring Changes In School Bus Seats
description: TRENTON, June 7 (AP)A bill that would require special seats instead of seat belts to protect children on school buses was conditionally vetoed today by Governor Cahill.

title: After the Coup, Restoring the Trust
description: NOTRE DAME, Ind.On Jan. 18, 1961, promptly at 10:29 A.M., Sterling Green of The Associated Press said: Thank you, Mr. President, and in stantly, amidst a standing ovation from 309 journalists, Dwight David Eisenhower, thirtyfourth President of the United States, waved goodby as he concluded his 193d news confer encehis last.

title: Notes on People
description: Foreign Minister Chi Peng fei of China and Sir Alec DouglasHome, the British Foreign Secretary, met in London for what were de scribed there as the first ma jor diplomatic talks between ranking representatives of the two countries in almost 25 years. Mr. Chi is the first Foreign Minister from Peking to visit London since the Communists took control of China in 1949. Among the topics expected to he dis cussed at the meetings was the possibility of new airline links between London and Peking. Mr. Chi is scheduled to confer with Prime Minister Heath today.

title: New York Stock Exchange Transactions
Pakistan Airline Buys Jets
description: Pakistan International Air lines announced yesterday it had ordered three longrange, widebodied Douglas DC10 Se ries 30 jet aircraft costing $100million. The first of the planes is scheduled for delivery in February, 1974, the second in March of that year and third in March, 1975. P.I.A, also has an option to purchase three ad ditional DC10s in 1976.

title: Pvt. Smiles Fits Profile of Belmont Spoiler
description: Hey, Mooch, a young groom called to an old groom yesterday in C. V. Whitney's barn at Belmont Park, you got any bread?

title: G. E. and 2 Major Unions Reach Tentative Accord on 22% Raise
description: New agreements between the General Electric Company and two major electrical work ers unions will provide raises and costofliving increases that could total 88 cents an hour, or 22 per cent over 37 months, for 100,000 workers.

title: CEMETERY STRIKE MAY BE EXTENDED
description: Striking gravediggers plan to expand their walkout Sun day morning  unless agree ment is reached by thento include 47 metropolitan area cemeteries, Sam Cimaglia, the union president, announced last night.

title: Irving S. Mates, 56, Dies; Published Trade Journals
description: Irving S. Mates, president of BMT Publishers Press, Inc., 145 Avenue of the Americas, died at Memorial Hospital on Wednes day. He was 56 years old.

title: Nixon Names Kelley for F.B.I.; Senate Confirmation Expected
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  After a sixweek search, Presi dent Nixon named Clarence M. Kelley, police chief of Kansas City, Mo., today to be director of the Federal Bureau of. In vestigation.

title: Saigon Won't Sign a Pact, But Hints It Would Accede
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 8  The Saigon Government said this morning that it would not sign any new appeal to carry out the Vietnam peace agreement that was put Forward by the United States and North Vietnam.

title: Experimental Jazz By Castaluquingan
description: There is a lively amount of experimental, noncom mercial new jazz in the New York area, and it has much in common with avantgarde classical music in this city. Neither, attracts a large pub lic; both break down old structures in their search for newand often similarex pressive devices; both share many of the same patrons, Performing spaces and pub licity; and both equate their music in occasionally explicit fashion to the art world.

title: SOVIET'S EXPORTS OF OIL SHOW DROI
description: MOSCOW, June 7  For th?? first time since World War II the Soviet Union has reporter a decline in its net export o?? petroleum, which has Iong served as a major earner of the foreign exchange needed to ac quire Western equipment and technology.

title: Roundup: Unexpected Bat Helps White Sox Win, 32
description: When the Chicago White Sox acquired Eddie Leon from Cleveland for Walt Williams, an outfielder, last October, they were looking for a glove not a bat, but after their 32 victory over the Orioles in Baltimore last night it appears they may have gotten a bonus.

title: Nixon Aide Sees Waning Role for Connally
description: WASHINGTON, June 7John B. Connally's role on President Nixon's staff will shrink no ticeably in the next few weeks, a ranking White House official declared today.

title: Brandt Arrives for Israeli Visit, Noting We Cannot Undo Past
description: JERUSALEM, June 7With the Israeli Army band playing Deutschland uber Alles, Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany arrived here today on a fourday state visit heavy with emotional memories.

title: Wedding of Mrs. Horstmann To Arthur Houghton Jr. Held
description: Arthur A. Houghton Jr., chairman of the board of Steuben Glass, and Mrs. Nina Horstmann were married in a civil ceremony in Annapo lis, Md., on May 22. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. J. I. Rodale of Allentown, Pa., and the late Mr. Rodale, whose enthusiasm for organic farming brought him fame and fortune through his mag azines and books.

title: SEAVER AND JOHN TO START TONIGHT
description: After a disastrous mad trip in which they won only three of 12 games while their in jury list grew to calamitous length, the Mets hope to field a competitive team tonight at Shea Stadium when they open a ninegame home stand against the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Hypertension Peril Found on Increase Among City Youths
description: The New York City Health Research Council yesterday called attention to the leading contributing factor to death and disease in this city as well as the country  high blood pressure.

title: Rise in Prices Announced For Sugar and Chlorine
description: Price increases for several major commodities, including sugar and chlorine, were an nounced yesterday by a num ber of companies.

title: Panel on Family Therapy Popular at Health Talks
description: NEWARK, June 7When the twoday conference or mental health at the Robert Treat Hotel wound up here today, the most popular of the various small panel dis cussions proved to be family therapy. As it has in years passed, the family therapy panel played to standing room only even though space had been increased to allow for 150 participants.

title: Off Off Broadway Shows
description: It's advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices before going to the show. Most, if not all, theaters accept Theater Development Fund vouchers.

title: 12 HELD IN KILLING OF POLICE OFFICER
description: Two men were arrested last night and charged with the mur der of Police Officer Robert B. Laurenson, who was slain while trying to thwart a holdup in a West Side tavern early last Sat urday.

title: Load of LSD Seized
description: SEATTLE, June 7 (UPI) Enough LSD to turn on 80,000 persons was seized yes terday as a drug dealer attempt ed to make delivery to another dealer, according to the United States Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs. David F. Ladely, 31 years old, was ar rested carrying 26 pounds of the hallucinogenic in five brown plastic garbage bags, a bureau spokesman said.

title: Humphrey Charges Lag in Giving Food To Infants of Poor
description: WASHINGTON, June 7De partment of Agriculture offi cials were criticized today by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey for not spending authorized funds in a special food program for pregnant women and babies.

title: FORMER NAZI LOSES EXTRADITION APPEAL
description: The United States Court of Appeals upheld yesterday court proceedings that stripped a for mer Nazi concentration camp guard of her United States cit izenship and made possible her extradition to West Germany to face charges of murdering prisoners.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 8, 1973

title: OldTimers Run Le Mans Race as It Used to Be Run
description: LE MANS, France, June 7 The ancient cars went sputter ing down the Le Mans circuit seconds after the elderly gen tlemen went puffing across it.

title: English Cow Gives Birth to Calf Grown From 2d Cow's Embryo
description: LONDON, June 7A calf grown from an embryo that was removed from its mother and frozen for a week before being implanted in another cow was born at an agricultural research unit near Cambridge today.

title: Kissinger and Tho Meet After a Delay of a Few Hours
description: PARIS, June 7  Henry A. Kissinger and Le Due Tho continued their discussions to day in a meeting that had been postponed for several hours at Ithe American's request.

title: Dance: There's This Tub Built for Six
Fuchsberg Staying Ahead of Weinstein In Chief Judge Race
description: Jacob D. Fuchsberg continued to lead Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein by a fragile margin yesterday in the race for the Democratic nomination for chief judge of the state.

title: Child Missing Since Wednesday Sought in Yankee Stadium Area
description: The police and students of the area around Yankee Stadi um searched yesterday for Maria Acierno, a 3yearold girl who disappeared from a small park opposite her home at 901 Walton Avenue.

title: Colson Says Dean Urged Hunt to Flee the Country
description: WASHINGTON, June 7John W. Dean 3d, the former White House counsel, ordered E. How ard Hunt Jr. to flee the coun try two days after the Water gate burglary, Federal prosecu tors have been told by Charles W. Colson, who was then spe cial counsel to President Nixon.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mrs. Eleanor Holmes Norton, chairman of the city's Commission on Human Rights and the Mayor's executive assistant for neighborhood government, told the City University Graduate School's ninth annual doctoral com mencement that there were signs of economic recupera tion here. She said, for example, that the loss of manu facturing jobs had slowed and that employment gains nonmanufacturing industries have more than offset manu facturing job losses500,000 service jobs in 1950 becoming 790,000 by 1970.

title: Loeb, Wall St. Banker, Is Fined On Campaign Gift to Humphrey
description: John L. Loeb, a prominent Wall Street investment banker was fined $3,000 in Federal Court here yesterday for illegal ly disguising a $48,000 con tribution to Senator Hubert H Humphrey's unsuccessful cam paign for the Democratic nomi nation for President last year.

title: Jan Attwood Bride of David McGreevy
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 7William Attwood, president and publisher of Newsday, and, Mrs. Attwood have announced the mar riage on May 26 of their daughter, Miss Jan Attwood, to David McGreevy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Mc Greevy of Miami. The civil ceremony took place in Chapel Hill, N. C., where the bride has a secretarial job and Mr. McGreevy is with a construction firm.

title: Astronauts Free Skylab's Power Wing
description: HOUSTON, June 7The fixit crew of Skylab 1 pulled off the first major repair job in space today when, in a daring space walk, they managed to de ploy a stuck solarpower wing on their orbiting space station.

title: HALDEMAN STATES WATERGATE DOUBT DISTURBED NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  President Nixon urged his aides, both before and after the election last Nov. 7, to clear up the Watergate case and ease public doubts, according to H. R. Haldeman, former White House chief of staff.

title: Morning at Belmont
description: Lucien Laurin hung up the telephone in the cottage next to Meadow Stable's barn at Belmont Park and walked out through sunshine to the postandrail fence along the road. In two hours entries would close for the 105th Belmont Stakes and he hadn't yet dropped Secretariat's name in the box. But I do not think they will let me forget, he said. The trainer fretted about his $6million colt before he won the Kentucky Derby. When he got Secretariat's stall on the morning of the Prealiness he said he hoped the horse had enjoyed a better night's sleep than he had. Now with the Triple Crown in sight, the little man was suffering visibly. If we can just get through 24 hours more, he said. I'll be glad when it's over. They make such a fuss about this horse; If we got beat I guess I would hide in a hole like a groundhog.

title: CONSPIRACY CASE ON MARGIN FILED
description: A broker and a Swiss banker were indicted by a Fed eral grand jury here yesterday on charges that they conspired between 1965 and 1971 to buy $67million of stock entirely on credit.

title: Witness Details Workings Of the Recording Industry
description: The former Columbia Rec ords executive who has been cooperating with Federal au thorities in their investigation of payola and narcotics traffic in the recording industry de tailed yesterday the events that led to his appearance be fore a Federal grand jury, and his decision to tell the Federal Strike Force Against Organ ized Crime in Newark any thing and everything I know about the record business.

title: The Screen:Oedipus Myth Is Theme of 'Parade of Roses'
description: Eddie, the transvestite hero of Toshio Matsumoto's 1969 Japanese film, "Funeral Parade of Roses," keeps up a brave but frankly fake front.While his lover, Gonda, has a post-breakfast cigarette, Eddie frets with his hair. "Do you like it up or down?" he asks Gonda, who is the manager of Tokyo's Club Genet, where Eddie works as a B-boy. Gonda likes Eddie with hair up or down, but he has a ferocious mistress named Leda, who's jealous of Eddie and threatens to tell the cops about Gonda's drug trade.Eddie is young, beautiful and in love, but his story is messier than the plots of a half-dozen Bette Davis films. "I feel as if life left me behind some time ago," he says.He keeps having these visions. Well, they aren't truly visions. The're more like flashbacks. As a child, Eddie murdered his mother and her lover with a carving knife. That was extremely messy and led to a certain period in jail, which was no fun at all.The one stable factor in Eddie's life is Gonda, but when you read in the ads that "Funeral Parade of Roses" is "a modern reworking of the Oedipus myth," you are given a major clue as to who Gonda actually is. When Eddie finds out, it's back to the old carving knife.Like Eddie, who wears make-up, wigs, miniskirts and false eyelashes, which are as thick as the brushes in a carpet sweeper, the movie spends most of its time trying to disguise, its identity. "Funeral Parade of Roses" is a mopey soap opera made by someone who has seen too many better movies.Matsumoto uses speeded-up action, reverse-negative photography and "in" movie jokes that the subtitles invariably get wrong, as in a reference to "Jonas Mecas." Time is splintered for no apparent purpose and individual sequences are introduced by title cards that say such things as "all doors are already open."The film shows us an underworld of male prostitutes, pimps and drug pushers that looks comfortably middle-class, not much more desperate than Saturday at a country club. As literature, "Funeral Parade of Roses" is closer in spirit to something like "A Stolen Life," in which Bette Davis played twins, than it is to the work of Gent, whose name the film uses in vain."Funeral Parade of Roses" opened yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room.

title: New Representative Sworn
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (Reu ters)Mrs. Cardiss Collins, widow of a Democratic Repre sentative from Illinois, was sworn in today to replace her husband as a member of the House. She won a special elec tion on Tuesday to fill the va cancy.

title: Market Place: The Influence; Of Institutions
description: Many investors are tlisen chanted with the stock mar ket because they feel unable to compete with the huge in stitutional traders that now account for the bulk of the volume on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Colson Says Dean Urged Hunt to Flee the Country
description: WASHINGTON, June 7John W. Dean 3d, the former White House counsel, ordered E. How ard Hunt Jr. to flee the coun try two days after the Water gate burglary, Federal prosecu tors have been told by Charles W. Colson, who was then spe cial counsel to President Nixon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Too many of your correspondents are still missing the point about nu clear safety. By stressing the great care taken in fission technology, they evade the central question: Are the safety problems of fission too difficult to solve? If they are, then (as Profes sor Alfvn points out) one cannot claim that they are solved by pointing to all the efforts made to solve them.

title: Senate Approves Top Policy Council Of Education Group
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  The Senate confirmed today the appointment of a 15mem Iber policymaking council for the National Institute of Educa tian, ending months of contro versy over the conduct of the new agency, which is supposed to provide central direction to federally supported education al research.

title: Classic Schiavone Canvas Is Purchased by the Met
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has purchased what is considered by critics to be an outstanding and historically important canvas by the 16thcentury Venetian Andrea Schiavone. It will go on dis play today.

title: Syria Says Israel Sent Jets to Invade Territory on Coast
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 7 Syria charged that Israeli jets tried twice today to penetrate her air space but were driven off.

title: New F.B.I. Chief
description: Clarence M. Kelley is an experienced, competent and thoroughly qualified expert in law enforcement. Because of his work over the last dozen years in Kansas City, he would probably be on any list of the best police chiefs in the nation. Having earlier served for twenty one years in the F.B.I., he is also familiar with the work and the problems of the agency. His nomination as F.B.I. director deserves sympathetic consideration by the Senate.

title: SIDEROWF ADVANCES IN GOLF AT WALES
description: PORTHCAWL, Wales, June 7 (AP)Dick Siderowf, a 36 yearold stockbroker from East on, Conn., fought his way into the quarterfinals of the British Amateur golf championship to day, the last of 50 United States competitors who started the title chase four days ago.

title: SEAVER AND JOHN TO START TONIGHT
description: After a disastrous road trip in which they won only three of 12 games while their in jury list grew to calamitous length, the Mets hope to field a competitive team tonight at Shea Stadium when they open a ninegame home stand against the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Joseph Macchia of Civil Court, ExLindsay Manager, 57 Dies
description: Judge Joseph A. Macchia of the Civil Court, 111 Centre Street, died in Roosevelt Hos pital yesterday after heart surgery. He was 57 years old and lived at 530 East 23d Street.

title: Nazi Party Linked to G.O.P. AntiWallace Move
description: LOS ANGELES, June 7  Secret funds from President Nixon's reelection campaign financed an unsuccessful effert to remove Gov. George C. Wal lace's American Independent party from the, California ballot last year, according to a former Nixon campaign official.

title: State and City Suing a Legal School, Charging Deception on Jobs as Aides
description: A training school for lawyers' assistants has been sued by the city and state on charges of having failed to live up to its promise that students would get jobs as paralegal assistants, starting at at least $9,000 a year, or would get their full tuition refunded.

title: Man Held in Extortion Plot On Coast Gets New Lawyer
description: LOS ANGELES, June 7 (UPI)  Gerald Priddy, a former major league baseball player accused of trying to  extort $250,000 from a cruise ship line with bomb threats, dis missed his lawyer today.

title: Boating Outlook
description: The National Weather Serv ice issued this forecast at 6:45 P.M. yesterday for New York Harbor, Long Island Sound, Long Island south shore and nearby coastal area:

title: BEAME CAMPAIGN GOES ON STREET
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame shook hands serenely through crowds of shoppers in Manhattan and elderly bench sitters in the Bronx yesterday while his staff  apparently caught unaware by his failure to win 40 per cent of the vote on Monday  worked to im provise a runoff mayoral cam paign.

title: Nicklaus Trails by Eight Strokes on a 73
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., June 7  Jack Nicklaus, here to sharp en his game under competitive conditions for next week's United States Open, scored a 73 today and trailed an obscure campaigner, Jim Barber, by eight strokes in the first round of the $150,000 I.V.B. golf tournament.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 7 (UPI)Charles O. Finley said today he could not afford to lose $550,000 a year and was selling the Memphis Tams of the American Basket ball Association to a Providence, R. I., group. Finley also owns the Oakland Athletics in baseball and the California Golden Seals in hockey.

title: Lone Dutch Sailor Rescued
description: KEY WEST, Fla., June 7 (UPI)A Dutch sailor found in his 35foot sloop south of Key West was hospitalized today for sunburn and exposure. A Coast Guard spokesman said the man, idulitified as Jakob Jonker, spoke no English, but indicated that he had been adrift for two months on a voy age from Curacao, in the Dutch West Indies, to the Netherlands.

title: THOMAS F. DRISCOLL
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 7 Thomas F. Driscoll, a retired executive of Armour & Co., the meat packers, died last night. He was 92 years old.

title: Fresh Hope for Ulster
description: Elections on both sides of the border that divides Ireland have generated modest hopes for a turn toward peace in Ulster.

title: Yanks Acquire Dobson and McDowell
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., June 7The Yankees took two startling steps today in their determined effort to win a pennant. In separate deals announced about seven hours apart, they acquired two onetime 20game winnersSam McDowell from the San Francisco Giants and Pat Dobson from the Atlanta Braves.

title: Karate Kick Kills Youth
description: PASCO, Wash., June 7 (UPI) Ronald D. Morrison 18 years old of Pasco, died from a karate kick in the chest during a city sponsored karate class, accord ing to officials.

title: AUSTRALIA WEIGHS SIHANOUK REQUEST
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 7 A Government official said to day that a request from a rep resentative of Prince Norodom Sihanouk for Australian help in arranging talks with President Lon Nol of Cambodia might have to await consideration by the Australian Cabinet.

title: Senate Panel Contends Cox and Courts Have No Authority to Restrict Its Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  The Senate Watergate commit tee contended today that nei ther the Federal courts nor the special prosecutor in the case had the authority to prevent the committee from taking tes timony from Watergate figures in public and on television.

title: MRS. IRENE CARR
description: Mrs. Irene Carr, who retired from The New York Times as a telephonedepartment supervis or last year, died of cancer Tuesday at her home in Cape Coral, Fla. She was 65 years old.

title: N.C.A.A. Track Summaries
U.S. Reassures Philippines Of Continuing Aid Program
description: MANILA, June 7American officials reassured the Philip pines today of continued mili tary and economic assistance.

title: OldTimers Run Le Mans Race as It Used to Be Run
description: LE MANS, France, June 7 The ancient cars went sputter ing down the Le Mans circuit seconds after the elderly gen tlemen went puffing across it.

title: U.S. Cautions NATO Allies on Security and Affirms Its Support
description: BRUSSELS, June 7The Unit ed States cautioned its Atlantic allies today that the Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact continued to pose a nuclear and nonnuclear threat to Western Europe and that the present climate of improved relations could change overnight.

title: Biggest Street Scalper Unperturbed
description: Leroy, an amiable 36year old family man with a Brook lyn apartment filled with Spanishmodern furniture, proudly described himself as the United States's biggest street scalper. No one has disputed his claim.

title: U.S. Said to Reject New French Plea To Support Dollar
description: PARIS, June 7With the cur rency markets nervous once more, France today renewed her demand for United States inter vention to support the sagging dollarand the United States was reported to have rejected the demand again.

title: L. T. Bauman Weds Miss Margy Block
description: Miss Margy Block, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Cy Block of Lake Success, L. T. was married here last evening to Lawrence Todd Bauman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Bauman of Great Neck, L. I. Cantor David Benedict per formed the ceremony in the Plaza.

title: Keeping It Secret
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  One extreme seems, alas, to call forth an other. And so, in the wake of Water gate, guardians of the press are shouting that the perils of secrecy far outweigh its advantages. What, we must ask, can they mean by that? Are there to be no state secrets?

title: Child Missing Since Wednesday Sought in Yankee Stadium Area
description: The police and students of the area around Yankee Stadi um searched yesterday for Maria Acierno, a 31/2yearold girl who disappeared from a small park opposite her home at 901 Walton Avenue.

title: Sports Ticket Scalpers Get Millions, State Says
description: Attorney General Louis J. efkowitz yesterday disclosed a sixmonthold investigation of an alleged multimilliondollar black market in the most soughtafter hot sports tick ets in town, including those for Knickerbocker, Ranger, Gi ant and Jet games.

title: Bridge:Last Hours in Tourney Play Were Happy for Contender
description: The death of a player dur ing a tournament is always a cause of sadness, but a grain of comfort can sometimes be found if it is clear that his last hours at the bridge table were happy and successful. This was the case during the American Bridge Association tournament here two weeks ago, when Frank Tucker of Montclair, N. J., suffered a fatal heart attacx two days after capturing the Mixed Pair title.

title: The Cahill Collapse
description: Having won his election by a landslide four years ago, Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey has now lost his bid for renomination in the Republican primary by what may be called a reverse landslide. He received only about 40 per cent of a total vote that was itself disap pointingly small.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 8, 1973

title: Governor Signs Bill That Limits Power of Urban Renewal Agency
description: ALBANY, June 7  Governor Rockefeller signed into law to day a bill that curbs some of the power of the State Urban Development Corporation, one of the Governor's pet agencies.

title: JAMES R. GILMORE
description: WEST LOVELL, Me., June 7 James R. Gilmore, who had been a pilot for Pan American World Airways for 33 years when he retired last year, died today at Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 60 years old and had lived here for the last several years.

title: HAROLD K. LAROWE
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 7 Harold X. LaRowe, who re tired as purchasing director of the American Cyanamid Com pany in Wayne, N.J., in 1962 after 15 years in the post, died today in Lawrence Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived here.

title: The Theater: Othello Is Given by Stratfordians
description: STRATFORD, Ontario, June 7  The great dis advantage of David William's production of Othello, which opened rather shakily at the Festival Theater in Canada last night, is the Othello. To take unfortunate first things first, Nachum Buchman, the very dis tinguished Israeli actor from the Habima Company, who is playing Othello, does not really have sufficient command of the English language to pull it off. It is absolutely amazing that the festival director, Jean Gas con, did not have the sense to realize that before the opening and save everyone, including, I presume, Mr. Buchman, a great deal of em barrassment.

title: FordHall Team Shares Lead in Anderson Golf
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 7  Mike Ford, a Rollins Col lege senior who was beaten in the final last year while playing with Bob Christie, dem onstrated today that he may again be a top factor in the Anderson Memorial fourball golf tournament.

title: G.M. EXPECTS SALES TO REMAIN AT PEAK
description: Edward N. Cole, president of the General Motors Corpora tion, said yesterday that he did not expect a break in the rec ord rate of auto sales until March, 1974, and even then it might not be much of a breather.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on June 7 were:

title: New Jersey Sports
