title: A Haunted Playwright
description: When William Inge saw Tennessee Williams's The Glass Menagerie in Chicago in 1944, he thought he saw a way of life in which he could participate. If Mr. Williams could make something poign antly beautiful out of com monplace people, Mr. Inge realized that the people he knew in his na tive Kansas had creative mean ing. Born and educated in Kan sas, steeped in the familiar culture of the Middle West, he understood the hopes and frustrations of middleclass people because he was one of them.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Senator's DrugFrame Trial to Open

title: Diana Wynn Married
description: Miss Diana Blake Wynn and Michael Bruce Riegler were married here yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Lewis Stat low performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Wynn of New York, father and stepmother of the bride, whose mother is Mrs. Karen Blake Wynn of Lewes, England. Mr. Wynn is deputy commissioner of the New York City Addiction Services Agency. The bride groom, son pf Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Riegler of Bayside, Queens, is a student at Queens College.

title: Screen: 'The Hireling':Cannes Co-Winner Is at 68th St. Playhouse
description: "The Hireling," Alan Bridges's film version of the L. P. Hartley novel, is about England in the nineteen-twenties, about county aristocracy, about the cruelties of a class system that Hartley (who also wrote "The Go-Between") remembers with an outrage so tempered that it often seems a kind of fondness.Lady Franklin (Sarah Miles) is recovering from a mild breakdown she suffered following the loss of her husband, a young Tory Member of Parliament for whose death she feels vaguely responsible. She was at a party when it happened. It? Probably a heart attack, though we never learn exactly. Lady Franklin wears sensible shoes and cardigans that droop almost to the floor. She doesn't much care what she looks like, but she knows she must take hold.In a hired limousine, a magnificent old Rolls-Royce, which takes her from the clinic to her mother's house in Bath, Lady Franklin engages the chauffeur in small talk. She talks to the back of his head, to one eye seen in a mirror. She tells him that people say things to one another but rarely make contact. He answers "yes, my lady," because it's his style and because his customers are always right.When they arrive at her mother's and Leadbetter, which is the name of the chauffeur, gets out to open the door for Lady Franklin, the camera suddenly looks at him for the first time. Lead-better (Robert Shaw) is not just the back of a head, an eye and a uniform. He is a singular man, youngish, handsome, polite and, above all, calculating. Lady Franklin has been so invigorated by the depth of their communication that she engages Leadbetter to take her on a series of afternoon drives.Thus begins "The Hireling," which is about the recovery of Lady Franklin and the misunderstanding that develops between the lady and the chauffeur. It's all very cool and precise and, to me, anyway, a bit less than entirely engrossing. The characters in Wolf Mankowitz's screen play simply aren't very interesting, despite a calm, intelligent performance by Miss Miles and an almost diabolical one by Shaw who, not really tragically, aspires to love above his station.For Lady Franklin's benefit, the unmarried Leadbetter fabricates a complete family for himself, with stories about two small children and a wife named Frances who looks at lot like her ladyship. Lady Franklin, in turn allows Leadbetter to think she fancies him. She insists on riding next to him in the front seat. She draws him out about his business as well as family affairs, and she even lends him money so that his Rolls won't be carried off by creditors."The Hireling" is very good in individual scenes, in the look of its landscapes, in its observation of manners and especially in its refusal to overexplain narrative details. However, by effectively reducing the conflicts within the English social order to a misunderstanding, It becomes not only silly but grossly misleading.The excellent supporting cast includes Peter Egan, as an ambitious young Liberal politician, who succeeds with Lady Franklin without half trying; Elizabeth Sellars, as Lady Franklin's mother, who is as self-absorbed as Lady Franklin will one day be, and Caroline Mortimer, as Egan's cast-off mistress."The Hireling," which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, shared the grand prize at this year's Cannes Film Festival with an American film, "Scarecrow."

title: S.I. PARISH OFFERS DRIVEIN SERVICE
description: Mrs. Joan Tellefsen yester day eased her Dodge camper into the parking lot of Zion Lutheran Church of Staten Is land, turned off the motor, set the brake and sat back with her three children for a drive in church service.

title: PopMusic Scandal Laid to Pursuit of Fast Money
description: Pop music is a business in which some 25yearold super stars gross $3million a year while others die from a heroin overdose, a business in which $10,000 press parties and $1 million touring road shows are not uncommon, a business in which a former school teacher can get $150 for a subscription to a mimeographed tip sheet predicting hits.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator Sam Ervin was stating a truism when he told John J. Caulfield that our greatest conflicts arise when we must choose between our loyalties. The current debate raging over whether Senator Ervin's committee should con tinue his open, televised hearings represents such a choice for the American people.

title: NAGUA TRIUMPHS IN HUNTER EVENT
description: GREENWICH,. Conn:, June 10After E. C. Bowen's Nagua won the green working hunter championship at the Greenwich Horse Show today, his rider proclaimed the 5yearold brown gelding in the best form of his career.

title: Atlantic City Blaze Destroys 500 Club, Famed Night Spot
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 10A generalalarm fire that raged for more than four hours today virtually wiped out the 500 Club, the entertainment spot where Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis first performed as a team and where many other big name stars once played.

title: MARCHI ADVOCATES EAST RIVER TOLLS
description: State Senator John J. Marchi, the Republican candidate for Mayor, yesterday recommended placing bridge tolls on the East River crossings and he chal lenged the Democratic mayoral candidates to support him by urging that the matter be placed on the agenda of the special legislative session in July.

title: FREEDOM URGED FOR RADIO AND TV
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 10 Television and radio station should be freed immediately from all Government control over the content of their broad casts, including requirements for political balance and fair ness on issues, a conference of lawyers and journalists pro posed yesterday.

title: GIMBEL AND F.T.C. NEAR SETTLEMENT
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The staff of the Federal Trade Commission and Gimbel Broth ers, Inc., are close to a settle ment of the yearold complaint by the F.T.C. on Gimbel's alleged restrictive covenants in 24 shopping centers.

title: Court Orders a Company to Fill Cavern It Dug Off Staten Island
description: A Chicago company has been ordered, in what was described as the first case of its kind, to fill in a giant cavern in Lower New York Bay that state en vironmental officials said had been caused by the company's unlawful dredging operations.

title: A New Geography Wins Greater Scholarly Respect
description: To most Americans, the study of geog raphy probably conjures up dim grade school recollections of memorizing dreary facts about the flax production in Poland, the length of rivers in India and the loca tion of the Torrid Zone.

description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Opera
description: What is style, and how is it acqqquired? These ageold questions having to do with theater performance were raised again and again on Saturday night by the Metro politan Opera's presentation of Mascagni's Cavalleria Rusticana, in which the leading roles were taken by Rgine Crespin and Enrico Di Giuseppe.

title: Old Statue Gets LongLost Head
description: CAIRO, June 10The head and torso of a 2,600yearold statue of an Egyptian notable were joined here today after having been separated for 2,000 years, and the young Frenchman from Brooklyn who made the reunion pos sible called it a fantastic event in iconography.

title: Dodgers Inflict 5th Def eat in Row on Koosman, 40
description: Apart from the fact that 41, 319 persons paid to watch them, the Mets gained absolutely nothing at Shea Stadium yes terday as Claude Osteen of the Los Angeles Dodgers stopped them on three hits, 40.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WAYNE, June 10A tennis dynasty is being created here.

title: Radio
description: 6.6:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Sonata in D, Stradella; Flute Concerto in D, Galuppi; Sinfonia Concer tante in C. Boccherini

title: 7 Jewish Scientists, Forbidden To Quit Soviet, in Hunger Strike
description: MOSCOW, June 10 (AP) Seven Jewish scientists, dis missed from their jobs and barred fromleaving the Soviet Union, began a hunger strike today.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The performing arts of Asia will be featured in a series of programs at Carnegie Hall next season under the joint auspices of the Asia Society and the Carnegie Hall Corpo ration, by arrangement with the city's Department of Cul tural Affairs.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The pilot of a homemade airplane powered by a Volks wagen engine was killed Saturday in Ocean County in New Jersey when the plane crashed on its first test flight. The pilot, Raymond W. Kowell, 54 years old, of Staten Island, had built the 10footlong singleengine plane with his son, Paul. Mr. Kowell's wife, Martha, 43, suffered a heart attack and was hospitlaized when she heard her husband had been killed.

title: Crenshaw Ready for Open
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., June 10 (AP)Ben Crenshaw of Austin, Tex., the country's leading ama teur golfer, fired a closing round of 67 today and won the Sun nehanna amateur golf tourna ment by three strokes. Cren shaw, a. University of Texas standout who will compete in the United States Open this week had a 275 total.

title: Workers at Two Guys Vote to Extend Strike
description: NEWARK, Tune 10 (UPI)Retail clerks voted today to strike at an additional 22 Two Guys department stores in North Jersey, extending the sixday walkout to all of the stores on the East Coast, union officials said.

title: Bonn's Watergate Rivals Washington's in Confusion
description: BONN, June 10 (AP)  A cartoon in one of West Ger many's biggest newspapers last week showed Uncle Sam and John Bull sitting in a coinop erated laundry, with bundles of dirty laundry labelled Water gate and Lambton Sex Scan dal. Timidly approaching, with his dirty linen, was Grober Michel, the peasant character with the tassel cap who repre sents West Germany. His bun dle was labeled The Steiner Case.

title: Rochester Strike Continues
description: ROCHESTER, June 10 (AP)About 200 drivers of readymix concrete trucks, on strike since April 16, rejected a proposed new contract today, union of ficials said. A spokesman for Teamsters Local 398 said the strike against six Rochester area concrete suppliers would continue.

title: As Open Classroom Spreads, More Parents Face a Decision
description: Parents have always had to live by decisions. Now one of the questionsand it's a vital one  is going to be Open or traditional class room?

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on the Middle East.

title: FordHall Team Victor In Anderson Golf Final
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 10  For the second straight year collegians dominated the Anderson Memorial four ball golf event as Mike Ford and John Hall captured the 37th edition of the tournament to day.

title: Getting It Right This Time
description: MILL VALLEY, Calif.An indepth survey conducted among three New York cabdrivers stuck in crosstown traffic, two rushhour bus passengers and a man coming up out of the sub way suggests that a hundredyearold proposal of Dr. R. H. Gilbert's for an elevated railway might still be worth try.

title: VICTOR ERIC TAUSIC
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., June 10  Victor Eric Tausig, a con troller for Sears, Roebuck until his retirement in 1956, died here yesterday at the geriatric center of the Long Island Jew ish Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 15015 79th Avenue, Kew Gardens Hills, Queens.

title: Purchase College Holds First Graduation
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., June 10Two years ago the first 200 fulltime students to enter the State University of New York College at Purchase sat hud dled under a rainsoaked tent behind the administration build ing to receive their initial orientation.

title: Higher Money Cost Expected inCapital Markets
description: This assessment, widely held by analysts of the capital mar kets, prevails even if it is as sumedas virtually all com mentators now dothat some rather vigorous action to tighten controls will be announced shortly. The question now is not whether the Administration will tighten di rect controls to curb inflation, but only how much and when, said the research department of Blyth Eastman Dillon & Co., Inc., in its weekly letter, written late last week for pub lication this morning. The to tally terrible wholesale price statistics just reported [up 2.1 per cent] for May clinches the matter, the firm said.

title: A New CeaseFire Reported in Draft Of Paris Document
description: TOKYO, June 10 (Reuters)The Kyodo news agency said today that the draft of a docu ment agreed on at the Paris negotiations to salvage the Viet nam ceasefire had called for both sides in the South to order a ceasefire 24 hours after the document was signed.

title: Mrs. Meir Says Moses Made Israel OilPoor
description: JERUSALEM, June 10 (AP)  Let me tell you something that we Israelis have against Moses, said Premier Golda Meir. He took us 40 years through the desert in order to bring us to the one spot in the Middle East that has no oil.

title: Pekingese Best at Fairfield Show
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 10Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords Jr., who on Thursday night was chair man of the huge Belmont Ball, turned from the world of the thoroughbred horse today and calmly watched the Pekingese, Ch. Dagbury of Calartha, whom she coowns with Michael Wolf lof North Babylon, L. I., win his fourth best in show. This time it was at the 41st Longshore Southport Kennel Club event on the grounds of Fairfield Uni versity, with the little red cam paigner leading a record field of 1,895.

title: Petty Takes Alamo 500 As Bid by Baker Fails
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., June 10 (AP)Richard Petty, a fourtime NASCAR driving champion from Randleman, N.C., broke away from a neck andneck duel with Buddy Baker on the 214th lap today and won the Alamo 500 stock car race at Texas World Speed way. Each drove a 1973 Dodge.

title: STRIKE EXPANDED TO 47 CEMETERIES
description: Striking gravediggers refused to bury the dead at more ceme teries yesterday as they ex tended their twomonthold walkout from three cemeteries to all 47 in the metropolitan area.

title: Aides in Saigon Are Optimistic That Paris Talks Will Succeed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10American and South Vietnamese officials in Saigon wearily began preparing today for yet another round of Paris talks in search of a way to carry out the Vietnam cease fire strictly.

title: Priscilla Jane Jeffery Is the Bride In Mystic of Roger David Atkins
description: MYSTIC, Conn., June 10Miss Priscilla Jane Jeffery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wil liam Prentiss Jeffery Jr. of Greenwich, was married in St. Mark's Episcopal Church here this afternoon to Roger David Adkins, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Edward T. Adkins.

title: Josephine Baker, the Legend Is Back
description: Josephine Baker returned to Harlem early yesterday and re newed her legend on the stage of the Victoria Theater.

title: Contract Extension Averts Westinghouse Strike Threat
description: PITTSBURGH, June 10 (AP) Negotiators for the Westing house Electric Corporation and four major unions agreed today to a daytoday contract ex tension, temporarily averting threatened strike by 68,000 workers.

title: Books of The Times
description: Stefan Kanfer takes the title and the theme of his book, A Journal of the Plague Years, from Defoe. As Mr. Kanfer sees it, the blacklist that was most operative in the nineteenforties and fifties was a com municable disease, infecting everyone who touched itor was touched by it. Because they refused to answer House UnAmerican Activities Committee questions about par ticipation in leftist activities (or simply be cause they were named byothers in testi mony or listed in one of the many watch dog magazines that proliferated during this period), people were driven to unem ployment, bankruptcy, exile, pseudonymity, prison and suicide.

description: The Federal Bureau of Inves tigation and the District At torney's office in San Diego County in California are inves tigating charges that a top as sistant to Representative Sam Steiger, Republican of Arizona, planted an illegal listening device in a wall of a San Diego hotel as part of an investiga tion being conducted by the House Select Committee on Crime, of which Mr. Steiger is a member.

title: 2 KILLED IN BELFAST IN SEPARATE ACTIONS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 10 (AP)Two men were shot to death in separate in cidents here today, and four teenagers were hit by snipers from a speeding car.

title: N. T. Kwit Jr. Weds Miss Susan Hallett
description: Miss Susan Trenery Hallett was married here yesterday afternoon to Nathaniel Troy Kwit Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Kwit of 470 Park Avenue. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence T. Hallett of Bangor, Pa.

title: Harvard Ousted in Baseball Series
description: OMAHA, Neb., June 10 (AP)Tom Bigwood stopped Harvard on two hits and Georgia Southern pounded out 13 hits today for an 80 college world series baseball victory.

title: Chase Bag Elects Chairman
description: Francis H. Ludington, Jr., has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Chase Bag Company, it was an nounced over the weekend. The company, whose headquar ters are in Greenwich, Conn., announced also that John A. Book has been elected presi dent and chief operating officer.

title: Aussies Beaten in Golf
description: ASHAIKAWA, Japan, June 10 (AP)  Graham Marsh of Aus tralia scored a ninesroke vic tory today in the individual competition, but Japanese pro golfers beat the Australian team by five strokes in a 54 hole match between the coun tires. Marsh, the 1972 and 1973 champion of the Asian golf circuit, closed with a 67 for 209. Yoshitaka Yamamoto of Japan was second at 218.

title: Eastern Europe Is Flexible in Dealing With West
description: BUCHARESTThe dramatic appeal of big Western trade deals with the Soviet Union has stolen the limelight from East European countries which have already moved into more flex ible and experimental forms of industrial cooperation with the West.

title: JAMES K. NORRIS
description: James K. Norris, former chairman of the Utica Drop Forge and Tool Corporation and later president of the Cen tral Foundry Company in New ark, died yesterday at his summer home in Northeast Harbor, Me. He was 80 years old and lived also at 120 East End Avenue and in Palm Beach, Fla,

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Threedimensional maps of the United States, drawn by computer from census data, show con centration of population and how it has shifted toward the West in the last decade. Nevada, for example, although lowest area in density, has ex perienced heavy growth.

title: Secretariat Enjoys Lazy Belmont Day Away From Cheers
description: Secretariat started a two month vacation yesterday by enjoying what horsemen call a completely lazy day at his barn at Belmont Park.

description: To most Americans, the study of geog raphy probably conjures up dim grade school recollections of memorizing dreary facts about the flax production in Poland, the length of rivers in India and the loca tion of the Torrid Zone.

title: The Travers in August Looms As Secretariat's Next Race
description: Secretariat will race again, probably in the $100,000 Travers at Saratoga on Aug. 18. Now, however, the home bred Meadow Stable star is enjoying a rest following a strenuous spring campaign in which he rolled to record breaking success in the 1 mile Kentucky Derby, a mootrecord triumph in the 1 3/16mile Preakness, and a quite unbelievable record breaking score in Saturday's 1mile Belmont Stakes.

title: BEANIE SEEKS OUT THE ETHNIC VOTES
description: Under a cloudless sky  a politician's best advance man  Controller Abraham D. Beanie sought out the voters in their sunny Sunday habitats yesterday and managed, in the process, to touch bases with several of the city's major ethnic groups.

title: Westbury Beats Bethpage In Polo League Opener
description: BETHPAGE, N.L., June 10Westbury overwhelmed Beth page, 83, today in the Metro politan Polo League opening game at Bethpage State Park.

title: Ellen B. Kanner Bride of Brian Donovan
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK, L.I., June 10Miss Ellen Barbara Kanner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Lee Kanner, was married this afternoon to Brian R. Donovan, son of Mrs. Marion E. Casey of Syracuse and the late Wil liam E. Donovan.

title: WEISKOPF VICTOR BY FOUR STROKES
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., June 10 I want to win the Open next week, that's my goal, said Tom Weiskopf today after his 14underpar 72hole total of 274 won the I.V.B. Golf Classic by four strokes.

title: JESSE FELD, ACTUARY FOR CITY SINCE 1961
description: Jesse Feld, actuary for the City of New York since 1961, died of a heart attack Saturday on the Split Rock golf course in the Bronx. He was 65 years old and lived at 8615 Broadway, Elmhurst, Queens.

title: ALL 47 CEMETERIES ARE STRUCK HERE
description: Striking gravediggers refused to bury the dead at more ceme teries yesterday as they ex tended their twomonthold walkout from three cemeteries to all 47 in the metropolitan area.

title: Nixonalysis
description: WASHINGTONThe President has set the antennae of Nixonwatchers quivering by selecting Ron Ziegler to take charge of all outward appear ances, Mel Laird to call the shots on noneconomic domestic affairs, and Al Haig to be general manager of the White House.

title: STATE'S OUTPUT OP SYRUP DROPS
description: ALBANY, June 10  For the first time in recent years, New York State has fallen from first place as the country's leading producer of maple syrup, as the result of a disastrously early and warm spring in the maple sugar tree belt.

description: Secretariat started a two month vacation yesterday by enjoying what horsemen call a completely lazy day at his barn at Belmont Park.

title: Bank of Canada Raises Its Credit Rate to 6%
description: OTTAWA, June 10 (Reuters)  The Bank of Canada an nounced today that it had raised its bank credit rate by  per cent to 6 per cent, the third increase in two months.

title: End to Slide in Stock Market Is Forecast by Analysts
description: The behavior of the stock market has been confounding ivestors for months. The na tion's economy has been ro bust and corporate profits are setting records. Yet the market has been iii the doldrums and wall Street's spirits are at low ebb.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1973
description: International

title: Brooklyn Man Is Accused Of CabRelated Crimes
description: A Brooklyn man robbed a taxi driver, stole the cab, side swiped three children before he drove the vehicle into a ditch, and then fired a shot at a pur suer before he was captured in Queens yesterday, the police reported.

title: ABRAHAM E. HORN
description: Abraham E. Horn, vice presi dent of the Sun Chemical Com pany and general manager of its A. C. Horn division until his retirement in 1952, died at his home here yesterday. He was 87 years old and lived at 135 East 71st Street.

Dagbury of Calartha, whom she coowns with Michael Wolf of North Babylon, L. I., win his fourth best in show. This time it was at the 41st Longshore Southport Kennel Club event on the grounds of Fairfield Uni versity, with the little red cam paigner leading a record field of 1,895.

title: Vatican to Buy 600 Works By Modern Artists in U.S.
description: The Vatican will purchase at least 600 works by mod ern American artists over the next five years for its new museum, according to Law rence Fleischman, director of the Kennedy Galleries, who has been serving as the Vat ican agent for its purchases here.

title: In the Name of Security
description: BOSTON, June 10  To prevent crippling strike during the Korean War, President Truman seized the country's steel mills. There was no law authorizing the seizure. But when the steel companies sued to get their plants back, Government lawyers said the President had inherent power un der the Constitution to prevent such a national catastrophe.

title: MARY MILLS WINS 2D LP.G.A. TITLE
description: SUTTON, Mass., June 10 (AP)Mary Mills rallied with six birdies on the last nine holes and won the Ladies Professional Golf Association championship for the second time today, posting her first tournament victory since 1970.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Krulwich
description: At the Jewish Center here yesterday, Miss Terry Ann Krulwich, an assistant pro fessor of biochemistry at the Mount Sinai School of Medi cine, was married to S. Paul Posner, an associate profes sor of law at New York Uni versity. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Leo Jung and Norman Lamm.

title: William Inge, Playwright, Is Dead
GREENSPUN TO FIGHT ON HUGHES DATA
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 10The publisher of the Las Vegas Sun, Hank Greenspun, said to day that he would move in Fed eral court tomorrow to quash a subpoena of documents that concern the financial dealings of Howard R. Hughes, the in dustrialist.

title: Chase Stotttemyre In 4thMayberry Hits 14th Homer
description: KANSAS CITY, June 10 The Yankees 7.4 loss to the Kansas City Royals today served to point up a couple of reasons why the team isn't ready to run away from the rest of the Eastern Division.

title: Nepal Says Hijackers Got $400,000
description: NEW DELHI, June 10 (AP) Three armed men hijacked a twinengine Nepalese air, liner across the Indian bor der today and escaped into the jungle with about $400, 000, the Nepalese Embassy reported.

title: JEROME W. NAMMACK
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 10  Jerome W. Nammack, vice chairman of the board of gov ernors of the New York Stock Exchange from 1958 to 1960 and a member of the board from 1953 to 1959, died at his home here today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 73 years old and lived at 379 Stewart Avenue.

title: A HardEarned Age of Affluence Is Dawning in Japan
description: TOKYO, June 10  For most of the 104 million Jap anese, the affluent society has arrived. They have be gun to share in the rewards of the economy after years of hard work in which the emphasis was on industrial progress.

title: William Inge, Playwright, Is Dead
description: HOLLYWOOD HILLS, Calif., June 10William Inge, whose steady production of prizewin ning plays illuminated Broad way in the nineteenfifties, was found dead in the garage of his home early today, apparently suicide. He was 60 years old.

title: Roundup: Twitchell, the Slugger, Gets Three Hits and His Second Shutout
description: Wayne Twitchell has pitched with little distinction in his two previous major league seasons. His biggest recognition, although nega tive, came last month as a batter when he tied a Na tional League record by striking out eight consecu tive times in two games.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THREE RINGS Trinity Church, Wall Street and Broadway (2696640), is be ginning its fifth season of free arts and entertainments. with something doing every weekday.

title: Dangerous Threshold
description: Looking from afar at the entire history of American security policies, wrote David Brion Davis, historian at Yale University, one is struck by the appalling dis crepancy between noisy commotion and actual danger, At times we have approached the threshold of be coming a police state.

title: Heat Fills Beaches and Roads to Them
description: A sparkling Sunday and the lure of ocean breezes sent New Yorkers in full force to beaches yesterday for the first time this year.

title: PAPER REPORTS F.B.I. ENTERED C.I.A. FIELD
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP)  The Federal Bureau of In vestigation has been gathering overseas intelligence since Oc tober, 1970, despite its lack of legal authority to do so, The Washington StarNews said in its editions today.

title: Stage: Nude With Violin
description: Watching  and thorough ly enjoying  Noel Coward's Nude With Violin in a zest ful, Off Broadway revival, is plain fun. This witty, clever bundle of froth  typical Coward  is a welcome relief amid hot weather and grim, theatrical competition. For this we can thank a small, enterprising company called Lolly's Theater Club, operat ing by contribution at 808 Lexington Avenue at 62d Street.

title: N.C.A.A. BASEBALL
SHOP TALK
description: Fireflies darting around in your living room? It's an un likely goal, but Mildred Shul man of Luminere Creations can provide a convincing substitute in one of her Fire fly Lights. They're cubes, orbs and rectangles of trans parent smoked Plexiglas with tiny lights flashing on and off inside.

title: Bridge: New England Team Leader In Regional Finals Here
description: A New England sextet held a slender advantage against teams from New JerseyWest chester and New York going into the final session of the Grand National zonal final at the New York Hilton here last night.

title: CHARLES D. HARDY SR.
description: SUMMIT, N. J., June 10Charles Douglas Hardy Sr., chairman of Old Deerfield Fab rics, Inc., died Friday in Over look Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 257 White Oak Ridge Road.

title: Red Smith
description: The thing to remember is that the horse that finished last had broken the Kentucky Derby record. If there were no colt named Secretariat, then Sham would have gone into the Belmont Stakes Saturday honored as the finest 3yearold in America, an eightlength winner of the Ken tucky Derby where he went the mile and a quarter faster than any winner in 98 years and an eightlength winner the Preakness. There is, however, a colt named Secretariat. In the Derby lie overtook Sham and beat him by two and half lengths. In the Preakness he held Sham off by two and a half lengths. This time he and Sham dueled for the lead, and he beat Sham by more than a 16th of a mile, There is no better way to measure the class of the gorgeous red colt that owns the Triple Crown. Turning into the homestretch at Belmont Park, Ron Turcotte glanced back under an arm to find his pur suit. He saw nothing, and while he peeked, his mount took off.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Sean Kenny, Designer, 43, Dies; Set for Oliver! Won 63 Tony
description: LONDON, June 11  Sean Kenny, the stage designer and theater architect, died today in St. Bartholomew's Hospital of stroke. His age was 43.

title: State Has Power to Spare
description: NEWARK, June 11Despite the fact that New Jersey was exporting electricity to New York today to meet a shortage there, New Jersey had power to spare, according to Eugene J. Murphy, manager of informa tion services for the Public Service Electric and Gas Com pany. We are still maintaining a 20 per cent reserve capacity for the needs of the state, Mr. Murphy said.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A collection of 80 19th century paintings by 50 American artists born before 1850 titled, The American Frontier: Images and Myths, will open on June 25 at the Whitney Museum and con tinue through Sept. 16. The show focuses on Western scenes, depicting Indians, ranchers, scouts, miners and pioneers.

title: Cemetery Strike Mediation Bill Signed
description: Governor Rockefeller signed a bill yesterday that authorizes him to invoke mediation and binding arbitration in the cemetery strike if there is a threat to the health and wel fare of residents.

title: BRANDT IN MISHAP ON ISRAELI CLIFF;Wind Nearly Pushes Copter Off Height at Masada
description: TEL AVIV, June 11 (UPI)A parked helicopter in which Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany was sitting was struck by a gust of wind to day and nearly pushed off the 1,200foot mountain for tress of Masada.

title: British Prototype Train Sets Diesel Speed Mark
description: LONDON, June 11An ex perimental diesel train today reached a speed of 141 miles an hour during tests in York shire, breaking a record that had stood for 34 years.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: American League Tuesday, June 12, 1973
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: JAMES FLEMING DIES; FT. WA YNE PUBLISHER
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 11 (AP)James R. Fleming, presi dent and publisher of The Fort Wayne JournalGazette, died today at Lutheran Hospital here. He was 91 years old.

title: Lukens Steel to Lift Prices on 2 Grades
description: The Lukens Steel Company announced yesterday that it would raise its base prices by $5 a ton for carbon plate steels and by $10 a ton for alloy plate steels, effective Aug. 6.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 12, 1973 SECURITY COUNCIL

title: 2 Penn Central Divisions Disrupted Briefly by Fire
description: Train service on the Penn Central's New Haven and Har lem divisions was disrupted for about 70 minutes last night when an equipment fire under a new train being tested forced officials to shut off power, railroad spokesman said.

title: Mayan Temple Lost for 60 Years Is Rediscovered
description: A lost Mayan Indian tem ple, a willo'thewisp that has beckoned explorers for 60 years, was rediscovered last month by an expedition headed by Hugh and Su zanne Johnston, documentary film makers, and Gillett G. Griffin, pre Columbian art historian at Princeton Uni versity.

title: Black Muslin Hangs Himself In Baton Rouge Jail Cell
description: BATON ROUGE, La., June 11 (UPI)Warren Hall, a 26yearold former Black Muslim whose testimony helped convict nine Muslims for inciting to riot, hanged himself in his jail cell yesterday.

title: WEIS CUSTOMERS GET FIRST CHECKS
description: The trustee liquidating Weis Securities, Inc., the New York Stock Exchange brokerage house put out of business late in May after it was charged with having fraudulently altered its books, announced yesterday that he had begun reimbursing some of the firm's customers.

title: Wiesel Invokes a Plea for Hope At City College Commencement
description: Elie Wiesel, the author and chronicler of the Nazi holo caust, which killed six million European Jews, called last night for an invocation of hope to meet the challenges of today's disjointed world.

title: U.S.C., TEXAS WIN IN N.C.A.A. SERIES
description: OMAHA, June 11 (UPI)Ed Putnam, a catcher, singled with the, bases loaded in the fifth inning tonight and gave the University of Southern Califor nia a 31 victory over Arizona State in the college world se ries.

title: LATENESS OF DATA IS SCORED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 The Securities and Exchange Commission warned all regula ted companies today that they risked penalties and possible criminal prosecution if they failed to file current and peri odic reports with the agency on time and in proper form.

title: Levitt Says Willowbrook Needs An Overhaul of Its Practices
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt reported yesterday that longterm improvement in living conditions for patients at the Willowbrook State School for mental defectives would require, both a long and shortrange, overhaul of administrative prac tices and continued monitoring of progress by the Depart ment of Mental Hygiene.

title: Spain's Rightward Swing
description: When a country has suffered dictatorial rule for decades, there is usually hope that major governmental change will restore a measure of freedom or at least lighten the repression. No such hopes arose when Gen eralissimo Franco last week officially turned over admin istration of the Spanish Government to his loyal friend and longtime deputy, Adm. Luis Carrero Blanco.

title: Senator Nelson Assails Drug Industry and Says Its Dual Labeling Exploits Both Young and Elderly
description: WASHINGTON, June 11Senator Gaylord Nelson, chair man of a subcommittee in vestigating drug prices, charged today that the phar maceutical industry was ex ploiting the American people.

title: Governor Gives Courts His Plan To Implement the Antidrug Law
description: Governor Rockefeller me yesterday with leaders of the criminaljustice system to cm phasize that he expects a ful summer court schedule to cu into the court backlog in ad Vance of the toughened drill penalties that take effect it September.

title: Nixon Cruises on Potomac
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) President Nixon took a two hour dinner cruise with Ronald L. Zeigler, the White House press secretary, on the Potomac River tonight aboard the Presi dential yacht Sequoia.

title: $500,000 Cocaine Sizure
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP) The authorities said today that Ron Stallard Linkenoger, 50 years old, of Cocoa Beach, Fla., had been arrested at Inter national Airport with almost four pounds of cocaine that could have sold retail for $500, 000. He was held on $25,000 bond.

title: Court Tells States They Cannot Permit Air Quality to Drop
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 States cannot permit the quali ty of their air to deteriorate from present levels, under decision that an equally divid ed Supreme Court affirmed today.

title: HOUSING IN NASSAU IS SUBJECT OF SUIT
description: The trial of a suit to bar Nassau County from carrying out any plans to develop Mitchel Field that do not in clude the construction of low income and middleincome housing opened in Federal Dis trict Court in Brooklyn yester day.

title: ALEXANDER WESMAN, PSYCHOLOGIST, DEAD
description: Dr. Alexander G. Wesman, a vice president and director of the test division of the Psycho logical Corporation, died in his sleep yesterday at his home, 84 Ralph Avenue, White Plains. He was 58 years old.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATES HASIDIM'S CHARGE
description: The United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn began an in vestigation yesterday into charges by the Lubavitcher movement that the civil rights of Hasidic Jews had been vio lated by the police in a clash that took place outside their synagogue at 770 Eastern Park way on June 2.

title: Stock Trading Is Sluggish As Prices Decline Slightly
description: The stock market settled back slightly yesterday in the slowest trading in more than eight months. There were rela tively small declines through out the list.

title: Federal Agent Seized for Firing Gun
description: A Secret Service agent, one of the team that guards the two children of the late Presi dent John F. Kennedy, was ar rested here yesterday after he allegedly fired his revolver dur ing an altercation with a taxi driver.

title: Books of The Times
description: Edmund Wilson's mind was so original that he probably wrote on more unpopular subjects than any other popular, literary critic in our time. He usually brought enough to his essays to interest his readers in books or authors they were not in terested in. It was a pleasure to watch him at work. He had a quality of monolithic authority that reminded me of Samuel Johnson. In attacking a piece of shoddiness or pretension, they both used the same blunt eloquence, what you might call com mon sense raised to a pitch of grandeur. With so many swoonreaders even among professional critics, we needed Ed mund Wilson. He was rather like a one man literary supreme court, often reversing absurd decisions and reaffirming a sense of proportion that current fashion had for gotten.

title: 15,000 Weight Watchers Cheer Svelte Founder and Other Stars
description: Fifteen thousand Weight Watchers and their friends or relatives celebrated the 10th anniversary of their organiza tion last night at Madison square Garden with a standing ovation for a former Great Neck, L. I., housewife who turned big people into big busi ness.

title: AMEX PRICES UP IN SLOW TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday in the slowest trading in almost nine, months. The Amex index closedj up 0.01 at 22.58. Only 1,920, 000 shares changed hands, a! low since 1,786,000 on Sept. 18, 1972.

title: BOND PRICES DROP AS FED LIFTS RAT
description: The bond market sagged yes terday as it contemplated the sharp point increase in the Federal Reserve's discount rate and as it continued to nervous ly await official action to tight en economic con trols. Wall Street appeared split as to whether Phase 4, when announced, would prove ef fective against inflation, or whether it would be more cos metic than real. Credit Markets

title: Big Sky Conference Gives Idaho OneYear Probation
description: BOZEMAN, Mont., June 11 (AP)  Members of the Presi dent's Council of the Big Sky place the University of Idaho one oneyear probation and de layed consideration of the ap plication of Portland State Uni versity to join the conference.

title: State's First HealthMaintenance Unit Is Scheduled to Open in Trenton July 1
description: TRENTON, June 11  After three years of plans, hopes, haggling and the removal of prodigious roadblocks, New Jer sey's first healthmaintenance organization is now due to open here July 1.

title: Watergate Brings New Burglary Reports
description: Reports of mysterious bur glaries of radical groups, critics of the Administration and movement lawyers are begin ing to come to light after Watergaterelated revelations.

title: Gradual Airport
description: A sixvolume master plan for the development Stewart Airport has been released by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for the widest possible dis cussion by the public. It deserves that attention. Whatever the pressures on the metropolitan area's present facilities, a fourth airport is not to be undertaken lightly.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Josephine Baker, fresh from her triumphs at Carne gie Hall and the Victoria Theater in Harlem, slipped quietly into Pauline Trigere's Seventh Avenue salon yes terday in a white pants suit and stole the show. It was a good show too, one of Miss Trigere's best.

title: U.S. Ready to Sign Trademark Treaty For Simpler Filing
description: WASHINGTON, June 11A trademark treaty, providing for the filing of a single interna tional application instead of many, will be signed in Vienna tomorrow. It will be the final day of a diplomatic conference attended by representatives of the United States and other countries.

title: GRAY IS REPORTED WILLING TO WAIVE TRIAL IMMUNITY
description: WASHINGTON, June 11L. Patrick Gray 3d, the former acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has agreed to testify without im munity in any Watergate crim inal trials about his dealings with President Nixon and other top Administration officials after the June 17, 1972, epi sode, sources close to the case said today.

title: Federal Home Appoints
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation has ap pointed William J. Popejoy president and chief executive officer. He formerly was vice presidentsales and replaces Thomas Bomar, who was re cently appointed chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: Senator Turner's Trial Opens in Drug FrameUp
description: TRENTON, June 11  State Senator James M. Turner, Gloucester County Republican, went on trial today on charges of conspiring to frame a fellow state legislator after his co defendant, Charles Lentine of Williamstown, abruptly pleaded guilty.

title: New Murder Trial In Yablonski Case On in Pennsylvania
description: ERIE, Pa., June 11Testi mony in the Albert E. Pass murder trial began here today preceded by a statement by special prosecutor, Richard A. Sprague, suggesting that per haps Mr. Pass was not the originator of the plot to slay Joseph A. Yablonski.

title: Eternal Triangle?
description: After Henry Kissinger and Le Duc Tho broke off their second effort in Paris to restore the fractured Vietnam peace last week, an American official said that difficul ties had arisen due to a triangular argument among the Governments of the United States, North Vietnam and South Vietnam.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Route 280 Freeway in North Jersey will opened to traffic on June 22, eight days ahead of the latest schedule, according to Governor Cahill. The 12mile stretch of highway will run from East Orange in Essex County to ParsippanyTroy Hills in Morrris County. Gov ernor Cahill ordered a speedup in work on the highway in midApril after there were complaints about delays and meeting the previous timetable, which called for completion by Aug. 31.

title: NEW HANOI TALKS ON AID EXPECTED
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The United States plans to re sume negotiations with North Vietnam on extending economic aid to Hanoi once agreement is reached in Paris on ways to strengthen the Vietnam cease fire accord, a highranking Ad ministration official said today.

title: judge Says Phillips Illegally Heads Poverty Agency
description: WASHINGTON, June 11A Federal judge ruled today that Howard J. Phillips was serving illegally as acting director o the Office of Economic Oppor tunity and enjoined him iron taking further action as hem of the agency.

title: MRS. WILLIAM D. MAUS
description: Mrs. Irene Blanchard Maus, widow of William Donald Maus, former board chairman of Marsh & McLennan, Inc., in surance brokers, died Sunday at the De Witt Nursing Home, 211 East 79th Street. Her age was 79, and she lived at 1165 Fifth Avenue.

title: Major League Box Scores
Sex Stereotyping Persists in Schools
description: Despite nearly five years of challenges, American schools are still moving slowly to eli minate sex steretotyping in the classroom.

title: Soybean Futures Rebound
description: Soybean speculators took the long side of the market yester day, pushing up the July de livery by almost $1.40 a bushel. The contract, in which there are no daily limits because of its nearness, closed at $11.55 a bushel, up from $10.17 on Friday and one of the biggest recent jumps.

title: Laird, With the 6th Fleet, Bids U.S. Keep Up Strength
description: ABOARD U.S.S. John F. Ken nedy, in the Bay of Gaeta, June 11 President Nixon's new counselor for domestic affairs, Melvin R. Laird, called today for sustained United States mil itary strength as the best guar antee of peace

title: JOSEPH PERRY
description: Joseph Perry, head baker of The New York Times restaurant at his retirement in 1964, died Saturday in Parsons Hospital, Flushing, Queens. He was 74 years old and lived at 4734 45th Street, Flushing. Surviving is his widow, the former Anna Yogos.

title: Shippers on Coast And Longshoremen Reach 2Year Pact
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 (AP) Longshore union and shipping negotiators have agreed on a new contract. Pend ing ratification, the agreement removed the threat of a strike on West Coast docks this year.

title: Chinese Journalists Meet San Francisco Workmen
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11A delegation of 22 Chinese journalists today fulfilled its re peated desire to talk with American working men on their jobs and in their homes.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Chalk up one more spank ingnew, cleverly equipped hairdressing salon for New York. In enormous orange let ters, on the secondfloor win dows of 52 East 58th Street, Paul Mitchell is announcing his Superhair.

title: GRAY IS REPORTED WILLING TO WAIVE TRIAL IMMUNITY; ExF.B.I. Official Is Said to Be Ready to Testify on Watergate Dealings; INQUIRY RESUMES TODAY; Dean's Lawyers Ask Judge to Throw Out Subpoena or Grant Him Immunity
description: WASHINGTON, June 11L. Patrick Gray 3d, the former acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has agreed to testify without im munity in any Watergate crim inal trials about his dealings with President Nixon and other top Administration officials after the June 17, 1972, epi sode, sources close to the case said today.

title: U.S. DETAILS PLAN ON TAX DEFERRAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The Treasury Department, re sponding to widespread criti cism from industry, spelled out today the relatively limited cir cumstances in which it wants Congress to end deferral of cor porate taxes for American com panies that operate overseas.

title: City TV Aide, Resigning, Foresees Cable Growth
description: Effective last Friday, Herbed S. Dordick resigned as New York City's first coordinator to the Office of Telecommunica. tions. Appointed by the Board of Estimate in March, 1972, Mr Dordick was responsible for making recommendations to the board and acting as its repre sentative in formulating and carrying out city policy with respect to cable television and

title: Chess: Tal's Hopes, Once So High, Are Crushed by Huebner
Spectacular Defense Helps Giants Beat Mets, 21
description: The New York Mets finally scored a run last night but that was as far as the revival went because the San Francisco Giants scored two for a 21 vic tory that sent the Mets to their 12th defeat in 16 starts.

title: Santiago Beats Jiminez In Fillin Bout at Forum
description: Eduardo Santiago of San turce, Puerto Rico scored a unanimous 10round decision over Natalio Jiminez of the Dominican Republic before a crowd of 1,666 at the Felt Forum last night.

title: Former Aide Predicts Nixon Will Resign or Be Impeached
description: REGINA, Sask., June 11 (Ca n Press)A former aide o President Nixon said yester day that the President was on the road either to resignation or impeachment over the Wat ergate issue.

title: Ptarmigan Color Cycle Studied
description: TROMSO, Norway  Nor wegian scientists are raising and studying ptarmigans to try to find out why humans get gray hair. The color of the ptarmigan, an aggressive Arctic grouse, changes from white to brown as winter turns to spring and then re verts to white in the fall.

title: 27 FOOD PLACES CITED ON CODE VIOLATIONS
Equitable Gas Co. Expects Its 1973 Earning to Rise
description: The Equitable Gas Company expects its 1973 profit to be in the range of $4.25 to $4.35 a share, R. E. McCarthy, treasurer, said at the company's annual meeting yesterday in Pittsburgh. This would compare with $4.19 a share in 1972.

title: ATHENS CONSIDERS CIVILIAN CABINET
description: ATHENS, June 11Qualified sources reported today that Greece's Provisional President, George Papadopoulos, planned to remove the military from the the Government and set up civilian Cabinet.

title: MOSLEMS IN LEBANON WOULD OUST PREMIER
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 11Moslem members of Parliament have decided to boycott a ses sion tomorrow to force Leb anon's Premier, Dr. Amin Hafez, to resign.

title: STATE LABOR AIDE DECRIES OUTLOOK
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 11 (AP)The president of the state A.F.L.C.I.O. painted a nottoo rosy picture today of New Jer sey's industrial future as he addressed 1,400 delegates at the organization's annual conven tion here.

title: Nixon Inflation Move Called Imminent
description: WASHINGTON, June 11In a new attempt to check infla tion and dispel public and Congressional anxiety about rising prices, President Nixon was reported today to be pre paring a package of antiinfla tion measures to be announced in a television speech later this week.

title: NEW ARK COUPLE HELD IN DEATH OF BOY, 2
description: NEWARK, June 11 (UPI)A 23yearold Newark woman and her male friend are being held without bail pending a hearing Friday on charges of savagely beating her 2yearold son to death. Detective Capt. Rocco Paradiso said the two, Mrs. Lucille Schweer and An thony Volpe, 26 years old, both of North Fifth Street were or dered held without bail today for the hearing before Munici pal Court Judge Milton A. Buck.

title: Thomas J. P. Craven Sr., 67, ExU.P.I. News Cameraman
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) Thomas J. P. Craven Sr., a former White House news cam eraman for United Press Inter national, died today at the Na tional Institutes of Health after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States plans to resume nego tiations with North Vietnam on extending economic aid to Hanoi once agreement is reached in Paris on ways to strengthen the Vietnam ceasefire accord, a highranking Administration official said. [Page 1, Col. 4.]

title: IsraeliWest German Watershed
description: JERUSALEM, June 11The fourday state visit of West Germany's Chancellor, Willy Brandt, which ended this after noon, appears to have been an emotional and political water shed in IsraeliGerman relations.

title: City Summer Festival Is Opened by Lindsay
description: Mayor Lindsay proclaimed the opening of the city's Summer Festival yesterday at a party in Shubert Alley, off Broadway between 44th and 45th Streets.

title: RCA Plans to Produce Penney's Private Brand
description: The RCA Corporation and the J. Penney Company, Inc., announced yesterday a prelimi nary agreement under which RCA would manufacture stereo equipment, television sets and possibly other electronic prod ucts that the retail chain would sell under the J. C. Penney label.

title: Brown &
description: In a proposal involving more than $200million, the British owned Brown & Williamson To bacco Corporation yesterday an nounced an offer to pay $23 a share for all the common stock of Gimbel Brothers, Inc.

title: NIXON ESTATE COSTS NOW PUT AT $185,000
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The, General Services Administration confirmed reports today that, $76,000 was spent on landscap ing at President Nixon's house in San Clemente, Calif. The Gov ernment said the improvements were needed for security.

title: Rogers Terms U.S. Arms Sales to Persian Gulf Stabilizing
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 11 Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that large recent sales of American arms to Iran and other Persian Gulf countries would be a stabiliz ing influence for peace in this rich oilproducing area.

title: MADRID REPLACES FOREIGN MINISTER
description: MADRID, June 11Foreign Minister Gregorio Lopez Bravo, who pursued close relations with the United States as well as a more open policy toward the Communist world, was dropped from the Cabinet to day in what appeared to be political shift to the right.

title: WEINSTEIN TAKES LEAD IN ELECTION
description: Federal Judge Jack B. Wein stein overtook Jacob D. Fuchs berg last night to lead in the Democratic nomination for chief judge of the state.

title: Reid Gets Promotion
description: GEORGETOWN, Ky., June 11 (UPI)James B. Reid Jr., 25 years old, was promoted today from assistant to head basket ball coach at Georgetown Col lege. He succeeds Bob Davis, who resigned to become head coach at Auburn University.

title: Right City, Wrong Field For Landing of a Jet
description: MIAMI, June 11 (AP)The pilot and copilot of a United Air Lines jet that landed at a small field used by the Coast Guard instead of at Miami International Airport, eight miles away, were grounded today. They face possible charges, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: Gabriel Echavarria Obregon Marries Pilar Crespi in Italy
description: ROME, June 11Miss Pilar Crespi and Gabriel Echavar ria Obregon were married today in the Crespi castle of Mugnana, near Greve Chianti in Tuscany.

title: A JERSEY SENATOR TRIED IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON, June 11State Senator James M. Turner, a Gloucester County Republican, went on trial today on charges of conspiring to frame a fellow state legislator after his co defendant, Charles Lentine of Williamstown, abruptly pleaded guilty.

title: Publisher Seeks to Quash Subpoena of Hughes Data
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 11 (UPI)The publisher of The Las Vegas Sun, H. M. Green spun, began a legal battle today to prevent the Internal Revenue Service from seizing documents he has concerning the financial dealings of Howard R. Hughes, the industrialist.

title: City Officials Confer On Balancing Budget
description: Mayor Lindsay, Controller Abraham D. Beame and the City Council majority leader, Thomas J. Cuite, met at Gracie Mansion yesterday in efforts to work out agree ments on a balanced budget.

title: Agreement Is Reached on OTB for Nassau, Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., June 11 The first agreement for a re gional offtrack betting system for all of Long Island was reached here late today in joint meeting of the Nassau and Suffolk County Executives.

title: Hockey Transactions
Badillo Uiges Council to Override Lindsay RentBill Veto and Reinstate Original Controls
description: Representative Herman Ba reiterating his theme that his opponent in the Democratic mayoral runoff, Controller Abraham D. Beame, is allied with landlords, yesterday urged the City Council to override the Mayor's veto of the maxi mumbaserent law.

title: Roundup: Gibson Passes Milestone as Cards Win
description: Bob Gibson, one of major league baseball's senior citi zen's (he's 37 years old), pitched a fourhitter and moved into second place on the career strikeout list as the St. Louis Cardinals scored 124 victory over the Cin cinnati Reds in Riverfront Stadium.

title: $30,000 Watergate Funds Linked to Philippine Donor
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The Finance Committee to Re elect the President received $30,000 from an unnamed Philippine national, used the money in an urgent White House project and then, be lieving the money was donated illegally, returned it, according to a report made public today by the General Accounting Office.

title: Higher Equipment Spending For Newspapers Reported
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 11 (AP)  The president of the HarrisIntertype Corporation told the American Newspaper Publishers Association Research Institute Monday that the United States newspaper indus try was currently investing $250million a year on new equipment. He said this was an increase of 43 per cent from the $175million spent in 1970.

title: Utility Reports Income Rise
description: Prospects for the balance of 1973 are favorable for the Citizens Utitilities Company, Richard L. Rosenthal, chairman, said at the company's annual meeting yesterday at Stamforo Conn. He reported net income of just under $11million, or $2.20 a share for the 12 months ended March 31. This compared with $9.1million, or $1.83 a share, in the like 1972 period.

title: LLOYDS BANK SETS ACQUISITION PRICE
description: Lloyds Bank, Ltd., of Lon don, announced yesterday that it had agreed to pay $115mil lion in cash for the First West ern Bank and Trust Company of Los Angeles, which is 99.5 per centowned by World Air vays, Inc.

title: 39 ExP.O.W.'s Divorced Or in the Divorce Process
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI)Thirtynine of the 420 married American prisoners of war returned from Vietnam either have gotten or are get ting divorces, the Pentagon's chief medical officer reports.

title: London Exchange Is Now in Marble Walls
description: LONDON, June 11With scant ceremony and a minimum of fuss, the 3,600 members of the London Stock Exchange moved today into their new marblewalled trading floor.

title: Shostakovich Due To Get Doctorate At Northwestern
description: Dmitri Shostakovich sailed into New York yesterday on his way to Evanston, Ill., where Northwestern Univer sity will award him an hon orary doctorate of fine arts on Saturday.

title: Communists Press Attack West of Cambodia Capital
description: BEK CHAN, Cambodia, June 11Communist mortar and in fantry units maintained steady pressure against Government troops along a wide front west of Phnom Penh today, and for a second day, fired rockets into the Phnom Penh airport.

title: FRANCES STARR DIES; ACTED FOR BELASCO
description: Frances Starr, an actress who scored her first Broadway tri umph as Juanita in Rose of the Rancho, a David Belasco production that ran from 1906 to 1908, died yesterday at her home, 10 Mitchell Place. She was 92 years old and the widow's of Emil C. Wetten, a Chicago lawyer.

title: What's Right
description: Even President Nixon's known inclination toward hyperbole must have seemed somewhat extraordinary when he proclaimed at Florida Technological University last week: In the whole history of the world, in all the nations of the world, there has never been a time would rather be a graduate than in the year 1973 the United States of America.

title: Four Youths in the South Bronx Slay One TeenAger and Wound 2 Others
description: Four youths carrying pistols and ti rifle lined three teen agers against a wall in the South Bronx early yesterday morning and opened fire, killing one and seriously wounding the two others. The four young gunmen then fled.

title: Subpoenas Sought on Coast In Ellsberg Case Breakin
description: LOS ANGELES, June 11 (AP) The District Attorney's office was drafting subpoenas today that it will try to serve on two former White House aides named as directors of the plumbers squad that has been implicated in the burglary of the office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist.

title: William N. Wallace
description: It takes just one, not two, to sue. Roman Gabriel, I he pro football quarterback, was alone when he threw a bizarre law suit at his employers, the Los Angeles Rams, charging breach of contract and seeking $5,000 in alleged unpaid compensation. Because $5,000 is mere beerand wine money among the elitists of professional sports, few paid heed. But Roman added petulantly that Carroll Rosen bloom, the owner, and Don Klosterman, the general manager, would not take his phone calls when he in quired about the trade he had demanded, one that would end the 11year associa tion between the Rams and the giant passer with the heavy shock of long black hair. It was that gratuitous comment and not the law suit that changed Gabriel from a Ram to an Eagle, Philadelphia species, last Friday. One does not trifle with Rosenbloom, the giant among owners in the National Football League.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION SLIPS 1.1% IN WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended June 9 slipped by 1.1 per cent to 2,915,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Insti tute reported yesterday. This compared with the 2,948,000 tons poured in the holiday shortened June 2 week. The latest was the lowest produc tion level since the Feb. 24 week when output amounted to 2,908,000 tons and an index level of 119.2.

title: $30,000 Watergate Funds Linked to Philippine Donor
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The Finance Committee to Re elect the President received $30,000 from an unnamed Philippine national, used the money in an urgent White House project and then, be belling the money was donated illegally, returned it, according to a report made public today by the General Accounting Office.

title: 63% CUT IN CAR USE SUGGESTED BY U.S. FOR NORTH JERSEY
description: TRENTON, June 11The Fed eral Government has drafted an airpollutioncontrol plan for New Jersey that recommends a cut of 63 per cent hi vehicular travel in the state's northern metropolitan regions to cope with a smog crisis second only to that in Los Angeles.

title: Disputes Add to Bangladesh Food Crisis
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, June 10 Bangladesh, torn by econom ic crisis, is facing a food short age complicated by sharp con flict among claims and growing uncertainty about the scope of the scarcities.

title: Inge's Funeral Today
description: HOLLYWOOD, June 11 (UPI) William Inge will be buried in Independence, Kan., his boy hood home where he drew in spiration for Picnic and other widely acclaimed plays. Mr. Inge, who had been depressed in recent years over the recep tion of his later novels and plays, committed suicide Sun day by inhaling exhaust fumes from his car. He was 60 years old.

title: Disputed Entry on Jew Upheld By Editor of Oxford Dictionary
description: LONDON, June 11 (AP)The editor of the Oxford English Dictionary is standing his ground against a court suit over its secondary definition of Jew as a name of opprobri urn or reprobation; specifically applied to a grasping or extor tionate money lender or usurer, or a trader who drives hard bargains or deals craftily.

title: HOUSE PANEL DENIES COAST BUGGING LINK
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Spokesmen for Representative Sam Steiger of Arizona and for the House Select Committee on Crime said today that the bug ging of a hotel room in San Diego two years ago was not part of a committee investiga tion, but was undertaken solely for Mr. Steiger, a member of the committee.

title: 4th Goodrich Local Ratifies Pact, Making It Effective
description: MIAMI, Okla., June 11 (UPI)  Local 318 of the United Rubber Workers of. America became the fourth of seven locals at B. F. Goodrich plants to ratify a threeyear contract agreement yesterday, thereby making the contract effective nationwide.

title: 6 Cases on Rates Settled by El Paso; Refunds Scheduled
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (Reuters)The E1 Paso Natural Gas Company said today it had reached a settlement on six rate cases concerning its Southern division, which provides for refunds of $47.8mil lion to its customers plus in terest.

title: Equity Financing
description: A public offering of 350,000 common shares of the Nevada Power Company at $31 a share was made yesterday by underwriters managed by White, Weld & Co. The company's stock closed at 32, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Stennis Undergoes Surgery
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) Senator John C. Stennis, who was wounded in a holdup near his home last Jan. 30, under went additional surgery today to remove a bullet and to re pair abdominal wounds. The 71yearold Mississippi Demo crat tolerated the surgery sat isfactorily, a spokesman for Walter Reed Army Medical Cen ter said.

title: U.S. STEEL AND UNION NAMED IN A BIAS SUIT
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (UPI)  The United States Steel Corporation and they United Steelworkers of Ameri ca were named as defendants today in a Federal court suit charging the company with bias against blacks at its Fairless Hills, Pa., plant.

title: DEMOCRATS PAY MOST OF '72 DEBT
description: WASHINGTON, June 11In the last year, the Democratic party, despite losing a Presi dential election, has managed to pay off more than half of its longterm indebtedness with, some help from the Watergate scandal, according to reports filed with the General Account ing Office and made public today.

title: AGNEW CRITICIZES SENATE HEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, June 11Vice President Agnew declared today that the televised Senate Watergate hearings can hardly hope to find the truth and can hardly fail to muddy the waters of justice beyond redemption.

title: States Told to Weigh The LongRange Impact
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI)  The Environmental Protection Agency ordered states today to consider the longrange air pollution im pact of proposed shopping centers, sports stadiums and other trafficgenerating facil ities.

title: EBAN ASKS RESTRAINT IN REPORTS ON TALKS
description: JERUSALEM, June 11 (AP) Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel appealed to the world press today to permit diplomats to conduct negotiations free from the pressures and inhibi tions of publicity.

title: Cemetery Strike Mediation Bill Signed
description: Governor Rockefeller signed a bill yesterday that authorizes him to invoke mediation and binding arbitration in the cemetery strike if there is a threat to the health and wel fare of residents.

title: Service Station Dealers Ask Congress To Break Up Major Oil Companies
description: WASHINGTON, June 11A representative of service sta tion dealers suggested today that Congress break up the big, integarted oil companies to sep arate the crudeoil production business from the marketing of petroleum products.

title: NEW ZEALAND GAINS IN FIRST TEST MATCH
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 11 (Reuters)Bev Cong don, its skipper, gave New Zea land the chance for one of the great victories in cricket history today with 176 runs against England in the First Test.

title: Toronto Gets W.H.A. Name
description: TORONTO, June 11 (UPI)The World Hockey Association club here became the Toronto Toros today. Last season they were the Ottawa Nationals and the Ontario Nationals.

title: Theater: Dark Romance
description: STRATFORD, Conn., June 11 Measure for Measure, which opened tonight at the American Shakespeare Thea ter, is the darkest and strang est of Shakespeare's ro mances. It is often called a problem play, which is fair but ineffectual descrip tion.

title: A Soviet Liner Calls. Here For First Time in 25 Years
description: A Soviet passenger ship sailed into New York har bor yesterday for the first time in 25 years, sounded three blasts from her horn and signaled an end to one vestige of the cold war.

title: Rocket Tests Skylab Gear
description: WHITE SANDS MISSILE RANGE, N.M. June 11 (AP)A sounding rocket was launched today that was expected to help scientists determine the accuracy of the Skylab space station's telescope. Cameras on board photographed a small area of the sun while the Sky lab astronauts zoomed in on the same area with their tele scope. The pictures will be com pared at the end of the Skylab mission.

title: U V Industries to Expand
description: U V Industries, Inc., an nounced yesterday, that effec tive July 1, marketing of all grades of antimonal lead, other lead alloys and soft lead would be handled by its subsidiary, U. S. S. Lead Refinery, Inc., at East Chicago, Ind. The com pany said increased demand for these products had resulted in an. expansion of production and marketing facilities.

title: Mexican Rates to Climb
description: MEXICO CITY, June 11 (Reu ters)  Mexico will raise bank interest rates this week in order to draw capital into the coun try, the head of the central bank, Ernesto Fernandez Hur tado, said today. Currently, in terest rates in other countries are about a percentage point hihger than those in Mexico, where mortgage bonds, for ex ample, yield only 7.20 per cent, he added.

title: Quiz Kids Can't Answer Kekich's Question
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 11 While three Yankee Quiz Kids took a side trip to Los Angeles to try and success fully field some questions on Sports Challenge, Mike Kekich arrived here with the rest of the team today, wait ing for the answer to his future.

title: Fire Kills Six in Family
description: LINCOLNWOOD, Ill., June 11 (AP)A couple and their four children died of smoke inhalation here Friday in a fire that ignited in the recreation room of their twostory brick home. The victims were Nor man Pinsill, 37 years old, his wife, Cheryl, 33, and their children, Laurie 4, Denise, 2, and twin boys, Dale and Jeremy, aged 1.

title: 4 BOROUGH CHIEFS AGAIN BACK BEANIE
description: Four of the five Borough Presidents yesterday reaffirmed their support of City Controller Abraham D. Beanie in the June 26 primary runoff for the Democratic Mayoral nomina tion.

title: Ships Delayed at Panama
description: PANAMA, June 11 (AP)Fortyfour vessels were re ported backlogged in the Pana ma Canal today as a labor dis pute involving pilots entered its third week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is with some distress that one reads of the possible sale by our Gov ernment of two dozen or more Phan tom jets to Saudi Arabia and of other types of modern aircraft to Kuwait.

title: BRITAIN SPEAKS OUT FOR JARRING'S ROLE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 11  Britain told the Security Council today that the mission of Gunnar V. Jarring, the Secretary General's special representative for the Middle East, should be not merely re tained but be reenergized.

title: High Court Declines To. Review a Ruling Favoring Shell Oil
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (Reu ters)The Supreme Court de clined today to review judg ments of lower Federal courts in favor of the Shell Oil Com pany in a case in which four Shell retailers in California ac cused the company of antitrust violations.

title: Bridge:Fighting New England Team Captures the Grand National
description: A fighting team from New England captured the Grand National northeastern zonal title at the New York Hilton during the weekend, and will enter the quarterfinal stage of the national play offs in Washington next month. The winners, who recovered from a disastrous start in one of their matches, are Chet Davis, Mark Feld man, Norman Humer, Steve Labins, Bernard Miller and Larry Weiss.

title: NEW HANOI TALKS ON AID EXPECTED
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The United States plans to re sume negotiations with North Vietnam on extending economic aid to Hanoi once agreement is, reached in Paris on ways to strengthen the Vietnam cease fire accord, a highranking Ad ministration official said today.

title: 2 Young Boys From Kentucky Have Whirlwind 3 Days Here
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y. June 11  Howard Campbell, a 7yearold Kentucky farm boy, tackled his first black olive here today after a threeday round of adventures that in cluded his first subway ride, his first elevator ride and his first bath in a tub brim full of water.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: ANTITRUST LAW

title: Barker and Raskind Victors In State Tennis at Bayside
description: Secondseeded Bob Barker of Port Washington, L. I., fought back to defeat Richard Finn of White Plains, 4.6, 6.1, 62, in the third round of the New York State men's tennis cham pionship yesterday, at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.

title: TRAFFIC PLAN SET FOR All MIDTOWN
description: A program to end traffic congestion in midtown Man hattan by July 1 was unveiled by Mayor Lindsay yesterday Its ultimate effect, the May said, will be to drive privat autos out of the central busi tress district unless there are extremely good reasons for their being there.

title: RECORD 95 HEAT FORCES 8% CUT IN CITY'S POWER
description: Recordsetting temperatures yesterday led to an 8 per cent voltage cutback for 10 million people in the New York metro politan area, to an extensive loss of water pressure In parts of the city and to the buckling of two major roadways.

title: Film to Detail Plot to Kill Kennedy
description: LOS ANGELES, June 11Filming is under way here on a movie called Executive Action, which deals with a conspiracy to assassinate President Kennedy.

title: Avery Brundage Will Wed Princess
description: CHICAGO, June 11 (AP)Avery Brundage, former pres ident of the International Olympic Committee, will marry Mariann Princess Reuss, a German princess who served as a hostess at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich.

title: Open Hydrants on 95 Day Cut Pressure Drastically
description: The city sweltered through the hottest June 11 on record yesterday, with a maximum reading of 95 degrees com pounded by a drastic loss of water pressure.

title: A HOUSE BILL URGES GRAND JURY REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, June 11Charging that Federal grand juries have become a rubber stamp for Government prose cutors, Representative Joshua Eilberg, Democrat of Pennsyl vania, announced today the in troduction of a bill into the House to reform the Federal grand jury system.

title: U.S. DOLLAR STEADY IN LONDON DEALINGS
description: LONDON, June 11 (AP)The United States dollar held steady today in London foreignex change trading. This was the only major European market to be open during the Pentecost holiday.

title: RECORD 95 HEAT FORCES 8% CUT IN CITY'S POWER
description: Recordsetting temperatures yesterday led to an 8 per cent voltage cutback for 10 million people in the New York metro politan area, to an extensive loss of water pressure in parts of the city and to the buckling of two major roadways.

title: Bar Report Urges U.S. Courts to Reform Sentencing
description: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York asked the Federal courts here yester day to enhance the ration ality of their sentencing pro cedures by adopting six basic reforms.

title: Con Ed Has Bright View in Dimout
description: Despite the cutbacks yesterday, Con Edison officials maintainedas they have been maintaining for monthsthat the supply of electricity was much better this year than in the last several years.

title: EXGOV. ROY TURNER, OKLAHOMA OILMAN
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, June 11 Former Gov. Roy J. Turner died today of cancer at the age of 78. He had served as Gov ernor from 1947 to 1951.

title: Cox's Team of New Frontiersmen
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The fact has been little re marked upon, but it is clear nonetheless: President Nixon has put the responsibility for the Watergate prosecution with all its peril for his own future into the hands of a band of New Frontiersmenmen whose political activities have been closely intertwined with the Kennedy family that Mr. Nixon has fought so long. The spe cial prosecutor, Ar chibald Cox, is a Harvard professor who came to Wash ington in 1961 and served for four years as Solicitor Gen eral. His Kennedy ties are hard ly a secret; in fact, both Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy attended his swearing in as prosecutor last month.

title: State's Peach Crop Expected to Reach 90 Million Pounds
description: TRENTON, June 11 (UPI) The State Agriculture Depart ment said today that the New Jersey peach crop, which had one of its worst seasons ever in 1972, would rebound this year.

title: 65,000 Illegal Aliens Reported in City Schools
description: A member of the City Coun cil said yesterday that 65,000 illegal aliens were attending the city's public schools, and he demanded that school officials require parents of new pupils to furnish proof of legal resi dency.

title: A 5TH MAN SEIZED IN MAIL ROBBERY
description: Postal inspectors of the met ropolitan region and Manhattan homicide detectives announced the arrest yesterday of the fifth member of a gang accused in bungled mailtruck robbery on April 5 in which an armed postal guard was killed on crowded downtown street.

title: Chapter Xi Petition Filed By Avtek in Providence
description: A petition in bankruptcy under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act was filed yes terday in the United States Federal Court in Providence by the Avtek Corporation. The company listed assets of $1,271,871 and liabilities of $5,537,182. A petition for ap pointment of a receiver was also filed and a hearing was scheduled for tomorrow at 11 A.M.

title: Rabies Cases Said to Drop
description: ATLANTA, June 11 (AP)Four hundred ninetyfour cases oaf rabies in animals, most of them squnks and foxes, were reported in the United States in January and February, the United States Center for Dis ease Control said. This was 104 fewer cases than the number reported for the same period in 1972.

title: Texaco Ordered to Give Station Its Full Gas Quota
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., June 11 An acting Superior Court judge issued an order today di recting Texaco, Inc., to supply a gasoline station on the Gar, den Stale Parkway with its full quota of gasoline this month, despite the reported fuel short age.

title: CONGDON'S 176 RUNS SPARK NEW ZEALAND
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 11 (Reuters)Bev Cong don, its skipper, gave New Zea land the chance for one of the great victories in cricket history today with 176 runs against England in the First Test.

title: Libyan Chief, Citing U.S Aid to Israel, Seizes Oil Concern
