title: Environmentalists Scored As Affluent and Selfish
description: DENVER, June 12 (UPI)A spokesman for the timber in dustry says that supporters of the environment are selfish and that they lower the Amer ican standard of living.

title: 83 Women in Spotlight At Princeton Graduation
description: PRINCETON, June 12 Things have changed at Princeton, Marsha Levy of White Plains said today.

title: Gas Explosion Kills Woman
description: DENVER, June 12 (UPI)A bulldozer landscaping a new housing development crushed gas pipe that began leaking and caused an explosion yesterday, killing a 28yearold housewife, Mary Ann McGinnis.

title: 2 L.I.R.R. Crewmen Dropped From jobs After Fatal Crash
description: The Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority disclosed yes terday that the engineer and conductor of a Long Island Rail Road train that crashed at Ronkonkoma, L. I., on March 15 had been dismissed from their jobs.

title: Pupil Busing Is Ordered by Court Between Detroit and Its Suburbs
description: DETROIT, June 12A Fed eral appeals court ruled today that black children from De troit must ride buses out to the suburbs and that white sub urban children must ride them in to Detroit to achieve racial balance in the schools.

title: Harlem Fete Hails Countee Cullen
description: The Countee Cullen. Li brary in Harlem yesterday began a yearlong arts festi val of poetry readings, art exhibits, andmusic honoring the 70th birthday of the black poet and author for whom the library is named.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: East Europeans Min Voice Contest

title: Pentagon Approves FlyOff to Choose Fighter f or Navy
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., June 12A $250million flyoff among the three leading planes in America's future aerospace arsenal will be held some time before mid1976 to determine which one the Navy will pur chase.

title: Recent Soviet Films To Be Shown Free At Little Carnegie
description: Seven recent Soviet films, six of them never shown in this country, will be screened free here for a week starting Friday.

title: TV:Wurder in America
description: Murder in America, an hourlong documentary pre sented Tuesday on the Na tional Broadcasting Company network, had Fred Freed as both executive producer and writer. Not surprisingly, given Mr. Freed's impressive record in news and public af fairs programing, the N.B.C. Reports special was extreme ly effective in both concep tion and realization.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Fishing Trip
description: WRIGHTSVILLE BEACH, N. C.Nightfall and a fresh ening breeze brought welcome respite from the blazing sun as we anchored some 60 miles northeast of Wrights ville Beach and prepared to bottom fish.

title: Detective Is Accused of Perjury by Bronx Jury
description: A Bronx grand jury has in dicted Detective Raymond Mc Dowell, a 15year member of the Police Department, on charge of perjury in its investi gation of a confidence woman's story of having paid off detec tives who raided her motel room to escape arrest.

title: Judge Here Orders Trial On U.S. Role in Cambodia
description: A federal judge ordered yes terday that a suit by Repre sentative Elizabeth Holtzman to halt American combat op erations in Cambodia go to trial here on June 29.

title: STOCKTON DOWNS PASARELL, 98, 62
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 13 (AP)  Four United States playersTom Gorman, Erick Van Dillen, Dick Stockton and Jimmy Connors  played impressively today and gained the quarterfinals of the $75,000 Nottingham grasscourt tennis tournament.

title: Medgar Evers Is Honored at Mississippi Festival
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 13At the state fairgrounds here, where 10 years ago hundreds of blacks were herded into makeshift jail because they had marched for the right to vote, a biracial crowd of 9,000 people gathered last night to honor Medgar W. Evers, the slain black leader of the civil rights movement in Mississippi.

title: Baseball Transactions
New Jersey Sports
description: JERSEY CITY, June 13Chuck Wepner is a salesman, and he's good at it. The New Jersey heavyweight boxer knows what it takes to put a product over, and he sells prize fighting as well as he does liquor all over the state. For enthusiasm in both endeavors, he's unbeatable.

title: KIDNEY PATIENTS FACE RISK IN DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 Social Security legislation that is about to go into effect to aid kidney patients may also aggravate the health problems of some of them, two experts said today.

title: Ox Ridge Show Opens in Country Style
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 13Unperturbed by occasional thunder clouds and buckets of rain, horses and riders today began the Ox Ridge Horse Showthe largest in the New York metropolitan area  in the green, under stated splendor of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

title: The Class Of 1948
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13It is our twentyfifth Harvard reunion. Here we are, several hundred of us, meeting each other's wives and chil dren, drinking, listening to professors again, looking to see what has hap pened to us.

title: People in Sports Rayner's Goal
description: Chuck Rayner, who used to strap special pads over the toes of his boots, one of the many innovations of goalies, was one of five named yes terday to the Hockey Hall of Fame. Rayner spent eight of his 10 National Hockey League seasons with the Rangers, played in 425 games, registered 25 shutouts and al lowed 1,295 goals. But the figures do not reflect his abil ity to perform acrobatics in the cage with his catlike re flexes, producing spectacular saves.

title: April Increase Lags Behind Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, June 13The growth in total business inventories slowed in April af ter strong expansion in the first quarter of the year, the Com merce Department reported to day.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Stage: Splendid Revival
description: With sad irony an ex ceptionally fine revival of Natural Affection, William Inge's Broadway disaster of 10 years ago, has coincided with the death of the play wright. Chances are he would have watched it with a quiet satisfaction. A play, which when read seems merely to arrange unappetizing people and clanging sexual frustra tions, now comes to life strongly and vividly, perhaps for the first time.

title: NIXON'S NOMINEE FOR F.P.C.BLOCKED
description: WASHINGTON, June 13The Senate, reflecting consumer unhappiness with the energy crisis, voted today to kill, at least for now, President Nixon's nomination of Robert H. Morris, a San Francisco lawyer, to be a member of the Federal Power Commission.

title: NIXON FREEZES PRICES FOR UP TO 60 DAYS, THEN WILL ESTABLISH PHASE 4 CONTROLS; FARM PRICES, WAGES, RENTS UNAFFECTED
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 President Nixon ordered to night a freeze on all retail prices, including those of food, for as much as 60 days.

title: Transit Accountability
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt deserves the thanks every New York City straphanger for bringing the often remote and occasionally imperious Metropolitan Trans portation Authority under more effective public control. Confronted with refusal by Dr. William J. Ronan of the M.T.A. to turn over certain public records for an audit of the authority's operations, Mr. Levitt exercised his subpoena powers. The conflict between the auditor and the transit agency wound up in the courts, and now the state's highest court has ruled unanimously in favor of the auditor. Mr. Levitt will get a look at the records he seeks.

title: Filipino Says $30,000 Gift For Nixon Was Returned
description: MANILA, Philippines, June 13 (AP)Ernesto Lagdameo, a former Philippine Ambassador to the United States, said today that his $30,000 donation to President Nixon's 1972 reelec tion campaign had been re turned.

title: NEW INDICTMENT ISSUED ON YESCO
description: The Costa Rican Government is being asked to extradite Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, on the basis of secret arrest warrant issued (here nearly two weeks ago by Federal Judge John M. Can nella and made public yester I day.

title: Shoemaker Rides 4 Winners
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 13 (AP)Bill Shoemaker rode four winners at Hollywood Park, in cluding the $33,000 Cygnet Stakes, and raised his career victory total to 6,502, more than any jockey in thorough bred history. Shoemaker rode Lady By Choice to victory in the 5furlong Cygnet Stakes for 2yearold fillies.

title: Tennis Results EASTERN WOMEN'S CLAY CHAMPIONSHIP AT MAMARONECK, N. Y.
description: Quarterfinal RoundMarilyn Aschner, liswood, Queens, defeated Debbie Camp bell, Old Greenwich, Conn., 61, 63; Barbara Goldman, Fort Lee, N. J., de feated Pat Stewart, New York, 76, 67, 62; Mary Carillo, Douelaston, Queens, defeated Mrs. Jean Burnett, Hackensack, N. J., 64, 64; Sheila McInerney, Rome, N. Y., defeated Mrs. Mariann Greenberg, Harrison, N. Y., 61, 75.

title: Transcript of President's Speech and Text of His Executive Order on Price Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, June 13Following are a transcript of President Nixon's address tonight and the text of his Executive order providing for the stabilization of the economy:

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 73879
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or fast four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers In sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: FOR PUERTO RICO, A HEARTY SALUTE
description: By LOUIS CALTAA bit of Puerto Rico came to West 57th Street yesterday. For 45 minutes, a group of in strumentalists with guitars, ac cordions, a hand drum and a rattling gourd performed on the front steps of Carnegie Hall as passersby stopped to look, listen and enjoy the pulsating tunes.

title: U.S. MY TIGHTEN HEALTH PLANNING
description: The Federal Government Is working on plans to put more muscle into the sixyearold Comprehensive Health Plan ning programs that were set up to guide the expansion and distribution of future health services.

title: Sweden Gains in Soccer
description: BUDAPEST, June 13 (UPI)Sweden ousted Hungary from the 1974 soccer World Cup to day by holding the Hungarians to a 33 tie. Sweden needs only a twoday victory margin in the last game against Malta Nov. 11 to qualify.

title: Mets Turn Back Giants, 31
description: With Tom Seaver pitching and a rookie named Ron Hod ges catching in his big league debut, the New York Mets mus tered enough healthy hands last night to defeat the San Fran cisco Giants, 31.

title: INTERSTATE STORES SETS LOAN ACCORD
description: Interstate Stores, Inc., an nounced yesterday that it had concluded an agreement with its bankers and other leaders to restructure its credit agree ment loans totaling $69.7mil lion. Sol W. Cantor, chairman, said the terms of the agreement called for payments of $13.9 million each on Dec. 31, 1974, and a year later, with the bal ance payable Dec. 31, 1976.

title: Trading of Foreign Stock Is Seen Likely in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, June 13 (Reuters)The Tokyo Stock Exchange said today trading in a few foreign, stocks was likely to start next December.

title: COPPER CONCERNS JOIN IN PRICE RISE
description: The move toward higher prices for copper and zinc ac celerated yesterday.

title: PATH RAISES FARE TO 50C, UP 66.6%
description: PATH, the Port Authority's commuter railroad, announced yesterday that it would in crease its fare to 50 cents from 30 cents beginning July 29.

title: Chinese Foreign Minister Sees Pompidou and Jobert
description: PARIS, June 13 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Chi Pengfei of China discussed internation al problems today with Presi dent Pompidou of France and bilateral relations with Foreign Minister Michel Jobert.

title: FREEZE ON RENTS ASKED BY BEAME
description: Controller Abraham D. Beanie proposed an eightpoint program yesterday to solve the problem of runaway rents and deteriorating housing.

title: Ferry Schedule Cut
description: WOODS HODE, Mass., June 13 (AP)The Woods Hole, Martha's Vineyard and Nan tucket Steamship Authority puts its summer schedule into effect tomorrow but some serv ice from Woods Hole to Nan tucket will not be available because the Nobska, the line's oldest vessel, will be out of service. The authority advised travelers to the islands to check with it first.

title: NIXON'S NOMINEE FOR F.P.C.BLOCKED
description: WASHINGTON, June 13The Senate, reflecting consumer unhappiness with the energy crisis, voted today to kill, at least for now, President Nixon's nomination of Robert H. Morris, a San Francisco lawyer, to be a member of the Federal Power Commission.

title: Freeze and Phase 4
description: President Nixon has at last taken the inevitableand rightdecision in freezing prices and abandoning the voluntary Phase 3 program that has forced the nation to endure the worst inflationary explosion of the post war years. Had he acted sooner, Mr. Nixon might have spared consumers months of an inflation that had begun to feed on itself, with price markups racing to keep ahead of anticipated cost increases. As it is, the freeze locks up most prices at the very high level they attained during the period June 1 to June 8, 1973.

title: Clement B. Pollock, 68, Of American Smelting, Dies
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 13 Clement B. Pollock, who re tired two years ago as vice presidentexploration of the American Smelting and Refin ing Company, died Monday im Greenwich Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 52 Fair field Road.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On Nominee for F.P.C.
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)Following is the roll call by which the Senate voted today to recommit to the Commerce Committee President Nixon's nomination of Robert H. Morris to be a member of the Federal Power Commission:

title: POLICEMAN INDICTED FOR NARCOTICS SALE
description: A 24yearold police officer was indicted yesterday by Manhattan grand jury for crimi nal sale of narcotics, the Police Department announced last night.

title: MARGIN DEBT DOWN $500MILLION IN MAY
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that customers of member firms sharply reduced their margin debt in May.

title: PATH RAISES FARE TO 50C, UP 66.6%
description: PATH, the Port Authority's commuter railroad, announced yesterday that it would in crease its fare to 50 cents from 30 cents beginning July 29.

title: BELMONT FASHION TO IN HOT PURSUIT
KUWAIT SEEKING NEW PACT ON OIL
description: KUWAIT, June 13 (AP) The Kuwaiti Government an nounced today that it was seek ing a new participation agree ment with foreign oil compa nies operating in Kuwait.

title: PRICES OF BONDS LITTLE CHANGED
description: The capital markets played waiting game yesterday, with most investors and dealers re luctant to make commitments before hearing what antiinfla tion measures would be an nounced by President Nixon.

title: He's Adept at Diapering, Too
description: It was a whole new ball game for John Havlicek yes terday. He stood in front of a crowd of people with a bouncing baby girl in his arms, instead of a bouncing basketball.

title: WORLD CITIZENSHIP URGED AT HARVARD
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 (AP)  The president of Notre Dame University proposed to day that an international agen cy be set up to grant people world citizenship along with their national citizenship.

title: Jury at State Senator's Trial Hears of 2 Threats on His Life
description: TRENTON, June 13A wit ness who testified yesterday that he had suggested killing Assemblyman Kenneth A. Ge wertz, a Democrat from Gloucester County, as part of a deal with State Senator James M. Turner, Republican, told the court today that he had twice threatened to kill Senator Turner.

title: Torpedo Retriever Stolen
description: BREMERTON, Wash., June 13 (UPI)Two sailors have ad mitted taking a Navy torpedo retriever for a joyride, the Navy said yesterday. The 72foot vessel was found beached and empty with her motor running at full speed. Damage to the $200,000 vessel was about $4,300, the Navy said.

title: Three Editors Are Named By The Philadelphia Bulletin
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (UPI)  The appointment of two managing editors and a city editor was announced to, day by George R. Packard, new executive editor of The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin.)

title: Japan Acts on Pricing
description: TOKYO, June 13 (AP)Japan's Fair Trade Commission said today it was seeking to have eight Japanese companies scrap an allegedly illegal price and production quota agree ment for explosives. The gov ernment agency charged the companies with having violated the country's antimonopoly law.

title: Woman Said to Throw A Booklet at the Pope
description: ROME, June 13 (Reuters)A woman threw a small book let at Pope Paul VI today as he was being carried from his regular weekly general audi ence on his portable throne, a witness said.

title: Excerpts From News Conference by Saigon Official
description: PARIS, June 13Following are excerpts from a news conference given here today by Nguyen Xuan Phong, dep uty chief of the South Viet namese delegation to the Paris negotiations on Viet nam, as recorded and trans lated from the French by The New York Times:

title: New Testimony Is Said to Dispute Stans
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI)  The Senate Watergate Committee has secret sworn testimony indicating that Mau rice H. Stans was told the full story of the bugging of Demo cratic party headquarters by John N. Mitchell a week after the breakin last June, sources said tonight.

title: Events Today
description: Opera

title: No Instant Analysis Follows Nixon Talk
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System television network, which a week ago said it was ending instant analy sis of Presidential speeches, lived up to its promise last night.

title: Margaret Sanger BirthControl Clinic Will Merge Downtown and Expand Services
description: The Margaret Sanger ke search Bureau, the nation's oldest familyplanning clinic, will celebrate its 50th anniver sary by closing the doors of its two brownstones at 17 and 19 West 16th Street on Aug. 31. The bureau has served 250,000 patients since 1923.

title: Hearing Is Held on Plane Crash That Killed Mrs. Hunt
description: CHICAGO, June 13Sherman Skolnick, the freelance investi gator who contends that the airliner on which Mrs. E. Howard Hunt Jr. died was sabotaged, was given a special hearing today by the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: Sailor to Be Discharged
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 (UPI)The Navy said today that it was processing a dis charge for Patrick D. Cheno wet h, the sailor acquitted yesterday of sabotaging the aircraft carrier Ranger. He was granted a threeweek leave im mediately after a courtmartial hoard had found him not guilty of throwing two bolts and a paint scraper into a gear on the Ranger.

title: Union Rejects Airline Pact
description: MIAMI, June 13 (AP)Union negotiators rejected a contract proposal approved by the man agement of National Airlines today, and clerks and booking agents threatened to walk off their jobs. Spokesmen for both sides said that talks were con tinuing in Washington under the auspices of the National Medation Board. The main is sue was reported to be the length of a new contract.

title: Job Slip Released At Hearing as Proof Of G.O.P. Patronage
description: ALBANY, June 13A Demo cratic legislative hearing today received a copy of an Orleans Republican County job appli cation routing slip as proof that G.O.P. patronage was a factor in distributing state jobs.

title: HOUSE VOTE BACKS A DEBT EXTENSION
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 The House voted today to ex tend the Federal debt limit temporarily after defeating at tempts to attach to the bill rid ers that would have been sure to provoke a confrontation with the White House.

title: Lefkowitz Studies Reports Of Illegal G.O.P. Activities
description: ALBANY, June 13  The State Attorney General's Office has been investigating the pos sibility of illegal campaign ac tivities in connection with the Republican drive last year to retain majority control of the Assembly.

title: STOCKTON DOWNS PASARELL, 98, 62
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 13 (AP)  Four United States playersTom Gorman, Erick Van Dillen, Dick Stockton and Jimmy Connors  played impressively today and gained the quarterfinals of the $75,000 Nottingham grasscourt tennis tournament.

title: Mets Box Score
Ballet: Illuminations on a Precious Pair of Poets
description: There are very few ballets by Frederick Ashton in the American repertory, and this is largely or even totally the fault of Frederick Ashton. He is a great but timid chore ographer, and at times his cautiousness is oddly difficult to understand. Particularly as his ballets happen to be un usually resilient to alien re hearsal pressures. His ballets are a little like Balanchine's you can never go too wrong with them. The basic structure is simple and sound.

title: Wimbledon Is Facirik Loss of Top Players
description: LONDON, June 13 (UP1)Wimbledon today faced the prospect of its second year without the world's top tennis players.

title: Killing Suspects Found Dead
description: WAUKEGAN, III., June 13 (UPI)Two men charged in series of shooting deaths in Illinois in 1972, including the slaying of a wealthy suburban family, were found dead today in the Lake County Jail where they were awaiting trial. They were identified as Nathaniel Burse, 23 years old, and Ed ward Moran Jr., 23, both of Chicago. At the time of their arrests last year Cook County authorities said they were part of a black militant organization called De Mau Mau. Uncon firmed reports, said that they had been strangled in their cell.

title: CONVICT ACCUSES EXUNION OFFICIAL
description: ERIE, pa., June 13 (AP) A convicted murderer, William J. Prater, admitting he lied at his own trial, testified today against Albert E. Pass, the man Prater says had directed a plot to kill Joseph A. Yablonski, a United Mine Workers insur gent.

title: Miss Leonard Leads by Shot On 74 in Cross County Golf
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. L, June 13Laura Leonard of the home club took the lead by one shot with a 74, three over par, in the opening round of the 23d Women's Cross County Golf Association championship to day at Piping Rock.

title: Chess:
RICHARDSON SCORES BALKY WITNESSES
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson told Justice Depart ment employes today that un cooperative witnesses and a temporarily successful coverup had hampered the Federal in vestigation of the Watergate scandal.

title: Rockefeller U. Awards 27 Doctorates Without Pomp
description: In an intimate ceremony with a minimum of pomp, 27 persons graduated yesterday from the Rockefeller Univer sity.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 13 (AP)Those who thought Americans should have done better in the track and field portion of last year's Olympic Games get chance to assess the 1973 United States team starting tomorrow. The National Amateur Athletic Union champion ships open a threeday meet at Bakersfield Memorial Stadium.

title: Women Cry for Equality At a Sports Symposium
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI, June 13 A head varsity basketball coach with two years of ex perience at a Suffolk County high school receives an an nual average stipend of $1,420. A head girls basket ball coach with similar ex perience earns $330.

title: Growing Numbers Fail To Register for Draft
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)Although the draft is ending, registering with Se lective Service is still required for 18yearolds, but an in creasing number are failing to sign up.

title: JACQUES BELASCO, COMPOSER, 56, DIES
description: Jacques Belasco, a composer, musician and arranger, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 155 West 68th Street.

title: U.S.China Basketball Game To Be Telecast Here June 27
description: The opening game of the United StatesChina basketball series will be taped in Peking and telecast in prime time over a network of some 130 Ameri can stations June 27.

title: PHILADELPHIA KEEPS GRISCOM CUP IN GOLF
description: ARDMORE, Pa., June 13Philadelphia retained the Gris corn Cup with 26 points in the annual TriCity women's matchplay Nassau singles at the Merion Golf Club today.

title: School Boards Are Elected In Four Suburban Counties
Paragon Trading Suspended
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (Reuters)  The Securities and Exchange Commission sus pended overthecounter trading in Paragon Securities Company) for 10 days beginning today. The S.E.C. said the action was taken because of a lack of ac curate public information con cerning the results of the com pany's operations.

title: Transcript of Kissinger's News Conference on the Results of the Talks in Paris
description: PARIS, June 13Following is a transcript of a news conference today by Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security offairs, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Watergate News Too Extensive, 44% Say in Poll
description: A popular feeling throughout the country is that the Water gate affair has received too much attention from newspa pers, radio and television, ac cording to the latest Gallup Poll, released yesterday.

title: Singapore Premier Seeks Regional Role
description: SINGAPORE, June 13Two months ago Lee Kuan Yew, Prime Minister of Singapore, told the National Press Club in Washington: All I can say is that I am no danger to any body because you need a big power base to be able to pack a wallop. And not having big power base, one develops good, amiable, amicable life style.

title: Nixon's LIB
description: WASHINGTONIf Leonid Ilyich Brezhnev were an American political leader, he would be referred to by his initials: LIB.

title: 27 Food Places Face Charges Of Violating City Health Code
Paley Denies Political Reasons Led to Ban on Instant Analyses
description: William S. Paley, board chairman of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., said yesterday that he was aston ished to note, in recent press accounts of our new policy on Presidential broadcasts, alle gations, some attributed to anonymous C.B.S. newsmen, that the decision was inspired by political rather than journalistic considerations and that it was in response to Gov ernment pressures.

title: A Mentor of Sociologists Retires After 42 Years at Harvard Post
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13  Unlike the works of some other mandarins of modern sociology, the writ ings of Talcott Parsons are not likely to turn up on book stands in bus stations and drugstores. Nor is he likely to be found declaiming on the human predicament in glossy magazines or being quoted in the public press.

title: State Orders Ban on Sale In a MixUp on Epsom Salt
description: ALBANY, June 13 (UPI) An urgent recall order has been issued by the State Board of Pharmacy, directing pharma cists to remove from sale cer tain shipments of saltpeter and epsom salt.

title: Distillers Corpoiation Reports Drop in Net Income
STOCKTAPE PLAN ORDERED CHANGED
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered substan tial changes today the plan for a consolidated tape system submitted by the five national stock exchanges and the Na tional Association of Securities Dealers.

title: Zambia Offers Payment To Dead Girls Parents
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, June 13  President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia has of fered to pay compensation to the families of two Canadian women tourists who were shot dead at Victoria Falls on the Zambezi River frontier between Zambia and Rhode sia on May 15.

title: John W. Lamborn, 71, Dies; Led Firm of Sugar Brokers
description: CHILMARK, Mass., June 13 John W. Lamborn, who re tired in 1970 as board chair man of Lamborn & Co., sugar broker with headquarters in New York, died last evening in a hospital in Vineyard Haven. He was 71 years old and had lived in Upper Montclair, N. J., before moving here.

title: Sirhan Brother Convicted of Threatening Mrs. Meir
description: LOS ANGELES, June 13 (AP)  Sharif Bishara Sirhan, 39yearold brother of the assassin of Robert F. Kennedy, was con victed in a Federal court today of writing a letter threatening Israeli Prime Minister Golda Meir.

title: Tennis Results
2 ProMussolini Cantos Of Ezra Pound Found
description: FLORENCE, Italy, June 12 (AP)  Ezra Pound's two missing cantos, which extol the Italian Fascist dictator, Benito Mussolini, the politi cian the American poet most admired, have been found in the hands of the United States Government, the Flor entine historian Duilio Sus mel said today.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: HAND IN HANDEL Louis Zukofsky is a modern move ment poet who has written many words, and starting tonight, he's harnessing a good part of them to run simultaneously with Handers Harpsichord Pieces. Mr. Vs new work, arranged by Celia Zukofsky, his wife, is called L, Z. Masque A24, and it runs Thursday through Satur day at 8 this week and next at the Cubiculo, 414 West 51st Street (26521389).

title: Richardson May Reopen Kent State Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI)Attorney General. Elliot L. Richardson said today that the Justice Department might reopen the inquiry into the Ohio National Guard confronta tion at Kent State University that resulted in four student deaths during 1970 antiwar demonstrations.

title: Theater Blast Kills 5 In the Mekong Delta
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 13 (Reuters)  Five people died and 20 were injured when an explosion rocked an outdoor movie theater in the Mekong Delta province of An Xuyen, the South Vietnamese command said today. A spokesman said that five of the injured were policemen.

title: Wolff Seeks to Exempt L.I.R.R. From Labor Act
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI), Representative Lester L. Wolff, Democrat of New York, has introduced legislation to exempt the Long Island Rail Road from provisions of the Railway Labor Act.

title: Government Witness Defends Policy of Ocean Waste Dumping
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 Ocean dumping of municipal and industrial wastes into the New York Bighteast of Sandy Hook  may be the least en vironmentally damaging means now available of disposing of the wastes, a Government oceanic expert told a Senate Commerce Subcommittee today.

title: ZAPATA TO PURSUE TALKS WITH P. &O.

title: Illegal Death
description: Since January, when President Nixon disclosed in his budget message that he was requesting no funds for the Office of Economic Opportunity in the next fiscal year, the Administration has slowly been putting the agency to death. Programs have been phased out, employes fired, and money that Congress appropriated to wage war on poverty has been left unspent.

title: Policeman Is Indicted on Murder Charge in Killing of Queens Boy,
description: Police officer Thomas J. Shea was indicted in a murder charge by a Queens grand jury yesterday in the shooting of 10yearold boy in South Ja maica last April 28. The of ficer's partner, Walter Scott, was ordered suspended, charg ed with giving false answers to superiors and to members of the District Attorney's of fice during the investigation of shooting.

Gigante, a Roman Catholic priest from the South Bronx, is among several candidates for City Council who is just now find ing out that he was victorious in the June 4 primary. The former closed at 7, down  on the New York Stock Exchange and the latter added  at 6 on the Big Board.

description: A 74yearold retired Navy, Yard employe was found mur:1 dered yesterday in his Brook1 lyn apartment, apparently the victim of a robbery attempt.

description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (Reu ters)  A Civil Aeronautics Board judge recommended to day the award of a Floridato California route to Pan Ameri can World Airways. This would give the airline its first domes tic flights over the mainland United States.

description: A twicedecorated Transit Authority policeman was in fair condition at Kings County Hospital last night after a group of youths pushed him down the stairs at the Brighton Beach levated Station of the BMT. Hospital.

title: Psycopath Does His Grim Deeds in 'Wicked, Wicked':The Cast
description: Titles tell you nothing. Just on the surface, "Wicked, Wicked" sounds like a slightly misbehaving nineteen-fifties sub-deb. Actually, it is the story of Jason (Randolph Roberts), a poor confused lad who works in a huge California resort hotel where he occasionally slices up the guests (preferably good-looking younger blondes) and then pieces their bodies back together, secretly preserving them as per instructions in his correspondence-school mortician's course. It is also the story of a hotel dick named Rick (David Bailey), and his lovely lady, Lisa (Tiffany Bolling), and the marvelous old monstrosity (Hotel del Coronado, in San Diego) where Rick detects and Lisa entertains and Jason clears away the customers.What distinguishes "Wicked, Wicked" from all other recent psychopathic-killers-loose-in-rambling-old-hotels movies is its gimmick. "A unique projection process" according the distributor, which calls it Duo-Vision. Duo-Vision is in fact nothing more than split-screen unremittingly applied, as in "Chelsea Girls" and "Dionysus in '69," but never before with such winning simplicity of intention.By means of Duo-Vision we see: 1. two things at once, 2. two points of view on any one thing at once, 3. present action and flashbacks to past action at the same time, and 4.when there isn't much else going ona pop-eyed woman who plays spooky music on a big theater organ. Obviously, a big hotel full of rooms and corridors is a natural for multiple-screen projection. But not quite so obviously, the effect of such projection is to defuse the action.When you can see both the distant, stalking killer and his intended victim at the same time you have more activity but less anticipationand consequently less suspense. And the lifting of suspense, which in most such movies functions as an annoying burden upon the audience, is a very real advantage."Wicked, Wicked" thus emerges as an oddly pleasant movie about which there is not too much good to say. Everybody is likableeven the killer, who, like most amateur embalmers in movies for the last 10 years, owes a bit to Hitchcock's Norman Bates. And everybody is at least professionally competent.There should always be a place for the low-budget hotel movie, where the same six extras as guests continually crisscross the lobby and enjoy the show in the supper club, and where everything, from room service on up, has the attractively casual air of making do with the needs and opportunities of the moment."Wicked, Wicked," written, produced, and directed by Richard Bare, opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.

Vesco, a New Jersey financier.

description: UNIONDALE, LI, June 13 Officials of the projected Nassau County Reference Library may have to import a pair of concrete lions, a squadron of pretzel venders and a subway rumbling underground just to make their patrons feel at home.

description: PARIS, June 13Social se curity workers are returning to their jobs after a monthlong strike that has caused some basic questions to be asked about the workings of the French systeman antiquated moneydispensing machine that deals out $25billion a year in payments to nine out of ten Frenchmen.

description: Heavy selling and declining prices marked much of the trading in commodity markets yesterday. Observers attributed the weakness to a desire on the part of traders to sell out before the speech last night by President Nixon on inflation controls.

description: APPLETON, Wis., June 13 (AP)Larry Little, a guard for the champion Miami Dolphins, whose blocking helped Larry Csonka and Mercury Morris rush for 1,000 yards apiece last season, was named today to re ceive the National 1,000Yard Club Foundation's outstanding blocker award.

title: Notes on People
description: The White House an nounced that retired Maj. Gen. John C. Bennett of the Army had become chief dep uty to Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Nixon's new chief of staff. General Bennett, who is 48 years old, retired last summer after 27 years in the Army. General Haig, who is scheduled to re sign from the Army on Aug. 1, and General Bennett worked together in the Pentagon for several years. And, like Gen eral Haig, Mr. Bennett is a graduate of the United States Military Academy.

title: Singer Cleared on Charge of Marijuana Possession
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 13 (AP) Jaye P. Morgan, the singer, has been cleared of marijuana possession charges on the grounds the drug had been found through an illegal search.

title: Screen: 'O Lucky Man!':English Comedy Tells of a Classic Innocent The Cast
description: Mick Travis (Malcolm McDowell), at heart, is literature's classic innocent. He is wide-eyed and tireless, and he is possessed by such sweetness of temper that arbitrary cruelties go unrecognized. Instead, unpleasant shocks are absorbed by an optimism that serves him as a kind of ship's fender, protecting him on all sides.However, unlike Candide, even unlike Evelyn Waugh's Paul Pennyfeather, Mick would hardly qualify for citizenship in any but the most haphazardly administered state of grace. Mick wants to succeed and he is willing to try just about anything to do it. His completely unfounded belief that he can succeed, that he will overcome all obstacles, becomes the badge that certifies his innocence. It is a second-rate sort of badge, like something out of a cereal box, and a second-rate sort of innocence, quite in keeping with the second-rate morality of the times we live in."O Lucky Man!", the new English comedy directed by Lindsay Anderson (his first since "If . . .") and written by his "If . . ." collaborator, David Sherwin, chronicles the adventures of Mick from his humble beginnings as a trainee-salesman at Liverpool's Imperial Coffee Company, through various good fortunes and outrageous disasters, until, at the end, Mick has a kind of Zen illumination. A light bulb goes on inside his head. He smiles broadly: He is, after all, alive.Mick has hobnobbed with international tycoons, scientists and politicians, and he's been double-crossed by all. He has also been nursed (quite literally) with the milk of human kindness by a vicar's wife. He has been thrown into jail for simply wanting to succeed ("And you failed!" says the furious judge), and he's been rehabiliated ("Did you know you have eyes like Steve McQueen?" asks a kindly warden).He has been seduced by a rapacious landlady, abandoned by a beautiful London debutante, tortured at anatomic research center (in the name of national security) and beaten up by vagrants he would have helped."0 Lucky Man!" clearly has a number of things on its mind, but as a movie, it is a very mixed bagBecause Mr. Anderson is much more bold and free as a director than Mr. Sherwin is inventive as a social satirist, "O Lucky Man!" always promises to be much more stimulating and funny than it ever is. Staying with it through its almost three-hour running time becomes increasingly nerve-racking, like watching superimposed images that never synchronize. The result does not match the ambition of the intention. The wit is too small, too perfunctory, for the grand plan of the film and the quality of the production itself.Every member of the castheaded by McDowell, Ralph Richardson, Rachel Roberts, Arthur Lowe and Helen Mirrenis superb, and there is something surprisingly appealing (both to one's theatrical sense and to the dramatic unity of the film) in having lots of the actors turn up in different roles throughout the chronicle.The real star, however, is Alan Price, best known here for "The Animals," who wrote the film's fine score and sings at various intervals during the movie, either on the soundtrack or in scenes shot in a recording studio. The songs, which more or less punctuate the individual chapters of Mick's odyssey, provide the wit and sense of surprise that are lacking in Sherwin's screenplay. It is funny when Price sings cheerfully, "Sell, sell, sellsell everything you stand for"when Mick starts out on the road, since Mick, quite obviously, stands for very little.The score exhibits real irony about the ghastly indecencies that Sherwin so ponderously tries to ridicule. In this day and age, for those of us who have grown up with the truly epic visions of film makers like Buuel and Chaplin, it's hardly enough for a film to qualify as "serious" or "important" by pointing out to us the excesses of capitalism, the awesomeness of technology gone mad, or even that poor people can act like beasts, just like rich people.A more disturbing proposition by far would be a film that might suggest that rampant capitalism and technological madness could possibly succeed, by some terrible fluke, in fulfilling their promises. That is something that would force us to rethink the clichs we liberals live by. "O Lucky Man!", which opened yesterday at Cinema I, is a kind of homage to those clichs.

title: COPPER STRIKERS EMBARRASS CHILE
description: RANCAGUA, Chile, June 13 Copper is the wages of Chile, President Salvador Allende Gossens has often said during the two and a half years since his Marxist Government took office.

title: Bridge:High Honor Cards May Need Quick Disposal on Defense
description: High honor cards are al ways assumed to be assets in the bidding, but this assump tion is not always valid in the play. Situations can arise in which a defender belatedly comes to the realization that a high honor should have been disposed of before it became an asset to the declarer.

title: Business and Labor Say Freeze Fails To Meet Problems
description: President Nixon's 60day price freeze was criticized last night by both business and labor as failing to come to grips with the nation's eco nomic problems.

title: Sweden Gains in Soccer
description: BUDAPEST, June 13 (UPI)Sweden ousted Hungary from the 1974 soccer World Cup to day by holding the Hungarians to a 33 tie. Sweden needs only a twoday victory margin in the last game against Malta Nov. 11 to qualify.

title: 3% Cut Ordered in Cost Of Homeowner Policies
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 13Insurance premiums on 1,100,000 homeowner policies in New Jersey will be reduced by 3 per cent effective Aug. 1, Insurance Commissioner Rich ard C. McDonough announced today.

title: Text of the Joint Communique on Vietnam Issued in Paris by Kissinger and Tho
description: WASHINGTON, June 13Following, as made public by the White House, is the text of a joint communiqu signed in Paris today by Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho, detailing means of strengthening the Vietnam cease fire. The communiqu was drawn up in two versions. The four party version was signed first. Three hours later, because the Saigon Government is unwilling to imply recognition of the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government, a two party version mentioning that Gov ernment was signed by the United States and North Viet nam only.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Saigon Aide Finds Improvement In Accord but Cites Difficulties
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 14South Viet nam's Foreign Minister, Tran Van Lam, said today that he felt the Paris communiqu was an improvement over the orig inal Vietnam ceasefire accord, but he said that the document left unresolved some of the critical differences between Saigon and the Communists.

description: RICHLAND, Wash., June 13 (AP)The leak of 115,000 gal lons of radioactive waste into the ground at the Atomic En ergy Commission's Hanford res ervation poses no danger to human life, an A.E.C. official said today.

description: SHANNON, Ireland, June 13 (AP)Security workers today) called off a strike that had closed Shannon International Airport for 24 hours and stranded hundreds of American tourists bound for home.

description: President Nixon's 60day price freeze was criticized last night by both business and labor as failing to come to grips with the nation's eco nomic problems.

title: ASTRONAUTS FEEL EFFECTS OF SPACE
description: HOUSTON, June 13 (AP)Skylab's astronauts are feeling the effects of prolonged weightlessness on their 20th day in space. Two of the three men are experiencing a weak ened cardiovascular system, but doctors here said today that this was expected, add ing the crew is in excellent health.

title: The Turning of America
description: SAN FRANCISCOThe great story of Watergate is not the disclosures themselves but the reaction to them. Lawless abuse of power has been a major and horrifying fact of life in America, and especially official Wash ington, at least since the end of World War II. Watergate has thus far exceeded earlier abuses only in the egregiousness of its blunders and the fact that it was directed against the Democratic party rather than an un popular minority. The initial response of a large segment of the publicin difference because everybody does it"seems wholly understandable. What is new, and profoundly impor tant, is that the establishment is for the first time beginning to reject what it long ignored and passively sanc

title: Architecture: 6 Designs Win Bard Merit. Awards
description: Just a little more than 10 years ago, the City Club of New York made news by not giving its Bard Awards for Excellence in Architecture and Urban Design. It made the nonpresentation with considerable fanfare. There was nothing good enough, the City Club announced, to merit recognition in the pub lic sector, which it alternates annually for the prizes with buildings of the private sec tor. The nonprize was meant to chasten city and state agencies for the parlous state of the city's public architec ture.

title: Admission to Soviet films
description: The plan to show seven So viet films free of charge at the Little Carnegie Theater has been revised. Only today's screening of The White Son of the Desert will be shown free. Admission to other perform ances will be $3; students and children $1.

title: Hockey Transactions
One Indicted in the False Listing Of Donors to Agnew Fund Event
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 13One person was indicted on four charges today involving the false listing of 32 contribu tors to a Salute to Ted Agnew fundraising event held during the 1972 Presidential campaign.

title: Wilson School Endowers Identified as a L.I. Couple
description: PRINCETON, N.J. June 13The mysterious Foundation X, which donated $35million to endow the Woodrow Wilson School for Public and Interna tional Affairs at Princeton Uni versity 11 years ago, was iden tified today as a foundation set up by a Long Island couple.

title: LAW IS PROPOSED ON DOCTORS BIDS

description: The initial reaction of Wall Street's stock and bond men to the President's economic ad, dress ranged last night from r. strong optimism, at least over the next few sessions, for the bond market to dark pessimism for stocks.

description: Members of the City Plan ning Commission voiced con cern yesterday over what they consider the high costs of five housing developments proposed for construction here with methods used in Operation Breakthrough, the Federal Gov ernment's program to reduce construction costs through massproduction building tech niques.

description: CAMBRIDEG, Mass., June 13 (AP)The class of 1948 an nounced the first $1million class gift to Harvard Univer sity today during the school's 322d commencement ceremo nies, The total gift came to $1,148,448.48.

description: In commenting yesterday on an antitrust action filed against it by the Justice Department on Tuesday, Texaco, Inc., said that its agreement with Coastal States Gas Producting Company places no restrictions of Coast al's rights to sell to other com panies.

description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 13Premier In Tam said today that he still saw no im mediate possibility of negotiat ing the end of the war in Cambodia and virtually ruled out talks between the Govern ment and the deposed Chief of State, Prince Norodom Si hanouk.

title: Connecticut River Study Details Cost of Cleanup
description: HARTFORD, June 13Clean ing up the polluted air and water along the Connecticut River will cost the industries and towns in the four states through which the river flows more than $1.3billion by 1980, according to a study completed by the Chase Manhattan Bank of New York and 12 commer cial banks in New England.

title: 1,000 HONOR GOLAR, INCLUDING LINDSAY
description: Simeon Golar, who has re signed as chairman of the City Housing Authority to run for City Council president, was honored last night at a dinner attended by Mayor Lindsay.

description: BERLIN, June 13The East German Parliament today unanimously ratified a goodwill treaty with West Germany. The treaty is intended to end the hostility that has largely marked the relations between the two nations since the post war division of Germany.

title: Putting Key to U.S. Open
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 13Seeking a new goal with a bag of old clubs, Jack Nick laus begins his quest for his fourth United States Open title tomorrow. A triumph at the Oakmont Country Club would give golf's Golden Bear his 14th major cham pionship thus exceeding Bob by Jones's record of 13. It would also enable the 33yearold professional to join Jones, Willie Anderson and Ben Hogan as the only golf ers to win the Open four times.

description: The second Vietnam peace agreement that was signed yesterday in Paris by representatives of the United States, North and South Vietnam and the Vietcong is essentially a retread of the Jan. 27 Paris pact, with all the weak nesses of that muchabused document.
