description: Dr. Martin D. Davis, a psy chiatrist and former treasurer of the Psychoanalytic Associa tion of New York, died Tues day in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx, after a stroke. He was 53 years old and lived at 4430 Tibbett Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: New State Law Extends Sway Of Addict Unit to DrugAbusers
description: ALBANY, June 13The state agency dealing with drug abuse will have jurisidction over il legal users of amphetamines and other pills as well as users of heroin and similar narcotics un der a bill signed into law to day by Governor Rockefeller.

title: Heat's Off City and Con Ed As a Cool Front Moves In
description: Power company officials as well as the man on the street breathed a sigh of relief yester day as a cool front moved into the Northeast, bringing lower temperatures and humidity and a lessening in demands for electric power for aircondi tioning.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The fur houses, prestigious and sporty, continued their showings this week and it's a safe bet that if so many of the designs managed to look attractive to audiences wilted by 90degree weather and paralyzed aircondition ing, the lure of fur isn't yet on the wane.

title: Lefkowitz Studies Reports Of Illegal G.O.P. Activities
description: ALBANY, June 13  The State Attorney General's Office has been investigating the pos sibility of illegal campaign ac tivities in connection with the Republican drive last year to retain majority control of the Assembly.

title: First Bergdorf Branch to Open in 1974
description: WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 13  Bergdorf Goodman, the Fifth Avenue specialty store, broke ground here today for its first branch store in its 73year history. It will be a proto type for as many as four new Bergdorf stores in the New York area and New England in the next decade.

title: Maine Governor Signs Bill Eliminating Marijuana Law
description: AUGUSTA, Me., June 13 Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis signed today a bill that eliminates the state's criminal penalties for knowingly being present where marijuana is kept.

title: Merrill Stock: Market Place. Holt Still a.Bear
description: Distress sometimes makes heroes out of villains, and there's no doubt that distress has been reigning in the stock market for some time.

title: Newly Discovered Comet Will Light January Sky
description: Successive observations of Kohoutek Comet, discovered by accident on March 7, indi cate that late this year it will circle unusually close to the sun, producing what may be the most dramatic night sky display of the century.

title: JERSEY CORPORATION IS ACCUSED BY S.E.C.
description: A complaint was filed yester day by the Securities and Ex change Commission in the United States District Court for the Southern District here, seeking to enjoin Management Dynamics, Inc., four brokerage houses and 13 others from vio lations of the registration and antifraud provisions of the Fed eral securities laws.

title: W. STAPLEY WONHAM
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 13 W. Stapley Wonham, a re tired executive of R. R. Shims, Wonham & Co., export concern, died today in Greenwich Hos pital. He was 74 years old and lived here.

title: Xerox Signs 50 Stations To Rebroadcast America
description: The Xerox Corporation has signed 50 television stations to rebroadcast Alistair Cooke's America series for 13 con secutive weeks beginning in September through the facili ties of the Hughes TV network.

title: Reformer From Liberia
description: For nearly two decades as Vice President of Liberia, William R. Tolbert Jr. remained an unknown quantity at home and abroad, obscured in the imposing shadow of the flamboyant President William V. S. Tubman. Now, less than two years after becoming President following Mr. Tubman's death, Dr. Tolbert has come to this country on a state visit, bearing a substantial reputation as an engineer of constructive change and overdue reform Liberia and a man of influence in black Africa's turbulent politics.

title: Struck Cemeteries Urge State Move
description: Unburied bodies continued to increase at struck cemeteries yesterday, but state and city officials reported that they had not determined as yet that the walkout posed an actual threat to the health and wel fare of residents.

title: PHILADELPHIA KEEPS GRISCOM CUP IN GOLF
description: ARDMORE, Pa., June 13 Philadelphia retained the Gris com Cup with 26 points in the annual TriCity women's matchplay Nassau singles at the Merion Golf Club today.

title: Sports Today
Auto Companies Still Planning Peak Output
description: DETROIT, June 13Newcar sales. fell to 221,959 units dur ing the June 110 period from 259,223 in the comparable period last year.

title: ISRAEL RESPONDS TO EGYPT IN U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. June 13  Israel today direct ly challenged Egypt's conten tion that any settlement in the Middle East would have to elude the establishment of a new and separate Palestinian nation.

title: Mrs. Thanh Asks Release To Take Teaching Job in N.Y.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 13 (UPI)Mrs. Ngo Ba Thanh, imprisoned by the South Vietnamese Government for antigovernment activities, today demanded her release so that she can accept a teaching post at Columbia University in New York.

title: At Rug Concert, a Standing Ovation
description: Pierre Boulez and the New York Philharmonic laid them in the aislesand just about everywhere else at Phil harmonic Hall on Tuesday night, but it was no laughing matter. The program, first in a new series of six Rug Concerts, turned into a seri ous success for the orches tra and its music director, who were awarded a stand ing ovation by the predomi nantly young audience.

title: Anker to Be Named Schools Chancellor
description: The Board of Education plans to announce today the ap pointment of Irving Anker to a twoyear term as Chancellor. At the same time the board will fill several major new posi tions as part of a scheduled reorganization of central school headquarters.

title: Senate Group For Ending Underground Nuclear Tests
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved over whelmingly today a resolution urging a mutual suspension of underground nuclear tests by the United States and thel Soviet Union.

title: S.E.C. Suspends Trading On Five Stocks on OTC
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission sus Tended overthecounter trad ing in the stocks of the Na tional Environment Corpora tion of Anaheim, Calif.; Na tional Institute for Better Read ing, Inc., New York; the San dia International Metals Cor poration, Albuquerque, N. M.; Seaferro, Inc., Miami, and the Western Land Corporation, Chicago.

title: PANEL PASSES BILL TO CUT CAMPAIGNS
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 Legislation that would drasti cally curtail formal Presidential campaigns, including a nation al election in October, was ap proved today by the Senate Rules Committee and sent to the Senate floor for considera tion.

title: Dave Anderson The Last Stand
description: CAKMONT, Pa., June 13The narrow streets are snaded by majestic oaks. Some of the big white homes near the Oakmont Country Club, with, their big sloping lawns, have the look of old wealth. They never play the United States Open championship in a ghetto. But this suburb of Pittsburgh isn't really a fancy town. Down near the Allegheny River, which winds through the wooded valley, steelmill workers live in small homes that need to be painted. The wealthy club isn't that fancy, either. The greenandwhite gabled wooden club house is old, almost worn. And here, on a course where more sand traps than trees come into play, on a course that is only a few miles up the Pennsylvania Turnpike from where he lives and grew up, on a course that he has played perhaps 100 times, Arnold Palmer is making his last stand.

title: Martin Aranow, Who Led Fight Over Jersey Rent Hikes, Is Dead
description: FORT LEE, N.J., June 13 Martin Aranow, who as presi dent of the New Jersey Tenants Organization had led one of the most effective movements in the area against rent increases, died today in Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases in New York. He was 37 years old and lived at 2185 Lemoine Avenue.

title: Nancy McCarthy Wed To F.E.Richardson 3d
description: Miss Nancy Worth Mc Carthy and Frank E. Richard son 3d were married last Friday in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building. On Sunday a religious cere mony was performed by the Rev. William McCoy at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Anker to Be Named Schools Chancellor
description: The Board of Education plans to announce today the ap pointment of Irving Anker to twoyear term as Chancellor. At the same time the board will fill several major new posi tions as part of a scheduled reorganization of central school headquarters.

title: High Court Rejects Ban On Disclosure by I.B.M.
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) The Supreme Court refused today to block, pending appeal, an order requiring the Inter national Business Machines Corporation to turn over to the Government 1,200 documents it claims to have protected from disclosure.

title: Stans Attacked by Ervin and Talmadge For Denying Knowledge of Fund Deals
F.T.C. Sues Bestline Products Over Pyramid Sales System
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI)The Government to day went to court against a pyramid sales plan involving a line of soap products that, it said, has been tricking con sumers with an endless recruit ing process.

title: AMEX PRICES GAIN AS VOLUME EASES
description: After opening sharply higher and remaining that way until about noon, prices on the Amer ican Stock Exchange moder ated late in the session and closed up 0.04 to 22.69 yester day.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The outdoor swimming pool season begins Saturday, when the Parks Recreation and Cultural Affairs Adminis tration opens 37 pools in the five boroughs. Later this month, the agency will open 81 minipools throughout the city. This weekend, the outdoor pools will be open from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. From Monday through June 22, they will operate from noon to 8 P.M. Starting Saturday, June 23, the facilities will begin the regular summer schedule, 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. every day of the week.

title: Environmental Plan Offers Guide to Developing State
description: A 91page preliminary en vironmental plan designed to guide the development of New York State without endanger ing its land, air and water was released yesterday by the De partment of Environmental Conservation.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Upper Broadway Is aGreening
description: One of the largest block association efforts to add splashes of greenery to New York is under way on the Upper West Side, where a federation of associations has replanted 13 Broadway malls between 61st Street and 113th Street and plans to replant and landscape 17 more.

title: BADILLO PREPARES TV FILM CAMPAIGN
description: David Garth, whose cinma verit style of television com mercials helped put John V. Lindsay across to New York City voters, sent a crew out yesterday to film the mayoral campaign of Representative Herman Badillo.

title: A Model Medical System for Town in Land of the Midnight Sun
description: KIRUNA, Sweden  The midnight sun that shines for 24 hours a day now brings planeloads of tourists to this remote mining town that lies some 80 miles above the Arctic Circle. But a model system of medical care that serves the town's 35,000 res idents is also acting as a magnet for many of the vis itors.

title: Wilson School Endowers Identified as a L.I. Couple
Books of The Times
description: MALE CHAUVINISM! HOW IT WORKS. By Michael Korda. 242 pages. Random House. $6.95.

title: Little Hungarian Pulls Cutting a Large Figure
description: Of the 118 breeds regis tered by the American Ken nel Club, in 1972, the pull rated No. 64, with 869 of them listed. A leader in keep ing this little Hungarian dog in the public's eye has been Leslie Bemis, who has im ported from 60 to 70 from his native Hungary.

title: Policeman Indicted for Homicide in 1971 Shooting
description: A 29yearold police officer already facing perjury charges growing out of a traffic acci dent was indicted yesterday in the 1971 shooting death of a man described by the police as a leading Times Square pimp.

title: Nixon Aide Denies Energy Gap Is Caused by Ecological Effort
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)The President's top en vironmental advisor sharply criticized today allegations that the nation's energy crisis is due to antipollution efforts.

title: Nixon Action Generally Welcomed by Congress
description: WAHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) Congress generally welcomed President Nixon's decision to night to freeze prices, but some Democrats said that he had done too little, too late.

title: Message Spurs Confusion of Traders
description: Commodity dealers were in a quandary yesterday as they pondered the ramifications of the Administration's new steps to fight inflation. Traders con fusion over President Nixon's speech caused wildly swinging prices, and wheat, corn and soybean futures all closed low er. Silver was up and copper down.

title: Moscow Admits False Report That Power Plant Was in Use
description: MOSCOW, June 14  The Soviet Union, in an unusual admission of false economic reporting, conceded tonight that a huge Siberian power gener ator was put in service five years ago when it had in fact not been installed at all, having burned out on the factory floor.

title: The Personal Tragedies
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The other day, seeking to explain the human tragedies in the Watergate case, Sen ator Sam Ervin recalled Cardinal Wolsey's piercing cry of regret in Shakespeare's Henry VIII: Had but served my God with half the zeal I served my King, he would not in mine age have left me naked to mine enemies.

title: Chess: Larsen's Ambitious Thrust Folds Under Twin Attacks
description: LENINGRAD, June 13Two of the leaders  Bent Larsen of Denmark and Vik tor Korchnoi of the Soviet Union  met in Round 8 of the Interzonal Tournament for world championship aspi rants here in the Dzerjinsky Palace of Culture tonight.

title: Levitt Says State Ended Fiscal Year in the Black
description: The state entered its 197374 fiscal year April 1 in very good financial health but still needs a new accounting sys tem, Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday.

title: Magruder on Watergate: Ends Justify the Means
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Government officials he re spected had done it. The uni versity professor of ethics he admired had done it. So Jeb Stuart Magruder had done it too, he told the Senate com mittee investigating the Wa tergate affair today. He had let the ends justify the means.

title: CONNORS, GORMAN, CHRIS EVERT WIN
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, Jun 14 (AP)Two of America's brightest young hopes for Wim bledon, Chris Evert and Jimmy Connors, scored victories to day as United States players gained three semifinal berths in the men's and women's di visions of the $75,000 Notting ham grass court tennis tourna ment.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)A House committee that investigated drug use by athletes has recommended that the National Football League use a spotcheck urin analysis to determine whether players use narcotics. The committee also recommended that tough penalties be established for drug usefines, suspension or barring for life. Representative Harley O. Staggers, Democrat of West Virginia and chairman of the House Commerce Commit tee, said the committee's yearlong study showed drug use exists, in varying degrees, in all sports and levels of competitions with few exceptions. Ed Garvey, director the Players Association, called the urinalysis proposal an absolute outrage.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on June 14 were:

title: ASPIRIN MAKERS DISPUTE CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, June 14, (UPI)The makers of 10 lead ing aspirin products told the Government today that they were not guilty of false and misleading advertising in say ing that their preparations were better than just plain aspirin,

title: Colgate Clears Helena Rubinstein Deal
description: The ColgatePalmolive Com pany, in its first major move into highfashion cosmetics, disclosed yesterday that its di rectors had approved a tenta tive agreement to buy Helena Rubinstein, Inc., for stock now valued at nearly $125million.

title: TESTIFIES 5 HOURS
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Jeb Stuart Magruder, the former deputy director of President Nixon's 1972 reelection cam paign, told a firsthand story today of how he and other highranking officials had plot ted the bugging of the Demo crats and then tried to cover it up.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS CHARGE COVERUP
description: State Democratic leaders contended yesterday that At torney General Louis J. Lefko witz's investigation into the possibility of illicit campaign practices by Republicans had the makings of a Watergate coverup scandal for New York.

title: IRATE BYSTANDERS
description: Three pursesnatchers who had knocked their victims to the ground were thwarted in their escape on West 81st Street at the corner of Broad way last night as 50 angry by standers surrounded them in a taxicab until the police could arrive.

title: Two Bills Passed To Force Reform Of City Tax Panel
description: The City Council unanimous ly passed two bills yesterday to reform the city's Tax Com mission by lessening mayoral power and insulating the com mission's seven members from political pressures.

title: TV Review
description: Viewers who missed Joyce Chen's China on Sunday would do well to catch the repeat tomorrow night at 11:30 over WNET/Channel 13. This onehour documen tary, produced by WGBH of Boston, is a diverting hot weather treat.

title: Radio
description: 66:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Con certo in C (Op. 5, No. 12), Albi noni; Cello Concerto in A, Tar tini; Concerto Grosso No. 8 in IG minor, Corelii.

title: People and Business
description: James J. Needham, chair man of the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday placed some of the blame for the absence of many individual investors from the market on the accounting profession.

title: Miss Lee Is Bride of Jacques Istel
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., June 14Miss Felicia Juli ana Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. TuhYueh Lee of Menlo Park, Calif., formerly of New York, was married here this morning to Jacques Andre Istel, a pioneer of sport para chuting in this country.

title: Nets Present New Faces of 197,3 As a 1974 Face Watches Closely
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 14 The Nets opened a three day rookie camp today at Hofstra University with 21 new faces. Nineteen were try ing to win a place on the team, the 20th was Kevin Loughery, the new coach, and No. 21 was Dave DeBus schere of the Knicks.

title: Beame and Badillo Disagree Sharply in First Debate
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame and Representative Herman Badillo, in the first facetoface debate of their runoff cam paign for the Democratic mayoral nomination, sharply dis agreed on more flexible com munity budgets, housing policy and their past performance in office.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, June 14  Japan's balance of payments in May registered a deficit of $1.18billion, outstripping a pre vious record for the third consecutive month since March, the Finance Ministry announced in a preliminary report today.

title: L. A. Stone Jr. Weds Mrs. Botter
description: Mrs. Simmone Leffert Bot ter was married yesterday afternoon at her home at 35 Sutton Place to Louis A. Stone Jr. of Greens Farms, Conn. The Rev. David C. Love of Norfolk, Va., a bishop of the Pentecostal Church, and Epis copal Canon William J. Chase, chaplain of Roosevelt Hospi tal, officiated.

title: Soviet to Kill 4 for War Role
description: MOSCOW, June 14 (Reuters) A court in Pskov, 400 miles northwest of Moscow, has sen tenced four persons to death on charges of membership in Nazi punitive squad, near the Estonian border that killed more than 50 villagers during World War II, Pravda reported today,

title: Equity Funding Hearing Is Scheduled for June 22
description: A hearing to decide how to consolidate the 51 law suits al ready filed in the wake of the insurance scandal at the Equity Funding Corporation of Amer ica has been scheduled for June 22 in San Diego, Calif., the Stockholders and Creditors News Service reported yester day in Philadelphia.

title: Marcos's Lawyers Put Martial Law Before Civil Rights
description: MANILA, dune 14 (AP) Lawyers for President Ferdi nand E. Marcos have told the Supreme Court that martial law prevails over civil rights Ian the Philippines.

title: Juvenile Jail Ombudsman Is Decreed
description: Appointment of an inde pendent ombudsman to han dle grievances of children held in juvenile detention facilities here was ordered yesterday by Federal District Judge Mor ris E. Lasker.

title: A Mild Quake Rattles Windows Upstate and in Northeast Areas
description: A mild earthquake sent trem ors across a wide area of southern Canada, Northern New England and New York State last night, There were no re ports of injuries or of damage beyond some cracks in road surfaces.

title: COMMODITY BROKER ADMITS MAIL FRAUD
description: LOS ANGELES, June 14 (UPI)  Harold Goldstein, 28yearold former president of the world's largest commodity options concern, pleaded guilty to mail fraud today.

title: Exxon Is Accused by State Of Breach of Sale Contract
description: New York State has charged the Exxon Company with direct breach of contract in limiting the amount of gaso line it sells to state and local government agencies.

title: Appeal Due on O.E.O. Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) The Justice Department said today that the Nixon Adminis tration would appeal a United States District Court ruling that Howard Phillips has illegally served as acting director of the Office of Economic Oppor tunity. The department said it would ask the United States Circuit Court of Appeals tomor row to stay the order of Judge Williami B, Jones, pendng the appeal.

title: Anker, as Expected, Is Named City School Chancellor
description: The Board of Education an nounced yesterday, as expected, the appointment of Irving An ker as the new Schcol Chan cellor and also filled three oth er key headquarters posts.

title: Anniversaries
description: BABY BLUE EYES. Thanks for a marvelous four, You can make book there will be more. Love Wife D.

title: 2 IN QUEENS SEIZED IN AIR TICKET FRAUD
description: A Queens couple described by the police as the kingpins of a $100,000 airlineticket forging operation were arrested early yesterday,

title: People in Sports: Ali In Training, Not Hiding
description: There's only one contract out for me and that belongs to Ken Norton for our fight [Sept. 10 in Los Angeles] and I've got one out for him, too, said the former heavy weight champion Muhammad Ali, scoffing at reports that his life, too, might be in danger. Those reports sur faced after the gangland style shooting last Friday of Ali's Cherry Hill, N. J., neigh bor, Major B. Coxson, a Camden Mayoral aspirant, who was under investigation by a Philadelphia grand jury.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York State has charged Exxon with a direct breach of contract in lim iting gasoline sales to state and local government agen cies. The charge had been made in a telegram to Exxon, and the state said there had been no reply. Exxon has contracts with the state to supply gasoline through Aug. 31. But on May 30 Exxon sent a letter to the state saying that as of June 1, because of shortages, the supply to agencies would be limited.

title: WATERGATE TERMED JUDGMENT OF GOD
description: FORT WORTH, June 14 The Rev. Billy Graham said to day that it was too early to make a moral judgment about the Watergate scandal, but suggested that it may be a sign of the beginning of the judgment of God on America.

title: French Jumper Is Successful in Ox Ridge Debut
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 14 When a horse is named L'Arc en Ciel, there's only one place he possibly could come from  France.

title: R. L. PLAUT, AIDED NEGRO SCHOLARSHIPS
description: Richard Laurance Plaut, who retired in 1968 as president of the National Scholarship Serv ice and Fund for Negro Stu dents, died Wednesday at his home, 975 Park Avenue. He was 70 years old.

title: Beame Says Milk Is Seeking Backing Of Major Landlords
description: Controller Abraham D Beame charged yesterday that Representative Herman Badil lo had held a secret meeting with major landlords in an effort to squeeze them into supporting him for Mayor.

title: Talk of Payola Inf luenced Metromedia
description: The Metromedia Corporation decided two years ago against going into the production of rhythm and blues records be cause, one of its executives says, it had heard so much unsavory talk about payola and organized crime in that segment of the pop music business.

title: The Classic Nixon Assistant Jeb Stuart Magruder
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Up the escalator and down, Jeb Stuart Magruder has seemed the classic young Nixon assistant.

title: Fish Salad Is the Entree for Cold Meal
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an as terisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Market Place: Investor Takes Specialist Role
description: Specialists are the ultimate stock traders.They do busi ness strictly on the floors of stock exchanges and stand at the center of the auction market, buying and selling for their own accounts to even out supply and demand.

title: Gas Spreads in Rome Areas
description: ROME, June 14 (UPI)  A cloud of strong gas leaked from a refinery tank last night and spread over six districts of Rome south of the Vatican, sending thousands of residents fleeing. The fire department said that unusually low atmos pheric pressure caused the cloud of bluish gas to spread. It identified the gas as butylmer captan, a nonpoisonous addi tive used to make gas leaks more easily detectable.

title: (Reprinted from yesterday's late editions); U. S. C. NINE WINS 4TH N.C.A.A. TITLE
description: OMAHA, June 13 (UPI) Southern California scored four early runs to defeat Arizona State, 4.3, tonight to win its fourth consecutive college world series title.

title: YIELDS INCREASE IN BOND MARKET
description: In their initial response to President Nixon's new price freeze, the credit markets yes terday showed they thought the latest step in the fight against inflation would be in effective. Interest rates rose and bond prices fell.

title: Army Investigating Allegation of Fraud By Its Recruiters
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) The Army Criminal Investi gations Division has been look ing into reports that recruiters have been altering personnel records to meet enlistment uotas now that the draft has ended.

title: Going Out Guide
description: RIVERS AND HARBORS The South Street Seaport Museum has its own theater group. Indeed, later this year it plans to have its own the ater, in a yellow brick build ing at Beekman and Water Streets.

title: Kissinger Stresses Importance of Brezhnev's Visit
description: WASHINGTON, June 14President Nixon and Leonid Brezhnev will probably agree on a formula for promoting progress in limiting strategic arms, but will not reach any specific armscontrol agree ment during the Soviet leader's visit to this country next week Henry A. Kissinger said today

title: Tho's Statement and Excerpts From His Replies
description: PARIS, June 14Following are the text of a statement delivered at a news confer ence today by Le Duc Tho, special North Vietnamese rep resentative, and excerpts from questions and answers at the conference. The statement was issued in English by the North Vietnamese, and the questions and answers were recorded and translated from the French by The Times.

title: B. S. Spector Weds Shelley R. Bergman
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., June 14 Miss Shelley Ruth Berg man, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rolf Bergman, and Barry Stewart Spector, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Spector of Yonkers and Long Beach Isle, N. J., were mar ried here this evening by Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal, as sisted by Cantor Yitzhak Lef kovitz, in the Oceanside Jew ish Center.

title: BILL SIGNED TO SPUR AID IN FLOODED AREA
description: ALBANY, June 14 (UPI) A special 1 per cent invest ment tax credit designed to stimulate new capital invest ment in areas devastated by the tropical storm Agnes last June has been signed into law by Governor Rockefeller.

title: F.T.C. Says Navajos Are Being Cheated
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Abusive and unfair credit and trade practices by trading posts have placed most Navajo Indians in a state of economic indenture, according to a report released today by the Los An geles field office of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: P.O.W. General Gets Post
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) Brig. Gen. John P. Flynn of the Air Force, the highest rank ing of the returned prisoners of war, was assigned today as deputy commandant of the Air War College, at the Air Univer sity, Maxwell Air Force Base, Alabama. General Flynn, 50 years old, was shot down over North Vietnam in 1967. He is on leave, at his home in Shall mer, Fla and will take over his new job Aug. 20, a Penta gon spokesman said.

title: Chess: Larsen's Ambitious Thrust Folds Under Twin Attacks
Metropolitan Briefs
description: Robert McKiernan, head of the Patrolman's Benev olent Association, accused Police Commissioner Donald Cawley yesterday of trying to destroy the morale of the department by instituting a screening process to weed out police officers who might use unnecessary violence or fire their weapons too hastily in the performance their duties. He's attempting to make his commanders act as psychiatrists, Mr. McKiernan said. Precinct com manders are not qualified to make recommendations on the stability of policemen.

title: Coalition Says Nixon's Budget Seeks Urban Vietnamization
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Leaders of a coalition Of or ganizations seeking Congres sional support to alter proposed Federal spending programs as cused President Nixon today of seeking a Vietnamization of America's urban problems in his 1974 budget proposals.

title: Frustration Marks Efforts by Nixon to Curb Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, June 14When Richard M. Nixon took office in early 1969, he inherit ed a boom in the economy with low unemployment but an in flation that seemed then of grave proportions6 per cent a year.

title: Bahamas'
description: LONDON, June 14 (Reuters) Queen Elizabeth II gave for mal approval today to legisla tion granting full independence to the Bahamas on July 10, Both the Government and the Opposition in the Caribbean group of islands had asked for independence.

title: Brezhnev Praises Nixon For Realistic Approach
description: MOSCOW, June 14Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Com miunist party leader, expressed his great respect today for President Nixon's realistic, constructive approach to So vietAmerican relations and said he was looking forward to their summit talks in Washing ton next week.

title: Curbs Placed on Appetite Suppressants
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 The Justice Department's Bu reau of Narcotics and Dan gerous Drugs placed sharp re strictions today on a group of widely used prescription diet pills to prevent their becoming a major national drug abuse problem.

title: Paper Rolls Back Price Rise
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) Last Saturday The Washing ton Post raised its newsstand price to 15 cents a copy. Today under an article reporting one President Nixon's action freez ing prices at June 18 levels The Post said: The 15cent newsstand price of The Wash ington Post that went into ef fect last Saturday is beings rolled back to 10 cents effec tive today. Coinoperated vend ing machines will be converted as soon as possible.

title: Connally, Unhappy in Job, To Quit Soon, Friends Say
description: WASHINGTON, June 14John B. Connally, who has been unable to reestablish in the second Nixon Administra tion the almost legendary clout that he exercised in the first, has decided to resign as parttime Presidential adviser soon, according to persons close to him at the White House and in Texas.

title: Filtrol Cuts Dividend; Anticipated Deal Cited
description: The Filtrol Corporation said yesterday that its directors had approved a reduction in the dividend paid on the com mon stock to 15 cents a share from 35 cents a share, effec tive with the quarterly divi dend payable in the third quarter.

title: The Clifford Plan (Cont.)
description: In an article on this page on June 4, Clark Clifford, former Secretary of De fense, put forth an ingenious proposal that President Nixon and Vice Presi dent Agnew resign their offices to per mit the formation of a government of national unity. This result could be accomplished, he suggested, through the mechanism provided by the 25th Amendment to the Constitution for fill ing a vacancy in the office of the Vice President. Thus, Mr. Agnew would re sign first, Mr. Nixon would appoint new Vice President subject to confir mation by both houses of Congress, then Mr. Nixon would resign anti the new Vice President would succeed him. Mr. Clifford further proposed that Mr. Nixon should select his successor from a list of three qualified individuals named by Congress.

title: Greens Rough for Open Golfers
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 14On the 10th green of the Oakmont Country Club to day, Jack Nicklaus carefully surveyed a 35foot putt.

title: SWEEPING CUTOFF OF FUNDS FOR WAR IS VOTED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The Senate voted overwhelm ingly today in favor of cutting off all funds for the bombing of Cambodia or for any other United States military action in Indochina unless specifically authorized hereafter by Con gress.

title: Some Industries Will Get Special Profits Scrutiny;Chemicals and Electrical Machinery Are Cited Among Seven or Nine SectorsRollbacks Possible
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 James W. McLane, chief of the Government's new special freeze group, identified elec trical machinery and chemicals today as two of seven or nine industries to get special at tention in a Federal profits sweep ordered by President Nixon in conjunction with the new price freeze announced yesterday.

title: CAMBODIA REBELS PRESS ON CAPITAL
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 14  Communist forces were pressing toward Phnom Penh from several directions today as heavy fighting con tinued through the day.

title: I.T.T. and Soviet Agree To Trade Technical Data
description: An agreement opening the way for an exchange of vast stores of technical knowledge between the Soviet Union and one of the West's giant multi national corporationsthe In ternational Telephone and Tele graph Corporationwas an nounced yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: So here now, right on schedule (what else?), we have the second volume of L. Rust Hills's Fussy Man trilogy, already known and loved by compulsive types the world over. It is called How to Retire at 41, this second volume is (the first, pub lished almost exactly a year ago, was How to Do Things Right, and the third, which I guess we can relax and expect a year from nowone trilogy in three years, which is neat and right and symmetrical  will he called How to Be Good); and it goes straight for the jugular of a problem that cer tainly has always bothered mejust as it should trou ble any right thinking work work ethicoriented neu rotic worth his or her salt  namely, that while the rat race and a job and pressure and gen erally having to live up to the expectations of people who are paying you to perform according to their standards is awful, drop ping out and doing nothing and feeling no outside pressure and generally having to live simultaneously up and down to the standards of a divided self, one tiny part of whom is telling you, For God's sake, take it easy; you're supposed to be relaxing, and the rest of whom is telling you to get busy and do something, even if it's only sharpening every pencil in the house or lining up the clothes hangers so that they all face one way (or the other), is far, far worse.

title: Bunker Hill Nationalization Will Cause $4Billion Loss
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 14 Libya's nationalization of the Bunker Hunt Oil Company of pallas, Tex., means the loss of more than $4billion to the con cern, a spokesman for the com pany said today.

title: Suit Attacks City's ChildCare System
description: New York City was accused in Federal Court here yesterday of running a system of child welfare services, with the help of the state, that discriminates against children on the basis of race and religion.

title: U.S. Seeks News of Sloop Ordered Into Cuban Port
description: MIAMI, June 14 (UPI)The State Department has asked the Swiss Embassy in Havana to find out why a Florida family on a roundtheworld cruise was ordered into port in Cuba after encountering a Cuban patrol boat.

title: A Proper Forum
description: The testimony of Jeb Stuart Magruder, the deputy manager of President Nixon's reelection campaign, sets forth an appalling picture of chicanery and deceit at the highest levels of the Federal Government. It also brings into focus the difficult questions concerning civil liberties and criminal law which arise when serious charges of illegality are made in any forum other than a courtroom.

title: A U.S. ASSURANCE GIVEN AUSTRALIA
description: CANBERRA, Australia, June 14Marshall Green, the new American Ambassador here, strongly suggested today that Washington was willing to take a more flexible approach toward its relations with Au stralia. Those relations have been troubled almost since the moment the present Labor Government assumed power in Australia last December.

title: Italy Tops England in Soccer
description: TURIN, Italy, June 14 (UPI) Goals by Pietro Anastasi and Fabio Capeloo in the 38th and 52d minutes gave Italy a 20 victory over England tonight in an exhibition soccer match.

title: A 3d Ave Rail Terminal Foreseen by U.S. Official
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  A high Federal official said today that a proposed $341million railroad and subway terminal for New York City likely Would be built with Federal aid. It would be below Third Avenue between 48th and 53d Streets.

title: SWEEPING CUTOFF OF FUNDS FOR WAR IS VOTED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The Senate voted overwhelm ingly today in favor of cutting off all funds for the bombing of Cambodia or for any other United States military action in Indochina unless specifically authorized hereafter by Con gress.

title: Study Will Explore State's Doctor Shortage
description: An intensive study of the doctor shortage in the state will be undertaken starting this summer by state education and health officials and private medicalschool leaders.

title: LEBANESE PREMIER RESIGNS HIS OFFICE

title: List of Officials Mentioned by Magruder
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Roles in relation to the Watergate burglary and the subsequent coverup were at tributed to the following high White House and Nixon cam paign officials today by Jeb Stuart Magruder, deputy cam paign director:

title: Senate Vote Cancels Accord For a U.S. Base in Azores
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)The Senate voted yester day to cancel a United States Executive agreement with por tugal allowing American use of a military base in the Azores unless the accord is submitted to the Senate as a treaty.

description: Overriding Mayor Lindsay's veto, the City Council voted 34 to 2 yesterday to repeal the local rentcontrol law's contro versial maximumbaserent for mula, which permits rent in creases of up to 7.5 per cent a year in many controlled apartments here.

title: Red Smith
description: The other heavyweight from Louisville, the one who sings hymns and knocks people out, ornaments the New York scene today because Jose Luis Garcia walked into a fist and Jerry Quarry got the flu. Jimmy Ellis, substi tuting for Quarry, is working in Madison Square Garden Monday night against Earnie Shavers, a substitute for Garcia. Ellis, who used to be champion of the World Boxing Association's world, has whipped every heavy weight he ever met who wasn't named Joe Frazier or Muhammad Ali. Shavers, who used to be Sports the star of a stable owned and operated by Dean Chance, has scored 43 knockouts of winning 44 of 46 bouts without meeting The Times anybody who could fight. Dean Chance, who used to be the best pitcher in baseball, now lives on a farm at Jeromesville, Ohio, and has investments in jellies. There, that should tie up the loose ends.

title: Federal Reserve Reports Member Banks'
description: Member bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve Sys tem, which increased its Inter est rate to a 50year high of 6 per cent last Monday, in creased moderately in the week ended June 13, according to data released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Prices Cut on Key Items As Nixon Freeze Begins
description: Prices of steel, copper, rub ber tires and other major prod ucts were cut back yesterday as an immediate result of Pres ident Nixon's 60day freeze based on prices in the June 18 period.

title: Disappointment Is Expressed in Europe
description: PARIS, June 14Disappoint ment over President Nixon's antiinflation measures brought the dollar still lower today in European foreign exchange centers.

title: Senator Defends Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) Senator Carl T. Curtis, Re publican of Nebraska, charged today that publicityseeking politicians were out to get Nixon in their pursuit of the Watergate scandal. He said the President was totally inno cent of any wrongdoing in the case.

title: Wine Industry Is Growing
description: SAN FRANCISCO (UPI)Grape production and crush in California are expected to double in this decade if the state is to hold the 75 per cent share of the domestic wine mar ket it now has.

title: West German Police Clear NATO Base of Protesters
description: NORDHORN, West Germany, June 14 (Reuter)About 1,000 policemen with several water cannons drove demonstrators today from a NATO bombing range that they had been oc cupying for two days as protest against the noise of bombing practice.

title: RAYMOND M. LAHR, 58, POLITICAL REPORTER
description: BALTIMORE, June 14 (UPI) Raymond M. Lahr, United Press International political reporter, died today at Johns Hopkins Hospital after suffer ing a heart attack. He was 58 years old.

title: Football Transactions
description: BRITISH COLUMBIASigned Clyde LeSaron, Santa Clara quarterback; Tom Lorenz, Towe State tight end, and Eugene Teague, San Jose State running back.

title: A.E.C. MOVES HINT SAFETY CONCERN
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The Atomic Energy Commis sion made two seemingly un related moves today that, taken together, appear to serve notice on environmental groups that the agency will be more re sponsive to complaints of in sensitivity to atomic hazards.

title: Study of New York Food Prices Gives Buyers a Guide on Ceiling
Eugene McCarthy's Father
description: WILLMAR, Minn., June 14 (UPI)Michael J. McCarthy, father of former Senator Eu gene J. McCarthy, died Tuesday at a nursing home where he had been a patient for five years. He was 97 years old, re tired as a cattle buyer in North and South Dakota and owned a farm in Meeker County before entering the nursing home. Sur viving also are another son, Dr. Austin McCarthy, and two daughters, Mrs. Mildred Ryer and Mrs. Marian Enright.

title: PBW in Appeal on Institutional Measure
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The PBW Stock Exchange urged Congress today to write a fiveyear protection clause into any legislation barring institutional membership on national secu rities exchanges.

title: Meany Says Freeze Reflects Failure
description: George Meany, president the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Indus trial Organizations yesterday assailed the Nixon Administra tion's 60day price freeze as a failure of policy and said that prices had been frozen at the highest level in more than two decades.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS CHARGE COVERUP
description: State Democratic leaders contended yesterday that At torney General Louis J. Lefko witz's investigation into the possibility of illicit campaign practices by Republicans had the makings of a Watergate coverup scandal for New York.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)A House committee that investigated drug use by athletes has recommended that the National Football League use a spotcheck urin analysis to determine whether players use narcotics. The committee also recommended that tough penalties be established for drug usefines, suspension or barring for life. Representative Harley O. Staggers, Democrat of West Virginia and chairman of the House Commerce Commit tee, said the committee's yearlong study showed drug use exists, in varying degrees, in all sports and levels competitions with few exceptions. Ed Garvey, director the Players Association, called the urinalysis proposal an absolute outrage.

title: State Study Urges Curb On Zoning
description: The state was urged yes terday to set up zoning standards that would, in ef fect, make it impossible for suburban and rural commu nities to erect zoning barriers against members of minority groups trying to migrate from cities.

title: Pension Swindle
description: Robert Pratt is the victim of a fraud for which there isinexcusablyno legal redress. For 47 years Mr. Pratt worked for an upstate company manufacturing conveyor equipment. Last year, as his 65th birthday approached, he looked forward to retiring with an employerfinanced pension of $94 a month added to the $359 to which and his wife would be entitled under Social Security.

title: Westminster Bank Rate Cut
description: LONDON, June 14 (Reuters) The National Westminster Bank, Ltd., said today it had cut its base rate to 8 per cent from 8.5 per cent effective tomorrow. The sevenday de posit rate was cut to 6.25 per cent from 6.75 per cent.

title: Roundup: Oriole Rebirth Gives Royals the Blues
description: The Baltimore Orioles, once the scourge of the American League, have fall en upon desperate times. As ot last weekend, the once mighty sluggers of Earl Weaver were at the bottom of the league in team bat ting with a meager.231 mark,

title: Excerpts From Kissinger's News Briefing on Brezhnev's Visit and Indochina
description: Following are excerpts from a news briefing by Henry A. Kissinger in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

title: Brezhnev Praises Nixon For Realistic Approach
description: MOSCOW, June 14Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Com munist party leader, expressed his great respect today for President Nixon's realistic, constructive approach to So vietAmerican relations and said he was looking forward to their summit talks in Washing ton next week.

title: Screen: 'The Last of Sheila' Arrives at the Sutton:Murder Mystery Puts Fun Into Format The Cast Turns Search for' Killer Into a Cruise Game
description: "The Last of Sheila," directed by Herbert Ross from an original screenplay by Stephen Sondheim and Anthony Perkins, is an old-fashioned murder mystery that has been dressed up fit to kill and set aboard a fine, white-hulled, teak-decked Mediterranean yacht of the sort that souls have been sold to obtain.The characters are Hollywood types who, by this time, must be as familiar to any woman who has ever spent a minute under a hair dryer as they are to people who read The Hollywood Reporter: the sadistic producer, the down-and-out director, the flesh-peddler (talent agent), the sex symbol, the ambitious writer, and so on. They are beautiful but edgy people, the kind who greet good jokes with a rating ("That's beautiful") rather than laughter. For these people even casual conversation can be a form of competition. The wisecrack is the weapon.For as long as it runs, "The Last of Sheila" is also a good deal of fun, like one of those tricky, after-dinner party games that always seem dreary in advance but then somehow turn out to be more amusing than one had any right to expect.The movie is, quite literally, a game, one that has been set up by the producer (James Coburn) who, on the first anniversary of his wife's mysterious hit-and-run death, invites six friends for a week's cruise off the coast of southern France. Any one of the guests, it turns out (as it must in this sort of thing), could have had a motive for doing in Sheila, which is the name of the producer's wife as well as of the yacht.The format of the cruise is as strict as that of a television quiz show. Each guest has been given a slip of paper with a guilty secret written on it, a secret, it further turns out (as it must) that actually applies to one of the guests, though not the one who holds the paper. One is an alcoholic, one a child molester, one a homosexual, etc. They are, in short, just folks, and by the end of the week the host plans not only to have exposed each of them, but also to have his murderer.I'm not a great after-dinner game person and I must admit that at various points in "The Last of Sheila" my mind wandered from the clues, even though it's difficult to avoid noticing them. They are only slightly less inconspicuous than would be snowshoes around a swimming pool.Since I'm told that Sondheim and Perkins are serious game people, I assume that the plot, if run backward, would make sense. More important to me was the generally festive air in which all this genteel mayhem takes place, as well as the rather charming, Agatha Christie manners that are observed. As plot points are explained, people get themselves drinks from the bar. If someone is murdered, the pall of gloom lasts for a maximum of five minutes.No one takes himself seriously and the characters are a colorful though not a very nice lot. Beautiful people, after all, haven't got time to be nice.Most colorful is Dyan Cannon who plays the talent agent for all that the wisecracks are worth ("My mouth is so dry they could shoot 'Lawrence of Arabia' in it" or "I hate my luggage more than life itself"). It's not wit, but it's funny, and she gives a very good, very comic performance.The others are also good, especially Richard Benjamin and Joan Hackett (as the writer and his wife) and James Mason (as the failing director), but the essential bitchery that makes the film work is provided by Miss Cannon and by all of the Sondheim-Perkins inside referencesto things like pool maintenance, Joyce Haber and Hammer Films  which really are not too inside for us ordinary people to get.Perhaps the best thing about "The Last of Sheila," which opened yesterday at the Sutton, is that it never tries to convince us that its characters are not having fun. They enjoy having money, or having access to it. It makes murder, as well as life, more interesting.

title: Tho Says Accord Can Lead to Peace
description: PARIS, June 14Le Duc Tho today hailed the new Vietnam agreement he and Henry A. Kissinger had negotiated as victory of reason and said that, if strictly observed, it would insure a lasting peace.

title: ERNEST GLUECK
description: Ernest Glueck, an insurance broker, died yesterday at Uni versity Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Rock ville Centre, L.I.

title: MRS. HERBERT FRIED
description: Mrs. Ruth Weiss Fried, who retired in 1972 after serving 50 years in the classified advertis ing department of The New York Times, died yesterday at Caledonian Hospital, Brooklyn. She was 68 years old and lived at 5801 14th Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: The Pop Life
description: A plus factor in Lindsay Anderson's new film, Oh Lucky Man!, is Alan Price, who is both heard and seen throughout either comment ing on the action or singing about it with some neat rock n roll lyrics.

title: Little LastMinute Fighting Is Reported in Vietnam as New Truce Goes Into Effect
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, June 15The second Viet nam ceasefire went into effect as scheduled at noon today, amid reports from the battle field that there had been less lastminute fighting than ex pected.

title: Patrick F. Fahy, Authority On Woolens and Worsteds
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla., June 14Patrick F. Fahy, an author ity on the woolens and worsteds market, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 80 years old and had lived for Imany years in Westport, Conn., before moving here in 1964.

title: VOIDING OF PRIMARY ASKED BY WEINSTEIN
description: Federal Judge Jack B, Wein stein, who was apparently de feated by Jacob D. Fuchsberg in the Democratic primary for chief judge of the state, yes terday asked the State Supreme Court in Albany to set aside the election results and order a new primary.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating Outlook
description: AREA ABlues from 6 to 12 pounds are running on the Ridge off Surf City, N. J., and chummers from as far as Bridle have been hauling them in for the last week. Fluke (2 to 4 pounds) are in good supply in Barnegat Inlet and Beach Haven Inlet for fishermen using squid or spearing. Offshore at Seaside Park, N. J., blues from 7 to 12 pounds have been re sponding to bunker and mackerel. A variety of fish, including whiting, fluke and sea bass, have been caught at The Wrecks off Point Pleas ant.

title: U.S. Aide Asks 50c PATH Fare Be Canceled as Freeze Violation
description: WASHINGTON, June 14A high Federal transportation official called today for can cellation of a 20cent fare in crease on PATH, the Port Au thority's commuter railroad, to conform to President Nixon's 60day price freeze.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION

title: News Summary and Index
Soviet Trade Gamble
description: With only a few days to go before Leonid I. Brezhnev is scheduled to arrive in this country, vigorous efforts are being made to set the stage for his visit with predic tions of important agreements to be reached between him and President Nixon. Perhaps the most spectacular to date is Moscow's announcement of a tentative agree ment of what would be, if realized, the largest commer cial transaction ever concluded between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Dance: Passionate Placidity of Allegro Brillante
description: Speed is of the moment. There are certain ballets in the New York City Ballet reperatory where sheer speed carries everything. There is a guts and a zest. It is no secret that these dancers move very fastat times they even move faster than an orchestra can play. And also, and this can be no secret either, at times their legs move faster than their arms with an effect that is more stylistic than stylish.

title: Off Off Broadway Shows
description: It's advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices before going to the show. Most if not all theaters accept Theater Development Fund vouchers.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Paramus employes, who shut down garbage collection and other services for one day in a wildcat strike, returned to work after further contract talks were scheduled for next week with a mediator of the State Public Employes Relations Commission. According to Andrew Trause, direc tor of public employes for Teamsters Local 97, the strike was called over the issues of pay raises, seniority, arbitra tion and posting of new jobs.

title: Mess Rest While Awaiting Padres and P.O.W. Guests
description: The New York Mets rested their twogame winning streak yesterday while await ing the majorleague trading deadline, the San Diego Padres and a guest group of 200 former prisoners of war all due to arrive today.

title: Rickover Promotion Gains
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) A bill to promote Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, retired to the grade of full admiral cleared the House Armed Serv ices Committee today, and backers predicted certain ap proval by the House.

title: Hall Says Watergate Shows Need for Campaign Change
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., June 14Leonard W. Hall, a former chairman of the Republican Na tional Committee, said tonight that some lessons had been learned from the Watergate sit uation, which he described as this unfortunate chapter in American politics.

title: City's Massage Parlor Law Ruled Invalid as Too Sweeping
description: A State Supreme justice de clared unconstitutional yester day a twomonthold city law that officials had hoped would eliminate places of prostitu tion advertised as massage parlors.

title: FAMILY LIVING COST IS PUT AT $11,800
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)It requires nearly $11, 800 a year for a city family of a year short of what is needed mediate standard of living, Government statistics showed today.

title: NATIONAL AIRLINES HAS A 6HOUR STRIKE
description: MIAMI, June 14 (AP)Na tional Airlines reached a con tract agreement with its clerks and booking agents early today, ending a sixhour strike that caused little disruption to the airline's operations.

title: JOE E. MARKS DIES; CHARACTER ACTOR
description: Joe E. Marks, a comedian and character actor, died, ap parently of complications grow ing out of pneumonia, at Poly clinic Hospital yesterday. He would have been 82 years old today.

title: EIGUERES TELLS OF VERCO PLEDGE
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 14 (AP)PreSident Jose Fi gueres says Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, has giv en him a personal promise to cooperate with Costa Rican courts considering his extradi tion to the United States.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The overzealousness of a cadre of paranoids in the Administration has been duplicated and is being duplicated again.

title: Bronx Zoo Adds Section for South American Fauna
description: An openair South Ameri can exhibit area, believed to be the first of its kind in the nation, will open today at the Bronx Zoo.

title: Connally, Unhappy in Job, To Quit Soon, Friends Say
description: WASHINGTON, June 14John B. Connally, who has been unable 14establish in the second Nixon Administra tion the almost legendary clout that he exercised in the first, has decided to resign as parttime Presidential adviser soon, according to persons close to him at the White House and in Texas.

title: A Detective Says Turner Sought to Set Up Gewertz
description: TRENTON, June 14A Glou cester County captain of detec tives testified today that State Senator James M. Turner, a Republican, had offered to set up Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz, a Democrat, for a hi jacking arrest if consideration would be given to a pending stolenproperty case the Sena tor wanted fixed.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 12%
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales for the last week were an estimated $1.001bil lion, up 14 per cent from the yearearlier $881million, Total retail store sales were about 9.860billion, up 12 per cent [rpm last year's $8.832billion.

title: House Unit Approves Newsman Shield
description: WASHINGTON, June 14A legislative authorization for newsmen to refuse to reveal professionally received infor nation was given preliminary Congressional approval for the first time today.

title: SANDY DE REFLER
description: Sandy De Refler, a music teacher in the Bethpage, L.I., school, and director of the schools orchestra, died follow ing heart surgery at Mount Sinai Hospital on Wednesday. He was 47 years old and lived at 77 Park Avenue and in Hampton Bays, L.I.

title: Bridge: Scholarship Fund Is Aided By a Check at Tournament
description: Both national bridge or ganizations, the American Contract Bridge League and the American Bridge Associa tion, raise considerable sums of money each year for chari table purposes.

title: Youth, 17,Accused of Trying To Steal Dog From Car Lot
description: A 17yearold Bronx youth was arrested yesterday after he allegedly asked a passerby wearing Bermuda shorts to help him get a Siberian huskyvalued at $250out of a fenced car lot at 1221 Jerome Avenue.

title: 32 Stranded on Cable Car Rescued in New Mexico
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 14 (AP)Thirtytwo sightseers who spent nearly 24 hours aboard a cable car that was stranded 650 feet above the western side of the Sandia Mountains were rescued late today.

title: Black Child's Identity: A Crusade by Private School Parents
description: Black parents... white administrations... selective admissions procedures... student and faculty popula tions that are gradually at taining ethnic pluralism but are still predominantly Cau casian. The potential for con flictor accommodation and innovationis ripe in the New York private schools.

title: ROSALYN SCHONBERGJ DANCE CRITIC, DEAD
description: Mrs. Rosalyn Krokover Schonberg, dancer and dance critic, died yesterday of cancer at the Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport. Her age was 60.

title: U.S. Revises Total of San Clemente Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) Federal officials updated to day the list of improvements that had been made at Presi dent Nixon's San Clemente estate, at Secret Service re quest, increasing to $460,312 the estimate of Government funds spent there to increase Presidential security. The list was compiled by the General Services Administration at the request of the White House, and made public by the agency and Presidential aides. It rep resented a full accounting of federally financed work on Mr. Nixon's oceanside California property, officials said.

title: COURT FINDS S.C.I. IS ILLEGAL PANEL
description: ALBANY, June 14A State Supreme Court justice today declared unconstitutional the Temporary State Commission of Investigation on the ground that it had become permanent, contrary to the law that created it in 1958.

title: Brezhnev, Who Ought to Know, Explains Politburo
description: MOSCOW, June 14Leonid I. Brezhnev, in his threeand ahalfhour session with American newsmen today, emerged as a quietspoken, relaxed and garrulous man who preferred to discuss gen eralities and sought to avoid specific issues in SovietAmer ican relations.

That Mysterious Faucet
description: Few items of life seem as arcane and unsusceptible to remedy as a leaking faucet or a faulty light switch when you have no knowledge of their workings.

title: 18 Hurt in Bus Crash
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., June 14 (AP) At least 18 persons, most of them scientists attend ing a seminar at the University of Missouri, were injured when a bus overturned at a busy in tersection yesterday.

description: Paul J. Curran, who took office last week as United States Attorney for the South ern Districtof New York, yes terday appointed Thomas D. Edwards as chief of his office's criminal division. Mr. Edwards, 42 years old, is a 1958 magna cum laude graduate of Harvard Law School. He has been in private practice here,

title: Carrier Bunker Hill Sold
description: SAN DIEGO, June 14 (AP)The carrier Bunker Hill, which survived Japanese Kamikaze attacks in World War II, was sold this week to the Zidell Corporation of Portland, Ore., for a high bid of $316:999 and will be torn apart for scrap. A group made up of about 2,000 former crewmen failed to have the aircraft carrier preserved as a Navy museum.

description: PORTLAND, Ore., June 14At a time when other major Protestant denominations in the United States are retrenching the Southern Baptist Conven. Lion was characterized at its 116th annual session that ended here tonight as being on tilt edge of an era of expansion

description: MARGATE CITY, June 14Lucy, the 90ton, wood and tin elephant that has been identified with this resort com munity for more than nine decades and has been threatened with demolishment on several occasions, is being rescued by her followers once again.

title: YUGOSLAV STUDENT JAILED OVER MOVIE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 14A Yugoslav student of film producing was sentenced today to two years in prison on con viction of hostile propaganda involving a film never shown publicly.

title: Hunt Reported to Have Blackmailed White House
description: WASHINGTON, June 14E. Howard Hunt Jr., the Water gate conspirator, effectively blackmailed the White House by threatening to disclose the operations of high Administra tion officials in secret illegal activities unless he received large sums of money and a guarantee of executive clem ency, The Washington Post said in its Friday editions.

title: Flag Day Reunion Draws Veterans of War Convoy
description: For a while on Flag Day yesterday, the crew members of World War II's Convoy N.Y. 119 relived their 31 days aboard the first smallcraft convoy of the war.

Goodman, chairman of May, said at the company's annual meeting yes terday in St. Louis.

title: Body of Queens Boy Found
description: PORT WASHINTON, L. I., June 14 (UPI)The body of 10yearold Queens boy who disappeared last Sunday was found today in Hempstead Har bor off Bar Beach here. The Nassau County Police said the boy Clay Winfree of 13340 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, was an apparent drowing vic tim. They said he was last seen in the water while swimming with an 11yearold friend and the friend's mother.

title: Missile Kill Record Claimed
description: CULVER CITY, Calif., June 14 (UPI)The Hughes Aircraft Company claimed a distance record yesterday for a kill by an airtoair missile, 126 miles. The company said the record had been set by a Phoenix mis sile fired by an F14 fighter plane from Point Mugu, Calif., over the Navy's Pacific missile test range at a target drone. The missile passed so close to the drone, 126 miles away, that in real combat the target would have been destroyed by the missile's warhead, Hughes said.

title: Arab Oil Chiefs to Meet
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 19 (UPI)Oil ministers of the or. ganization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet ;in Damascus June 23 to discuss several matters, the Syrian Arab News Agency said today. The agency said the meeting would be attended by represent atives from Egypt, Syria, Libya, Kuwait, Qatar, Abu Dhabi, Bahrain, Iraq and Algeria.

title: STOCKS SEESAW TO CLOSE LOWER
description: President Nixon's new eco nomic program did little to stimulate the stock market yesterday as shares finished sharply lower in slower trad ing.

title: Advertising: Dyed Blond and a Bear Freshening Brewer's Image
description: In advertising there is often a tremendous amount of effort expended between concept and execution, and agencies spare no expense to make a creative man's dream come true.

title: Notes on People
description: Looking weary as he stood in United States Dis trict Court in Miami, Meyer Lansky, the reputed under world financier, was sen tenced to a prison term of a year and a day for refusing to appear before a Federal. grand jury in 1971. Lansky was freed by the court pending an appeal of the sentence after he posted a $250,000 bail bond and a personal note for $400,000, The 70yearold Lansky, who underwent openheart surgery in March, faces one trial on charges of tax eva sion in Miami next month, and one in Nevada in Sep tember on charges related to avoiding tax payments on the profits at a Las Vegas casino.

title: Kissinger Gives Hint Of Accord With Tho On Cambodian War
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 Henry A. Kissinger hinted broadly today that the United States had received some kind of assurances from North Viet nam in Paris that could provide the basis for an end to the fighting in Cambodia.

title: BARCLAY M. M'FADDEN
description: MEMPHIS, June 13Barclay M. McFadden, president of Valmac Industries, a chicken processing company, died, ap parently of a heart attack, Monday. He was 48 years old.

title: Nation's Shoppers, Cool to Nixon's Freeze of Peak Prices, Prefer a Rollback
description: There was no dancing in the aisles of the nation's supermarkets yesterday over President Nixon's new 60day price freeze, although most consumers who were ques tioned welcomed any action that offered hope of a breath er from inexorably rising prices.

title: Byrne Assails Right Wing; Sandman Asks Party Unity
description: TRENTON, June 14  The tone of New Jersey's campaign for Governor was struck here today when Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate, charged that the Republican nominee, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., em bodied the politics of regres sion that was driving the Re publican party deeper into one of the darkest periods of its history.

title: The TalkShow Circuit
description: GREENSBORO, N. C.One thing the traveler on the talkshow circuit quickly learns these days is that there still is plenty of interesteven a consuming interestin the Watergate story. Some people may be calling the networks to complain that Sam Ervin vs. Ed Gurney is not as thrilling on the tube as John's Other Wife or as funny as The Dating Game"; but out there in radioandtelevision land, the house wives and the night workers and any one else with a telephone handy seem to be burning with curiosity about one central point: Did the President know?

title: Down to the Level of Business
description: LONDONThe United States busi ness is also the world's business. This is one of the present facts of life, though it is a nuisance both for United States citizens and for the 94 per cent of the planet's population who are aliens.

title: Williams Runs 100 in 9.4 To Pace A.A.U. Qualifiers
The Mighty Sparrow Flies at Calypso Spectacular
description: Calypso, it appears, is also taking a beating from the Great American Pop Music Machine. At the Calypso Spectacular at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, the Mighty Sparrow, a major name in the field, had a fully armed soul music band shouting behind him. Spar row's flight, incidentally, was short, erratic and of unre lieved vulgarity. Calypso Rose, one of the few female calypsonians, likewise belted and pushed around her ma terial, and again the en tendres were doubling.

title: MRS. DALE DEWITT
description: LUTHERVILLE, Md., June 14 Mrs. Margaret Lane De Witt, who retired in 1965 as assistant to the First Deputy Commis sioner of the New York City Department of Welfare, died in a rest home here today. She, was in her 70's and lived in Southampton, L. I.

title: A Bit of Vieille France in a Catskill Restaurant
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judg ment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Navy Force Ready To Renew Clearing Of Vietnam Mines
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) Seventeen ships in a naval minesweeping force began oper ations today to make North Vietnamese waters safe for shipping.

title: Beame and Badillo Disagree Sharply in First Debate
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame and Representative Herman Badillo, in the first facetoface debate of their runoff cam paign for the Democratic mayoral nomination, sharply dis agreed on more flexible com munity budgets, housing policy and their past performance in office.

title: Cambodian Asserts Hanoi Vows to Pull Out Troops
description: PARIS, June 14Brig. Gen. Lon Non, brother of President Lon Nol of Cambodia, said today that the United States had obtained an assurance from Hanoi that North Vietnamese troops would be withdrawn rather rapidly from his country.

title: Questions and Answers on the Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)Following are some key questions and answers about the new price freeze announced by President Nix on in a television and radio broadcast last night:

title: A's Glitter in 30 Victory Over Yankees
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 14Oakland's Fort Knox gold uni forms, with some help from Dave Hamilton's nifty pitching and consecutivepitch home runs by Sal Bando and Reggie Jackson, defeated the Yankees, 30, tonight and knocked them from first place to third in the Eastern Division.

title: ALVIN D. ETLER, 60, COMPOSER, OBOIST
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 14Alvin D. Etler, American composer and oboist whose concertos have been performed by most symphony orchestras and chamber music groups, died yesterday at the Cooley Dickinson Hospital. His age was 60, and he lived here.

title: Booksellers End Convention, Looking Ahead to Fall
description: LOS ANGELES, June 13Wilt Chamberlain discussed the satisfactions of author ship. Another new writer, Linda Lovelace, sighed, I never knew publishing was so involved, ad Jacqueline Susann criticized her critics, serene in the knowledge that her latest novel had already earned more than $1.5mil lion.

title: HOUSE UNIT BEARS SURVIVORS'
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Dorise W. Willis, one of two known survivors of the Browns ville incident of 1906 when he and 166 fellow black soldiers were wrongly discharged with out honor, went to Capitol Hill today to appear at a hearing on compensation for the soldiers and their survivors.

title: Mitchell Called  Anxious to Tell His Story to Exonerate Himself
description: Lawyers for John N. Mitchell said yesterday that the former Attorney General was eager to tell his story and exonerate himself, but they doubted whether he would have any im mediate comment on Senate testimony directly linking him with the Watergate scandal.

title: Dollar Eases Following Nixon Speech; Commodity Dealers Are in Quandary
FUTURES PRICES LOWER AT CLOSE
description: Wildly swinging prices in most commodity futures indi cated traders were somewhat confused yesterday after Pres ident Nixon's speech on price controls Wednesday night.

title: Bus Crash Injures 42
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 14 (UPI)A bus carrying 60 chil dren to summer camp ran into a ditch yesterday, injuring at least 42 passengers, two of them seriously, authorities re ported.

title: Pickets at Korvette Protest
description: Hundreds of members of trade unions affiliated with the New York City Central Labor Council demonstrated outside Korvette's department store at Herald Square late yesterday to protest the store's sale of prod ucts of the Farah Manufactur ing Company.

title: Kissinger Gives Hint Of Accord With Tho On Cambodian War
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Henry A. Kissinger hinted broadly today that the United States had received some kind of assurances from North Viet nam in Paris that could provide the basis for an end to the fighting in Cambodia.

title: DR. PAVEL LUKYANENKO
description: MOSCOW, June 14 (Reuters) Dr. Pavel Lukyanenko, So viet scientist who developed varieties of winter wheat, died yesterday, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported. He was 72 years old.

title: House, Matching Nixon Request, Votes to Double Funds for Arts
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The House of Representatives, after three hours of spirited ar gument about fiscal responsi bility and national priorities, today passed a bill that would nearly double the present au thorization of Federal money for the arts and humanities in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: Justice Roberts Reveals Attempt to Influence Him
description: State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts yesterday disqualified himself from sen tencing a major Brooklyn gambler because of an alleged attempt to corruptly influence my decision on sentence in this matter.

title: U.S. PILOT REPORTED DOWNED OVER LAOS
description: HONG KONG, June 14 (UPI) An American helicopter pilot was shot down over Laos and captured last month by Com munist forces, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency reported today.

title: Morris County Prisoners Tell What's Right and Wrong in Jail
description: MORRISTOWN, June 14 The Morris County jail was opened today to reporters, who heared a variety of complaints and some praise about condi tions inside from inmates.

title: Magruder Calls O'Brien a Key Target
description: WASHINGTON, June 14An effort to discredit former Democratic chairman Law rence F. O'Brien emerged pub licly today for the first time as a major objective of the breakin and espionage at the Democratic National headquar ters at the Watergate complex.

title: Cathy Baby Is the Fourth Of 5 Velasquez Winners
description: Jorge Velasquez rode five winners at Belmont Park yes terday, including Cathy Baby, upset winner of the 1 1/16 mile turf feature for older fillies and mares. Cathy Baby paid $32.80 for $2 to win after being timed in 1:41 1/5 and provided a birthday present for her owner.

title: James W. Nichols, Founder Of Mobile Home Company
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., June 14James W. Nichols, founder of Hallmark Group Companies, Inc., Dallasbased developer and manager of luxury mobile home parks, died Tuesday at his home here, apparently of a heart attack. He was 45 years old.

description: State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts yesterday disqualified himself from sen tencing a major Brooklyn gambler because of an alleged attempt to corruptly influence my decision on sentence in this matter.

title: The Screen
description: Red Psalm, which opened yesterday at the First Ave nue Screening Room, was shown at the 10th New York Film Festival. The following excerpt is from Roger Green spun's review, which ap peared Oct. 2, 1972, in The New York Times.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 7.1 %
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17 billion tonmiles, 7.1 per cent above the corresponding week last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc.,. reported in tercity truck tonnage was 8.7 per cent above last year.
