description: Winning numbers drawn on June 14 were:

title: Frick Plans Garden on Widener Site
description: The Frick Collection plans to create a temporary 100 footsquare garden and ter race on East 70th Street to be replaced in 10 to 20 years by a new wing.

title: Excerpts From the Debate Between Rivals in the Democratic Mayoral Runoff
description: Following are excerpts from the de bate between Representative Herman Badillo and Controller Abraham D. Beanie at The New York Times on Tuesday. Questions were asked by Times editors and reporters.

title: State Bank Chief Proposes Interstate Branch Banking
description: The New York State Superin tendent of Banks proposed yes terday that banks be permitted to establish branches in major moneymarket cities in other states on a reciprocal basis.

title: Player's 67 Leads U S. Open by 3 Shots
New Chancellor
description: The appointment of Irving Anker as Chancellor of the city schools may at first glance seem merely compromise to avoid another extended search for nationally known candidate. Dr. Anker is, after all, not only available but has actually been running the schoolsboth before Dr. Harvey B. Scribner came to New York and again currently in the wake of the conflict between the Board of Education and Dr. Scribner. Moreover, as a veteran of 39 years, Dr. Anker could not be challenged by the ranks of New York Firsters within the system.

title: Downstate Farmer Fighting Ruling Opening Up Migrant Labor Camps
description: SWEDESBORO, June 14 Sebastian A. (Benny Sorbello standing at the edge of one of the freshly plowed fields in the 550 acres he farms near here with his brother Joseph, said angrily that he and other New Jersey farmers could no longer put up with a 1971 New Jersey Supreme Court ruling permitting access to their migrant labor camps.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: JERSEY CITY, June 14  The coaching staff of the New York Giants already has opened offices in Roosevelt Stadium and the National Football League team will work out there this fall. This return of bigtime sports has started the adrenalin pumping among oldtimers here.

title: Burmese Rebels Said to Hold 2 Russians as Hostages
description: RANGOON, Burma, June 14 (AP)  Burma's intelligence chief today said rebel tribes men, with help from Chinese Nationalist spies, had kid napped two Russian doctors in remote northeast Burma and were holding them as hostages for the release of a rebel lead er.

title: U.S. BARS DEMAND BY ARABS ON TALK
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 14The United States to day emphatically rejected an Arab demand that Israel with draw to the borders that ex isted before the sixday war in 1967 as a precondition to any negotiations between the two sides to the Middle East dis pute.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Young Refuses to Testify Before a Grand Jury Hearing on West Coast BreakIn
description: LOS ANGELES, June 14David Young, a former member of the White House plumb ers unit assigned to stop se curity leaks, refused to testif today before a Los Angel( County grand jury investigat ing the breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychi atrist.

title: $6Million in Drugs Seized in 3 Raids; Ten Are Arrested
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) United States Custom officers made three major drug seizures totaling $6.3million in Califor nia, Florida and New England in a 24hour period, the Cus toms Bureau reported today.

title: No NixonBrezhnev Deals, Rogers Assures NATO
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 14  Secretary of State William P. Rogers promised the Atlantic allies today that Presi dent Nixon would make no de cisions or agreements with Leo nid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, that would be detrimental to the in terests of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Pennsy Settles Claims of Subsidiaries
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP)The Penn Central Com pany, parent Company of the Penn Central Transportation Company, said today it had completed settlement of claims with a subsidiary and two sub sidiaries of the transportation company.

title: Campora Meets and Cautions Guerrillas
description: BUENOS AIRES. June 14 (UPI) Guerrilla leaders called on President Hector J. Campora yesterday to thank him for freeing them and received a warning to drop their an nounced terrorist campaign against American companies, and other targets.

title: DIVERSION OF FUNDS ALLEGED IN PASS CASE
description: ERIE, Pa., June 14 (UPI)Five coal miners testified today at the murder trial of Albert Pass that a $20,000 fund that former United Mine Workers President W. A. Boyle said he had authorized for organizing activities had been returned instead to Mr. Pass. He is charged with using the money to pay for the killing of a union reformer, Joseph Yablon ski.

title: STOCK PRICES OFF ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and overthecounter markets declined yesterday in the wake of President Nixon's announcement Wednesday night of his plans to curb inflation. Most believed that the meas ures he was taking were not strong enough to accomplish his purpose.

title: Exploitation Investigated
description: MANILA, June 14 (UPI)Foreign Secretary Carlos P. Romulo ordered the Philippine Embassy in Washington today to look into allegations that Filipilo nurses were being ex ploited as cheap labor at the Hahnemann Hospital in Phila delphia.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M.

title: Prices Cut on Key Items As Nixon Freeze Begins
description: Prices of steel, copper, rub ber tires and other major prod ucts were cut back yesterday as an immediate result of Pres ident Nixon's 60day freeze based on prices in the June 1.8 period.

title: 3 Policemen Injured in Racial Clash
description: Five persons, three of then policemen, were injured slightly and four were arrested as a result of several incidents of racial violence in an East New York neighborhood late Wednesday and early yes terday.

title: Excerpts From Testimony Given Before Senate Select Committee on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 Following are excerpts from a transcript of testimony in the 11th day of hearings on the Watergate case today be fore the Senate Select Com mittee on Presidential Cam paign Activities:

title: THOUSANDS ON IND DELAYED 2 HOURS
description: Several thousand subway riders were delayed, some for two hours, at the height of the homebound rush last evening when power was turned off on the IND line between 59th and 125th Streets.

title: Doctors Go to a Rural County
description: WARSAW, N. Y.  Last February, Dr. Donald W. Burkhardt hung up his shingle here in the rolling, gentle hills of Wyoming County.

title: 14 Policemen in Baltimore Indicted in Numbers Case
description: BALTIMORE, June 14 (AP)A Federal grand jury indicted 14 Baltimore policemen and 19 civilians today on charges in volving payoffs to protect ille gal numbers operations in the city.

title: Harvard Graduates Hear Speech by ExDissident
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14Amid ritual that dates back three centuries and some mild protest that dates back only three or four years, Harvard University conferred 4,298 de grees and a dozen honorary doctorates today under glorious skies.

title: TESTIFIES 5 HOURS
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Jeb Stuart Magruder, the former deputy director of President Nixon's 1972 reelection cam paign, told a firsthand story today of how he and other highranking officials had plot ted the bugging of the Demo crats and then tried to cover it up.

title: Pentagon Asks Congress To Meet Grumman Price
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The Defense Department proposed to Congress today that the price of the Navy's new F14 plane he increased by about $2mil lion per plane, to $14million, in order to assure continued production by the Grumman Corporation at Bethpage, L. I.

title: Colson Says He Put Hunt on I.T.T. Job
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Charles W. Colson, former White House special counsel, confirmed publicly today that he had directed E. Howard Hunt Jr. to go to Denver in March, 1972, and interview Mrs. Dita D. Beard, Washington lobbyist for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, about her memorandum linking a promised $400,000 campaign contribution with Administra tion help in settling an anti trust suit.

title: ALVIN A. LICHT
description: Alvin A. Licht, senior part ner in the law firm of Licht & Schwartz, died apparently of a heart attack, at Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital on Wednesday evening. He was 71 years old and lived at 870 Fifth Avenue.

title: 3 GOLFERS SHARE L.I. AMATEUR MEDAL
description: UPPER BROOKVILLE, L. I., June 14Jimmy Bostwick of Meadow Brook, a former French amateur champion, shared the medal today with Mike Mattwell of Nassau County Club, and John Mamil ton of St. George's in the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at Mill River Club. Each had a 75, three strokes over par.

title: ASTRONAUTS END SURVEYS OF EARTH

description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, said today that Republican es pionage tactics had little effect on the 1972 Presidential elec tion, but the results would have been vastly different if the voters had known about the coverup.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating Outlook
description: AREA ABlues from 6 to 12 pounds are running on the Ridge off Surf City, N. J., and chummers from as far as Brielle have been hauling them in for the last week. Fluke (2 to 4 pounds) are in good supply in Barnegat Inlet and Beach Haven Inlet for fishermen using squid or spearing. Offshore at Seaside Park, N. J., blues from 7 to 12 pounds have been re sponding to bunker and mackerel. A variety of fish, including whiting, fluke and sea bass, have been caught at The Wrecks off Point Pleas ant.

title: HARLOW RETURNS TO NIXON'S STAFF
description: WASHINGTON, June 14President Nixon announced to day that Bryce N. Harlow was returning to the White House staff, which was shattered by the Watergate disclosures.

title: Miss Leonard's 82 for 156 Leads Miss Fried by Shot
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., June 14 Laura Leonard of Piping Rock continued to lead the 23d Wom en's Cross Country Golf Asso ciation medalplay champion ship today after the second round with a 36hole total of 156. Laura, who had a 74 at her home club yesterday, posted an 82 over the 5,876yard, par 74 Fresh Meadow course. Susan Fried of Old Westbury was sec ond with 157.

title: $980,000 Raised at G. O. P Fete
description: Despite the Watergate scan dal and several investigations of national Republican fund raising activities, the Republi can state committee last night grossed $980,000 at its annual fundraising dinner. Despite the Watergate scan

title: Magruder on Watergate: Ends Justify the Means
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Government officials he re spected had done it. The uni versity professor of ethics he admired had done it. So Jeb Stuart Magruder had done it too, he told the Senate com mittee investigating the Wa tergate affair today. He had let the ends justify the means.

title: No One Wanted to Speak, Arms Panel Adjourns
description: GENEVA, June 14 (Reuters) The 25nation Geneva dis armament conference, which opened its summer session last week after a seven week recess, met for only four minutes todaybecause no one wanted to speak.

description: WASHINGTON, June 14Dr. Morton H. Halperin, whose home telephone was tapped while he was working on Henry A. Kissinger's staff at the White House, filed suit today against Mr. Kissinger and other White House officials.

Investment Adviser to the real estate trust, headquartered in Dallas, is the Murray Management Corporation, a subsidiary of the Foursquare Corporation which is engaged in mortgage banking through another subsidiary, the Murray Investment Company.

description: Another triple crown climax will be on the program at Bel mont Park today with the run ning of the Coaching Club American Oaks. This 1mile test is the third pars of the triple crown for fillies, and has attracted a field of 13.

title: Turner Decrees a Xanadu in Florida
description: SANFORD, Fla., June 15 (AP)  A medieval castle with turrets and a bomb shelter looms near this cen tral Florida town. It is the $3.5million marbled hide away of the embattled busi nessman, Glenn W. Turner.

description: Tenant Evictions Are Ordered Halted

title: DOROTHY CAREW, 63, FINANCIAL WRITER
description: Dorothy Carew, who was the first woman journalist to be come a financial writer for The Associated Press, died Thursday of cancer at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 63 years old and in recent years had lived in Wash ington.

title: MAN HELD IN DEATH OF CITY POLICEMAN
description: Authorities said yesterday that a third suspect had been, captured in connection with the shooting of Police Officer Rob ert Laurenson, who was slain while off duty in a West Side bar on June 3.

title: New Vietnam Truce Is On And the Fighting Is Down
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, June 16  Scattered fighting continued throughout South Vietnam yesterday after the reinforced ceasefire went into effect, but reports from the field indicated that the en counters were fewer and on a far smaller scale than those that accompanied the original ceasefire last January.

title: Notes on People Spell It Onomastics
description: Onomastics  the science or word originswas the key word at the 1973 Na tional Spelling Bee in Wash ington. Stephen Hayes of Oxon Hill, Md., spelled it wrong. Barrie Trinkle of Fort Worth, Tex., spelled it cor rectly, and that made the 13yearold student the cham pion, and the winner of $1,000.

title: Futurity Has a RagstoRiches Hope
description: YONKERS, June 15There is a new kid on the block. He is Tamerlane, a deep chested, strong freeswinging colt who will throw off his rags image tomorrow night and race with the big boys for $93,242 in the Yonkers Futurity, the first leg of the triple crown for trotters.

title: NATO's Crumbling Flanks
description: BRUSSELSMore than half the pop ulation of NATO members is too young to remember World War II and seems increasingly uninterested in allied unity. The new era of EastWest detente further encourages lassitude. Despite the exhortations of its leaders, NATO is seen as anachronistic by many taxpayers who resent its cost.

title: MISS EVERT LOSES TO VIRGINIA WADE
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 15 (UPI)Topseeded Mrs. Billie Jean King defeated Rosie Casals today and moved into the final of the John Play er Grand Prix tennis tourna ment, but secondseeded Chris Evert suffered her second de feat in less than a week.

title: Budget Plan Faces Fight By Mayors
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 15A record attendance of nearly 800 mayors is expected for the annual United States Con ference of Mayors that begins here tomorrow. Many officials believe that the Watergate scandal offers an opening for their efforts to alter priorities established by President Nixon's 1974 budget proposals.

title: DR. ERNEST SAMUEL
description: NEW ORLEANS June 15 (AP)Dr. Ernest Charles Samuel, a pioneer in the field of radiology, died Wednes day at the age of 86.

title: JURY WILL STUDY STOCKSALE CASE
description: PATERSON, June 15  The Passaic County Prosecutor, Jo seph D. J. Gourley, announced today that a grand jury inves tigation would begin next month into an allegedly fraudu lent stock sale involving the president of the Passaic Valley Water Commission.

title: Volvo Reportedly Seeking U.S. Site to Build a Plant
description: CHESAPEAKE, Va., June 15 (AP)Volvo of America, Inc., a subsidiary of the Swedish owned auto manufacturing com pany, is reportedly Investigat ing sites here for possible construction of a $100million assembly plant.

title: Campus Notes
description: Twenty five students and faculty members from Staten Island Community College and two members of the city's Board of Higher Edu cation will spend three weeks traveling and studying in China this summer.

title: One Dies in Bridge Crash
description: One man was killed and an other was seriously injured last night when their car skidded into a wall on the Queensboro Bridge, the police reported. The dead man, who had been driv ing, was identified as Julius Rosa, 35, of 3269 43d Street, Astoria, Queens.

title: Farm Subsidy Bill With $20,000 Limit Approved by House
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) The House passed and sent to the Senate today a multi billiondollar appropriation bill that includes a $20,000 ceiling that any one grower of cotton, wheat or feed grains can re ceive as a farm subsidy.

title: NEW RATES ASKED BY STOCK GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, June 15A new approach to brokers com mission rates that would shift to institutional from individual investors a larger share of the cost of maintaining market li quidity was proposed today by the Securities Industry Associa tion.

title: The Screen: 'Hell House':The Cast
description: "The Legend of Hell House," unfolded at local theaters yesterday, brims with "psychic phenomena" that, a foreword insists, "are not only very much within the bounds of possibility but could well be true." Perhaps. But it's an unconvincing legend on screen despite this sober note and a pseudo-scientific approach to ghouls, poltergeists and the like. And if John Hough, the director, and his small, willing cast maintain mild tension during their harried visit to this haunted "hell house," the few chills they provide are of little help.The gloomy Victorian pile in question was once owned by a mysteriously departed, evil munitions tycoon, who filled it with those psychic phenomena. Now, it appears, Roland Culver, as another British millionaire, has acquired that specter-filled manse and hired a group of experts, including Roddy McDowall as a dour "physical medium," to check the dire legend for answers on survival after death.One member of the group, Clive Revill, as a physicist who scoffs at ectoplasm, night noises and survival after death, is, however, convinced there are forces in the mansion and has a slew of scientific gadgets to destroy them.Call it fairly standard procedure  the screams, seances, poltergeist's flying crockery and a couple of killings. But the young, decorative Pamela Franklin, as a "mental medium, and Gayle Hunnicutt, as the physicist's well-endowed wife, add an unusual, titillating facet to this film genre when they occasionally serve as sex objects for those dastardly ghouls. The rampaging spirits, however, are hard to believe, and we must agree with the realistic, unflappable Clive Revill when he exclaims: "It's impossible, I can't accept this."

title: Mrs. Hess Wed to Michael H. Dann
description: RYE, N. Y., June 15Mrs4 Louise C. Hess was married at her home here this after noon to Michael H. Dann, a consultant to the Children's Television Workshop and guest lecturer in the humani ties at Yale University. State Supreme Court Justice Theo dore B. Kupferman performed the ceremony. headed Cohen Goldman & Co., manufacturers of men's clothing.

title: Aide Asserts Cox Inquiry Will Look at Everything
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 The Watergate special prosecu tion force may open new in vestigations beyond those al ready publicly connected with the case, a top prosecution of ficial said today.

title: Paraplegic Sets Lift Mark
description: One record was set in the weightlifting competition yes terday as the 17th annual Na tional Wheelchair Games got under way at the Henshel Gym nasium of the Bulova School of Watchmaking, in Woodside, Queens.

title: Williams Victor in 1; Milburn Upset in Hurdles
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 15  Steve Williams, a 19yearold New Yorker, emerged as the crown prince of American sprinting tonight, but Rod Mil burn, the Olympic highhurdles champion, was upset by Tom Hill at the 85th annual National Amateur Athletic Union out door track and field champion ships.

title: Bowater Corp. Makes Bid For Hanson Trust Shares
description: The Bowater Corporation of London, a paper maker, an nounced yesterday that it had offered stock worth about $139million for all of the shares of Hanson Trust, Ltd., a buildingmaterials and con structionequipment concern.

title: The Dance
description: Meredith Monk's, canny as semblage of biographical in cidents from the past and present in her dance Educa tion of the. Girlchild re veals her imagination operat ing at a high creative pitch. The work, which was pre sented Tuesday evening at 29 Wooster Street, translates reminiscence into imaginative movement tableaus, dramatic incident and song.

title: Roundup: Baltimore Chop Tops Texas
description: Brooklyn born Tommy Davis, one of baseball's Have Bat, Will Travel hitters, pro duced the only run as the designated hitter last night to give Baltimore a 10 tri umph over the Texas Rangers.

title: CACTUS JOHNSON
description: KERRVILLE, Tex., June 15 (AP)Fred E. (Cactus) John son, former major league base ball pitcher, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital here. He was 79 years old.

title: C.B.S. Gives Free Time Tuesday To Three to Counter President
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System television and radio networks will give free time Tuesday to three spokesmen for views contrasting with those expressed by President Nixon in his speech this week putting a freeze on prices.

title: People in Sports: Shue to 76ers
description: Gene Shue, who says he likes challenges and believes in hard work, assured him self of both yesterday when he signed a twoyear contract to coach the Philadelphia 76ers. Shue quit the Balti more Bullets, Central Divi sion champions, last month and will take over a team that won 9 games and lost 73 last season for the worst record in the history of the National Basketball Associa tion.

title: Honor Code Suit by Cadets Dismissed
description: A Federal judge has dis missed a suit by six West Point cadets who charged that the Cadet Honor Committee had de prived them of their constitu tional rights in finding them guilty of honor violations with out giving them the right to legal representation, to pre pare a defense or to know the nature of the evidence against them.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Matlack Triumphs, 52
description: The Mets may not be rolling, but they at least are moving in a forward direction, some thing that could not be said of them in the last month.

title: LINDSAY ACCEPTS BEAME PROPOSALS ON CITY BUDGET
description: At a secret City Hall meeting yesterday, Mayor Lindsay ac cepted Controller Abraham D. Beame's budget package, which is expected to reduce substan tially the proposed property tax increase and provide funds for 3,000 new policemen.

title: A Delta Town Is Hopeful but Watchful
description: MY PHUOC TAY, South Vietnam, June 15At noon today, when the newly reaf firmed ceasefire was to go into effect, an army private sat at the wheel of a pickup truck in this village in the Mckong Delta intently listen ing to the thunder of artil ?? in the distance.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.5 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 170.7 from 170.2 last week.

title: Harvard, Yale to Row for 108th Time Today
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., June 15The HarvardYale crew race, which has been held 107 times, will be staged here on the Thames tomorrow, probably for the last time. If the crews do race next year, it will be earlier in the season and on a course shorter than the present four miles.

title: TRANSPORT RATES ARE FROZEN BY U.S.
description: Federal regulatory agencies advised airlines, railroads, truckers, bus lines and tele phone and telegraph companies yesterday that President Nixon's 60day price freeze applied to their rates.

title: G.O.P. Aid to Liberals in '70 Recalled
description: A former staff member of the state Liberal party recount ed yesterday how he and other members worked out of the office of a Republican Assem blyman on Long Island to make calls on behalf of a Liberal candidate in an unsuccesful attempt to help the Republican defeat his Democratic opponent.

title: FASHION TALK In a Fairly Serene Landscape, Some of the Wilder Outposts
description: By BERNADINE MORRIS

title: Lawyer Says Nixon's Home on Coast Was Paid for Through Title Company
description: LOS ANGELES, June 15 A lawyer here says that whenRichard M. Nixon acquired his San Clemente, Calif., estate in 1969, The Title Insurance and Trust Company paid the sellers $400,000 by its check and gave its $1million promissory note for the balance.

title: MISS EVERT LOSES TO VIRGINIA WADE
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 15, (UPI)Topseeded, Mrs. Billie Jean King defeated Rosie Casals today and moved into the final of the John Play er Grand Prix tennis tourna ment, but second seeded Chris Evert suffered her second de feat in less than a week.

title: LORD MELCHETT, STEEL LEADER, 48
description: LONDON, June 15  Lord Melchett, a Conservative peer chosen by the former Labor Government to run the nation alized steel industry, died to day at his seaside home on the Spanish island of Majorca. He had been swimming and had a heart attack after leaving the water. He was 48 years old.

title: Matlack Triumphs, 52
description: The Mets may not be rolling, but they at least are moving in a forward direction, some thing that could not be said of them in the last month.

title: 2 Experts on Children's Verse Find Everybody's an Authority
description: LONDONChildhood is the country that produces the most nostalgic, con tentious and opinionated exiles. As well as the most numerous.

title: Research Aid Sought
description: Multiple Sclerosis is chronic disease of the cen tral nervous system. It distorts or blocks nerve impulses from activat ing muscles vital to such functions as speech, move ment and vision. Victims are usually struck and disabled between 20 and 40 years of age, the vital years of family and career building.

title: Arab Ruler Seeks U. S. Technology To Foster Industry
description: Sheik Sultan alQasimi, ruler of Sharjah, the latest of the Arab states to find an oil bo nanza beneath its sands, is in the United States on a good will mission that encompasses a search for American com panies and technology to de velop industry.

title: Snub for Mr. Whitlam
description: Australia's first Labor Prime Minister in nearly a quar ter of a century is a man in a hurry. Even before Labor ousted the LiberalCountry coalition Government last December, Gough Whitlam had charted major shifts for his country's foreign policy, including prompt recognition of mainland China, withdrawal of the remaining Austra lian troops in Vietnam, a loosening of traditional dependence on the United States and Britain along with an effort to build much closer links to Australia's Asian neighbors.

title: BURNS ADVANCES IN THE L.I. AMATEUR
description: UPPER BROOKVILLE, L. I., June 15George Burns 3d, the 1972 winner, moved into the quarterfinals of the Long Island Golf Association amateur cham pionship today at the Mill River Club.

title: JARRETT'S QUARTET PLAYS AT VANGUARD
description: The quartet that Keith Jarrett, the jazz pianist and soprano saxophonist, is leading at the Village Vanguard this week is so strong in each of its individ ual members that the elemen tary nature of its occasional weaknesses is more startling than might otherwise be.

title: British Treasury Bill Rate Registered Decline in Week
description: LONDON, June 15 (Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of British Treasury bills fell to 7.0268 per cent (7.1539).

title: Votes in Congress This Week's Tally for Metropolitan Area Senate
description: 1. Vote on amendment to farm bill that would impose a $20,000 ceiling on subsidy payments to any one farm, which passed, 45 to 37, June. 8.

title: Corning Glass Sets Plans For South Korean Venture
description: Corning Glass Works said yesterday that it had agreed to build and operate jointven ture electronics facilities in South Korea on an equal own ership basis with South Korea's Samsung group. Plans include the annual production of 2 mil lion television tubes.

title: NEWSPAPER TALKS CALLED DIFFICULT
description: John M. Mortimer, vice pres ident for industrial relations at The New York Times, said yes terday that it had been difficult in the current round of contract talks to have productive nego tiations with Typographical Union No. 6 on important items, such as automation. However, he said negotiators for the Times would keep trying.

title: Player's 137 Leads Colbert by Stroke in Open
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 15Gary Player of South Africa retained the lead at the half way mark of the United States Open today while a 65 by an alternate, Gene Borek, a Long Island club professional, set a record for the Oakmont Coun try Club golf course.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Death in Venice To Bow at the Met

title: Justice Agency Is Facing Inquiry by a House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The House Judiciary Committee plans to investigate the politiciza tion of the Justice Department, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., the committee chairman, said today.

title: MISS BOURASSA'S 68 LEADS BY 2 STROKES
description: MONTREAL, June 15 (AP)A lotal favorite, Jocelyne Bourassa, birdied the final four holes today and finished with a fiveunderpar 68 to take twostroke lead after the first round of the $50,000 Montreal Ladies Professional Golf Asso ciation tournament.

title: Secretariat vs. Canonero
description: Did Secretariat break the Preakness record as well as the records for the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont?

title: I.T.T. Signs an Agreement To Build Plant in Taiwan
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said here yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the Directorate General of Tele communications of the Republic of China to build a plant in Taiwan for the manufacture of electronic switches and other telecommunication; equipment.

title: MINISTERS AGREE ON NATO REVIEW
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 15The 15nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today to review its poli tical, economic and military ar rangements in the light of the vast changes in the internation al situation in recent years.

title: Huge Solar Flare Sighted by Skylab And Photographed
description: HOUSTON, June 15 (UPI)Skylab's orbiting researchers observed a great radiation out burst on the sun today for the first time in a breakthrough in man's drive to unravel the mys teries of earth's nearest star.

title: Federal Employes Must Notify U.S. Before Seeing China Aides
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) Government employes are re quired to give the State De partment advance notice of per sonal or official contact with members of the new Chinese liaison office.

title: Nastase, Miss Evert Lead Grand Prix Net Standings
description: BOSTON, June 15 (UPI)Ilie Nastase of Rumania increased ?? lead in the Commercial Union Grand Prix of Tennis standings with two recent inter national competition victories.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., June 15A tennisplaying doctor in this town treats tennis elbows under stressthat is playing tennis as usual. No wonder then that players flock to Dr. Charles Steiner's offices from as far north as Con necticut and south as Washington.

title: Antiques. Forgotten Gems of Painted Furnishings
description: HARTFORDThe appear ance last August of that ex traordinary book, American Painted Furniture 16601880, by Dean A. Fales Jr., not only brought a wealth of fine ex amples into the marketplace and made some antiques col lectors and dealers think twice about stripping paint from vintage chairs and chests, but also resulted in a small but stellar exhibition here at the Connecticut His torical Society.

title: Presbyterian Church in South To Resist Separatist Elements
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., June 15Faced with its first schism since its founding more than a century ago, the general as sembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S. (Southern) adopted this week a policy of firm but restrained resistance to dissident elements within its. ranks.

title: EASED DRUG LAWS OPPOSED IN JERSEY
description: NEWARK, June 15Propo sals to decriminalize the use and possession of marijuana in New Jersey ran into solid opposition today from legis lators studying the possibility of amending the state's nar cotics laws.

title: Hudson Road Chief Accused of Misuse Of Men, Machines
description: JERSEY CITY, June 15An gelo Bevacqua, the Hudson County Road Supervisor, was indicted today for allegedly having public records altered to conceal the fact that public employes and equipment had been used illegally to fulfill a private contract with a county agency.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June. 15 (AP)The Interna tional Skating Union Congress voted today to prohibit speed and figure skaters from displaying commercial brand names during international championships and the Olympic Games, and to take the frills out of figureskating costumes. The delegates adopted a proposal that dresses must be simple, modest and dignified, and not show costumes.

title: JONAS AISTIS
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 Jonas Aistis, a Lithuanian poet and essayist, died Wednesday of abdominal cancer at the George Washington University Hospital here. He was 65 years old,

title: Little Hope Held for a Cambodia Peace
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 15Warring sides in Cam bodia appear to have locked themselves into positions so hard that Government leaders here and some of their Ameri can counterparts are saying at least privately that the war can be ended only by military victory. And victory, at least for the Government, seems wholly out or reach.

title: What They Are Saying of Mr. Clifford's Plan
description: To the Editor: This [Clifford] article is, in my opin ion, one of the most insidious as well as treasonable utterances yet ex pressed by those persons seeking on the unfortunately conceived action of a group whose efforts were prompted by their desire to uncover subversive practices for which the object of their search has been so noted, to under mine the work of a man who is with out question the most honest and loyally oriented President this country has had since Theodore Roosevelt.

title: Women on the Pill Have Higher Blood Pressure but Hear Better
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Scientists have found that the woman who uses birth control pills is likely to have slightly higher blood pressure, a higher pulse rate and somewhat more acute hearing than the woman who does not use the pill.

title: U.S. Asks Stay of Court Ruling Barring O. E. O.Chief From Job
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Government sought today to stay a Federal court order barring Howard J. Phillips from serving as acting director of the Office of Economic Oppor tunity.

title: Jersey Faces Stiffer Curbs
description: The Federal Government yes terday approved New York's stringent trafficcontrol pro gram, which is designed to meet cleanair standards through such measures as bans on taxi cruising in midtown Manhat tan, restrictions on parking and tolls on East River bridges to cut traffic in the heart of the city by 50 per cent.

title: E.P.A. Plans for 12 Areas
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Environmental Protection Agen cy proposed smogfighting trans portation controls today that, if ever imposed, could drastically reduce motor vehicle traffic in major cities by 1977.

title: Williams Victor in 100 Milburn Upset in Hurdles
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 15  Steve Williams, a 19yearold New Yorker, emerged as the crown prince of American sprinting tonight, but Rod Mil burn, the Olympic highhurdles champion, was upset by Tom Hill at the 85th annual National Amateur Athletic Union out door track and field champion ships.

title: U.N. Ends First Phase of Mideast. Debate.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 15After eight days of debate  occasionally acrimo nious, at times evidencing measure of goodwillthe Se curity Council today completed the first phase of its most com prehensive review of the Mid dle East since the 1967 war.

title: 7 ForeignOwned Banks Returned to Argentine Control
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 15 (AP)Argentina's new Peronist Government today ordered return to Argentine control for seven banks that had been ac quired by foreign interests since 1966.

title: 20thCentury Works Performed At Philharmonic Rug Concert
description: The cheering, predominantly youthful audience that greeted the first of the New York Phil harmonic's Rug Conceits on Tuesday night was not an iso lated phenomenon. Wednesday night's listeners, crowded on the carpeted orchestra floor and stage of Philharmonic Hall or seated normally in the loges, responded clamorously to each of the four works in the pro

title: Books of The Times
description: The ecumenical movement, or the search for Christian unity is now such an estab lished part of church life that one can easily forget that its history is really quite short. It was only when the Second Vatican Council of 1962 to 1965, responding to the vision of Pope John XXIII, accepted what until then had been a primarily Protestant and Orthodox ideal that ecumenism be came something other than a strange word.

title: Stamp Suspect Charged
description: WESTON, Mass., June 15 (AP) A Framingham man, Gary R. Fennell, 28 years old, was charged with receiving stolen property and larceny in con nection with stamps missing from the Cardinal Spellman Philatelic Museum at Regis Col lege in Weston.

title: John J. Kelly Dead at 88; A Leader in Tammany Hail
description: NORWALK, Conn., June 1John J. Kelly, a Democratic leader in New York and a pow er in Tammany Hall in the nineteenthirties and forties, died Wednesday in Norwalk Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: Benguet Shows Rise in Profits; Other Companies List Earnings
HALDEMAN DENIES MAGRUDER REPORT ON COVERUP PLOT;Lawyer Says ExStaff Chief Has a Diary That Refutes Testimony on His Role
description: WASHINGTON, June 15H.R. Haldeman's attorney denied today that the former White House chief of staff had learned of the Watergate coverup plot in January at a meeting with Jeb Stuart Magruder.

title: Plan to Intercept Comet For Close Study Weighed
description: With a recently discovered comet due to make a spectacu lar circuit. of the sun late this year the National Aeronautical and Space Administration is considering an attempt to in tercept and study it at close range.

title: Minor Leagues
Racial Tension Building Over Old Mill Park
description: Michael Augugliaro was lay ing the dust in his driveway with a garden hose yesterday afternoon, down the block from a park in the outlying Old Mill section of Brooklyn that has be come a maneuvering ground for hostile white and black youths on recent hot evenings.

title: People and Business
description: The Dayco Corporation, a diversified industrial com pany based in Dayton, Ohio, has a number of major sub sidiaries. But one of themthe Cadillac Plastic and Chem ical Companyseems to be the spawning ground for the Presidency of the parent cor poration.

title: Sports Today
description: The Grand Prix of Monaco. (TelevisionChannel 7, 3 P.M., tape)

title: Proceeding With Caution
description: The initial public reaction to President Nixon's new price freeze and its coming successor, Phase 4, has been far more cautious, skeptical and critical than that which greeted his first freeze of Aug. 15, 1971.

title: PeaceKeeping Unit in Cyprus Is Continued by U.N. Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 15The Security Council voted 14 to 0 today to extend for six months the United Na tions peacekeeping force on Cyprus, which for nine years has acted to prevent renewed fighting between the island's Greekspeaking and Turkish speaking communities.

title: Stocks Decline Sharply; Dow Average Off 14.37
description: Investors disappointment over President Nixon's new eco nomic program sent the stock market down sharply yester day in lighter trading.

title: MINISTERS AGREE ON NATO REVIEW
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 15The 15nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today to review its poli tical, economic and military ar rangements in the light of the vast changes in the internation al situation in recent years.

title: Coffy,' Black-Oriented Film, Arrives:The Cast
description: As the obviously sexy, black heroine of several recent black-oriented, gory and, naturally, sexy shoot-'em-ups, Pam Grier again is tougher than the opposition as the titular "Coffy," which crashed into the Penthouse and 86th Street Twin I Theaters yesterday. And, if it can be called a switch, she plays a nurse who operates on bad scenes, bad guys and dolls, with explicit dialogue, but almost never in an operating room.Despite a good deal of lip service against the evils of drugs and the like, there's a maximum of footage devoted to exposing Miss Grier. She is plagued by problems. Her kid sister is hooked on drugs, so she uses a shotgun to dispatch a pusher. Then there's that bigtime white hood, Allan Arbus, who's muscled in on Robert DoQui, the black pimp and pusher. And there's Booker Bradshaw, her boyfriend and a politico in cahoots with the gang lords and cops who've maimed her admirer, William Elliott.What happens? She kills them all off, including her two-timing lover. All of which leaves a viewer with the happy thought that she now can get back to nursing and away from films like "Coffy."

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: Last Schedule Items Being Settled on Eve Of Brezhnev's Visit
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Nixon Administration officials and Soviet diplomats sought to day to smooth over remaining problems in the schedule and agenda for the visit here of Le onid I. Brezhnev.

title: Notes on People
Sports Today
New Jersey Briefs
description: A military prosecutor has begun investigating charges brought against an Army drill sergeant at Fort Dix by a number of recruits, who say he slapped and shoved at least two of them. An Army spokesman said the staff judge advocate's office began investigating charges against S. Sgt. Michael Walschmidt, 26 years old of Bethesda, Md., immediately after he allegedly slapped one recruit in the ear and shoved another into a wall locker June 8.

title: Vatican Reports Gains From Interfaith Talks in the Soviet Union
description: ROME, June 15Theo logians representing the Romar Catholic and the Russian Ortho dox Churches have agreed to recognize the fact that there is a strong tendency toward some forms of socialism in many parts of the world, the Vatican announced today.

title: Stottlemyre Tops Angels, 43
Brig. Gen. Richard Cutts Dead; Marine Invented a Rifle Device
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Brig. Gen Richard Malcolm Cutts, U.S.M.C., retired, whose 23year military career encom passed inventing, serving in the White House and battle field combat, died yesterday at Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Grania O'Malley, Actress; Known for Her Irish Roles
description: Grania O'Malley, a dramatic actress known for her Irish roles, died Thursday at Poly clinic Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived at 325 West 45th Street.

title: C.M. Strikers Return
description: More than half of the work ers scheduled for the General Motors Corporation Norwood, Ohio, assembly plant returned to their jobs on the early shift yesterday.

title: Bedridden Ulster Youth Killed In Home of a Protestant Leader
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 15Two gunmen forced their way into the home of a leader of the militant Protes tant Ulster Defense Association in Belfast today and killed his bedridden brotherinlaw.

title: Stottlemyre Tops Angels, 43
description: ANAHEIM, June 15The California Angels scored a run off Mel Stottlemyre tonight the first in two years, but they fell short of beating him for the first time in six years when the Yankees won 43, on Felipe Alou's runscoring fly in the 10th inning.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The New York Stock Exchange and its member firms are currently being attacked by Senator Harrison A. Wil liams Jr. of New Jersey and Repre sentative John Moss, of California, who plan to present bills for theoretical reformation. From their own experi ence, these two gentlemen know noth ing of the functioning of this great institution and industry, and apparently they are being prejudicially and badly advised by bureaucratic staffs who know less. If left unchecked, they are going to ruin an international market place and do untold damage to the economy of this country. Yet their opinions are constantly reported in the press with no contradictions.

title: HALDEMAN DENIES MAGRUDER REPORT ON COVERUP PLOT
description: WASHINGTON, June 15H. R. Haldeman's attorney denied today that the former White House chief of staff had learned A the Watergate coverup plot in January at a meeting with ?? Stuart Magruder.

title: Where to Stuff Yourself and. Not Feel Sinful
description: HINSDALE, Mass.  The. First Congregational Church of Hinsdale (there is no Sec ond) is buying a pipe organ, and it was a pleasure to contribute toward it. Espe cially since in return you got a supper cooked by the ladiesall you could eat for $2.50. (Here in the Berk shires, even inflation is a little behind the times.)

title: DAY AN SAYS ISRAEL MUST HARDEN STAND
description: TEL AVIV, June 15Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said to day that the expected surge of arms purchasing by Arab gov ernments would compel Israel to harden her resistance to withdrawal from Arab terri tories.

title: U.S. Open Golf Scores at Oakmont
Equity Financing
description: The public offering of 2,895,750 common shares of the Communications Satellite Corporation at 44 per share yesterday was reported to be over subscribed and the books closed by Salomon Brothers, Merrill Lynch and the First Boston Cor poration. The company's stock, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed at 43, down 1.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: RENAISSANCE Years back, a Columbia student named Allen Ginsberg and a dropout named Jack Kerouac discussed life, art and all that stuff day in and day out at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, near 114th Street (8648817), which made it, if not the birthplace, at least a gestation compartment for the Beat Generation. Later, the Columbia radicals crossed the street to the cafe to plan further campus dissidence. Whatever has been done at Columbia has for almost a halfcentury been reflected in this neighborhood bar.,

title: Henry Stevens Dies at 94; Former Canadian Minister
description: VANCOUVER, June 15 (Cana dian Press)  Henry Herbert Harry Stevens, the last surviv ing member of R. B. Bennett's Conservative Government of the nineteenthirties and the archi tect of the former Prime Min ister's downfall, died here yes terday. He was 94 years old.

title: GrandJury Review Of Karate Assault On Police Weighed
description: The Manhattan District At torney's office said yesterday that it might present to a grand jury the case of a Black Muslim newspaper seller who used karate to injure six policemen.

title: Gallagher a Product. Of Kenny's Machine
description: Once mentioned as a pos sible Democratic running mate for President Johnson and a potential candidate for Governor of New Jersey, for mer Representative Cornelius Edward Gallagher rose to po litical prominence with the help of John V. Kenny, the former Democratic leader of Hudson County.

title: COURT BACKS P.B.A. ON ELECTION LAIN
description: WESTBURY, L. L, June 15A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a section of the state's election law prohibiting police. men from participating in poli tics was unconstitutional.

title: Farah Strike Has Become War of Attrition
description: EL PASO  The strike of Chicano workers against the Farah Manufacturing Com pany, now in its second year, has settled into a kind of holy war of attrition.

title: Silent Paging System Gets a Patent
description: WASHINGTON, June 15An electronic system that was patented this week finds people in an office or plant without paging them. Patent 3,739,329, granted to Robert W. Les Patents ter, a consulting engineer, is as signed to Rec Week ognition Devices, Inc., New York. The company is beginning production of the Trakatron, or Silent People Finder. The equipment includes a central console, transceivers (or sensors) for various rooms, and pensized instru ments to be worn in the pocket.

title: FORE ROGARD, 73, EXCHESS OFFICIAL
description: STOCKHOLM, June 15 (AP) Folke Rogard, former pres ident of the World Chess Fed eration, died Monday. He was 73 years old.

title: Local D.A.'s May Get Data On Investigation of G.O.P.
description: The State Attorney General's investigation. Into a suspected votesiphoning scheme to pro tect the Assembly Republican majority was reported yester day to have reached the point of deciding whether local dis trict attorneys should be noti fled for possible criminal prose cution.

description: Import Liberalization Backed in Japan

title: Bridge: FourThree Trump Fit Called A Difficult, Neglected Area
description: A difficult area that has been neglected by most au thorities is the fourthree trump fit. As Alphonse Moyse Jr. used to point out regu larly in the Bridge World, many excellent contracts are missed by partnerships that refuse to consider the ad vantages of such fits.

title: Dare to Be Great Promoter Arrested in West Germany
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, June 15 (AP)The West German police took the Ameri can businessman Glenn W. Turner into custody today on warrant issued by British au thorities investigating Mr. Turn er's Dare to Be Great sales promotion.

title: PENN CENTRAL CUTS RAILFREIGHT TRIPS
description: PHILDELPHIA, June 15 (AP) The Penn Central Railroad said today that it was immedi ately reducing the frequency of freight service in the New Eng land area in an effort to con serve fuel.

title: New Law Helps Take Heat Off AirConditioner Buying
description: If the heat is leading you to run out and buy an air conditioner, you can deter mine the most efficient one for your needs, and thus save a little energy and a little money.

description: Old Mill inn, Route 202, Bernardsville. (201) 5381413 or (201) 7661150.

title: New Ambassador to U.S. Is Appointed by Japanese
description: TOKYO, June 15 (AP)The Government today appointed Takeshi Yasukawa, counselor of the Foreign Ministry, to suc ceed Naruhiko Ushiba as Japa nese Ambassador to the United. States.

title: Nixon Offers Congress Olive Branch
description: PEKIN, III., June 15Presi dent Nixon inched an olive branch toward a hostile Con gress today, saying that the executive and legislative arms of Government must develop spirit of give and take to realize that neither side can have his way all the time.

title: TUGBOAT CAPSIZES, KILLING CREWMAN
description: One seaman was killed and five were rescued by nearby vessels from the Lower Bay, yesterday afternoon when the 94foot tugboat Norwalk cap sized and sank while escorting a disabled tanker into port.

title: Chances Bleak for Accord on Subcontinent
description: NEW DELHI, June 15Efforts to reach a settlement between India, Pakistan and Bangladesh over three groups of political hostages have turned into a stalemate marked by confusion and violent rhetoric.

title: U.S. SHIFTS HANDLING OF FARM REPORTING
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The Agriculture Department, superseded by the White House announced today a suspension of its planned reporting pro gram for keeping track of United States exports.

Crime, Death and Life on West Side Are Topics of Children's Winning Essays
JUDGMENT LEVIED AGAINST BESTLINE
description: LOS ANGELES, June 15 (UPI)A Los Angeles Superior Court judge levied a $1.85 million judgment against a soap distributor today for vio lation of state laws restricting socalled pyramid sales.

title: A Better Idea
description: A New Haven man writes that while he believes impeachment of the Presi dent might be an excessive reaction to the scandals known as Watergate, some lesser response is certainly called for. He proposes impoundment of the President.

title: AUTOMATION WINS AT OX RIDGE SHOW
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 15 Automation of Fox Lake Farms made shambles of the regular conformation hunter division at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show today and won the championship with a whopping 23 points.

title: STATE PURCHASES 3,000 CHOICE ACRES

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, JUNE 16, 1973

[Page 1, Columns 23.]

description: PHOENIX, Ariz., June 15 (AP)Harland Reynolds of the Army and Columbus, Ga., cap tured the standard pistol event by a point today in the 13th United States international championships.

title: WINE TALK That 35Cent Tunisian Rose Has a $1.66 Price Tag Here
description: Most wine enthusiasts are familiar with the basic facts of increasing wine prices: exploding demand, fixed pro duction in some premium areas, the shrinking value of the, dollar abroad and, to some extent, speculation.

title: Dave Anderson
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 15It usuaily happens in the first round. E. Z. Shank from Big Slice, Okla., shoots 65 for the early lead in the United States Open golf cham pionship, then disappears in the rough somewhere. But today it happened in the second round. Gene Borek shot a sixunderpar 65, a competitive record for the ominous Oakmont Country Club, and the headlines in most news papers will refer to him as an unknown. He's not an unknown in the New York area. He's a 36yearold club pro at Pine Hollow out on Long Island's North Shore, where he charges $8 for a halfhour lesson when he's not winning local tourna ments. Quietly, he's regarded as one of the nation's best players among the club pros. He won't disappear in the rough. But the irony of what he accomplished today is that he got into the Open as an alternate when Dave Hill withdrew Tuesday because he didn't think he could break 80 here.

title: The Screen: An Almost Sublime 'Interval Opens:Story of Love Comes to 34th St. East
description: "Married?""No""Never?""Not yet!" . . . sigh . . . And so Serena Moore (Merle Oberon), as tremulous as any girl, parries the charming but too insistent German restaurateur who rescued her from her stalled car and has already fallen in love with her on the short drive from nowhere to the Mayan ruins at Chichen-Itza. She has come to the Yucatan, Serena Moore, in search of peace. And she has brought with her a gold-framed Romantic landscape painting, a 5 million-year-old fossil fish ("to put me in perspective"), a change of wardrobe for every occasion, and an unquenchable thirst for life."It's so beautiful here," she exclaims, forging her way through a tropical rain forest, "only one thought on its mindto grow!"Who could resist a lady like that? Nobody. Not the helpful German, nor the old rake at the bar, nor the handsome stranger on the beach, nor the teen-age boy on room servicebut, always graciously, Serena refuses them. Until Chris. Tempestuous, passionate, young, it is the vagrant artist Chris (Robert Wolders), also in search of peace, who awakens Serena's dormant fire and provides the occasion for "Interval," the story of a woman who finally stops running from love. The film opened yesterday at the 34th Street East Theater.It is one of those ecstatic affairs, full of wonder and discovery, and yet it doesn't work. Perhaps Serena is just too fine, too sensitive. Perhaps it is something else. There is a problem, a silent traveler with Serena on her journeys, which I wouldn't bring up if the movie didn't keep bringing it upin whispers: "The age thing." Though it is the last thought on his mind, and though you could never tell from looking at her, at some point Chris has to admit that Serena iswell"over 40."But truth to tell, Merle Oberon is well over 60, and from time to time it shows. "Are you a statue or are you real?" asks Chris, marveling at her beauty. You can't always say. Such uncanny freedom from wrinkles has not been achieved without a certain cost, and at this stage in her career Miss Oberon seems to have only two or three facial expressions left. Consequently, she acts mainly with her eyes, and with a small shake of her shoulders, which may be spunk, but which is never quite appropriate for the emotion of the moment. There was never such a movie for observing its leading lady from the back of the head.There probably was never such a movie for anything. As performed by Miss Oberon, directed by Daniel Mann, written by Gavin Lambert, with a musical score by Armando Manzanero and Ruben Fuentes that flows over everything like detergent back-up, the tragic tale of Serena Moore in "Interval" provides the first genuinely funny comedy of the year.On the scale of awfulness, it is almost sublime, better than "Pope Joan," nearly as good as "The Great Waltz." A few movies like this can last you for a lifetime.

title: New Vietnam T ruce Is On And the Fighting Is Down
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, June 16Scattered fighting continued throughout South Vietnam today after the second ceasefire went into af fect yesterday, but reports from the field indicated that the bat tles were fewer and on a far smaller scale that those that accompanied the original cease fire last January.

title: LINDSAY ACCEPTS RENE PROPOSALS ON CITY BUDGET; They Would Cut Property Tax Rise by 20 Cents and Add 3,000 Patrolmen; SECRET MEETING IS HELD; Council Leaders at Session TransitFare Subsidy for Aged to Continue
description: At a secret City Hall meeting yesterday, Mayor Lindsay ac cepted Controller Abraham D. Beame's budget package, which is expected to reduce substan tially the proposed property tax increase and provide funds for 3,000 new policemen.

title: Roundup: Baltimore Chop Tops Texas
description: Brooklyn born Tommy Davis, one of baseball's Have Bat, Will Travel hitters, pro duced the only run as the designated hitter last night to give Baltimore a 10 tri umph over the Texas Rangers.

title: The Brezhnev Visit
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev arrives in this country today. Gen eral Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, he is to all appearances the most powerful single individual in the Soviet Union, the contemporary successor of Lenin, Stalin, Malenkov and Khrushchev. His ,arrival is a sign of the very substantial thaw in the cold war, a thaw that has progressed with gratifying rapidity since Presi dent Nixon's visit to Moscow last year. The people of the United States will undoubtedly greet Mr. Brezhnev with the respect due the leader of a great nation with which this country wishes to live in peace and friendship.

title: Sudan Postpones Hearing in Killings Of Three Envoys
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, June 15 (AP)A magistrate's hear ing for Palestinian guerrillas accused of killing three diplo mats, two of them American, has been postponed the Sudan ese Government said today.

title: ' Super Fly TNT' Continues With His Adventures in Rome and Africa:The Cast
description: Coming after a fast, colorful movie like "Super Fly," a follow-up called "Super Fly TNT" is a wet firecracker. Long on talk and short on action, this juiceless bundle comes close to being super dull. It opened yesterday, with Ron O'Neal repeating the protagonist role and also directing.Most of the time Priest, the reformed, cocaine pusher from Harlem simply slouches around Rome, as a tired, cynical expatriate, trailed by the loving Sheila Frazier, from the first film. He plays poker. Occasionally, the couple ride past Roman landmarks. Priest finally lets himself be persuaded to fly off to Africa on a gun-running mission for a small, oppressed country, and the picture ends just when it should be starting.The Africa of the climax is a feeble, low-budget simulation, with some brief, standard, travelogue footage, as Mr. O'Neal is yanked off a plane and sadistically beaten in a room that could be anywhere.One thing stands out like a small, personal lighthouse. This is the excellent performance of Roscoe Lee Brownestrong, dignified and piercingas an impassioned African revolutionary. His patient recruiting in Rome of Mr. O'Neal, who often looks bored to death, takes most of the picture. Sharing that patience requires real indulgence.

title: BEAME WON'T GET BADILLO BACKING
description: Representative Herman Ba dillo declared yesterday that he would not support Control ler Abraham D. Beame for Mayor if Mr. Beame defeated him in the June 26 runoff pri mary for the Democratic nomi nation.

And as varied and melo dious a sampling as anybody could hope for, along with rep resentative dances, is being of fered at Carnegie Hall through Sunday night.

description: ASAU, Western Samoa An American timber enter prise on this heavily wooded tropical island, though mod est in size by industry stand ards, is one of the most widely discussed foreign in vestments in the South Pacific.

description: ALBANY, June 15 (UP)Citing serious practical prob lems, Governor Rockefeller has vetoed a bill aimed at avert ing school bus crashes like the one that took five lives in Rock land County last year.

description: PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP)Mrs. P. Watson Pedlow, widow of Cohn P. Kelly Jr., World War H flier hero, died yesterday in Sault St, Marie, Ontario, Her first husband, an Army Air Forces captain, died on the third day of the war, when his bomber was downed after crippling a Japanese

title: AnnapolisNewport Race For Yachts Begins Today

description: WASHINGTON, June 15The White House has confirmed that a secret list of President Nixon's preApril 7 campaign contributors, which had been thought destroyed, has been in the possession of the Presi dent's personal secretary.

title: Chess: Korchnoi Assumes the Lead In Round 9 of Tournament
description: LENINGRAD, June 14 Viktor Korchnoi of the Soviet Union took over the lead in Round 9 of the Interzonal Tournament in the Dzerjin sky Palace of Culture tonight by defeating me with the sharpest combination played in the event thus far.

title: Vampires of 'Jonathan' Strike a Metaphoric Blow Against Fascism:The Cast
description: Hans W. Geissendrfer's "Jonathan," which opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater, was first seen here last year when it was the most entertainingif not exactly the best  of the movies in the excellent New German Cinema show at the Museum of Modern Art. It is a vampire movie (Jonathan Harker, you may remember, is the principal narrator in Bram Stoker's "Dracula," an exceptionally classy vampire movie, and the distributor is billing it as the first anti-Fascist film of its kind.None of this gets so seriously into "Jonathan" as to spoil the fun. But when Professor Van Helsing complains (to a meeting of 19th-century Transylvanian student activists) that "the power of these blood suckers increases every day," you can bet he's at least two-thirds of the way into political metaphor.But the quality of imagination behind the film is generally much better than this. You can see it in such inventions as the malicious dwarf who lives in the forest outside Count Dracula's estate and who collects the paraphernalia  crosses, wooden stakes, old sprigs of garlic  of fearless vampire killers who came before our hero, Jonathan, and failed. And you can see it in the disciplined troop of ethereal little girls who attend the vampires  not the brides of Dracula (they are there also), but perhaps the bridesmaids, or even the first communicants. For this Count Dracula, an anti-Christ of parts, not only takes blood but also gives it too  from a wound in his side which, with infinite sadness, he offers to the lips of his victims.Nothing else quite matches that gesture. Nothing ever matches the ritual of the first voluptuous kiss in any vampire movie, and "Jonathan" is especially cannythough very restrainedwith the erotic potential of its material. But the whole film is invested with a kind of solemnity that is sometimes terrifying (though never cheaply shocking) and sometimes silly, but that, on balance, makes it the most beautiful-looking vampire movie I have seen.Geissendrfer's camera glides  almost floats  through extremely long takes orchestrated to marvelously florid sequences of pans and tracks. The cast is huge (there is ultimately a veritable plague of vampires, and they decimate whole villages), the settings are unusual and very sumptuous. "Jonathan" doesn't really make movie history. But it substantially adds to one of the oddest and grandest traditions of recent popular art.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: One crewman was killed and five others were rescued by nearby vessels from the Lower Bay of New York Har bor after their 94foot toug boat capsized and sank while escorting a disabled tanker into port.

title: NEW COSMOS LOFTED; SOVIET TEST HINTED
description: MOSCOW, June 15The So viet Union, in an evident effort to demonstrate it is still com mitted to a manned space pro gram, today launched a Cos mos spacecraft with the char acteristics of a manrelated test mission.

description: HONG KONG  The blond American girl, wearing loose fitting pajamas, looked some what incongruous in the Kore an street scene built on the set of the latest production of Hong Kong's Golden Harvest Film Studios.

Gallagher was sentenced to two years in prison and a $10,000 fine today on an incometax evasion charge after an hour and15minute plea in which he asked for leniency and an op portunity to put his life back together again without being put in an institution.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 9  Every day, Koreans stroll through a newly opened sub way station that stretches long block under City Hall Plaza to inspect it and to peek down the stairs to the tracks on which sleek new trains are scheduled to start running early next year.

description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 15Clashes in which stones were thrown broke out in downtown Santiago today between thou sands of antiGovernment dem onstrators and leftists wit( back President Salvador Al lende Gossens in his dispute with striking copper miners.

Pace of Rise Slows In Industrial Output
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 The steep increase in the na tion's industrial production slowed in May, the Federal Re serve Board reported today.

description: The Environmental Protection Agency disclosed yesterday that high concentrations of poten tially dangerous asbestos fibers had been found in the drinking water of Duluth and surround ing Minnesota communities that use Lake Superior for their water supply.

description: Governor Rockefeller signed an executive order late yes terday putting into effect spe cial emergency procedures aimed at settling the strike at 47 cemeteries in the metropoli tan area.

Gallagher was sentenced to two years in prison and a $10,000 fine today on an incometax evasion charge after an hour and15minute plea in which he asked for leniency and an op portunity to put his life back together again without being put, in an institution.

title: ANTONIO GUGNONI
description: Antonio Gugnoni, a restau rateur who had operated the San Marino Restaurant at 236 East 53d Street for the last 23 years, died yesterday at his home, 220 East 54th Street, He was 86 years old.

title: RADCLIFFE EIGHT PACES QUALIFIERS
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 15The Radcliffe College eight oared shell, stroked by Char lotte Crane, sped to a three foot victory over the Vesper Boat Club in a qualifying heavyweight heat of the eighth annual national women's row ing championships today on the muddy Schuylkill River amid ideal weather conditions.

title: New Dean Is Appointed At Yale Medical School
description: NEW HAVEN, June 15The appointment of Dr. Rob ert W. Berliner, deputy di rector for science of the Na tional Institutes of Health, as dean of the Yale School of Medicine was announced today.

title: Confusion Persists on Price Rollbacks
description: Scores of industrial price in creases were rushed through in the days and hours imme diately preceding President Nixon's 60day price freeze after speculation that the White House was plannir; to take action circulated through the business community.

title: SILVER FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Silver futures contracts rose yesterday, indicating, according to observers of the market, that European speculators did not think President Nixon's price control plans would curb inflation.

title: In Innsbruck, Austria, new apartment buildingsmoneymakers for realestate developersrise near Alpine peaks Second Home Craze Is Threatening Serenity of Big Alpine Region
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria From the smiling lakes near Salzburg to the majestic En gadine Valley in Switzerland, the Alpine scene tends this season to have a building crane in the foreground.

title: Mrs. Christine Paddock Is Married
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 15  Mrs. Christine Watling Paddock and Will Reeves Gregg Jr., both of Cincinnati, were married here this afternoon in a gar den ceremony performed at the home of the bride's t mother, Mrs. Frederick Spof ford Gilbert, by the Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. of the First Presbyterian Church, assisted by the Rev. Grant A. Morrill of St. Mark's Epis copal Church. divorce, as did the bride groom's.

title: RealEstate Groups Sue to Void Repeal Of RentRise Setup
description: Realestate groups went to court yesterday, as expected, to seek nullification of a measure enacted over Mayor Lindsay's veto by the City Council on Thursday that re peals the local rentcontrol law's maximumbaserent for mula. The formula permits rent rises of up to 7.5 per cent a year in many controlled apart ments here.

title: Aircraft Contracts Awarded
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration has received a $57.5 million Air Force award for the production of 20 C130H cargo planes. The United Technology Center, a unit of the United Aircraft Corporation, obtained a $49.7million Air Force con tract for building a Titan III rocket engine.

title: Fake Campaign Letter Brings Term of a Year
description: TAMPA, Fla., June 15 (AP) George Hearing received today a maximum one year prison sentence on charges of distributing a fake letter in Florida in the Presidential campaign of 1972.

title: Let Them Learn
description: Murry Bergtraum, chairman of the Board of Educa tion's finance and budget committee, has taken a sensible and humane, position in opposing the meanspirited de mand that school officials ferret out children of illegal aliens and expel them from the city's classrooms. In replying to pressures by members of the City Council Finance Committee, Mr. Bergtraum held that the school authorities ought not be required to take over the law enforcement agencies job of policing the illegal entry problem. Quite apart from its effect on the relationship between the schools and the estimated 65,000 youngsters involved, Mr. Bergtraum pointed out that you do not handle the problem of illegal aliens by punishing the children.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: IN A PRELIMINARY MOVE to Phase 4, President Nix on announced a 60day freeze on prices at the levels in the first eight days of June. Excepted were farm prices, wages and rents.... Prices of steel, copper, rubber tires and other major commodities recently raised were rolled back volun tarily.... Reaction to the freeze was mixed, with business groups voicing concern about production and distribution problems and consumer groups and unions arguing that the freeze was too limited.... The C.A.B. suspended all airline rate increases until Sept. I. The I.C.C. postponed all rail road increases.

title: Friday's Fight
description: St. Cloud, MinnDuane Bo hick, 210 pounds, Bowlus, Minn., knocked out Doug Kirk, 200, Lowell, Mass., 2 rounds.

title: Bees Accused of Pollution
description: CLIFFSIDE PARKBees, of all things, have become the center of an ecological scuf fle between Paul Semenick, the owner of a centuryold castle high over the Hudson River, and the workers at a group of industries along the foot of the Palisades.

title: A History Of Phases: Not All Work Well
description: Among Western Industrial countries since World War II, direct government interven tion to control the wageprice spiral has been far more com mon in Europe than in the United States.

title: It Would Take 18 Years to Visit Every Museum
description: THE late Robert Ripley used to claim that if all the Chinese in China were to march at a smart clip 20 abreast past a given point their parade would go on forever as new generations replaced the old. A similar notion of endlessness, somehow both comforting and troubling, comes to my mind when I contemplate the shuffling American museumgoer and the staggering number of museums in ex istence for him to visit. At last count there were 6,657 mubeurps In the United States and Canada, five new ones were opening every week and they were at tracting visitors at the rate of 700 mil lion annually.

title: More Than One Year in Europe
description: BRUSSELSThe White House deci sion to call this The Year of Europe for American foreign policy is un fortunate. The slogan implies the Europe everyone talks about but which doesn't really exista com munity of Common Market nations with some semblance of unified ad ministration. It also implies that major improvements in relationships between the United States and this community can be accomplished in 1973not likely.

title: He Comes to Praise the Met
description: COMPELLED by the firm conviction that when everyone agrees in the art world there is much to be said for the other side, I have studied more than 100 separate writingssome 200, 000 wordsabout the great Metropolitan Museum art selling scandal, or disaster, or menace, or catastrophe, according to what you read. Some balance could be pro vided, especially on these pages. To do this, I have taken the main points of the critics one by one.

title: Bridal Held for Miss Hilary Gillespie
description: In St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church yes terday afternoon, Miss Hilary Gillespie became the bride of Hamilton Hadden 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Had den of Jericho, L.I., and Man chester, Vt.

title: Soviet Executes Armenian
description: MOSCOW, June 16 (Reuters) Soviet newspapers have re ported that the director of home appliances store in Armenia has been executed for systematically defrauding the Government and that two men in Baku, the capital of Azer baijan, have been sentenced to death for selling adulterated fruit drinks.

title: Democrat Sues Republicans For $5Million on Wiretap
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) R. Spencer Oliver, whose tel ephone at Democratic headquar ters was tapped by the Water gate conspirators last year, has filed a $5.5million damage suit against President Nixon's cam paign committee and 16 indi viduals.

title: Are the Soviet Deals Overrated?; Prospects For Trade: Real but Restrained
description: Hotel rooms are at a pre mium in Eastern Europe this summer. American business men, excited by visions of vast markets once beyond their reach, are crowding Moscow, Warsaw, Bucharest and other capitals behind an Iron Curtain that appears to be rusting rapidly.

title: Leftists Emerge in Italy's Church Ranks
description: ROME, June 16  A left wing in Italy's Roman Catholic hierarchy, with ideological po sitions close to Marxism, emerged in a meeting of the nation's 300 bishops this week.

title: Yes, She Watched the Whole Thing
description: I CAN'T believe I watched the whole thing: Three straight hours of tele vision commercials. No, it wasn't some kind of Madison Avenue torture treat ment; the commercials were occasionally interrupted to bring the 1,500 viewers program of entertainment, such as a song by Sally Stark, who warbled, Mr. Whipple [of toilet tissue fame] isn't squeezing Charmin, you see, Mr. Whipple is squeez ing me. It was the 14th annual Clio Awards ceremony. in Philharmonic Hall, where 71 (yes 71) gold statues, or Clios, the Oscars of the advertising industry, were handed out the other night for the year's best television commercials.

title: Pennsylvania Panel Yielding to Court On Audit of Home
description: HONESDALE, Pa., June 16A state legislative committee has bowed to a court order di recting it not to seek the re lease of an audit of a home for retarded children whose former owner is under a mur der indictment.

title: Science and Richard Nixon
AROUND THE
description: If beets, melons, radish, beans, etc. have not germ inated within two weeks, resow.... The wet month of May may have resulted in rotted seed.... Water deeply during hot spells to encourage deep root growth.... Scale are in the crawling stage; control with Sevin and malathion.

title: Boy, 8, Taking Illicit Swim Drowns in Pool on 41st St,
description: An 8yearold Brooklyn boy, missing since Friday night, was found drowned yesterday morn ing in the Sunset Park swim ming pool, where he had ap parently climbed an eightfoot high fence to get in.

title: Where Belasco Once Acted
description: AMERICA'S wild west during the second half of the 19th century was not without culture. The larger centers had their opera houses, which were less likely to offer opera than plays, popular musical shows and concerts. One of the more famous ones was Piper's Opera House in Vir ginia City, Nev. It was run by John Piper, with the assistance of his brother, Henry, who took over an existent theater in 1867. John maintained monopoly on local entertainment: every time someone established a rival theater, he bought it and put it to some kind of other service such a dance hall.

title: A Monument to the AirMail Pioneers
description: SOUTH PLAINFIELD Where the first hangar once stood, Holiday Inn is near completion. Where additional hangars were once situated, a Howard Johnson now sits. And where the first biplanes of the transcontinental air mail service once took off and landed, a shopping mall and an industrial park have been built.

title: Power Grid Finds. Energy to Spare
description: NEWARKA combination of poli tics, power pools and gas turbines was among the factors that spared New Jer sey from blackouts and brownouts dur ing the heat wave that constricted power supplies in neighboring New York last week.

title: Police
description: For years, New York's police have been trying to cope with the problem of the crooked cop. Last week an effort was begun to come to grips with another police deviant: the brutal cop.

title: 30 in Westchester Debut
description: RYE, N. Y., June 16 Thirty young women were presented at the 35th West chester Cotillion at the Shen orock Shore Club here to night. The grand march was led by Miss Kerri Beaumont Hubbard of Corwin Spring, Mont., a granddaughter of Mrs. Beaumont Packard of Bronxville, a founder of the dinner dance. Another debu tante was Miss Katharine Artley Pennell, whose moth er, Mrs. Edward H. Pennell of Bronxville, was general chairman of the cotillion.

title: Restless Acquirer And Still Looking
description: Charles G. Bluhdorn's sprawling brass and wood desk is surrounded by deep, soft divans and chairs, Callers, suppli cants and salesmen who make their way into his 42d floor office get swallowed up and find themselves peering between their knees at the chairman of Gulf & Western Industries.

title: Camera World
description: NEW photography, maga zine entitled PHOTO World is now available on American news stands.
