Inspired by the well known French  magazine PHOTO, this new periodical is actually an adaptation of that magazine and is priced at $1. Although the current issue is dated simply Sum mer, 1973, associate pub lisher Fred Smith has indi cated that plans are for the magazine to become monthly sometime later this Year.

title: East Side Drive Captures Springbrook Jumper Title
description: BLOOMINGDALE, N. J., June 16East Side Drive, owned by the Homestead Stables of Sparta, N. J., won both the touch class and the timed first jumpoff events today to score 10 points and capture the open jumper championship at the Springbrook horse show.

title: Nourishing Mix at General Mills
description: MINNEAPOLIS  A dis erect sign at the entrance tc the stunning corporate corn plex in suburban Golden Val ley announces that this is the home of Betty Crocker and of Counterweight.

title: Health Classes Required For Restaurant Workers
description: The personnel of all restau rants cited as major violators of the city Health Code will be required to take a threehoura day, fiveday food protection training program at the Health Services Administration's Health Training Center.

title: The Old Gray Museum, She Ain't What She Used to Be
description: AT the Ontario Science Centre in suburban Toronto you can step into an exhibit and feel your hair stand on end as 800,000 volts of static, and harmless, electricity pass over your body. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York you can look at a 17thcentury harpsichord, a baroque trumpet or a Yugoslav double flute and listen, with earphones, to their music. At the Mod erna Museum in Sweden you can dress up in costumes provided by the Stock holm Opera. At New York's American Museum of Natural History last winter you could have helped with the casting of a bonebybone reproduction of the museum's prized 200millionyearold Stegosaurus, a type of dinosaur noted for its dermal armor.

title: BritishAmerican Tobacco's Big Move
description: LONDONAny time we can borrow at 8 per cent and make 10 or 11, we think it is part of our job to do it.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Curing Damp Basements: Part II
description: AS described here in last week's column (June 10) the homeowner who is trying to cure a damp basement should first make certain that the prob lem is not actually being caused by condensation on the inside, rather than from seepage or leakage that al lows water to penetrate from outside. Next, he should eliminate as many outside sources of water as possible, such as those caused by poor surface drainage or improp erly installed gutter down spouts. Then he should repair all cracks or holes in the foundation walls with a wa terproof vinyl patching ce ment or a quick drying hy

title: 6 WELFARE WORKERS ACCUSED OF FRAUD
description: George F. Berlinger, the state's Welfare Inspector Gen eral, charged yesterday that six employes of the city's Depart ment of Social Services had illegally received welfare pay ments while they were collect ing salaries from the depart ment.

title: Through the Years With Betty Crocker
description: More than 115,000 tourists a year troop past a portrait of Betty Crocker on their way to visit her kitchens at Gen eral Mills headquarters.

title: Peter Charles Rupert Gerard And Sophie May Are Married
description: GREENVILLE, Del., June 16Christ Episcopal Church in Christiana Hundred was the setting here this after noon for the marriage of Miss Sophie Christine May, a jun ior at American University, to Peter Charles Rupert Gerard, who attends George Washington University. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Calhoun W. Wick of Christ Church and Msgr. Henri I. Foltz of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Dole's Rogue Takes 2 Sailing Honors At Huntington Y.C.
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., June 16 Edward Dole's Rogue cap tured Division A honors and the trophy for the best cor rected time in Huntington Yacht lub's. annual Day Race ;today on Long Island Sound.

title: J. E. McKinney, Ann M. Marrow Marry in Chapel
description: The Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyte rian Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Ann Macklin Marrow, daughter of Mrs. Macklin Marrow and the late Mr. Marrow, to James Edward McKinney.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
The trouble with the truth
description: Multiple Choice Question for the 1970's: The Government of the United States lies: (a) never; (b) only when it has to for reasons of national security; (c) whenever it feels like it, wheth er or not it affects national se curity; (d) whenever it feels like it, to protect itself from domes tic political embarrassment; (e) most of the time; (f) all of the time.

title: MRS. CORTLANDT FISH
description: CARMEL, N. Y., JuneMrs. Viola Pratt FiSh, wife of Cortland!: Fish, a retired real estate broker, died today in Putnam County Hospital. She was 83 years old.

title: CARTER IS WINNER AS FOG ENDS RACE
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., June 16An enormous mass of fog, moving with incredible swift ness, blotted out the Watkins Glen Grand Prix road course shortly after 6 P. M. today to put an abrupt end to the third TransAmerican championship race of the season.

title: Travel Notes: A.A.A. SoftPedals
description: THE threat of gasoline shortages continues to confront Motorists like a slowblinking yellow caution light, but severe Inconvenience for travelers this summer appears unlikely. The American Automobile Association, which makes weekly surveys of gasoline stations throughout the country, has re ported that only a small percentage are rationing fuel and it says that shortages will probably be encountered only in occasional local instances in the South east and Northwest. As a result, the AAA sees no reason to advise its mem bers to change their vacation plans. It has, however, warned that gasoline prices. might go up and that drivers might have to stop for gas more often than usual if rationing becomes wide spread.

title: RIVA RIDGE OPPOSES BEE BEE BEE TODAY
description: BOSTON, June 16 (AP)Riva Ridge will be out to avenge his defeat in last year's Preakness when he meets Bee Bee Bee tomorrow in the 39th running of the $50,000 added Massa; chusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

title: Helaine Kass Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Helaine B. Kass, a su pervisor with the American Arbitration Association, to Warren H. Tockerman, budg et manager for the Arlen Realty and Development Cor poration. Miss Kass is the the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Kass of Hicksville, L. I. Mr. and Mrs. Louis Tocker man of the Bronx are parents of the future bridegroom. The couple plan to wed in September.

title: Palmer Is Man to Beat
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 16At an age that would make him the oldest golfer to win the United States Open cham pionship, 43yearold Arnold Palmer was described by Lee Trevino as the man to beat tomorrow in the final round of the tournament.

title: Watchung Preserve Getting New Center
description: MOUNTAINSIDE  A $500,000 trailside nature and science center is being erected on the edge of the 1,965acre Watchung Res ervation near here, Hopeful ly, it will be ready for use in November.

title: Sandy Blue Upsets Cellist In $84,300 Hollywood Oaks
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 16 (UPI)  Sandy Blue staged powerful stretch drive today to score an upset victory in the 28th running of the $84,300 Hollywood Oaks for the 3yearold filly championship of the Hollywood Park meeting.

title: State's Inmates Produce Book of Poetry
description: TRENTONIn an effort to demonstrate the positive po tential of creativewriting pro grams for prison inmates, the New Jersey State Council on the Arts has published a book of articles by prisoners at Bordentown Reformatory.

title: 2d Suspect Held in South In City Policeman's Death
description: SPARTANBURG, S. C., June 16 (UPI)New York City de tectives flew here today to bring back two men suspected of being part of a stickup team that killed an offduty New York policeman on June 2.

title: Slims'
description: The Jersey Shore Tennis Classic, third stop on this sum mer's Virginia Slims Circuit, has been scheduled for the Allaire Racquet Club, Aug. 1319.

title: Mitchel Field Housing Case Has Its Day In Court
description: The ultimate disposition of a 500acre tract of valuable land in the middle of Nassau County may depend on a Federal judge, who since last Monday has been hearing a suit that seeks to force the county to include lowincome housing in the tract's devel opment.

title: SENIORS AT ANTIOCH HOLD GRADUATION
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, June 16  Antioch College seniors and their parents gathered on the campus this morning for an informal graduation ceremony but the bitterness associated with a 45day student strike that ended June 6 was not for gotten.

title: AID CUTS PLAGUE DENTAL SCHOOLS
description: The proposed cutbacks in Federal money for research and training have placed the city's dental schools in the same pre dicament as its medical schools wondering how they will sur vive and, if they do, where they will get future dentistry teachers.

title: The Region
description: For the two candidates in the runoff Democratic mayoral primary, it was the week of the great search: for money, for the issue and for a way to raid the con stituencies of the two con testants eliminated the week before.

title: 60 HELD IN CLASHES AT A BUILDING SITE
description: KALKASKA, Mich., June 16 Sixty people arrested in out breaks of violence this week in clashes between union and nonunion building trades work ers at the construction site of a Shell Oil Company gas proc essing plant near here will be arraigned in Kalkaska County District Court here Monday morning.

title: Reform of Tuition Aid Urged
description: TRENTON  Among the controversies that erupted in the Legislature last year was one stemming from Governor Cahill's proposal to increase the tuition at state, colleges. The Legislature eventually approved a Republicanspon sored plan to raise the tuition by $185 a year, despite Dem ocratic pleas that the incre ment would adversely affect poor students.

title: Jane Hammond Wed to A. H. Corbett Jr.
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 16  The marriage of Miss Jane Rebecca Hammond, to Alfred Hoyt Corbett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Corbett of Washington and Portland, Ore., took place here this afternoon. The Rev. Edward B. Fiske performed the non denominational ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis James Hammond Jr., parents of the bride.

title: A Lack of Gas Is Welcome for Some
description: SEWAREN  Mrs. Fred Klopsch is facing a gasoline shortage, and she is quite happy about it.

title: Youthful Swimmers Hail Opening of Pools in City
description: Despite rain and a lack of sunshine, large numbers of young swimmers turned out at the 36 city pools that opened yesterday, the Parks, Recrea tion and Cultural Affairs Ad ministration reported. The 37th pool, on the lower East Side, was closed pending repairs.

title: Carlsen's Sweetness Wins Star Class Sail Off Sea Cliff
description: SEA CLIFF, L.I., June 16Rolf Carlsen's Sweetness, mak ing her first start of the season, won Star Class honors in to day's Hempstead Harbor sail ing races conducted by the Sea Cliff Yacht Club.

title: Magazine Sets Oaks Mark; Windy's Daughter Is 11 th
TwoThirds in Gallup Poll See Nixon Involvement in Watergate
description: With public awareness of the Watergate affair reaching 97 per cent, twothirds of those persons surveyed in a Gallup Poll in early June said they believed President Nixon was involved in either the planning or the coverup of the case.

title: Handbook Will Aid Brooklyn Planners
description: The officials who are try ing to guide the development one of the largest plan ning districts in Brooklyn got new tool last week, a 200 page, computerproduced en cyclopedia of the area's so cioecconomic conditions.

title: Bogie Gains 3Point Edge In ArmsWhite Trophy Sail
description: MILFORD, Conn., June 16Russ Bogie of Lake George, N.Y., sailed his One Over Par to victory in both races today for a 2point lead in the 37th an nual Star Class regatta for the ArmsWhite Trophy. The races were sailed on Long Island Sound off Milford Yacht Club.

title: State Assigns Dollar Value to Farmland in Effort to Preserve
description: ALBANY, June 16  New York State has set an official dollar value on various cate gories of farmland in all parts of the state, except for New York City, ranging from a minimum of $20 to a maximum of $1,400 an acre.

title: Robin Kinnear Becomes Bride
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 16Miss Robin Wood Kin near and David Bruce Ander son, who were graduated last month from Duke University, were married here this after noon in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Harold Bassage.

title: Watergate Raises Serious Governmental and Constitutional Issues
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Watergate case has broad ened from a rivulet to a rip tide, leaving serious political, governmental and constitution al issues bobbing in its wake.

title: BREITEL OUTLINES VIEWS ON COURTS
description: Associate Judge Charles D. Breitel of the State Court of Appeals, the RepublicanLiberal candidate for chief judge of the state, opened his campaign last week by outlining his views on the courts, twitting the Democratic primary con fenders and expressing con cerns about the cost of a media campaign and the fundraising problems of judges.

title: RISING ISRAELI TOLL ON ROADS A CONCERN
description: JERUSALEM, June 15Israeli drivers are compiling a high fatality rate on the na tion's overcrowded highways.

title: Proms and liking Ike
description: I hope you'll forgive me if I don't partake of the current feast of nostaliga for the fifties. I am class of '49, which disqualifies me right there. Sing no Howdy Doodie Time for me: I rarely watched early television. A later generation ogled as An nette's sweater filled out; for me, adolescent stir rings were aroused by a moviemag pic of Elizabeth Taylor demonstrating that she had obviously out grown her training bra. Leather jackets and souped up cars and Bill Haley and d.a. haircuts were as dis tant from me as the mating customs of the Trobri and Islanders. Truth to tell, I thought Elvis was thug, and though I liked early rhythm and blues (we had it in the fortiesrace musicbut it had to be smuggled across the state line from some mysteri ous station in Kentucky, or maybe it was a 50,000 watter in Radio Free Tijuana), songs like Teen Ager in Love made me reach for the Dramamine. As you can see, I'm a hopeless reactionary.

title: WALL STREET
description: If the New York Stock Exchange has its way, the cost of buying a share of American business will go up this year, for the second time in two years.

title: the traveler's world
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.They call it the Historic Triangle, the three points being Jamestown, site of the first permanent English colony in the New World; Colo nial Williamsburg, the great 18thcen tury restoration, and Yorktown, where Lord Cornwallis struck his colors to be gin the end of the Revolutionary War. One would be hard put to find another area so small that encompassed so many primal events in the founding of the United States of America.

title: Computer Ends Old Days on Waterfront
description: This thing here, the big, burly shipping executive said as he happily punched away at a computer console in a downtown office building, is here to stay.

title: Girl and Policeman Killed; Suspect Critically Wounded
description: BERKELEY, Calif. June 16 (UPI)A suspected prowler fa tally shot a police sergeant and a 4yearold girl hostage today, and then was critically wound ed by policemen as he emerged from a house where he held two other persons.

title: Subverting America
description: If political tyranny ever comes to America, it is likely to arrive not in the guise of some alien ideology such such as Communism or Nazism but as a uniquely Ameri can way of preserving this country's traditional values. Instead of tyranny being the dramatic culmination radical protest and revolution, it can come silently, slowly, like fog creeping in on little cat feet.

title: Butler Is Concerned About Its Young
description: BUTLER  When a couple turns up at the local Munici pal Building to take out a marriage license, Borough Clerk Carl Whritenour greets them warmly, sees to their requirements and gives them a plastic bag filled with an as sortment of household needs: soap, headache remedies, mouthwash andother articles that would be pur chased on begin ning a home. I've been doing itsince 1949, Mr. Whritenour said, and I think we may be the only community in New Jersey that has any such gift for young people. Some of the products have changed over the years, but the idea re mains the samethings new lyweds will need right away to get started.

title: New Hampshire Replaces Insurance Commissioner
description: CONCORD, N.H., June 16 (AP) John Durkin, who built reputation as a consumer cham pion during five years as state insurance commissioner, has been replaced by Frank Wha land, an insurance consultant.

title: The many selves of Sybil
description: The Sybil of Flora Rheta Schreiber's casestudy bears as a diagnosis the peculiarly dra matic form of hysteria known as multiple personality. Like the Eve of The Three Faces of Eve, she acts at different times as if she were different people; however Sybil has not three but 16 personalities.

title: Badillo Asks Antitrust Suit on Fuel Cost
description: Representative Herman Badil lo called yesterday for a city antitrust suit against major oil companies who he said had created a phony fuel shortage to get higher prices.

title: IDAHO TOWN FACES EXTINCTION ORDER
description: OBSIDIAN, Idaho, June 16This tiny central Idaho com munity, little more than a col lection of summer homes, mo tels and service stations set around a 50yearold post of fice, has suddenly found itself facing possible extinction.

title: Archives Director Named
description: Carlyle R. Bennett, an archiv ist for the Federal Government, has been appointed director of the New York City Municipal Archives and Records Center, the city announced yesterday. Mr. Bennett has been director of the Federal Archives and Records Center of the National Archives and Records Service in New York since 1953, super vising its accession and dis posal branch.

title: Philadelphia Prison Shifts 235 After Slaying of Two Officials
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 16Holmesburg Prison, where the warden and deputy warden were stabbed to death two weeks ago by inmates jailed for earlier police killings, is losing 235 of its most troublesome prisoners.

title: AirMonitoring Network Being Improved
description: TRENTON  In a move designed to further combat the smog problem, the state's airmonitoring network is be ing outfitted with new equip ment.

title: 16 Bergen Scales Condemned in May
description: HACKENSACKThe Ber gen County Division of Weights and Measures con demned 16 scales and ad justed 35 of the 327 scales inspected in May, according to James A. Pollock, super intendent of the department. Of 970 gasoline pumps in spected, 52 were condemned and 32 were adjusted.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Jules Irving Honored For Work in Theater
description: Jules Irving, whose eightyear tenure as director of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center is drawing to an end, was presented with the 12th annual Margo Jones Award following last night's per formance of his company's production of A Streetcar Named Desire.

title: Civilian Pilot Is a P.O.W. In Laos, the U.S Confirms
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI)  Emmet Kay, a civilian pilot working in Laos for a concern on contract with the Central Intelligence Agency, has be come the first confirmed Amer ican prisoner of the Commu nists since the January agree ment on ending the war in Viet nam.

title: Christine Whitney Wed To Thomas H. Clark
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., June 16Miss Christine Whitney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Harding Whitney, was married here this after noon to Thomas Havemeyer Clark, son of Mrs. Benn Wainwright Jesser and the late Thomas Ray Clark. The Rev, Alan C. Stover per formed the ceremony in the Old Paramus Reformed Church. Both families are of HoHoKus.

title: WASHINGTON WINS SCHUYLKILL RACE
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 16The University of Washington, stroked by Kathy Roberts, left four other crews well behind in winning the lightweight eight title in the eighth annual women's national rowing cham pionships today on the Schuyl kill River.

title: LouisvilleFlorida AutoTrain Is Set
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The AutoTrain, which shut tles travelers between Vir ginia and Florida along with their automobiles, will be ex tended next year to a second route, according to officials of the line.

title: Liberia to Get $5.6Million
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, June 16 (AgencePresse) The World Bank and its affiliate, the Inter national Development Associa tion, will lend Liberia $5.6mil lion towards a fiveyear high way maintenance and develop ment program, the Finance Ministry announced here.

title: Astronaut's Father Dies
description: DENVER, June 16 (AP)Dr. John Leonard Swigert, an oph thalmologist and father of Apollo 13 astronaut John, L. Mercy Jr., died yesterday at Mercy Hospital. He was 69 years old. Mr. Swigert was in jured May 2 in a threecar col lision here and had remained in the hospital since then.

title: South African Ring Victor
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 16 (AP)Arnold Taylor of South Africa out pointed Billy Waith of Wales in a 10round featherweight bout tonight.

title: Scheckter: Record in RentaCar
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., June 16  Who is Jody Scheckter? And why are they saying those wonderful things. about him?

title: On Great Issues, Law and Politics Are Intertwined
description: At the first sound of a new argument over the United States Constitution and its inter pretation the hearts of Americans leap with fearful joy. The blood stirs powerfully in their veins and a new lustre brightens their eyes. Like King Harry's men before Harfleur, they stand like greyhounds in the slips, straining upon the start.The first contest to be formally resolved was between Mr. Cox and the committee. The prosecutor wanted Senator Ervin to suspend public hearings; he feared that they would make his search for the truth more difficult by ex posing the potential prosecution case, and by creating so much publicity that it would be hard to bring people to trial.

title: Colgate and Penn to Meet In Scrimmage on Sept. 15
description: Colgate and Pennsylvania, as they have last two years, will meet in a preseason football scrimmage in 1973. The scrim mage will be held in Hamilton Saturday, Sept, 15.

title: Watergate Impact: New Words, New Leaders, New Ideas
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Since a band of five Republi canhired burglars was discov ered inside the offices of the Democratic National Committee on June 17, 1972, new words have been added to the lan guage of politics: Watergate, shredder, inoperative.

title: Sunday Observer; Seeing Ame??ka
description: MEMORANDUM OF EX TENUATING CIRCUM STANCES. ATTENTION V.S.O. PETROSINOV, DIRECTOR BUREAU TRAVEL ARRANGE MENTS, TOP COMMISSAR DIVISION, MOSCOW. EYES ONLY AND BURN BAG. ASHES TO SHREDDER.

title: Courses Are Urged On Environment
description: TRENTON  The New Jersey Education Association has asked educators through out the state to weave en vironmental education into all subjects, where appropri ate, and at every grade level.

title: Preston Farr Marries Miss Katherine Putnam
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 16The Passionist Monas tery Chapel was the setting here at noon today for the marriage of Miss Katherine Elizabeth Putnam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lowell Putnam, to Preston Witherspoon Farr, son of H. Bartow Farr Jr. and Mrs. Anne Witherspoon Farr, both of New York.

title: Chinese Dig Wells to Beat a Drought
description: PEKING, June 16What happens to an agricultural area, with a population of about 45 million, when most of its riv ers dry up for two years? This problem has been faced and, it seem?? to a large extent solved by the Province of Hopeh, which surrounds the municipal area of Peking.

title: Judge Says He Rejected Offer in Secret Spy Unit
description: SEATTLE, June 16 (UPI)A Federal judge says he turned down an offer in 1970 from the former White House domestic adviser, John Ehrlichman, to head an intelligence evaluation committee when he learned that the committee would be kept secret from the public. The Seattle PostIntelligencer said today in a copyrighted article.

title: Mrs. Hicks Runs for Council
description: BOSTON, June 16 (AP)For mer Representative Louise Day Hicks has filed nomination papers for a seat on the Boston City Council. Mrs. Hicks, a Democrat, was defeated last Congress.

title: A Bright Young Man Confesses
description: WASHINGTONThe witness was boyish and handsome, his manner belying the occasion, his testimony articulate in a brisk, precise way whether he was pronouncing guilt or dispensing his estimate of innocence. And what Jeb Stuart Magruder had to say before a Senate committee last week had been largely forecast for the last several months.

title: Plaque Unveiled Upstate Honoring Times Founder
description: LIMA, N. Y., June 16A plaque was dedicated here today at the birthplace of Henry J. Raymond, who founded The New York Times in 1851 and was its first editor, in a ceremony at tended by officials of the newspaper and local civic leaders. Mr. Raymond was born in 1820.

title: LINDSAY REJECTS ROW BID FOR AID
description: Mayor Lindsay has rejected a request from Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metro politan Transportation Author ity, to restore $100million in operating subsidies for the Transit Authority during the fiscal year that begins July 1.

title: School Boards Weigh Uniting
description: TRENTONSchool boards throughout the state are con sidering whether to form loose coalitions, based on New Jersey's 40 new legisla tive districts, as a more ef fective way to press home their problems here when the 1974 Legislature convenes.

title: SKYLAB REHEARSES TRIP BACK TO EARTH
description: HOUSTON, June 16 (UPI)The Skylab astronauts success fully rehearsed their trip home today, but missed recording new explosion on the sun be cause the earth blocked their view.

title: MONZON IS NAMED FIGHTER OF YEAR
description: I'm not going to retire as long as I keep getting offers to defend my title, said Carlos Monzon, world middleweight champion, yesterday. Monzon attended the Boxing Writers Association dinner here where he received the Edward J. Neil Award as fighter of the year.

title: Volunteers Aid the Bereaved
description: Hundreds of Jewish, dead were buried in cemeteries in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island last week despite the strike by gravediggers in the metropolitan area, now go ing into its second week.

title: Looking Jefferson in the Eye
description: CONWAY, Mass.Time is famous for its ironies: a national anniversary fallen in an incongruous year; a noble past and an ignoble present brought face to face by the conclusion of century, two centuries. Men have tasted that irony in other ages but never more bitterly than we do today. For months we have been preparing to celebrate the bicentennial of the, estab lishment on this continent of the first, great, selfgoverning people in history. And now, on the eve of that celebra tion, we discover that a conspiracyo ripening among officials and function aries of the Republic over this same period of time, appears to have been a conspiracy to undermine precisely the institutions and practices of self government.

title: U.S BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: There is a tradition in the United States, dating to the nation's founding, of an in formed public being a vital element in the process of government.

title: Yankee Quiz Kids No Whiz Kids
description: ANAHEIM, Calif, June 16The Yan kee quiz kids would just as soon avoid any attention they might receive for their appearance on Sports Challenge, the television sports quiz show. Ralph Houk, Bobby Murcer and Thurman Mun son filmed a show against Frank Robin son, Nolan Ryan and Bobby Valentine, and it was like batting against fastballer Ryan in the dark.

title: Stamps
description: THE Boston Tea Party made the American Revolution inevitable. The die is now cast. The Colonies must either sub mit or triumph, wrote King George III of Great Britain to his Prime Minister, Lord North.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONThere was one thing worrying Soviet correspondents in Washington in advance of Leonid Brezhnev's arrival.

title: Two F111's in Collision In Cambodia
description: HONOLULU, June 16 (AP)Two United States Air Force F111 aircraft collided over Cambodia today and one of the swingwing jets crashed, the Pacific military command reported.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read with interest the two articles  one condemn ing city living, the other praising itunder the head line 'Somewhere, Over the Rainbow, Lies the Good Life but Where? [June 3].

title: Basic Pointers For Good Compost
description: MANY gardeners have of sorting their ANY gardeners have adopted the practice wastes for recycling. Though it takes a little re organizing of refuse, you quickly get the new habit of putting vegetable garbage, papers, bottles and cans in different containers.

title: IRT Train Kills Man
description: A man of about 30 years of age who had been hit by train was found dead on the Lexington Avenue IRT subway tracks near the 59th Street sta tion early yesterday. The police tentatively identified the man as Robert Cannon. They said he apparently worked for the Singer Sewing Machine Com pany.

title: If You Go...
description: ... to see the Brahman and Jain temples of Khajuraho, a morning flight is operated daily from Delhi by Indian Air Lines, the country's domestic carrier. The flight takes about 90 minutes. The plane lands at Agra before going on to Khajuraho, and then Benares; it returns to Delhi each afternoon on the same route. The trip also can be made by rented car from Delhi, the distance being about 375 miles. While the new motel is the first hostelry expressly for drivers, there are two modern hotels as well: the Traveler's Lodge and the Hotel Chandela. The 24 temples, famed for their carvings, are in three groups, known as Western, Eastern and Southern, according to the direction they face.

title: LAZAR BARS CURB ON CABS IN CITY
description: Michael J. Lazar, chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, yesterday objected to proposals for ending taxi :cruising in the city as a means of reducing automotive air pollution.

title: Photography
description: Quin some time ago, Barbara Rose, New York magazine's art critic, pledged herself and the magazine to a policy of regular coverage of pho tography as a medium of cre ative expression.

title: College StrikeOat King Gets Top Twins'
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 16 (AP)  Edward Nor man Bane, a lefthander who set the National Collegiate strikeout record at Arizona State, today became the first bonus player ever intention ally assigned directly to the Minnesota Twins majoi, league roster.

title: U. S. Is Turning Back to Controls In Running Battle Against Inflation
description: WASHINGTON  The United States's oldest estab lished permanent floating controls game returned to a familiar venue last week.

title: Abigail J. Pessen Is Bride of Lawyer
description: At the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn last night, Miss Abigail Judith Pessen, a law clerk with Fed eral District Judge Whitman Knapp, was married to Rich ard Tobin Wolf, a lawyer with the city's Department of Investigation. Rabbi Joseph Singer performed the cere mony.

title: Donkey's Zebra Mate In Israel Gives Birth
description: JERUSALEM, June 16 (Reu ters)The director of the Bib lical Zoo in Jerusalem said today that a zebra that had been mated with a donkey has given birth.

title: The Region
description: A $2.5billion corporation has dis covered what minority group families have known all along: It isn't always easy to break into the suburbs.

title: A Field Day for Strawberry Lovers
description: Front early June to mid July, Suffolk County goes on the quick weightgain straw berry diet, indulging in a profusion of strawberries accompanied by the inevita ble drifts of cream and fur ther prolonging the agony with jams and preserves. Farms and roadside stands announce Local Strawber ries. Residents and visitors throng to buy or pick quart baskets of the fresh fruit at bargain prices.

title: Toll Road Patrol Setup Is Revised
description: TRENTONIn the wake of the fatal shooting of a state trooper on the New Jersey Turnpike last month, the Stare Police have instituted twoman night patrols on ??th the turnpike and Garden state Parkway.

title: Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid
description: THERE are half a dozen things wrong with Sam Peckinpah's Pat Gar rett and Billy the Kid. Bob Dylan's lyrics sound silly and a century out of place. Dylan himself, in his acting debut, is saddled with a char acter who calls himself Alias. (Alias what? Just Alias.) When asked who he is, Dylan replies, That's a good ques tion. Other such portentously symbolic moments are strewn throughout the film, rocks on which both characters and audience stumble.

title: EDWAB, POWERS GAIN STATE TENNIS FINAL
description: Neal Edwab of Roslyn, L. I., is University of Miami player, upset topseeded Steve Ross of Brooklyn, 62, 62, in the semi finals of the New York State men's tennis championship yes terday. Ross was the defending champion.

title: World News Briefs
description: ATHENS, June 16  The Greek Government plans to seize real estate worth more than $300million owned by the deposed King, Constantine II.

title: Cambodia Cuts Phantom Soldiers, but Her U.S.Financed Roster Is Still Padded
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 16 (AP)Phantom soldiers in the Cambodian Army are disappearing, but senior West ern diplomats say officers are still collecting Americanfi nanced salaries for about 44, 000 nonexistent troops.

title: The New Left and the Origins of the Cold War; By Robert James Maddox. 169 pp. Princeton:; Princeton University Press. $7.95.; Who started it? You did! Who says so? We do! Who are you?
description: This is an important book on an important subject.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:
N.A.A.C.P. ASSAILS CRITICS OF BLACKS
description: A magazine article that an gered many blacks, especially in academic circles, has been challenged by the N.A.A.C.P. in a rare attack by that group on the American Jewish Commit tee's publication Commentary.

title: Television
description: AT a recent gathering of American Broadcasting Company affiliates in Los Angeles, Walter A. Schwartz, president of ABC Television, declared that broadcasters should be en couraged to present pro grams dealing with signifi cant moral and social issues. He called for progressive programing, dealing real istically with adult and often controversial topics in a manner that reflects soci ety's social consciousness and demand for such pro graming.

title: 3 RESIDENTS SEIZE 2 MEN IN MUGGING
description: A State Liquor Authority Commissioner, a Manhattan Democratic district leader and a businessman recalled with enthusiasm yesterday how they had chased, grappled with and captured two suspects in doorway mugging Friday night in Washington Heights.

title: On With the Show in Clinton
description: CLINTON  The summer season has arrived once again in this picturesque Hun terdon County town and, also once again, has endowed the community's venerable Music Hall with a troupe of talent ed performers.

title: MANILA CRITICIZED ON CURBS ON PRESS
description: JERUSALEM, June 16 (AP) The International Press In stitute has protested restric tions on the press in the Philip pines, Chile, Greece, Singapore and Sri Lanka (formerly. Cey lon).

title: Officers Fail to Meet as Vietnam Fighting Goes On
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, June 17Fighting con tinued to sputter across South Vietnam yesterday, despite the beginning of the second cease fire Friday, and the local com manders of the opposing forces did not meet as required by the Paris communiqu.

title: Jean Day Wed To Milan Kofol; 5 Attend Bride
description: In the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church yester day afternoon, Miss Jean Brush Day, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert McClelland Day of New York and Buck Hill Falls, Pa., was married to Milan Kofol, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril Kofol of Wantagh, L. I.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR: I have read (with deep regret) Elizabeth Hardwick's essayreview of Doris Lessing's The Summer Before the Dark. May I join you in the hopeexpressed in your own Last Word columnthat her negative reaction will not keep readers away from this fine novel?

title: Multihulls to Race to Bermuda
description: Anything you can do, we can do better., That is what multihull sailors like to tell monohull sailors. Most of the time they can, too, for it is acknowledged that two hulls or three hulls are faster than one hull. However, because of this, multihulls usually are not allowed to race with monohulls, and true comparisons are difficult to make. Now conies the multihull race from Newport, R.I., to Ber muda, (next Saturday), a bi event that monohull skippers hold in evennum bered years. Although the tri maran and catamaran fans wan't admit it, they're out to show the singlehullers.

title: The Fighting Gangs
description: The jackets are called colors. Em blazoned on the back with ominously colorful symbols of machismo, they parody the style of the archetypal out law gang, the Hell's Angels.

title: Beame Says Badillo Is Linked To Law Firm Dealing in Realty
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame, who has been accused by Representative Herman Ba dillo of being indebted to the real estate industry, said yesterday that Mr. Badillo was associated with a law firm rep resenting some of the city's largest real estate interests.

title: Fatherless Family of 4 Is a Success At Farming
description: BRANCHBURG TOWN SHIPDairy Farm Visitation Day this year is today, Fa ther's Day. And what makes it ironic for Mrs. Grace ants and her three sons is that, in the six years since Mr. Staats was killed in a tractor acci dent, they have managed to make Brookview Farm a showplace.

title: Works by Two Artists On Display in Bergen
description: PARAMUSWorks by two New Jersey artists, a figura tive painter and an abstract sculptor, are on view this week at the Bergen Commu nity Museum.

title: Diana Khinoy Has Nuptials
description: OVERBROOK HILLS, Pa., June 16Miss Diana Mar garet Khinoy was married here at noon today to Peter Blake Reed, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Reed of Levittown. Kenneth Smith, senior leader of the Philadel phia Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's par ents, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Khinoy.

title: For a Few at Ox Ridge, Dressage Is the Show
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 16To almost everyone at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club, tomor row's Boyden International Grand Prix for jumpers, the final event of the fiveday horse show, is the most im portant equine happening of the year.

title: B. A. McMurray to Wed Jane Woodward
description: SEVERNA PARK, Md., June 16  Mr. and Mrs. Henry Woodward have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane O'Dono hoe Woodward, to Brien Aloysius McMurray, son of Dr. Joseph P. McMurray of New Rochelle, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Isabelle McMurray.

title: MINIM DROPS PLAN ON ELECTION
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 16 Prime Minister Gough Whit lam, faced with dissidence in his Labor party and a slip in popularity ratings of his Gov ernment, has dropped a plan to recall the House of Repre sentatives ahead of schedule as a step toward an early new election.

title: Will the Real Irene Please Stand Up?
description: IT IS probably stretching the word a bit to call the version of Irene that is currently playing at the Minskoff Theater a revival since almost twothirds of the score heard in this produc tion was not in the original Irene that opened in New York in 1919. Such wholesale revision leads one to wonder what was so dreadfully wrong with that original score, par ticularly since it ran on Broadway for 670 perform ances, played another 399 in London and was at one time being performed by 17 road companies.

title: Briton Says Coeducation Aids Happy Marriage
description: LONDON, June 16 (Reut ers)  People educated in mixed schools are more like ly to have happy marriages than those from singlesex schools, according to the re sults of a survey in a Gov ernmentbacked publication.

title: INVESTIGATOR SEES CHARGES OF PERJURY
description: SAN DIEGO, June 16 (UPI)Indictments of Government of ficials for perjury will be major result of the Watergate affair, Representative Bob Wil son, Republican of California, a Watergate investigator, said today.

title: Watergate Got Its Name From Old Canal Locks
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Watergate complex got its name from the section, called Watergate, that lies just west of the Foggy Bot tom area where the State De partment is situated, accord ing to Carlo Neal, a spokes man for the Watergate Hotel.

title: Salutatory In Latin Is All Greek To Audience
description: PRINCETONThe way it seemed to John J. Schire last week was:

title: Darcy B. Kelley Becomes Bride Of a Physican
description: COLEBROOK, Conn., June 16  Miss Darcy Brisbane Kelley, granddaughter of the late Arthur Brisbane, colum nist and editor with the Hearst newspapers, was mar ried here this afternoon to Dr. Richard Steven Bockman, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Bockman of New York and Ellenville, N. Y.

title: U Nu Must Leave Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 16 (AP)The Thai Government has requested that U Nu, the former Burmese Premier who has been living here in political asylum, leave the country early next month, the Thailand radio re ported. It said that the Thai Foreign Ministry had expressed dissatisfaction over U Nu's re cent interview in a local Eng lishlanguage newspaper, in which he called for a free and fair election in Burma. He also offered to meet Gen. Ne Win, the present Burmese leader

title: Fantasies for after dark
IRK, A POODLE, IS BEST IN SHOW
description: MALVERN, Pa., June 16Capt. Joe Tacker of Honolulu, who has been flying planes for the Hawaiian Airlines for 23 years, is a man accustomed to making fast decisions. It took him just eight minutes today to pick his best in show at the Bryn Mawr Kennel Club's 53d annual fixture, which drew 1,794 dogs to the grounds of the Radnor Hunt Club. Tack er's winner was a black mini ature poodle, Ch. Villa Russe Bismark, owned by Mrs. Ruth Wurmser of Louisville, Ky. I guess he liked the wet track, she said. Wet it was, for the final Was held in a driving rain.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
Cosmos Have a Power Shortage
description: Except for the game against Atlanta, the New York Cosmos, the defending North American Soccer League champion, haven't looked anything like the Cosmos of last year. Gor don Bradley of the Cosmos has tried different combina tions, but whatever the offensive minded coach has ex perimented with hasn't worked. Today, when the Cosmos meet the Montreal Olympiques at Hof stra, Bradley will try a new formation.

title: DEAN SAID TO TELL OF KROGH REPORT IMPUGNING NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, June 16John W. Dean 3d has told Gov ernment investigators that high White House aide in formed him early last January that the orders for the burglary of files belonging to Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist came from the oval office of President Nixon, sources close to the Watergate case said to day.

title: A great mix
description: Modern and Early American? The city residence of the Ernest Rubensteins proves something that sophisticates have known all along: The spare func tional lines of contemporary design are complemented by naive country crafts. The Rubenstein's budding col lection of contemporary art fits beautifully into the city coop they bought when they decided commuting was not for them. But they had long been attracted by rustic country antiquesa trestle table, a hutch, country bench. Designer Lila Schneider of Planned Office Interiors brought the two together (and even introduced Eastern prints) in an unorthodox but utterly compatible mix.

title: Paul Alper the Fiance Of Joanne Lisa Fogel
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., June 16Mr. and Mrs. Ben R. Fogel have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Joanne Lisa Fogel, to Paul Alper, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Alper of New York. An Aug. 4 wedding is planned.

title: In Cold Print: Taking Stock
description: Is there any area of publishing that you regard hopefully at this point? a leading Wall Street analyst was asked in the course of a recent roundtable on publishing sponsored by The Wall Street Transcript. His reply:

title: GANG WAR STRIKES COAST CHINATOWN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 16An unusually violent gang war has erupted along the narrow, noisy streets of San Francisco's famed Chinatown.

title: Anne Winton Plans Bridal
description: LITTLE FALL, N. J., June 16Mr. and Mrs. David H. Winton of Little Falls and South Woodstock, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Baldwin Winton, to Rodman Richardson Black Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Black of Cum berland, R. I., and North Newport, N. H.

title: Tennis Out to Curb the Unruly
description: A showdown is finally ap proaching on how to deal with tennis players guilty of unsportsmanlike conduct.

title: Women Then and Now
description: When I was graduated from Bran deis University in 1959, Pierre Mendes France and Edward R. Murrow spoke of lofty goals and remote global prob lems. They were addressing the young men in our class who were expected to forge out and do the world's work. Even if we women had been included in their remarks, we would have exempted ourselves. The price of excellence and accomplishment for woman was simply too great. As Matina Horner demonstrated in her study on Why Bright Women Fail, the fear of success has a chilling effect on young women. We would rather be popular than President. We would rather marry power than pos it.

title: State Control of Zoning Asked To Give Mixture of Housing
description: The words seemed innocuous and were almost buried in the 234 pages of a report on local government in New York State sent to Governor Rockefeller last week after more than two and a half years of work.

title: Sanford and Son Is White to the Core
description: WEAPONS are not always obvious. Every one knows at a glance that a gun or knife is a dangerous weapon which can do fearful damage. But in the hands someone very clever or someone very naive, the most innocentappearing things can be just as dan gerousa drapery cord, a table fork, a household cleanser. A kiss, if you happen to be Judas.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: IRECENTLY saw Elaine May's new movie, The Heartbreak Kid, and found it frightening, al= though excellent. When thought back to her first film, A New Leaf, I was struck by the great similar ity of tone between the two movies; that is to say, by the enormous pessimism, by the biting, contemptuous humor, and by the conviction that the world is populated entirely by cheats and gulls, by victims and victimizers, by either colossal egotists or amazing fools. There seems to be no center in Ms. May's work, no character to which we can attach ourselves, no matter how lightly, and feel that this person, if far from perfect, is at least morally acceptable, someone to whom we can throw our sympathy and support. In plain words, there's simply no one to root for.

title: Lightnin Leads Fleet to Newport
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 16Overcast skies and 12to15 knot winds provided perfect conditions as the Annapolis, Md., Newport, R. I., yacht race got under way today.

title: Charles Forrest Palmer Dead; Early Public Housing Advocate
description: ATLANTA, June 17 (AP) Charles Forrest Palmer, a for mer special assistant on hous ing to President Franklin D. Roosevelt and organizer to one of the country's first Federal public housing projects, died here today at the age of 80.

title: Forsythe Reluctant to Label Himself
description: MOORESTOWNEdwin B. Forsythe was a freshman Congressman even before he officially began his first full term in the House of Repre sentatives. By his seventh week on the job, he was a veteran.

title: Con Ed
description: At a Consolidated Edison command post last Tuesday, engineers watched the num bers on an electronic digital gauge click slowly upward, recording a spiraling appetite for electricity by 10million New Yorkers on a day of record heat.

title: San Juan Port Plan Stirs a Dispute
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., June 16 A proposal to build a super port and oil refining com plex capable of transshipping a million barrels of crude oil daily to United States ports and refining 600,000 more barrels has run into opposi tion from environmentalists and proindependence groups here.

title: Connecticut Inn Has Fire
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 1.6A score of residents were evacuated from the Roger Sher man Inn early today when smoke, starting in the kitchen area, filled the building, Hotel officials said that a few up stairs rooms would have to be closed. The fire is under inves tigation since no cooking was going on when the blaze started.

title: A Prometheus by Puppets
description: GREAT NECK, L. I.Ever since Judy whacked Punch on the head in England two cen turies ago, puppet shows have been considered mainly light comic entertainment, suitable for the child and the childlike. The National Theater of Puppet Arts, Inc., a Long Islandbased group of puppeteers, is attempting to bring serious drama back to the puppet stage and adults back to the audience.

title: Dave Anderson
description: OAKMONT, Pa, June 16They're easy to distinguish because they're black in stead of the usual shiny steel.

title: FEW CMS MADE ON PRICING RULES
description: The Internal Revenue Service kept two offices open in Man hattan and Brooklyn yesterday to answer inquiries about the President's new 60day price freeze, but only a few people took advantage of the weekend service.

title: Mass Wins Pole Position
description: HOCKENHEIM, West Ger many, June 16 (AP)Jochen Mass of West Germany aver aged 124.89 miles an hour in Surtees TS15 today and won the pole position for tomor row's Formula Two race.

title: HOME FURNISHINGS
description: Carpeting, a major item in home furnishings, has been hit by inflation but not enough to affect total vol ume.

title: Learning Geography
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Strange as it seems, until fairly recently the schoolchildren here never learned anything in geography class about their own polyglot city. They yawned through classes on the state capitals, the tribes in Africa and the export of copper from Chile.

title: Christy Carpenter Is Married To Harvey A. Levin in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Miss Christy Carpenter was married to Harvey Alan Levin in a garden ceremony here this afternoon at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Carpenter. The 200 guests, according to Mrs. Carpenter, who is Elizabeth (Liz) Carpenter, former press secretary and staff director to Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson, included people from the Johnson years in the White House. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Mark Levin of Sewickley, Pa.

title: Correction
description: As the result of an editing error, a story in The Week in Review of May 27 incorrectly said that Daniel Ellsberg had been acquitted. His case was dismissed before it went to the jury.

title: LEXINGTON PARK MONMOUTH VICTOR
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., June 16  Lexington Park, under they high weight in his division, and Dartsum, the lowweight horse in his, were the winners today, in the split Oceanport Handicap at Monmouth Park.

title: Music
description: HISTORICALLY, the American congressman has shown little interest in the performing arts, and one can understand that. What possible thrill could it be for congressman to hear Joan Sutherland sing when he has heard such artists as Jarres McCord and John Dean? Can he feally be moved by the experience of tome baggykneed actor masquerading as Macbeth when he need only drop, by his committee room any day and listen fo a reallife Macbeth or Hamlet or Bru lin? He has only to open the door to bring in half a dozen Tartuffes or Julien Sorels, each eager to play out his per sonal drama for congressional delecta tion. A congressman's daily life is crammed with artful performances, plots, unmaskings, exeunts, alarums and excursions (in Washington argot, jun kets).

title: Bay Ridge Housing For Aged Is Debated
description: The City Planning Com mission heard hours of heated debate last week over plans for a housing develop ment for the elderly sin the Bay Ridge section of Brook lyn as it met in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: CHINESE NEWSMEN FIND U.S. FRIENDLY
description: TOKYO, June 16 (AP) China's Government press agency has distributed a re port from its United Nations correspondents giving a glow ing account of their visits to American cities in the last 12 months.

title: JUNGLE SOIL SAID TO LACK FERTILITY
description: In the world's great tropical jungles, appearknces can be de ceeptive. The vast and luxuriant vegetation is a facade, an out ward magnificence cloaking the poverty beneath.

title: Our Native Overtakes Hearts of Lettuce and Captures $100,000 Ohio Derby
description: CLEVELAND, June 16 (AP)Our Native, the favorite, staged a fast finish from deep in the pack to win the $100,000 Ohio Derby today at Thistledown.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: (VANCE) PACK ARD: (A) NATION OF STRANGERSBusinesses... de pendent upon com puters... have recently gone... into demanding night people.... With several mil lion dollars tied up in computers which, unlike humans, don't need to sleep... , the company managers feel guilty if the machines are idle.

title: ExNew Yorkers Stir Ohio
BQLI Bulletin Board
description: BellmorePaintings by Marion P. Rep sis, reception today, 2 to 5 P.M. at the public library, 2288 Bedford Avenue.

title: Eastern Tennis Opens Aug. 20 at So. Orange
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., June 16 (AP)The 47th an nual Eastern tennis open tournament will be played at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club here Aug. 20 to 26.

title: Top Education Post Still Goes Unfilled
description: TRENTON The president of the State Senate, Alfred N. Beadleston, confirmed this weekend what was apparent when Governor Cahill was denied renomination in the Republican gubernatorial primary election: that a Cahill nominee for State Commis sioner of Education probably would not be approved by the Senate.

title: Pilic, Seeking to Practice, Turned Away at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 16 (UPI)Nikki Pilic of Yugo slavia, who is at the center of the threatened Wimbledon boy cott, was refused permission to practice today.

title: Calendar of Upcoming Events in Motor Sports
description: TodaySports Car Club of America L&M 5000 championship race at Watkins Glen, N. Y. First heat: 1:25 P.M., final 5 P.M.

title: F.D.A. Grants Extension On Stiff New XRay Rules
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI)The Food and Drug Ad ministration has granted a oneyear extension on strict new requirements for diagnostic Xray equipment.

title: Train Kills L. I. Man
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., June 16 (AP)David G. Espa raza, 60 years old, of Long Beach, L. I., was killed last night by a Penn Central com muter train that struck him as he was walking along the tracks next to the fivefoot high station platform here.

title: Watching the Open Is No Picnic
description: OAKMONT, PA., June 16 (AP)They fight aggravat ing traffic jams over winding singlelane roads, pay $2 park, walk a mile to the course and thenspend eight to hours being shoved, pushed and herded like cattle by hard hatted marshals carrying restraining ropes.

title: Treasure Hunt in Queens
description: A treasure trove of archi tectural building styles Federal farmhouses, Greek Revival, Gothic revival and high VictorianItalianate man sions, plus solid company town rowhouses has been tracked down in Queens by Mrs. Ellen Fletcher Rose brock, an art historian with a special enthusiasm for architecture. The buildings reflect architectural prefer ences flourishing during post Revolutionary, Civil, War and postCivil War days.

title: Letters: An Agent's Liability
description: To the Editor: In his May 20 Traveler's World column, entitled A New Legal Umbrella for Tourists?, Paul J. C. Friedlander reported on the case in which Mrs. Helen Buchholtz of Bayside, Queens, won her negligence suit against Sirotkin Travel, Ltd., and was awarded a partial refund of the cost of a three day weekend in Las Vegas.

title: THE OPENINGS OF THE WEEK
description: THE FAGGOTTomorrow, Truck and Warehouse Theater, 7. A musical Al Carmines.

title: Dealers Discover New Talent
description: AS a finale to the New York exhibition season, a group of 14 uptown galler ies recently put on a New Talent Fes tival. It lasted 10 daysJune515and is expected to be repeated (with new names, of course) next year, when an even larger number of galleries will be asked to participate. Meanwhile, the American Fed eration of Arts is said to be planning smaller show culled from the New Talent gathered together this year, and there is also the possibility of a paper back book that will serve as a permanent catalogue of the Festival.

title: German Soccer Star To Go to Real Madrid
description: MOENCH ENGLADBACH, West Germany, June 16 (UPI) A West German interna tional soccer star, Guenther Netzer, will play for Real Madrid starting July I, said officials of his Club.

title: Tales of The Warrior Ants; By Dee Brown. 127 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $4.29. (Ages 10 to 15)
description: I think I was about 11 when I was first horrified and fasci nated by Carl Stephenson's story of Leiningen Versus the Ants. Terror stalked the jungle as one man battled 20 square miles of South American driver ants in scene after scene like this one, showing the demise of a pampas stag: Blinded, it had reeled in the madness of hideous torment straight into the ranks of its persecutors, and now the beast swayed to and fro in its death agony... After six minutes the white polished bones alone re mained. Terrific. Other fiction al ants of my acquaintance were nothing to thiscertainly not La Fontaine's Frenchclass moralist La Fourmi, nor even the fascistic swarms encoun tered by Wart in The Sword in the Stone.

title: San Diego to Get Hearing On Bid to Restrain Padres
description: SAN DIEGO, June 16 (UPI)A hearing on a request for permanent injunction to keep the San Diego Padres from mov ing to Washington will be held here June 29.

title: '74 FUNDS SOUGHT FR POVERTY UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 Congress is expected to move ahead next week with legisla tive action to save the Office of Economic Opportunity from the oblivion assigned to it in President Nixon's budget pro posal.

title: M.I.T. Aide to Retire
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 (AP)Dr. F. Leroy Foster, di rector of Lowell Institute at Massachusetts Institute of Tech nology for 14 years, will retire June 30. He will be succeeded by Dr. Bruce D. Wedlock, a former faculty member in the department of electrical engi neering.

title: ALEXANDER MOSKOWITZ
description: SMITHTOWN, L.I., June 16 Alexander Moskowitz, a lino type operator for The New York Times for 35 years until his retirement in 1963, died to day at the Smithtown Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 99.45 67th Road, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: DROUGHT BLIGHTS SUBSAHARA AREA
description: OUALLAM, Niger, June 11Every two steps Souleman Tiam flicked a gnarled stick fitted with a metal bladea dabainto the yellow sand and made a shallow hole in the moist earth. His wife, carrying their youngest of three children on her back, followed him and threw at least 10 millet seeds into each hole and with a stamp of her bare feet, she covered the seeds.

title: Vonder Scholl Fiancee Of John C. Kniley Jr.
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., June 16 Thomas Francis Scholl has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss yonder Scholl, to John Charles Kniley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kniley of Cummaquid, Mass. Miss Scholl is the daughter also of the late Mrs. Scholl.

title: New South, New City New What?
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.The traveler to the smaller cities and towns of Amer ica used to run the risks of the old downtown hotels, with their musty rooms, sagging beds and lurching ele vators. Then came the bright new era of motels, strung like the glittering beads of a national chain along the broad new highways and freeways and thruways that linked us.

title: Russell Schlote Jr. Weds Miss Kubiak
description: KINGS POINT, LI., June 16 Lieut, Karen Ann Kubiak of the Navy Nurses Corps was married here at noon today to Russell Charles Schlote Jr., a veteran of service with the Navy and a student at Cleve land State University.

title: News of the Rialto
description: IT was one of the most dramatically romantic moments of the century, that December day in 1936 when Edward VIII stepped to the micro phone in Windsor Castle and told the world he could not carry on as king of England without the help and sup port of the woman I lovethe Ameri can divorce, Wallis Warfield Simpson. For months now London has been re living the episode through Royce Ryton's play, Crown Matrimonial, and New York will get its chance come fall.

title: MRS. RICHARD HARKNESS
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Mrs. Richard L. Harkness, wife of the former Washington correspondent of The Philadel phia Bulletin and commentator for the National Broadcasting Company, died today at the George Washington University Medical Center.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was erroneously report ed in The. New York Times on June 3 that the only un defeated Yale athletic team this year was the women's tennis team. Actually, this team won eight matches and then lost one to Princeton. The freshman (men's) soc cer team was Yale's only undefeated team this year.

title: Women Are Making Waves in Rowing
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 16 The Amazon syndrome has been rocking the boat in women's rowing, and the talk here at the national championships is about weight lifting, ergometers, running the steps of stadiums and the flattening of the bosom.

title: Barbara Brosious, Radcliffe, 73, Wed
description: BOSTON, June 16Miss Barbara Lee Brosious, who was graduated magna cum laude Thursday from Radcliffe College, was married here this morning to Second Lieut. Theodore G. Lindsay Jr., U.S.M.C.R., a magna cum laude graduate of Harvard College, class of 72, The Rev. Theodore Evans performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University.

title: John Wayne: I Know Most of You Feel the Same as I Do
description: PERHAPS no one can make the American dream seem deader than he who dreams it still. John Wayne, the Duke, dean of patriotic action flicks, turns out to be their biggest casualty: even now, at this point in history, he continues to believea faith that he has now committed to vinyl in America, Why I Love Her (RCA LSP4828). As pictured on the album cover, his nobly squinting eyes gleam with the grandeur of the American experience, the greatness of her people. Behind his sunbaked, leathery visage,  topped off with sweatbrimmed cowboy hatthere flutters the stars and stripes, their red and blue primary colors reiterated in the album's lettering. Another photo of the Duke on the back cover, sitting tall and some what corpulent in the saddle, presents us in addition with a signed letter stating in part: I. know most of you feel the same as I do about our coun try. My hope and prayer is that everyone know and love our country for what she really is and what she stands f6r. This may well be the most honest record jacket ever designed. No visualiza tipn can adequately represent Beethoven's Ninth or Sergeant Pepper; but this jacket not it tells reducing the record itself to superfluity.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two years after a city budget freeze forced a cutback the hours that the New York Public Library's research facilities could be used, the library is reverting to almost the same schedule it operated on before the freeze. The expanded schedule, which goes into effect July 2, was made possible by $1.2million in capital funds earmarked for support of the libraries.

title: Patricia Pippitt Is Wed
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 16Miss Patricia Ann Pippitt and Peter Withington Hall were married here this afternoon in the first Presby terian Church by the Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M, Pippitt of London, where Mr. Pippitt is man aging director of the Bank Xerox Corporation. The bride groom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hiland W. Hall of New Canaan, where Mr. Hall is executive vice president of Raymond Control Systems.

title: Movies
description: THE big guy with the pug face and the pop eyes sits with his shirt opened and his feet propped up on the coffee table in his suite at the SherryNetherland. His hair is still wet from the rain and his new wifehis fifthis visiting friends elsewhere in the hotel. He holds  a shrimp on a toothpick in one hand and a ginger ale in the other and confesses that his days as a tequilaandbeer man ended 10 years agoabout the time his marriage to Katy Jurado ended.

title: Two new ways with an old technique
description: The last time we ran a story on cook ing in unglazed clay pots, readers asked for still more recipes to try. Here are two that will enhance a hot weather menu and get the pot off the shelf again. Most main dishes or vege table combinations that are usually roasted or braised can be cooked in clay with a few adjustments. For in stance, less liquid is required in a pot roast or stew, and there is no need to prebrown the meat.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: A major real estate devel oper, H. R. Shapiro, Inc., has announced plans to build three new luxury apartment buildings in Manhattan. At the same time, the developer has acquired a hotel on the Upper East Side, the Croy don.

title: Feminism in the $12,000ayear family; What do I do for the next 20 years?
description: I'm short, fat and 45.

title: Barker Is 62, 75 Victor In New Jersey Title Tennis
description: KEARNEY, N. J., June 16Bob Barker of Sands Point, L. I., opened play today in the New Jersey State men's tennis cham pionship with a 62, 75 victory over Jim Ambrose of Millburn at the Arlington Players Club. Barker is seeded No. 3.

title: India Wins Team Golf
description: JAKARTA, India, June 16 (AP)  India broke a first place tle with the defender, Ja pan, and won the sixth Asian amateur golf team champion ship by three strokes today. The Indian team shot 219 to 222 for the Japanese on the last day of the ninenation tourna ment, finishing with an 876 to tal.

title: A'S BEAT RED SOX ON RUN IN Till, 43
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 16 (AP)Deron Johnson's second runscoring single of the game snapped a seventhinning tie to lay and sent the surging Oak land A's to a 43 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Wife Fishes, State Cuts Bait
description: LANSING, MICH. June 16 (UPI)Mrs. Vicki Lange of Ann Arbor, was told that only husbands could buy family fish ing licenses in Michigan. She complained to the Michigin Department of Natural Re sources. The agency, acting on an opinion of the Attorney General's office has ordered Michigan outlets to start sell ing the licenses to wives, too.

title: Japan to Seek the Remains Of War Dead in Six Areas
description: TOKYO, June 16 (Reuters)Missions are to go to six areas in the Pacific in an attempt to collect the remains of Japanese killed in World War IT, the Welfare Ministry has announced here.

title: Miss Lindsay Wed Outdoors On L. I. to James E. Morrison
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., June 16In the outdoor chapel of St. John's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Marion Austin Lindsay was married to James Ed ward Morrison, director of field work for special serv ices for the Country Dance and Song Society of America in New York.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Skindiving for a mess of sea clams off Martha's Vine yard a few days ago, I came across several empty chan neled whelk shells and re solved that I would add whelks to the list of edible creatures I take from the sea.

title: Indochina
description: WASHINGTONNearly five months after peace was declared, another Viet nam agreement was reached in Paris last week and another ceasefire was proclaimed, And the new text looked almost like the old.

title: AN ANCIENT SKULL DATED IN FLORIDA
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 16 (AP)  The skull of a man who lived on a dry and windy Florida peninsula that was cold in winter has been confirmed as 10,000 years old, a state archeologist said this week.

title: Bank Street College Gets New Head
description: Francis J. Roberts has been elected president of the Bank Street College of Education by the college's board of trustees.

title: Tunney Voices Caution
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 16 (UPI)  Senator John V. Tunney, Democrat of Califor nia, said yesterday that it was premature to talk of im peadhing President Nixon be cause of the Watergate affair, but added that Congress should create some way to impeach an entire election.

title: Boros, Palmer Share 4Way U.S. Open Lead
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 16 An older golfer has to win once in a while, said 43yearold Arnold Palmer today after he tied with 53yearold Julius Boros and two younger profes sionals, John Schlee and Jerry Heard, for the lead in the United States Open. Each had a 54hole total of 210, three under par.

title: MALAYSIA BUILDS A ROAD TO FUTURE
description: KOTA BHARU, Malaysia, June 16 (AP)Tigers come at dawn some days to watch bull dozers cutting a road into the thick jungle of the Malay peninsula.

title: Legislature May Still Act to Curb the Use of Phosphates
description: TRENTONThere Is still a possibility that, before the year is out, the ecology minded Legislature may ap prove a controversial pro posal that would give the state's Department of Envi ronmental Protection the power to restrict, if not ban altogether, the use of phos phates in detergents.

title: New York City
description: New York City's school system is the country's largest and most complex. It has 900 schools, 1.1 million pupils, 60,000 teachers and staff personnel, and 31 community boards. Often beset in the past by labor, racial and administrative troubles, the system periodically provokes the question of whether it is manageable.

title: Open Meeting Slated On StuyvesantTown
description: The City Council's Com mittee on Housing will hold an open meeting at 10 A,M, tomorrow in the Council's meeting room to consider ex tending the tax exemption for Stuyvesant Town for an additional 25 years.

title: Numismatics
description: IN THE old days, it is said, youngsters whose inter est in numismatics had advanced beyond the pocket change stage would find their path to greater ex pertise smoothed by the kind ly counsel of dealers who had not only the time and the in clination to be helpful, but also the necessary abundance of indepth knowledge.

title: Russians Seeking Investment and Trade as Spur for Lagging Economy
Crane Plucks Illegally Parked Cars From Streets in London
description: LONDON, June 16  The newest weapon in the battle to keep London's traffic mov ing is a truckmounted crane that can pluck an illegally parked car off the street in three minutes flat.

title: Power Fails in Scarsdale
description: SCARSDALE, June 16 (UPI) A power failure here early today left 700 homes without electricity. A Con Edison spokesman said a major cable burnout caused the problem in the Garth Road section.

title: INDIAN BUREAU HELD REMISS ON POLICIES
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The Bureau of Indian Affairs is deliberately underfunding programs designed to help In dians develop reservations and protect their natural resources, two former bureau officials have told a Senate committee Tuesday.

title: The Nation
description: Space object 1973.027A continued to orbit the earth last week. It swept, 270 miles high, over continents and oceans, moving swiftly from daylight into dark and back to daylight again, circumnavigating the earth every 93 minutes.

title: Air Force Studying. Feasibility Of Disarnbiguation by Computer
description: ROME, N.Y.  Zbigniew L. Pankowicz, who came to this country from Poland in 1950, speaks English with the exquisite correctness only a nonnative can muster.

title: FORMER P.O.W.'S HONORED BY METS
description: Col. James L. Lamar took his 16yearold son to a baseball game for the first time last night, and few such outings have ever been so fervently anticipated or so genuinely ap preciated.

title: Boys to Sing for Pope Paul
description: NEWARK  The Newark Boys Chorus is scheduled to leave today for Rome, where, together with Leonard Bern stein, it will appear next Sat urday in a special perform ance for Pope Paul VI.

title: Things We Fear Most
description: WASHINGTON, June 16  The Brezhnev visit to the United States is a welcome reminder that the things we fear the most in this capital are often the things that never happen.

title: Williams Wins 2d Sprint; Hilton's 3:55.9 Takes Mile
ExNew Yorker Visits For Wheelchair Games
description: It's funny, all those years I lived in New York I never competed in the national wheelchair games, until came back here last year, said Steve Goldman, I guess it's like New Yorkers who've never been to the Statue of Liberty or the Empire State building.

title: Employment Up 15% For College Graduates
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 16 (UPI)Overall employment of this year's college and uni versity graduates improved about 15 per cent over a year ago, the College Placement Council announced this week.

title: Charity Ball to Aid Morristown Center
description: MORRISTOWNA charity ball to benefit the Community Medical Center of Morris town will be held next Satur day at the former mansion of Hamilton McK. Twombly. The home, in Madison, is now part of Farleigh Dickin son University.

title: Nancy Revell Tindale Is Married
description: THOMSON, Ga., June 16Miss Nancy Revell Tindale was married here this after noon to Kenneth Barnhart 3d of South Pomfret, Vt., where the bridegroom is di rector of the Ottauquechee Regional Planning and Devel opment Commission. The Rev, C. Edward Reeves Jr. per formed the Episcopal cere mony at Hickory Hill, the home of the bride's step father and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Brown of Spar tanburg, S.C., and Thomson.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The nation today faces severe inflationary prob lems, i almost without prece dent n a peacetime economy. Certainly, we are seeing rates of inflation that vir tually no one would have anticipated a year or so ago.

title: Watergate Grows A Year After Raid
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 One year after the burglary, the accepted definitions of Watergate have come to in clude (1) a plot within Presi dent Nixon's reelection cam paign to use criminal tactics against the Democratic opposi tion and (2) a perjured cover up among high Presidential aides.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: HAROLD R. SHEAFFER
description: NEPTUNE, N. J., June 16Harold R. Sheaffer, retired vice president of Metals Disinte grated, a metals reduction con cern in Union, died today at Jersey Shore Medical Center here. He was 75 years old and lived in Sea Girt.

title: Gardens
description: PORTSMOUTH, R. L HIGH on a green slope overlook ing Narragansett Bay not far from Newport, R. I. a fat lion and docile elephant stand facing each other. Neither one has made move toward the other in nearly 40 years. They can't. They are plants root ed deeply in the soil and growing fatter each year.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: Muggings and Vandalism Said to Increase in England
description: LONDON, June 16 CAP)Vandalism, muggings and mindless aggression toward property and persons rose substantially in England and Wales during 1972, the Home Office said this week.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:
BEEMAN CAPTURES ETCHELLS22 RACE
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. June 16John Beeman's Hust ler again captured Etchells22 Class honors today as 46 boats sailed with the Port Washing ton Yacht Club in the Cow Bay area, Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association regatta.

title: A monstrous, miraculous novel about monsters and miracles
description: According to the ancient legend of the Blessed Ines which, in all its per mutations, pervades this novel, in the 18th century a beautiful daugh ter of a powerful South American family was suddenly and mysterious ly cloistered in a convent specially built for her on a family estate be cause it was believed she was either a witch or a saint, or perhaps both at the same time. Some claimed to have seen a horrible head with ears like batwings flying through the air on moonlit nights, bearing Ines's lovely face; others recalled how, by piety, she miraculously saved the convent from destruction by earth quake.

title: L.I. Traveling Camps Escape Stringent New Regulations
description: Many thousands of Long Island children going off to camp on the Island or else where in the state will be protected this year by the most stringent camp regula tions in the nation.

title: HERMAN J. SCHECTMAN
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 16 Herman J. Schectman, founder of H. Schectman & Co., Inc., brokerage firm, dealing in the sale of pharmacies, died here yesterday in Mount Sinai Hos pital. He was 85 years old and had lived in New York before retiring in 1970.

title: C. M. Coe Marries Deborah Matthews
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 16Miss Deborah Gren nell Matthews, daughter of State Representative John G. Matthews and Mrs. Matthews of New Canaan, and Charles Martin Coe of Canton, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Coe, were married here this evening.

title: LIBERTY STAKES WON BY MR. CORRELATION
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 16Send him to the front at the start and keep him there, were the instructions issued to Buck Thornburg by Danny Perlsweig, the trainer, prior to the Key stone Handicap at Liberty Bell this afternoon and the jockey followed them perfectly.

title: Two U.S. Players Take Tennis Finals
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 16Mrs. Billie Jean King and Erik van Dillon won the singles titles in the $75,000 Notting ham grasscourt tennis tourna ment today.

title: S. K. Kleiner Fiance Of Darlene Diamond
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 16The engagement of Miss Darlene Meryl Diamond to Samuel K. Kleiner, son of Mrs. Sidney Kleiner of New York and the late Mr. Klein er, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. J. George Dia mond of Plainfield.

title: Paul Alper the Fiance Of Joanne Lisa Fogel
