description: ACROSS

title: E.P.A. Studies Oxide Controls Disputed by Agency's Officials
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The Environmental Protection Agency is considering a system for controlling emissions of sulphur oxides that is vigor ously opposed by many of its own officials and the principal drafters of the Clean Air Act of 1970.

title: F.T.C. Judge Orders Eaton To Divest Itself of McQuay
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  A Federal Trade Commission judge issued today an order against the Eaton Corporation of Cleve land, requiring the company to divest the McQuay Norris Manu facturing Company, an auto parts manufacturer.

title: POLICEMAN SLAIN IN A HARLEM BAR
description: A man who walked into a crowded Harlem bar waving a gun precipitated a wild shoot out last night in which a police officer, the bartender and an other person were killed and seven others were wounded.

title: Scheckter Slows Down To Win by Modest Margin
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., June 17Scheckter won. What else is new? Well, he is a gentle man: he slowed down so that the finish did not look like Secretariat's lead of 31 lengths. He is modest: he said it came as a surprise that his crew could put it together in only two days and prepare a bor rowed car to win.

title: W. C. BREED JR., 69, LAWYER HERE DIES
description: William C. Breed Jr., a part ner in the Wall Street law firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan un til his retirement last year, died yesterday at the Manhat tan Eye, Ear and Throat Hos pital. He was 69 years old and lived at 131 East 66th Street.

title: Vanya Stars Tie Success to Nichols
description: Inside the new Circlein theSquareJoseph E. Levine Theater, the S.R.O. sign is up. This would be unusual on Broadway at any time, but particularly at the sagging end of the season and es pecially because the play that is selling out every per formance is Chekhov's Uncle Vanya.

title: MRS. GREENBAUM
description: Mrs. Sylvia Sobel Greenbaum, widow of Lawrence S. Green baum, who was a senior partner in the law firm of Greenbaum, Wolff & Ernst and a former chairman of the New York State Board of Social Welfare, died yesterday in Daytona Beach, Fla. She was 77 years, old and had been living here for the last five years.

title: Huntington Beats Bethpage In L.I. Polo Tourney, 10.5
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., June 17The Huntington polo team crushed Bethpage, 105, today to win the Rothmann invitation tournament at Bethpage State Park. Paul Rizzo led the Hunt ington attack with four goals and Fred Braunstein added three.

title: Neglected Agenda
description: One tragic side effect of Watergate is that this monu mental scandal has diverted public and Congressional attention from the disastrous cuts which President Nixon has proposed in Federal funds for pressing social needs. The result could be approval, with inadequate concern for consequence, of a misshapen budget that would cripple the capacity of the nation's cities to meet such problems as education, housing and health.

title: Nixon Leaflets Tied to Alleged Vote Plot
description: The people who ordered the State Assembly campaign lit erature now being investigated by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, also ordered leaf lets urging the reelection of President Nixon, the printer said yesterday.

title: COSMOS DEFEAT OLYMPIQUES, 20
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 17The faultless goalkeeping of Jerry Sularz, Randy Horton's best game of the season and Josef Jelinek's improved play were the main ingredients to day in the New York Cosmos 20 victory over the Montreal Olympiques at Hofstra Stadium.

title: RIVARIDGE EQUALS WHIRLAWAY MARK
description: BOSTON, June 17 (AP)Rival Ridge, the 1972 Kentucky Derby and Belmont Stakes champion, equaled a track rec ord set by the great Whirlaway three decades ago with an easy victory in the $56,050 Massa chusetts Handicap today at Suf folk Downs.

title: DAVE CHASEN DIES; RESTAURATEUR, 74
description: Dave Chasen, a successful vaudevillian, the death of whose art sent him into a sec ond career as one of Holly wood's bestknown restaura teurs, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 74 years old.

title: SPORADIC CLASHES GO ON IN VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, June 18The spo radic fighting that marked the start of the second Vietnam ceasefire on Friday continued yesterday, though there were no reports of major attacks by either Communist or Gov ernment troops.

title: Renewed Friction Is Seen;Between 2 Police Forces
description: A Housing Authority patrol lan's allegation that he was recently beaten by a city police man in the back of a radio car has threatened to revive old interrnittent frictions between the two police forces.

title: 13Hit Outburst Tops PadresStone Wins
description: The Mets again combined strong pitching with a sturdy offensive barrage, to defeat the San Diego Padres, 31, yester day at Shea Stadium, to sweep a threegame series and extend their winning streak to five games.

title: Peking Toasts U.S. Fives

title: Badillo Chides Pollsters About Miscalculations on the June 4 Primary Vote

Her man Badillo said the other day while basking in the 29 per cent vote he received in the Democratic primary that made him eligible for the run off on June 26 againSt Con troller Abraham D. Beame, who received five points more. The reason the poll sters are keeping quiet, Mr. Badillo said, Is that they were so far off in predicting the vote I would get. And knew they would be. They are very weak in polling ghetto areas, particularly where there is a language dif City Hall Notes

title: MalcolmKing: A College Geared to Help Highly Motivated Adults
description: College was out of the question for Marguerite Mar shall when she graduated from high school in the nine teenthirties. She was poor, black and orphaned and it was the Great Depression.

title: INTEREST RATES SEEN CLIMBING
description: Interest rates will continue to climb, the dominant view in the credit markets appears to have concluded.

title: Emotional Return to Russia Buoys Chagall
description: PARIS, June 17Marc Chagall raised his arms to shoulder height and squeezed his biceps appreciatively.

title: Soviet Local Elections Held
description: MOSCOW, June 17 (UPI)Soviet citizens voted today for municipal, district and regional officials, The candidates, as usual, were unopposed. The official press agency, lass, said that 67.2 per cent of the can didates were workers and farmers and that 47.4 per cent were women. The elections are held every two years.

title: National League Monday, June 18, 1973
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES New York 3, San Diego 1. Chicago 9, Atlanta 3 (1st). Atlanta 8, Chicago 5 (2d). Cincinnati 3, Pittsburgh 1 (1st). Cincinnati 5, Pittsburgh 1 (2d). Houston 7, St. Louis 3. Los Angeles 3, Montreal 2 (12 Inn.). Philadelphia 11. San Francisco 7.

title: Off the Track
description: Two recent incidents have underscored the dangerous deterioration of the Penn Central'S commuter operation. The still unexplained delay of more than an hour before the alarm was sounded on May 29, after a fire had broken out in a Penn Central engine beneath Park Ave nue, was followed by the crash of two trains at Mount Vernon which killed one passenger and injured others.

title: M'Dowell Victor in Debut, 41, After 80 Loss
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 17It will be left to the psycholo gists to interpret the outcome, but the Yankees and California Angels played a doubleheader today with different results.

title: Film: Paul Mazursky's 'Blume in Love':The Cast
description: Paul Mazursky's "Blume in Love" is an oddly affecting comedy about a successful Los Angeles divorce lawyer named Blume (George Segal) who is hopelessly in love with his ex-wife, Nina (Susan Anspach). Nina is pretty and almost painfully thin, and she approaches her social work, her yoga and her status as a newly liberated woman with such humorless determination that it's difficult to understand what Blume ever saw in her. That, however, is very much a part of the mystery and the mood of the comedy.The air is chilly, but the sun is warm as Blume wanders around Venice, mostly around the Piazza San Marco, remembering what happened in Southern California in more or less chronological sequence. Not always. He remembers his honeymoon with Nina in Venice before he remembers their meeting at a fund-raising party for lettuce pickers. He even remembers things he didn't see, such as Nina's first encounter with Elmo (Kris Kristofferson), an out-of-work musician who seeks welfare aid from Nina and winds up living with her.Blume is at loose ends, which is virtually the style of a film that is composed of flashbacks. Blume is haunted, sometimes hilariously, by memories of Nina, by memories of his own postdivorce impotence and his visits to an analyst (the same analyst who was in "Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice"), and by memories of life in Southern California.More than anything else, perhaps, "Blume in Love" is a Southern California movie, to such an extent that Mazursky can't resist the temptation to recall Visconti's film version of "Death in Venice" as a rueful background gag while Blume wanders through Venice. It's not terribly funny, but it somehow seems appropriate to Mazursky, a very bright film maker who seems torn between a desire to be hip and a need to ridicule the kind of fraudulent hipness he identifies with life in Southern California.There has been this contradiction in all of Mazursky's films so farin "I Love You, Alice B. Toklas," which he wrote in collaboration with Larry Tucker, as well as in "Bob & Carol" and "Alex in Wonderland," both of which he directed from scripts written with Tucker."Blume in Love," his first solo effort as writer, director and producer, strikes me as being by far his most interesting film to date, a little too self-absorbed and smart-mouthed for its own good, like Blume, but intelligent and full of healthy disrespect and energy.These are also the qualities of Segal's performance as Blume, the sort of man who takes terrible risks for things that aren't worth risks. The divorce, for example, is prompted by the fact that he was caught when, instead of taking his secretary to a motel for an afternoon affair, he took her to his house. Blume's life is full of such suicide substitutes.Miss Anspach's Nina, who begins as such a touchy character, eventually becomes conventionally sweet, not, I suspect, because Mazursky really understands her but because the film has a conventionally comic shape. Kristofferson, so ill at ease in Peckinpah's "Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid," is most relaxed and debonnaire as the musician, and Mazursky himself is extremely funny as Segal's uptight law partner.I also very much liked Shelley Winters in the brief role of a tearful wife who wants a divorce as well as the house, the children, the beach house, the Jaguar and all the money."Blume in Love" is a restless, appealing, sometimes highly comic contemporary memoir. It opened yesterday at the Tower East.

description: WASHINGTON, June 17Conditions that could endanger consumer health have been found in 43 per cent of meat and poultry plants checked in a random survey by the Agri culture Department's Office of the Inspector General, accord ing to an internal report com pleted late last year but never made public.

description: Sellers of gasoline have al ready raised their cumulativ prices by as much as $4bil lion a year because of the fue shortage.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 17The resolutions committee of the United States Conference of Mayors has endorsed the concept of the Nixon Admin istration's major special rev enuesharing proposal but has pledged to seek basic revisions of the proposal in Congress.

title: EDWABTOPS POWERS IN STATE NET FINAL
description: Neal Edwab of Roslyn, L. I., defeated Mike Powers of Glen Head, L. I., 63, 62, 64, to win the New York State men's ten nis championship yesterday.

title: Gothic Novels for Women Prove Bonanza for Publishers
description: Reaching out, he pulled her to him. He saw the stars twinkling beyond her head and smelled the odor of her hair and skin, sweetsmiling and clean, like I good soapand newmown hay... A Portion for Foxes by Jane Mall vaine McClary.

title: Advertising: Wooing the ApartmentHouse Dweller
description: It may not seem so on the island of Manhattan, but in this country the apartment dweller is a member of a minority group.

title: Minisubmarine, 4 A board, Is Trapped 360 Feet Down
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Monday, June 18The first attempt to rescue four men trapped in tiny research submarine 360 feet deep in the Atlantic failed last night when divers found the craft trapped in the tangled wreckage of a scuttled de stroyer.

title: AARON H. RUBIN
description: Aaron H. Rubin, a realestate investor, died yesterday at Uni versity Hospital of complications following surgery. He was 80 years old and lived at 35 Sutton Place.

title: Black Youth's Quest for Job Sketches a Study in Despair
description: On hot days. Freddy Rivers, a 21yearold black in search of a job paying more than chump change, stands on the steps of a crumbling stoop with twisted railing.

title: MINORITY WOMEN ARE PLEDGED AID
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 17 A group of 350 prominent wo men from 42 states pledged themselves today to more ex tensive efforts on behalf of minority women.

title: Miss Robbins Wed To Jay Jacobson
description: Miss Peggy Robbins, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey A. Robbins of Valley Stream, L. I., was married here last evening to Jay Jacobson, who is on the finance staff of the Ford Motor Company in Dearborn, Mich. He is the son of Mr, and Mrs. Jack Jacob son of Las Vegas, Nev. Samuel A. Spiegel, Assistant Administrative Judge of the State Supreme Court, per formed the ceremony at the Hampshire House.

title: Carson and the Movies Sweep Ratings on Mexican Cable TV
description: MEXICO CITYIn an in formal vote of cable television viewers here last month, Johnny Carson made a much stronger showing than anyone expected, but he lost to the latenight movie, anyway, 149 to 116, with 17 saying they really didn't care what they saw on television at that hour. In spite of the voting, cable television will continue as it haswith Johnny Carson twice and the latemovie three times during one week, then Mr. Car son thrice and the movie twice on the alternating week.

title: A Growing Number of Israeli Women Are Now Pioneers for Sex Equality
description: JERUSALEM, June 17  Is there a need for women's liber ation in Israel, where women are drafted into the army, work in the fields alongside men and where a woman serves as Premier?

title: Chinese Farmers Expect Good Crop
description: CREAM RIDGE, June 17In the gently rolling fields of Upper Freehold Township, where early Dutch farm ers raised wheat for bread and hay for their cattle, this year's crops of bok toy, snow peas and guy Ion show promise of bumper yields.

title: U.S. and India Taking Up BlockedRupees Problem
description: NEW DELHI, June 17The United States is seeking to remove a key barrier to good relations with India by trying to settle the complex and politi cally emotional rupee prob lem, in which millions of rupees meant to pay back food loans of the nineteensixties are piling up in an American bank account here.

title: KELLEY PANEL SET FOR WIDE DEBATE
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. June 17 Although Police Chief Clar ence M. Kelley is expected to win speedy confirmation as the new director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, some Senators plan to use his nom ination as a platform for fur ther debate about law and order issues in general and the role of the bureau in particular.

title: Paramount Signs Schaefer To Produce a TV Series
description: George Schaefer, the televi sion producerdirector, has been signed by Paramount Television as executive producer of Love Story, a new hourlong series of dramas to be shown in the fall on the National Broadcast ing Company network.

title: Francis Defeats Faruolo For L.I. Amateur Golf Title
description: UPPER BROOKVILLE, N. Y. June 17  Gene Francis of Wheatley, Hills won the 50th Long Island Golf Association amateur championship, defeat. ing 21yearold Frank Faruolo a clubmate, 8 and 7, in the scheduled 36hole final today at Mill River Club.

title: Miller's Record Round A Distracting Weapon
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 17Suddenly, on the big score boards throughout the Oak mont Country Club today, a red minus 5 was alongside Johnny Miller's name. From a distance, Arnold Palmer could see the minus 5, but a tree covered the name.

title: Urban Ills Dog Binghamton, But It Hopes to Fight Back
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., June 18A $35million complex of city, state and county of fices was dedicated today in this city, whose reputation for comfortable tidiness has worn a bit since the days when it was known as the Parlor City.

title: Excerpts From Toasts By Nixon and Brezhnev
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)Following are excerpts from the exchange of toasts tonight between President Nixon and the Soviet party leader Leonid I. Brezhnev:

title: Chou's Wife Says C.I.A. Knew Of Lin's Death Before Russians
description: PEKING, June 18 (Reuters) Teng Yingchao, the wife of Premier Chou Enlai, asserted today that the United States Central Intelligency Agency learned of the death of Lin Piao even before the Russians. Mr. Lin, the former Defense Minister and designated heir to Chair man Mao Tsetung, was ac cused of attempting to over throw Mr. Mao.

title: A Second Opinion Reduces Surgery
description: The United Store Workers Union says that it has been able to reduce the amount of surgery performed on its mem bers by having a second doc tor review each recommended operation before it is performed.

title: 11th Navy Man Sentenced; On Vietnam Minesweeping
description: MANILA, June 18 (UPI)An 11th crewman of the United States Navy vessel who was charged with disobedience while minesweeping off North Vietnam pleaded guilty today and was sentenced to three months imprisonment at hard labor, the Navy reported.

title: SOYBEANS, WHEAT AND CORN STRONG
description: Prices of grain and soybean futures were strong yesterday, One commodity expert said that perhaps lower prices last week indicated that the con tracts had been oversold. He noted that good export busi ness continued.

title: General Electric Employes Ratify 37Month Contract
description: A 37month contract cover ing 83,000 General Electric Company employes has been ratified by the membership of the International Union of Elec trical Workers, the union an nounced yesterday.

title: Index at 875.08, Its Lowest Close in 18 Months
description: The stock market decline?? again yesterday as investors in. creased their concern over the growing pressure on the dollat and on the effectiveness of the Administration's new economic measures to combat inflation;

title: Silencing the Critics
description: The Center on Corporate Responsibility, a small public interest group that conducts research and litigation improve business behavior in such areas as environ mental protection, minority hiring and product safety, is struggling for its life against the Internal Revenue Service. The I.R.S. has denied the group taxexempt statuswhich will cut it off from the support of tax exempt foundations and reduce the contributions it can hope to raise from individuals.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Board of Higher Education last night approved plans for the City University's first law school, to opened by 1976 at Queens College. In announcing the plan, which still must be approved by the State Board Regents and the Governor, the board noted a dramatic growth in the demand for lawyers over the last decade. Luis QueroChiess, chairman of the board, said the Queens College law school would concentrate on training lawyers, especially women and members of minority groups, who will deal with critical social and urban problems and focus on the increasing need for lawyers in the public sector.

title: SUBMARINE LIFTED, 2 TRAPPED INSIDE 30 HOURS RESCUED
description: KEY WEST, Fla., June 18Navy rescue vessels today ripped a research submarine, containing four men, from the grasp of a scuttled destroyer whose rusting hulk had held the tiny vessel prisoner for more than 30 hours in the Atlantic Ocean off Key West.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Billy Williams of the Chicago Cubs edged past Bobby Bonds of the San Francisco Giants for a starting outfield berth on the National League AllStar team in the voting announced yesterday. Williams, who was fourth last week, took over second place behind the outfield leader, Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds. Bonds dropped to fourth, just 3,000 votes behind Cesar Cedeno of the Houston Astros.

title: Pass Trial Takes a Quick Turn as. Defense Rests
description: ERIE, Pa., June 18 (UPI) The defense rested suddenly today in the Yablonski murder trial of Albert E. Pass after calling 15 witnesses, including two celimates who testified that a convicted slayer, Wil liam Prater, a prosecution wit ness, was prepared to lie against anyone to get out of prison.

title: WHITE HOUSE FILES SOUGHT FOR CALLEY
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) Attorneys for First Lieut. Wil liam L. Calley Jr. sought today, to obtain full details of any White House involvement in an investigation of the My Lai massacre by two figures in volved in the Watergate case.

title: RACE YACHTS NEAR NEWPORT FINISH
description: NEWPORT, R. I.,June 18The first yacht to complete the 473mile race from Anna polis, MA., is expected to finish off the Castle Rock lighthouse here tomorrow morning. It might be Jack Potter's Equation, the lean, powerful 68foot ketch from Oyster Bay, L. I., or James Baldwin's Sorcery, the 62foot sloop also out of Oyster Bay.

title: Georges Bonnet, a Participant In Munich Agreement, Is Dead
description: PARIS, June 18  Georges Bonnet, who as French Foreign Minister in 1938 was a signer of the Munich agreement that precipitated World War II, died here today at his home. He was 83 years old.

title: BALLISTICS TESTS AWAITED DEATH
description: The Police Department said yesterday that it would not know until the end of the week if police bullets were respon sible for the death of a bar tender in a shootout in a Har lem bar Sunday night during which a police officer and gunman were also killed.

title: Postal Service Reported Near Pact With 4 Unions
description: The United States Postal Service is close to agreement on a twoyear contract with a coalition of four unions repre senting 600,000 postal workers, it was disclosed here yesterday by the head of the largest of the four unions.

title: Cahill Supports Sandman, Citing Shift on Some Issues
description: TRENTON, June 18Gover nor Cahill, who once charged that the nomination of Repre sentative Charles W. Sandman Jr. would be a disaster for the Republican party in No vember, announced his support of Mr, Sandman for Governor today.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rose at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Stine 18Yileds on United States Trea sury bills rose in the Govern ment's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Invitations Abound in Affluent Westchester for Charity Galas
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., June 18An en velope arrived at a few thousand West chester County homes several weeks ago. It contained a printed invitation to the Palazzo Ball, a benefit evening for Channel 13, and offered the recipient three choices:

title: Informer Shield Upheld Over Rights of a Father
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The promises given to a Gov ernment informer prevailed in the Supreme Court today over the right of a father to custody of his children.

title: Lost Domenichino Is Found and Bought for $392
description: What has been described as a firstrate painting by the 17thcentury Italian master. Domenichino was discovered nearly three months ago by an American art dealer and his wife in a small antiques shop in StoweontheWold Glou cestershire England, and purchased by them for $392

title: Faculty Hiring Bias Is Laid to Princeton
description: PRINCETON, June 18The National Organization for Wo men (NOW) has challenged Princeton University's hiring practices, charging that the overall faculty position of wo men and blacks at Princeton remains dismal.

title: Ithaca Aide Stepping Down
description: ITHACA, N.Y., June 18 (AP)Carlton Carp Wood, athletic director at Ithaca College for the last 14 years, will step down July 1, but will continue as a member of the faculty and as varsity baseball coach.

title: N. G. Hickman Weds Mrs. Donovan
description: Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Minnie Cassatt Donovan, daughter of Mrs. Anthony Drexel Cassatt of New York and a greatgreatniece of the late Mary Cassatt, the Amer ican artist, to Norman Gil bert Hickman. The civil cere mony was performed in Santo Domingo on Feb. 1.

title: Cloistered Visitor
description: The welcoming ceremonies for Leonid I. Brezhnev went off as planned at the White House yesterday. Presi dent Nixon and his guest both expressed appropriate words of goodwill. Mr. Brezhnev took advantage of his minutes before the camera to shake hands with a few ordinary Americans, and otherwise to strengthen the image that he is a human politician. There was no sugges tion in Mr., Brezhnev's behavior of the oneupmanship of Nikita S. Khrushchev when he arrived in Washington in September 1959 and boasted of Soviet space superi ority. The Brezhnev visit has had a good beginning.

title: Mayoral Primary
description: His 5foot2 inch frame all but submerged in a herd of shoving regular Democrats, re porters and broadcast techni cians, Controller Abraham D. Beame received a mass en dorsement of his mayoral can didacy yesterday in the echo ing City Hall rotunda.

title: Space Walk Set Today to Retrieve Skylab Sun Photos
description: HOUSTON, June 18 (AP)The Skylab 1 crew prepared today for a space walk out side their station tomorrow to recover film that is expected to include a precious sequence showing the first solar flare ever photographed by a manned telescope from orbit.

title: Deadline for Whales
description: The International Whaling Commission holds its annual meeting in London next week. This meeting is critical for the survival of whales on this planet. The American dele gation under leadership of Dr. Robert White, head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, is com mitted to proposing a tenyear moratorium on the killing of all whales.

title: $17MILLION LOAN SOUGHT BY PENNSY
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (AP)The Penn Central Rail, road, continuing to pile up debts and running short o: cash, asked a Federal judge today to approve an application for a $17million loan, most o?? which already has been spent.

title: She Uses a Needle as a Brush and Thread as a Medium
description: Juliette Hamelecourt de scribes herself as a painter who uses embroidery as medium.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The President's temporary price freeze and future control program may be helpful in gaining time. In an ex cessdemand situation, however, the main job has to be done through fiscal and monetary policy. The Administra tion should hold firmly to its expendi ture ceilings for fiscal 73 and 74. The Congress should promptly reform its budgetcontrol procedures so that it can actively participate in planning the total budget balance. The Federal Reserve should have strong backing in pursuing gradually intensifying credit restraint.

title: Schlesinger Sees Rising Defense Costs
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 James R. Schlesinger portrayed himself today as a Defense Sec retary who accepted the poli cies of the past and was recon ciled to a steady increase in the military budget.

title: FIIITZ MAHLER, 72, CONDUCTOR, DEAD
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., June 18Fritz Mahler, the con ductor, died today at a nursing home. He was 72 years old and had lived at 340 West 72d Street', New York.

title: A.T.&T. Gets Authorization, To Construct Pacific Cable
description: The Federal Communications System has authorized the American Telephone & Tele graph Company and six other big communications carriers to construct and operate a $180 million transPacific cable sys tem.

title: RIGHT BY SHAVERS STOPS ELLIS IN 2:39
description: With a blazing righthand uppercut, Earnie Shavers knocked out Jimmy Ellis in minutes 39 seconds of the first round last night in what was to have been a 12round heavy weight bout at Madison Square Garden.

title: 7 Major Concerns Support Planfor Madison Ave. Mali
description: Seven Madison Avenue stores and hotels, including Abercrom bie & Fitch and the Roosevelt and Biltmore Hotels yesterday endorsed the proposed Madison Avenue mall.

title: The Young Men
description: Most of the witnesses before the Senate Watergate hearings have been notable for their youth, their attrac tive appearance, their exemplary manners and their laud able goals of public service. Their involvement in this sordid affair seems an aberration. Even their ambitions generally look like those that have been considered desirable in young men ever since McGuffey's Reader pointed American youth on its way to success.

title: MISS BOURASSA WINS 3WAY GOLF PLAYOFF
description: MONTREAL, June 18 (UPI) Jocelyne Bourassa, the home town favorite, sank a 15inch putt on the third hole of a threeway, suddendeath play off today to win the $10,000 first prize in the La Canad ienne golf championship.

title: Security Is Tight as Brezhnev Arrives
description: WASHINGTON, June 18There were red flags on the lampposts, demonstrators scat tered from the Washington Monument to the State Depart ment and policemen on street corners and roofs in the White House area today as Leonid I. Brezhnev began his official visit.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: JohannesburgArnold Taylor, South Africa, outpointed Billy Waith, Wales, 10 rounds, feather weights.

title: Watergate One Year Later
description: A year after the Washington police caught five burglars redhanded in the offices of the Democratic National Committee, the most burning questions in the public mind still seem to be: Did Richard Nixon know that the Watergate Five were hired hands of the Committee for the Reelection of the President? Did he help cover up the committee and White House in volvement? Whatever he knew, how will it all turn out?

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON ANIEX ANDOTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthe counter market fell sharply yesterday in continued light trading, although volume was slightly higher than on Friday. Traders continued to act nega tively to the Administration's efforts to curb inflation.

title: People in Sports: Frazier Starts the Comeback Trail
description: Appearing fit but tense and carrying a briefcase upon which the word Champ was emblazoned in faded gold lettering, Joe Frazier arrived in London yesterday to prepare for his fight against Joe Bugner on July 2.

title: JUSTICE OFFICIAL FAILS TO TESTIFY
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The frustrations experienced by Congress in attempting to de termine the status of the Justice Department's investigation of corruption and mismanagement in the Immigration and nat uralization Service continued today when a top department official did not appear, as promised, before a House sub committee.

title: Corning Glass Will Appeal F.T.C. FairTrade Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) Corning Glass Works plans to appeal a Federal Trade Com mission ruling clamping down on the upstate New York com pany's use of the pricefixing practice known as fair trading.

title: Leaders Parley Reflects Vastly Altered Relations
description: WASHINGTON, June 18As this morning's White House ceremonies ended, Leonid I. Brezhnev put his arm around President Nixon and said ex uberantly in Russian: We're moving forward!

title: $1 Votes Decided Connecticut Issue
description: ROCKY HILL, Conn.,June 18A referendum in this town was won by votes bought for $1 apiece, according to Mayor David W. Moser, who said that a search of the law failed to turn up anything making it clearly illegal to buy the votes, It is not that definite, he said ROCKY HILL, Conn., June 18

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, JUNE 19, 1973
description: International

title: Ohio Publisher Deal Set
description: TIFFIN, Ohio, June 18 (UPI) The Tiffin (Ohio) Advertiser Tribune Company, publisher of The Daily AdvertiserTribune here, has been sold to Buckner Ohio, Inc., an affiliate of Buck ned News Alliance, it was an nounced today. Terms of the sale were not disclosed.

title: Invitation List For the Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Fol lowing is the White House list of those invited to attend the state dinner tonight given by President and Mrs. Nixon for Leonid I. Brezhnev:

title: Big Board Seat Sold
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced a seat sale yesterday for $90,000, un changed from the previous transaction on June 11.

title: Saigon's Foreign Minister To Quit Post Temporarily
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 18 (Reuters)South Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Tram Van Lam is temporarily withdrawing from the Saigon Government to run in the Senate elections in August, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Liberal Mailing Was G.O.P.Assisted
description: The mailing labels affixed to some Liberal party campaign literature that is under inves tigation by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz followed a circuitous route that apparent ly began with the Nassau County Republican Committee.

title: American Apparel Group Plans Textile Exposition
description: A fullscale exposition of American textiles for the fash ion industries, will be held next year at the New York Coliseum, it was announced yesterday by the American Apparel Manufacturers Asso ciation and the textile Distrib utors Association, which are sponsoring the event.

title: Yankees Ready to Begin 6Man Pitching Rotation
description: After arriving in New York at 6 o'clock yesterday morn ing, the Yankees couldn't have enjoyed a very good day off, but they had better like it be cause it's the last one they have scheduled until July 16.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Amidst the tall timbers that gave a cathedrallike grandeur to the Olympic Country Club in San Francisco, I became aware of the existence of Johnny Miller for the first time. This was at the United States Open in 1966 when Miller was a 19yearold sophomore at Brigham Young University and an amateur golfer of no especial distinction, The stars of the ensemble that year were Arnold Palmer, Billy Casper, Jack Nicklaus, Gary Player and a few others. They were the ones to remember. Yet Miller also was remembered and retrospect fails to explain why he left so deep an impression. Could it have been his ingenuousness?

title: CAHILL SWITCHES, BACKS SANDMAN
description: TRENTON, June 18Gover nor Cahill, who once charged that the nomination of Repre sentative Charles W. Sandman Jr. would be a disaster for the Republican party in No vember, announced his support, of Mr. Sandman for Governor. today.

title: Tax Evasion Admitted
description: Louis J. Inglese, identified by Government authorities as a major narcotics dealer, pleaded guilty in Federal Court here yesterday to one count of at tempted incometax evasion. He could face up to five years in prison when sentenced Sept. 11 by Judge Dudley Bonsal Inglese was indicted on tax charges two months ago in a new campaign by the Internal Revenue Service against alleged narcotics dealers.

title: Enlistments Lag for Combat Forces
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) An increased enlistment bonus failed to draw enough volunteers into the Army and Marine ground combat arms during the first month of a new test.

title: Alejandro Remon, 60, Dies; Consul General of Panama
description: Alejandro Remon, Panama's Consul General in New York, died Sunday at St. John's Hos pital, Yonkers, after a heart attack. He was 60 years old and lived at 2500 Johnson Av enue, Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: TEST FOR CANCER SET IN MINNESOTA
description: Two international experts on environmentally caused can cer left last night for Duluth, Minn., to set up a crash testing program to try to determine whether asbestos fibers de tected in the city's drinking water presented a risk of can cer to its 100,600 residents.

title: GEORGE C. SMITH
description: George C. Smith, an econo mist who once headed the St. Louis Chamber of Commerce, died yesterday at Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital He was 86 years old.

title: Secretariat's Preakness Time Faces a Third Look
description: BALTIMORE, June 18 (AP) Mrs. Helen B. Tweedy owner of the Triple Crown winner, Secretariat, asked today for a review of the official Preak ness, clocking after watching films which purported to show that the time listed for the race was incorrect.

title: Carrier W asp Gets Ina Last Blow Before Scrapping
description: NEWARK, June 18Although the aircraft carrier Wasp picked up her quota of battle stars in the Pacific dur ing World War II, she was never known as a lucky ship and she lived up to that reputa tion on her last voyage today.

title: HARRY MOUNTAIN, 72, OF AETNA INSURANCE
description: OCEANSIDE, Calif., June 18 (AP)Harry M. Mountain, re tired president of the Aetna Insurance Company of Hart ford, died Saturday at TriCity. Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Lake San Marcos.

title: Paine, Webber Abandons Active Role in Treasurys
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis disclosed yesterday it is withdrawing from an active dealer role in Treasury securi ties but will continue operating in the Federal agency and com mercialpaper areas.

title: HURLERS WARNED ON HELP TO AARON
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, responding yesterday to an Associated Press story on Sun day, threatened pitchers with suspension if they help Hank Aaron achieve a recordbreak ing 715th career home run.

title: U.S.North Vietnam Aid Talks Resume in Paris
description: PARIS, June 18 (Reuters)The United States and North Vietnam resumed talks today on how to direct the flow of American economic aid to Hanoi, which could come to $2.5billion over the next five years.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: MINNESOTAOptioned Jim Strickland, pitch, er, to Tacoma to make room for Eddie Bane, rookie pitcher from Arizona State.

title: I.T.T. Termed Misleading on Merger
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation al legedly misled the investing public and the Internal Revenue Service in obtaining approval for the biggest merger in cor porate history, according to pretrial report filed last Friday in United States, District Court in New Haven.

title: $10.3Billion City Budget, With RealtyTax Rise Held to 36 Cents, Is Agreed To by Leaders
description: A $10.3billion expense budget for 1973.74, calling for a realestate tax increase of 36 cents per $100 of assessed val uation, was adopted informally yesterday by the Lindsay ad ministration, Controller Abra ham D. Beame, the Board of Estimate and City Council lead ers.

title: All for the Love of That Green Gold
description: SAIGON, South VietnamOne of Saigon's top coutu riers wears a green jade brace let on her left wrist that is reputed to have cost six million piasters ($12,000). Since she bought it a few years ago her business has boomed and she has achieved everything she wanted.

title: K. C. Jones Named Coach Of N.B.A.'s Capital Bullets
description: K. C. Jones, who played on eight championship teams in his playing career with the Boston Celtics, was named yes terday to be head coach for the Capital Bullets of the Na tional Basketball Association. Jones, the sixth black to coach in the N. B. A., resigned last week as head coach of the San Diego Conquistadors of the American Basketball Associ ation after one year in the job.

title: Senate's Ban on Bombing Is Sent to the House Floor
description: WASHINGTON, June 18A compromise money bill that includes a proposal to cut off funds for American bombing in Cambodia was cleared today by a SenateHouse conference and sent to the House floor.

title: WHITE HOUSE DENIES WATERGATE REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 The White House stated today that no one with authority or access to the facts had said that President Nixon was pre paring to say he was misled in the Watergate case by two for mer aides, John D. Ehrlichman and H. R. Haldeman.

title: Badillo Accuses Beame of a Budget Deal
description: Representative Herman Ba dillo continued to charge yes terday that his rival for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, Controller Abraham D. Beame, and Mayor Lindsay had held a secret meeting at which they and other members of the club got together to save one of their own from blame for the city's escalating fiscal difficulties.

title: Miss Martha Rebecca Sadick Is the Bride of Peter Jablow
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 18Miss Martha Rebecca Sadick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Michael Sadick of Providence, was married here at noon today to Peter An thony Jablow of New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Jablow of New York and a grandson of the late Maurice Rentner, founder of the Fashion Originator's Guild.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Power Craft Disdained
description: With no desire to seem opposed to healthy fun, this writer must, nonetheless, register his disapproval of a new recreational vehicle that has been described as a motorcycle for the water.

title: RICHARD F. IRWIN
description: Richard F. Irwin, a systems analyst for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, was killed Friday in a road acci dent while en route to train ing with the New York Na tional Guard. He was 39 years old and lived in Monsey, N. Y.

title: VAN DILLEN GAINS IN LONDON TENNIS
description: LONDON, June 18  With the threat of a players boy cott still looming over Wimble don, the AllEngland Club will announce seedings for the men's singles tomorrow, ignor ing the dispute between the In ternational Law Tennis Federa tion and the Association of Ten nis Professionals that is being argued in the High Court. Nikki Pilic has applied for an injunction against the LOL.T.F. and the AllEngland Club over his suspension for not playing for Yugoslavia against New Zealand in the Davis Cup com petition

title: Miller Is 2d to Brezhnev On White House Schedule
description: I don't want to be a flash in the pan, but I don't think I will be, said Johnny Miller, the new United States Open golf champion, yesterday.

title: COX STAFF LOOKS AT IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 The Watergate special prosecu tor, Archibald Cox, conceded today that his office was stuuy ing the questions of whether a President might be subpoenaed in a criminal case and whether a President might be indicted prior to impeachment.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Billy Williams of the Chicago Cubs edged past Bobby Bonds of the San Francisco Giants for a starting outfield berth on the National League AllStar team in the voting announced yesterday. Williams, who was fourth last week, took over second place behind the outfield leader, Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds. Bonds dropped to fourth, just 3,000 votes behind Cesar Cedeno of the Houston Astros.

title: Theater: The Faggot,'
description: As the perceptive might have guessed from the title the new musical that opened last night at the Truck and Warehouse Theater, called The Faggot, is concerned with homosexuality. But not that concerned; indeed it rather seems to like it.

title: Suit on Air Force Award
description: WOOD RIDGE, N.J., June 18 (UPI)  The CurtissWright Corporation said today that it had sued the Air Force in Newark Federal Court to, upset the award of an engine over haul contract to the Southwest Airrnotive Company of Dallas. CurtissWright said the con tract, which has a potential value of $75million over five years, had been awarded im properly.

title: Carrier wasp Strikes Last Damaging Blow
description: By RICHARD PHALON Special to The New York Times NEWARK, June 18 Although the aircraft carrier Wasp picked up her quota of battle stars in the Pacific dur ing World War II, she was never known as a lucky ship and she lived up to that reputa tion on her last voyage today.

title: Petrograd Ties Dash Mark in Aqueduct Feature
description: Petrograd, the consistent sprinter owned by Mrs. Thomas M. Walsh, flashed to a most significant triumph in the $27, 725 Gravesend Handicap yes terday. The six furlong test featured the opening day card of the summer meeting at Aqueduct. In taking the event, Petrograd, with Angel Cordero riding, tied the course record of 1:08 3/5 and beat the stakes standard by a fifth of a second.

title: Summit Parleys Since '45
description: Since the final days of World War II, there have been seven summit conferences involving American Pres idents and Soviet leaders. Following is a list of them:

title: L.I. SHORE EROSION THREATENS HOMES
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., June 18The steep bluffs of Long Is land's North Shore are eroding at a critical rate that threat ens many homes that overlook Lonab Island Sound, scientists reported today.

title: Brief Arrests of 11 Jews In Moscow Are Reported
description: MOSCOW, June 18 (UPI)Eleven Moscow Jews were ar rested and held at police sta tions yesterday but were re leased last night, Jewish sources said today.

title: ROSEMARY A. GORSKIE
description: Rosemary A. Gorskie, an as sistant vice president of the Seamen's Bank for Savings, died yesterday while attending classes in banking at Brown University in Providence, R. I. She was 46 years old and lived at 3731 73d Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: A Nature Boy Who Runs Fast
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 18 Steve Williams studied the Old Mexico decor of the restaurant, as if sizing up a rival sprinter on the starting line, then frowned as he pointed to a group of musi cians playing rock music at a far corner of the room.

title: Building Inspectors Suspended In a Dispute Over Work Rule,
description: Twentyeight of the city's 32 construction inspectors in Man hattan have been suspended for the last 12 days because, the city says, they have refused to comply with new work schedules designed to increase productivity.

title: ALAN P. L. PREST, 73, FORMER ACCOUNTANT
description: NEW HAVEN, June 18Alan P. L. Prest, a retired partner in the public accountants firm of Price Waterhouse & Co. of New York, died yesterday at Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Token eke Park, Darien, Conn.

title: USLIFE Will Acquire All American Life Corp.
description: The USLIFE Corporation has reached an agreement to ac quire the All American Life and Financial Corporation of Chi cago, it was announced yester day by Gordon E. Crosby Jr., chairman of USLIFE, and John M. Gardiner, president of All American. The agreement pro vides that threetenths of a share of USLIFE common stock will be exchanged for each share of All American com mon. The total transaction involves about 1.8 million shares of USLIFE com mon, which has an approxi mate value of $93million based on the current market price of the stock.

title: Lefkowitz Gives His Data On Vote Scheme to Hogan
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced last night that his investigation of a sus pected Republicanaided scheme to siphon votes from Demo cratic candidates for the As sembly had been turned over to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan for possible criminal prosecution.

title: 2 Killed in Auto Accident On Southern State Parkway
description: MALVERNE, L. I., June 18 (AP)  Two Pennsylvania men were killed early today when a car going in the opposite di rection jumped the divider along the Southern State Park way and landed atop their vehicle, the police reported.

title: ROBERT H. MACKEY
description: Robert H. Mackey, an in surance agent for 57 years with the New York Life Insur ance Company, died Saturday at New York University Hos pital. He was 86 years old and lived in Spring Lake, N. J.

title: BIAGGI PREFERS BADILLO VICTORY
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Representative Mario Biaggi, the Conservative party candi date for Mayor who ran third in the Democratic primary, said today that his chances of victory in November would be enhanced if Representative Herman Badillo won the Demo cratic runoff primary next week.

title: Big Bird and Pals Greeted Warmly at Willowbrook
description: Big Bird, in his 15pound cos tume of yellow turkey feathers, and four other members of the cast of Sesame Street, visit ed Willowbrook State School on Staten Island yesterday in the first performance of their live road show before re tarded youngsters.

title: EQUATION IS FIRST IN NEWPORT RACE
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 18 tion completed the 475mile race from Annapolis, Md., to Newport tonight in record time.

title: Administration Termed Willing To Accept TradeTalk Limits
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) The Nixon Administration re portedly indicated willingness today to accept some limita tions on the sweeping bargain ing powers sought in his pro posed international trade legis lation.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The police arrested a 27yearold woman at Somers Point and charged her with cruelty to animals after find ing 35 dogs, some of them apparently maimed; nine cats, a wolf, and an iguana inside the twostory home she occupied here with her parents. Detective Capt. Michael Colao said the woman, Marsha Oberle, was sent to the state psychiatric hospital at Ancora for examination after being arrested. Her mother, Stella, 49, was charged with aiding and abetting the cruelty, as was her father, Charles, 69, who had been arrested over the weekend.

title: Tiffany Cancels Rise in Prices of Gold Wedding Rings
description: Tiffany & Co., the Fifth Ave nuebased jewelry and silver ware chain, has rolled back re cent price increases on several thousand gold wedding rings, bracelets and earrings, in keep ing with President Nixon's 60 day pride freeze.

title: Another General Chosen As Brazil's Next Leader
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 18Brazil's military leaders have chosen Gen. Ernesto Geisel, the 64yearold head of the state oil monopoly, to become the na tion's next President.

title: Yonkers Entries
Suitors Terminate Offer For Empire National Bank
description: Financial General Bank shares, Inc., and the Bank of Commerce announced jointly yesterday that they had with drawn their offer to acquire by merger the shares of the Empire National Bank, a rapid ly growing Middletown, N. Y., bank with assets of $500mil lion.

title: Peacemaking
description: In their first meeting Mr. Brezhnev and Mr. Nixon asked each other how their trips had been. Mr. Brezhnev said that his had been very dull, He had never flown the Atlantic Ocean before and, while he did not know what he had been expecting, he had found it disappointingly monotonous after the first few hundred miles.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A recently organized coun cil to promote cultural events in Lower Manhattan will be gin operations this month. The Lower Manhattan Cul tural Council sponsored by businessmen and city offi cials was initially funded by a $10,000 grant from the Chase Manhattan Bank ac cording to Florence Barnett, executive director. It is based in the Seamen's Church Insti tute, 12 State Street. Al though Lower Manhattan is largely a business commu nity the council plans to serve both workers and the increased number of people living there.

title: Urban Ills Dog Binghamton, But It Hopes to Fight Back
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., June 18A $35million complex of city, state and county of fices was dedicated today in this city, whose reputation for comfortable tidiness has worn a bit since the days when it was known as the Parlor City.

title: Yankees Ready to Begin 6Man Pitching Rotation
description: After arriving in New York at 6 o'clock yesterday morn ing, the Yankees couldn't have enjoyed a very good day off, but they had better like it be cause it's the last one they have scheduled until July 16.

title: Koyo Seiko to Build Plant
description: Ground was broken yester day near Orangeburg, S. C., for a $10million antifriction bear ing manufacturing plant to be built by Koyo Seiko Company, Ltd., of Japan.

title: Satellite Lease Expanded
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (Reuters)  The Federal Corn punications Commission said today that it had authorized the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to lease 396 more satellite circuits. The lagency said the additional voice channels would provide added satellite service to Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

title: House Votes, 3910, $2Billion Measure To Combat Crime
description: WASHINGTON, June IS (AP) The House today unanimous ly authorized Federal expendi tures totaling $2billion over the next two years to help states and cities fight crime.

title: Roundup: Ellis in Control As Pirates Top Cubs, 31
description: When Dock Ellis is right, he walks few batters, and the Pittsburgh Pirates hope he is right at last. Dock hurled a threehitter to help them defeat the Chicago Cubs, 31, last night.

title: Consumer Product Safety Unit Gears Up
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The newest Federal regulatory agncy is gearing up for what its chairman describes as a reasonable, rational and re sponsible effort to reduce un reasonable risks to users of consumer products.

title: Newark Court Postpones Trial on Heroin Conspiracy
description: NEWARK, June 18The trial of five men and two women allegedly implicated in a multi. milliondollar conspiracy to im port and distribute heroin was postponed today to the fall term of Federal District Court here.

title: Last Army Survivor, 101, Of Indian Wars Is Dead
description: CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) Fredrak Fraske, the last sur viving Army veteran of the, In dian wars, died today at the age of 101, the Veterans Ad ministration announced.

title: White House Logs Show Nixon Met Dean on Day of Indictments
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) President Nixon, according to a White House log, had only one substantive meeting with his counsel, John W. Dean 3d, in 1972. That was on Sept. 15, the day indictments were re turned against seven men in the Watergate breakin.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WRITES OF SPRING Fif teen playwrights from Ger many, Britain, Canada, Israel and here will have 16 of their hitherto unstaged works (one has two going for him) in the Second International New Plays Festival of the Off Off Broadway WPA Theater, 333 Bowery (GR 39345).

title: 3HOUR MEETING;Soviet Aide Describes Session as Good, Businesslike
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 the leaders of the world's two most powerful nations, Presi dent Nixon and Leonid I. Brezh nev, met on the lawn of the White House today in a swirl of military pageantry and pledged to strive together for peace.

title: 2 COLUMBIA MEN VICTORS IN TENNIS
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 18Two Columbia players advanced today at the start of the Na tional Collegiate tennis cham pionships. Henry Bunis defeated Michael Quintin of Southern California, 63, 63, and Rick Fagel posted a 75, 62 victory over Greg Jablonski of Irvine.

title: Sugar Manufacturer Agrees to Clarify Misleading Advertising
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The Amstar Corporation has agreed to a Federal Trade Commission order requiring it to correct allegedly deceptive advertise ments for Domino sugar.

title: The Dance
description: In the hierarchy of aspira tions, entertainment is con sidered a lesser calling by many in the dance world. Thank heaven it is not a universal opinion or else we would not have had the pleasure of the First Tap and the Humming Birds dance companies last weekend:

title: 11 Districts Termed. Cross Section
description: The 11 Assembly District: termed by Attorney Genera: Louis J. Lefkowitz's investiga tors the centers of alleged clandestine Republican cam paign efforts include areas both traditionally Republican and normally Democratic. The dis tricts range from Nassau County to New York City and upstate.

title: Catholics Defy Rhodesia on Race Law
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 18  The five Roman Catholic bishops of Rhodesia have threatened a civildisobedience campaign to protest legislation that, they maintain, pre vents whites and blacks from worshiping together.

title: Mrs. Bower, on 77, Paces Match Play Golf Qualifiers
Equity Financing
description: A special offering of 42,700 common shares of Noel Industries, Inc., at 5 was completed yester day according to Shields & Co., Inc. The company's stock closed at 5 dciwn  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: N. C. A. A. TO TEST FOR USE OF DRUGS
description: WASHINGTON June 18, (UPI)An official of the Na tional Collegiate Athletic As sociation said today that urine tests would be required of all athletes competing in N.C.A.A. championships beginning this fall in an effort to combat drug abuse.

title: Greater Home Rule
description: All levels of governmentFederal, state and localhave become so interdependent that every effort rationalize their relationships is bound to spark at least as many conflicts as it resolves. That is likely to prove true even of so bland a document as the middleofthe road report just issued by the Temporary State Commis sion on the Powers of Local Government.

title: Mandatory Allocation of Crude Oil Seen
description: WASHINGTON, June 18President Nixon's promise last week to stabilize retail gaso line prices is seen by officials as a fresh indication that Wash ington will adopt a mandatory system for allocating supplies of crude oil and refinery prod ucts.

title: New Britten Opera Praised in England
description: LONDON, June 18A new opera by Benjamin Britten had its premiere at the Aldeburgh Festival Saturday, and news paper critics were enthusiastic over it.

title: Acquisition of 4. Banks in Texas Is Approved by Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 Rejecting pleas from the De partment of Justice, the Supreme Court affirmed today a lower court decision per mitting a Texas bank holding company to acquire four legally separate but econom ically allied banks in the E1 Paso area.

title: JURY SAID TO BALK IN PATRICK CASE
description: A Manhattan grand jury re portedly has refused to indict Ted Patrick and four other per sons accused of kidnapping a member of the New Testament Missionary Fellowship, a con servative religious group here, last month.

title: Millionaires in Coast Club Ardent as Ever for Nixon
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., June 18  The Watergate scandal has produced very few misgivings among the yachtracing racehorseown ing millionaires of Orange County's Lincoln Club, who like to boast that without their help Richard M. Nixon could never have become President.

title: Butz Joins Oil Policy Panel
description: Washington, June 18 (UPI)  Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz has been named to the Oil Policy Committee and promises to make sure farmers get the fuel they need, representative W. R. Poage, Democrat of Texas, said today. Mr. Poage's House Agriculture Committee had adopted a reso lution recently urging the ap pointment.

title: President's Greeting and Soviet Leader's Response
description: Mr. General Secretary and all of our distinguished guests:

title: Argentina Trying to Quell Militants for Peron Return
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 18In an effort to create a peaceful atmosphere for the return of former President Juan D. Peron, Government officials and Pe ronist party leaders are trying to quell a wave of illegal seiz ures of universities, radio sta tions, hospitals and public buildings by Peronist militants.

title: Power Shutdown Traps Thousands On Penn Central
description: Thousands of Penn Central riders, most of them home bound commuters, were stranded in their trains last night when equipment prob lems and a fire aboard a train forced the railroad to shut down power on its Hudson Di vision line from Marble Hill, Manhattan's enclave in the Bronx, to Glenwood in West chester County.

title: Truce Optimism Prevails Despite Sporadic Clashes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 19  Sporadic clashes were reported from all regions of South Vietnam yes terday on the fourth day of the new ceasefire.

title: SENATE SEEKING END OF FIXED STOCK FEES
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) The Senate today passed, 85 to 3, a bill specifying that insti tutional investors such as mu1 tual funds may trade on stock exchanges for their own ac counts so long as the ex changes maintain a system of fixed brokerage commissions. The bill now goes to the House.

title: 20 in DrumBugle Corps Felled by Food Poisoning
description: HARTFORD, June 18 (AP)About 20 members of the Staf ford Springs Crusaders drum and bugle corps were treated in Johnson Memorial Hospital in Stafford Springs last night for food poisoning, authorities said.

title: $1 Votes Decided Connecticut Issue
description: ROCKY HILL, Conn., June 18A referendum in this town was won by votes bought for $1 apiece, according to Mayor David W. Moser, who said that a search of the law failed to turn up anything making it clearly illegal to buy the votes. It is not that definite, he said.

title: Chicago Bank Lifts Prime Rate
description: The First National Bank of Chicago posted yesterday a quarterpoint increaseto 7 per cent, effective today in its base interest rate on loans to corporations.

title: ExCelloO's Quarter Profit Up; Other Company Reports Issued
TURNER JURY TOLD RAID WAS ORDERED
description: TRENTON, June 18A high state law enforcement official testified today that State Sena tor James M. Turner practi cally ordered him to raid the home of Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz last fall in search of drugs.

title: Haldeman Back in Calif., Wife Says It's For Good
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) H. R. Haldeman, the former White House chief of staff, has moved his family back home to California.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 18. (Reuters)The Federal Re serve's Open Market Committee voted at its March 1920 meeting to slow down the growth in the money supply, it disclosed today. However, to accommodate a large in crease in certificates of deposit issued by member banks, the committee voted to foster a growth in reserves avail able to support private nonbank deposits of 12 to 16 per cent.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the Peace ful Uses of Outer Space, working group on direct broadcast satellites10:30 A.M. and 5 P.M.

title: Notes on People Pickets Compliment'Mrs. Gandhi
description: Beauty, of course, is in the eye of the beholder. And when Roland Michener, the Governor General of Canada, contemplated the pickets dogging Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India, he advised her to regard such demon strations as a compliment. Visiting high officials, he said at a luncheon in Ottawa, are often accorded the tribute of picket lines. The demon strators were protesting In dian retention of prisoners taken during the 1971 war with Pakistan. Mrs. Gandhi, in Canada on a state visit, is scheduled to address Parlia ment today.

title: Protestant Extremists Active in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 18The specter of Prot estant extremism has reap peared in Northern Ireland with the emergence of a militant group that says it has carried out two assassinations and two bombings in the last five days.

title: Invitations Abound in Affluent Westchester for Charity Galas
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., June 18An en velope arrived at a few thousand West chester County homes several weeks ago. It contained a printed invitation to the Palazzo Ball, a benefit evening for Channel 13, and offered the recipient three choices:

title: Bavarian Court Bars Delay Of the 2Germany Treaty
description: KARLSRUHE, West Ger many, June 18 (AP)The West German Constitutional Court cleared the way today for car rying out the Bonn Govern ment's treaty normalizing rela tions with East Germany.

title: INFLATION FIGHT SAID TO COOL OFF
description: BASEL, June 18The Bank for International Settlements warned today that no end was in sight for world inflation, and that floating exchange rates have helped the inflationary process along by removing an element of discipline.

title: Telex Asks Court Curbs On I.B.M. Leasing Terms
description: TULSA, Okla., June 18A Federal judge was urged today to clamp severe restrictions on the International Business Ma chine Corporation to guarantee free and open competition in the computer industry.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street the Bronx, 7:30 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 7:30 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 7:30 P.M.)

title: NIXON, BREZHNEV GIVE PEACE VOWS AS SUMMIT BEGINS; 3HOUR MEETING; Soviet Aide Describes? Session as Good, Businesslike
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 The leaders of the world's two most powerful nations, Presi dent Nixon and Leonid I. Brezh nev, met on the lawn of the White House today in a swirl of military pageantry and pledged to strive together for peace.

title: JAMAICA SIGNS DEAL TO BUILD REFINERY
description: The Jamaican Government said yesterday that it had signed an agreement, with the Moretti Group of Milan, Italy, for construction of a $350 million refinery capable of pro ducing 250,00 barrels of petro leum a day.

title: Stage: Feminist Musical
description: Marjorie DeFazio and Pa tricia Horan's ... What Time of Night It Is is the Feminist equivalent of In White America. Call it In Male America. The show works both as a course in consciousness raising and as a call to arms.

title: Leaders'
description: WASHINGTON, Tune 18As this morning's White House ceremonies ended, Leonid 1. Brezhnev put his arm around President Nixon and said ex uberantly in Russian: We're moving forward!

title: ALBERT SYLVESTER, INVESTMENT ADVISER
description: COHASSET, Mass., June 18Albert Lenthall Sylvester, a Boston businessman and invest ment counselor, died Saturday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

title: Housing Chief Tells Mayors Criticism of Nixon Plans Perils New Federalism
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 18The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, James T Lynn warned the nation's mayors today that continued criticism of President Nixon's domestic proposals placed the entire New Federalism pro gram in jeopardy.

title: Oklahoma Tornado Hits Nursing Home; 45 Hurt, None Dead
description: FREDERICK, Okla., June 18 (UPIA tornado spun out of a massive storm raging through southwest Oklahoma tonight and slammed into a nursing home, injuring at least 45 per sons.

title: Union at City University Challenges Board of Education on Unilateral Settlement of Contract Dispute
description: Acting under the Taylor Law, the Board of Higher Educa tion yesterday took the first step toward unilaterally deter mining a settlement of its yearold contract dispute with the City University's faculty and staff union, the Professional Staff Congress.

title: SUBMARINE LIFTED, 2 TRAPPED INSIDE 30 HOURS RESCUED
description: KEY WEST, Fla., June 18Rescue vessels today ripped trapped re search submarine from the grasp of an old scuttled Navy destroyer resting on the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean off Key West, rescuing two members of the fourman ocean ographic crew.

title: Mansfield Acted to Aid Summit Talks
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The Senate Watergate com mittee today canceled its hear ings this week so that they would not detract from the talks here between President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MENDHAM, June 18In the winter of 1957, Ralph Terry, a righthanded pitcher for the Kansas City Athletics, fractured his hip in a car crash, As a result of that mishap, Terry was introduced to golf.

title: CemeteryStrike Talks
description: Vincent. D. McDonnell chair man of the State Mediation Board, said yesterday that he and his aids were making a final mediation effort to settle the strike at 47 metropolitan area cemeteries before impos ing binding arbitration. He re ported however that the strik ing gravediggers were continu ing to say that their demands! for $12aweek increases and other benefit improvements were rockbottom and non negotiable. He said that there had been no progress in the talks.

title: New Welfare Rules Issued By the City to Save Money
description: The city last night announced new welfare regulations de signed to save money, eliminate kickback temptations and estab lish orderly policy in paying the moving expenses of welfare families.

title: Informer Shield Upheld Over Rights of a Father
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The promises given to a Gov ernment informer prevailed in the Supreme Court today over the right of a father to custody of his children.

title: Advertising: Similarity on TV
description: Procter & Gamble, the country's largest national ad vertiser, this week pulls out the stops in its efforts to introduce Sure, an antiper spirant.

title: School Aid Cut by $400Million Under New White House Spending Guideline
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 The Nixon Administration has directed school districts to eliminate educational programs totaling nearly $400million, in cluding impact aid funds for school districts with large num, bers of Federal employes, for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: AUTO HILL CLIMB SCHEDULED SUNDAY
description: The 23d annual Mount Equi nox Hill Climb will be run this weekend at Mount Equinox, Manchester, Vt., under the sponsorship of the Vintage Sports Car Club of America.

title: Chess:Writer Gains 11thRound Lead In Leningrad Interzonal Play
Book Publishing Is Flowering on Coast
description: LOS ANGELESAlan Rinz ler a prominent California pub lisher was displeased with book designer the other day, and so he said later Since I'm a Scorpio and have a great deal of potential energy, I knocked him down.

title: Queens Woman Killed in Fall
description: An unidentified woman, 19 to 21 years old, jumped or fell to her death about 5 A.M. yesterday from the roof of a sixstory apartment building at 6433 98th Street, Rego Park, Queens, the police reported. The victim was 5feet3 inches tall, with black hair, brown eyes and a small rose tattoo on her upper left shoulder.

title: Not Yet a Good Man
description: NEW HAVENI was very fond of Jeb Magruder when we were together at Williams College. It was in 1958, his senior year and my first year as teacher and college chaplain. He and two classmates used to take my wife and me to dinner. He babysat for our daughter. Although we never saw each other after his graduation, for several years we corresponded.

title: Heavy Fighting Is Said to Go On 13 Miles West of Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH. Cambodia, Tuesday. June 19 (UPI)Heavy fighting was reported yesterday around two towns only 13 miles from Phnom Penh as a Communist offen sive continued in the area.

title: Italian Communists Are Asking Workers to Restrict Walkouts
description: ROME, June 18The Commu nist party is tryingprudently, but unmistakablyto curb the propensity of Italian workers for walking off their jobs.

title: Fall Laid Partly to Watergate Scandal Gold Advances
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 18 (Reuters)The United States dollar lost more ground in major European currency markets today, reaching a rec ord low against the West Ger man mark.

title: JUDGE HERE AGREES TO HEAR VESCO CASE
description: Judge Charles E. Stewart Jr. ruled in Manhattan Federal Court yesterday that he would exercise jurisdiction over Vesco & Co., Inc., a family corpora tion formed in Delaware last year by Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier and former chairman of the International Controls Corporation.

title: U.S. Sweeping Will Leave Deactivated Mines in Haiphong Harbor
description: HONOLULU, June 18Under current plans, the Navy's re newed minesweeping in North Vietnamese waters will leave numerous deactivated mines at the bottom of Haiphong Harbor, according to a highranking military commander here.

title: Long Island Man Gets Key Post at Boston U.
description: BOSTON, June 18 (UPI)Douglas W. Palmer of Old Westbury, L. I., has been named vice president for ad ministration of BostonUni versity, according to an an nouncement today by the university's president, John R. Silber.

title: Nixon Signs Bill Ending Head Tax Levied at Airports
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) President Nixon signed today legislation eliminating airport head taxes.

title: FOOD TALK
description: For years, Dr. Bernard A. Sachs, an endocrinologist who has done considerable research on cholesterol, has sought to convince high priced restaurants and bake ries about the need to pro vide dishes and products low in saturated fat and choles terol.

title: Records Ordered on the Freeze Prices
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 The Cost of Living Council's freeze group announced today that all sellers would be re quired to maintain freezeprice records and post notices that such records are available start ing next Tuesday at 11:59 P.M.

title: Air Canada Strike Settled; Full Service Due Thursday
description: MONTREAL, June 18 (Ca nadian Press)The president of Air Canada says the airline will restore full service by Thursday after tentative set tlement of a contract dispute with the company's 6,400 ma chinists.

title: Michael Reilly Is Dead at 63; Headed Secret Service Detail
description: BUTTE, Mont., June 18 (AP) Michael Reilly, who served as head of the White House Secret Service detail and was President Franklin D. Roose velt's personal bodyguard dur ing World War II, died Satur day while on a visit to his na tive Montana. He was 63 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Mets Streak Ends at 5 In 9 to 6 Loss to Phillies
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 18It all began when Tom Seaver, tonight's scheduled starter for the Mets, complained of an aching back just before the opener of a threegame series with the Phillies. Manager Yogi Berra lost little time in substi tuting Jim McAndrew for his ace righthander.

title: Dean Said to Keep $14,000 Fund
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 John W. Dean 3d has told Fed eral investigators that he kept $14,000 in 1972 Republican campaign funds and at one time borrowed $4,000 to finance his wedding and honeymoon, sources close to the Watergate case said today.

title: Richardson Collapses
description: SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA June 18, (UPI)  Sir Ralph Richard son, the actor, was discharged from the Royal South Sydney Hospital today, a day after col lapsing at Sydney Airport after a flight from London. Sir Ralph, who is 70 years old, was re ported to have been suffering from exhaustion. A hospital statement said that he would rest in seclusion. Sir Ralph and his wife came to Austrialia to appear in Lloyd George knew My Father.

title: PRICES OF BONDS DECLINE BROADLY
description: The capital markets staged another broad price retreat yesterday, unconvinced that the Government's price freeze will prove a major step in curbing inflation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Seven Madison Avenue stores and hotels, including Abercrombie & Fitch and the Roosevelt and Biltmore Hotels yesterday endorsed the Madi son Avenue mall. It was the first major breakthrough in the heretofore solid wall of opposition to the project among the major midtown retail stores.

title: Mansfield Acted to Aid Summit Talks
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 The Senate Watergate com mittee today canceled its hear ings this week so that they would not detract from the talks here between President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader.

title: BALL WARNS ON CUTS IN TROOPS IN EUROPE
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (Reuters)Former Under Secretary of State George W. Ball warned Congress today against allowing euphoria over progress toward improved EastWest relations to lead to an early withdrawal of some American troops from Western Europe.

title: Another General Chosen As Brazil's Next Leader
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 18Brazil's military leaders have chosen Gen. Ernesto Geisel, the 64yearold head of the state oil monopoly, to become the na tion's next President.

title: MAFIOSO SENTENCED TO LIFE FOR MURDER
description: Robert Bongiovi, once re putedly a bodyguard to the late Joey Gallo, was sentenced to life imprisonment yesterday for the murder of the night man ager of a midtown restaurant.

title: Books of The Times
description: CITY POLICE. By Jonathan Rubinstein. 462 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux $10.

title: Tornado in Iowa Kills 2
description: MOVILLE, Iowa, June 18 (UPI)  A tornado struck the northwest Iowa community of Moville before dawn today, killing two persons and injur ing several residents of two trailer courts.

title: Pennzoil to Build Refinery
description: The Pennzoil Company an nounced yesterday; plans to build a 150,000 to 200,000 barrel a day refinery on the Gulf Coast. The company said the new refinery, would cost more than $200 million. The refinery should be completed within three years, the com pany said.

title: Earle J. Machold, 69, Dies; Niagara Mohawk Chairman
description: SYRACUSE, June 18Earle J. Machold, board chairman of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, died last night at Crouse Irving Memorial Hos pital. He was 69 years old and lived here and in Ellis burg, N. Y.

title: People and Business
description: Dixy Lee Ray, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commis sion, said yesterday that the transition from reliance on oil and natural gas to better usage of coal would be the major energy requirements of the century.

title: $1 0 3Billion City Budget Is Agreed To by Leaders
description: A $10.3billion expense budget for 197374, calling for a realestate tax increase of 36 cents per $100 of assessed valuation, was adopted in formally yesterday by the Lindsay administration, Con troller Abraham D. Beame, the Board of Estimate and City Council leaders.

title: History Has Its Claims
description: Twenty years ago today on Friday, June 19, 1953, a little after 8 P.M., Ethel Rosenberg and Julius Rosenberg were electrocuted at Sing Sing Prison in Ossining, N. Y., by order of the United States Government.

title: ARTHUR BERK
description: Arthur Berk, a taxi broker, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home, 1950 Hutchinson Parkway, the Bronx. He was 54 years old. He leaves his wife, Sandra; two sons, Mi chael and Stewart; his father, Herman Berk, and two broth ers.

title: FREEZE CONFUSES FUTURES TRADERS
description: The President's latest price freeze, imposed last Thursday, has thrown most commodity futures markets into deep con fusion. Not since early in the Korean War have we seen such a mess, one Chicago broker said in a telephone interview yesterday.

title: London: A Lack of Stage Daring Seen
description: LONDON  Robert Bru stein the American critic who has just finished a year here reviewing plays for The Observer departed sounding slightly dubious about the English theater. True he mentioned the sense of foreboding with which I leave your stable society, with its eloquent and homogeneous theater, to enter once again the Ameri can wilderness. But he added that he found that the English theater. stylish and accomplished as it was, lacked emotion andthis last year at leastimag inative daring It has not been a very good season and the point can be underlined by reference to the Old Vic's new production of The Cherry Orchard, which should have been a triumph It was polished and funny but the play's central line of forcethe intolerable loss that leaving the house and orchard meant to Mme. Ran evsky and her familywas never conveyed.
