title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: High Court, by 6 to 3, Reinstates Two Districting Plans
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The Supreme Court reinstated today reapportionment plans for the legislatures of Con necticut and Texas that lower Federal courts had struck down as violating the oneman, one vote requirement.

title: Lawrence Bendiner Dead; Reporter and Publicity Man
description: Lawrence Bendiner, a former newspaper reporter and public relations man died Wednesday at his home, 17025 Highland Avenue, Jamaica, Queens. His age was 72.

title: F.D.A,'S AUTHORITY UPHELD BY COURT
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) The Supreme Court affirmed today the Food and Drug Ad ministration's authority to re move ineffective drugs from the market.

title: Soviet TV at White House
description: MOSCOW, June 18 (UPI)Leonid I. Brezhnev's arrival at the White House today was broadcast live by satellite to the Soviet Union. The description of the ceremony was by the Soviet television commentator Valentin Zorin.

title: Water Panel Urges Cost Shift To Users of Federal Projects
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) The National Water Commis sion's final report today recom mended sweeping changes in the nation's policies that would shift most of the cost of Fed eral water prrojects from the taxpayer to those who benefit from them.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: BOSTONSigned Doug Gibson, center and third choice in draft, to multiyear contract.

title: FAST METROLINER LURES AIR RIDERS
description: Trains are gaining ground on jetliners in the competition for travelers along the 226mile route between New York and Washington.

title: HOUSING STARTS PICKED UP IN MAY
description: WASHINGTON, June Housing starts rebounded May after a threemonth cline and new building permits stabilized, the Commerce partment reported today.

title: African Leaders Will Meet on Drought
description: NIAMEY, Niger, June 16Leaders of the south Saharan African nations struck by fifth year of drought will meet in August in Ouagadougou, the capital of Upper Volta, in an attempt to formulate long range plans to deal with the disaster.

title: 2 Votes on City Budget Open to Public Today
description: The City Council will meet at 1:30 P.M. today to vote on a balanced 197374 executive budget. The Board of Esti mate will also vote today on its version of the municipal budget.

title: Lefkowitz Gives His Data On Vote Scheme to Hogan
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced last night that his investiation of a sus pected Republicanaided scheme to siphon votes from Democra tic candidates for the Assembly had been turned over to Dis trict Attorney Frank S. Hogan for possible criminal prosecu tion.

title: Market Basket Here Off 38c, Reversing the Trend
description: For the first time since the city started its market basket reports in May, the cost of food for a family four declined.

title: Bridg: Moyse Contributed to Game As an Editor for 3 Decades
description: Bridge players all over the world will mourn the loss of Alphonse Moyse Jr., who died here Sunday. He made an immense contribution to the game as editor for some three decades of the most influential of all the game's periodicals, The Bridge World. A few months ago he was honored by being named an honorary member of the International Bridge Press Association.

title: Strike Halts Lindenwold Transit Line
description: CAMDEN, June 18 (UPI)A Superior Court judge issued temporary injunction today, or dering striking trainmen back to work on the Lindenwold High Speed line into Philadelphia.

title: RETIRED GENERA JAILED IN GREECE
description: ATHENS, June 18A retired general who was chief of the Greek intelligence service until 1967 was jailed for 15 months and fined $500 today for spreading alarming false re ports.

title: Dean Said to Keep $14,000 Fund
description: WASHINGTON, June 18John W. Dean 3d has told Fed eral investigators that he kept $14,000 in 1972 Republican campaign funds and at one time borrowed $4,000 to finance his wedding and honeymoon, sources close to the Watergate case said today.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Dairylea Joining National In Bottled Water Company
description: The Dairylea Cooperative, Pearl River, N. Y., one of the country's largest dairy organi zations, is entering the bottled water business. In cooperation with the National Water Cor poration, Dairylea has formed D. L. Nawco, Inc., which will be equally owned and controlled by the founding companies.

title: Miss Ingrid A. Heenan Is Married
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 19  The marriage of Miss Ingrid Anne Heenan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Heenan of New Ca naan, to Ogden Haggerty Hammond 3d, son of Mr. Hammond Jr. of West Palm Beach, Fla.; and Mrs. Living ston Hammond of Geneva, formerly of New York, took place here Saturday.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Securities and Exchange Commission terminated today the suspension of the over thecounter trading in securities of the WestgateCalifornia Corporation and its majorityowned subsidiary, Air Cali fornia, effective at midnight.

title: SUFFOLK ELECTS VILLAGE OFFICIALS
description: Long Island's first woman Mayor, Mrs. Sandra Swenk of Port Jefferson, won reelection yesterday, and two of her Unity party running mates de feated incumbents for Village Trustee posts.

title: Pass Guilty in Yablonski Deaths; One More Arrest Is Predicted
description: ERIE, Pa., June 19 (AP) Albert E. Pass, a former as sistant to W. Boyle, the United Mine Workers president was convicted of firstdegree murder today in the Yablonski slayings.

title: Phnom Penh Regains Part of Key Route
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 19 (UPI)  Cambodian troops today regained control of a section of a supply road southwest of here that had been in Communist hands for two weeks.

title: 2 YOUNG MEN SLAIN AT ILLINOIS SCHOOL
description: MAYWOOD, Ill., June 19 (UP1)Two young men study ing to be teachers in religious schools were stabbed and axed to death today on the grounds of the school where they had taken summer jobs.

title: PAYOLAJURY ASKS TESTIMONY ON TIPS
description: The Federal grand jury in Newark investigating allegation of payola in the record indus try has subponeaed Kal Rud man, a leading pop music tip sheet publisher, to appear this week, Mr. Rudman's lawyer acknolwledged yesterday.

title: Records: Shearing Solos
description: When George Shearing, re cording with a quintet in 1949, stumbled upon an at tractive and slightly different sound by using a unison of piano, vibraphone and elec tric guitar, he had the key that opened the door to popu larity and fortune. But when he walked through that door he found himself locked into a small musical closet, doomed to repeat his for mula, or a close approxima tion of it, over and over again on records.

title: STATE RESTRICTS WELFARE SYSTEM
description: Charging that the city admin. istration's highly prized corn puter operation for processing welfare and medical assistance cases was not working, the state issued a stoporder yes terday on further expenditlire: to develop the system.

title: NEW PAVLOVA, 17, WINS GRAND PRIZE
description: MOSCOW, June 19A new Pavlova, at 17 Russia's latest dance prodigy, was awarded the grand prize today in the Inter national Ballet Competition as Soviet dancers collected 11 of the 17 medals offered.

title: Rohm Plant Set for Houston
description: Rohm & Haas, Inc., announced yesterday that it would locate its new 400 million pound a year acrylate monomer plant the world's largestin Deer Park at Houston. The Company said the plant was scheduled to start operations in late 1975.

title: Hospital Room Terrorized
description: NEWNAN, Ga., June 19 (UPI) A gunman took over the emergency room of the New nan Hospital early today and held three nurses hostage for nearly three hours. Police Chief Jerry Helton said the gunman, Billy Trivett, about 30 years old, of Coweta County, was finally talked into surrendering by a friend. No one was injured. The chief said Trivett, at the time of the incident, had been using prescription drugs and had been drinking.

title: U.S. Men Win, Women Lose Against Chinese Quintets
description: TOKYO, June 19 (AP) George Karl of North Caro lina and George Pennell of South Plains College led a United States basketball team to an 8859 victory over the Chinese Physical Culture Insti tutes combined team in Peking tonight, Hsinhua, the Chinese government press agency re ported.

title: Columbia Broadens Voting On University's Trustees
description: Columbia University's 125,000 alumni will have a direct voice in the selection of six of the university's 24 trustees accord ing to new rules adopted by the trustees, it was announced yesterday.

title: Vietnamese Child Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) Senator Harrison A. Wil liams, Democrat of New Jersey, introduced a bill today to au thorize a program of assistance for Vietnamese children or Thaned or otherwise displaced by the war. The bill would au thorize $2.5million to help the Vietnamese Government set up agencies and programs for the health and welfare of South Vietnamese children.

title: SHARED U.S. FUNDS USED IN BUILDING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 19State and local governments are pouring generalrevenue sharing money into building projects and public safety while virtually ignoring social service programs, according to a Fed eral survey.

title: Brookdale Hospital Plans Health Fair on Saturday
description: A Summer Health Fair featur ing free medical tests and edu cational exhibits will be held Saturday at the Brookdale Hos pital Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: U.S. Men Win, Women Lose Against Chinese Quintets
description: TOKYO, June 19 (AP) George Karl of North Caro lina and George Pennell of South Plains College led a United States basketball team to an 8859 victory over the Chinese Physical Culture Insti tutes combined team in Peking tonight, Hsinhua, the Chinese Government press agency re ported.

title: Paris Says Bugging Phones Is Its Right
description: PARIS, June 19 (AP)A high Government official told the French Senate today that Gov ernment wiretapping was none of its affair. He reaffirmed that the taps would continue in a wide variety of cases.

title: Exxon Stations on 2 Toll Roads Are Limiting Sales of Gasoline
description: NEWARK, June 19 (AP)Exxon stations on New Jersey's two major toll roads are limit ing gasoline sales.

title: Rhodesian Bishops Gain Some Support In RaceLaw Fight
Texts of U.S.Soviet Accords on Exchanges in Technical and Cultural Matters
In Poland, Posters Reign as a PreEminent Art Form
description: WARSAW  in Poland, which so far as is known has the world's only museum devoted exclusively to poster art, posters must promote Marxist consciousness as well as sell toothpaste or announce the arrival in town of a threering circus.

title: POLICE IN HARTFORD HANDED A NEW CODE
description: HARTFORD, June 19The Hartford police have been handed a new code that re quires them to be more con siderate of the rights and feel ings of citizens, especially black and Spanishspeaking ones.

title: Construction Worker Killed By Fall in East River Tunnel
description: A 40yearold construction worker was killed yesterday when he fell 400 feet into an excavation in the East River subway tunnel being built be tween Queens and Manhattan at 61st Street.

title: Pele Takes Over Goal After Tallying Twice
description: BALTIMORE, June 19 (AP) Reid scored on a corner kick and a penalty shot to night, then played the last nine minutes as the goalie, as Santos of Brazil beat the Baltimore Bays, 40.

title: HOUSE PANEL ADDS TO FUNDS FOR CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI)  The House Appropria tions Committee today proposed spending $820million that Pres ident Nixon left out of his 1974 budget for city improvement projects.

title: Abortion Law Voided
description: LANSING, Mich., June 19 (UPI)The Michigan Supreme Court today ruled unconstitu tional Michigan's abortion law, which permits the operation only to save the life of the mother. Basing its decision on the United States Supreme Court ruling on abortion stat utes, the court said abortions might be performed for any reason in Michigan during the first three months of preg nancy.

title: Business Records
Dr. Richard Newhall, 85, Dies; History Professor at Williams
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 19Richard A. Newhall, emeri tus professor of history at Williams College and inter. nationally known as an author ity on medieval English military history, died last night at North Adams Regional Hospital. He I was 85 years old.

title: Equity Financing
description: A special offering of 34,200 common shares of Saunders Leasing at 9 per share was made yes terday by Bear Stearns & Co. The company's stock, traded on the American Stock Exchange, closed at 9, down .

title: Unhappy U.S. Marxists
description: In 1848 the French and Prus sian police, working together, flad Karl Marx expelled from the European continent. He fled to liberal England, the foremost capitalist power of the time. Soon afterward, a Prus sian police spy wrote this de scription of the slum in Dean Street, Soho, where Marx was living with his wife and three children and their usually unpaid servant: He lives in one of the worst and cheapest neighborhoods in Lon don. He occupies two rooms there is not one clean or decent piece of furniture in either room, everything is broken, tattered and torn, with thick dust over everything and the greatest untidiness everywhere.

title: MEDICAL COLLEGE AND UNION IN PACT
description: NEWARK, June 19  The College of Medicine and Den tistry of New Jersey and the American Association of Uni versity Professors have ratified a twoyear contract that is re ported to be among the first of its kind in the country.

title: REFORM JEWS PLAN FAMILY PROGRAMS
description: ATLANTA, June 19Ameri can Reform Judaism, faced with the breakdown of the Jewish family unit as the dominant force in the survival of Judaism, moved today to arrest this con dition through a comprehensives series of familycentered pro grams.

title: Mayor and Cawley Hail Citizens on Aid In Seizing Suspects
description: Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Donald F. Caw ley yesterday applauded an evident new willingness on the part of New Yorkers to get involved and to try to stop crimes of violence.

title: Bridge: Efforts Under Way to Form Teams in City. Area Schools
description: The English Bridge Union has for many years organized a tournament for schools in which more than 60 teams compete. The United States has been passive in this area, in part perhaps because of the Puritan traditioncards are the Devil's Pasteboards and in part because of some feeling that bridge may tempt a student from his aca demic efforts.

title: Advertising: Backing U.S. Way
description: Thomas B. Adams, chair man of CampbellEwald, yes terday joined that giowing list of agency executives who are trying to promote public service advertising support ing the American way, American business and the American profit system.

title: U.S. Says 2 Realty Groups Fixed Fees in Coops Here
description: Two major realestate groups were charged by the Gov ernment yesterday with fixing commissions for the sale and the management of cooperative apartments in Manhattan.

title: Banker Indicted on Four Counts In Maryland Salute to Agnew
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 19 A fourcount indictment charging violations of state elec tion laws was served today on Blagden H. Wharton, treasurer of a Salute to Ted Agnew fund raising committee.

title: Great Lakes Carbon Is Accused Of Anticompetitive Practices
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) The Federal Trade Commis sion said today it had ruled that the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation and eight oilre fining companies had engaged in anticompetitive practices through their longterm, full output contracts for petroleum coke used primarily in the chemical and metalrefining industries.

title: Police to Use TV to Scan Times Sq. Area for Crime
description: A crackdown on crime in the Times Square area through the use of closedcircuit television is due to begin next month. Under plans being made by the Police Department, the television eyes for the Great White Way and its side streets will be set up with the arrival of a police trailer in the Times Square area. The trailer will have television screens.

title: Nassau Again Votes on Budgets For Schools and Spurns 2 of 3
description: Voters in three Nassau. Coun ty communities who rejected proposed school budgets ear lier returned to the polls last night and turned down two revised outlays. The third was approved.

title: The Bidding's a 4Alarm Blazer As City Auctions Off Firehouse
description: At 2:30 yesterday after noon, the grand ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel was filled with 500 people, most of them dreaming dreams of a renovated firehouse.

title: CHILE POLICE ROUT FOES OF ALLENDE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 19 (UPI)  Riot policemen used tear gas on rockthrowing op ponents of President Salvador Allende Gossens tonight at the end of a torchlight demonstra tion whose participants de manded settlement of the 62 day strike at El Teniente, the nationalized copper mine.

title: Prosecutor Moves to Protect Dean Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Watergate special prosecution force presented a sealed folder of evidence to Federal District Court today in a move to pro tect any future criminal case that it might bring against John W. Dean 3d.

title: Clash Over Police Revives Rivalries in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, June 19  A longstanding battle with occasional comicopera overtones broke into the open here last week between remnants of the largely Irish and largely Reform Democratic groups that ran this city and its Police Department for many years and the largely Democratic regulars who have supplanted them.

title: NEW JERSEY GETS 75 TAX DEADLINE
description: TRENTON, June 19  The State Supreme Court today gave the Legislature 18 months to approve a new, constitution al, method of financing public school education in New Jersey. If the Legislature fails, the court said it would impose a new system on its own.

title: Notes on People
description: Lots of things happen on the floor of the Senate, but rarely a birth announcement. Nevertheless, yesterday it was the place where Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Vir ginia announced the birth of a grandchildnot his, but the first for Senator Mike Mansfield. The child, a girl, was born in London to the Montana Democrat's daugh ter, Anne, wife of Dr. Robin Marris, a professor of eco nomics at Cambridge Uni versity. The baby's name, with allowance for the fact that members of the Sena tor's staff are not positive about the spellings, is Caro line Hayes Theresa. Senator Byrd called the birth his col league's first taste of im mortality.

title: Hospital Room Terrorized
description: NEWNAN, Ga., June 19 (UPI) A gunman took over the emergency room of the New nan Hospital early today and held three nurses hostage for nearly three hours. Police Chief Jerry Helton said the gunman, Billy Trivett, about 30 years old, of Coweta County, was finally talked into surrendering by a friend. No one was injured. The chief said Trivett, at the time of the incident, had been using prescription drugs and had been drinking.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 Daily index numbers and spot primary market commodity prices for June 5, 1973 to June 12, 1973, follow:

title: Two in Atlanta Killed in Dispute Laid to Sales by Black Muslims
description: ATLANTA, June 19 (AP)Two persons, one a policeman, were killed and three others wounded in a burst of gunfire on a downtown street today as crowds returning from lunch looked on.

title: MAYER ADVANCES IN N.C.A.A. TENNIS
description: PRINCETON, N.J., June 19 (AP)The top favorites ad vanced through the second round of the annual National Collegiate tennis championship today.

title: StakeOut Squad Is Disbanding As Cawley Shifts Special Units
description: Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley is disbanding the de partment's controversial stake out squad, which has killed about 25 holdup men since it was organized in May, 1968.

title: Dynamite Found in Home Of Late Minuteman Aide
description: BRENTWOOD, Md., June 19 (UPI)Federal Bureau of Inves tigation agents found 50 pounds of dynamite last night in the home of Jesse Stephens, an extremist rightwing leader who died last week,

title: C.O.P. Reelects Calandra
description: State Senator John D. Calan dra was unanimously reelected last night to a fourth oneyear term as chairman of the Bronx Republican party, party officials reported. Mr. Calandra was chosen by some 1,100 county committeemen meeting at Evan der Childs High School, 800 East Gunhill Road.

title: Mrs. Mitchell Says Media Make Her Prisoner in Home
description: Mrs. John N. Mitchell came out of her luxury apartment building yesterday and charged that the news media had made her a prisoner on Fifth Avenue.

title: 2 CREWMEN DEAD; BODIES REMOVED FROM SUBMARINE
description: KEY WEST, Fla., June 19The bodies of two oceanograph ers were removed late tonight from the research submarine JohnsonSeaLink 29 hours after the vessel was rescued from the ocean floor off Key West.

title: Street Peddler Ignored 1,050 City Summonses
description: A street peddler with 1,050 unanswered sum monses received for operat ing without a license was ar rested last night at 14th Street and the Avenue of Americas, where officers of the Manhattan warrant squad said he was selling two box es of cherries,

title: U.S. Oil and Gas Reserves Fell Almost 5% Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) United States oil and gas re serves decreased almost 5 per cent last year as consumption continued to outstrip new dis coveries, the American Petrol eum Institute reported today.

title: Vietcong Deny Their Troops Shot at Truce Team Copters
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 19 (UPI)The Vietcong denied today that any of their troops fired on two helicopters of the international peacekeeping force on Sunday and accused the Canadian delegation of in accurate reporting of the in cident.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Medical College Signs 2 Year Union Pact
description: NEWARK, June 19The Col lege of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and the Ameri can Association of University Professors have ratified a twoyear contract that is reported to be among the first of its kind in the country.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Police to Use TV to Scan Times Sq. Area for Crime
description: A crackdown on crime in the Times Square area through the use of closedcircuit television is due to begin next month. Under plans being made by the Police Department, the television eyes for the Great White Way and its side streets will be set up with the arrival of a police trailer in the Times Square area. The trailer will have television screens.

title: Voluntary Overtime a Key U.A.W. Issue
description: DETROIT, June 19The de mand that overtime be made voluntary has become a key and decisive issue in the up coming negotiations for a new contract between the United Automobile Workers Union and the auto companies.

title: VINCENT M. GUGLIELMO
description: Vincent M. Guglielmo, a vice president of the Flygt Corpora tion, a subsidiary of the Inter national Telephone and Tele graph Corporation that manu factures pumping equipment, died in Copenhagen on June 9, apparently of a heart attack. He was 42 years old and lived at 510 East 20th Street.

title: PRESIDENT YIELDS IN FIGHT TO SLASH DOMESTIC FUNDS; Signs Three Bills Exceeding Budget by $671Million in Compromise Move; VICTORY FOR CONGRESS; Nixon HardLine Is Dropped on Health, Economic and Airport Aid Programs
New Jersey Sports
description: TEANECK, June 19When she was appointed Fairleigh Dickinson University's vice president for development last September, Evelyn Terhune was urged by friends to quit as the women's fencing coach.

title: Equation Breaks Record In AnnapolisNewport Sail
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 19Equation, a 68foot ketch as loaded with modern technology as an Apollo spacecraft, won today the AnnapolistoNewport race, the leading offshore yacht ing event on the East Coast this year. John T. Potter's long, lean craft, called endearingly a mean monster by her crew, smashed the 8yearold course record by 4 hours 19 minutes for the 473mile race that be gan last Saturday at Annapolis in Chespeake Bay. She routed her opposition.

title: Red Cross Manager Here Enters Retirement Today
description: Joseph L. Carter, manager of the American Red Cross in Greater New York since the citywide headquarters was es. tablished in 1959, is retiring today.

title: U.S. Aides Reach Haiphong To Resume Minesweeping
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, June 19 Agence France Presse  The first group of American special ists who will renew minesweep ing arrived yesterday in the port of Haiphong, the official Vietnam press agency said to day.

title: 2 Kidnapped in Argentina As Country Awaits Peron
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 19Police officials disclosed to day that an American execu tive had been kidnapped on Monday in what appeared to be a guerrilla operation. The disclosure came as thousands of Argentines poured into Bue nos Aires for what organizers hoped would be a largescale but peaceful homecoming cele bration for former President Juan D. Pern.

title: CITY GETS BUDGET OF $10.16BILLION
description: The Board of Estimate and the City Council yesterday for mally approved a $10.16billion expense budget for 197374 n the basic realestate tax rate. informal agreement had been reached Monday.

title: StakeOut Squad Is Disbanding As Cawley Shifts Special Units
description: Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley is disbanding the de partment's controversial stake out squad, which has killed about 25 holdup men since it was organized in May, 1968.

title: CONRAD BRINGS IN SKYLAB SUN FILM
description: HOUSTON, June 19Two of the Skylab 1 astronauts went outside their space station to day to retrieve exposed film from solar telescopes and, in a return engagement as orbital repairmen, to hammer a battery back into action.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Oregon Paper Honored
description: TEMPE, Ariz., June 19 (AP)  The Bend, (Ore.) Bulletin will receive the 1973 Citation of Merit presented by the Ameri can Society of Journalism School Administrators. The newspaper has fostered a com munity press council since 1967.

title: Football Transactions
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: Graduated Taxes on New Cars Studied for Gasoline Economy
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Administration spokesmen told Congress today that the energy crisis could be met largely by voluntary measures but that the gasoline shortage might call for new or increased Federal taxes to discourage waste.

title: MRS. JERRIER HADDAD
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., June 19Mrs. Margaret Van Hamlin Haddad, wife of Jerrier A. Haddad, a vice president of the International Business Ma chines Corporation who directed development of the company's first electronic computer, died today in Memorial Hospital, New York. She was 48 years old and lived at 162 Macy Road.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The woman and her son who were wounded when Major Benjamin Coxson was slain in his rented $200,000 mansion earlier this month have applied for medical reim bursement from the State Violent Crimes Compensation Board. The application was filed in behalf of Lois Luby, 35 years old, and her son, Toro, 15, by Mark Boyer, manager of patient accounts at Cherry Hill Medical Center, where the two are listed in good condition following the June 8. shootings.

title: Stage: Antiques Opens
description: Sad to relate, but for me the worst moment at the new geriatric show, Antiques, which opened at the Mercer O'Casey Theater last night, came with a simple an nouncement. The playbill re ported that the show would be performed without an in termission. Then, after a pe riod of some pain, about halfway through the show, someone announced: There will be a 15minute inter mission, and bang went an other 15 minutes of my ex istence.

title: Chavez Aide Is Arrested
description: COACHELLA, Calif., June 19 (UPD)Marshall Ganz, a top aide to the United Farm Work ers leader, Cesar Chavez, was arrested today when he at tempted to prevent nonU.F.W. workers from packing grapes in boxes bearing the union's label. Harvesting of table grapes continued despite the presence of 850 U.F.W, pick ets at vineyards where growers had contracts with the Team sters' union.

title: JOHN M'INERNEY
description: RED BANK, N.J., June 19 John McInerney, a member of the staff of Travel Trade, a business publication in the travel field, died, apparently of a heart attack, Sunday at his home, 99 McLean Street. He was 41 years old.

title: Columbans Name Leader
description: BELLEVUE, Neb., June 19 (AP)The Rev. Joseph Murrin has been appointed to head the Columban Fathers community, at national headquarters at St. Columbans near Bellevue. He succeeds the Rev. Paul Keppner of Buffalo, who plans to study business and accounting at Creighton University.

title: DOLLAR IN EUROPE RALLIES STRONGLY
description: LONDON, June 19 (AP) The dollar rallied strongly to day as a degree of stability re turned to European currency ex changes.

title: COURT TELLS CITY TO STAY RENT LAW
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice yesterday ordered that the city hold off implementing new law that repeals the maxi mumbaserent formula of the local rent control program which permits rent rises of up to 7.5 per cent a year in many controlled apartments here.

title: Israel's Borders...
description: The renewed United Nations debate on the Middle East has recessed, still deadlocked on the issue that has been blocking progress toward peace since Ambassador Gun nar Jarring tried to break the ArabIsraeli impasse by submitting questionnaires to the parties in early 1971. The crucial issue revolves around the withdrawal from territories occupied in the recent conflict, as called fir in the Security Council resolution of November 1967.

title: People in Sports: Worsham a Winner Again
description: Lew Worsham didn't swing a golf club in the United States Open at the Oakmont Country Club but was quoted on television as having said he might surpass the $35,000 Johnny Miller took home for winning the championship Sunday. The 56yearold Wor sham, the Oakmont club pro, sold concession itemsgolf caps, jackets, chairs and other thingsto some of the 102,623 persons who attended the three days of practice rounds and the four days of the tournament. Worsham failed to qualify for the Open.

title: U.S. ASKS TO STAY LITTON PAYMENTS
description: The Government took new legal action yesterday to delay further payments to Litton In dustries on its $1billion con tract to build five longdelayed LHA amphibiousassault ships.

title: Shades of the MidiLonger Skirts Make Hesitant Comeback
description: It's hardly a landslide and not even its stanchest sup porters dream it will dom inate the way women look next fall. Many retailers tend to close their eyes and wish it would go away. Even the designers who have promul gated it tread softly and speak gently, saying things like, It's up to the customer to decide.

title: RollerCoaster Market Mixed in Active Trading
description: The stock market was ,on roller coaster yesterday. A sharp rally in the last halfhour enabled it to finish mixed in steppedup trading.

title: 25 YOUTHS STONE HOUSE IN JAMAICA
description: About 25 youths, believed to be members of a gang called the Seven Crowns, stoned private house on Linden Boule vard in the South Jamaica sec tion of Queens last night and, according to the police, threat ened to burn it down.

title: U.S. Says 2 Realty Groups Fixed Fees in Coops Here
description: Two major realestate groups were charged by the Gov ernment yesterday with fixing commissions for the sale and the management of cooperative apartments in Manhattan.

title: SHULTZ WELCOMES IDEAS FOR CONTROLS
description: Washington, June 19Secre tary of the Treasury George P. Shultz has invited the grocery industry, and by inference all industries, to let the Govern ment know at once what rules and standards should be ap plied in Phase 4 of the price wage control system.

title: GORDIE HOWE GETS $1MILLION PACT
description: The World Hockey Associa tion, grappling for recognition and boxoffice dollars, reached into the National Hockey League's past yesterday for Gordie Howe.

title: Car Injuries Fatal To Angel of Attica Day After Wedding
description: WARSAW, N. Y., June 19 (AP)Walter C. (Tiny) Swift, who won the nickname Angel of Attica for administering to the injured during the 1971 Attica prison riot, died last night.

title: SCHOOL LUNCH CUTS PUT 665 OUT OF JOBS
description: A $27million cut in its pro jected $106 million school lunch budget has forced the Board of Education to dismiss 665 employes in the program and abandon plans to start providing fullcourse, hot mid day meals instead of soup and sandwiches in 180 elementary public schools.

title: Sports News Briefs.
description: CHICAGO, June 19 (UPI)Janet Lynn of Rockford, Ill., the 20yearold figureskating star, signed contracts today that will pay her more than $2million. One contract, with the Ice Follies, will pay her $1.455million over three years as a special guest star. Negotiations are under way for television specials and a motion picture. The contracts were signed in the office of Arthur Wirtz, owner of the Chicago Stadium and the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: American Y.C. Women Win Morgan Cup Sailing Title
description: Rye, N.Y., June 19 Mrs. Beverley Becker and Mrs. Nancy Meade finished one, two, respectively, today to lead the American Yacht Club to vic tory in the Morgan Cup, emble matic of the women's interclub sailing championship of Long Island Sound. The ninemile race was sailed in Etchell 22's off the American Yacht Club in a 12mile easterly.

title: U.S. and Hanoi Aides Talk
description: PARIS, June 19 (UPI)Ameri can and North Vietnamese of ficials met today for the 10th time to determine how much money Washington should give Hanoi in reconstruction as sistance.

title: HitachiSinger Is Formed
description: TOKYO June 19 (Reuters) An American Japanese, joint venture company, Hitachi Singer, Ltd., will be started here this. week to sell pointofsale products and systems and free standing cash registers for use in department stores and super markets, Hitachi, Ltd.. and the Singer Company jointly an nounced today. Capitalized at about $11.5million and equally owned by Hitachi and Singer, the new company will also maintain and service the sys tems and machines.

title: Nixon Ends Fees on Imports Of Canadian Oil Products
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) President Nixon today re moved ali Federal tariffs from 1973 imports of petroleum prod ucts from Canada, in a move to increase those imports if the Canadians agree.

title: Dean Reportedly Says Nixon Wanted List of Trouble Newsmen
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 John W. Dean 3d has told Sen ate investigators that President Nixon asked him to keep a list of newsmen who were giving the President trouble during last year's election campaign, according to Senate sources.

title: Some Senators Not Convinced by Brezhnev on Jews
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Senators who listened to an afterlunch monologue by Leonid I. Brezhnev today said later that they were impressed by his preparations, his charm, his eagerness for better Soviet American relationsbut not necessarily by his defense of his country's policy toward Jews.

title: Will Seek to Learn If Funds for Campaign Were Misused
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Senate Watergate committee plans to investigate the per sonal finances of the partici pants in the bugging and cover up episode to determine whether large sums of Republican campaign money were misap propriated or in other ways wrongfully used Senate sources said today.

title: YOUTH IS WOUNDED AT AMUSEMENT PARK
description: A 17yearold youth was shot in the chest at about o'clock last night at the Ad venturer Amusement Park on Linden Place next to the Flush ing Airport in Queens.

title: RISE IN INVESTING FROM JAPAN SEEN
description: Minoru Segawa, chairman of the Nomura Securities Com pany, Ltd., one of Japan's lead ing brokerage houses, predicted yesterday that Japanese in vestors would put $4billion to $5billion in American stocks in the next few years.

title: Dynamite Found in Home Of Late Minuteman Aide
description: BRENTWOOD, Md., June 19 (UPI)Federal Bureau of Inves tigation agents found 50 pounds of dynamite last night in the home of Jesse Stephens, an extremist rightwing leader who died last week.

title: FaceLift Studied for Botanical Garden Conservatory
Most Prices Decline in Credit Markets
description: The credit markets continued yesterday to reflect a belief that no major progress against inflation would occur through the freeze in prices and that interest rates must rise still further. Prices de clined in most sectors of the money and bond markets, driving rates broadly high er as the corporate and tax exempt markets prepared to underwrite a staggering amount of new financing today.

title: AMEX PRICES SLIP; 0TC ISSUES RISE
description: Reversing the direction that prevailed during the morning, prices dropped during the after noon to close lower in quiet trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Garelik Also Backs the Controller's Bid for Mayor, but Favor Isn't Returned
description: A ballroom full of chanting taxi drivers  whose parked vehicles made a vast yellow splotch on the western edge of Union Squarethe officers of the Patrolmen's Benevolent As sociation and City Council President Sanford D. Garelik, who tried briefly to run for Mayor himself, all endorsed Controller Abraham D. Beame yesterday in the Democratic mayoral runoff.

title: Feuerbach Wins in Prague
description: PRAGUE, June 19 (AP)A1 Feuerbach of San Jose, Calif., won the shotput at an'interna tional track meet here today with a put of 66 feet 11 inches. Jim Bolding of Oklahoma City won the 400meter hurdles in 49.9 seconds.

title: Roundup: Hendrick Clouts 3 Homers as Indians Win
description: Shortly after he was traded from Oakland to the Indians this year, George Hendrick made a big impression on Cleveland's pitching coach, Warren Spahn. No doubt he made an even bigger impres sion on Detroit last night as he led the Indians to an 87 victory over the Tigers that snapped a sixgame losing streak.

title: People and Business
description: The appointment of an American to head the Aus tralian branch of the General Motors Corporation was sharply criticized yesterday in Canberra by Prime Minis ter Gough Whitlam.

title: GOINGI OUT Guide
description: AUTHOR, AUTHOR What With everyone talking about directors and actors, there's a feeling in some quarters that there should be a word in behalf of the people who write movies, too. The New York Cultural Center, 2 Co lumbus Circle (5812311), is doing something about it, launching a 17film lookback at the nineteenthirties and forties called Hollywood Screenwriters, running from today through Aug, 16.

title: GORDIE HOWE GETS $1MILLION PACT
description: The World Hockey Associa tion, grappling for recognition and boxoffice dollars, reached into the National Hockey League's past yesterday for Gordie Howe.

title: Ross Takes Two Matches In New Jersey Title Tennis
description: KEARNY, N. J., June 19Topseeded Steve Ross of Brook lyn opened the defense of his New Jersey State men's tennis championship with two victories today at the Arlington Players Club. He ousted Steve Sinoway of South Orange, 61, 63, and Bob Zeckhauser of East Or ange, 61, 62.

title: Voluntary Overtime a Key U.A.W. Issue
description: DETROIT, June 19The de mand that overtime be made voluntary has become a key and decisive issue in the up coming negotiations for a new contract between the United Automobile Workers Union and the auto companies.

title: French Are a Bit Upset By White House Menu
description: PARIS, June 19 (UPI)A menu half in French and half in English? A Cabernet wine with beef?

title: Laird Assures G.O.P. Senators Of Closer Ties to White House
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Melvin R. Laird, who was named Presidential Counselor for Domestic Affairs less than two weeks ago, went to the Capitol today to improve White House relations with Republi can Senators and apparently succeeded.

title: Fun for Children
description: Films

title: Record $6.2Billion Is Bid For U.S. Offshore Leases
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 19 (UPI)Oil companies offered record $6.2billion today to ob tain drilling rights to 104 sec tions of offshore territory south of Texas and Louisiana.

title: Charles W. Lester, Surgeon And Teacher, Is Dead at 80
description: Dr. Charles W. Lester, a chest surgeon and a teacher of sur gery, died yesterday at Roose velt Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 320 East 72d Street.

title: LUIS VAN ROOTER ACTOR, 66, IS DEAD
description: CHATHAM, Mass., June 19Luis d'Antin Van Roolen, an actor whose voice and face were more famous than his name, died here Sunday at the retirement home he had de signed himself, He was 66 years old.

title: Tishman Heads Montefiore
description: Robert V. Tishman, president of Tishman Realty and Con struction Company, Inc., has been elected president of the Montefiore Hospital and Medi cal Center in the Bronx. Mr. Tishman is chairman of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., and director of the New York Urban Coalition. The center has 2,037 beds.

title: Kelley Says He Will Resist Pressure
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Clarence M. Kelley, the Kansas City, Mo., police chief who has been nominated by President Nixon to head the Federal Bu ?? of Investigation, said to day that he had never bowed to political pressure and I don't mean to start.

title: Memo To All Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Before long the prosecutors in the Watergate case will start investigating the big financial contributions to the Nixon reelection committee, and this likely to open up a whole new chap ter in the current political scandals.

title: NEW PAVLOVA, 17, WINS GRAND PRIZE
description: MOSCOW, June 19A new Pavlova, at 17 Russia's latest dance prodigy, was awarded the grand prize today in the Inter national Ballet Competition as Soviet dancers collected 11 of the 17 medals offered.

title: Herbert Schlosser Named President of N.B.C.TV
description: Herbert S. Schlosser was ap pointed president of the Na tional Broadcasting Company television network yesterday, replacing Don Durgin, who has been named an executive vice president of N.B.C.

title: TV: Plight of Racially Mixed Children in Vietnam
description: The National Broadcasting Company fared rather poorly in this year's Emmy Awards for news, but the network apparently is determined to make the competition stiffer the next time around. Last week N.B.C. Reports offered the producer Fred Freed's Murder in America. Last night, at 10, it presented Rob ert Northshield's equally tough and unblinking The Sins of the Fathers.

title: Records: Shearing Solos
description: When George Shearing, re cording with a quintet in 1949, stumbled upon an at tractive and slightly different sound by using a unison of piano, vibraphone and elec tric guitar, he had the key that opened the door to popu larity and fortune. But when he walked through that door he found himself locked into a small musical closet, doomed to repeat his for mula, or a close approxima tion of it, over and over again on records.

title: GENESCO CANCELS COMMON DIVIDEND
description: Genesco, Inc., yesterday omitted its regular quarterly dividend payable July 31 on common stock and announced it was considering setting up reserve of up to $60million against potential losses due to discontinuation or restructur ing of several operating divi sions.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Prices of all grains and soy beans for future delivery shot upward yesterday despite what brokers termed a scared mar ket.

title: SENATOR ASSAILS REVISED F14 PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Senator Stuart Symington, the acting chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee complained today that the F14 interceptor had been shoved down the throats of the Marine Corps to lower the cost of the plane to the Navy.

title: FREEZE PUZZLING TO ALLIED STORES
description: Thomas M. Macioce, presi ent and chief executive officer of the Allied Stores Corporation New York, told the annua meeting here yesterday that is difficult to comprehend how prices can be controlled wher rent, interest and wages are exempt from the President's latest price freeze.

title: GEORGE DONALD BILLOCK
description: George Donald Billock, secre tarytreasurer of Vulcan, Inc., al nationwide manufacturer of steel ingots, died yesterday in Presbyterian Hospital in Pitts burgh. He was 64 years old and lived in Greensburg, Pa.

title: Congressman Says Plan for Continuing Accounting Would Curb Abuses
description: Representative Herman Ba dillo promised yesterday that if he became Mayor he would have independent certified pub lic accounting firms conduct continuing audits of all city agencies and programs.

title: Robintech in Joint Venture
description: Robintech, Inc., said yester day that it had agreed with ShinEtsu Chemical Company, Ltd., of Japan to jointly con struct a 250milliontonayear polyvinyl chloride resin plant in Freeport, Tex.

title: HOUSE UNIT CURBS NIXON ON EXPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 The House Banking Committee approved legislation today that apparently will give President Nixon the authority he seeks to control exports of grains and oilseeds such as soybeans.

title: 40 BUSINESSMEN TO MEET BREZITNEY
description: Invitations have gone out to 40 American business leaders to meet with Leonid I. Brezh nev, the Soviet Communist party leader.

title: Win or Lose, Horses Hit Wire Faster Here
description: When an undistinguished claimer named Portangle ran six furlongs in 1:10 4/5 at Aqueduct yesterday, hardly anyone in the crowd of 21,195 raised an eyebrow.

title: CITY GETS BUDGET OF $10.16BILLION
description: The Board of Estimate and the City Council yesterday for mally approved a $10.16billion expense budget for 197374, in the basic realestate tax rate. Informal agreement had been reached Monday.

title: People in Sports: Worsham a Winner Again
description: Lew Worsham didn't swing a golf club in the United States Open at the Oakmont Country Club but was quoted on television as having said he might surpass the $35,000 Johnny Miller took home for winning the championship Sunday. The 56yearold Wor sham, the Oakmont club pro, sold concession itemsgolf caps, jackets, chairs and other thingsto some of the 102,623 persons who attended the three days of practice rounds and the four days of the tournament. Worsham failed to qualify for the Open.

title: Coed Is Slain in C. W. Post Dormitory
description: GRENVALLE, L.I., June 19A 21yearold coed was found dead today of multiple stab wounds in her second floor room in a dormitory at the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University.

title: U.S. Says 2 Realty Groups Fixed Fees in Coops Here
description: Two major realestate groups were charged by the Gov ernment yesterday with fixing commissions for the sale and the management of cooperative apartments in Manhattan.

title: Hearings Tentatively Set To Resume Next Monday
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)The Senate Watergate hearings are tentatively set to resume Monday with John W. Dean 3d, ousted White House counsel, scheduled to begin his testimony.

title: Merger Called Off by Slater Walker and Hill Samuel
description: LONDON, June 19The proposed merger of Slater Walker Securities and Hill Samuel & Co., the merchant bankers, was called off to day because of incompati bility of work style and personalities of the men who shook hands on the deal less than eight weeks ago.

title: Will Seek to Learn If Funds for Campaign Were Misused
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Senate Watergate committee plans to investigate the per sonal finances of the partici. pants in the bugging and cover up episode to determine whether large sums of Republican campaign money were misap propriated or in other ways wrongfully used, Senate sources said today.

title: Wimbledon Boycotted By Top Tennis Players
Saigon Stages Big Parade 5 Days Alter New Truce
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 19Jet fighters howled overhead and snarling tanks shook the streets of Saigon to day as the South Vietnamese Army staged the biggest armed forces day parade in the his tory of the country. only five days after the reaffirmation of the ceasefire.

title: May Fund Redemptions Continued to Top Sales
description: Mutual fund redemptions con Ainued to outpace sales by wide margin, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: YANKEES TRIUMPH OVER ORIOLES, 54; LYLE SAVES GAME
Textbooks a Start in Campaign To End PolishGerman Hatred
description: WARSAW, June 11  For a thousand years, ever since King Mieszko, we have lived in conflict with the Germans to our west. But we must think now of the next thousand years.

title: Cut in Deer Deaths Sought
description: BEAVER, Utah, June 19 (AP) Highway and wildlife offi cials say they will advertise for bids next month on a free way overpass for deer, The overpass is to be built in a part of Beaver County where offi cials say 67 deer have been killed by motorists so far this year.

title: SHOP TALK
description: You wouldn't expect table legs sold without a top to be wildly popular items. But the legs, designed by Francois Arnal and called Tablemak ers, have been proving sale able beyond expectations, ac cording to Bonniers.

title: Choice of the Brazilian Military Ernesto Geisel
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 19 An unfamiliar face ap peared in Brazilian news papers today as after months of censorship, Brazilians learned that Gen. Ernesto Geisel had been chosen by the military to be the next President.

title: Tunisian Bids Arabs and Israelis Recognize Each Other's Rights
description: GENEVA, June 19President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia to day called for talks between Arabs and Israelis for a just and lasting peace based on recognition of the rights of all in the area, among them the right of Israel not to he ex terminated and cast into the sea.

title: RACE CONSIDERED FOR SECRETARIAT
description: Lucien Laurin, trainer of Sec retariat, the Triple Crown win ner, said last night he was considering running his colt in an invitation race at Chicago's Arlington Park June 30. But he emphasized that arrangements had not been completed, The Associated Press reported.

title: Jury Convicts Hijacker
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (UPI)Michael S. Green, 35 years old, of Washington, D.C., was convicted by a Federal jury today of hijacking a Na tional Airlines jet carrying 113 passengers and a crew of seven last June 12. The jetliner was pirated over Kennedy Interna. tional Airport by two gunmen. The hijackers transferred later to a second craft and usrren dered in Texas with their $500, 000 ransom the next day.

title: Austere $3Billion Budget For Space Voted by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI)  The Senate approved today the most austere space budget since 1962, voting a $3 billion authorization for the program in the fiscal year 1974.

title: 53 Food Places Named by City As Violators, a Record Total
Political Budget..
description: In a municipal election year, budgetmaking becomes an exercise in political heromaking for those in control of the Board of Estimate and City Council. In line with that dubious tradition, the dominant Democrats have sought to advance the fortunes of their mayoral favorite, Controller Abraham D. Beame, by pushing onto future taxpayers part of the bill for the services New Yorkers will receive in the new fiscal year.

title: MARSHALL G. SAMPSELL
description: CHICAGO, June 19  Mar shall G. Sampsell, a senior part ner of !sham Lincoln & Beale one of this city's oldest law firms, died today in North western Memorial Hospital at the age of 69.

title: The Coldest Poker
description: BELFAST, Northern IrelandThe quintessential aim of President Nixon's foreign policy has been arrangement of a sensible deal with Moscow, bal ancing off the interests of the two superpowers while at the same time protecting United States commitments to West Europe and reassuring China against any conceivable threat of So viet force.

title: Auto Safety Measures Create Other Problems
description: In dealing with the prob lem of fire hazards in Cham pionship Trail races, the United States Auto Club may have created another problem equally serious. At least that's the way it appears to Dr. Joseph Mattioli, president of Pocono International Race way at Long Pond, Pa. His concern is with USAC's second 500mile race of the season, which Pocono will run on July 1. Quali fying for 33 starting positions will be conducted Saturday and Sunday.

title: Blumenthal Gives Beame Edge, But Does Not Count Out Badillo
description: Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, who ran last in the fourway race for Demo cratic nomination for Mayor, believes Abraham D. Beame has the best chance of winning the runoff, based on statistics, but believes also that Representa tive Herman Badillo can pull an upset.

title: ATHENS ANSWERS REPORTS OF SHIFT
Art: New Look at an American Artist
description: A new exhibition open ing today at the Brooklyn Musem might appropriately have been called Make Way for William Trost Richards if it didn't sound funny. Richards wasor let's make it is, since he may now be considered reborn  a mid 19thcentury American land and seascapist who was quickly forgotten after his death at the age of 72 fol lowing a long and successful career. He has somehow re mained in obscurity in spite of the 19thcentury Amer can art boom, but the Brook jyn show should put him up there as a colleague of the best.

title: Monsanto Expecting Its Profits To Nearly Double in Quarter
description: John W. Hanley, president of the Monsanto Company, said here last night that he expected the company approximately to double its net income for the second quarter over the 1972 period.

title: A GOOD SAMARITAN PLUNGES TO DEATH
description: A man slipped and fell four floors to his death yesterday in the Bronx as he tried to open a window for a woman who had lost her key, the police said.

title: Decision Reserved In Antitrust Action By Telex on I.B.M.
description: TULSA, Okla., June 19 Citing the possibility of misuse of inside information by courtroom spectators, a Federal judge decided here today against issuing an oral opinion in a major antitrust suit against the International Business Ma chines Corporation.

title: Nixon and Brezhnev View Signing of 4 New Accords
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 With Leonid I. Brezhnev and President Nixon looking on, Soviet and American officials signed four new agreements to day intended to enhance the atmosphere of the Soviet Com munist party leader's visit and to promote SovietAmerican cooperation.

title: Mayor and Cawley Hail Citizens on Aid In Seizing Suspects
description: Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Donald F. Caw ley yesterday applauded an evident new willingness on the part of New Yorkers to get involved and to try to stop crimes of violence.

title: Kramer Gets Austin Post
description: SHERMAN, Tex., June 19 (AP)  Larry Kramer, former University of Nebraska stand out and thead coach at South ern Oregon College, was named head football coach at Austin College today.

title: Lottery Winners Sought
description: TRENTON, June 19 (UPI)The state Lottery Commission said today that six winning tickets, each worth $50,000, had not been claimed this year and that one top weekly prize for 1972 remained unclaimed.

title: Touch of California, Bit of Dayton
description: Michael Davie of The London Ob server, Eric Sevareid and other pun dits are spreading the libelous notion that the roots of Watergate can be traced to the politics and sociologywhat they call the peculiarities"of Southern California, more particularly Orange County. This notion is pure rubbish. My credentials for offering rebuttal include several books about California, the advantage of a long and close observation of the local scene denied Messrs. Davie and Seva reid, and a deep affection for the re gion which 22 years of exile in Man hattan have not extinguished.

title: ExUnion Official Gonvicted Of Arranging $10,000 Bribe
description: Kenneth Fundus, former busi ness manager of Local 52 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, was convicted yesterday of arrang ing to accept a $10,000 bribe in return for granting a private detective union membership.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A fire in a transmission line at the Consolidated Edison Company's Ravenswood plant in Queens caused the shutdown of two generators yesterday, but posed no problem for customers, a Con Edison spokesman reported. The 3 A.M. blaze, of undetermined origin, damaged circuit breaker, which tripped out generators at the Ravenswood plant and at the Arthur Kill station on Staten Island.

title: Books of The Times
description: Most of us know something about the tragedy of war: in Spy in the Vatican 194145, Branko Bokun shows us its inci dental comedy. He depicts the desperate improvisation of people in impossible posi tions, the endless adaptability of the hu man animal, the absurd domesticated as the everyday. He couldn't have been better placed for the purpose: at the age of 21, he was sent to Rome by the Yugoslav Red Cross to seek Vatican intervention on be half of Orthodox Serbs, Jews and Gypsies who were being slaughtered by fanatic Croatian Catholics. Italy at that time was just beginning to play out its pathetic opera buffo and Rome was the principal stage, a city where every other person seemed to be either a spy or a refugee, where the inefficiency of the Government and the demoralization of the people com bined to turn the traditionally conventional Italians into practicing surrealists.

title: THRIFT UNIT CEILING ON LENDING RAISED
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (Reuters)  Federal savings and loan associations will be permitted to increase to 80 per cent from 75 per cent the maxi mum loantovalue ratio on cer tain specified construction loans, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.

title: CONRAD BRINGS IN SKYLAB SUN FILM
description: HOUSTON, June 19Two of the Skylab 1 astronauts went outside their space station to day to retrieve exposed film from solar telescopes and, in a return engagement as orbital repairmen, to hammer a battery back into action.

title: Police to Use TV to Scan Times Sq. Areafor Crime
description: A crackdown on crime in the Times Square area through the use of closedcircuit television is due to begin next month. Under plans being made by the Police Department, the television eyes for the Great White Way and its side streets will be set up with the arrival of a police trailer in the Times Square area. The trailer will have television screens.

title: Social Agency Employes Seek Arbitration on Wages
description: The union representing 1,235 professional and nonprofession al employes of seven social service agencies affiliated with me rederation of Jewish Philan thropies said yesterday that it was, seeking arbitration of its sixmonthold contract dispute with the agencies.

title: Escaped Convict Caught After Holding 5 Hostages
description: The prisoner, Charles Whit ted, 23 years old, of Green burgh, was subdued by three policemen and Warden Nor wood Jackson of Grasslands Penitentiary at Valhalla after they agreed to a deal  re lease of the hostages in return for a loaded gun and a car.

title: Court Directs City to Hold Off Ending of RentBase Formula
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice yesterday ordered that the city hold off implementing a new law that repeals the maxi mumbaserent formula of the local rent control program, which permits rent rises of up to 7.5 per cent a year in many controlled apartments here.

title: Mayor and Cawley Hail Citizens on Aid In Seizing Suspects
description: Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Donald F. Caw ley yesterday applauded an evident new willingness on the part of New Yorkers to get involved and to try to stop crimes of violence.

title: Dean Reportedly Says Nixon Wanted List of Trouble Newsmen
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 John W. Dean 3d has told Sen ate investigators that President Nixon asked him to keep a list of newsmen who were giving the President trouble during last year's election campaign, according to Senate sources.

title: WOMAN ASKS CITY TO UNDO BRIDAL KNOT
description: A Bronx woman who says the city has recorded a 1971 marriage that never took place wants the record expunged, but will have to go to court to do so.

description: WASHINGTON, Tune 19 (AP)  The nation's scheduled air lines announced today that they planned to continue their anti hijacking program of searching all baggage and of screening all passengers.

description: Twenty years to the day after the execution of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg for wartime espionage, the couple's two sons yesterday sued Doubleday & Co. and Louis Nizer, the law yer, for $3million in connec tion with Mr. Nizer's book The Implosion Conspiracy.

title: Four Agreements
description: The four SovietAmerican agreements signed in Wash ington yesterday had been prepared previously and rep resent consequences rather than causes of improved MoscowWashington relations. Dealing with such differ ent areas as oceanography, transportation, cultural ex change and agriculture, their very diversity is evidence that the present thaw in political relations is having useful impact on other fields of mutual interest.

description: KEY WEST, Fla., June 19The two crew members remain ing locked aboard the research submarine Johnson Sea Link failed to show any signs of life today, 24 hours after the vessel was pulled from the ocean floor, and were pronounced dead.

Berry, in which the minisub marine JohnsonSeaLink be came entangled, was one of two naval vessels that were sunk about 20 miles south of Key West, Fla., 13 months ago, according to a spokes man for the Navy's Atlantic Fleet in Norfolk, Virginia.

description: TRENTON, June 19  With its final questioning apparent ly calculated to show that the defendant's motive was political rivalry, the prosecution rested its, case today in the trial of State Senator James M. Turner. The Gloucester County Repub lican is charged with conspir ing to take bribes in an effort to frame Assemblyman Kenneth A. title: COLSON CITES CALL ON C. I. A. LIAISON
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Charles W. Colson, a former White House aide, told a Sen ate panel today that he had personally asked John D. Ehrlichman to help E. Howard Hunt Jr. establish liaison with the C.I.A. in the summer of 1971.

title: NEW JERSEY GETS 75 TAX DEADLINE
description: TRENTON, June 19  The State Supreme Court today gave the Legislature 18 months to approve a new constitutional method of financing public school education in New Jersey. If the Legislature fails, the court said it would impose a new system on its own.

title: Upset Victory by Girl, 18, Is Upset by Official Vote
description: ROCHESTER, June 19An 18yearold girl believed at first to have scored an upset victory in a District primary election did not win, an official tabula tion shows.

title: J. PAR CAREY, 74, CAR RENTER, DIES

title: Picasso's Erotic Prints Exhibited In Tokyo, After a Little Censorship

title: Red Smith
description: I had him! Jimmy Ellis said. Had him! Had him! Had him! He sat slumped with his shoulders against the wall of his dressing room in Madison Square Garden. A few minutes earlier those shoulders had felt the canvas floor of the ring as he pitched and lurched in ponderous somersaults trying to regain his feet, Party of the second part in a onepunch knockout by Earnie Shavers, Ellis had leaned into a single right uppercut that neither he nor many at ringside ever saw. He plunged face foremost, went heels overhead in slow motion, pushed up Sports to all fours and went overhead first again, wallowing sluggishly like some creature of rooting in a swamp. When Harold Valan, The Times the referee, spread his hands palms down the count of 10, the timekeeper's watch showed 2 minutes 39 seconds of the first round gone. It was the 46th fight in a professional career spanning 13 years, during which Jimmy Ellis had won and lost the heavyweight championship of the World Boxing Associa tion's world and demonstrated to witnesses in the United States, Canada, England, Sweden and Texas that he was a boxer who could dish it out and take it.

title: New General, Old Policy

They contend that only by denying freedom can they insure continuation of economic development that admittedly has been spec tacular, though so uneven that the poorest Brazilians have become steadily poorer.

title: Screen: And Now It's 'Shaft in Africa':Roundtree on Track of a Labor Smuggler
description: When Gordon Parks's "Shaft" opened here two years ago, Vincent Canby praised it in the Sunday New York Times for recalling an almost lost tradition: the good Saturday night movie. A lot of people must have agreed. We are now into the third installment of John Shaft's adventures. But if the original "Shaft" was Saturday night, the latest sequel, John Guillermin's "Shaft in Africa," has become by some benign process, inescapably Saturday afternoon. It is still goodquite surprisingly goodfairly violent and very sexy. But it is less daring, less ethnically sophisticated, more antiseptic, more comfortably middle-class. Having left his West Village pad, Shaft now lives in a luxury high-rise at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighth Street. It is here that representatives of an emergent African nation begin to persuade him (kidnap is a better word) to use his unmatchable talents to break up a sinister ring smuggling cheap illegal labor out of Africa and into the factories, the construction sites, the road gangs of Paris.So Shaft leaves his native wilderness (Manhattan) and is spirited to Addis Ababa, where he sets out on a mission that seems designed to benefit French labor unions more than black workersthough a certain dimness in the plotting has never bothered movies of this nature. Shaft will pose as an ignorant job-seeking tribesman and go the whole route, by foot, by camel, by ship and by truck, to unmask the master criminal behind this 20th-century black servitude.As Shaft, Richard Roundtree remains among the most attractive of recent movie actors. As an African tribesman he looks about as indigenous as, say, during the nineteen-thirties heyday of filmed colonialism, Ralph Richardson might have looked if gotten up with blackface in order to infiltrate the Fuzzy Wuzzies. In either case, you give up authenticity in favor of more dramatic virtues.Of the two women in Shaft's current life, Vonetta McGee, here the daughter of Shaft's employer, the Emir of Kemant, is a well-known, well-admired personality. Neda Arneric, an exciting, very young Yugoslav actress, plays Jazar, a sensuous beauty with a taste for everybody, including Shaft, who makes her happy before she dies.She is the mistress of Amafi (Frank Finlay), the smugglers' leader, and her death occasions a brief and curiously gentle exchange of regrets between him and Shaftthe kind of gallantry that sometimes enters action movies and complicates them in surprising and wholly gratifying ways. Mr. Guillermin's direction has never pleased me before, but I like it here for its economy, its generally serviceable professionalism."Shaft in Africa" opened yesterday at the Cinerama and RKO 86th Street Twin 2 theaters.

description: TUNIS, June 20A former Tunisian Government minister who escaped from prison here in February and is now reported living in Belgium has been sen tenced in absentia to a new term of five and a half years.

description: LONDON, June 20 (UPI) Nikki Pilic, a man made famous by tennis politics, went home to Yugoslavia today.

title: Union and Firestone Negotiate in Effort To End a Walkout
description: CLEVELAND, June 20 (AP) Negotiations resumed here this afternoon in an attempt to end a strike by the United Rubber Workers Union against the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company that began early to day.

title: NEW TEST DETECTS GENETIC DISORDER
description: The National Genetics Foun dation announced yesterday the development of a laboratory test to detect acute intermittent prophyria, an inherited disor der of body chemistry whose symptoms are brought on by some commonly used drugs.

description: ROME, June 20Jose Ri vera, who is 12 years old and is here to sing for Pope Paul VI with the Newark Boys Chorus in the Vatican on Saturday, has had a look at the Eternal City and has found it exactly the way he had imagined it.

description: WASHINGTON, June 20 President Nixon has accepted with regret and with admira tion and gratitude for his splen did service the resignation of Robert Gottschalk as Commis sioner of Patents, effective June 29.

description: WASHINGTON, June 20 The Leonid I. Brezhnev who came to Washington this week is a different man from the one who met President Nixon a year ago in Moscow.

title: MRS. JOHN K. HERBERT
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 20 Mrs. Lucretia Reiner Herbert, widow of John K. Herbert, who had been a vice president of Hearst Magazines, Inc., and president of the Magazine Pub lishers Association, died, appar ently of a heart attack, today in Southampton Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Persons Listed in Summary and Notes
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Following is a list of names in the Senate Watergate Committee's staff summary prepared after the interview with John W. Dean, 3d:

description: 32 Book Clubs To End False Ads

title: DROPOUTS CAN GET NEW CITY DIPLOMA
description: Highschool dropouts here who earn a state equivalency diploma will now also be en titled to a city high school diploma under a measure adopt ed last night by the Board of Education.
