description: BONN, June 20  West Ger many today passed a milestone in its policy of establishing re lations with the Communist states of Eastern Europe, ini tialing a treaty with Czechoslo vakia and putting into effect its basic treaty with East Ger many.

title: Segal and Glenda Jackson Star in 'A Touch of Class':The Cast
description: Steve Blackburn (George Segal) is an American insurance executive living in London with his wife and two children. Vicki Allessio (Glenda Jackson) is a high-voltage young Englishwoman who successfully pirates Paris fashions for New York's Seventh Avenue. She has two children but is separated from her Italian husband who lives in Milan. "He'd send me money for the children," she says, "if I sent him money for the cars."Steve and Vicki meet in a manner that Hollywood writers used to call cute. He's playing softball in the park and almost tramples her son trying to catch a fly ball. Steve and Vicki trade rebukes and after two more meetings, they are preparing to have an affair in Marbella. "It'll probably do us both a world of good," says Steve, although he throws his back out of joint on their arrival in Spain and the next night they are throwing lamps at each other while a comic desk clerk is pleading: "Is this any way to treat a hotel?"Melvin Frank's "A Touch of Class" is a very patchy movieenormously funny in bits and pieces and sometimes downright dumb. When the material matches their intelligence, Segal and Miss Jackson are extremely funny lovers, as on their first night when they find themselves lying in bed, each on his (or her) "wrong" side, arguing about how they will change locations with a minimum of fuss.There are also some fine farcical scenes more or less dedicated to the proposition that maintenance of a love nest is, at best, full of peril. On one occasion, after Steve has left his house telling his wife he is going to walk the dog, he returns home unaccompanied. In a transport of illicit joy he has left the dog with Vicki.Steve and Vicki obviously are perfectly matched, sharing not only the star billing of Segal and Miss Jackson, but also a common fondness for the excitement to be found in periodic domestic rough-house. Steve's wife (Hildegard Neil) seems to be a frigid bore and Vicki's life alone is certainly unrewarding. They were made for each other.However, Mr. Frank, who directed the film, and his collaborator on the screenplay, Jack Rose, will not let the characters alone. They keep forcing them into awkward attitudes. To set up the kind of laughs the film wants, the Segal character is asked to behave like such an idiot he wouldn't know second gear from third, which has the effect of turning Miss Jackson's Vicki into a wisecracking shrew.The problem, I suspect, is that "A Touch of Class" is a remodeled comedy out of the nineteen-forties, when it was written in Hollywood (in the old Production Code) that adultery was tabu. Adultery must not be consummated, but it was O.K. as long as it was being constantly interrupted. It's not adultery that gets interrupted in "A Touch of Class," but the natural instincts of two supposedly sophisticated people.This may be taking "A Touch of Class" more seriously than most audiences looking for easy laughs will care to. Others may share my feeling that there is something contradictory about a contemporary comedy that wishes to tell us that adultery is simply not worth the effort, even though the partners are so clearly in love. The ending is not sad, only a bit fraudulent.Somehow I expect more of a movie that can contain a desperately funny defense of an American mother who, though the family was not rich, saw to it that her children always had fresh grape-fruit in winter and were the first on their block to own electric blankets.

title: Text of the BonnPrague Treaty and of Letters on Law and Berlin
description: BONN, June 20 (Reuters) Following, in unofficial trans lation from the German, is the text of the treaty initialed here today by West Germany and Czechoslovakia and the texts of accompanying letters on criminal law and on the status of Berlin. The letter on law is from Foreign Min ister Bohuslav Chnoupehk of Czechoslovakia to Foreign Minister Walter Scheel of West Germany. The Berlin letter is from Mr. Scheel, the reply from Mr. Chnoupek.

title: American Reform Rabbinate Votes Its Opposition to Having Its Members Officiate at Mixed Marriages
description: ATLANTA, June 20After many years of struggling with the problem, the American Re form rabbinate officially went on record today in opposition to Reform rabbis officiating at mixed marriages.

title: Daring Briton Dumps Big Bomb Into Ulster River
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, June 20A British Army major drove a postal truck containing a 150pound bomb 600 yards along the dock side in the center of London derry today and pushed the vehicle into the River Foyle. Thirty seconds later, as the water shortcircuited the timing device, the bomb exploded, sending the vehicle's doors 300 feet into the air.

title: Radio
description: 8:0510 A.M., WNCN. Lachrimae Antiquae, Dowland; Fantasia in C minor, Bach; Fireworks, De bussy; Flute Concerto in E mi nor, Vivaldi; Jeux d'eau, Ravel; Der Freischuetz Overture, Weber; String Quintet in E, Boccherini; Piano Sonata in D minor, Woelfi.

title: Perfume Promotion Was a Sniff and Tell
description: It was billed as a psychoscentual trip and several hundred noses went along for the ride at a breakfast meet ing in the Plaza Hotel. In the end, scented to the membrane with six basic fragrance ingredients, the noses sniffed the final product. It was called Charlie, which wasn't too surprising since Revlon was picking up the tab for the strawberries in port, the quiche lorraine and the experience.

title: 8 Antiwar Veterans Lose Plea to Query Government
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., June 20 (UPI)A Federal judge refused today to allow eight antiwar de fendants to interrogate Govern ment lawyers about the Water gate case and quashed seven of eight subpoenas issued for top Florida law officers.

title: H.E.W. Said to Kill Health Aid for Poor
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 The Administration had already taken steps to nullify provisions of an important health bill be fore President Nixon signed it this week, a Congressional lead er in health affairs charged today.

title: MRS. STRAUB WINS, GAINS SEMIFINALS
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., June 20Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks in Westbury, L. I., and Mrs. Austin Straub, the defending champion from Roll ing Hills in Wilton, Conn., reached the semifinal round of the 70th Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.

title: Glacier Brings Flood in Soviet Asia
description: MOSCOW, June 20A huge lake dammed up by an advancing glacier in a remote Central Asian mountain valley broke through its ice barrier today, producing a flash flood that caused heavy damage but apparently no casualties.

title: EXCHANGE FILES CHARGES ON WEIS
description: The New York Stock Ex change filed yesterday formal disciplinary charges against five former executives of Weis Securities, Inc., a brokerage house now being liquidated at the instigation of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.

title: Psychiatrists Alarmed by Steady Invasion of Confidential Communications With Patients
description: The presidents of the Ameri can Psychiatric Association and the American Psychoanalytic Association have become in creasingly alarmed about what they regard as a steady inva sion of confidential communi cations between patients and their psychotherapists.

title: Bridge: Muhsam's Retirement Ends Distinguished Club Service
description: An act of personal kind ness by Ely Culbertson many years ago turned out to be a permanent benefit to bridge in New York City. At the world championship in 1937 he met a young bridge or ganizer of obvious ability and was later able to help him to leave Germany and enter the United States.

title: Bill Is Signed to Aid Collection Of Black History and Literature
description: ALBANY, June 21  An im portant New York City source of AfroAmerican history will be augmented under a bill signed into law today by Governor Rockefeller. It is the Schomburg Collection in the Countee Cullen Branch of the New York City Public Library, in Harlem.

title: Orantes Suffers Knee Injury In South of England Tennis
description: EASTBOURNE, England June 20 (UPI)Manuel Orantes of Spain,. the topseeded player, limped out of the South of Eng land lawn tennis championships today with a knee injury. He was hurt during his second round match with Ian Fletcher of Australia, who led, 75, 21.

title: H.E.W. Said to Kill Health Aid for Poor
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 The Administration had already taken steps to nullify provisions of an important health bill be fore President Nixon signed it this week, a Congressional lead er in health affairs charged today.

title: AndersonClayton Cutbacks
description: The foods division of, Anderson, Clayton & Co., Houston, Tex., will curtail operations at two of its plants due to the price freeze, begin ning next Wednesday. The move will result in some lay offs but the extent of the cutback and the number of layoffs has not yet been decided, the company said. The two plants employ a total of about 700 persons and produce primarily fats and oil shortening and salad oil.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Led Fight For Domestics Base Pay
description: WASHNGTON, June 18 Representative Shirley Chis holm, working behind the scenes with uncharacteristic anonymity, supervised a Con gressional office that served as the command post in the suc cessful fight to extend the House's minimumwage legis lation to include domestic workers.

title: MRS. STRAUB WINS, GAINS SEMIFINALS

description: HARTFORD, June 20 In the rush of business before the Connecticut General As sembly adjourned on June 1, a bill was lost.

description: TRENTON, June 20The lawyer for State Senator James M. Turner opened the defense case today with efforts to im peach the credibility of wit nesses against the Gloucester Republican, who is accused of attempting to frame Assembly man Kenney A, Gewertz with a narcotics charge.

description: Japan's giant Sumitomo Group of banking, mining and manufacturing interests has given $2million to Yale Uni versity and $1million to the Japan Society here to promote JapaneseAmerican cultural un derstanding.

title: Italian President Asks Rumor To Set Up a New Government
description: ROME, June 20  President Giovanni Leone today asked former Premier Mariano Rumor to form a new government, Italy's 35th since the fall Fascism.

title: Railroad Names Officer
description: BOSTON; June 20 (AP) The executive vice president of the Bangor and Aroostook Railroad in northern Maine was appointed today as execu tive vice president and chief operating officer of the Boston and Maine Railroad. The appointment of Alan G. Dustin of Bangor, Maine, to the bankrupt railroad is subject to the approval of the U.S. District Court.

title: Israelis, on Bedouin Carpets, Drink to a Sheik's Wedding
description: EL TUR, IsraeliOccupied Sinai, June 18Tout Sinai was thereBedouin sheiks in long white robes, Israeli gen erals in fatigues and com bat boots, a Greek Orthodox priest from St. Catherine's Monastery in black cassock, young Israeli women from the hotels and tourist offices in Sharm el Sheik in dunga ree shorts and bare midriffs they all gathered at this p galmfrined on the Gulf of Suez for the social event of the Sinai season.

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, JUNE 21, 1973
description: The Senate investigating committee has received sharply divergent reports about when President Nixon first knew about White House involvement in the Watergate burglary and coverup. A White House ac count asserts that John W. Dean 3d with held all information from the President until March 21. But a summary of Mr. Dean's in terrogation by committee lawyers contains his assertion that the President knew about it earlier. [Page 1, Column 8; Text, P. 28.]

title: Israel Is Acting to Test Tunisia's Sincerity on Peace
description: JERUSALEM, June 20Is rael is using a combination of public statements and private diplomatic contacts to plumb the seriousness of repeated offers by President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia to open peace talks.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The Ducks Hockey Club, owner of the Long Island Ducks of the Eastern Hockey League, filed a $7.5million antitrust suit yesterday alleging that certain major and minor hockey leagues have conspired since 1958 monopolize ice hockey. The suit, filed in Manhattan Federal Court, also claims that the National Hockey League, along with the American, Central and Western.Hockey Leagues, have attempted to prevent the Ducks from competing.

title: Ross Victor Over Foreman In Jersey Tennis, 76, 62
description: KEARNY, N. J., June 20The defending champion, Steve Ross of Brooklyn, defeated Bill Fore man of Belle Meade, 76, 62, and advanced to the round of 16 in the New Jersey state tennis championship today at the Arlington Players Club. Ross is seeded No. 1.

title: Hospital Closing Fought
description: The Disabled American Vet erans is seeking a permanent injunction to enjoin the Federal Government from closing in March the 1,500bed St. Albans Naval Hospital in St. Albans, Queens. A hearing on a show cause order has been set for next Thursday before Judge Walter Bruchhausen in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: Court Hears Man's Plea For Equal Death. Benefit
description: TRENTON, June 20 (AP)  threejudge Federal court reserved decision today after hearing arguments concern ing a man seeking the same Social Security benefits a wo man would receive in the event her spouse died.

title: U.S.BACKED LOAN IN SOVIET VENTURE REPORTED AT HAND
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 The Soviet Union and the United States ExportImport Bank were reported close to a final agreement today on the extension of $180million in ??redits to help finance the con struction of a SovietAmerican fertilizer complex in the Soviet Union that could lead to as much as $8billion in trade over 20 years.

title: Business Briefs
description: BadDebt Losses Approach $6Billion Bad debt losses of United States corporations are approaching the $6billion mark, Dun & Bradstreet, reported yesterday. For all incorporated industries, losses averaged 0.38 per cent of sales in the fiscal year ended July 1, 1970, or a total of $5.87billion. The estimate is based on data from recently released Internal Revenue Service reports covering a sample of Federal tax returns filed by 1.7 million corporations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is hardly to be expected that newspapers will probe into their own culpability for the climate which produced Watergate. We shall continue to be treated with tedious selfpraise of a valiant, free press. The newspaper men, in their peculiar world, can af firm that they sought only to give the news to the citizenryeven as John Mitchell sought only to reelect the President.

title: Goodyear Halts Increase
description: AKRON, June 20 (AP)  A 7 per cent Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company price in crease on polyvinyl chloride packaging. films was suspend ed today in line with President Nixon's price freeze, the com pany said. The film is used by the supermarket industry. The price increase was to have become effective June 18.

title: MRS. JOHN J. RICCIARDI
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 20 Mrs. Rose Codella Ricciardifi mother of Franc M. Ricciardi, president and board chairman of the Richton International Cor poration and former president of Walter Kidde & Co., died yes terday at her son's home in Ridgewood. She was 69 years old.

title: PhiIs Sweep Series
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 20 The lowly Phils tonight downed the New York Mets for the third straight time to increase their winning streak to five games as they produced a 4 to3 victory. A crowd of 24,302 witnessed the victory that en abled the home team to gain a series sweep and move out of the cellar as the Pirates lost to Cubs, 53.

title: 13 DIE IN GUNFIRE AS PERON RETURNS
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 20 Juan D. PerOn returned to Ar gentina today, ending almost 18 years of exile, and violence among the more than one mil lion people gathered to wel come him left at least 13 dead and more than 250 injured.

title: Congress Is Told of Trade Woes by 4 Businessmen
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Four businessmen who deal in foreign trade and investment told Congress today some of the difficulties of living in a world of floating currency exchange rates, but none of them con demned the new system out right.

title: Texts of U.S.Soviet Accord to Avoid Double Income Taxes and of Shultz Letter
description: WASHINGTON, June 20Following are the texts of an agree ment on taxation signed today by the United States and the Soviet Union and of an accompanying letter from Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz to Nikolai S. Patolichev, Minister of Foreign Trade:

title: Crops and Farm Income Expected to Rise Sharply
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI)United States crop pro duction will probably rise sub stantially this year while net farm income leaps to another record of more than $22bil lion, Agriculture Department economists said today.

title: Todd Shipyards Expects Big Contracts
description: The Todd Shipyards Corpora tion expects to be awarded con tracts for new vessels running at an estimated $600million to $750million, John T. Gilbride, president, told shareholders at the 57th annual meeting here yesterday.

title: CHILEAN DOCTORS BACK MINE STRIKE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 20 (UPI)  Thousands of physi cians, teachers and students went on strike today to pro test against the Allende Gov ernment's handling of the 63 day copper workers strike at the nationalized Teniente mine.

title: BonnCzech Pact Initialed; Treaty With East in Force
description: BONN, June 20  West Germany today passed a milestone in its policy of establishing relations with the Communist states of Eastern Europe, ini tialing a treaty with Czechoslo vakia and putting into effect its basic treaty with East Ger many.

title: U.S. Title Bouts Planned By Garden in 10 Classes
description: In an effort to provide more activity and more pres tige for United States box ers, along with more busi ness for Madison Square Garden's boxing program, Teddy Brenner announced yesterday a plan to create American championships in each of 10 weight divisions, with recognition by the New York State Athletic Commis sion.

title: A S. I. College Professor Accused of Making Drugs
description: A parttime assistant profes sor of psychology who is also a student at Staten Island Com munity College and a divorced mother of two children were charged yesterday with the il licit manufacture and posses sion of amphetamine.

title: Lehman Opens Tokyo Unit
description: The investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers said yesterday that it had opened a representative office in Tokyo to capitalize on the ties in the Far East. Lehman said the move reflects our conviction in the future growth of Japan as an inter national investment and busi ness center and... the future potential of the investment industry in the Far East.

title: In Brezhnev's Baggage, A Supply of Ebullience
description: By HEDRICK SMITH Special to The New York TimessWASHINGTON, June 20 The Leonid I. Brezhnev who came to Washington this week is a different man from the one who met. President Nixon a year ago in Moscow.

title: Union Endorses Badillo
description: District 65 of the Distributive Workers of America yesterday endorsed Herman Wino for Mayor. The 1,000 delegates of the union's general council also voted to contribute $5,000 to the Badillo campaign. The union has a membership of 35,000 warehouse and office workers and has headquarters at 13 As tor Place.

title: Market Place : Factors Behind Pullman's Gains
description: Pullman, Inc., which moved out of the sleepercar busi ness some time ago, proved to be something of a sleeper itself in the stock market this week. On Monday, it was the only issue on the New York Stock Exchange to register a 1973 high. (There were no new highs on Tuesday.)

title: At U.N., Croissant Issue Raged Until Concessionaire Gave in
description: Not all worthy causes are lost at the United Nations.

title: Mafia Informer Says Aloi Ordered Gallo Killing
description: Joseph Luparelli, a Mafia in formant, said under oath yes terday that Vincent Aloi, re puted head of the Joseph A. Colombo Sr. crime family, had ordered the murder of his rival, Joseph Gallo, more than a year before Gallo was killed.

title: Newark Boys Give Rome a Bravo
description: ROME, June 20Jose Ri vera, who is 12 years old and is here to sing for Pope Paul VI with the Newark Boys Chorus in the Vatican on Saturday, has had a look at the Eternal City and has found it exactly the way he had imagined it.

title: Anthony Powell Now Plans Fiction
description: FROME, EnglandThrough the slightly bowed Regency windows of Anthony Pow ell's living room comes the unchanging radiance of the Somerset countryside, and an occasional boom.

title: JAMES REARDON
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 20 James Reardon, former general superintendent of the Universal Terminal and Stevedoring Com pany, died today at his home. His age was 72.

title: Charles Town Big Exacta Brings $22,799 Return
description: CHARLES TOWN,W. Va., June 20 (AP)One ticketholder won $22,799.20 in the big exacta at Shenandoah Downs Race Course tonight. The winning combina tion for the fifth and sixth races was 54 and 63.

title: Pet Enters Into a Pact for Sale Of 22 Schrafft's Units to Riese
description: Pet, Inc., the big dairy and food products company with headquarters in St. Louis, announced yesterday an agree ment to sell 22 Schrafft's res taurants to Riese Brothers, the New York organization that operates Luchow's, several Longchamps restaurants, the Steer Palace, the Riverboat, Autopub and other New York dining places. Terms were not disclosed. Pet, which had ac quired the Schrafft's business in January, 1968, for about $25million, plans to sell the other 13 Schrafft's restaurants. Earlier it had held discussions with the Chock Full O'Nuts Corporation for the sale of 25 Schrafft's resturants.

title: BELGRADE REVIVES DJILAS AS TARGET
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 19For almost 28 years, Milo van Djilas, the Yugoslav politi cal dissident, has either been in prison or living in isolation from most of his countrymen, rarely moving far from his apartment on Belgrade's tree lined Palmoticeva Street, in the shadow of the Federal Assem bly.

title: Director of Freeze on Prices
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Whenever James Woods Mc Lane accompanies his wife on family shopping trips for food and clothes and the other things needed for two growing sons, he is, she said, continually astonished by how much things cost.

title: Mackell Honored Here. by 500, Including Hogan
description: Thomas J. Mackell; who re signed as District Attorney of Queens after he was indicted on charges of covering up a criminal investigation, was honored last night by 500 peo ple at a dinner attended by two District Attorneys and several politicians.

title: WHITE HOUSE DATA AND DEAN'S DIFFER ABOUT WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 20A White House account of Presi dent Nixon's conversations this year with John W. Dean 3d charges that Mr. Dean, despite constant pressure from the President, withheld from Mr. Nixon all information about White House involvement in the Watergate burglary and coverup until March 21.

title: MAX BARSHIS
description: Max Barshis, an artist and designer, died following a heart attack May 28 on the Italian island of Ischia. He was 78 years old.

title: Nixon Billed for $6,300 By HomeCounty Party
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., June 20 (AP)  President Nixon is being billed for $6,300 by his home county's Republican central committee for pay ment of a bill stemming from a fundraising dinner, the committee chairman says.

title: A Courageous Leader
description: WASHINGTON I wouldn't defend the people who are responsible and who took part in Watergate. I do think that it is being vastly over played. It was wrong but it should not be blown out of proportion. It was a stupid act and in violation of law. It does not constitute a betrayal of our country, nor a pilfering of the Treasury. No elected official was involved.

title: Personal Finance
description: Commuting expenses for the average businessman and woman who tote briefcases to work every day have never been tax deductible since the Income Tax Act of 19613 went into effect.

title: Correction Officers Give Third Term to President
description: Leo C. Zefferetti has been reelected to a third twoyear term as president of the Cor rection Officers Benevolent As sociation, representing 3,000 members of the City Correc tion Department. A spokesman said yesterday that Mr. Zef feretti had polled 904 votes to 440 for Dennis Cowan and 240 for Stanley Landau in a mail ballot.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: MANCHESTER, Vt.Forty years ago, armed with clumsy, floppy bamboo rod and a thin braided line in tended for baitcasting, I set forth to master the art of flyfishing. At the end of my first day I. was singularly depressed.

title: Beame Takes Campaign Underground
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame went into the subway yesterday morning to urge riders to put pressure on Gov ernor Rockefeller to help the city maintain the 35cent fare.

title: Music: Good Neighbor
description: Since the members of the New York Philharmonic work on a yearround basis now, the management of the or chestra is constantly faced with the problem of finding productive things for the mu sicians to do. In the last decade, we have seen the de velopment of the popular Promenades, the free summer concerts in New York parks, the recently completed series of Rug concerts and this week, for the first time, a series of neighborhood con certs in which the orchestra is divided into two groups of 50 players each, playing un der two conductors.

title: PUBLIC PENSION PLAN PRESSED AT HEARING
description: Melvin H. Osterman Jr., the state's Director of Employe Re lations, urged the members of the Legislature's Select Com mittee on Public Pensions here yesterday to adopt the agree ment worked out between the state and the Civil Service Em ployes Association for all pub lic employes.

title: Chess:Even the Leaders Can Slip (and Even the AlsoRans Triumph)
description: LENINGRAD, June 19  Viktor Korchnoi took the lead again today in the Interzonal Tournament for world cham pionship candidates by de feating his Soviet compatriot Mikhail Tal in a 57move rookandknight ending and agreeing to a draw with Svetozar Gligoric of Yugo slavia.

title: Mitchell Ordered To Testify on Data In Article on Alioto
description: Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell was ordered by State Supreme Court Justice Birdie Amsterdam yesterday to answer questions about whether he leaked Federal Bureau of Investigation and Justice Department reports to magazine article writers.

title: Excerpts From Account of NixonDean Talks
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Following are excerpts from a White House account of conversations between Presi dent Nixon and John W. Dean 3d, former White House counsel, which was sent to the Senate Watergate com mittee this week and was made available to The New York Times by a person with access to it:

title: Tenure May Be Abolished For Faculty at Bloomfield
description: BLOOMFIELD, N. J., June 20 A small, 125yearold liberal arts college here is expected to abolish the tenure system, one of the most entrenched tra ditions in higher education.

title: Tenure May Be Ended For Faculty at Bloomfield
description: BLOOMFIELD, N. J., June 20 A small, 125yearold liberal artscollege here Is expected to abolish the tenure system, one of the most entrenched tra ditkins in higher education.

title: BIG BOND BLOCKS SOLD OUT IN HOUR
CONNALLY INSISTS HE ISN'T UNHAPPY
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 John, B. Connally, special un paid adviser to the President, called a news conference at the White House today to deny re ports that he was unhappy with the way he has been treated. However, he confirmed that he was leaving by midsummer to travel abroad and resume his Houston law practice.

title: BestinShow Judging Assailed
description: The question of whether or not to have bestinshow competition is raised periodi cally. Only one major all breed fixture in the United States currently has no top awardSaw Mill, held every March at the Westchester County Center. Now a strong plea is being made by a lead ing Italian exhib itor. I'm entirely opposed to the award, said Mrs. Franca Simondetti of Novi Ligure, who breeds English cocker spaniels and Italian marem mas, big, longcoated white dogs that resemble the Kuvasz. There are far too many breeds for one man to be versed in them all. It's just a question of preference. Some like a big dog, others a small one. I'm happy when one of my dogs just takes the breed. I know then my breeding program must be all right. News of Dogs

title: 4 PANTHERS RECEIVE 3 YEARS IN SLAYING
description: Four Black Panthers who pleaded guilty to killing a mem ber of a rival faction of their party were sentenced yesterday to three years in prison.

title: City Songsters
description: It isn't only country folk who hear birds sing. Robins are loud and full of melody in the city every May and June. And, though not quite so numerous, so are brown thrashers and catbirds. Listen any morning, in a park or near an open space where there are a few trees and little shrubbery, and you can hear them. Central Park Van Cortlandt, or the shrubbery strips along the rivers are the best places.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 64560
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers In sequence win $25. Tickets with all five cumbers scrambled Win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third end fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2,51

title: ESS EFF, AT $11.60, CAPTURES REGRET
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., June 20 (AP)Ess Eff, ridden by Jack O. Sturgeon, broke from the inside post and held the lead; all the way in winning the $27,975 Regret Handicap at Monmouth Park today.

title: Carbon Dioxide, Not Exposure to Cold, Killed Two in Trapped Minisubmarine
description: KEY WEST, Fla., June 20  An autopsy revealed today that the two men who died aboard the Smithsonian Institution re search suomarine Johnston SeaLink were killed by carbon dioxide poisoning.

title: SANDMAN RUNNING ON NOTAX PLEDGE
description: TRENTON, June 20  Rep resentative Charles W. Sandman Jr, reaffirmed his firm opposi tion to a state income tax to day in a gubernatorial and leg islative campaign platform re leased here by New Jersey's Republican party.

title: CLASS I YACHTS WIN TOP 4 SPOTS
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 20 The AnnapolisNewport yacht race concluded today as winners in the remainder of the five classes were determined and the slowest, most unlucky sailors dragged into port at the end of their 473mile voyage that began Saturday

title: Morality Play
description: Probing for the rationale of Watergate, Senator Baker of Tennessee asked one of the witnesses before the Ervin committee the other day, Did you ever have any qualms about what you were doing, about the propriety of hiring these people for the dirty tricks or whatever it was? .. Where does the system break down, he continued, when concern for what is right... is never asserted?

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Nixon Committee Is Fined For Concealing Vesco Gift
description: WASHINGTON, June 20President Nixon's reelection committee was found guilty and fined the maximum $3,000 in Federal District Court here this morning for concealing a $200,000 cash contribution from Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier.

title: 800 Demonstrate for Hour At Soviet Mission's Estate
description: GLEN COVE, L. L, June 30 Chanting Let my people go now, 800 people from Long Island interfaith groups staged an hourand15minute vigil to night outside the ironbarred gates of Killenworth, the Soviet Mission's residence here.

title: Equity Financing
description: Fasco Industries Inc., a Rochesterbased, family owned manufacturer of fractional horsepower motors and other electrical products, said yesteday it had delayed, temporarily, a planned public offering of 400,000 shares of common stock. The company said the delay was being made until such time as Fasco feels the market has achieved at least a stabilized condition.

title: Soviet Coverage of Talks Generates Expectant Air
description: MOSCOW, June 20Inten sive Soviet news coverage of the Washington summit meeting appears to be gener ating an illdefined air of ex pectancy that the Brezhnev Nixon camaraderie on the television screen may ulti mately translate into a better life for the average Russian.

title: Welfare Groups Elect Chief
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, June 20 (UPI)The director of the Monmouth County Welfare Board, Robert C. Wells of Mat awan, was elected tonight pres ident of the New Jersey Wel fare Council and the Social Wel fare Research Foundation of New Jersey, Inc. Mr. Wells was elected at the annual meeting of the two groups here. He suc ceeds Arnold Fisher of Newark.

title: Bridge's Opponents Wary, But Hail Governor's Move
Businessman Is Stunned At Watergate Reference
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Walter L. Scott was a little stunned at the news from last week's Watergate hearings.

title: Try Baking Them In Home Kitchen
description: UNITED NATIONS CROISSANTS

title: 3:53.3 By Wottle Beats Prefontaine
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 20 (AP) Dave Wottle of Bowling Green became tonight the third fastest miler in track history, charging past Oregon's Steve Prefontaine to lead six men under the 4minute mark with 3:53.3.

title: The Army Way
description: SPRINGFIELD, Va.America needs an Army. Not a small, professional cadre, nor an undermanned organiza tion which requires extensive filling before it is ready to fight, nor a collec tion of combat units which must rely on reserve mobilization for their logis tical support. Instead, what is needed is a relatively large and selfsufficient force, ready to be committed to war on short notice.

title: Cox Weighs Grand Jury On Campaign Extortion
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The staff of Archibald Cox, special prosecutor in the Watergate case, is considering a grand jury investigation to determine whether the President Nixon's reelection organization used extortion and other illegal forms of fundraising while collecting more than $50mil lion in campaign contributions last year, sources close to the case said today.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Detroit at New York (7:30 P.M.) Lolich (7.6) vs. Dobson (11).

title: Battista Files a Suit to Void Defeat in Brooklyn Primary
description: Assemblyman Vito P. Bat tista filed suit in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday in a bid to overturn his 173vote defeat in the Republican pri mary for Councilman at Large.

title: Nixon Committee Is Find For Concealing Vesco Gift
description: WASHINGTON, June 20President Nixon's reelection committee was found guilty and fined the maximum $3,000 in Federal District Court here this morning for concealing a $200,000 cash contribution from Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier.

title: Soviet Diplomat's Car Is FireBombed in Queens
description: A Soviet diplomat's car, parked outside his summer home near the ocean in Far Rockaway, Queens, was de stroyed by fire shortly before dawn yesterday.

title: TV:Off Broadway Failure Gets New Lease on Life
description: Antiques opened Off Broadway on Tuesday eve ning at a cost to the pro ducers of about $70,000. The musical about elderly citizens received generally disastrous reviews and is scheduled to close this Sunday. The aver age Off Broadway production might be wiped off the thea trical map with that kind of flop. But the producers of Antiques claim they will eventually show a profit. The difference is cable television.

title: Israel Is Acting to Test Tunisia's Sincerity on Peace
description: JERUSALEM, June 20Is rael is using a combination of public statements and private diplomatic contacts to plumb the seriousness of repeated offers by President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia to open peace talks.

title: BIAGGI AIDES MET WITH BABELLO MEN
description: TO aides of Representatives Herinan Badillo and Mario Bi aggi met four days after the June 4 Democratic mayoral primary and discussed the pos sible endorsement of Mr. Badil lo by Mr. Biaggi in Tuesday's runoff.

title: Briscoe to Fight Mundine
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 21 (UPI)  The Commonwealth middleweight boxing champion, Tony Mundine of Australia, will fight a 10rounder with Benny Briscoe of Philadelphia in New Caledonia Aug. 18.

title: Soviet Words and Deeds
description: LONDON, June 20Dmitri M. Segal is a young Soviet scholar of extraor dinary brilliance and breadth of inter est. His field is linguistics, but he has worked also on folklore and anthro pology. He has written on language theory, on mythology, on the structure of Edward Lear's limericks.

title: Advertising: Happy Day at D.D.B.
description: As far as accounts go it was an in day and an out day at Doyle Dane Bernbach yesterday. And since the in business was bigger than the out business, it added up to a happy day as well.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS JAIL SIX IN ALLEGED PLOT
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, June 20  Two white foreign ers and four South African blacks were sentenced to long prison terms today on charges in an alleged conspiracy to overthrow the Government.

title: G.O.P. Unit Asks Funds To Keep Party Alive
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 The Republican National Fi nance Committee, its treasury depleted by the Watergate scandal, is quietly appealing to its largest contributors for funds to keep the party alive.

title: Hunt Reportedly Says Colson Wanted Him to Search Bremer Home
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 E. Howard Hunt Jr. has told the Senate's Watergate investi gating committee that a White House aide ordered him to fly to Milwaukee and search the apartment of Arthur H, Bremer shortly after Bremer had made an attempt on the life of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama last year, according to a source close to Hunt.

description: WASHINGTON, June 20 The following are excerpts from the summary prepared by staff members of the Sen ate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activi ties after their interview last Saturday with John W. Dean 3d, the former White House legal counsel:

title: Mayoralty Choice
description: New York City's Democratic voters will go to the polls Tuesday to decide whether Representative Herman Badillo or Controller Abraham D. Beame will be their party's nominee for Mayor in November. Since Demo crats so dominate the total electorate in this city, the decision in the runoff primary may well determine for the next four years the occupant of this office of supreme importance to the people of New York.

title: Michigan Girl's Suit Filed Against Little League Ban
description: YPSILANTI, Mich., June 20 (AP)Twelveyearold Carolyn King, one of the nation's first female Little Leaguers, filed suit in Federal Court yesterday against the National Little League organization.

title: JUDGE IS ACCUSED BY INQUIRY GROUP
description: TRENTON, June 20 (AP) The State Commission of In vestigation accused a work: men's compensation judge to day of illegally practicing law and also charged that he had lied in private testimony before the commission.

description: BASEBALL

title: Improvements Made in 2 Significant Measurements
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 The deficit in the United States balance of international pay ments declined further in the first quarter of this year, the Commerce Department report ed today.

description: MONTREALSigned Glen Goldup, right wing; Bob Galney, left wing, and David Ellenbaas, goalie.

title: EDWARD L. M'KEANY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 Edward L. McKeany, who estab lished in 1949 the sugar broker age company now known as Mc KeanyFlavell Company, Inc., died Sunday at the age of 72.

description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Defiant Judge Again Backs Right to Abortion Privacy
description: State Supreme Court Justice Samuel A. Spiegel defied a higher court and ruled for the second time that women receiving abortions should not have their names and addresses on fetal death certificates.

title: Aspin Charges Bail Out for Grumman
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 The charge of bailoutone that causes shudders in the, Pentagon hierarchywas in jected today into the Congres sional debate over the Defense Department plan to raise the price for continued production of the Navy's F14 plane by the Grumman Corporation.

title: Different Tune f or Fiddler in Barrio
description: A robust production of Fiddler on the Roof, its words and music reworked to fit the lifestyle of blacks and Puerto Ricans living in East Harlem, was put on by a cast of 64 fifthand sixthgraders yesterday at Public School 108.

title: Women Also Consider Boycott of Wimbledon Tourney
description: LONDON, June 20With men's boycott in force at the devalued Wimbledon tennis championships starting Mon day, the women now are turn ing militant.

title: Market Advances Slightly While Turnover Declines
description: The stock market finished slightly higher yesterday in very dull trading after moving in a narrow price range throughout the session.

title: Rose Denounces Reported G.O.P. Help To Liberal Slates as Certainly Immoral
description: Alex Rose, vice chairman of the Liberal party, yesterday characterized as perhaps not illegal but certainly immoral reported Republican attempts to subsidize Liberal candidates in key Assembly districts tact year in efforts to draw off votes from Democratic candi dates.

title: The Quality of a Loner
description: DAN RATHER: What can the Presi dent do? What needs to be done most right now?

title: Mrs. Mitchell Urges Husband to Tell All About Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI) Mrs. John N. Mitchell said today that she was urging her husband to disclose whatever he knows about White House involvement in the Watergate scandal, no matter who is con cerned, and that she still thinks President Nixon should resign.

title: Vatican Warns Bishops Against Publicly Disagreeing With Views Held by Pope
description: ROME, June 20The Vatican warned Roman Catholic bishops everywhere today against pub licly voicing any dissent from the views held by the Pope and by their fellow bishops.

title: Feminists and Writers Back 3 Facirg Trial in Portugal
description: Feminist leaders and profes sional writers groups met yes terday at the Drake Hotel to rally support for three women writers in Portugal who are facing trial next month because of their book New Portuguese Letters, Sales of the book were prohobited by the Lisbon Government early this year.

title: WHEAT FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Traders in grains and soy beans decided to take profits or pay up on their losses yes terday as they awaited some action by Washington on the problem of how to deliver com modities under a price freeze.

title: WHITE HOUSE DATA AND DEAN'S DIFFER ABOUT WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 20A White House account of Presi dent Nixon's conversations this year with John W. Dean 3d charges that Mr. Dean, despite constant pressure from the President, withheld from Mr. Nixon all information about White House involvement in the Watergate burglary and coverup until March 21.

title: Good. Old Summertime Arrives at 9:01 A.M.
description: At 9:01 A.M., Eastern Day light Time, today the sun will reach its most northerly point; relative to the earth's surface, and summer will commence.

title: People and Business
description: George Baylis has been ap pointed president of Bonwit Teller, the 13unit specialty store.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO FINE I.B.M. $1MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The Department of Justice asked a Federal judge today to hold the International Business. Machines Corporation in con tempt of court for, failure to produce some 12,000 documents that the Government wants as potential evidence in its long standing antitrust action against I.B.M.

title: COURT STAYS ORDER ON LANDLORD DATA
description: Justice Theodore B. Kupfer man, of the Appellate Division yesterday granted a request of four commercial landlords and continued in effect a stay that bars the press and public from examining income and expense statements filed by landlords seeking tax reductions.

title: Peking Names Woman As Minister of Health
description: PEKING, June 20 (Reuters) China has appointed Liu Hsiangpin to be Minister of Public Health. She is the first woman to hold ministerial rank for many years.

title: Cox Weighs Grand Jury On Campaign Extortion
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The staff of Archibald Cox, special prosecutor in the Watergate case, is considering a grand jury investigation to determine whether the President Nixon's reelection organization used extortion and other illegal forms of fundraising while collecting more than $50mil lion in campaign contributions last year, sources close to the case said today.

title: Peron in Seclusion as Fatal Clashes Mar Homecoming
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 20 Juan D. PerOn returned to gentina today, ending almost 18 years of exile, and violence among the more than one mil lion people gathered to wel come him left at least 13 dead and more than 250 injured.

title: Miss Bradley Shoots a 73, Beats College Course Mark
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., June 20 (UPI)Pat Bradley of Florida International University broke a 43yearold course record with a oneunderpar 73 de spite a twostroke penalty to day to take the openinground lead in the Association of Inter collegiate Athletics for Wo men's national gold champion ship.

title: Personal Income Rise Slows
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)  The rate of growth in personal income in the United States slowed in May for the third month in a row, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Court Is Told Laird Sought Information On S. E. C. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Melvin R. Laird, the former Secretary of Defense who has become President Nixon's chief domestic adviser, asked aides to seek information about a Securities and Exchange Com mission investigation of the Florida East Coast Railway at the behest of the railroad's chairman, according to testi mony at a closed hearing in Federal District Court here last Friday.

title: Notes on People
description: Owning up to something akin to a factual gutter ball, Helen McCain Smith, Mrs. Richard M. Nixon's press sec retary, has revised her ac count of the finances behind that newly revealed bowling alley under the North Portico of the White House. Mrs. Smith, who first said that the Nixons had paid for it, now says that further checking has revealed that the alley was donated by a friend of the President, Charles G. Re bozo. The price is something the White House has declined to disclose.

title: Council Approves $2Million For Primary Runoff Vote
description: The City Council has ap proved, without a dissenting vote, an amendment to the 197273 budget calling for the expenditure of $2,191,750 to pay for the city's first runoff primary, scheduled for next Tuesday. The vote, taken two days ago, was 35 to 0.

title: Many Groups Engaged in Long Battle of the Bridge
description: The decadeold Battle of the Bridge will undoubtedly go down in history as one of the region's longest and hardest fought controversies over pub lic works.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
RUDOLPH TIKTIN
description: Rudolph Tiktin, former syndi cate manager for the invest ment banking firm of Hallgarten & Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, died Sunday at Leroy Hospital, 40 East 61st Street. He was 92 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: 5,000 Bootleg PopMusic Tapes Seized by F.B.I. in Jersey Raids
description: NEWARK, June 20  More than 50 agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation seized approximately 5,000 bootleg popmusic tape cartridges and more than $500,000 worth of duplicating equipment yester day in raids on 10 New Jersey bootlegtape factories, United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern announced today.

title: MEYER ADVANCES IN N.C.A.A. TENNIS
description: Firstranked Alex Mayer of Stanford defeated David Rich of Appalachian, 62, 63 in today's fourth round of the National Collegiate tennis tour nament reducing the field to 16.

title: Intense Fighting Reported in Areas Of South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 21 (AP)In tense fighting, the heaviest since the reaffirmation of the ceasefire last Friday, was re ported yesterday in three areas of South Vietnam.

title: F.D.A. ASKS LABEL ON SPRAY PERILS
description: After two years of study and reports of some adverse reac tions, the Food and Drug Ad ministration has proposed that labels for all vaginal deodorant sprays carry warnings on usage and possible problems.

title: Concert
description: The Festival Casals of Puerto Rico, which closed its 17th season in San Juan last Friday, transplanted it self to Carnegie Hall Tuesday night. The program, first of three in the festival entitled New York Salute to Puerto Rico, turned out to be a successful transplant, musi cally, though the 96yearold Pablo Casals himself did not appear, as rumor indi cated he might.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PARTIAL RECALL Back in the good old nineteen thirties when there was nothing more serious to worry about than the Great Depression and the impend ing horrors of World War II, yes, way back then there was a lot to gladden the movie goer's heart. A package of thirties fluff opens today and plays through next Wednes day at the First Avenue Screening Room, the fairly new house on First Avenue and 61st Street (PL 3.5755).

title: LOCAL BOARD SEEKS TO RETAIN FUENTES
description: The outgoing school board in District 1 on the Lower East Side adopted two changes in its bylaws last night in the hope of making it more difficult for the newly elected board to re move Luis Fuentes, the contro versial superintendent of the district.

title: Five Die in Collision
description: BASSETT, Ark. June 20 (UPI)  Six tractortrailer trucks and 12 cars, lost in a swirling dust storm, collided in a chain reaction last night, killing five persons and injur ing eight.

title: Miller Is Ineligible for Ryder Cup
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 20Al though he is golf's newest star and the United States Open champion, Johnny Miller will not represent his country as a Ryder Cup team member against the British profession als at Muirfield, Scotland, in September.

title: Death Ends Woman's Bid to Right Moral Wrong
description: In the coming week, Gover nor Rockefeller will act on a bill that would allow Mae Neu stadt to sue the state for her allegedly wrongful confinement in Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminally Insane for 40 years.

title: Death Penalty Bill Signed
description: BATON ROUGE, La., June 20 (UPI)  Gov. Edwin W. Ed wards said today that he had signed a bill restoring the death penalty in Louisiana, but added: I have serious reser NationS in my mind as to whether or not the United States Supreme Court would hold any bill which provides for capital punishment consti tutional.

title: Eastport Divided Over Risk and Benefit of Refinery Planned for Its Harbor
description: EASTPORT, Me., June 20 The bright blue waters off this port were calm today, but oil was still troubling its citizenry.

title: Major League Baseball
description: American League

title: House Panel Says Concern Dealt With Crime Figures
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The House Select Crime Com mittee approved a report today concluding that the Emprise Corporation of Buffalo, a na tionwide sports vender, had done business with designated organized crime figures.

title: Aaron Has Cyst Lanced And Will Miss 3 Games
description: LOS ANGELES, June 20 (UPI)Hank Aaron, the At lanta outfielder, 23 shy of tying Babe Ruth's record of 714 career home runs, had cyst on his abdomen lanced tonight and is expected to miss all three games of the Braves series against the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Books of The Times
description: We have here, in Paul Spike's Photo graphs of My Father, an excellent example of why it sometimes pays for an aspiring young fiction writer to write nonfiction. First, to state the negative side of the case, it is doubtful that Mr. Spike could have handled this autobiographical material as fiction. His only previous book, Bad News, was a fairly runofthemill col lection of short stories. Even in this new book, which shows clear evidence that the author has grown as a stylist, his command of lan guage is not yet distinctive enough for the purposes of firstrate fic tion. (Although it is apparent from the cogent com ments on writing included in Photo graphs of My Father that Mr. Spike understands how a writer goes about developing his own style, he has not yet made this knowledge instinctive.) And had Mr. Spike imagined the story he tells here and tried to convey it in a novel, he would have been hard put to make believable.

title: A MillionPlus Winner Finds It's All in the Cards
description: HOLMDEL, June 20 (AP) The odds were estimated at 324 trilliontoone, but that didn't stop Don Heasley.

title: TALKS AUTHORIZED ON CHARTER FARES;C.A.B. to Allow Scheduled and Nonscheduled Airlines to Set Minimum Rates
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized scheduled and non scheduled United States and foreign. airlines for the first time yesterday to negotiate minimum fares for transAtlan tic charter flights.

title: Guerrilla Unit Attacks Cairo Proposal
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 20 Egypt's proposal that a Pales tinian state be created as part of an Arab political settlement with Israel drew strong opposi tion today from the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: E. E. C. Decisions On Farm Imports Upset U.S. Aides
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 20 (AP)  United States officials were reported upset by today's decisions of the Common Mar ket agriculture ministers that will make it harder for Ameri cans to export oranges, canned juices and other farm products.

description: The question of whether or not to have bestinshow competition is raised periodi cally. Only one major all breed fixture in the United States currently has no top awardSaw Mill, held every March at the Westchester County Center. Now a strong plea is being made by a lead ing Italian exhib itor. I'm entirely opposed to the award, said Mrs. Dogs Franca Simondetti of Novi Ligure, who breeds English cocker spaniels and Italian marem mas, big, longcoated white dogs that resemble the Kuvasz. There are far too many breeds for one man to be versed in them all. It's just a question of preference. Some like a big dog, others a small one. I'm happy when one of my dogs just takes the breed. I know then my breeding program must be all right.

title: Geisel's Brother Dies
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 21Gen. Henrique Geisel, older brother of Gen. Ernesto Geisel who has been named to be Brazil's next President, died of cerebral hemorrhage in the Army Hospital last night. He was stricken in the afternoon while working at his office in a private maritime company. He was 69 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Garden at 63 Bayard Street, who was described as a sup plier of Chinese heroin; the ownersof the house, George and Elizabeth Coromilas, and Richard Lanoue of Rahway, N. J.

title: MIDSHIPMAN SUES TO OBTAIN DEGREE
description: A New Jersey man who was asked to resign from the United States Naval Academy a week before graduation when he applied to be a conscientious objector may be unable to accept a fellow ship at New York University Law School because the Navy has refused for two years to grant him his under graduate degree.

title: 6Month High Reached
description: Corporations borrowed more money from New York City banks during the week ended Wednesday than they had in six months.

title: Return of Astronauts
description: The Skylab 1 astronauts are scheduled to splash down today at 9:50 A.M. in the Pacific Ocean, ending their 28day mission. Page 22.

title: JOSEPH G. ABRAMSON, LAWYER, BANK AIDE
description: Joseph G. Abramson, a prom inent lawyer in this city for more than 65 years and a direc tor of the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company, died yesterday at his home, 710 Park Avenue. He was 89 years old.

title: Struck Hospital Increases Vigil After Tires Are Slashed in Lot
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 21  Security guards at Moun tainside Hospital, where 300 nonprofessional workers are on strike, are checking visitors to the institution's parking lot as a result of two tireslashing in cidents there.

title: General Mills Posts Record Sales and Net in Year
description: Operations of General Mills, Inc., in the fiscal year ended May 27 resulted in record sales and earnings and the largest annual gains in the company's 45year history, the unaudited preliminary statement disclosed yesterday.

title: U.S. Broadens Inquiry on Pop Music
PRICE INDEX ROSE SHARPLY IN MAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Consumer prices continued to rise steeply in May, although the increase was a little less than in the two preceding months, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Money Yes, Ethics No
description: In this space on June 8, a favorable report appeared on a bill to finance Federal elections partially with Federal funds. A modest note from Senator Charles Mathias, Republican of Mary land, to whom authorship of the bill was attributed, states that Senator Adlai Stevenson, Democrat of Illinois, is in fact primarily responsible for developing the measure, of which Mr. Mathias is a cosponsor.

title: Stockbroker, 62, Strolls 502 Miles Around Manhattan
description: Herman N. Liberman Jr. has recently completed a sev enyear walking tour of Man hattan.

title: Amateur Boxer Dies
description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex., June 21 (UPI)  Mike Britain, a 16yearold boxer who un derwent surgery after being injured in the national Ama teur Athletic Union champion ships in Boston last month, died today of what doctors said was a blood clot in the brain.

title: 5 DECISIONS BY 64
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Supreme Court handed down today a new set of guide lines on obscenity that will en able states to ban books, mag azines, plays and motion pic tures that are offensive to local standards, even if they might be acceptable elsewhere.

description: CHICAGO, June 21 (Reuters)The Midwest Stock Exchange said today that it and six Chicago banks had signed a memorandum of understanding to use the Midwest Securities Trust Company as a comprehensive securities depository.

title: Artistic Arranging Matches the Food
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judg, ment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable estab lishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Edgar Woog, an Organizer Of Swiss Communist Party
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, June 21 (AP)Edgar Woog, who helped organize Communist parties in Mexico and in this country, died yesterday. He was 75 years old.

title: Heroin Smuggler Convicted
description: LOS ANGELES, June 21 (AP) A Thai citizen Was convicted here yesterday of smuggling more than 44 pounds of pure heroin, with an estimated street value of $14.4million, Sukit Benjatarupong of Bangkok was found guilty by United States District Judge Manuel L. Real. Sentencing was set for July 16. Court testimony showed that the heroin was brought here aboard an airliner from Malay sia by Benjatarupong and an American undercover agent posing as a diplomatic courier.

title: WALTER AMBERG, 85, AN INVENTOR, IS DEAD
description: SPRINGFIELD, III., June 21  Walter E. Amberg, who in vented more than 100 products and machines for the railroad, automotive and paperproducts industries, died here yesterday at the age of 85.

title: 3 Character Witnesses Testify in Turner Trial
description: TRENTON, June 21Three defense witnesses testified to day that State Senator James M. Turner, who is on trial on charges of conspiring to frame a fellow legislator on a nar cotics offense, has a reputation for honesty and truthfulness.

title: Nalees Folly Wins Aqueduct Dash at $41.40
description: A shipper from the Middle Atlantic circuit, Pamela Fir man's Nalees Folly, registered a smashing upset in the fea ture race at Aqueduct yester day.

title: A NixonBrezhnev Deal on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The 1974 target date that Presi dent Nixon and Leonid I. Brezh nev have set for a permanent treaty on offensivearms con trols seems the key to their efforts to put limits on the costly arms race.

title: GOVERNOR VETOES 8 PENSION BILLS
description: ALBANY, June 21  Gover nor Rockefeller today vetoed bills passed by the Legislature that would have increased benefits for a variety of New York City employes and for employes of other local govern ments.

title: Peron Appeals for Unity. After 20 Die in Shootings
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 21Former President Juan Domingo Perlin tonight called for unity in his movement and in the country in the wake of the serious shootings that broke out yesterday as throngs hailed his homecoming.

title: Mrs. Short Is Wed To P. E. Truesdale
description: Mrs. Patricia Allen Short, a stockbroker with White, Weld & Co., Inc., was married here yesterday afternoon to Philemon Edwards Truesdale, president of the Truesdale Chemical Sales Company, Inc.

title: Mr. Nixon's Reappraisal
description: Critics of the extended investigations of the Water gate scandals have largely based the case for a speedy end to the proceedings on their fear that the Presidency might be dangerously weakened. A most persuasive reply to such arguments has now been made, however unin tentionally, by Mr. Nixon himself as he has publicly retreated from his earlier tough stand on the funding of at least some domestic programs.

title: Data on DeanNixon Conflict Incomplete
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The expected conflicts on the Watergate affair between the White House and its former counsel, John W. Dean 3d, have failed to emerge fully in the limited statements made public so far.

title: RUDOLPH TIKTIN
description: Rudolph Tiktin, former syndi cate manager for the invest ment banking firm of.Hallgarten & Co., member of the New York, Stock Exchange, died Sunday at Leroy Hospital, 40 East 61st Street. He was 92 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: NEW PREMIER NAMED IN LEBANESE CRISIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 21President. Suleiman Franjieh called on a member of Leb anon's most distinguished Mos lem political family today to try to form a new Cabinet.

title: DOLLAR OFF A BIT; GOLD UP SLIGHTLY
description: LONDON, June 21 (AP)The dollar weakened slightly in Europe today, while gold inched ahead.

title: Madison Ave. Mall Decision Delayed
description: The Board of Estimate, after nearly three hours of public hearing last night on a proposal to establish a mall on Madison Avenue, agreed to postpone a decision on the controversial plan until July 10.

title: Excerpts From Pornography Opinions
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Following are excerpts from majority, opinions written by Chief Justice Warren E. Bur ger and dissenting opinions written by Justice William O. Douglas and Justice. Wil liam J. Brennan Jr. in two obscenity cases decided to day:

title: Mills Joins Henderson State
description: ARKADELPHIA, Ark., June 21 (UPI)Bradley Mills Jr., a de fensive coordinator and secon dary coach at Wake Forest, joined the football coaching staff at Henderson State. Col lege today. Mills also has coached at East Texas State University and Texas Tech.

title: White Couple Get The Right to Keep 2 Black Children
description: ELLENVILLE, N. Y., June 21 (AP)The Ulster County Social Services Department today de cided to let a white couple keep two black foster children, averting a planned demonstra tion in this Catskill Mountain community.

title: AGREEMENT REACHED IN STRIKE BY WRITERS
description: LOS ANGELES, June 21 (AP) The board of directors of the striking Writers Guild of Amer ica voted unanimously today to accept a contract offered by the Association of Motion Pic ture and Television Producers. It will be submitted to the membership Sunday.

title: Frank Leahy Notre Dame Coach, Dead
description: PORTLAND, Ore., June 21 (AP)  Frank Leahy, coach of many of the University of No tre Dame's winning football teams, died shortly after noon today at Good Samaritan Hos pital. He was 64 years old.

title: Advertising: Halt for Mobil Gas
description: Mobil Oil announced yes terday that, because of the energy situation, it was stop ping all of its gasoline ad vertising.

title: BADILLO EXPLAINS TALK WITH BIAGGI
description: Representative Herman Ba dillo conceded yesterday that he had asked Representative Mario Biaggi about possible support in the Democratic may oral primary runoff, but he de nied that he was seeking Mr. Biaggi's endorsement.

title: Minister Dead at 103
description: PENDLETON, Ind.; June 21 (UPI)Dr. Thomas R. White 2d, a retired Presbyterian minister who may have been the oldest member of the John Birch Soci ety in the country, died Tues day; a month before his 104th birthday.

title: ADMIRAL ACCUSES EXP.O.W. OFFICERS
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) A former highranking pris oner of war, Adm. James V. Stockdale, has filed miscon duct charges against two other officers who were with him in North Vietnamese prison camps, Pentagon sources said tonight.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn announced yesterday that it would close 10 of its elementary schools next fall. The parish schoolsnine in Brooklyn and one in Queenshave a combined enrollment of 4,000 pupils and will be merged with 20 of the other 191 elementary schools in the diocese.

title: Cosby at Schaefer Festival
description: Much of the effectiveness of Bill Cosby's art comes from audience recognition of situation. Whether it's the father chastising junior, or an adolescent on a roller coaster, there's an immediate audience ripple of Hey, that happened to me... And in terestingly, it should be noted. that this recognition crosses ethnic lines, despite the fact that Cosby is retelling the mores of growing up coolor being attacked by puberty, as he puts itin a minority section of Philadelphia.

title: Total Eclipse Putting Remote Kenya Area in Limelight
description: LOIENGALANI, Kenya, June 20  There are only about 200 members of El Molo, a tribe in Kenya, and there are approximately the same number of solar astron omers in the United States. The solar eclipse of June 30 is bringing the two groups together on the banks of Lake Rudolf, in the north ern Kenya desert.

title: MAYER ADVANCES IN N.C.A.A. TENNIS
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 21 (AP)  Stanford placed two men today in the California dominated semifinals of the Na tional Collegiate Athitic Asso ciation tennis tournament. The fifth and quarterfinal rounds were played on Princeton Uni versity's indoor courts..

title: U.S. UNIT RELAXES RULE RESTRICTING DIVIDEND PAYOUTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Government's Committee on In terest and Dividends announced today a significant relaxation in the amount of dividends that many companies can pay to their stockholders.

title: Foreman Bout Sought
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., June 21 (UPI)  A group of Puerto Rican sportsmen reportedly have offered the heavyweight champion, George Foreman, $1 million to meet Jose Manuel Urtain, a Basque from Spain, a title bout here or in Madrid. The offer was announced today by the wouldbe promoters, who include Rafael Ramos Cobian, an industrialist, and Henry Guitterres, an architect.

title: SHORT INTEREST UP ON THE BIG BOARD
description: Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose 82, 336 shares to 18.742 million in he period ended June 15, it was reported yesterday.

title: MRS. COOPERSTEIN GAINS GOLF FINAL
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., June 21Mrs. Austin Straub of Roll ing Hills, the defending cham pion, and Mrs. Walter Cooper stein of Glen Oaks, the 1962 titleholder, will meet in the 36 hole final of the 70th Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament tomorrow at the Essex County Country Club.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.8 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials rose to 172.1 from 171.3R last week.

title: DEMOCRATS HEED LAX ON VOTE DATA
description: In an apparent counterattack in the current controversy over campaign practices, Governor Rockefeller has disclosed that state Republicans are filing charges that. Democratic cam paigners failed to live up to the law.

title: Salem Is Awarded Contract
description: The Salem Corporation said yesterday that it had been awarded a contract worth close to $20million to install a coke oven battery for the Algoma Steel Corporation, Ltd., at the company's plant in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

title: JET DOWNS ITSELF WITH AIR MISSILE
description: An F14 Tomcat fighter plane shot itself down over the Pacific on Wednesday with a Sparrow airtoair missile that evidently was erratically launched, the Navy said yes terday.

title: Pompidou, in Bonn, Meets With Brandt On Market Issues
description: BONN, June 21 (Reuters)President Pompidou and Chan cellor Willy Brandt began a de tailed twoday review of Com mon Market problems and other European issues today at Gymnich Castle near here.

title: Red Smith
description: Four matted artists called The Disciples  nobody explained whose, but definitely not Beethoven'shit it, like wow, with two electric guitars, piano and traps. A trotting horse named Sound of Music standing imme diately in front of them bared his teeth and drooled. The horse's trainer, Randy Perry, held one side of his bridle and Leon Greenberg, president of Monti cello Raceway, clutched the other as fearing the worst, hut. Sound of Music stood more quietly than Greenberg. The heat got to Leon, bringing a spastic twitch to his left knee. One of the guitar players thrust his mustache within an inch of a microphone and burst into song, or something:

title: DONN BARBER
description: Donn Barber, who for more than 40 years had been with the American Mail Line of Seat tle and its predecessor, the American Hawaiian Line, died Wednesday, apparently of heart attack, at St. Luke's Hos, pital. He was 62 years old.

title: Law on SexLabeled Job Ads Is Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Supreme Court, rejecting protests that press freedom was being endangered, upheld to day the validity of a Pittsburgh ordinance that prohibits news papers from carrying sexdesig nated employment advertise ments, such as help wanted male.

title: U.S. UNIT RELAXES RULE RESTRICTING DIVIDEND PAYOUTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Government's Committee on In terest and Dividends announced today a significant relaxation in the amount of dividends that many companies can pay to their stockholders.

title: Players. Call the Boycott Irrevocable
description: LONDON, Friday, June 22 (AP)The world's leading men tennis stars confirmed early this morning that their boycott of the Wimbledon champion ships remained in effect.

title: Hunt Said to Get $72,000 After a Threat to ell All
description: WASHINGTON, June 21E. Howard Hunt Jr. received a final cash payment of $72,000 in midMarch after he had warned John D. Ehrlichman that he was ready to tell all about the White House opera tions against Dr. Daniel Ells berg in 1971, sources close to the Watergate case said today.

title: 20 Policemen Told to Issue 4,000 Parking Tickets in 2Day Test
description: As part of a new crack down on midtown parking violators; 20 police officers, each accompanied by a su perior, were directed to issue 2,000 summonses yesterday and 2,000 today.

title: 50 Hours of Volleyball
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., June 21. (AP)  Twentyfour Holyoke High School students claimed a new record for marathon volleyball today by completing a nonstop game of 50 hours 5 minutes. They said the pre vious record was 20 hours.

title: HARRY. MARSH, 85, WELFARE OFFICIAL
description: EVANSTON, Ill., June 21 Harry W. Marsh, a former fare of Public Wel fare and Civil Service Commis SLioner under Mayor Fiorello H. a Guardia, died Tuesday at the James C. King Home here. His age was 85.

title: 5 DECISIONS BY 54; Burger's Opinions Say Views of Community on Prurience Apply
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Supreme Court handed down today a new set of guide lines on obscenity that will en able states to ban books, mag azines, plays and motion pic tures that are offensive to local standards, even if they might be acceptable elsewhere.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LEISURE TIME Nicol Wil liamson passes his time in the early part of the eve ning playing the title role of Uncle Vanya for the Circle intheSquare on the West Side. He's solved the prob lem of what to do with him self after the show, when the night is still young: do an other show.

title: Senate Panel Votes Increase in Pensions
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The Senate Finance Committee voted today to increase all So cial Security benefits by 5 per cent, starting next Jan. 1.

title: CITIBANK REDUCES SOME LOAN RATES
description: The First National City Bank disclosed yesterday that it was trimming interest rates 15 per cent for the next month and a half on both personal and auto loans in a move it said was designed to make it fully competitive with other banks in the New York area.

title: HANLEY ACCUSED BY HORIBLOWER
description: Hornblower & WeeksHemp hill, Noyes, a large member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, demanded yesterday that, the exchange's board of directors investigate and take disciplinary action against Ed wards & Hanley, another mem ber firm, for spreading false rumors about Hornblower's fi nancial status.

title: Samuels Asks State Aid For Election Campaigns
description: Howard J. Samuels, who ran for Lieutenant Governor of the state in 1966 and who is ex pected to seek the Democratic nomination for Governor next year, urged yesterday that the state government help finance political campaigns.

title: Parun Tops Gimeno, 98,97, In South of England Tennis
description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 21 (UPI)Andres Gimeno of Spain, the defending South of England tennis champion, lost today, 98, 97, to Onny Parun of New Zealand in the quarter finals.

title: Thomas Perkins, Lawyer, Dies; Corporations Director Was 67
description: RYE, N. Y., June 21Thomas L. Perkins, a lawyer and cor porate executive, died today in United Hospital, Port Chester, after a brief illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 603 Purchase Street.

title: Dr. Walter Eckstein Dies: Leader in Ethical Culture
description: Dr. Walter Eckstein, a leader in the American Ethical Union, a federation of Ethical Culture societies, died Tuesday at Midtown Hospital. His age was 81, and he lived at 3900 Grey stone Avenue, the Bronx.

title: U.S. Request Halts Trading in Soybeans
description: Trading in soybeans and soy bean meal for delivery over the next three months was halted yesterday by the Chicago Board of Trade folowing a request by the Government.

title: People and Business
description: Edward E. Fitzgerald has been named president and chief operating officer of the BookoftheMonth Club, Inc. Mr. Fitzgerald, a 53yearold former president of the Mc Call Publishing Company and editorinchief of the Literary Guild of America, joined BookoftheMonth as a vice president in 1971.

title: There Are, It Appears, 2 Beames and 2 Badillos
description: Braless and perky, a girl in her late teens or early 20's paused with a start of surprise in front of Controller Abraham D. Beanie, who was shaking hands the other day amid the calculated cacophony of a street stop outside the Church Avenue BMT station in Flat bush.

title: National Steel Studying Soviet Aluminum Process
description: MOSCOW, June 21The Na tional Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh, which has been go ing into the aluminum business in recent years, is quietly con ducting negotiations with the Soviet Union for a Russian process that may help open up newly discovered mineral de posits in the Western United States for the making of alumi num.

title: CITY CLUB ASSAILS FUCHSBERG'S ADS
description: The City Club of New York accused Jacod D. Fuchsberg yesterday of conducting a de liberately misleading adver tising campaign in his recent  and apparently successful  primary fight for the Demo cratic nomination for chief judge of the state.

title: Bridge:
description: Exactly what constitutes trump support is a simple question to which there is no simple answer. At one ex treme, four cards may not be sufficient, as when a take out double has extracted a cheap response in a suit. At the other, a singleton or even a void can suffice.

title: Hunt Said to Get $72 ,000 After a Threat to Tell All
description: WASHINGTON, June 21E. Howard Hunt Jr. received a final cash payment of $72,000 in midMarch after he had warned John D. Ehrlichman that he was ready to tell all about the White House opera tions against Dr. Daniel Ells berg in 1971, sources close to the Watergate case said today.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET PLEDGE SPEEDUP IN ARMS PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, June 21President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev pledged the United States and the Soviet Union to day to accelerate negotiations so that a permanent treaty on limiting each side's offensive strategic weapons could be achieved by the end of next year.

title: Allende Target of Proposals By E. W. KENWORTHY
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  A Senate subcommittee said to day that the International Tele phone and Telegraph Corpora tion had overstepped the line of acceptable corporate behav ior by seeking to enlist the help of the Central Intelligence Agency to prevent the election of Salvador Allende Gossens as President of Chile in 1970.

title: For Nikki Giovanni, Her Poetry Is Her Way of Life
description: Nikki Giovanni, the black poet who wrote that she used to dream militant dreams of taking over America to show these white folks, took over Phil harmonic Hall last night to celebrate her 30th birthday and share some joylet the young take over the burden of that kind of con frontation.

title: YOUTH, 2 SOLDIERS KILLED IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Friday, June 22 (UPI)Gunmen shot a Protestant teenager be tween the eyes and dumped his body on a Belfast street late last night hours after booby trap bombs killed two British soldiers.

title: Minister Dead at 103
description: PENDLETON, Ind., June 21 (UPI)Dr. Thomas 11. White 2d, a retired. Presbyterian minister who may have been the Oldest member of the John Birch Soci ety in the country, died Tues day, a month before his 104th birthday.

title: Excerpts From Kissinger's Briefing on Arms Accord
