description: As you know, the second round of SALT started last November and, as you know also, our representative is Ambassador [U. Alexis] John son, who is here to help with the briefings. The objective of these talks had been to consider a permanent agree ment limiting offensive weap ons to replace the interim agreement that was signed in Moscow last May and which came into effect last October to run for five years.

title: Spoon River Is Staged On East River's Pier 15
description: New York itself is still the best show in town, and one of its more appealing byways is the South Street complex of vintage ships and water front buildings, with enter tainment as an added, pier attraction. In a tent on Pier 15, next to a towering, old British merchantman, four gifted players of the South Street Theater are interpret ing Edgar Lee Masters's Spoon River Anthology.

title: ASTRONAUTS SET TO RETURN TODAY
description: HOUSTON, Friday, June 22The Skylab 1 astronauts were making final preparations early today to leave their orbiting space station and return to earth, ending their record 28 day mission.

title: Pentagon's Statistics Underscore Intensity of Cambodia Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) In the five months since the signing of the Vietnam cease fire, the United States has bombed Cambodia as heavily as it did in the preceding three years, according to Pentagon statistics just made public.

title: Stocks Fall Sharply in Sluggish Trading
Corporate Infighting Noted
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's hardline approach toward Chile has been sharply disputed within the company, according to sources knowledgeable about the internal situation there.

title: LEFELAR, 60, WINS SENIORS GOLF TITLE
description: WEST CALDWELL, N. J., June 21Art Lefelar of Glen Ridge scored three straight birdies and finished with 36, 37.73 to win the 46th Metro politan seniors championship today at the Mountain Ridge Country Club.

title: RUDOLPH TIKTIN
description: Rudolph Tiktin, former syndi cate manager for the invest ment banking firm of Hallgarten & Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, died Sunday at Leroy Hospital, 40 East 61st Street. He was 92 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: More Banks Lift Prime
description: Interest rates continued to sweep higher yesterday in re sponse to the surging economy and resulting inflation.

title: Reform Jews Urge A Complete Amnesty For War Resisters
description: ATLANTA, June 21  The rabbinic body of American Re form Judaism has called for unconditional amnesty for Viet nam war resisters. It was the first such action taken by major Jewish religious group.

title: Exchange Scans Finances Of Nine Brokerage Firms
description: Nine member firms, have been placed under special, intensive surveillance by the New York Stock Exchange because of fi nancial difficulties and some of them probably will have to be liquidated, a Big Board of ficial disclosed yesterday.

title: U.S. LISTS OUTLAY ON 2 NIXON HOMES
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) The Federal Government said today that it had spent nearly $2million on President Nixon's homes in Key Biscayne, Fla., and San Clemente. Calif.

title: RETAIL PRICES UP 4% HERE IN
description: Retail prices for the goods and services bought by people in the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area rose again in May. But the rate of increase declined for the second con. secutive month and was a shade less than the national increase, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: PICKETS OCCUPY A BEAMS OFFICE
description: While Controller Abraham D. Beame campaigned yesterday, pickets from the Morningside Tenants Union tried to take over his political headquarters at the Barclay Hotel, 111 East 48th Street.

title: No Lunch for a Fascist Means No Quiet in Italy
description: CASALECCHIO, Italy, June 21 A swiftmoving attend ant at a busy allnight serv ice station on the northsouth Motorway of the Sun filled a gas tank early this morning, checked the oil, wiped the windshield and with a grin told the traveler: This is the hottest spot in all Italy.

title: Descendant of Christian Dies on Pitcairn Island
description: GLENDALE, Calif., June 21 (Reuters)The ship's bell on tiny Pitcairn Island in the South Pacific tolled 77 times today marking the passing of another descendant of the mutineers of H.M.S. Bounty.

title: People in Sports: Wottle Caps Winning Night in Fast Fashion
description: Dave Wottle, known for his habit of running with a white golf hat, ended up with skinned legs Wednesday night after chasing and catching a souvenir hunter who grabbed his cap. Wottle had just finished running the mile in 3 minutes 53.3 sec onds when a young man grabbed his hat at Hayward Field in Eugene, Ore., and took off outside the stadi um. Wottle gave chase into a nearby field, where the hatstealer fell and Wottle tripped over him.

title: A Letter From Ohio
description: Lawrence Mitchner died a few days ago.

title: School and Library Budgets Voted in 4 Places in Nassau
description: Four Nassau County commun ities last night approved library and school budget proposals.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET PLEDGE SPEEDUP IN ARMS PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, June 21President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev pledged the United States and the Soviet Union to day to accelerate negotiations so that a permanent treaty on limiting each side's offensive strategic weapons could be achieved by the end of next year.

title: LiberalG.0.P. Entente: A Growing Alliance
description: The investigation of election time alliances betwen Republi cans and Liberals to insure the election of Republican Assem blymen points up the increas ingly close ties between the G.O.P. and Liberals despite the ideological gulf between the parties. The latest example of this entente was the bizarre agreement, which later collapsed, be tween Governor Rockefeller and Alex Rose, the Liberal leader, to support Robert F. Wagner for Mayor.

title: Northside Subway Work Imperils Talks
description: The beginning of construction of a Transit Authority substa tion has threatened to under mine months of sensitive nego tiations between the city and 37 families being relocated in the Northside section of Brook lyn to allow a manufacturer to expand so that he can remain in the city.

title: People and Business Shift Set at BookoftheMonth
description: Edward E. Fitzgerald has been named president and chief operating officer of the BookoftheMonth Club, Inc. Mr. Fitzgerald, a 53yearold former president of the Mc Call Publishing Company and editorinchief of the Literary Guild of America, joined BookoftheMonth as a vice president in 1971.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: The Nixon Brezhnev Promises
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Nixon Brezhnev agreements on the limitation of strategic offensive arms and the joint development of peaceful atomic energy promise a great deal more than they deliver, but at least they main tain the spirit of cooperation.

title: Raped Wife Kills Attacker As He Threatens Children
description: BALTIMORE, June 2 (Reu ters)a 22yearold housewife who was raped yesterday by a fugitive pretending to be a po liceman shot him to death when he threatened her children, ac cording to the police.

title: Baseball Transactions NATIONAL LEAGUE
description: HOUSTONPlaced Larry Dierker, righthanded Ocher, on disabled list with ailing right shoulder. Activated Tons Griffin, right handed pitcher.

title: 5 BANKERS TESTIFY ON FLOATING RATES
description: WASHINGTON, June 21At titudes ranging from enthusias tic endorsement to strong op position were expressed by bankers to Congress today to ward the new experiment in floating currency exchange rates.

title: For 5th Time in 73, Police. Honor Slain Colleague
description: The men in blue stood in neat columns along the tree lined street, their faces solemn, their posture proud and stiffall silent, all wearing the small black bands on their badges that signified they were in mourning.

title: Frank Leahy Is Dead
description: Frank Leahy, the coach of some of Notre Dame's finest football teams, died yester day in Portland, Ore. Details on Page 38.

title: MACTIER'S HORSE WINS TWO EVENTS!
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 21Jan Mactier's Chris topher Robin, who had a brief career with the United States Equestrian Team, was a double winner today at the opening session of the fourday Mid dlesex County Horse Show.

title: HOUSE UNIT DEFIES NIXON OVER FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 In a new Congressional con frontation with the Nixon Ad ministration, the House Appro priations Committee approved today funds to continue a variety of domestic programs the White House has sought to abolish or cut back.

title: Denver Districting Is Unconstitutional
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 ['he Supreme Court served no ice today that any Northern city school system with a sub stantial pocket of demonstrable segregation will be regarded as an entirely dual system with an unconstitutional level of dis crimination.

title: Pact to Save Jobs Of 48 Now Working On School Lunches
description: While more than 1,000 school lunch workers demonstrated outside the Board of Education offices yesterday, school and union officials reached a con ditional agreement that will ap parently save the jobs of 48 annual employes who face dismissal today because of budget cuts.

title: Paris Leftists and Police Clash Over Rightist Rally
description: PARIS, June 21 (AP)Street battles broke out tonight be tween leftist militants hurling gasoline bombs and riot police men who were protecting a rightwing meeting. At least 76 policemen were injured, one critically.

title: Roundup: Hendrick Hits 10th Homer in 14 Games
description: George Hendrick is for real.

title: Equity Financing
description: An initial public offering of 1,000,000 common shares of Circle Income Shares, Inc., a new closed end diversified management investment company whose investment adviser will be the American Fletcher National Bank and Trust Company, a SC sidiary of the American Fletcher Corporation, $15 a share was made yesterday by Goldman Sachs; Hayden Stone; Thomson McKinnon Auchincloss; Robert W. Baird; and the Ohio Company.

title: SANDMAN OFFERS KEY POST TO TODD
description: TRENTON, June 21 Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., moving quickly to gain a foothold with the Republican leadership in north ern New Jersey that has traditionally opposed him, has asked Webster B. Todd, the party state chairman during the nineteensixties, to become chairman of the Republican state finance committee.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City Relief Reform Called Myth
description: The State Welfare Inspector General assailed the Human Re sources Administration's wel fare reform program yesterday as a myth and a costly bungle.

title: Jet With 153 Passengers Slips Into Mud at Kennedy
description: A British Overseas Airways COrporation Boeing 747 jet car rying 153 passengers and a crew of eight skidded off a run way after landing at Kennedy Airport last night. Officials said there were no injuries.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 6.6%
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Association of American Rail roads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.9 billion tonmiles, 6.6 per cent above the corresponding week last year.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Jersey Gets Into Title Act

title: Miss Laurel Takes Lead In Women's College Golf
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 21 (AP)The Michigan amateur champion, Bonnie Laurer of Michigan State, took the lead at the halfway mark in the national women's inter collegiate golf tournament to t:lay with a 36hole total of 151 at Mount Holyoke Golf Club.

title: Mills Joins Henderson State
description: ARKADELPHIA, Ark., June 21 (UPI)Bradley Mills Jr., a de fensive coordinator and secon dory coach at Wake Forest, joined the football coaching staff at Henderson State Col, lege today. Mills also has coached at East Texas Slate University and Texas Tech.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: National Presto Industries, Inc., received a $71.6million Army contract for metal parts for 105millimeter artillery, rounds, it was announced yes terday.

title: The Stage: Shaw Festival in Ontario
description: NIAGARAONTHELAKE, Ontario, June 21For some it may seem as incongruous to invite the present writer to a Shaw festival as to in vite a Montague to a Capu let ball, a poacher to a game preserve or a Mets fan to the mysteries of the Mary lebone Cricket Club Lords in London. But my wellpubli cized antipathy to the plays of Shaw has been vastly ex aggeratedpartly, I confess, by myself. It is not that think that Shaw is so much worse than he is, but rather that so many academicians, and even a few of my col leagues, imagine that he is so much better.

title: Lake Morale Dips As Water Goes Up
description: DETROIT, June 21 This is the time of year that Dave Mercier used to love best: the beginning of summer.

title: Parun Tops Gimeno, 98,97, In South of England Tennis
description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 21 (UPI)Andres Gimeno of Spain, the defending South of England tennis champion, lost today, 98, 97, to Onny Parun of New Zealand in the quarter finals.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: JERSEY CITY, June 21When the Amateur Fencing League of America starts its championships Saturday Tucson, Ariz., petite Ann O'Donnell of Bayonne will be the thick of the battling for the women's foil title.

title: Fuerbach and Bolding Win
description: WARSAW, June 21 (UPI)Al Fuerbach and Jim Bolding were winners today at an inter national track and field meet. Fuerbach took the shot with a put of 67 feet 5 inches and Bolding won the 400meter hurdles in 49.3 seconds.

title: N.B.C. Asks Reversal of Ruling in Fairness Case
description: The National Broadcasting Company has requested a full Federal Communications Com mission review and reversal of the agency's staff ruling that the N.B.C. News special Pen sions: The Broken Promise vio lated the fairness doctrine. The N.B.C. television network car ried the hourlong documentary on Sept. 12, 1972.

title: U.S.Soviet Accords on Nuclear Arms Talks and on Peaceful Atomic Programs
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 Following are the texts of the basic principles of negotia tions on the further limitation of strategic offensive arms and the agreement on the peaceful uses of atomic en ergy signed today by the United States and the Soviet Union:

title: Barker Conviction Upheld On Notary Seal Charge
description: MIAMI, June 21 (AP) Cir cuit Judge William Herin has upheld the conviction of Ber nard L. Barke a Watergate burglar, on charges of misusing a notary public seal.

title: Retail Store Sales Rise
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Department of Commerce re ported today that total retail store sales for the latest week was an estimated $10.096 billion, up 11 per cent from the yearearlier $9.071billion. De partment store sales were about $1.075billion, up 17 per cent from last year's $921million.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: The Great Central Park Quilting Bee Nearly a Washout
description: The Midsummer Night's Quilting Bee, billed as the bee to produce the longest quilt in the world, almost pro duced the shortest yesterday afternoon.

title: Return of Astronauts
description: The Skylab 1 astronauts are scheduled to splash down today at 9:50 A.M. in the Pacific Ocean, ending their 28day mission. Page 22.

title: Exchange Scans Finances Of Nine Brokerage Firms
description: Nine member firms have been placed under special, intensive surveillance by the New York Stock Exchange because of fi nancial difficulties and some of them probably will have to be liquidated, a Big Board of ficial disclosed yesterday.

title: Louis R. Menagh, ExPresident Of Prudential Insurance, Dies
description: MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 21 Louis R. Menagh, who re tired as president of the Pru dential Insurance Company in 1962 after 48 years with the company, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 80 years old and lived here.

title: U.S. Maps AirportNoise Curb; Pilots and Industry Assail Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 Sweeping recommendations de signed to quiet the din of jet aircraft at airports around the country were made public to day by an Environmental Pro jection Agency study group. The proposals were quickly as sailed in statements by pilots and airport and airline execu tives as potentially unworkable and, in some cases, unsafe.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Fairleigh Rejects Land Trade

title: Six in Soviet Reject Plea to End Fast
description: MOSCOW, June 21Six So viet Jewish scientists said to day that they had rejected plea by two American Senators to end a hunger strike over the Soviet refusal to let them emi grate to Israel.

title: Pirates Win, 21, in 9th On Met Defensive Lapse
description: PITTSBURGH, June 21It took one run that was dis puted and another that was a gift to send the New York Mets tumbling to their fourth straight defeat tonight as they bowed to the cellardwelling Pittsburgh Pirates, 21.

title: Books of The Times
description: With the publication of The Lice in 1966, W. S. Merwin embarked on a spiritual discipline: to so rid the landscape of place and person that he could work out for him self, as if in Zen exercises, a way toward ultimate light. In that place he inhabits in his poems, conflict within the self is stilled, desire is stilled (except as desire for the right way); no one speaks except stone, rocks, mountains and sometimes an animal (totemistic guides for the spirit). The speaker of the poems is a we or us but completely impersonal, signifying the deepest nub of feeling within the self that is meant to be the universal or bare con sciousness, conscious need without person ality, place or individuality. The poems represent a very quiet withdrawal into the darkest part of the self, where the light of the world filters through, described exactly but in terms not quite human: All the stones have been us/and will be again/as the sun touches them can feel/sun.

title: Manhattanville's Head Presents Resignation
description: PURCHASE, N.Y. June 21 Elizabeth J. McCormack an nounced today that she had submitted to the board of trustees her resignation as president of Manhattanville College, to take effect at the end of the the 197374 aca demic year.

title: Senator Seeks Elimination Of Stock Certificates
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (Reu ters)Senator Harrison A. Wil liam Jr. Democrat of New Jersey, chairman of the Securi ties subcommittee, said today he would introduce a bill calling for the elimination of stock cer tificates in interbroker trans actions by 1976.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating Outlook
description: AREA A  Allday party boats are enjoying great suc cess chumming for blues off Barnegat Ridge. Catches have been averaging 10 to 12 pounds, with a few 15 pounders hauled in. Halfday boats report good fluke fish ing around Sea Girt, N. J. Bunkers and butterfish have attracted fluke in the seven pound range. In Barnegat Bay and in the ocean along the beaches flounders are be ing taken. The Bay also has fluke, weakfish and striped bass, but some patience is necessary.

title: Thomas Perkins, Lawyer, Dies; Corporations'
description: RYE, N. Y., June 21Thomas L. Perkins, a lawyer and cor porate executive, died today in United Hospital, Port Chester, after a brief illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 603 Purchase Street.

title: HARRY MARSH, 85, WELFARE OFFICIAL
description: EVANSTON, III., June 21 Harry W. Marsh, a former Commissioner of Public Wel fare and Civil Service Commis sioner under Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, died Tuesday at the James C. King Home here. His age was 85.

title: Invitation List For the Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 Following are the Americans who attended the dinner at the Soviet Embassy tonight in honor of the visit of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Com munist party leader, to the United States:

title: 2 HIGH G.O.P. AIDES
description: ALBANY, June 21Testimo ny given to State Attorney Gen eral Louis J. Lefkowitz names two top assistants to the Assem bly Speaker and the Assembly majority leader as Republican officials who aided in the print ing and mailing of campaign material portrayed as Liberal, a source close to the investiga tion said yesterday.

title: Miller Gets HoleinOne And Ties for Golf Lead
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 21 Johnny Miller is still hot. The man who shot a record 63 four days ago to win the Unit ed States Open, scored a hole inone today and shared the firstround lead at 67 in the $160,000 American Golf Classic.

title: FREDERICK E. BELL
description: FORT LEE, N.J., June 21Frederick E. Bell, a former vice president and executive as sistant to the president of PrenticeHall, Inc., the publish ing company in Englewood Cliffs, died yesterday at his home, 2100 Linwood Avenue. He was 79 years old.

title: The Pop Life
description: Johnny Winter stopped his Madison Square Garden show last Saturday to upbraid the audience for throwing things at himcardboard hotdog holders, items of clothing and the like. Alice Cooper was hit and hurt at his Garden con cert by a neatly aimed love token from the audience. Led Zeppelin (which winds up its current tour with three dates at the Garden next month) stopped its show at Tampa, Fla., because identified flying objects got in the way of the real actionthe music.

title: Economical Stuffed Cabbage
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an aster isk are followed by a recipe.

title: Dauber &
description: I feel like I've just gotten a reprieve, said Murray Dauber yesterday, surveying the happy crowd sipping champagne among the 200, 000 books that clutter every available inch of his store on Fifth Avenue.

title: Coty Awards: Calvin Klein, Burrows
description: The young set in fashion received recognition from the old guard as Calvin Klein, age 30, and Stephen Burrows, 29, were announced winners of the Coty American Fash ion Critics Awards for 1973.

title: Ousted Midshipman Sues for B.S. Degree
description: A New Jersey man who was asked to resign from the United States Naval Academy a week before graduation when he applied to be a conscientious objector may be unable to accept a fellow ship at New York University Law School because the Navy has refused for two years to grant him his under graduate degree.

title: Notes on People
description: With a bouquet of yellow, long stemmed roses sent to his wife, Patricia, President Nixon marked the 33d anni versary of their marriage 1940 at the Mission Inn in Riverside, Calif. The family Mr. and Mrs. Nixon, their daughters, Julie and Tricia, and their sonsinlaw, David Eisenhower and Edward F. Cox, planned a private family celebration at the White House before a Soviet Em bassy dinner to be given by the Communist party leader Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: POP MUSIC INQUIRY BROADENED BY US,
description: The Justice Department has intensified its investigation of Columbia Records and its sub sidiaries and is now poring over carloads of expense vouchers, personnel records, fi nancial and legal documents of the record label and its sub sidiaries, sources close to the case said yesterday.

title: Illegal Fireworks Dealing Laid to an F.A.A. Employe
description: COMMACK, L. I., June 21 (UPI)An airtraffic controller at MacArthur Airport was ar rested last night for trying to sell fireworks to a customer who turned out to be a Suffolk County plainclothes policeman.

title: State WelfareWork Law Upheld by U.S. High Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 The Supreme Court today re versed a lower court and up held a New York State law that requires ablebodied wel fare recipients to demonstrate that they have sought employ ment or be put to work on publicworks projects.

title: Strauss Details BreakIn at His Home
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 Robert S. Strauss, the Demo cratic National Chairman, has, for the first time, provided de tails about a mysterious burg lary at his Dallas home two weeks after the Watergate arrests.

title: Werblin Expects Bond Issue in Week
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, June 21 After a postponement of more than a month, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority hopes to be able to bring a bond issue of more than $200 million to market next week but underwriting officials doubt that the move can be made that quickly.

title: 20 Policemen Told to Issue 4,000 Parking Tickets in 2Day Test
description: As part of a new crack down on midtown parking violators, 20 police officers, each accompanied by a su perior, were directed to issue 2,000 summonses yesterday and 2,000 today.

title: Weicker Defends Dean's Right To Tell His Story on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, a Republican member of the Senate Water gate committee, defended today the credibility of John W. Dean 3d, former White House counsel, and charged that the Nixon Ad ministration had stepped on anyone willing to search for the truth about Watergate.

title: Amex List Off in Quiet Trading As OTC Prices Drop Sharply
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower yester day after trading in a desultory fashion within a narrow range for most of the day.

title: Rent in the Courts
description: The temporary injunction issued by a state Supreme Court justice is admirably designed to safeguard the interests of tenants, landlords and building service employes in the mess created by City Council's repeal of the formula for establishing fair rents in 1.2 million rentcontrolled apartments in this city.

title: PRISON CHIEF OUSTED IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: BOSTON, June 21 (AP)Cor1 rections Commissioner John O. Boone resigned under fire to day and Gov. Francis W. Sar gent ordered the state police into Walpole State Prison.

title: MAYER ADVANCES IN N.C.A.A. TENNIS
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 21. (AP)  Stanford placed two men today in the California dominated semifinals of the Na tional Collegiate Athitic Asso c iation tennis tournament. The fifth and quarterfinal rounds were played on Princeton Uni versity's indoor courts.

title: Mrs. Mitchell Leaves; Destination Unknown
description: Mrs. John N. Mitchell, left her Fifth Avenue apartment yesterday in a station wagon loaded with suitcases. She has complained of being be sieged by newsmen.

title: British Land Co. Unit to Make Offer for Uris Buildings Stock
description: The British Land Company, Ltd., announced yesterday that its United States subsidiary would make a cash tender offer for all outstanding common stock of the Uris Buildings Cor poration. This would involve a maximum consideration of about $145million, assuming the exercise of all Uris out standing warrants and tend of the underlying com mon stock. The net price of the offer would be $14.50 a share, compared with the proposed tender offer of $17.50 a share when the first announcement was made April 23. At that time Uris traded at 15 on the New York Stock Exchange. It closed yesterday at 13 up  point. The year's high was 16 and the low was11

title: ATTORNEYS RESIST MITCHELL HARING
description: WASHINGTON, June 21At torneys for John N. Mitchell said today that they had tem porarily blocked any attempts by the Senate Watergate com mittee to take testimony from the former Attorney General in private.

title: LEO MARDER
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jane 21 Leo Marder, president of the Matson Manufacturing Com pany, Long Island City, Queens, until his retirement in 19674 died today at the Hollywoo Memorial Hospital. His age was 79, and he lived in Hallandale near here.

title: Soviet Bids for Estate
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 (UPI)The Soviet Union has bid nearly $200,000 for an estate of several acres in the wooded, affluent suburb of Woodside on the San Francisco Peninsula. George Meriwether, a realtor with Coidwell, Banker & Co. of Atherton, confirmed the bid yesterday. He said the estate, owned by a wealthy San Francisco socialite, Oliver Dibble Jr., had been en the mar ket 18 months.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: PITTSBURGHSigned Syl APPS, center, and Dave Burrows, defenseman, to multiyear contracts.

title: George Washington Beats Cardozo Nine For P.S.A.L. Title
description: George Washington won the Public Schools Athletic League baseball championship yester day by defeating Cardozo, 4.3, at the Yankee Stadium.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on June 21 were:

title: Radio
description: 8:0510 A.M., WNCN. Esther: Overture, Handel; Three Novel ettes, Poulenc; Oboe Concerto in D, Albinoni; Symphony No. 6 in G minor, J. C. Bach; Violin Con certo No. 1 in A minor, Bach; Scherzo Capriccioso, Dvorak; Clarinet Concerto, Copland.

title: Senator Seeks Elimination Of Stock Certificates,
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (Reu ters)Senator Harrison A. Wil liam Jr. Democrat of New Jersey, chairman of the Securi ties subcommittee, said today he would introduce a bill calling for the elimination of stock cer tificates in interbroker trans actions by 1976.

title: Pact Widens U. S.Soviet Quest for Future Energy
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 Under the new atomsforpeace agreement signed today at the White House, the United States and the Soviet Union plan to broaden their cooperation in the peaceful development of atomic energy with particular emphasis on new types of nu clear power plants.

title: CUT IN WAGE RISE UPSET BY COURT
description: WASHINGTON, June 21A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Pay Board erred last year in cutting back a de ferred costofliving wage in crease for 120,000 aerospace workers and ordered the Cost of Living Council to reopen the case.

title: Edgar Won, an Organizer Of Swiss Confrnunist Party
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, June 21 (AP)Edgar Woog, who helped organize Communist parties in Mexico and in this country, died yesterday. He was 75 years old.

title: Corporate Infighting Noted
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's hardline approach toward Chile has been sharply disputed within the company, according to sources knowledgeable about the internal situation there.

title: C.B.S. Picks Woman As Half of Its Team For Morning News
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System has chosen Sally Quinn, a Washington Post reporter with no previous television ex perience, to coanchor its forth coming revamped morning news program.

title: Casey Urges World Group of Oil Users
description: The United States yesterday gave its strongest indication that it was interested in some form of union of oilconsuming countries in light of the present and possible future tightness of world energy supplies.

title: YANKEES WIN, 51, IN 6INNING GAME
description: Pat Dobson made his second start as a Yankee last night as the Detroit Tigers tried to slip a Mickey (Lolich) past the firstplace New Yorkers in the opener of their fivegame series at Yankee Stadium before 14, 940 paid fans.

title: Lottery Numbers Winning numbers drawn on June 21 were:
description: Tickets matching the num ber above win $50,000. Tick ets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four num bers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

title: Bridge A Singleton or Void Can Be Enough for Trump Support
description: Exactly what constitutes trump support is a simple question to which there is ho simple answer. At one ex treme, four cards may not be sufficient, as when a take out double has extracted a cheap response in a suit. At the other, a singleton or even a void can suffice.

title: President and Chairman
description: The leaders of the Soviet Union and the United States have vividly staked their personal reputations on the commitment to political dtente between two super powers, whatever the opposition on specific issues they may respectively anticipate on their homefronts.

title: Lithium Found to Aid Some Alcoholics
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 The element lithium, which it compounds has proved valu able as a drug for some psy chiatric problems, has also proved useful in treating some alcoholics, a scientist reported here today.

title: DONN BARBER
description: Donn Barber, who for more than 40 years had been with the American Mail Line of Seat tle and its predecessor, the American Hawaiian Line, died Wednesday, apparently of heart attack, at St. Luke's Hos pital. He f was 62 years old.

title: F.T.C. Member Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Mayo J. Thompson of Texas to the Federal Trade Commission. Mr. Thompson, approved routinely by voice vote, replaces A. Everette Maclntyre, who re signed.

title: Geisel's Brother Dies
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 21Gen. Henrique Geisel, older brother of Gen. Ernesto Geisel who has been named to be Brazil's next President, died of cerebral hemorrhage in the Army Hospital last night. He was stricken in the afternoon while working at his office in a private maritime company. He was 69 years old.

title: Collapsing Pennsy
description: The bankrupt Penn Central Railroad is back on Capitol Hill, rattling its tin cup for Federal cash to keep the trains running. The acuteness of the Penny's financial crunch is beyond argument, but giving its trustees big bundle of Government funds would merely unlock the Treasury vaults for an endless drain.

title: State WelfareWork Law Upheld by U.S. High Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 The Supreme Court today re versed a lower court and up held a New York State law that requires ablebodied wel fare recipients to demonstrate that they have sought employ ment or be put to work on publicworks projects.

title: U.S. DENIES KILLING HEALTH AID TO POOR
description: WASHINGTON, June 21A. high official of the Department of Health, Education and Wel fare described today as totally false the charge of a Con gressional leader in health affairs that Administration poli cies would doom several im portant health programs for the poor.

title: They Don't Go for Baroque in Great Barrington
description: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., June 21 A classic confrontation between city folk and country folk is heating up the normally cool air of this Berkshire com munity.

title: FREDERICK E. BELL
description: TORT LEE, N.J., June 21Frederick E. Bell, a former vice president and executive as sistant to the president of PrenticeHall, Inc., the publish ing company in Englewood Cliffs, died yesterday at his home, 2100 Linwood Avenue. He was 79 years old.

title: 27 DIE AS AIRLINER HITS MEXICAN PEAK
description: PUERTO VALLARTA, Mexico, June (UPI)A Mexican DC9 jetliner flying from Houston to Mexico City with 27 persons aboard struck a mountain peak on Mexico's Pacific Coast last night and exploded.

title: LEO MARDER
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., June 21 Leo Marder, president of the Matson Manufacturing Com pany, Long Island City, Queens, until his retirement in 1967i died today at the Hollywoo Memorial Hospital. His age was 79, and he lived in Hallandale near here.

title: U.S. Defends Role of Sixth Fleet Against Libya's Attack in U. N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 21The United States told the Security Council today that the American Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean neither constitutes aggression, nor re fleets an aggressive intent.

title: Kheel Praises Rockefeller For Dropping Bridge Plan
description: Theodore W. Kheel yesterday complimented Governor Rocke feller for dropping his efforts to build a Long Island Sound bridge between Rye, in West chester, and Oyster Bay, L. I. He also promised he would campaign strenuously to de feat the Governor's proposed new transportation bond issue if it provided what he consid ered too much money for high ways.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on the admission of East Germany and West Germany.

title: House Passes Legal Aid Bill With Amendments That Backers Say Cripple It
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  A blearyeyed House voted late tonight to create an independ ent corporation to provide legal services for the poor.

title: Allende Target of Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  A Senate subcommittee said to day that the International Tele phone and Telegraph Corpora tion had overstepped the line of acceptable corporate behav ior by seeking to enlist the help of the Central Intelligence Agency to prevent the election of Salvador Allende Gossens as President of Chile in 1970.

title: Chris Evert Is Upset in London Tennis
description: LONDON, June 21  The players boycotting Wimbledon got their comeuppance today: the four semifinalists at the Queen's Club event may play in the world's most famous tournament next week. Ilie Nastase of Rumania, Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union and Owen Davidson of Aus tralia already have declared themselves in. Roger Taylor, Britain's No. 1, has been torn by divided loyalties and is dithering over a decision that must be made by tomorrow morning.

title: Theories in Coed Slaying Appear to Exceed Clues
description: But new information did not seem plentiful two full days after her body, stabbed 21: times, was found in her un locked dormitory room.

title: Strikes and Shootings Spread Across Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 21 (AP)Gunfire, bombings and fighting, along with strikes supporting and opposing the Marxistled Government, threw Chile into new turmoil today.

title: Alcoholism Bill Voted
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) The Senate passed today and sent to the House a $460million authorization bill extending Federal programs to fight al coholism for three more years. The action came on a voice vote without dissent.

title: 4 SEIZED AS HEADS OF DRUG BOUTIQUE
description: Three men and a woman were arrested yesterday on charges of running what Dis trict Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn called a drug bou tique in an expensively fur nished home in the Mill Basin section.

title: Ordering of Goods Up in April and May
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 New orders for durable goods rose by $525million, or 1.3 per cent, to $41.86billion in May after seasonal adjustment, the Department of Commerce re ported today.

title: National Steel Studying Soviet Aluminum Process
description: MOSCOW, June 21The Na tional Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh, which has been go ing into the aluminum business in recent years, is quietly con ducting negotiations with the Soviet Union for a Russian process that may help open up newly discovered mineral de posits in the Western United States for the making of alumi num.

title: Embassy Burglaries? Old Hat
description: OXFORD, EnglandBreaking into embassies, as a White House official urged doing in papers leaked recently, is not new.

title: Arab IceBreaker?
description: Shortly after the June 1967 ArabIsraeli war, President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia called for an end to the Arab countries state of belligerency against Israel, denouncing the Arab position as a deadend policy.

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, JUNE 22, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Two Bronx Judges Sworn
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday swore in two Bronx Demo crats as judges in the city's Criminal Courts for terms ex piring Dec. 31. The two were Archie A. Gorfinkel and Wil liam J. Holland. They will re ceive $33, 250 a year.

title: M'DONALD'S WINS IN LOTTERY CASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 The Federal Trade Commission has absolved operators of the McDonald's hamburger chain of deceptive business practices in sponsoring a $500,000 pro motional sweepstakes in 1968.

title: General Instrument Lifts Profit 59.1%
description: The General Instrument Cor poration's earnings rose to 59.1 per cent in the first fis cal quarter. ended May 27, and were the highest for any simi lar threemonth period in five years. In announcing the re sults to shareholders at the an nual meeting yesterday in Newark, N.J., Moses Shapiro, chairman, noted that sales were the, highest for any quarter in the company's history.

title: REV. CYRIL R. DELANEY
description: WORCESTER, Mass., June 22 (AP)The Rev. Cyril R. Delaney, associate professor of religion at Holy Cross College and head of the theology department from 1959 to 1964, died Wednesday at a hospital here. He was 61 years old.

title: J. H. BUTLER
description: HOUSTON, June 22 (AP) J. H. Butler, retired executive vice president and general man ager of The Houston Chron icle, died Wednesday at the age of 79. He retired in 1965 after 55 years with The Chronicle.

title: Aid Barred to Industrial Park Over VoteBuying
description: HARFORD, June 22Gov. Thomas J. Meskill today blocked state participation in a pro posed industrial park in Rocky Hill because of a scandal over votebuying in the referendum by which the townspeople nar rowly approved the park.

title: STARTS SAYS HAIG IS VIOLATING LAW
description: WASHINGTON, June 22The Controller General has con cluded that Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. is violating Federal law by serving as an assistant to the President while remain ing on active military duty.

title: A Classmate Remembers...
description: WASHINGTONAs a farmer class mate of Patrick Buchanan at the Co lumbia University Graduate School of Journalism, class of 62, an litist in stitution if there ever was one, I re member the drill we used to go through trying to make sense out of a jumble of bits and pieces of information and turning them into an understandable story.

title: WINE TALK
description: The story must have lost something, as they say, in translation. It came out of Paris June 19 and said that Paris newspapers were shocked by the dinner Presi dent and Mrs. Nixon gave for Leonid I. Brezhnev, the So viet leader.

title: G.O.P. County Leader Is Ousted On S.I. Despite Marchi Backing
description: Richard Bolton, the Staten Island Republican county lead er, was defeated for reelection last night by a vote of 204 to 100 at a noisy meeting of the party's county committee, dur ing which he was personally endorsed by State Senator John J. Marchi.

title: Roundup: No. 692 Puts Aaron 22 Behind Ruth
description: Still bothered by occasional muscle spasms in his back, Hank Aaron, the Atlanta Braves slugger who is in hot pursuit of Babe Ruth's career home run record of 714, has evidently decided to shrug off that ailment and the minor abdominal surgery he under went this week.

title: JAMES WILLIAM MORRIS
description: James William Morris, who retired last year as domestic communications manager for United Press International, died Wednesday at the age of 67.

title: People and Business
description: Clement Stone, president of the Combined Insurance Company of America, has been named chief executive officer. He succeeds his father, W. Clement Stone, who will continue as chair man.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The meataxe methods proposed by the Environmental Protection Admin istration for dealing with the airpollus tion problem may serve as shock ther apy, but the cure, if carried out, may be nearly as bad as the disease, and in any case will entail serious conse quences which can be avoided by the use of more refined methods.

title: 69 Campaign Donor Admits Tax Charge
description: NEWARK, June 22 (UPI)A Camden electrical concern pleaded guilty today to a charge of having filed a false income tax return to disguise a $1,000 contribution to the 1969 campaign of Governor Cahill.

title: Leahy Tried Acupuncture In His Struggle to Survive
description: The death of Frank Leahy Thursday, following a fiveyear battle against leukemia and other crippling ailments, was no surprise to Johnny Lattner, one of four winners of football's Heisman Trophy that Leahy coached at Notre Dame.

title: Auto Production Up by 5,300 Units From a Week Ago
description: DETROIT, June 22 (AP) Domestic auto production jumped by 5,300 cars this week as two General Motors plants returned to work after wildcat strikes, according to Automo tive News.

title: 2 SeaLink Victims Decided to Reject An Escape Attempt
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., June 22 (AP)  Two undersea research ers Who died after their mini submarine was trapped on the ocean floor had vetoed a plan to swim 351 feet to the surface, preferring to wait for Navy divers, two surviving comrades said today.

title: ChiefJudge Nomination Is Won by Fuchsberg
description: ALBANY, June 22 (AP)New York Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo announced officially today that Jacob D. Fuchsberg had captured the Democratic nomination for chief judge of the Court of Appeals by 755 votes, defeat ing United States District Court Judge Jack B. Wein stein.

title: World Court Asks Paris to Halt Tests
description: THE HAGUE, June 22 (Reu ters)At the request of Aus tralia and New Zealand, the International Court of Justice today asked France to suspend her nuclear tests in the South Pacific pending a judgment on their legality in international law.

title: PROVING FLIGHT WINS JUMP CLASS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 22Frank Chapot piloted Fox brook Farm's Proving Flight through rain and gloom today to win the intermediate jumper class at the Middlesex County horse show.

title: Cemetery Union Defies Order And Continues Work Stoppage
description: Striking cemetery workers defied a temporary injunction yesterday and continued their stoppage at 46 cemeteries in the metropolitan area.

title: Energy Czar Choice
description: Administration and oil in dustry officials report that Gov. John A. Love of Colo rado, a Republican, is Presi dent Nixon's choice to head the proposed Department of Energy and Natural Re sources. Page 11.

title: A Bill to Preserve The Tidal Wetlands Signed by Governor
description: ALBANY, June 22Gov ernor Rockefeller today signed a bill designed to pro tect and preserve the state's tidal wetlands, most of which are in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yan kee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 2 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 2 P.M.)

title: Students Satirize Thai Chiefs But Government Isn't Amused
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 22 (UPI)  To university students it seemed an appropriate subject for a satire, but the Government did not agree.

title: Equity Financing
description: An initial public offering of 1,200,000 cumulative preference shares, at $20 a share plus accrued dividends if any, at 2,900,000 common shares, at $15 a share, SG Securities Inc. was made yesterday by under writers managed by Shearson Hammill. The offering the new closedend diversified investment company, advised by the SonneblichGoldman Management Corporations, consists of a firm underwriting of 640, 000 cumulative preference shares and 1,280,000 common shares and best efforts offering of 560,000 cumulative preference shares and 1,120,000 common shares.

title: Brush Fire Reward Offered
description: BANNING, Calif., June 22 (UPI)The state offered a $500 reward yesterday for the arson ist who set the first major brush fire of the year. Firemen said early today they were win ning the battle against the blaze, which burned through 7,200 acres.

title: ExMissionary Dies at 100
description: LYONS, Colo., June 22 (AP) Edith B. Manford of Estes Park, a former missionary to Thailand, has died here at the age of 100.

title: Not a Bridge but...
description: Governor Rockefeller's explanation of why he abandoning the RyeOyster Bay bridge, which for years he so emphatically championed, elevates his decision from a forced surrender to an act of statesmanship. It is true that both the House of Representatives and the Depart ment of the Interior had raised probably insuperable barriers to the building of this bridge across Long Island Sound which environmentalists have vigorously and rightly opposed. Nevertheless, the Governor deserves credit for turning what must be a reversal for himself into a ringing defense of the environmental viewpoint.

title: Southland Corp., Will Close 31 Barricini, Loft's Units
description: The Southland Corporation, Dallas, announced yesterday, that it planned to close 31 of its Barricini and Loft's candy shops in 11 states. The com pany said that the Baskin Bobbins Ice Cream Company, Durbank, Calif., would negoti ate new leases for these shops and open new ice cream stores them this year and next.

title: Cartons of Coupons Waiting For a Chance at Redemption
description: The Green Giant Company recently made a premium offer. For eight labels from any of its canned vegetables, or for six of its frozen package fronts, con sumers could send for a free polyethyl ene Ho, ho, ho kite (retail value 75 cents).

title: Employment Picture Brightens In Nassau and Suffolk Counties
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I., June 22 The employment picture is getting better in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and is expect ed to improve even further as work starts on defense con tracts, according to Louis L. Levine, the State Industrial Commissioner.

title: Firestone Reaches 3Year Agreement To End Brief Strike
description: CLEVELAND, June 22 (AP) Tentative agreement was reached early today on a new contract between the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and the striking United Rubber Workers.

title: Yablonski Case Motion Filed
description: PITTSBURGH, June 22 (AP) The United States Attorney's, office filed a motion in Dis trict Court here yesterday to drop a Federal conspiracy charge against Albert Pass, who was convicted earlier this week on state murder charges in the slayings of Joseph A. Yablon ski, the mine union reform leader, and his wife and daugh ter.

title: C.B.S. TV to Study Charges of Payola At Disk Subsidiary
description: The television news depart ment of the Columbia Broad casting System has assigned a special reporting team to in vestigate allegations of wide spread payoffs and other mis conduct by executives of a C.B.S. subsidiary, Columbia Records.

title: 23 ARE CHARGED IN SHRIMP THEFT
description: Twentythree men, including a reputed underworld figure who operated a trucking and freezerstorage concern, were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of stealing more than $100,000 worth of frozen sea food, mostly shrimp, from the New York waterfront.

title: Books of The Times
description: While conscientiously studying the text of this conscientiously objective book, always taking care to avoid dislodging the chip on my shoulder, I had the pleasantest kind of feeling that Thomas M. Messer somewhere along the line of his researches had joined me as a member of the very small club where Edvard Munch is thought of as a secondrate painter. Disparagements of the work of few other widely admired artists, living or dead, can be counted on to bring quite so hefty a packet of hate mail and so little applause as a bad word or two for the Master of Oslo. But never mind. I've already been through all that as a result of a few reservations concerning the genius of the Genius of the North expressed at the time of the 1965 Munch exhibition arranged by Mr. Messer at the Guggenheim Museum, where he is director.

title: Haiphong Harbor Is Declared Saf e For Ships by U. S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) The Navy today declared the main channel of Haiphong har bor, the principal port of North Vietnam, to be open and safe for shipping.

title: Agenda for Europe Talks Approved by 33 Nations
description: BONN, June 22Thirtythree nations from the Soviet and Western blocs have agreed on a detailed agenda for the forth coming European security con ference including such pro posals as an exchange of mili tary observers between the At lantic alliance and the Warsaw Pact and advance notice of major military movements.

title: SOVIET INCREASING OUTPUT OF FODDER
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. June 22  At a time of soar ing prices for cattle fodder, the Soviet Union is stepping up its production of a single cell protein grown from petroleum to he used as feed for live stock and poultry.

title: $3Million Suit for Slander Filed Against Billy Graham
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., June 22 (AP)Madalyn Murray O'Hair, a champion of atheist causes, has filed a $3million slander suit in Federal court here against the Rev. Billy Graham.

title: MRS. CROCKER'S 67 LEADS BY A STROKE
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., June 22 (UPI)Mary Lou Crocker of Louisville, Ky., who has not won a Ladies Professional Golf Association tourmi I in'. shot a sixunderpar 67 today to take the firstround lead in the $30, 000 Heritage Village open.

title: Decisions Protested by Nation's Media
description: The Association of American Publishers, which represents more than 250 bookpublishing concerns, said yesterday that it would fight the effects of Thursday's Supreme Court ob scenity decisions, and it took the first steps toward forming an alliance with librarians, booksellers, magazine publish ers and moviemakers.

title: Rain Cuts Short U.S Jet Raids On Rebel Positions in Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 22 (UPI)American F111 fighter bombers struck at Communist positions along roads north and south of Phnom Penh early today, but low clouds and rain cut short the raids during the afternoon.

title: Power Agency to Yield Secret Data
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 The Federal Power Commission agreed under compulsion and under protest today to turn over to a Congressional committee confidential reports on the known natural gas re serves owned by the 79 biggest gas producers.

title: YANKEES, SUBWAY AND CITY TRAFFIC TURN BACK TIGERS
description: New York was no summer festival to the Detroit Tigers last night.

title: Moyers's. Journal And 2 Other Shows Kept on Public TV
description: The Ford Foundation has made it possible for Bill Moyers's Journal, Behind the Lines and Washington Week in Review to return to public television next season.

title: Workmen's Compensation Held To Need Shift to State Courts
description: TRENTON, June 22 (UPI)The State Commission of In vestigation, citing abuses, im proprieties, unethical conduct and obvious fraud, recom mended today that control of the Workmen's Compensation Court be taken away from the Division of Workmen's Com pensation. and be given to the Administrative Director of the State Courts.

title: 3 Networks to Telecast Dean at Senate Inquiry
description: The three television net worksthe Columbia Broad casting System, National Broadcasting Company and American Broadcasting Com panywill all provide live coverage Monday of the ap pearance of John W. Dean 3d, the former White House counsel, before the Senate Watergate committee, the networks said yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: CALIFORNIAPlaced Ron Perranoski, left handed pitcher, on 21day disabled list with sore left shoulder. Recalled Andy Hassler, lefthanded pitcher, from Salt Lake City of the Pacific Coast League.

title: MARILYN PUBLISHER WILL RELEASE BOOK
description: Undeterred by charges of plagiarism, Norman Mailer and his British and American pub: lishers went ahead yesterday with plans to release Marilyn, a biography of the late film star Marilyn Monroe written by the Pulitzer Prize winning author.

title: Excerpts From Remarks by Brezhnev
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 Following are excerpts from Leonid I. Brezhnev's talk to day to a group of American business leaders, as tran scribed by the Treasury De partment:

title: Man Drowns Saving Wife
description: WESTWEGO, La., June 22 (UPI)  Lawrence Parks, 44 years old, jumped into the Mis sissippi River yesterday to save his wife, Verinta, 30, who had fallen in. Mr. Parks pushed her to the shore, saving her life, but he was caught in an under tow and drowned. His body was recovered an hour later.

title: STRESS ON TRUST
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev signed an agreement today to try to avert military confrontations that could lead the United States and the So viet Union into a nuclear war either with each other or with any other country.

title: Duke Power Plans Appeal
description: The Duke Power Company, Charlotte, N. C., announced yesterday that it intended to appeal in court the rate order of the North Carolina Utilities Commission, issued Thursday, and to apply immediately for a stay of the order pending con clusion of the appeal. This or der granted the utility only 72 per cent of the rate increase that had been put into effect, subject to refund on Jan. 1, 1973.

title: Judge Denies Plea for Trees
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 22 (UPI)A Federal judge de nied yesterday a request by group of Lansing residents for a permanent injunction to keep the State Highway Department from cutting down 28 stately elm trees. District Court Judge Albert J. Engel also vacated a temporary order he issued last Wednesday prohibiting the de partment from chopping down the trees as part of a $400,000 road widening project to ease traffic congestion at an Inter section.

title: Proposal to Enlarge Grand Canyon National Park Is Criticized at Senate Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, June 22A bill to enlarge the Grand Can yon National Park in Arizona to protect the outstanding scenic, natural and scientific values of the Grand Canyon has run into opposition at Senate hearing.

title: Soggy MusicLovers Pay Tribute to Casals in the Park
description: Mayor Lindsay and a thou sand or so musiclovers paid a fond tribute to Pablo Casals yesterday on his special appearance at a free concert in Central Park.

title: Rain and Fog Mar Hudson Cruise for Handicapped
description: Rain and fog marred out door fun for nearly 1,500 dis abled people yesterday on the 44th annual Hudson River Cruise.

title: 8 Democrats in House Bid Harlow Put Stock in Trust
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) Eight House Democrats de manded today that Bryce N. Harlow be dismissed as Presi dent Nixon's aide for Congres sional liaison if he does not transfer his stock holdings to a trust.

title: Bridge: Worries in Duplicate Play Top Cares in Team Games
description: Unreliable statistics suggest that duplicate players have more gray hairs than the devotees of rubber bridge or headtohead team play. They certainly have much more to worry about, for small profits and losses are highly signifi cant.

title: West Germans Dominate Downstream Canoe Events
description: MUOTATHAL, Switzerland, June 22 (AP)West German crews took all five events of the torrent downstream contest of the World Canoe championships today.

title: Nixon to Meet. French Aide To Discuss Atlantic Alliance
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 22 (Reuters)The French For eign Minister, Michel Jobert, will meet President Nixon here next Friday to discuss trans Atlantic relations and a new declaration of principles pro posed by the United States, the western White House an nounced tonight.

title: Badillo Modifies Earlier Stand On Backing Beame if He Loses
description: Representative Herman Ba dillo declared yesterday that he might support Controller Abraham D. Beame for Mayor if Mr. Beame won the Demo cratic primary runoff next Tuesday, but that his decision would depend on the total record.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: BUFFALOSigned Mike Macaluso, Canisius forward, sixthround draft choice.

title: Sutton Throws His Hat Into 77 Mayoral Ring
description: Manhattan Borough Pres ident Percy Sutton said last night that he would run for Mayor in the 1977 election and that he thought his can didacy would have wide support.

title: Seoul, Shifting Policy on U.N. Entry, Won't Oppose Admission With North
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Satur day, June 23President Park Chung Hee, in a drastic shift in South Korea's diplomatic policy, declared today that Seoul would not oppose the entry of both North and South Korea into the United Nations.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York Stock Ex :change has issued a report on recent trading in shares by leading stockholders, directors and officers of the listed com panies.

title: Railways in 3 National Regions To Ask FreightRate Increases
description: The Eastern railroads plan to file new tariffs next week with the Interstate Commerce Commission under which they seek to make a 3 per cent gen eral freightrate increase effec tive Aug. 13, on all shipments within the socalled Eastern territoryall states east of the Mississippi and north of the Potomac rivers.

title: Newport JazzFestival NewYork
Mrs. Cooperstein Wins in Golf
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., June 22Mrs. Walter (Judy) Coop erstein of Glen Oaks, battling a severe afternoon storm and the determined play of the defend ing champion, Mrs. Austin (Gwen) Straub of Rolling Hills, won the 70th Women's Metro politan Golf Association title to day over the rainsoaked Essex County Country Club course.

title: Stage: Brass Butterfly
description: NIAGARAONTHELAKE, Ontario, June 22  This year the 12th Shaw Festival held in the pleasant Canadi an town of Niagaraonthe Lake has a special bonus the opening of the festival's new and very delightful 830 seat Festival Theater. The problem last night was how to follow the previous night's very successful opening of Shaw's You Never Can Tell. For the second play of the season, Paxton White head, the artistic director, decided to move away from Shaw, but not too far away.

title: U.S. Court Denies Delay In Standards for Mattresses
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)  The United States District Court of Appeals denied today a request to delay implementa tion of new fireproofing stand ards for mattresses.

title: BERNARD BERGEN
description: Bernard Bergen, president and chairman of the board of the Bernard Bergen Companies, Inc., general agents for the Madison Life Insurance Com pany, died Wednesday at University Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 70 East 10th Street. Mr. Bergen was one of the founders of the Madison Life Insurance Com pany in 1963.

title: Pope Assails Church Discipline While Stressing a World Role
description: ROME, June 22Pope Paul VI told the College of Cardinals today that he deplored doc trinal confusion and indisci pline in the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in rela tion to the price of meals and the quality of compara ble establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: AMEX STOCKS DIP IN HEAVY TRADING
description: In the heaviest trading In a week, prices on the American Stock Exchange failed to main tain early gains and closed nar rowly lower in accelerated trading yesterday. However, in the overthecounter market, where trading also was com paratively heavy, prices showed an increase.

title: STRESS ON TRUST; Both Promise to Avoid Provocations That Could Bring War
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 President Nixon and Leonid I: Brezhnev signed an agreement today to try to avert military confrontations that could lead the United States and the So viet Union into a nuclear war either with each other or with any other country.

title: People in Sports: Parent Returns to N.H.L.
description: Bernie Parent, the 28yearold goalie who was the first National Hockey League player to jump to the World Hockey Association, hopped back to the older league yes terday. He signed a multiyear contract with the Phil adelphia Flyers, for whom he played from 1967 to 1971.

title: Philadelphia'sHead Of Police Is Cited For Civil Contempt
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP)  Police Commissioner Joseph O'Neill was cited for civil contempt today for in terfering with demonstrations when President Nixon signed the Revenue Sharing Act here last October.

title: Mets Win, 54, to Stop Slide
description: PITTSBURGH, June 22One big scoring outburst in the sec ond inning that produced all their runs plus a rare route going pitching effort by George Stone enabled the New York Mets to end tonight their los ing streak at four games.

title: Dance: Anthony Company
description: One good reason for at tending the current brief sea son of the Mary Anthony Dance Theater, which runs through Sunday afternoon at the theater of the Riverside Church, is that two of its members, Yuriko Kimura and Ross Parkes, are among the most outstanding performers in modern dance today.

title: 6 U.S. Jews in Soviet Say They Are Held at Airport
description: MOSCOW, June 22 (UPI)Six young American Jews said today that they had begun hunger strike at a Moscow air port hOtel, where they said authorities were illegally de taining them.

title: Brother Held in Apparent Mercy Killing
description: NEPTUNE, N. J., June 22A young man was charged today with slaying his older brother, who had reportedly begged to be killed after being paralyzed in an accident.

title: OFFICER'S BULLET WASN'T FATAL ONE
description: Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley said yesterday that the bullet that killed the bar tender in a shootout in a Har lem tavern last Sunday was not fired by a policeman, but came from the revolver carried by Boyce Russell.

title: Academic Tenure Is Ended at Bloomfield
description: BLOOMFIELD, June 22The trustees f Bloomfield College last night voted to abolish aca demic tenure and put all faculty members on contracts subject! to periodic renewal.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:
SEMKIW WINS TITLE IN JUNIOR SHOTPUT
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., June 22 Ron Semkiw won the shot put this evening at the Amateur Athletic Union national junior track and field championships and became the first qualifier for a team which will compete in Europe next month. The Arizona State freshman put the ball 64 feet 1 inches, and won by more than 5 feet.

title: Agenda for Europe Talks Approved by 33 Nations
description: BONN, June 22Thirtythree nations from the Soviet and Western blocs have agreed on a detailed agenda for the forth coming European security con ference including such pro posals as an exchange of mili tary observers between the At lantic alliance and the Warsaw Pact and advance notice of major military movements.

title: HOUSE APPROVES $19B1111011 BILL
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 The House approved tonight $19billion appropriations bill that includes funds for urban renewal and Model Cities pro grams that the Nixon Admin istration had not sought.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: A former Fort Lee tax collector who admitted not paying his own taxes was sentenced in Newark to threeyear prison termthe maximum sentencesubject to modification within three months for health reasons.

title: Antipollution Charade: Drastic Proposals by the E.P.A.
description: The nation's campaign against air pollution has seemingly taken on some aspects of soap opera, with dire and sometimes implausible exigencies material izing almost by the day.

title: East Of the Ostpolitik
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland  The cold war in Germany officially ended June 21one day after all exchange of notes between Bonn and East Berlin acknowledging that both capitals of Europe's largest partitioned state have ratified an accord recognizing each other's existence. Those countries which have not yet recognized the East German Democratic Republic are expected swiftly to do so.

title: AntiAllende Ad Brings Shutdown of a Chilean Paper
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 22 (UPI)  An opposition news paper failed to appear today by Court order after the Govern ment had accussed it of in citing subversion by publish ing an advertisement directed against President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: CRANGLE DENIES IMPROPER FILING
description: The state Democratic chair man, Joseph F. Crangle, and Attorney General Louis J. Lef kowitz disagreed yesterday over whether the State Democratic Committee had filed adequate statements of campaign expen ditures for last year's elections.

title: FLORENCE EHRHART
description: Mrs. Florence Hodgson Ehr hart, daughter of the late Ed win Allan Hodgson, a pioneer in education for the deaf, died Tuesday in Oklahoma City, where she was visiting rela tives. She was 81 years old and lived at 310 Riverside Drive.

title: Mayer and Ramirez Advance To Final of N.C. A. A. Tennis
description: PRINCETON, N.J., June 22 (AP)Top seeded Alex Mayer of Stanford overcame Bob Kreiss of the University of Cali fornia, Los Angeles, 46 76, 63, today in the singles semifinals of the National Collegiate Ath letic Association tennis tourna ment at Princeton University.

title: U.S. Cancels a Flight to Hanoi; Communists Won't Sign Forms
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 22 (Reuters)  The weekly American flight carry ing Communist officials be tween Saigon and Hanoi was canceled today because North Vietnamese passengers re portedly refused to sign a form saying that they were not car rying explosives.

title: Miss Blalock's Suspension Ruled Antitrust Violation
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., June 22 (AP)It's a great load off my mind, Jane Blalock said today about the Federal District Court ruling in Atlanta that her sus pension by the Ladies Profes sional Golf Association violated antitrust laws.

title: Newport JazzFestiva Newyork
description: Putting together this kind of festival, George Wein said, is a kind of, well, mystical process.

title: Merrill Lynch Is Charged With Fraud by the S. E. C.

title: Antiques: Duck Decoys
description: BELLPORT, L. I.  Fifty years ago s this summer, a concern for duck conserva tion among sportsmen here sparked what many collec tors regard as the first seri ous decoy collecting on this continent.

title: Bloomfield College Panel Ends Academic Tenure
description: BLOOMFIELD, N. J., une 22 The trustees of Bloomfield College last night voted to abolish academic tenure and put all faculty members on contracts subject to perio dic renewal.

title: AIDE SAID TO URGE NIXON TO OUST 2
description: WASHINGTON, June 22Assistant Attorney General Henry E. Petersen urged Pres ident Nixon on April 15 to suspend John D. Ehrlichman and H. R. Haldeman immedi ately because of their involve ment in the Watergate scan dal, sources close to the case said today.

title: CRITICISM VOICED ON JETPORT PLAN
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 22A consultant's blueprint for transforming Stewart Airport into a $1billion super jetport came under fire today for as sertedly failing to consider the project's potential impact on the broad midHudson region, its people and public services.

description: Mrs. Theodora Bersbach Haggin, a freelance editor and photographer, was married here yesterday afternoon to Samuel Dodson Crawford of Tuxedo, N. Y., a partner in Newburger Loeb & Co., New York stockbrokers. The cere mony was performed in the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. by the Rev. Norman Stanton.

title: PEROT'S CONCERN GIVEN STATE JOB
description: ALBANY, June 22With a push from Governor Rockefel ler, the State Social Services Department awarded a consult ant contract today to a con cern controlled by H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer mil lionaire, for preliminary work in the state takeover of welfare and Medicaid adminis tration.

title: Business Protocol Texts
description: WASHINGTON, June 22Following are the texts of protocols that were signed here today on a projected AmericanSoviet chamber of commerce and on the alloca tion of office space for trade missions:

title: The Goldman Band Gets Breezy Start For Park Concerts
description: The weather gods chose to smile for the opening of the 56th Guggenheim Memorial Concerts season on Wednesday night in Damrosch Park. The temperature hovered in the mid70's, the sky remained clear, and light, pleasant breezes cooled the audience.

title: Century's Envoy Captures Sprint at Hollywood Park
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 22 (UPI))Century's Envoy solidi fied his claim as the West's top 2yearold with a 1length victory over laterushing Money Lender in the $33,350 Haggin Stakes at Hollywood Park to day. Century's Envoy, owned by J. J. Elmore, President Nix on's San Clemente neighbor, raced the 5 furlongs in 1:03 3/5 and returned $3.60, $2.60 and $2.40.

title: RAIN AND TICKETS PLAGUE DRIVERS
description: Heavy rains, which rendered many major streets and high ways impassable at times, com bined with the second day of the midtown parking crack down, made the city miserable for motorists yesterday.

title: Kresge May Be Compelled To Open Fewer KMarts
description: The S.S. Kresge Company, operator of the Kmart discount stores, may be compelled to open fewer than 100 KMarts this year because of wet weather throughout much of the nation, Robert Dewar, chair man of Kresge, told the com pany's annual meeting yester day in Troy, Mich.

title: Lomenzo Is Cleared by Inquiry On Role in Award to Contractor
description: Governor Rockefeller's office issued a brief statement last evening clearing Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo of any wrongdoing in his alleged in tervention in a Dormitory Au thority contract award.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The official New York City bicentennial symbol was introduced yesterday at a poster presentation ceremony at City Hall Plaza. Derived from the Betsy Ross flag adopted by Congress on July 14, 1777, the symbol features the flag's stripes designed as the figure 76 in honor of the Declaration of Independence, and a circle of 13 stars within a sphere of six. Framing the upper left corner are the words The New York City Bicentennial.

title: Naval Academy Fights Suit On Degree for ExStudent
description: BALTIMORE, Md., June 22Federal Judge Frank A. Kauf man Is expected to rule early next week on a motion to dis miss the complaint of a former student at the Naval Academy that he was unjustly denied a degree because he had applied for conscientiousobjector sta tus.

title: Legacy of Peronism
description: It was not surprising that factions among the motley assortment of Argentines who claim to support Juan Pern were unable to wait even until the plane carrying the returning strongman had landed before they started to shoot each other. If the affair had not turned quickly into major tragedyat least twenty killed, more than 400 woundedMr. Peren's return would have been pure opera buffa.

title: Energy Czar Choice
description: Administration and oil in dustry officials report that Gov. John A. Love of Colo rado, a Republican, is Presi dent Nixon's choice to head the proposed Department of Energy and Natural Re sources. Page 11.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: SUMMIT, N. J., June 22Almost without notice, and certainly without any open campaign by the women's lib movement, Summit High School broke tradition this spring by having 23yearold Laura Menza coach the boys tennis team.

title: Screen: Simplicity Marks Soviet Films in Festival:Five Premieres Held at Little Carnegie Collective-Farm Tale Is Among Features
description: A brief festival of new Russian moviesfive feature-film premieres, a kids' film and a revival of Andrei Smirnov's "Byelorussian Station"played last week at the Little Carnegie Theater in a program meant to tie in with Leonid I. Brezhnev's visit to the United States. The films are scheduled for further showings in this country, possibly for commercial distribution. Two have been dubbed into English; the rest, mercifully, are subtitled.They are presented as representing a cross section of recent Soviet film making. I suspect they do represent certain aspects of popularly accepable Russian film making, and for people whose idea of the Soviet cinema has been formed by "Potemkin," "Alexander Nevsky," "The Lady With the Little Dog" or even "Ballad of a Soldier," the new movies may come as a discouraging surprise.Consider the story of Aleksei Sakharov's "In His Right Place": Semyon, a young engineer, gets himself elected chairman of his collective farm. He believes in much work and no wasted time. He does not believe in smoking, drinking or miniskirtsand neither does the film. He proposes many changes with a view to modernizing the collective. At first the older people oppose him, but eventually they see the light, and the young chairman succeeds.Or consider the story of Oleg Bondaryev's "The Stepmother": When Pavel, who maintains and operates machinery on a collective farm, learns that a woman he was once in love with has diedleaving behind a little girl who is, in fact, his daughterhis good wife, Shura, agrees to take the child in and to become her stepmother. At first the child is mistrustful and withdrawn; but eventually Shura's goodness and maternal warmth win her over, and the stepmother succeeds.I've left out a lot. The films are full (but not too full) of humanizing and individualizing details. Some of the performancessuch as Tatyana Doronina's as the plump, good-natured, perpetually flustered, slightly dimwitted stepmotherare very expert. But despite the details and the performances, these are films of an almost numbing simplicity. They are exactly the "realism" that might do for edification in some ideally placated society. And compared with other East European cinemascompared with what we have seen over the last few years, say, from Yugoslavia, from Hungary, even from Bulgariathey are film making at a kindergarten level of cultural awareness and dramatic sophistication.Two of the Russian movies are escapist entertainment. Vladimir Motyl's "White Sun of the Desert" is a picaresque adventure, involving the heroic exploits of a Red Army soldier in the insufficiently socialized wilds of Turkestan. Leonid Gaidai's "Ivan Vassilyevich Changes His Profession" suggests what might happen if, by means of a time machine, Ivan the Terrible were suddenly to find himself in 20th-century Moscow, while two 20th-century Muscovites were, taking Ivan's place in medieval Russia.With the kind of madcap comedy idea that withers the imagination even before it hits the screen, "Ivan Vassilyevich" is of interest mainly for its director's unflagging devotion to the assumption that rapid-motion photography is always funny, for the graffiti that show up on Moscow apartment-building walls (extensive, but still preaerosol-spray-can) and for the intimations of luxury in middle-class urban life. Convertibles, cameras, tape recorders, black-market transistorsthe film is a small-scale homage to conspicuous consumption.The best of the films also ostensibly the most officiala long semidocumentary called "The Taming of Fire." Written and directed by Edward Smirnov and Miss Doronina (the stepmother is also a scenarist), it concerns a pioneering space scientist who suffers a heart attack and then, hovering between life and death, immediately has a 2-hour-and-20-minute flashback covering the entire history of Soviet rocket development from the beginnings to the present.There are interesting sidelights, such as the shooting down of Francis Gary Powers's U-2 spy plane in 1960, or the exploding of a Soviet nuclear bomb (justified on the grounds, more or less, that the Americans already have it, and the only language those people understand is force). But the movie really comes alive with its rocketry and with its exotic and marvelously theatricaland, I assume, authenticspace hardware.Unfortunately the dialogue is English-dubbed, and, through the universal alchemy of dubbing studios, it has been transformed into 50 per cent non sequiturs. But from what I can make out, "The Taming of Fire" is not wholly enamored of state science or hard work or success.
