description: FALLSBURG, N. Y., June 25 Leader of the largest Ortho dox rabbinic body in the coun try today criticized duplica tion, rivalry and wasteful frag mentation in the institutions and programs of American Orth odox Judaism.

title: Advertising: Trade Magazines
description: Robert L. Edgell, who worked his way through col lege with a magic act and still has a few tricks up his sleeve, seems like a real life oftheparty type  a hail fellow well met. He goes for funny props and posters.

title: SHOW ON WATERGATE BLOCKED BY U.S.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (Reu ters)The United States Infor mation Agency today denied the British Broadcasting Company the use of its facilities for tele vision transmission tomorrow of a program on Watergate on grounds that such a program was not in the best interests of the United States.

title: Dutch Cruise Liner Veendam Greeted Here a 2d Time
description: The port rolled out the welcome mat yesterday for a luxury liner for the second time in her career. She was the 23,372ton cruise liner Veendam of Holland America cruises.

title: Rise in Ceiling Prices Weighed To Avert Shortage of Chickens
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Raising the ceiling price on such products as chickens and eggs is one possible course of action if serious shortages develop, members of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers said today.

title: Newport Jazz, on Radio
description: Radio station WRVR will broadcast more than 20 hours of Newport Jazz Festival New York concerts from Saturday to Thursday, July 12. The con certs,, each lasting about two hours, will be heard nightly except Sundays. The starting time for Saturday concerts on WRVR will be 7 P.M., for Wednesday concerts 8:30 P.M., and for all other nights, 8 o'clock. The FM station is at 106.7 on the dial.

title: Profit Gains Outlined In Building Products
description: The profits of buildings products and materials con cerns rose 64 per cent and sales increased 27 per cent during the first quarter of 1973, compared with a year ago, according to the F. W. Dodge Division of the McGrawHill Company.

title: Buckley Wants Record Industry Investigated by 4 U.S. Agencies
description: Senator James J. Buckley, the New York Conservative Republican, called yesterday for a fourpart Federal investiga tion into charges of drug use and payola in the recording industry.

title: Dean's Wife Gives Him Some Tea and Advice
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)As John W. Dean 3d testified at the Senate's Watergate hearing today, his wife, Maureen, whom he married eight months ago, sat behind him.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 25Larry Ellis, coach of track and crosscountry at Princeton University, and the Ivy League's first black head coach when he was appointed in 1970, has been named head coach of the United States track team in the second annual Pacific Conference games in Toronto on Wednesday and Thursday. The PanPacific competition involves teams from countries whose borders touch on the Pacific Ocean, and includes Australia, Canada, Japan, and Mexico and the United States.

title: U. S. AUTO SALES RISE TO A RECORD
description: DETROIT, June 25U.S. car sales in the June 1120 period totaled 311,044 units, a record for the period and reversing a decline in the previous two selling periods.

title: North Korean Rebuff to Seoul Seems to Leave the Door Ajar
description: TOKYO, June 25  North Korea appears to have rebuffed without completely rejecting a South Korean proposal that both Governments apply for United Nations membership at the same time.

title: Senate Votes to Double Funds for Ervin Panel
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)As John W. Dean 3d testified before the Senate Watergate committee today, the Senate by voice vote dou bled to $1million the money it had authorized for com mittee expenses.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended June 19.

title: BRITISH AIDES END RHODESIA MISSION
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 25 (Agence FrancePresse)A team of top British officials left Salisbury today at the end of a surprise mission to deter mine the Rhodesian Govern ment's attitude toward a set tlement of the independence dispute with. Britain.

title: Desegregation Upheld
description: The Supreme Court has taken an important step assuring the nation's racial minorities that the protec tion of their children from the evils of school desegrega tion applies throughout the United States, and not just in the South. The 7to1 ruling in a case involving the Denver schools holds that when a district has been guilty of a deliberate policy of racial discrimination, the burden is on the public education authorities to show why they should not repair the resulting harm by desegregating all the schools.

title: Strike Ends at Two Guys
description: The 19day strike of employes of Two Guys Department Stores in six states has been settled and the strikers have returned to work, officials of the Retail Clerks International Associa tion said yesterday. The com pany said that a new threeyear contract would provide in creases between 45 and 50 cents an hour. Employes earned $2.55 an hour under the old contract.

title: ExCounsel, Cool and Dogged, Reads 6Hour Story to the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, June 25John W. Dean 3d had his turn today.

title: Dean Hearing Highlights
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Following are highlights of John W. Dean 3d's testimony today before the Senate Watergate committee:

title: TrafficTicket Drive in Midtown To Cover Moving Vehicles Next
description: The steppedup campaign against illegal parking con tinued in midtown yesterday, with city officials promising to extend the crackdown to mov ing vehicles and to some vehi cles with special permits.

title: YOUTH IS ACCUSED OF DROWNING BOY, 3
description: A 14yearold youth was charged yesterday with drown ing a 3yearold boy in the Breukelen Houses in the Caner sie section of Brooklyn.

title: Few Mercy Killers Draw Full Penalties
description: Robert Waskin's mother was in a Chicago hospital dying of leukemia. One day in 1967, just before he was to graduate from college, he went to her room and fired three shots: He made no attempt to hide his action, saying: She's out of her misery now. I shot her.

title: Gus Hall Confirms He Met Brezhnev In Embassy Friday
description: Gus Hall, general secretary of the Communist party, U.S.A., yesterday confirmed reports in Moscow newspapers that he met with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, in Washington last week.

title: PlanonStateTax Reform Is Drafted by Democrats
description: TRENTON, June 25  Bren dan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for Governor, pledged himself and his party today to a tax reform program that almost certainly would include a state income tax to resolve the constitutional crisis sur rounding the financing of public schools in New Jersey.

title: 2 More Die at Golden Gate
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 (UPI)The Golden Gate Bridge has claimed its 482d death leaper since it opened in 1937. The latest victim was Ellen S. Schiff, 28 years old of Oakland. She went over the railing Satur day night just minutes after Jeannette Duro, 37, of Sausali to, Calif., plunged to her death.

title: Sandra Post's 72 Takes Old Westbury Golf Event
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 25Sandra Post of Oakville, Ontario, won $850 today in the sixth annual woman promem ber invitation event with a par 72 at the Old Westbury Golf and Country Club, She won by two strokes over Clifford Ann Creed, Sue Roberts and Sherry Wilder.

title: Roundup: Pirates Beat Expos, 86, 31
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, who had skidded to the bottom of the National League's Eastern Division standing, blasted four Montreal pitch ers for 11 hits that produced an 86 victory in Montreal's Jarry Park last night.

title: Dean Hearing Highlights
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Following are highlights of John W. Dean 3d's testimony today before the Senate Watergate committee:

title: Shorter Vacations Sought For School Supervisors
description: The Board of Education has proposed cutting in half the traditional summerlong vaca tion of principals and other school supervisors.

title: U.S. Swimmers Make Splash in Tour of China
description: Ten American swimmers and divers, who learned to use chopsticks and narrowly avoided an international in cident, have returned after a threeweek tour of China.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Hatch Act, 6.3; Says Curbs on Political Activity Are Fair
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Supreme Court upheld to day Federal and state bans on partisan political activity by government employes after its first reexamination of the poli cy in 26 years, The vote was 6 to 3.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: Inglewood, Calif.Ruben Oli vares, 125 pounds, Mexico, knocked out Bobby Charon, 126, San Fernando, Calif., 9 rounds.

title: SANFORD SECURITIES PENALIZED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission today revoked the brokerdealer registration of Sanford Securities, Inc., New York, on charges the firm con ducted business while insolvent without disclosing this to the public.

title: J. L LOEB JR. ACTS ON ENVIRONMENT
description: John L. Loeb Jr., a general partner and member of the management committee of Loeb Rhoades & Co., will become limited partner in the invest ment firm at the end of this week so that he can devote more time to public affairs, especially environmental mat ters, he said yesterday.

title: HONG KONG PAPER ASSAILS ARMS PACT
description: HONG KONG, June 25The press in China has made no mention so far of the United States visit of Leonid I. Brezh nev, the Soviet Communist par ty leader, but comment over the weekend in Chinese Com munist newspapers here in Hong Kong has been critical.

title: Nixon Personality. Tied To Mood of White House
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Other former insiders have vaguely spoken of an almost paranoid mood in the Nixon White House and a fightfire withfire reaction that under cut respect for law.

title: Two LifeStylesParents Fled to Suburbia
description: CRANFORD, N. J.  Donald Ellenberg sipped a diet soda in the recreation room of his sevenroom splitlevel house. The street outside, with its panoply of neat lawns, was almost as quiet as the noiseless aircondi tioning.

title: Gas Explosions in Madrid
description: MADRID, June 25, (Reuters)  A series of explosion ripped through a main square in northern Madrid late tonight and several people were be lieved injured, the police said. They said the blasts, on the edge of the Plaza de la Repub lica Argentina, were caused by igniting gas in underground pipes.

title: Libel Suit Thrown Out in Monkey Case
description: A scientist's $2million libel suit against an animalwelfare organization that criticized a monkey's space flight was dis missed yesterday by Judge Ed ward Weinfeld in Federal Court here.

title: Mother of 10 Is Arrested On ReliefFraud Charge
description: ALBANY, June 25 (AP) A 37yearold mother of 10 is be ing held in what officials say may be the largest single case of welfare fraud yet uncovered in the state.

title: BREZHNEV LEAVES U. S. FOR FRANCE
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Leonid I. Brezhnev's visit to the United States ended today with a joint communique extolling his talks with President Nixon as a further milestone to ward a major improvement in relations but indicating that, in such areas as the Middle East, differences remained.

title: SOVIET GIVEN FUND FOR CITIZENS VISITS
description: The Soviet Embassy has been presented with 200 fieldstudy grants by the Citizens Exchange Corps, an American nonprofit organization, it was announced, yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Seeks to Enjoin L.&M. and Official
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Securities and Exchange Com mission asked a Manhattan Fed oral Distrlct Court today to en join Liggett & Myers, Inc., and an official of the company from further violation of insidertrad ing provisions of the Federal securities laws.

title: An Embarrassment
description: It was not bad taste so much as bad judgment, compounded by grief, that finally did in the pornographers. Pornography is always in bad taste, but then so are a great many other things dear to the American heart. Las Vegas, the indigenous American funeral, doubleknit suits, the road side hamburger culture, the U.S. Air Forceall are monuments of bad taste, yet we love some and endure others.

title: GEM, ROBIN LEAD BLOCK IS. SAILING
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., June 25  William Ziegler 3d's 44 foot sloop, Gem, out of Noroton, Conn., and Ted Hood's 36foot sloop, Robin from Marblehead, Mass., were the outstanding boats in to day's lightair race, which opened Block Island Week.

title: Market Basket Resumes Increase Despite Freeze
description: Despite President Nixon's price freeze, food prices here resumed their upward climb last week.

title: Fire Near Badillo Office
description: A rubbish fire set off by a molotov cocktail last night slightly damaged the roof of a building net to a Brooklyn storefront campaign office of Representative Herman Badillo, the police said. The fire, at 404 Seventh Avenue in the Park Slope section is under investi gation.

title: School Budget Is Defeated Second Time in Bellmore,L.I.
description: BELLMORE, L. I., June 25Voters defeated the school budget for the second time to day, rejecting by a vote of 593 to 436 a proposed expenditure of $3,626,249.

title: Books of The Times
description: Drug addicts telling you about their habits remind me of old women talking about their operationsonly in my experi ence the old women are better raconteurs. They start at the beginning and take you through to the end, no political or philo sophical digressions. Their diction is a matter of care and pride, but it is not pretentious, and they are strong on details. Addicts, though, tend to overlook the human interest, the why and wherefore. When they're not philosophical, they're pharmaceutical. They explain what we're not interested in hearing and slide right over the heart of the matter. They always start their accounts in media res, taking all the springs of action for granted. scored for this, swallowed that, injected something else. That's no way to grab your audience.

title: Graham Backs Court Ruling
description: ATLANTA, June 25 (AP)The Rev. Billy Graham said to day at a news conference that while he had not read the Su preme Court's ruling against pornography, he would be glad if it stopped people from profiting from it.

title: Amnesty on Vietnam War Urged by Jewish Congress
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) Unconditional amnesty for all who refused to participate in the Vietnam war has been called for by the American Jewish Congress.

title: CITY GIVES A FAIR FOR U.N.DIPLOMATS
description: Diplomats and their families had a choice of culture, carni val or a combination of both yesterday at a fair for them on West 53d Street near Fifth Avenue.

title: Carroll to Fight Ahumada
description: Hal (TNT) Carroll, 32year1 I old Syracuse fighter, will meet} Jorge Ahumada, 27, of Buenos Aires next Monday night in a lightheavyweight bout at the Felt Forum. Carroll has a rec ord of 27 victories, six defeats and one draw. Ahumada, mak ing his United States debut, has a 3151 record.

title: SUIT SEEKS RELEASE OF U.S. YOUTH FUNDS
description: NEWARK, June 25 (UPI) A coalition of New Jersey anti poverty groups filed a Federal Court suit today in an attempt to force the Nixon Administra tion to release $270million appropriated by Congress to operate summer Neighborhood Youth Corps programs around the country.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:
Notes on People
description: I have no plans for poli tics right now. If the right time and the right place come together, I might run for office. So said 25yearold David Eisenhower, respond ing to speculation he might covet Pennsylvania's 19th Congressional District seat, now held by George A. Goodling, the 76yearold Republican, who is keeping his own plans to himself. I am not seeking his seat, said Mr. Eisenhower. I am con centrating on the business at handwriting sports for The Philadelphia Bulletin. In the fall, I shall decide whether to continue as a sports writer or to law school.

title: Victory Today Is Predicted By Both Beame and Badillo
description: Both candidates in the Democratic mayoral runoff pre dicted victory in public and exuded confidence in private yesterday. Some 600,000 Democrats will nominate one of them today and make him a prohibitive favorite to become New York City's next Mayor.

title: New Zealand Cabinet Aide To Go on Trip to Test Area
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, June 25The Minister of Immi gration was chosen by lot to day to represent New Zealand's Cabinet aboard a navy frigate that will sail into the area of the French nuclear test zone at Mururoa Atoll, 800 miles south east of Tahiti.

title: A.E.C. Releases Studies on Nuclear Plant Safety
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 The nation's nuclear power plants are extremely safe but if a Major accident occurred it could be extremely dangerous. These views are contained in separate documents made public today by the Atomic Energy Commission in re sponse to requests from Con gress.

title: Look What Olga Korbut Has Done for the Exercise Class
description: Aria Klatell, a former fash ion model, pampered her self for almost three years because of a painful muscu lar problem in her back. Then she began a gymnastics routine in a Manhattan exer cise studio, and her back problem vanished.

title: BANK IN CHICAGO PLANS U. S. CHAIN
description: The First National Bank of Chicago, eighth largest in the nation with $13.1billion in as sets, is planning to open a chain of 24 regional wholesale bank ing offices in cities all over the country in the next three years.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Sports fans usually find themselves drawn irresistibly toward every type of allstar selection, and not even compilation that's definitely farfetched can alter their builtin fascination for these groupings. One such list popped up recently in the authoritative pages of The Sporting News, the baseball weekly, and was given prominent display in the corner reserved for Johnson Spink, editor and publisher. He was obviously intrigued by it. So am I.

title: A Vote for Badillo
description: In today's runoff primary, New York Democrats have the choice between Representative Herman Badillo, with his promise of a dynamic, socially progressive mayoralty, and Controller Abraham D. Beame, with the probability of four years of governmental stagnation at City Hall.

title: U.S. PANEL READY ON PAY PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 25An independent commission charged with the responsibility of recommending pay rises for Government officials, including Congressmen and Federal judges, has decided on the figures it will transmit to the President on Saturday.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS 4 JERSEY PROJECTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) Four New Jersey proj ects were included today in financing approved by the House Appropriations Commit tee for fiscal 1974 Federal wa ter resources activity.

title: Seoul Makes Drug Arrests
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 25 (UPI)  Customs officials have smashed an international nar cotics smuggling ring that sold $1.9million worth of illegal drugs during the last two years, Seoul authorities announced today. Officials said four mem bers of the ring, including the leader, were arrested and four others were fugitives.

title: Proxmire Urges Navy to Drop Procurement of F14's
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Senator William Proxmire en tered the dispute over the Navy's new F14 fighter plane today by charging that the pro gram had become a fouledup mess that should be termi nated immediately.

title: American League Tuesday, June 26, 1973
Wood, Field and Stream
description: SHARON, Conn.  Driving south from Manchester, Vt., where I had just purchased my first Orvis flyrod, I was possessed with an over whelming desire to see how it performed.

title: Policeman Is Shot Dead In His Staten Island Home
description: A policeman was found dead, shot in the chest, at his home in Eltingville, S.I., yes terday afternoon. Officials were questioning his wife in connection with the death.

title: A VIETNAM VETERAN ACCUSED IN STABBING
description: A marine veteran of the war in Vietnam who had been in Veterans Hospital until yester day was charged by the police last night with stabbing five patrons of a Queens diner with a knife and fork.

title: Mexico Is Tapping Desert For Geothermal Energy
description: CERRO PRIETO, Mexico, June 23  On a savagely hot patch of desert in Mexico's Baja California, the energy needs of nearly half a million people are being met without the use of gas, oil or coal and with virtually no pollution. For the people of Baja and the Mexicali Valley, the energy crisis has become someone else's problem.

title: Indians Win, 42
description: CLEVELAND, June 25Gay lord Perry, the ace of the In dians pitching staff, scattered nine hits and trumped the New York Yankees, 42 tonight to snap their longest winning streak since 1969 at eight games before a crowd of 18,670 in Cleveland Stadium.

title: 5 German Children Killed
description: WANGEN, West Germany, June 25 (AP)  A school bus driven by a 66yearold man collided with a diesel locomo tive at an unguarded grade crossing in this southern town today, killing five children, the driver and his assistant.

title: AGNEW DISCUSSES AGNEW AS CHIEF
description: Vice President Agnew says that if he were to become President he would follow the foreign policy directions set by President Nixon, but would probably try some different things with domestic policy.

title: CONNECTICUT'S ELKS TO FIGHT RACIAL BAR
description: CLINTON, Conn,, June 25 (AP)  The national Order of Elks will be destroyed, said Clifford R. Gasparini, head of the state association, unless the whitesonly membership clause is removed.

title: Private School Aid in State Upset by Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Supreme Court struck down today as unconstitutional four programs of Governor Rockefeller and the New York Legislature to provide financial assistance to private schools, principally those of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Clerk Is Shot Dead Outside Hotel Off Times Sq.
description: A night desk clerk at a hotel in the Times Square area was fatally shot early yesterday morning as he smoked a ciga rette outside his place of em ployment just before reporting to work, the police reported.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:
CHRYSLER BIDS E.P.A. DELAY 76 STANDARD
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)The Chrysler Corpora tion told the Environmental Protection Agency today that it could not yet meet any of the mandatory Federal emission standards for 1976 cars be cause the technology is sim ply not there.

title: New Irish President Takes Office and Vows to Work for Harmony
description: DUBLIN, June 25 (AP) Erskine H. Childers, an Eng lishborn Protestant with an American mother, took office as Ireland's President today with a pledge to work for har mony on the divided island.

title: Ticket Sale At Discount Brisk Here
description: The Times Square Theater Center, a nonprofit sales fa cility for lastminute distribu tion of unsold tickets on day of performanceonly basis, opened yesterday un der what appeared to be auspicious beginnings.

title: PETERSEN CALLED CONDUIT FOR DATA
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Henry E. Petersen, while head of the Justice Department's criminal investigation of the Watergate case, passed infor mation on grand jury testi mony to the White House and arranged for high White House aides to be questioned outside the presence of the grand jurors, the Senate's Watergate committee was told today.

title: A Cairo Paper Criticizes Mideast Policy at Summit
description: CAIRO, June 25 (UPI) The newspaper Al Ahram said today that President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, had taken a strangely negative attitude toward the Middle East Crisis and appeared to be unwilling, to see it re solved.

title: Many Young Puerto Ricans Held to Be Nearsighted
description: A study of the visual prob lems of schoolchildren in East Harlem has indicated that a very high percentage of Puerto Rican children, particularly girls, may be nearsighted and in need of glasses.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York City Board of Education has proposed cutting in half the tradi tional summerlong vaca tion of principals and other school supervisors. The pro posal, which is being re sisted by the supervisors union, would give principals an annual total of 27 vaca tion days, instead of the two summer months plus Christmas and Easter weeks. The board made the demand during the current contract talks with the union and has reportedly said that the supervisors hopes for higher salaries de pend on their willingness to give up some vacation time. With the school term end ing this week, it is unlikely there will be any changes affecting this summer.

title: $2.43Billion for A.E.C. Is Authorized by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) The house passed and sent to the White House today a bill to authorize the Atomic Energy Commission to spend $2.43billion in the next fiscal year, nearly half of it for mili tary purposes.

title: The Crucial Witness John Wesley Dean 3d
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Until last spring, until the base of the Watergate ice berg surfaced, John Wesley Dean 3d, basked in his own notion of success.

title: People and Business
description: Robert M. Schaeberle has been named chairman and chief executive officer of Nabisco, Inc., effective next Sunday. He will be succeeded by Val B. Diehl as president and chief operating officer.

title: HOME LOAN BOARD WEIGHS RATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The new chairman of the Fed eral Home Loan Bank Board said today that an increase in the ceiling on interest rates that savings and loan associa tions may pay their deposi tors would be considered, if necessary, to avert a drying up in the supply of funds avail able for mortgage loans.

title: Panel Urges Raises For Staff Nurses Of City Hospitals
description: An impasse panel appointed by the City's Office of Col lective Bargaining has recom mended pay increases of $850 in each year of a twoyear contract for 4,000 staff nurses in municipal hospitals and health agencies, Arvid Ander son, the office's chairman, an nounced yesterday.

title: Going Out Guide
description: OUTSIDERS The Metro politan Opera returns today for its seventh year of free opera concerts in the city's parks. This year it will be do ing Johann Strauss's Fleder maus and Giacomo Puccini's Tosca in concert version, without costumes or staging. Each opera will have four performances, and all bor oughs will be visited.

title: WENER, TERRELL TO BE REMATCHED
description: PATERSON, N. J., June 25 (AP)  State Athletic Com missioner Abe J. Greene direct ed today that a rematch be held within short order be tween Ernie Terrell and Chuck Wepner, whose heavyweight battle Saturday ended in a widely disputed decision for Wepner.

title: Green H. Hackworth Dies; Former World Court Head
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) Green Haywood Hackworth, an authority on international law who served for three years as President of the Interna tional Court of Justice at the Hague, the Netherlands, after a distinguished legal career at the State Department, died yesterday at the Sibley Memo rial Hospital of a heart attack. He was 90 years old.

title: CUBS GET 3 IN 9TH TO TOP METS, 32
description: The Mets released their lat est medical report last night and it included words like X rays, aspirated and physiother apy. In between those excerpts from an unexpurgated medical dictionary, the Mets also played a game with the Chicago Cubs. They lost, 32.

title: PAN AM AIRWAYS HAD LOSS IN MAY
description: Pan American World Air ways, Inc., yesterday reported a net loss for May of $1.8 million after a tax credit of $2.2million, compared with loss of $2.2million after a tax credit of $2.7million in May, 1972. Last month there was an operating profit of $359,000, in contrast to an operating loss of $312,000 in May, 1972.

title: ART OF VAN GOGH IN A NEW MUSEUM
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether landsEvery day at 10 A.M., Dr. Vincent van Gogh enters a gray cubeshaped building on Amsterdam's broad Museum Square. He goes straight to work, which at the moment is editing the letters written between his uncle, also Vincent van Gogh, and a fellow artist, Paul Gauguin.

title: Dean Says White House Put a Friend in C.I.A.
Statue in Park Dedicated to Papp
description: A 14foot bronze statue of Prospero and Miranda, two characters from Shake speare's The Tempest, was dedicated last night in Cen tral Park to Joseph Papp, founderproducer of the New York Shakespeare Festival.

title: Planes to Keep Clear Of Toronto Track Meet
description: TORONTO, June 24 (AP) Planes landing and taking off from Toronto Airport will be diverted from their usual flight paths tomorrow and Thursday so as not to dis turb the concentration of athletes at the Pacific Con ference Games.

title: 8 Hurt in Gas Explosion
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 25 (UPI)A gas explosion rocked the Monte Carlo Motel, near the downtown area, yesterday, injuring eight persons, includ ing two critically.

title: 9 Jews Reported Seized
description: MOSCOW, June 25 (AP)Nine Jewish activists were ar rested today by the Soviet security police, Jewish sources reported. It was the eighth time in a series of arrests that be gan just before Leonid I. Brezh nev, the party leader left for the United. States on June 16.

title: Man Is Held Without Bail In Death of Girlfriend's Son
description: A Bronx man was held without bail yesterday, ac cused of killing his girlfriend's 2yearold son and of abusing her two other children.

title: Rising of Water Tables Angers Long Islanders
description: BABYLON, L. I., June 25 Everybody used to worry about running out of water on Long Island, but lately some Long Islanders are wor ried more about the ponds forming in their basements. If this is a drought, nobody wants to see the flood.

title: O'Hara Is Named Coordinator Of State's New Drug Program
description: Governor Rockefeller yester day announced the appointment of Almerin C. O'Hara, Com missioner of General Services, as overall coordinator of the state's new program to deal with illicit drugs through toughened prison terms and enlarged treatment facilities.

title: Four Americans Victors In International Track Meet
description: SODERHAMN, Sweden, June 25 (AP)Dwight Stones won the high jump and led a surge of four Americans who cap tured events today at an inter national track meet.

title: Interest Rates Show Another Advance
description: Interest rates climbed another notch yesterday as banks stepped up their furious bidding for shortterm money and Wall Street wondered how it would marshal the huge amounts of capital required to underwrite this week's influx of new long term issues.

title: Bronx Girl, 9, Raped AndHurledOff Roof To Death by 2 Boys
description: A 9yearold Bronx girl was tossed to her death last night from the roof of a 20story tenement, according to the po lice.

title: Thomson and Halle, Brokerage Firms, To Combine July 9
description: Thomson & McKinnon Auch incloss, Inc., and Halle & Stieglitz, Filor Bullard, Inc., an nounced yesterday that they had agreed to combine their businesses, effective July 9. The new securities firm will operate under the name of Thomson & McKinnon Auchin doss, Inc. Thomson has 57 offices in 18 states and the District of Columbia; Halle & Stieglitz, which combined with Fi lor. Bullard last year, has 16 offices, primarily in the East and in Europe.

title: Witness Submits List of Those He Believed Might Be Indicted
description: WASHINGTON, June 25John W. Dean 3d submitted to the Senate Watergate com mittee today a list he had pre pared of persons he thought might be indicted in the Water gate burglary or its coverup.

title: Ballinger Goes Undefeated To Win National Foil Title
description: TUCSON, Ariz., June 25 (UPI)Ed Ballinger of New York became the national foil champion last night by win ning all his bouts in a sixman roundrobin final. Ballinger scored 51, 52, 5.4, 5.1 and 50 victories.

title: Sir Lloyd Dumas, 81, Dies; Australian News Executive
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 25  Sir Lloyd Dumas, journalist and newspaper executive, died last night in Calvary Hospital, Adelaide, at the age of 81.

title: MORGAN BANK DUE FEE ON GIMBELS
description: The Morgan Guaranty Com pany of New York will receive $750,000 as a finder's fee if the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation buys at least 51 per cent of the common stock of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., ac cording to the proxy statement issued by Brown & Williamson.

title: F.B.I. BACKS DATA ON WEATHERMEN
description: DETROIT, June 25In an affidavit filed in United States District Court today, an official of the Federal Bureau of Inves tigation said that the bureau had not engaged in illegal wire tapping, burglary, sabotage, provocateurism or any other unauthorized activity while invesigating Weatherman radi cals now on trial here.

title: Police and Firemen Urge Rise, Not Cut, in Pensions
description: Representatives of police and fire unions here urged the Le gislative Select Committee on Pensions yesterday to recom mend increases  not reduc tions  in pensions for mem bers of the emergency serv ices and for widows of po licemen and firemen killed in the line of duty.

title: Rome: Revival for Painter of Bottles
description: ROME, June 25Intellec tual Rome is thrilled these days by the rediscovery of an artist whom many had condescendingly pigeonholed as that painter of bottles.

title: Steel Production Shows a Decline Of 1.7% for Week
description: Steel production for the week ended Saturday totaled 2,881, 000 tons, a decline of 1.7 per cent from the 2,932,000 tons in the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute re ported yesterday.

title: HighRise Construction Stirs Jerusalem Debate
description: JERUSALEM, June 25The future of the Jerusalem sky linethat natural ampithea ter of undulating hills that encircles the walled Old Cityhas become a focus of a major debate here.

title: STATES ASK RELEASE OF IMPOUNDED FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Pennsylvania and eight other state began ,proceedings in United States District Court here today, seeking the release of $18.3million for Pennsyl vania and $380.4million nation wide in Federal education funds impounded by the Nixon Ad ministration.

title: WattSaver Light Bulb Introduced by DuroTest
description: The DuroTest Corporation introduced yesterday a new light bulb called WattSaver, that consumes up to 10 per cent less watts of electrical energy yet provides the same amount of light as the conven tionalwattage bulb of the same life.

title: 3 Killed in Blasts and Fire On Tanker Off South Africa
description: EAST LONDON, South Af rica, June 25 (Reuters)The captain and two crewmen of a Philippine oil tanker were killed and two sailors were missing after explosions set fire to the vessel early today, port officials said here.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Scholarship Aid For Music Study

title: People in Sports: Ball In Sen. Kennedy's Court
description: Senator Edward M. Ken nedy, who admitted he used influence last year to get himself paired with Arthur Ashe, will appear in the sec ond annual Robert F. Kenne dy procelebrity tennis tour nament at Forest Hills on Aug. 25. The proceeds go to the Robert F. Kennedy Foun dation, which supports proj ects for young minoritygroup members.

title: Urban League Academies Graduate 60 Dropouts Here
description: Livingston L. Wingate, ex ecutive director of the Urban League, told the graduating class of the Urban League Street Academies yesterday that they were symbolic of the myth and lie that black, kids cannot learn.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The murder trial of a defendant in a reported under world slaying last year was abruptly postponed in Monti cello yesterday by Judge Robert C. Williams of the Sullivan County Court.

title: The Rains Came
description: The rains have started and the grasses will grow and the herds will come back and grow fat again.

title: MODERATE STANCE BY PERON HAILED
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 25Within a week of his return to Argentina after almost 18 years in exile, Juan D. Perlin has moved to win the backing of moderates and conservatives and to strengthen his image as an unifying force for the country.

title: Senators Told of Move to Cover Up Ties Between High Nixon Aides and Segretti
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The White House attempted to cover up the relationship be tween high Presidential aides and Donald H. Segretti, a young California lawyer who reported ly led a broad campaign of political sabotage during last year's primary elections, John W, Dean 3d said today.

title: Turner Denies Lying or TakingMoney To Frame Gewertz on a Drug Offense
description: TRENTON, June 25State Senator James M. Turner, a Re publican, denied on the witness stand today that he had lied, accepted money or conspired to frame Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz, a Democrat, with a narcotics possession offense.

title: Nastase and Taylor Win at Wimbledon
Accusations at Hearing Fit Mosaic of Evidence
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Many of the most pointed ac cusations made by John W. Dean 3d today before the Sen ate Watergate committee fit neatly into the mosaic of direct and indirect evidence on the scandal.

title: Bud Westmore, Makeup Artist For Movies and Television, Dies
description: SHERMAN OAKS, Calif., June 25 (UPI)  George Hamilton Westmore, head of makeup at Universal Studios for 24 years, died of a heart attack Saturday night at his home here. He was 55 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, June 25 (AP)  The United States dollar held even in European currency markets today and the price of gold dipped. Trading was only moderately active.

title: Bond Buyer Appoints
description: John J. Winders has been ap pointed editor of The Daily Bond Buyer and The Weekly Bond Buyer. Mr. Winders, pre viously executive editor, suc ceeds Paul Heffernan, who re tired June 1 and is now con tributing editor of The Bond Buyer and The Money Manager. Mr. Winders will continue as a senior associate editor of The Money Manager.

title: FRANCE PRESSING ES. ON TRADE STEP
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 25 (UPI)  France today fought for a harder Common Market line toward the United States on the reform of world trade and monetary systems.

title: 2 Drown in Rescue Effort
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., June 25 (AP)Two young men drowned in the.Yellow Breeches Creek Saturday while trying to rescue a third member of a swimming party. The victims were identi fied as Larry L. Wright, 22 years old, of Middletown, and William Hawley, 19, of Harris burg.

title: STOCKS IN DRUGS HELD BY A. M. A.
description: The American Medical As sociation, which has in the past made judgments on the value and quality of drugs, owns more than $6million worth of stocks in pharmaceutical com panies in a $134million re tirement fund portfolio.

title: Miller, in Thistle Sloop, Leads for Hipkins Trophy
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 25 James C. Miller 2d of the SeawanhakaCorinthian Yacht Club, Oysetr Bay, L.I., sailed into the lead for the Hipkins Trophy today when the first four races of the 22d annual men's championship of Long Island Sound were sailed off the Cedar Point Yacht Club.

title: Kansas City Blacks Differ on Kelley
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Senate Judiciary Commit tee, winding up its hearings on the nomination of Clarence M. Kelley as director of the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation, heard witnesses today describe Mr. Kelley as both superbly qualified for the job and as a bureaucratic machine insensi tive to human compassion.

title: Queen and Philip Begin Canadian Tour
description: TORONTO, June 25Queen Elizabeth came to Canada to day for a crosscountry tour intended to provide a maximum of personal contact with her subjects in this corner of the Commonwealth.

title: Rodriguez Captures Unanimous Decision Over Chavez Here
description: Guerrero (Ray) Chavez, a native of Venezuela who lives in Montreal, seems to do better as a promising middleweight boxer both north and south of the United States borders than in his occasional fights in this country.

title: Too Many, Too Soon
description: WASHINGTONThe Watergate tes timony of John Dean and other im portant witnesses to follow could settle the next Republican Presidential nomination three years ahead of time. If the result should be the resignation or removal of President Nixon, Vice President Agnew would succeed him and become the 1976 nominee almost automatically.

title: BMT Train Kills Man
description: A man fell or jumped to his death in front of an M train yesterday from the northbound BMT platform at Canal and centre streets. The man was described as black, in his 40's. There were no identification papers on him. Service on the line was delayed 35 minutes while the body was being removed.

title: U.S. COURT ORDER OBTAINED ON HIM.
description: The Justice Department ob tained yesterday a Federal Court order for the Interna tional Business Machines Cor poration to show cause next Thursday why it should not be declared in contempt of a Fed eral Court order to hand over almost 1,200 business docu ments as pretrial material in the Government's antitrust suit against I.B.M.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Some of the city's most pervasive crises will be dramatized before the City Planning Commission in a few weeks when the pro longed and complex fight is resumed over whether the city should build a $200mil lion convention and exhibi tion hall along and over the Hudson River from 44th to 47th Street.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships.

title: $650MILLION SOLD IN TAX NOTES HERE
description: The city sold a record $650 million in taxanticipation notes yesterday at an average interest rate of 4.992 per cent.

title: A Sense of Trust at a Bland Summit Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, June 25So much have SovietAmerican re lations improved in three years that the harmonious summit meeting of President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev in the last week is being taken as only modest success, more impor tant for promoting the climate of dtente than for providing practical results.

title: PRICES PLUMMET N AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe counter market tumbled yes terday in dull trading as rea sons for traders to be optimis tic continued to be scarce.

title: 15,000 Commuters Are Delayed By a Derailment on Shore Line
description: LONG BRANCH, June 25More than 15,000 commuters were delayed today after eight cars and an engine of a Penn Central shoreline train derailed here early this morning.

title: Body Language Helps U.S. Professor Read French Psyche and His Own
description: PARIS, June 25Laurence Wylie, a Harvard professor and Methodist minister's son from southern Indiana, has spent his life in ardent pur suit of the essence of the French soul.

title: The Congress Moves
description: The Congress of the United States has now served unequivocal notice on the President that it considers the continued warfare of American forces in Cambodia to be illegal, unjustified in the national interest and contrary to the will of the American electorate. This a stirring and courageous gesture. It will stand as turning point in the tragic saga of American military engagement in Southeast Asia.

title: Attacks Near Phnom Penh Among Heaviest in Weeks
description: KOMPONG KANTUOT, Cam bodia, June 25  Communist forces attacked Government positions in a wide arc around Phnom Penh today in some of heaviest fighting that the coun try has seen in weeks.

title: Tomorrow Begins Oct. 2
description: The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it would begin telecast of its new early morning talk show, Tomorrow, on Oct. 2. The program, which will follow the Tonight show beginning at 1 A.M. each Tuesday through Friday, will star Tom Snyder, a Los Angeles newscaster. The 1 to 2 A.M. Saturday time slot will continue to be filled by Midnight Special, a music show aimed at young audi ences.

title: Badillo Reports Donations Of $426,172 Since May 25
description: Herman Badillo, the Bronx Congressman who looked like an unpromising fourth when the race for the Democratic nomi nation for Mayor began, has re ceived campaign contributions of $426,172 since May 25, ac cording to reports filed with the Board of Elections.

title: Accused Man Misses Rites for His Brother
description: PERRINEVILLE, N. J., June 25The body of George Zyg maniak, who was allegedly shot to death by his brother in a possible mercy killing, was buried here this morning as his mother, his widow and his 3yearold son stood with other members of the family in a quiet semicircle around the grave.

title: Miss Modley Bride of Max Schling 3d
description: LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., June 25Miss Marion Elisabeth Modley was married here last Saturday afternoon to Max Schling 3d. The Rev. John Beaver performed the Episcopal ceremony at the lake's edge on the property of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Haken. Mr. Haken and the bride groom were classmates at Rensselaer Polytechnic Insti tute in Troy.

title: WEPNER, TERRELL TO BE REMATCHED
description: PATERSON, N. J., June 25 (AP)  State Athletic Com missioner Abe J. Greene direct ed today that a rematch be held within short order be 1 tween Ernie Terrell and Chuck Wepner, whose heavyweight battle Saturday ended in widely disputed decision for Wepner.

title: I.R.S. Agents in City Check Up On Compliance in Price Freeze
description: Agents of the Internal Rev enue Service fanned out through supermarkets, gasoline stations, pizza parlors and oth er stores in the city yester day to check on compliance with the price freeze, which officially went into effect throughout the country at 11:59 P.M. Sunday.

title: Saturday Afternoon Dates Approved for Roosevelt
description: Saturday afternoon harness racing, in addition to the regularly scheduled night pro gram, was approved yesterday for Roosevelt Raceway in West bury, LI., for August while the thoroughbreds are racing at Saratoga.

title: Television
description: 6:20 (2)News Reports

title: Brezhnev Stops in Paris for Talks With Pompidou
description: PARIS, Tuesday, June 26Leonid I. Brezhnev arrived here from the United States last night for two days of talks with President Pompidou.

title: Water Bucket Error Costly
description: BOSTON, June 25 (AP)An Avis car rental employe spotted a small fire crackling in a trash basket at Logan rnterna tional Airport, grabbed a water bucket from the garage, and doused the flames. The buck et turned out to be full of gaso line. The mistake hospitalized three persons and cost Avis an estimated $15,000 in damage.

title: Corning Glass. Works Expands Profit
DE GUSTIBUS
description: Hygiene Versus Hedonism: Following a recent outbreak of botulism, a woman urged in a letter to the editor that everybody boil all canned goods for 10 minutes. A fein schmecker from New Lon don, Conn., retorts, I hope I am never invited to her house for dinner.

title: 35YEAR TERM GIVEN IN MURDER ATTEMPT
description: Minutes after 32yearold Jose Diaz threatened in open court to kill the prosecutor, State Su preme Court Justice Harry Git tleson yesterday sentenced him to a minimum 35year prison term for the attempted murder of three police officers and a love rival.

title: GLAMOUR STOCKS DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Leading glamour stocks were pounded yesterday as the gen eral market produced another drab showing amid the Water gate hearings and inflation jit ters.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: 157 Moroccans Go on Trial Accused of Plot Against King
description: KENITRA, Morocco, June 25 The trial of 157 Moroccans charged with plotting to over throw King Hassan II opened here today.

title: HAROLD E. IRISH
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., June 25Harold E. Irish, a retired executive of the Western Elec tric Company in New York, died here Friday at the age of 80.

title: Telecasts of Hearing Start at 10 A.M. Today
description: The Senate hearing on the Watergate case will be tele vised today by the American Broadcasting Company, the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem and the National Broad casting Company, beginning at 10 A. M.

title: Cuild Strike Authorized
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., June 25 (UPI)Spokesmen for The Newspaper Guild said to day that employes of the Mor gantown newspapers have authorized a strike pending a contract settlement by July 1.

title: Text of Communique Issued by Nixon and Brezhnev After Soviet Leader's Visit
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 25Following is the text of joint communiqu issued at the Western White, House today on the weeklong summit meeting of President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev:

title: I. T. T. Memos on Marxism Disclosed
description: Fourteen months after the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation pointed out with alarm that freedom is dying in Chile because of her election of a Marxist presi dent, the giant conglomerate was quietly negotiating a mas sive program of business proj ects with the Soviet Union, ac cording to internal I.T.T. doc uments.

title: CHURCH SCHOOLS WILL STAY OPEN
description: Leaders of the churchre lated schools in the state said yesterday, following the Su preme Court ruling against state aid to parochial schools, that their schools would survive de spite growing financial burdens and declining revenue.

title: Brooklyn Girl Fatally Shot As Gun Is Fired by Mistake
description: A 17yearold Brooklyn girl was fatally shot by her half brother yesterday when a shot gun was fired accidentally, the police said.

title: Filling Station Rollbacks First of Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 The Government reported to day its first price rollbacks un der President Nixon's June 13 freeze.

title: Victory T oday Is Predicted By Both Beame and Badillo
description: Both candidates in the Democratic mayoral runoff pre dicted victory in public and exuded confidence in private yesterday. Some 600,000 Democrats will nominate one of them today and make him prohibitive favorite to become New York City's next Mayor.

title: Text of Memo to Dean
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Following is a memorandum from President Nixon to John W. Dean 3d that was sub mitted by Mr. Dean to the Senate Watergate committee today and made public by the committee:

title: House Crime Group Reports Wide Fixing of Races
description: WASHINGTON, June 25A House committee reported to day that enough horse races in this country were fixed to threaten the integrity of the industry and the states in which the sport was sanctioned.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
New Jersey Briefs
description: A state appeals court declared part of the 1918 Workmen's Compensation Law unconstitutional because denied benefits to illegitimate grandchildren. The Appellate Division of the Superior Court said the taw that provided benefits for illegitimate children, but not grandchildren, violated the equality clause of the 14th Amendement the United States Constitution.

title: Accused Man Misses Rites for His Brother
description: PERRINEVILLE, N. J., June 25The body of George Zyg maniak, who was allegedly shot to death by his brother in a possible mercy killing, was buried here this morning as his mother, his widow and his 3yearold son stood with other members of the family in quiet semicircle around the grave.

title: STATEMENT CITED
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 26The White House said to day that President Nixon stood by his May 22 statement on the Watergate case, which con flicts with sworn testimony of John W. Dean 3d that the President was involved in the coverup.

title: Vase Is Again Defended By NICHOLAS GAGE
description: Douglas Dillon, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said yesterday that museum officials had con cluded on the basis of available evidence that the Eu ?? vase bought last year for $1million had not been smuggled out of. Italy as con tended by Italian authorities,

title: HIGH COURT DIMS PAROCHIAL HOPES
description: The Supreme Court appears to have dashed any hope at ei ther the national or state level for major new forms of public help for financially pressed pa rochial and private schools.

title: Dean at Witness Table: A Calm and Cool David
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Considering that he sees him self as David going up against Goliath without a slingshot, John W. Dean 3d seems about as cool and collected as a man could be.

title: French Keep Watch Factory Ticking
description: BESANCON, France, June 26 Workers have seized France's bestknown watch factory and are continuing to operate it and sell its wares in a struggle to head off a job cutback ordered by the Swiss owners.

title: Publisher Stands By Accusation
description: LONDON, June 26Mark Goulden, chairman of W. H. Allen, which has published two biographies of Marilyn Monroe, _insisted today that Norman Mailer was a plagiar ist and knew he was one.

title: In This Technological Age, Even the Dogs Prefer Not to Walk
description: MT. KISCO, N.Y.Arthur and Sylvia are a pair of nice, slurpy Saint Bernards  the breed famed for trudging the Swiss Alps and saving the lives of peo ple trapped in snowbanks.

title: 42 FOOD CONCERNS GIVEN VIOLATIONS
description: The Health Services Adminis tration has announced the names of 42 more foodprocess ing establishments charged with having violated the health code.

title: 1972 Mail Rate Increases Upheld by Appeals Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals, rejecting the argu ments by some publishers and mail order companies, upheld today the 1972 rate increases for third and fourthclass mail.

title: MRS. W. G. DELLABOUGH
description: TEANECK, N. J., June 26Mrs. Mariitt Bruske Della bough, widow of Walter Grant Dellabough, a real estate man, died yesterday in the Hudson Manor Nursing Home in North Bergen. She was 84 years old.

title: Gen. Ryan Scored on Flight Pay Order
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 Gen. John D. Ryan, the Air Force chief of staff, signed an order last week entitling him self and 64 other Air Force gen erals to continue receiving flight pay despite a new law banning such payments to gen erals and admirals in non combat assignments.

title: Johnson Reportedly Told F.B.I. to Check on Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, June 26President Johnson ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate Spiro T. Agnew shortly after he was elected Vice President in November, 1968, reliable Government sources said today.

title: ExCounsel Says White House Kept Enemy List That It Used For Harassment
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 The Nixon White House kept and continually updated an enemy list, John W. Dean 3d testified today, and often used Government investigators to harass the people on it.

title: Spokane Fair Aide Named
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 26 (AP)J. Wells Henderson, Philadelphia lawyer, was named yesterday by President Nixon to be commissioner general of Spokane's 1974 In ternational Exposition on the Environment.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Lindsay formed a city task force yesterday for what was described as a last chance for his administration to plan the development of South Richmond.

title: Kelley Is Unanimously Approved By Senate Panel as F B.I. Head
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 The Senate Judiciary Commit tee unanimously approved to day the nomination of Clarence M. Kelley, the chief of police in Kansas City, Mo., as the new director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Vincent, Doyle in Final
description: Tony Vincent and Al Doyle of New York reached the final of the Eastern senior tennis championship yesterday. Vin cent beat Tony Franco of Briar cliff Manor, N.Y., 61, 26, 62. Doyle won from Bill Tully of Pelham Manor, N.Y., 62, 67, 76, at the New York Tennis Club in the Bronx. The final is next Tuesday.

title: The Beame Victory
description: The designation of Controller Beame by a margin of three to two as the Democratic nominee for Mayor re flects the regard in which he is held by large numbers of New Yorkers as an intelligent, dedicated public offi cial of long experience. The competence he has shown as the city's chief fiscal officer evidently convinced many voters in the runoff primary that he was wellequipped to provide the prudent management he had promised if elected Mayor.

title: Panel Weighs Lumber Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The National Association of Home Builders urged Senators today to vote specific controls on export of softwood logs and lumber. But the National Forest Products Association opposed such controls. The Senate Bank ing Comittee, before which the: witnesses testified, is consid ering a bill asked by President Nixon to give him flexible au thority to impose export con trols on commodities.

title: Bank Meeting Inconclusive
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., June 26  The contested annual meeting of the Empire National Bank ended inconclusively here today asboth factions seeking to control the halfmilliondollar upstate bank ap peared likely to elect some directors to the 19man board. The results of the voting will be announced Thursday.

title: McCloskey Accuses Nixon Of Violating Oath of Office
description: WASHINGTON June 26 (UPI)Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., Republican of California, said last night that President Nixon had violated ihis oath of office by ordering creation of an extralegal intel ligence unit directed by the White House.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, JUNE 27, 1973
description: John W. Dean 3d told the Senate Water gate committee that President Nixon had misled the nation in his public statements on the Watergate case and insisted that his charges. of Presidential complicity in the Watergate coverup were factual. His stead fast adherence to the accusations in a 245 page statement Mr. Dean read to the com mittee Monday posed an immediate  and crucial  conflict with the White House. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: 2 Killed as Freight Train Hits Another in California
description: INDIO, Calif., June 26 (AP) Two crewmen were killed yesterday when a westbound Southern Pacific freight train slammed into the rear of park ed freight and derailed, the authorities said.

title: CLASHES CONTINUE NEAR PHNOM PENH
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 26American planes, in cluding B52 bombers, again raided Cambodia today as heavy fighting continued near Phnom Penh.

title: 4 Plants in Japan Closed in a Dispute On Mercury in Fish
description: TOKYO, June 26 (AP)Four chemical companies accused by fishermen of contaminating the sea with mercury pledged today to suspend operations at the offending plants until fisher men's compensation demands are settled.

title: People and Business
description: Robert T. Wieringa has been named president of the Warner Lambert Company, effective on Sunday. He suc ceeds E. Burke Giblin, who will become chairman and continue as chief executive officer.

title: Documents Give Insight On White House Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 The documents that John W. Dean 3d submitted with his testimony before the Senate Watergate committee give rare insight into the White House and related 1972 Presi dential campaign activities.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The United States should pause and take stock.

title: WINNING EDGE 32
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame won the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday with an overwhelming 3to2 victory over Representative Herman Badillo in the city's first runoff primary.

title: Ignition SeatBelt System Is Put on Display by Ford
description: DETROIT, June 26 (AP)A federally mandated ignitionseat belt interlock system for 1974 Model cars has been put on display by the Ford Motor Com pany. Included is a button to bypass the device in event it fails.

title: Medicare Aid Is Extended To Major Kidney Patients
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The Federal Government an nounced regulations today extending Medicare coverage persons of any age who need kidney transplants or regular periodic treatment with artifi cial kidney machines.

title: HOUSE AGAIN ACTS 10 CURB BOMBING
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 In its second antiwar action in two days, the House of Repre sentatives voted today to ex tend through Sept. 30 a pro posed ban on the use of funds for United States bombing in Cambodia.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CASTLE KEEP In 1850 Jenny Lind, the Swedish Nightingale, opened her American tour under the auspices of P. T. Barnum at Castle Garden. In 1852 she gave her farewell perform ance there. Today at 12:30, two Jenny Linds will give a program of coloratura Lind like arias at the same spot, now known as Castle Clin ton, an unroofed round stone wall, which is all that's left of it, in Battery Park. The two are the winners of Jenny Lind competitions: June an derson, soprano, won the American title at the Barnum Festival in Bridgeport, Conn., held annually in honor of its favorite son. Ingrid Stalne was the winner in a similar Swedish contest. They will go on tour of both countries under sponsorship of War naco Company, of Bridge port. Today, however, they will appear together with pi ano accompaniment in what is believed to be the first con cert in the Castle since the

title: N.B.C. Arranges Program Exchange With B.B.C.
description: The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday an ambitious schedule of tele vision specials for the 197374 season, including a longterm exchange program with the British Broadcasting Corpora tion, dramas by Arthur Miller and Clifford Odets, an original play by Truman Capote and 90minute drama on the life of Roberto Clemente.

title: Roundup: Too Good to Lose, Pirates Resume Losing
description: Willie Stargell wants every one to know that the Pitts burgh Pirates are too good to be residing in the nether regions of the National League's Eastern Division.

title: 197173 Deals Studied
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, embroiled in controversy over its handling of bequests, its policies on deaccession and disposal and its acquisitions, yesterday made public new pro cedures governing the removal and sale or exchange of works from its collections.

title: Dean Warned His Future Wife of Rough Situation but Did Not Explain
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)John W. Dean 3d told his future wife in September that at some point down the road it's going to be a rough situation. He did not explain why.

title: A Hudson Adventure Ends for 12
description: A dozen students, most of them from Boston University, arrived triumphantly at Bat tery Park yesterday after an exhausting 310mile land and water trip from upstate.

title: A Woman Is Mugged Near Tennis Protest
description: Outraged over a season's, delay in resurfacing the Cen tral Park tennis courts and. over deteriorating tennis fa cilities throughout the city, about 75 tennis players dem onstrated and met with Parks, Commissioner Richard Clurman at the Central Park tennis house last night. He said 13 of the 26 clay courts there would be resurfaced by Aug. 1.

title: SUIT SAYS GIRLS WERE STERILIZED
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 26 (AP)An illiterate, woman put her X on a paper she thought permitted her minor daughters, to be given some shots, but actually allowed them to be sterilized, a suit filed here asserts.

title: TODAY'S PITCHERS
description: New York at Baltimore (n.)Peterson (67) vs. McNally (59).

title: Chief Soviet Astronaut Acts To Allay Fear on Joint Shot
description: MOSCOW, June 26 (AP)The Soviet Union's chief astro naut insisted today that the Soviet space program was pro ceeding smoothly and painted a rosy picture of future United StatesRussian space coopera tion.

title: Files of Landlords Seeking Cuts In Assessment Studied by Hogan
description: The Manhattan District At torney's office disclosed yester day that it had pulled from its raft of taxassessment re duction applications the files of a number of commercial landlords that had aroused its curiosity.

title: Pine Plains Fights Incursions of Progress
description: PINE PLAINS, N.Y., June 26  The biggest controversy this year in. Pine Plains was how to stop students from smoking cigarettes in the lo cal high school.

title: AGENCY MAPPING CENSUS DATA PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The Commerce Department will ap peal to the Senate to reverse a decision made by the House Appropriations Committee to scrap a program designed to update the population data col lected in the 1970 census.

title: Business Records BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition Filed by:

title: Ceausescu of Rumania in Bonn To Shop for Investment Deals
description: BONN, June 26 (UPI)Presi dent Nicolae Ceausescu of Ru mania began a fiveday visit today to shop for foreign in vestments during the first of ficial trip to West Germany by a head of state from the East bloc.

title: Papp and CBS End Contract to Produce Dramatic Specials
description: Producer Joseph Papp's muchpublicized contract to produce dramatic specials for the CBS television network was reported, ended yesterday by both Mr. Papp and the net work.

title: Colon Praises Badillo
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., June 26 (UPI)Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon of Puerto Rico tonight commended the showing of RepreSentative Herman Badillo in the New York Democratic runoff as highly meritorious. The Governor's statement was read in New York by his press aide, Rafael de Santiago. He has been bedridden with a back ailment for several days. Mr. Badillo is a native of Caguas, Puerto Rico.

title: MRS. CHARLES MALONEY
description: Mrs. Marie Maloney, a per former with the Ziegfeld Fol lies who in later years op erated a talent agency, died of cancer on Monday at the French and Polyclinic Hospital. 1She was 67 years old and lived with her husband, Charles Maloney, at 55 Tiemann Place.

title: Johnson Reportedly Told F. B.I. to Check on Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 President Johnson ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate Spiro T. Agnew shortly after Mr. Agnew was elected Vice President in No vember, 1968, reliable Govern pent sources said today.

title: Inquiry Takes Patronage Out of Shadow
France Defies the Court
description: France's apparent determination to conduct nuclear tests in the South Pacific in defiance of a request from the International Court of Justice is a blow not only nations that are threatened by fallout from the tests but to the World Court.

title: Black U.S. Technicians Going to Assist Uganda
description: Roy Innis leader of the Congress of Racial Equality announced yesterday that 50 black American technicians would leave for Uganda Aug. 1 to start filling the void left by President Idi Amin's ex pulsion of Asians.

title: Carousel Is Revived At Beach
description: After two Rodgers and Hammerstein smashes at the Jones Beach Theater like The Sound of Music and The King and I, it was al most inevitable that Carou sel would be a lavish, taste ful production, beautiful to see and hear. Add to this, for the sake of family entertain ment (a cause worth noting), the reasonable prices and the parking and dining facilities at the big, shore stadium.

title: 2 OFFICERS ACCUSED OF P.O.W. CRIMES
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)The Navy disclosed to day that Rear Adm. James B. Stockdale had charged two for mer prisoners of war with six alleged offenses, including mutiny, aiding the enemy, re fusing to obey orders and try ing to persuade other P.O.W.s to be insubordinate.

title: State Begins Dismantling PrivateSchool Aid Plan
description: TRENTON, June 26  New Jersey began dismantling its $19.5million program of state aid to private and parochial schools today as the Cahill ad ministration reviewed a United States Supreme Court ruling that struck down similar pro grams in New York and Penn sylvania.

title: Best Market Gains In 2 Weeks Scored
Corrosion Perils a Part Of Tower of London
description: LONDON, June 26 (AP) Salt is corroding part of the Tower of London, and scien tists are seeking to prevent the collapse of the section.

title: Books of The Times
description: There's no arguing with one thing: as an anthology of journalism written during the last dozen years or so, Tom Wolfe's and E. W. Johnson's The New Journal ism is just fine. It's a pleasure to read, even for a second or third time, the best of its twodozen selections (among the self contained pieces, these are Joan Didion's Some Dreamers of the Golden Dream, Garry Wills's Martin Luther King Is Still on the Case, and Barbara L. Goldsmith's La Dolce Vita). What's more, the book is a useful historical and journalistic rec ord of the period it covers: it's good to have available in a single volume some of the better reporting that was done on the counterculture (Robert Christgau's Beth Ann and Macrobioticism and Joe Eszterhas's Charlie Simpson's Apoc alypse) and Vietnam (Michael Herr's Khesanh and Nicholas Tomalin's The General Goes Zapping Charlie Cong), not to mention some of the extraordinary pieces written during the period by writers like Rex Reed, Truman Capote, Terry Southern, Hunter S. Thompson, Norman Mailer, George Plimpton, James Mills, Adam Smith, and Toni Wolfe himself (represented here by selections from The Electric KoolAid Acid Test and Radical Chic & ManMauning the Flack catcher).

title: In Hungary and Rumania, Realism Prevails
description: BUCHAREST  After al absence of a few years, a vis does first impressions of this part of Europe indicate little change.

title: Miller and Neuharth Named to Top Posts by Gannett Newspapers
description: ROCHESTER, June 26 (AP)Paul Miller, chief executive of Gannett Co., Inc., since. 1967, became chairman of the board today. Allen H. Neuharth, 49 years old, president and chief operating officer since 1970, was named president and chief executive.

title: Fog, Lack of Wind Puts Off Block Island Sail Race
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., June 26  Fog and the absence of wind forced the Storm Trysail Club to cancel the second scheduled day of racing to day in Block Island Week.

title: Biaggi Plans to Attack a Lack of Stamina
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, the Conservative party candi date for Mayor, said last night that he would attack Controller Abraham D. Beame on what Mr. Biaggi said were the Con troller's lack of vigor and stamina, political obligations in cluding his indebtedness to the Democratic machine and pas sive performance in office.

title: DISPUTE IN H.E.W. ON SCHOOL FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 26A revolt is developing in the De partment of Health, Education and Welfare over an effort by Secretary Caspar W. Wein berger to disburse Federal funds to four school districts previously found in violation of the department's civil rights, regulations.

title: Commuter Injured By a Rod Thrown At a Hudson Train
description: An iron rod that apparently had been tossed by a vandal came hurtling through the win dow of a Penn Central com muter train in North Tarry town, N.Y., late yesterday after noon, showering several pas sengers with broken glass and striking one commuter in the face, cutting his nose and forehead.

title: Tremors Hit Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA, June 26 (Reu ters)Repeated earth tremors rocked the Guatemalan capital today, cutting electricity and spreading panic among the one million inhabitants. There were no immediate reports of dam age or loss of life.

title: Seven Slain in Chicago Suburb; Man Charged With Killing Four
description: PALOS HILLS, Ill., June 26 (UPI)A man carrying a rifle went berserk in a quiet, wooded neighborhood of this southwest Chicago suburb today. Seven persons were shot to death in three homes within a twoblock area.

title: Surgery for Congressman
description: HOUSTON, June 26 (AP)Representative O. C. Fisher, Democrat, underwent heart surgery today at St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital. A spokes man said the San Angelo Con gessman was in satisfactory condition.

title: U.S. Group Enters Race To Build Suez Pipeline
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 26An American financial and con struction group has launched an effort to replace a Euro pean consortium in the build ing of a proposed SuezMedi terranean oil pipeline in Egypt.

title: CPC Expects No Cutbacks For Remainder of Freeze
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N. J., (Reuters) June 26CPC Inter national, Inc., expects to be op erating as usual during the re mainder of the 60day price freeze, according to its financial vice president, Gene A. Burns.

title: Official Does Not Suspect Arson in New Orleans Fire
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 26 (AP)  Assistant State Fire Marshal Timothy A. Driscoll said today that he did not sus pect arson in the fire that raced through a threestory apartmentbar building in the french Quarter Sunday night, killing 29 persons.

title: Vesting and Funding in Plans Favored
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's largest Manager of pension fund in vestments, yesterday advocated major reforms for private pen sion plans.

title: CAPITOL PROJECT ENTERS 3D PHASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 23Twelve and a half years ago President Kennedy rode along Pennsylvania Avenue in his in augural parade and, shocked by the thoroughfare's deteriorating appearance, vowed to trans form it.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rose at Monthly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Yields on United States Treas ury bills rose in the Govern ment's monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Votes Undo
description: Challenged voters were given a break of sorts yesterday: for the first time special voting machines were set up at 10 sites where 27 Supreme Court justices many of them put ting in rare overtime  held righttovote hearings.

title: 6 Consumer Aides Named To Hospital Budget Unit
description: TRENTON, June 26 (AP)The appointments of six con sumer representatives to the New Jersey Hospital Budget Review Committee were an nounced today.

title: Two Guys Strike Ends
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP)  A threeyear contract between Two Guys Stores and the Retail Clerks Union was ratified yesterday, ending a threeweek strike against the chain by 8,500 retail clerks in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Del aware, Maryland, New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts.

title: A 3102 VICTORY;Controller Is a Heavy Favorite to Become 105th Mayor Here
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame won the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday with an overwhelming 3to2 victory over Representative Herman Badillo in the city's first runoff primary.

title: New Books
description: A Minority of Members: Women in the U.S. Congress, by Hope Chamberlin (Praeger Publish ers, $10).

title: Dog Saves Five From Fire
description: CHUR, Switzerland (AP) The police credited a dog's harking with alerting five people in a burning vacation hostel. The five and the dog jumped to safety through window.

title: Medicare Aid Is Extended To Major Kidney Patients
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The Federal Government an nounced regulations today extending Medicare coverage persons of any age who need kidney transplants or regular periodic treatment with artifi cial kidney machines.

title: Single Sex Standard Set By Court for Sentencing
description: TRENTON, June 26 (AP)Declaring the use of different standards for sentencing men and women to be unconstitu tional on its face, the New Jersey Supreme Court today ordered that in the future women be sentenced to state prison on the same terms as men.

title: Data Burned at Dump May Have Been Hanes
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) Eight cartons of doc uments from the office of E. Howard Hunt Jr. may have been locked in the trunk of a Junked car for six months and then burned at a city dump, a Watergate witness told United Press Interna tional today.

title: L.I. Plant Gets Navy Order
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI)The Navy Ships Com mand has issued a $2,414,992 contract to the Dynell Elec tronic Corporation of Melville, L. I., for sonar receiving sets, the office of Representative Angelo Roncallo, Republican of Massapequa, announced today. The sonar sets are intercept receivers designed for use on advanced submarines.

title: TODAY'S PITCHERS
description: Philadelphia at New York (2, 5:35 P.M.)Lersch (22) and Brett (72) vs. Stone (32) and Parker (51).

title: Walter Dunbar Appointed State Probation Director
description: Walter Dunbar, executive deputy commissioner of the State Department of Correction al Services, has been appointed State Probation Director, Gov ernor Rockefeller's office an nounced yesterday.

title: Illegal Wiretaps Rejected In Ruling on J.D.L. Case
description: Government efforts to com pel the key witness to testify in a fatalbombing case were blocked by the United States Court of Appeals here yester day in a decision vehemently assailing illegal wiretaps.

title: Colson Says Dean Lied About Nixon To Protect Himself
description: Charles W. Colson, one of the central figures in John W. Dean 3d's televised testimony before the Senate Watergate committee, appeared on televi sion himself yesterday to ac cuse Mr. Dean of lying when he charged President Nixon with complicity in the Water gate coverup.

title: 197173 Deals Studied
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, embroiled in controversy over its handling of bequests, its policies on deaccession and disposal and its acquisitions, yesterday made public new pro cedures governing the removal and sale or exchange of works from its collections.

title: SENATE APPROVES MILITARY AID BILL
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The Senate, 50 to 42, passed a scaleddown foreign military aid authorization bill today after rejecting a mandatory fouryear phaseout of the pro gram.

title: Ulster's Opiate: Violence
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern IrelandAlmost fifteenhundred years ago this city was founded by a man so gentle that all creatures loved him and his old white horse came weeping to his deathbed. Saint Columcille called this Derry, my own oak grove, little cell, my home, my love. But apart from grim Protestant cathedral beneath whose chancel tough apprentice boys who withstood a Catholic siege in 1689 are buried, none of sweet Columcille is left.

title: Anderson Named Winner Of N.F.L. Writing Award
description: Dave Anderson of The New York Times was named last] night the winner of the story oftheyear award for 19721 among National Football League writers. He received a $1,000 check at the pro football writers dinner at the Ameri cana.

title: Theater
description: An evening as Uncle Vanya might provide enough chal lenge and work for any usual actor, but Nicol Williamson star of Nicol Williamson's Late Show, which opened last night at the Eastside Playhouse, as well as a star of the Chekhov play at the CircleintheSquare  is far from the usual actor.

title: Bridge:
BLOMBERG RISING IN AllSTAR POLL
