description: Ron Blomberg of the Yan kees, the major leagues only 400 hitter, has moved into the top six in balloting for the first base position on the American League AllStar team, but still has a long way to go to catch the leader, Dick Allen.

title: Back to Simla?
description: It is now nearly one year since President Bhutto Pakistan and India's Prime Minister Gandhi met at Simla in a historic bid to resolve differences that have locked their two countries in bitter confrontation since they gained their separate independence in 1947. Despite promising first steps and pledges of peaceful intent which emerged from that meeting, the Indian subconti nent today is more divided than ever, its ageold hostil ities and pressing problems dangerously aggravated by still unresolved legacies of the 1971 war which resulted in the separation of Bangladesh from Pakistan.

title: At Least 30 in Madrid Hurt As Leaking Gas Explodes
description: MADRID, June 26 (UPI) Explosions caused by a huge gasmain leak ripped through a fashionable section of down town Madrid last night, hurtling manhole covers hundreds of feet into the air and blanketing the area in clouds of dust.

title: City Expects Surplus for Pension Fund
description: A special legislative commit tee studying possible revision of publicemploye pensions in the state received a report yes terday from the City Control ler's office that said increased investment of pension funds in corporate bonds and common stock would yield a $40million surplus this fiscal year for the city's five pension systems.

title: STATEMENT CITED
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 26The White House said to day that President Nixon stood by his May 22 statement on the Watergate case, which con flicts with sworn testimony of John W. Dean 3d that the President was involved in the coverup.

title: Market Place:
description: Every devotee of the stock market has seen it happen again and again. The market gains a little momentum only to fall back further than be fore.

title: Germans Victors in Soccer
description: TOKYO, June 26 (UPI)The F.C. Cologne soccer team of West Germany defeated the Japanese national team, 31, last night in a driving rain in the first game of a threegame tour of Japan.

title: FANNIE MAE AUCTION BRINGS 8.094% YIELD
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (Reu ters)The average auction yield on fourmonth commit ments to purchase 7 per cent Federal Housing Administration Veterans Administration mort gages rose to 8.094 per cent from 8.040 per cent in the pre vious auction, while on non Government backed mortgages the average yield advanced to 8.512 per cent from 8.442 per cent, record levels for four month pledges, the Federal National Mortgage Association announced today.

title: American League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES New York 10, Cleveland 2 (twi.).

title: CLARK TO DEFEND AN ATTICA INMATE
description: BUFFALO, June 26 (UPI) Ramsay Clark, former United States Attorney General, today was accepted as a defense attor ney for one of the inmates ac cused of killing a guard during the 1971 Attica prison uprising.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: CLEVELANDSigned Glenn Tufts, firstround choice in freeagent draft.

title: CHILD ABUSE HELD A LEADING KILLER
description: Child abuse is believed to be the most common cause of death among small children in this country, a medical sym posium was told last night.

title: OFFICER WHO SHOT BOY FACES CHARGE
description: The police officer who shot an 11yearold. black Staten Is land boy last August during stolencar chase will be brought up on departmental charges, Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley said last night.

title: Tuskegee, as a Southern Model of Racial Harmony, Isn't Working
description: TUSKEGEE, Ala., June 24 Murder and bitter political feuding have stirred up old fears and new turmoil in this predominantly black college town that off and on has been the hope and despair of the civil rights movement.

title: ROCKLAND JUSTICE CENSURED BY COURT
description: A Rockland County police justice who allegedly inter vened on behalf of his law partner also a police justicein a shoplifting case, was cen sured yesterday by the Ap pellate Division. But it said his removal from the bench would be unwarranted.

title: U.S. STEP REPORTED ON FUEL ALLOCATIONI
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The Nixon Administration is preparing to impose a manda tory allocation system for gaso line and other petroleum fuels, informed Government sources said today.

title: Jackson Denies Account Of His Meeting With Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that the Senate's Water gate investigation never came up at a December meeting he had with President Nixon.

title: Dean Says Ziegler Didn't Know  Truth of Watergate CoverUp
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 John W. Dean 3d told the Sen ate Watergate investigating committee today that Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, did not know the truth when he repeatedly denied any White House in volvement in the burgeoning scandal and the attempted coverup.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Colonialism 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: John Cranko Dies at 45; Stuttgart Ballet Director
description: John Cranko, the British choreographer and director of the Stuttgart Ballet who led the West German company to inter national acclaim, collapsed and died yesterday on a flight from Philadelphia to Stutgart. He was 45 years old.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein Posts 76 To Lead Long Island Golf
description: JERICHO, L. I., June 26Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks took the lead with a 76 today, four strokes over par for the 5,919yard Meadow Brook Club course, in the first round of the 35th women's Long Island medal champion ship.

title: National League
description: National League

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, twi lightnight doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 5:30 P.M.

title: Chess:
description: LENINGRAD, June 25 Viktor Korchnoi retained the lead in Round 16 of the In terzonal Tournament here by defeating Guillermo Estevez, who played White against his French Defense.

title: Notes on People
description: Moshe Dayan, Israel's Min ister of Defense was mar ried last night to Mrs. Rachel Korem, his friend and com panion of many years. It was the second marriage for both.

title: G.M. Asks OneYear Delay In Car Pollution Standards
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI)  General Motors urged the Government today to delay for one year implementation of 1976 Federal clean air stan dards for reducing oxides of nitrogen from automobile ex hausts.

title: That Old Family Feeling Gets The Cardinals Moving Upward
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 26Joe Torre sat in the St. Louis Cardinals locker room here today, smoking a cigar and watching the Watergate hear ings on television, and re flected on one of the burning questions of the day:

title: 500 WIVES SPUR CLASHES IN CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 26The arrival of about 500 wives of striking copper miners spurred street clashes here to day between opponents and supporters of the Marxist coali tion Government.

title: West Berlin Orders Girl, 17, East to Face Murder Trial
description: BERLIN, June 26 (UPI)West Berlin authorities today ordered a 17yearold student nurse returned to East Ger many to stand trial on charges that she had murdered her father.

title: Marchi Expects to Get Votes of the Young
description: Abe Beame is a nice fellow, but he's an anachronismhis experience is narrowgauged, State Senator John J. Marchi said last night as he sat in hotel suite and watched the votes pile up for Controller Abraham D. Beame.

title: Disaster Areas Designated
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 26 (UPI)President Nixon de clared Texas and North Caro lina disaster areas yesterday, making them eligible for Fed eral financial help to recover from spring storms.

title: VOLCKER REVIEWS CURRENCY SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Paul A. Volcker, Under Secre tary of the Treasury for Mone tary Affairs, told Congress to day that the current system of largely floating currency ex change rates seems to be working for the present Bur he said he was not at all happy about the drop in the dollar's exchange rate against European currencies in recent weeks.

title: Indicted in Threat to Ship
description: LOS ANGELES, June 26 (UPI) Gerald E. Priddy, a former professional baseball player, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday in connection with a $250,000 extortion plot against a cruise ship line. Mr. Priddy, who remained free on $150,000 bail, was arrested by F.B.I. agents June 5 after an anonymous caller phoned Prin cess Lines demanding a quarter of a million dollars in exchange for information, about where bombs could be found on one of its ships.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Although volume dipped slightly and declines outnum bered advances by only a small margin, prices on the Ameri can Stock Exchange rose yes terday. They also increased in the overthecounter market.

title: Finnish Athletes Will Try Acupuncture to Keep Fit
description: HELSINKI, Finland (AP)The Finnish Track and Field Association's athletes are on pins and needles.

title: People in Sports: Frazier Told To Trim His Beard Before Bout
description: Joe Frazier appeared jazzy in a silk out fit and red platform shoes yesterday when he arrived in London's Leicester Square for the official signing of his work permit for Monday night's fight with Joe Bugner. Dressed in matching silver gray and black knickers and soft peaked cap, with a short black shirt at the waist, Frazier appeared as if he might have been more at home on a golf course.

title: WILLER CAPTURES HIPKINS SAILING
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 26 James C. Miller 2d of the SeawanhakaCorinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, L. I., won the 22d annual men's sailing championship of Long Island Sound for the Hipkins Trophy today.

title: Dr. Aron Gurwitsch, 72, Dead; Philosopher at the New School
description: Dr. Aron Gurwitsch, profes sor of philosophy in the gradu ate faculty of the New School for Social Research until, his retirement in February, died Monday in Zurich, Switzerland, while on a visit. He was 72 years old and lived at 820 West End Avenue.

title: A NEW CHALLENGE
description: WASHINGTON, June 26John W. Dean 3d said today, in a new clash with the White House, that President Nixon had misled the nation in his public statements on the Water gate case, and he insisted that his charges of Presidential com plicity in a Watergate coverup were factual.

title: Counterfeit Plates in Prison
description: FLORENCE, Ariz., June 26 (UPI)About $35,000 in coun terfeit money and counterfeiting plates have been found in the Arizona State Prison printing plant, the Secret Service said today.

title: FANNY BRADSHAW,76, A DRAMATIC COACH
description: Fanny Bradshaw, a speech and dramatic coach and an ex pert on Shakespeare, died yes terday at her studio at 45 West 55th Street. Her age was 76 and she lived at 49 West 12th Street.

title: Inquiry Takes Albany Patronage Jobs Out of Shadow
description: The recent disclosure that $26,000ayear director of com munications for the Assembly majority is one of the Repub licans under investigation in an alleged scheme to siphon votes from Democrats has focused attention on one of the lesser known operations of the State Legislaturethe Speaker's of fice and the $5million in an nual patronage jobs it controls.

title: PICKET IN A FRACAS IN CEMETERY STRIKE
description: The 17day cemetery strike was marked yesterday by a fracas at Mount Hebron Ceme tery in Queens between a pick et and a young man seeking to enter to dig a. grave. The police reported that there were no serious injuries but that the men filed assault charges against each other.

title: U. S. TRADE IN MAY FELL INTO DEFICIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 The nation's foreign trade slipped back into deficit in May after a surplus in April, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Business Briefs
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, June 26 (UPI)  A threejudge Federal court today struck down an attempt by the Okla homa Corporation Commission to set a minimum price 20 cents per thousand cubic feet on natural gas produced in Oklahoma.

title: 12 INQUIRIES ORDERED IN BUFFALO UNREST
description: BUFFALO, June 26 (AP)Two investigations into last week's street disorders on Buf falo's West Side have been or dered by Mayor Stanley M. Makowski.

title: BARNETT IS SEEKING 7 BANKS IN FLORIDA
description: Barnett Banks of Florida, Inc., announced yesterday that it would file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the exchange of up to 1,149,950 of its common shares for all the outstanding shares of seven Florida banks it has agreed to acquire.

title: N.F.L. Bolsters Drug Prevention
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle an nounced yesterday a strength ened program to prevent drug abuse among the National Foot ball League's 1,300 players.

title: Brezhnev Reports to Pompidou on Nixon Discussions
description: RAMBOUILLET, France, June 26Leonid I. Brezhnev report ed to President Pompidou at length today on his weeklong talks with President Nixon. The Soviet party leader told Mr. Pompidou that there had been no decisions by the Russians and Americans on behalf of partners or third countries.

title: Mailer Denies He Plagiarized
description: Norman Mailer, in an angry statement issued through his literary agent yesterday, threatened un specified revenge against those who called him a plagiarist.

title: New U.S.Italian Treaty
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 26 (UPI)President Nixon to day sent to the Senate for ap proval a revised extradition treaty between the United States and Italy which adds aircraft hijacking and narcotics offenses to the list of extra ditable crimes. This treaty will make a significant contribution to the international effort to control narcotics traffic and to cope with other offenses, Pres ident Nixon said in a message to the Senate.

title: A Major Classicist
description: The tragically sudden death of John Cranko will have con siderable reverberations all over the dance world. He was not only the director, and in effect, the founder of the Stutt gart Ballet, he was also one of the acknowledged major classic choreographers in the world today. He worked compara tively little in North America@An@ although in 1950 @Appraisal@ he did create a shortlived work for the New York City Ballet, called The Witch. His Pineapple Poll is in the repertory of the Joffrey Ballet, and the National Ballet of Can ada has his and Juliet.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jersey residents who refuse to pay gambling debts incurred in Puerto Rico can be Sued in New Jersey courts, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

title: Florida Regents Disclose 5Year Plan to Desegregate University System
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 26 Under Government and Fed eral court pressure to improve desegregation in its state uni versity system, the Florida Board of Regents has an nounced a pledge to seek 321 additional black professors and 4,576 additional black students for eight of its nine schools, all predominantly white, over the next five years.

title: Excerpts From Testimony by Dean Before Senate Panel Investigating Watergate
Six Are Kidnapped In Spite of Warning By Argentine Chief
description: BUENOS AIRES. June 26 (Reuters)Six persons were kidnapped in COrdoba today, less than a day after a warning by President Hector J. Cmpora that violence and guerrilla ac tivity must cease in Argentina.

title: LINDSAY CREATES AN S.I. TASK FORCE
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the formation of task force to produce plans for the development of South Rich. mond in what was described as a last chance for his admin. istration to develop new com munities in the city's last fron tier.

title: Goliath Whips David In a Political Arena
description: It was a sort of David and Goliath affair, Assem blyman Seymour Posner ex plained yesterday after he was arrested for assault at a polling place in Taft High School, East 172d Street and Sheridan Avenue, in the Bronz.

title: Yankee Records
Fearful White House
description: Final judgment on many details in the massive testi mony of John W. Dean 3d on President Nixon's specific part in the Watergate scandal must be suspended until all the statements and recollections can be checked against the words and documentation of all the other witnessesand ultimately the testimony that will clearly be needed from the President himself.

title: CUTBACKS PLANNED BY GENERAL CABLE
description: The General Cable Corpora tion announced yesterday that it was terminating certain un economic operations.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Halston really meant it about lengths. When he showed most of his clothes an inch or two below the knee three weeks ago in his wholesale collection, he made store buyers nervous but not hysterical. Maybe the Hal ston customer will go for it, they rationalized. If not, the hems could be, shortened. You see, the shibboleth this fall is at or around the knee for hems.

title: WORKER SAFEGUARDS ON PESTICIDES EASED
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)The Department of La bor, under pressure by farmers groups and representatives from farm states, issued today revised pesticide regulations narrowing the scope of re quired safeguards for farm workers.

title: Hanover Bank Lists Some Trust Data
SAIGON REPORTS FIGHTING STEPUP
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 27An in crease in military attacks by Communist forces was reported yesterday by the Saigon Gov ernment, but most of the ac tions were described as small.

title: U. S. TRADE IN MAY FELL INTO DEFICIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The nation's foreign trade slipped back into deficit in May after a surplus in April, the Commerce Department reported today.

description: Blaring trumpets from the balconies of the New York Stock Exchange, a parade through Manhattan and a cannonade of fireworks will highlight the city's Fourth of July celebration.

title: Advertising: Howdy to Mr. Pibb
description: Those hot, thirsty days when the American people do most of their annual 30gallon percapita soda pop sipping are a comin in. And this year the new factorspreading out from test markets in the Southwestis Mr. Pibb, a Dr Pepperlike entry from Coca Cola.

title: HOUSE AGAINACTS TO CURB BOMBING
description: WASHINGTON, June 26In its second antiwar action in two days, the House of Repre sentatives voted today to ex tend through Sept. 30 a pro posed ban on the use of funds for United States bombing in Cambodia.

title: Who After Mr. Dean?
description: WASHINGTON, June 26How the Senate Watergate committee handles its investigation in the coming daysparticularly who it calls to the witness stand immediately after it finishes with John Deancan be of critical im portance to the opinion of the nation and the reputation of the President.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: The Lenox Arts Center, the production group directed by Lyn Austin that gave the premiere of Stanley Silver man's Dr. Selavy at the Music Barn in the Berkshires last summer, is moving to luxurious quarters for its coming summer season. The new location will be Wheat leigh, a Florentine villa over looking the Stockbridge Bowl, in the outskirts of Lenox, Mass., with a seating capa city of 125.

title: SUNNI IS DEAD; VIOLINMAKERI, 78
description: Fernando Sacconi, head of the violin department of Rem bert Wurlitzer, Inc., since 1950, died yesterday at his home at Point Lookout, L. I. He was 78 years old.

title: Shavers Agrees to Fight Quarry in Garden July 25
description: For a guarantee worth five times as much as it was for the same match last month, Earnie Shavers was assured $60,000 yesterday to oppose Jerry Quarry on July 25 in a 12round heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden.

title: OLDFASHIONEDPUMPS RUN OUT OF GASOLINE
description: CONGERS, N. Y., June 26 (UPI)  Burt Kimbark's old fashioned gasoline pumps can not register more than 50 cents a gallon. They only go as high as 49.9 cents, so when Mr.

title: ULSTER ELECTION SPURS VIOLENCE
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 26There's none of you going to do anything about it, said a woman on Donegal Road. The bombs. That thing last night.

title: Ailing Lion of Kashmir's Hopes of Achieving SelfRule Fading
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir, June 25  Sheik Mohammed Abdul lah, the Lion of Kashmir, now dreams of death.

title: House Unit Asks Penal Reform To Help Cut Repeated Terms
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The House Select Crime Com mittee recommended today wideranging priscin reform to lower the high rate of repeat imprisonments and to help pre vent prison riots.

title: ELEANOR M. TOWNSEND
description: Eleanor Meneely Townsend, a past president of the Rad cliffe Club of New York, died Monday at a nursing home in Miami at the age of 68. Mrs. Townsend, formerly of New York, lived in Islamorada, Fla.

title: OFFICIALS SEEKING NEW SMUT POLICY
description: Law enforcement official and representatives of the Po lice Department are to meet here today to discuss what las week's Supreme Court decisior on obscenity means w!th regarc to pornographic bookstores in the Times Square area and else. where.

title: HOUSE AND NIXON ACT TO AID O,E.O.
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 Congress and the White House took steps today to keep the embattled Office of Economic Opportunity in business, at least temporarily.

title: Watergate: When Law and Morality Stand in the Way
description: LA JOLLA, Calif.The treatment of the Watergate scandal has con cealed more than it has revealed. With rare exceptions, mainly in the under ground press, the significance of the events has been hidden or minimized by publicizing it as an extraordinary case of corruption in the highest circles of the Governmentextraordi nary because of its bungling brutality, its violation of elementary constitu tional rights. However, this sort of treatment isolates the scandal from the context which makes the extraordinary an ordinary event, not an aberration but the extreme political form of the normal state of affairs.

title: Governor Signs Measure For Mortgage Unit Here
description: ALBANY, June 26A bill de signed to preserve and reha bilitate housing in New York City has been signed by Gov ernor Rockefeller, his office said today.

title: Haldemans Now Living On Island Off California
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., June 26 (AP)  How did you find us, a startled Mrs. H. R. Haldeman asked a newsman standing in front of the posh and secluded new residence of the former Presidential aide.

title: Con Ed's Nuclear Plant Produces Power in Test
description: BUCHANAN, N. Y., June 26 (UPI)  Consolidated Ed ison's Indian Point nuclear power plant No. 2 produced electric power for the first time today in a series of tests, a company spokesman said.

title: Bing Crosby's Big A Pick, Kin Run, Didn't
description: I can't find him, groaned the millionaire horseplayer as he swung his binoculars across the landscape in search of a 2yearold named Kin Run at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: S.E.C. TO INVESTIGATE THREE BROOKLYN MEN
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered an in vestigation to determine wheth er three Brooklyn men violated antifraud provisions of Federal securities laws.

title: Busch Strike in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS, June 26 (UPI)Production was stopped today at the world's largest brewery as two unions went on strike against AnheuserBusch, Inc., in an effort to secure new con tracts with provisions for early retirement. Local 187 of the Beer Bottlers Union with 1,100 members and Local 262 of the Lab Technicians Union with 125 members set up picket lines at the sprawling brewery that were honored by some 4,000 other employes. Production at Busch plants in seven other cities not affected.

title: MIXED MARRIAGES FOUGHT BY RABBI
description: FALLSBURG, N. Y., June 26  The major American Ortho dox rabbinic body today agreed to pressure Jewish secular and religious organizations to bar from its leadership ranks those who marry out of the faith and those who officiate at such marriages.

title: EXPLORERS CLUB WINS TAX BATTLE
description: The Explorers Club, by unanimous ruling of the Ap pellate Division, has regained exemption from realestate taxes on its headquarters at 46 East 70th Street.

title: Foreman to Get $1Million
description: TOKYO, June 26 (AP)George Foreman, the world heavyweight champion, will re ceive $1million when he de fends his title against Joe (King) Roman of Puerto Rico in Tokyo Sept. 1, the sponsor ing NET television said today. The Japanese television net work said the challenger would get $100,000.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Two of New Jersey's finest high school athletes, Bill Paterno of Christian Brothers Academy in Lincroft and Rich Allocco of New Providence High School, will attend Notre Dame in the fall. Each has received a full athletic scholarship valued at $16,000.

title: Dillon Stands By Vase
description: Douglas Dillon, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said yesterday that, museum officials had Con cluded on the basis of available evidence that the Eu phronios vase bought last year for $1million had not been smuggled out of Italy as con tended by Italian authorities.

title: A NEW CHALLENGE
description: WASHINGTON, June 26John W. Dean 3d said today, in a new clash with the White House, that President Nixon had misled the nation in his public statements on the Water gate case, and he insisted that his charges of Presidential com plicity in a Watergate coverup were factual.

title: State Physics Failures Get a Glimmer of Hope
description: ALBANY, June 26 (UPI)For any of the 40,000 high school pupils who took the State Regents examination in physics earlier this month and just missed passing, there is still a slim hope.

title: Scout Sponsoring May End
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP) The Roman Catholic Church is considering lifting its spon sorship of Girl Scout troops here because of a new merit badge for sex education. The proposed contents of this badge would be totally unacceptable to Catholic people and puts us in a position as to be unable to sponsor troops and support the program, said the Rev. Francis X. Schmidt, director of youth activities for the Philadelphia Archdiocese.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was
Freezing the Status Quo in Korea
description: TOKYO, June 26The North Korean Government of Presi dent Kim Il Sung today harshly denounced a South Korean pro posal that both states enter the United Nations at the same time.

title: Numbers Man Sentenced
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 (AP) Anthony Grosso, convicted in Federal court of running a $30  millionayear western Pennsyl vania numbers empire, was given a 10year prison sentence yesterday.

title: YIELDS INCREASE FOR TAXEXEMPTS
description: A flood of new taxexempt financing met a lackluster re sponse from investors yester day despite yields about one tenth to onefifth of a per centage point higher than the levels that prevailed late last week.

title: SOVIET FLIER ASKS ASYLUM IN TURKEY
description: ANKARA, Turkey, June 26 (Reuters)A soviet pilot flee ing to the West made an emer gency landing in a Turkish corn field today after a fivehour flight that almost ended in dis aster.

title: Record Budget Approved By California Legislators
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 26 (UPI)California's legisla tive budget writers officially approved the largest state spending program in the na tion's history yesterday$9.22 billion for the next fiscal year.

title: LETTER RETRACTS TURNER CHARGE
description: TRENTON, June 26State Senator James M. Turner ack nowledged today that a state. ment dated Jan. 6 and ostensibly introduced at his trial to absolve him of wrong doing had never been men tioned to the state police, the State Attorney General's office or to the state grand jury Mal indicted him.

title: For S.R.O. Hotel Roomers, It's a Precarious Life
description: In the early hours of June 17, the resident of Room 533 of the Manhattan Towers Hotel staggered from the ninth floor into the elevator, his throat slashed open with a knife.

title: Plaintive Colson Memo Gets Laugh at Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (Reuters)A secret memo only seven words long brought laughter from the Senate Watergate committee hearing today. On White House note paper, it was addressed to John W. Dean 3d, dismissed Presidential counsel, from Chgles W. Colson, another farther White House aide. It said: Now what the hell do I do?

title: 2 Years for Killing Mother
description: MEMPHIS, June 26 (UPI)Fred Van Dresser 3d who told officers he shot his mother be cause she had been bugging him for 35 years, has been sentenced to from two to 10 years in prison. Van Dresser, 47 years old, pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge of in voluntary manslaughter in the death last year of Mrs. Helen Van Dresser, 74.

title: Sadat and Qaddafi Confer On Proposals for Merger
description: CAIRO, June 26 (UPI) Egypt's President, Anwar el Sadat, met the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar, elQuaddafi, for seven hours today to discuss their plans to merge their na tions by September, Govern ment sources said.

title: Yanks Beat Indians, 102, Unleashing 1 7Hit Attack
description: CLEVELAND, June 26There was a storm brewing over Lake Erie near Cleveland Stadium tonight, and the New York Yankees added the lightning and thunder, unleashing a 17 hit attack against four pitchers to defeat the Indians, 102, be fore a crowd of 7,926.

title: H.J. Heinz Co. Reports Record Sales and Earnings
Use of Shotguns in Attica Revolt Deplored in House Unit's Report
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The use of shotgun's by po licemen who put down the At tica prison riot led to the need less wounding and killing of hostages and inmates who were not acting in a hostile manner, a Congressional committee said today.

title: A Writer's Wife Becomes Mayor for Beverly Hills
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. (AP) Phyllis Seaton has become the first woman Mayor of Bev erly Hills.

title: Jet to Be Used as Canvas By Very WellKnown Artist
description: Alexander Calder, the artist wellknown for his mobiles and stabiles, has been commis sioned to paint a jet for Braniff Airways, The Associated Press reports.

title: China and NATO Receive U.S. Assurance on Summit
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The United States has taken steps to assure both China and the North Atlantic Treaty Or ganization allies that President Nixon's talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev did not harm their interests. Administration offi cials said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 20yearold Bronx youth who said he was a student at New York University and wanted to see how easy it was to rob a bank, succeeded, once but was caught on a second try, according to the police. They reported that Michael Merchant of 1760 Bruckner Boulevard at 9:35 A.M., handed a note to a teller and fed after receiving $2,000 cash, including $500 in marked bills.

title: Suit Demands State Permit Abortions Under Medicaid
description: The American Civil Liberties Union sought a restraining or der in Superior Court in Bridgeton yesterday to force the state to make Medi caid payments for nontherapeu tic abortions.

title: Uganda Adopts Carmichael
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, June 26 (AP)President Idi Amin grant ed Uganda citizenship today to Stokely Carmichael, the Ameri can black activist, and to his wife, Miriam Makeba, the singer. The couple live in Guinea in Western Africa but are on a visit to Uganda, on the eastern side of the conti nent.

title: Ballet: Strong Bolshoi Company, Big/ Little Bonus
description: It is already seven years since we saw the full Bolshoi Ballet in New York, and it is not the full Bolshoi Ballet that we are seeing at the Metropolitan Opera House. It is a large troupe of Bolshoi dancers led by Raissa Struchkova, and in cluding a number of the com pany's greatest stars, chiefly in highlights and excerpts from the repertory.

title: Dean Charges, if Proved, Would Be Felony Offenses
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  If the allegations that John W. Dean 3d has made against Pres ident Nixon over the last two days could be proved, they would constitute felony of fenses, according to experts in criminal law.

title: Doctors Challenge U.S. Law On Peer Review of Practice
description: Three physicians and an or ganization representing doctors in private practice filed suit yesterday in Federal court in Chicago challenging the consti tutionality of a Federal law re quiring peer review of medical practice.

title: MRS. JOHN D. MILLER
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Mrs, Leila Madeline Miller, in formation officer of the British Information Services here dur ing World War II, died yester day of a heart ailment at her home in Sardinia, Italy.

title: The Ayes Have to Have It
description: INDIANAPOLIS (AP)Lieut. Gov. Robert Orr asked for roll call vote from the state legislature by announcing: Will all senators please show their presence by voting aye and all senators absent by voting no.

title: Dean Says Ziegler Didn't Know Truth of Watergate CoverUp
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 John W. Dean 3d told the Sen ate Watergate investigating committee today that Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, did not know the truth when he repeatedly denied any White House in volvement in the burgeoning scandal and the attempted coverup.

title: College Aid Offered Girl Whose Dress Barred Graduation
description: CLIFTON, Ariz., June 26 (UPI) A 13yearold girl who was not allowed to go through eighth grade graduation be cause she did not have the right kind of dress has been deluged with sympathy and of fers of help, including the pay ment of four years college tuition.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TORONTO, June 26 (AP)The second Pacific Con ference Gaines open tomorrow night at Etobicoke Memorial Stadium and the United States, with a maximum con tingent of 35 athletes, is favored to win most of the med als in the competition against Australia, Canada, Japan and New Zealand. Australia won the first meet in 1969 in Tokyo, with the United States second. The American team includes Rick Wohlhuter in the 800 meters, Maurice Peoples in the 400, and Herb Washington and Ivory Croc kett, sprinters.

title: ' The Friends of Eddie Coyle' Is a Good Tough Movie
description: Peter Yate's "The Friends of Eddie Coyle," adapted by Paul Monash from the George V. Higgins novel, is a good, tough, unsentimental movie about the last days of a small-time Boston hood.Eddie Coyle (Robert Mitchum) is a guy who knows his place. Once he didn't. Once he bought some guns for some associates, and when the guns were traced to those associates, the associates of the associates took Eddie aside and broke all the knuckles on one hand. There was nothing personal. Eddie could undetrstand how they felt.Now Eddie is getting old, not like most movie gangster heros, with grandeur, but with desperation. He's facing a two-year sentence in New Hampshire for driving a truck that carried stolen whisky. He has no money in the bank and his wife and children will probably have to go on welfare.Eddie was never one to think big. He let the other guys do that. He buys stolen guns for the guys who pull the bank jobs, and at night he goes home to the wife and kids or, sometimes, to a hockey game.Eddie is not very imaginative, and he's not a tragic hero, but as played by Mitchum he has wit and a certain dignity. In the end, even the dignity is taken away from him."The Friends of Eddie Coyle" is so beautifully acted and so well set (in and around Boston's pool halls, parking lots, side-streets, house trailers and barrooms) that it reminds me a good deal of John Huston's "Fat City." It also has that film's ear for the way people talkfor sentences that begin one way and end another, or are stuffed with excess pronouns. "What you don't know, it don't bother you," a friend might say to Eddie.Unlike "Fat City," however, "The Friends of Eddie Coyle" is interested in plot and narrative suspense. The film splits its attention between Eddie, as he slowly evolves into a stool pigeon in an effort to stay free, and the more or less conventional caper movie sequences that show us how to rob a bank. Mr. Yates ("Bullitt") is so good at this sort of thing that it's probably difficult to resist putting it in.There's nothing wrong with it, but it does diminish the impact of Eddie's story, which could have been quite special.Giving Mitchum excellent support are Peter Boyle, as a bartender who deals in larceny and contract murder on the side, and Richard Jordan, as a young detective who looks deceptively soft, talks much like the hoods he is tracking, and is genuinely fascinated by the game he must play with them.The detective's manner with Eddie is direct, absolutely straight, but he is always pushing him. "You help uncle, uncle will help you," he tells Eddie. It's fairly typical of everything that's wrong in Eddie's life, that when he decides to turn in several associates he is 12 hours too late. Someone else squealed before he could."The Friends of Eddie Coyle" opened yesterday at the National and Cinema II Theaters.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, twi lightnight doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 5:30 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 8 P.M.) (RadloWHN, 5:30 P.M.)

title: CITY TO CONTINUE RELIEF COMPUTER
description: The city administration de clared yesterday it would pro ceed with its welfare and Med icaid computerization as rapidly as possible and chal lenge a state notice that last week barred state reimburse ment for future computerizing expenditures.

title: Ehrlichman Sees Blurring of Reforms
description: SEATTLE, June 26 (AP) John D. Ehrlichman, former White Housse adviser, says he fears that the very important things the President did and was trying to do in the domes tic area are going to be lost in the shuffle of the Watergate investigation.

title: Karl's Pushrod Engine Makes New Bid Today
description: Jerry Karl's string of bad luck has to run out some time and it may end today, when he gets another shot at qualifying for the Schaefer 500 at Pocono International Raceway. When he tried last Saturday, the United States Auto Club timers gave him incorrect speed readings on the first two of his scheduled four laps, figures that were 10 miles an hour slower than his actual 183.599 and 183.824. So Karl stepped up his pace and, unfortunate ly, hit the wall. The Smokey Yunick crew rebuilt the EagleChevrolet overnight in time for Sunday's qualifying. Karl was taking his first lap Sunday when his engine Blew.

title: LAW CUTTING JURY TO 6 IS DEPLORED
description: HARTFORD, June 26  A law reducing Superior Court juries in criminal cases in Con necticut from 12 members to six has come under renewed criti cism from trial lawyers and civil libertarians here.

title: Football Transactions AMERICAN CONFERENCE
description: NEW ENGLANDSigned Desmonu Ley, Aus trallan football Player.

title: Private Colleges in Crisis: Costs Rise as Income Dips
description: New Jersey's private col leges are in a financial crush because of a tight money mar ket, rising operating costs, change in youth attitudes and the end of the draft, The Asso ciated Press reports.

title: U.S. FLAG RAISED AT PEKING OFFICE
description: PEKING, June 26 (Reuters)The Stars and Stripes was cere monially raised by uniformed United States marines in Pe king today as the United States liaison office formally opened for business in new redroofed premises near the center of the foreign residential area.

title: Chief of F.P.C. Debates Kennedy on GasPrice Issue
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  John N. Nassikas, chairman of of the Federal Power Commis sion, in a heated exchange with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, testified today that it was im possible to calculate in ad vance exactly how much house holdheating bills would rise if Congress ended Federal regu lation of natural gas wellhead prices.

title: Never Too Old to Fly
description: SANDSPOINT, Idaho, June 26 (UPI)Tom Moran com pleted his solo flight for his pilot's license yesterday. Mr. Moran, a retired electrical engi neer, is 78 years old.

title: Doctors Challenge U.S. Law On Peer Review of Practice
description: Three physicians and an or ganization representing doctors in private practice filed suit yesterday in Federal court in Chicago challenging the consti tutionality of a Federal law re quiring peer review of medical practice.

title: Energy Curbs Urged
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 26 (UPI) The director of the Ford Foundation's energy policy project said today that the Fed eral Government had shown a lack of urgency despite the impending energy crisis. The di rector, S. David Freeman, call ed for a research and develop ment effortof Apollotype intensity and for strict controls on energy use. He spoke to about 9,000 delegates to the 53d annual national. Jaycees conven tion.

title: Court Voids Ban on Giving Jobless Aid in Pregnancy
description: NEW HAVEN, June 26A Connecticut law denying un employment benefits to preg nant women has been declared unconstitutional in a ruling in New Haven by Federal Judge Robert C. Zampano.

title: Man Is Fatally Stabbed In Hotel Near Times Sq.
description: A 25yearold man was stabbed to death and his room mate was wounded last night in what the police said was knife attack by a third man at the Hotel One Twenty Three on 44th Street east of Times Square.

title: 8 Die and 97 Are Missing As Ship Capsizes Off Africa
description: DJIBOUTI, Territory of Afars and Issas, June 26 (Reuters)Eight persons died and 97 were missing after an Indian vessel was abandoned in heavy seas off Cape Guardafui in neigh boring Somalia in the north eastern corner of Africa, the ship's agents said.

title: WATERGATE SHOW BARRED BY 1.1,S.11.
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 The United States Information Agency said today it was barring its facilities to foreign broadcasters sending feature programs abroad on the Water gate scandal since such pro grams may be detrimental to United States interests.

title: Hooton Stops Mets on 4 Hits As Cubs Roll Up 51 Victory
description: Hundreds of the Midget Mets who were admitted free to Shea Stadium yesterday began filing out quietly around the seventh inning with the Mets trailing the Chicago Cubs by four runs. When these young fans, who hope for miracles, don't object to their leaders request to leave early, it has to say some thing about their belief in the Mets.

title: FILIPINOS WILL HOLD VILLAGE ASSEMBLIES
description: MANILA, June 26President Ferdinand E. Marcos has called on the Filipino people to con vene in village assemblies be ginning July 27 to discuss vital issues related to developments here and abroad.

title: Proposed Traffic Limits Peril Paramus Life Style
description: PARAMUS, June 26Though no one expects to see grass growing at the intersection of Routes 4 and 17 here, one of the most heavily traveled in the country, businessmen and poli ticians are slowly awakening to the possibility that traffic limitations proposed under the Clean Air Act of 1970 could profoundly change the life of this town.

title: Red Smith
description: The first time Hank Greenberg served, he and Bobby Riggs won the game with the loss of only 1 point. Riggs grabbed the microphone. How about that for a guy who hit 50 home runs? he asked the gallery, giving Henry wee edge on the records as aging athletes are wont to do. How about the way he plays tennis? And how about us, 117 years old between us, playing these young guys that must add up to around 90? Tony Vincent, junior member of the opposition, plucked the microphone away. How can you talk like that, Bobby, bein the ladykiller like the way you are? Guests at the Nevele Hotel may hear even wittier repartee some nights from the stars who work the Borscht Circuit, but nobody ever left the swimming pool to watch Don Rickles hit a forehand drive. If Bobby Riggs is a sex symbol, Abe Beame is heavyweight champion of the world. The reigning deity of male chauvinism is foureyed, indifferent of build and a bit bandy in the legs. At 55, the hair that covers his nimble brain is still reddish brown but the furry sideburns are gray. Yet the chick who addressed him breathlessly as Mr. Riggs and asked for his autograph had stars in her eyes.

title: U.S. AGENCY OFFERS OLD NAUTICAL MAPS
description: WASHINGTON, June 26A sale of 2,500 collectors item nautical charts was announced today by the National Ocean Survey.

title: Blumenthal Will Stress Beame as Mechanic
description: Albert H. Blumenthal, the Liberal party's candidate for Mayor, will stress in his cam paign against Controller Abra ham D, Bearne the charge that the winner of last night's Dem ocratic runoff primary is just a mechanic, without imagina tion.

title: New Head of A.M.A.
description: When Russell Burton Roth was undergoing surgical training in Pierre, S. D., 32 years ago he was given the title Young Boy Who Dis covered Rock Pile by a Da kota Sioux after performing an operation to remove a gall bladder. Since then Dr. Roth has amassed a large ar ray of titles, in eluding a new one he will re ceive toaay president of the American Med ical Association.

title: Mrs. Evelyn Annenberg Jaffe Wed in London to M. W. Hall
description: LONDON, June 26Mrs. Evelyn Annenberg Jaffe, sis ter of Walter Annenberg, the United States Ambassador to Britain, and Melville Wake man Hall, a retired New York real estate investor, were married here last Friday, The civil ceremony was held at the Caxton Hall Registry Of fice in Westminster.

title: Increase in Phone Rates Seen As a Threat to Independent TV
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) Hughes Sports Network said today that proposed new telephone rates requested by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for tele vising special events would drive many of the smaller in dependent networks out of the business.

title: MRS. BILLY HITCHCOCK
description: OPELIKA, Ala., June 26 (AP) Mrs. Billy Hitchcock, wife of the former major league ball player and manager who is now !president of the Southern League, died yesterday. She was 51 years old.

title: HARRY L. LURIE, 81, OF JEWISH COUNCIL
description: OGUNQUIT, Me., June 26Harry L. Lurie, a social work er, scholar, author and a found er and executive director of the Council of Jewish Federa tions and Welfare Funds, died yesterday at his summer home here. He was 81 years old and lived also at 325 Central Park West, New York.

title: Chavez Union Struggling for Survival
description: COACHELLA, Calif., June 26Despite long picket lines of bannerwaving, impas sioned United Farm Worker Union strikers, the grapes are being harvested from this mountaingirded desert.

title: Dean's Transcript of News Briefing Practice Session
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Following is a transcript of a news briefing practice ses sion, for Ronald L. Ziegler, the Presidential press secre tary, with members of the White House staff, which was referred to yesterday by John W. Dean 3d before the Senate Watergate committee. The transcript was provided by Mr. Dean to the commit tee, which released it today. No date on the practice ses sion was provided, but the transcript indicates it was in midOctober, 1972.

title: 8 U.S. Legislators Will Pay A Visit to China Next Month
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) Four Senators and four House members and their wives will visit China July 2 to 16 to dis cuss trade and other matters.

title: PHILIP C. SCOTT
description: LONG VALLEY, N. J., June 26Philip C. Scott, a member of the New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, died of a heart attack here yesterday. He was 63 years old and lived at Wil low Springs Farm.

title: Source of Fatal Botulism Remains Mystery in Idaho
description: BOISE, Idaho, June 26 (UPI)  State health officials said yesterday that the souce of botulism poisoning that killed an Oregon man and left his daughter and her premature baby critically ill remained mystery.

title: BOMBER RISING IN ALLSTAR POLL
description: Ron Blomberg of the Yan kees, the major leagues only 400 hitter, has moved into the top six in balloting for the first base position on the American League AllStar team, but still has a long way to go to catch the leader, Dick Allen.

title: INFLATION FOUND WORRYING PUBLIC
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 26 (UPI)  Consumers were bub bling with confidence in the economy at the end of 1972, but inflation has burst public confidence, according to a study by economists at the University of Michigan.

title: Strangling of Boy, 3, in Brooklyn Is 3d Recent Child Murder Here
description: The strangling on Monday a 3yearold Brooklyn boy, al legedly by a 14yearold men tally disturbed youth, was the third child murder reported here recently.

title: TV's Profit and Impact
An Uninterested Lindsay Still KeepsEye on Runoff
description: Outwardly, Mayor Lindsaythe most conspicuous noncan didate in town yesterdayap peared to be not overly inter ested in the progress of the Democratic primary runoff.

title: Humbard's College on Mackinac Island Is Shut Down by Flagging Financing and Lawsuits
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 26 Classes at the Rev. Rex Hum bard's Mackinac College have ended, closing another chap ter in the selfordained minis ter's financial career.

title: AIRLINES EXPECTED TO SEEK FARE RISE
description: Edward E. Carlson, president of United Air Lines, told a meeting of security analysts here yesterday that he expects his industry to file with the Civil Aeronautics Board for general fare increase later this year.

title: RICHARDSON TELLS VIEW ON PRIVILEGE
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson told Congress today. that legislation to detail the. limits of the President's execu tive privilege was neither nec essary nor desirable.

title: Democrats File Outlay for Races In Legislature Half Year Late
description: Democrats who ran for the Legislature last year filed their campaign financial statements yesterday, six months beyond the legal deadline.

title: Mrs. King and Miss Evert Triumph at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 26Mrs. Billie Jean King, the defending champion, eradicated stately Lucia Bassi of Italy, 60, 62, in 36 minutes in the Wimbledon tennis champion ships today; 18yearold Chris Evert started uneasily with a 63, 63 victory over Fiorella Bonicelli of Uruguay and then the first reel of the annual hor ror movie was unrolled in gloomy silence on the center court as Dianne Fromholtz, 16yearold lefthander from Australia, quickly dissected the game of Britain's No. 1 player, Virginia Wade.

title: Grain and Soybean Futures Battered
description: CHICAGO, June 26Prices of grains and soybeans were battered here today after the President's. Cost of Living Coun cil announced that it would not ease its rules to permit food prices to rise.

title: Submerged Woman Saved
description: NEW SALEM, Mass., June 26 (AP)A woman was res cued this morning after she was trapped underwater for more than six hours when her car plunged into a small pond. The police said Barbara J. Mc Laren, 20 years old, or Orange, apparently survived by breath ing an air pocket trapped in the car. A passerby noticed Miss McLaren's arm above the water's surface, waving a white plastic bag.

title: Papers in Britain Put Banner on Watergate
description: LONDON, June 26 (AP)Britain's morning newspapers headlined today the first day of testimony of John W. Dean 3d before the Senate Water gate committee

title: Gangster Found Guilty of Lying To Grand Jury on Gallo Killing
description: Vincent Aloi, the reputed head of the Joseph A. Colombo Sr. crime family, was con victed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan last night of lying to the grand jury that investi gated the murder of the gang leader Joseph Gallo. He faces a sevenyear prison sentence.

title: 3 DEAD, ONE ACCUSED IN A MIXED FAMILY
description: IPSWICH, Mass., June 26 [UPI]  A pregnant black mother and her two children were found suffocated here to day. Her white husband was charged with murder after the police found a note saying: I am sorry, but blacks and whites don't mix.

title: Documents in Watergate Case Sought by Prosecutor on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, June 26Local prosecutors will seek a Federal court order to secure documents that are said to implicate John D. Ehrlichman in the planning of the breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: Altair to Resume Flights
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP)Altair Airlines, an East Coast commuter carrier, has announced that its regular serv ice will resume tomorrow, fol lowing a federal court restrain ing order yesterday directing Altair pilots back to work,

title: Panel Is Told White House Urged I.R.S. Political Acts
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Members of the Nixon White House staff made repeated at tempts to get the Internal Revenue Service to conduct political actions and investiga tions but were often balked by the President's own ap pointees to head the agency, according to a document sub mitted today to Senate inves tigators.

title: Ailing Nastase Scores Wimbledon Victory
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 27Wimbledon nearly lost its star today.

title: Moment of Truth
description: LONDON, June 27The United States has had many Presidents who took a broad view of their power under the Constitution but never be fore has any President sought to amend the Constitution by himself brazenly, defiantly, by fiat.

title: Rabbinical Council Urges Ban on Sex and Nude Films
description: FALLSBURG, N. Y., June 27 The Rabbinical Council of America called on Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay today to prohibit the showing of sex and nudity motion pic ture films, which, the council held, were undermining the very moral fabric of our so ciety.

title: Shipbuilder Gets Contract
description: The Commerce Department announced yesterday that the National Steel & Shipbuilding Company of San Diego had been awarded a $112.8million contract to build four tankers, It added that the Maritime Administration would pay $41million of the total con tract as a subsidy for the petroleum carriers. National Steel & Shipbuilding is an affiliate of the Morrison Knudsen Company and the Kaiser Industries Corporation.

title: CUTOFFS FOR POOR AT H.E.W. DENIED
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Caspar W. Weinberger, Secre tary of Health, Education and Welfare, denied today any in tention to cut off health programs for the poor by in sisting that the programs be come financially selfsufficient.

title: Metropolitan's Study Reflects Museums New Attitude
description: The importance of the Metro politan Museum's Report on Art Transactions 19711973, prepared for its members and issued to the press at a con ference on Monday morning, lies less in its potential effect on this one museum's policy than in its reflection of a change in the relationship be tween all Ameri can museums and their public. Ten years ago the prep aration of a 42 page document giving the rationale of the pur chase of certain objects and the sale of others would have been inconceivable except as an exercise in a survey of standard museum procedures.

title: Personal Finance: Savings on Taxes
description: Advance planning can sometimes enable taxpayers to save money on legal bills, provided they have their lawyers cooperation in item izing types of work handled.

title: Transcript of White House Memo on Dean's Senate Testimony and His Comments
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Following is the transcript of a White House memorandum analyzing John W. Dean's. testimony on Watergate, as read during the Senate Water gate committee's hearings to day by Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, and Mr. Dean's comments.

title: Senator Turner Repeats Denial Of Agreeing to a $10,000 Bribe
description: TRENTON, June 27 (UPI) State Senator James M. Turner, Republican of Gloucester, un derwent crossexamination to day in his conspiracy trial on charges that he attempted to frame a Democratic Assembly man in a drug case.

title: Taiwan Opera Troupe Will Tour U.S.
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 27 In what local newspapers have dubbed a cultural of fensive to compete with the Chinese Communists, Taiwan has arranged to send a full scale Peking opera theater troupe on a tour of the United States this fall for the first time.

title: Cosmos No. 576
description: MOSCOW, June 27  The Soviet Union orbited the un manned Cosmos 576 satellite today, with characteristics of a series of military reconnais sance and surveillance missions identified by Western experts. It was placed into an orbit of 132 by 221 miles at an angle of 72.9 degrees to the earth's equator. The missions, usually recovered after 10 days to two weeks, have been launched from the north Russian space center of Plesetsk, according to Western tracking data.

title: Earl Browder Dies
description: Earl Browder, who led the Communist party of the United States as general secretary from 1930 to 1946, its years of greatest influence, died yesterday at 82. Page 50.

title: Minor Leagues
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: Smoking Ban in Oregon
description: SALEM, Ore., June 27 (UPI) Gov. Tom McCall today signed into law a ban on smoking at state government meetings, ef fective immediately.

title: The Screen: 'Live and Let Die' Opens:The Latest James Bond Fights Heroin Ring
description: Torchlight, Voodoo drums. Dark bodies writhe in the mounting frenzy of some unspeakable tropical rite. Suddenly a door is flung open and framed within it stands a beautiful white girl held captive by two monstrous black men. Her filmy white gown scarcely covering the soft contours of her body, she is dragged  protesting  to a crude scaffold and there is tied fast.As if by signal, the ranks of jeering celebrants open and there advances an executioner, laughing, stomping, hideously costumed. He holds a poisonous snake in his outstretched hands, a snake whose bite is destined for the smooth young bosom. . . .Whatever the quality of this little scenario, you must admit that to stick it into a movie these days takes nerve. Merely to make a new adventure movie in which all the bad guys are black and almost all the good guys are white, and which includes in its climax the (near) sacrifice of a (recent) virgintakes nerve.Nerve, and certain insolence toward public pieties, and a lot of canniness about just what level of sophistication its audience is up toall of them qualities that have characterized the James Bond movies since the beginning, 10 years ago, and that abundantly characterize the latest, Guy Hamilton's "Live and Let Die."There are now eight Bond movies, and though they are the work of many different talents (Hamilton has directed two previously: "Goldfinger" and "Diamonds Are Forever") they do represent a recognizable tradition in which the wholeor the memory of the whole  seems to be greater than the sum of the parts.The plots tend to flow into each otherone scheme after another for controlling all the money in the worldchanging their elements to fit changing anxieties (in "Live and Let Die" the evil is a heroin monopoly operating out of some Caribbean island kingdom with pipelines into New York City and New Orleans), but remaining the same in essence.And always there is a woman waiting to be converted by the power of sex. In "Live and Let Die" she reads the Tarot pack to tell fortunes for the enemy. James Bond's card keeps coming up "Lovers," though she thinks she is hoping for "Death."There are three chases (four, if you stretch a point), including one by car and motorboat that gets so complicated it allows for character development. One actor, Clifton James, who appears only during the chase, gets fourth billing in the cast list.The names above Mr. James's do not seem so impressive. Roger Moore is a handsome, suave, somewhat phlegmatic James Bondwith a tendency to throw away his throwaway quips as the minor embarrassments that, alas, they usually are.As Solitaire, to whom the cards speak truth only so long as she remains a virgin, Jane Seymour is beautiful enough, but too submissive even for this scale of fantasy. Yaphet Kotto (Dr. Kananha), a most agreeable actor, simply does not project evil.However, I could list compensating virtues by the score. There is a marvelous escape from an alligator farm (deadly reptiles are rather a motif in this movie), a superb collection of grotesque ways of killing, and a fine sense of pace and rhythm. "Live and Let Die" has been especially well photographed and edited, and it makes clever and extensive use of its good title song, by Paul and Linda McCartney."Live and Let Die" opened yesterday at several local theaters.

title: A MEMO FOR PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The White House, in a counter attack against testimony by John W. Dean 3d that President Nixon was deeply enmeshed in the Watergate coverup, de clared today that Mr. Dean was the coverup mastermind.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Right to Photograph Migrants In Jersey Sought by Newsman
description: BRIDGETON, N. J., June 27 Confronted with a challenge by farmers to the right of news men to photograph migrant la bor camps, civil rights attor neys here announced plans to day to take legal steps to clari fy the issue.

title: Burns Asks Early End to Price Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, urged today an end to the price freeze well before 60 days and an immediate end of the freeze for many food products.

title: The Danger of Doing Nothing
description: WASHINGTON  With the deepen ing dependence of the United States on imported petroleum has come an in creasing awareness of the risks to our national security and the stability of our national economy. The closing of gas stations around the country, the prospect of severe summer shortages, and the readying of plans to ration gasoline on a nationwide basis have brought home to the American people the sense of a problem without an easy solution.

title: Mrs. Hooker, Alberto Mejia Are Wed Here
description: Mrs. Margaret Cartwright Hooker and Alberto Meji Hernandez were married here yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. EdwardGordon Hooker, mother of the bride. Justice Owen McGivern of the State Supreme Court, Appellate Division, performed the ceremony.

title: ' Playtime' a Funny Film, And Tati's Most Brilliant:The Cast
description: "Playtime," which opened yesterday at the Festival Theater, is Jacques Tati's most brilliant film, a bracing reminder in this all-too-lazy era that films can occasionally achieve the status of art."Playtime" is a gloriously funny movie about a Paris so modern it does not yet exist, a Paris composed entirely of streets like our Avenue of the Americas, hemmed in by efficiently beautiful glass-and-steel towers in which, if we are quick about it, we may see momentary reflections of Sacre Coeur, the Arch of Triumph or the Eiffel Tower.It is a city inhabited almost entirely by tourists and their shepherd-guides who are spreading a terrible pox among the natives. It is not an immediately fatal disease but it makes everyone behave with the kind of frigid competence affected by air-line stewardesses and reservation clerks.Not even nuns are immune. Their heels click importantly as they glide across marbleized floors. A receptionista man so ancient that he could be a veteran of Verdunoperates a complex of computer buttons designed to announce a visitor's arrival in an office building. The old man does his best and the machine bleeps and gurgles successfully. It is the world of Kubrick's "2001" without the metaphysics and without Richard Strauss."Playtime," which was made in 1967 and is only now being released in this country, is Tati's most free-form comedy to date, as well as his most disciplined, even more so than "Traffic," which was made in 1971 but was seen here last winter.It is virtually three major set pieces, or acts. The first act is set at Orly Airport, where we pick up some American tourists who arrive in a single, all-expenses-paid clump. The second is more or less devoted to a trade fair, where the tourists cross paths with Tati's Mr. Hulot.The last act, a kind of neon-lit Gotterdammerungis set in a posh nightclub whose opening night turns into the sort of chaos that civilizes. Everything goes wrong, including the air-conditioning, but in going wrong, life is somehow restored to the tourists as well as the natives.You may well recognize the shape of the film, which is a variation on the favorite comedy theme about the family that inherits a lot of money, tries to put on fancy airs, loses it soul, and only finds itself again when the fortune is taken away.However, it is not the shape of the film or its cheerful philosophy that are important. Rather it is the density of the wit. It is the gracefulness of the visual gags that flow one into another, non-stop, in a manner that only Tati now masters.Mr. Hulot is still the nominal focal point of the comedy, particularly in the trade-fair sequence, but he is less in evidence in "Playtime" than in any other Hulot feature. The film is even further removed from character than was "Traffic." It observes not persons, but social clusters, in a manner that serves curiously to humanize group action and response instead of to dehumanize the individual.However, don't waste time analyzing "Playtime" too much. It can easily withstand such critical assaults, but they serve to distract attention from the film's immense good humor, from, for example, the closing sequence that shows us a Parisian traffic circle that has been turned into a giant lazy Susan, serving, among other things, the sacred cause of inefficiency.In addition to everything else, "Playtime" is a reckless act of faithby Tati in himself. He photographed it in 70-mm (though it is being shown here in 35-mm), and he invested not only huge amounts of time in it, but also his own money. As anyone connected with films can tell you, this is certifiable madness.The movie business is supposed to exist so that people other than its artists can lose their shirts in it, thereby to gain things that are called (by those who can use them) tax-loss carry-forwards. I hope "Playtime" will make Tati very rich so that at some future time he can use a tax-loss carry-forward.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein Leads By 3 Shots on Long Island
description: JERICHO, L. I., June 27 Mrs. Walter Cooperstein, the metropolitan titleholder, drew away from the field today as she added a 78 for a 154 total in the 35th women's Long Island medal championship over the waterlogged par72, 5,919yard Meadow Brook Club course.

title: HENRY E. GARRETT, PSYCHOLOGIST, DIES
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 27Dr. Henry Edward Garrett, professor emeritus of psychology at Columbia Uni versity and president of the American Psychological Assoc iation in 1946, died yesterday at Martha Jefferson Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived here.

title: Heavy Voting Expected in Ulster Today
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 27  With Northern he land due to vote tomorrow on its new assembly and its in ture, one part of the British plan to restore normality to the province is clearly succeeding.

title: RENT PLAN STAYS SAME FOR 300,000
description: In the year beginning next Sunday, residents of 300,000 rentstabilized apartments here will be able to renew expiring leases under the same rentin crease limitations that pre vailed since last July 1, the Lindsay Administration an nounced yesterday.

title: Judge Overruled on Limit For Legal Aid Case Loads
description: The United States Court of Appeals here ruled yesterday that Federal District Judge Or rin G. Judd overstepped his authority last May when he tried to limit the number of cases that Legal Aid Society lawyers could handle in Brook lyn Supreme Court.

title: STOCKS EDGE UP IN AMEX TRADING
description: A late surge sent prices slightly on the American Exchange yesterday after had seesawed through most the session. Prices also in overthecounter trading trading was unspectacular both markets.

title: Gaining Perspective
description: What elsewhere are regarded as problems, in the United States become magnified into crisesthe urban crisis, the school crisis, the dollar crisis, the environmental crisis, the energy crisis, the Watergate crisis.

title: GOVERNOR VETOES SUNDAYSALE BILE
description: ALBANY, June 27  Gover nor Rockefeller vetoed a bill that attempted to clarify the tangled maze of laws on Sun dayselling in the state, and signed a measure that gives sizable tax benefit to the New York Telephone Company, his office said today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Marine P.O.W., 24, Charged With Collaboration, Kills Himself
description: COMMERCE CITY, Colo., June 27 (AP)  A young mar ine charged with collaborating with the enemy while in North Vietnam prison camp shot himself to death today, the police said.

title: TEST WITH NIXON BUSIES CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The confrontation between Presi dent Nixon and Congress over the United States bombing of Cambodia heightened today as Mr. Nixon vetoed one move to halt the raids.

title: 5 Indicted in Investigation Of Graft in Passaic County
description: TRENTON, June 27A state grand jury investigating al leged corruption among law enforcement officials in Passaic County handed up five sealed indictments here this afternoon that were reported to name a county lawenforcement official and another one from Pater son.

title: RALLY EXTENDED BY STOCK MARKET
description: The stock market extended its rally into a second consec utive session yesterday in a display of strength that dis pelled some of the gloom hang ing over the investment com munity.

title: TradeTalk Negotiations
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 27 Ever so slowly, the world's greatest trade negotiations are moving forward as the two big gest forces in world trade, the United States and the European Economic Community, try to determine each other's position.

title: A.M.C. Is 4th Auto Maker To Ask Delay of '76 Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 27An American Motors Corporation executive testified today that it would be absolutely impos sible for the company to meet the 1976 Federal clean air standard for reducing oxides of nitrogen from auto exhausts.

title: Communist Mortar Barrage Pins Vietnam Truce Team
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27 (Reuters)Members of an international ceasefire observa tion team were caught in a barrage of Communist mortar fire east of Saigon yesterday during an inspection of the site of an alleged truce violation.

title: Discovery of Truth
description: At the core, it has now become one man's word against another's. John W. Dean 3d, a heretofore obscure young lawyer, and Richard M. Nixon, President of the United States, are now on public record in conflict on some vital points related to the Watergate conspiracy and its aftermath. These points are crucial to the determina tion whether or not specific crimes were committed the highest level of the United States Government. Much of the next phase in the various Watergate investigations will have to focus ultimately on the relative credibility of these two men, based on their testimony, their records and the availability of corroboration for their differing accounts. The tough, pointbypoint verbal duel yester day between Mr. Dean and the White House, through Senator Inouye's dramatic interrogation, brings the clash to a headon collision.

title: The Adversary's Book
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The text for today's sermon is Job 31:35, in which the bedeviled Job, who cannot understand why everything in his life has suddenly gone wrong, cries out: Oh that mine adversary had written a book!

title: Isabel Goldsmith Married to Baron
description: PARIS, June 27Miss Isabel Goldsmith, daughter of Jimmy Goldsmith, who heads one of Britain's largest stores and food conglomerates, was married here today to Baron Arnaud de Rosnay.

title: Excerpts From the. Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Following are excerpts from a transcript of the testimony on the 14th day of hearings on the Watergate case today before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

title: Basketball Transactions
description: BUFFALODropped Doug Little, Mike Lee, Aaron Covington, Bob Vartanlan, Ron Thor son, and Mike Jones, guards; John Farley, Phil Tollestrup, and Jim Chesser, forwards, and Curtis Biackmore, center.

title: House Votes $46.3Million Cut in Arts Budget
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  The House voted today to trim $46.3million from the Nixon Administration's budget for the arts and humanities.

title: POLICEMAN HELD AS A PAID SLAYER
description: A 29yearold patrolman, scribed by law enforcement sources as a moonlighting man, was charged yesterday with the murder last August of a reputed drug dealer Manhattan.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: In late spring and early summer, when striped bass and bluefish make their ap pearance along the East Coast from New Jersey to Cape Cod, this writer re. ceives many requests from those who would like to try surf casting for the first time.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Senate, 960, Approves Kelley As New Director of the F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Clarence M. Kelley, President Nixon's nominee as director of the Federal Bureau of Investi gation, was confirmed by the Senate today, 96 to 0.

title: Burns Wary on Floating Rate, Calls Dollar Decline Unjustified
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board said today that the present system of largely floating currency exchange rates was bound to continue for an indefinite period and has advantages.

title: Einstein Theory Will Be Tested in Eclipse
description: ABOARD THE CANBERRA, En Route to the African Eclipse Area, June 25At a picturesque oasis deep in the Sahara whose fort was once defended by the French Foreign Legion, scientists from the University of Texas are preparing what they hope will be the, most precise test of Einstein's general theory of relativity yet devised.

title: A Mysterious Power Frederick Cheney LaRue
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Frederick Cheney LaRue, who pleaded guilty today to ob struction of justice and will now help the Government prosecute the Watergate cov erup, is a Mississippi oil heir who for the last five years was an intimate friend and political lieutenant of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey. daily lottery number yester day was: 41622

title: GAS PIPELINE ROUTE SET BY CONSORTIUM
description: TORONTO, June 27 (Canadian. Press)A route for a natural! ;gas pipeline south from the, Mackenzie Delta and the North! Slope in Alaska has been agreed upon by the 26 partici pating concerns in Canadian; Arctic Gas Study, Ltd.

title: Market Place: Institutions And Investors
description: The letter had a pensive quality. The writer, a reader of this newspaper and an investor, said that if only the Little Guy could get out of the Big Guy's way, Maybe the Little Guy could make some money in the stock market.

title: Ban Lifted on Norwegian Zapata Bid
description: A Federal Court judge in Houston cleared the way yes terday for Hilmar Reksten, a Norwegian shipowner, to make an official offer to buy the stock of the Zapata Corpora tion, a Texasbased company with extensive shipping inter ests. Mr. Reksten is understood to be interested in offering about $38 a share, or a total of about $200 million, for the company but has not yet ap plied to the Secur ities and Exchange Commission for authorization.

title: At Least 20 Are Drowned As Ship Sinks in Philippines
description: MANILA, the Philippines, Thursday, June 28 (AP)  An interisland ship carrying 400 passengers sank yesterday and at least 20 persons were killed, a Philippine Coast Guard spokesman said today. He said that frogmen were trying to determine whether as many as 50 others might be trapped alive in the vessel.

title: Nixon Should Testify, Senator Montoya Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI)  Senator Joseph M. Montoya, Democrat of New Mexico, said today that it might be necessary for Pres ident Nixon to appear before the Senate Watergate com mittee to repel charges by his former counsel, John W. Dean 3d, of complicity in the scandal's coverup.

title: Faint Heart Ne'er Won a Tough Chess Tournament
description: LENINGRADFor more than three weeks the egos were strung out in pairs across the broad stage of Leningrad's Dzerzhinsky Palace of Culture, as 18 of the world's best chess players struggled for supremacy in the Interzonal Tournament to pick three candidates for a chance to challenge Bobby Fischer for the world title.

title: Panel Is T old White House Urged I.R.S. Political Acts
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Members of the Nixon White House staff made repeated at tempts to get the Internal Revenue Service to conduct political actions and investiga tions but were often balked by the President's own ap pointees to head the agency, according to a document sub mitted today to Senate inves tigators.

title: Met Opens Outdoor Opera Season
description: Of all the musical organ izations that perform out doors in the summer, none appears more unlike its usual self than the Metropolitan Opera. Stripped of stage ac tion, costumes, sets and most of its principal singers, the company takes on an anony mity that would make it un identifiable if the name were not announced or printed on programs.

title: Poodles Growing Into a Big Problem In French Circles
description: Mrs. Robert Monod of Paris, one of the top Gallic fanciers, who has had 24 in ternational champions in the two decades she's been ac tive with the breed, ex pressed concern about the poodle in her native land. Our minia tures run from 35 centimeters to 45 centimet ers [14 to 18 inches], she said. That's really too big for a miniature and too small for a standard. Our stand ard poodles are far too small. They cannot be above 55 centimeters [21 inches; in the United States the minia tures run from over 10 to 15 inches and the standard from over 15].

title: Notes on People
description: First it was cigarettes, and next it will be books, if Wilma Scott Heide, president of the National Organization of Women, has her way. Tell ing the 92d conference of the American Library Associa tion in Las Vegas that 95 per cent of all books in United States libraries are sexist, she went on to say: As a civil libertarian I do not pro pose that we burn all books that are sexist, but I might suggest you place disclaim ers in such books, warning that the sexism in these books may be harmful and dangerous to your health.

title: Pompidou, Alter Brezhnev Talk, Says Pacts Do Not Limit France
description: PARIS, June 27  President Pompidou and Leonid I. Brezh nev today ended two days of talks in which the French leader apparently warned that France would not be bound by bilateral SovietAmerican ac cords affecting European secur ity.
