title: BIG BOARD IS TAKING ACTION ON SHASKAN
description: The New York Stock Ex change said yesterday it had issued formal disciplinary charges against Shaskan & Co., Inc., alleging that the brokerage firm had filed erroneous fi nancial reports with the Big Board and had violated net capital and other rules.

title: Grand Jury Refuses to Charge 2 Policemen in Shooting of a 3d
description: A Manhattan grand jury has refused to return criminal charges against the two police men who shot Police Of ficer Irving Wright March 5, the Manhattan District At torney's office disclosed yes terday.

title: NIXON AIDE TRACE SECRET BARK FUNS
description: WASHINGTON, June 27An accountant for the Nixon re election committee, in a sworn deposition, has described in de tail the alleged use of a secret bank account, spawned jealousies within the organiza tion and kept secret for a time from top officials.

title: Text of Nixon's Veto Message on Money Bill and Cambodia Rider
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 27 (AP)Following is the text of President Nixon's message to the House of Rep resentatives today vetoing. a $3.4billion supplemental appropriation bill that includ ed a ban on United States bombing in Cambodia:

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Mead ow, Queens, 2 P.M. (RadioWHN, 2 P.M.)

title: Greek Political Party Appears, First Under the Athens Regime
description: ATHENS, June 27The first political party to be formed in Greece since 1967, when the military seized power and banned political activity, was introduced to the press in Athens today.

title: 2 in J.D.L. Cleared In Hurok Bombing
description: Bombing charges against two Jewish Defense League mem bers were dismissed in Federal Court here yesterday because two essential witnesses refused to testify despite an angry ju'dge's warning about criminal contempt.

title: PANEL GIVEN DATA
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The White House, in a counter attack against testimony by John W. Dean 3d that President Nixon was deeply enmeshed in the Watergate coverup, de clared today that Mr. Dean was the coverup mastermind.

title: Bargain Basement
description: What ails the stock marketand how can it be cured? Unfortunately, the doctorson Wall Street, in Washing ton and in the universitiesare not agreed even on the symptoms of the disease, let alone Its cure. As the cur rent issue of Money magazine notes, the DowJones average of thirty industrial stocks is about where it was five years ago, the Value Line index of 1,450 stocks has dropped 50 per cent, butjhe Vickers index of institu tional favorites has nearly doubled.

title: ICECAPADE SNAPS RECORD IN STAKES
description: Icecapade, competing in the silks of Mrs. Donald McVarish, won the Nassau County Handi cap, a sevenfurlong sprint that featured the program at Aqtie duct yesterday.

title: Picking of Principal Brings On a SitIn At Brooklyn School
description: The selection of a new elementaryschool principal in Brooklyn's Community District 18 led last night to a sitin at the school and charges that two members of the local board! had been working illegally in district schools.

title: Philip Glass Works To Broaden Scope Beyond In Crowd
description: Philip Glass, the avantgarde composer, has been making an effort of late to broaden his audience beyond the in crowd that attends concerts of new music in this city.

title: Judge Is Overruled on Limiting Legal Aid Lawyers Case Load
description: The United States Court of Appeals here ruled yesterday that Federal District Judge Or rin G. Judd overstepped his authority last May when he tried to limit the number of cases that Legal Aid Society lawyers could handle in Brook lyn Supreme Court.

title: CONTEMPT RULING CITES GREYHOUND
description: CHICAGO June 27 AP  A Federal judge ruled today that the Greyhound Corporation was guilty of criminal con tempt for failure to comply with an earlier order regard ing competition with Pacific Trailways, Inc., in the Pacific Northwest.

title: I achman Expected to Be Named
description: Dr. Seymour P. Lachman, who nearly gave up his mem bership on the city's Board of Education last year and who again considered the possibil ity in recent weeks, is now expected to be elected presi dent of the board.

title: Mass Transit Barrier
description: Last November, Governors Rockefeller and Cahill an nounced what they called a dramatic and significant breakthrough in the effort of New York and New Jersey to involve the Port Authority in the development of vitally needed mass transit facilities. Last week the Port Authori ty sold $100 mil lion worth of its bonds to an eager investinent com munity  people who, bond special ists say, never would have touched those securities if the Port Authority was to be forced to spend the proceeds of the issue on subways or conunuter railroads.

title: Some Who Made Dean's List Honored
description: There were 20 names culled from the list of enemies submitted to John W. Dean 3d, then counsel to the Presi dent, by Charles W. Colson, then White House special counselor. When they learned yesterday of their official elevation to the select White House hall of infame, some of these public enemies num ber 1 to 20 were delighted to even the score.Sidney Davidoff, a former aid to Mayor Lindsay of New York, was cited as a first class s.o.b., wheeler dealer and suspected bagman.I admit to being a first class s.o.b., said Mr. David off, who now runs a New York restaurant called Jim my's, where the favorite ini tials are really S.R.O. But it's hard for me to conceive of a Jewish boy from Brook lyn making it this way. From Manhattan I would have un derstood it easier. He con tinued:My first reaction was, Why me and not Dick Aure liowho runs this restaurant with me? He didn't indicate he was upset at being left off t he enemies list, but I have my suspicions.Now that I've made this list I have no more ambi tions in life. How do you top Public Enemy Number One? The first thing I did was call my mother in Florida and as sure her it was a good list. She wasn't sure if it was a good list or a bad list, and I assured her it was a good one.Maxwell Dane, retired chairman of the advertising firm of Doyle, Dane and Bernhach, was cited for his firm's work. They destroyed Goldwater in '64, said the list's citation.

title: Israel Expands Town In Occupied Territory
description: KIRYAT ARM, IsraeliOccu pied Jordan, June 26Under a scorching sun a huge crane lifts prefabricated concrete walls into place atop the shell of an apartment building. Bulldozers push tons of rocky brown soil aside for the foundation of a synagogue.

title: Survey of Investors
description: Many small investors believe the securities industry favors large institutional investors and that these institutions receive inside information, according to a study released yesterday by the New York Stock Ex change.

title: STARS TOP COSMOS ON TROST'S GOAL, 21
description: ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) The St. Louis Stars rallied from a 10 halftime deficit tonight to slip past the New York Cosmos, 21, and into the North American Soccer League South ern Division lead.

title: Chile Declares Emergency in Capital Region After Disorders
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June The Government declared state of emergency tonight in the Province of Santiago in cluding the capital  because of disorders resulting from an incident in which the Com mander in Chief of the Army allegedly fired a shot at a car driven by a woman who had insulted him.

title: Soybeans and Cottonseed Under Export Embargo
description: WASHINGTON, June 27In a move to prevent food short ages and hold down prices, the Government imposed export controls late today on soybeans and cottonseed and the meal and oil produced from them, with an embargo on export shipments at least until Mon day.

title: North Korea Notifies U.N. It Plans Observer's Office
description: TOKYO, June 27 (AP)  North Korea said today it had advised Secretary General Waldheim of the United Na tions of its decision to set up a permanent observer's office at the United Nations center at Geneva.

title: SCORES OF NAMES
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  John W. Dean 3d told the Sen ate Watergate committee today that the White House lists of political enemies filled a file several inches thick.

title: Arthur Daley
description: It was as unlikely and as spectacular a finish as ever was produced in the National Football League, an organi zation with a predilection for preposterous finishes. Six months have passed since the bizarre ending of the playoff game between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Oakland Raiders, a game that the Steelers apparently had lost with 65 seconds left to play, but reclaimed with only five seconds showing on the clock.

title: Cooper Union's 1,000Acre Green Camp In Ringwood to Be BrokenUp and Sold
description: Cooper Union, New York City's last tuitionfree private college, has decided to sell most of its 1,000acre Green Camp in Ringwood, N. J., which had served as a retreat for students, faculty and alumni for more then 30 years.

title: After a Polite Opening, Gurney and Dean Fence
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 The Senate Watergate hear ings turned into a verbal fencing match for more than three hours today, but if any blood was drawn it could probably have been sopped up by a BandAid.

title: Earl Browder, ExCommunist Leader, Dies at 82
description: Earl Browder, general secre tary of the Communist party of the United States in the years of its largest membership and greatest influence, died yester day in Princeton, N. J. He was 82 years old and had been in frail health for years as a result of a stroke. Hehad lived at 21 Maple Street with his son Wil liam, chairman of the mathe matics department at Princeton University.

title: U. S. AIDE ACCUSES 3 GAS PRODUCERS; Senior F.T.C. Official Says Gulf, Union and Continental Understate Reserves; FIGURES ARE COMPARED
DR. HAROLD DIEHL OF CANCER SOCIETY
description: Dr. Harold S. Diehl, a former director of research and medi cal affairs at the American Cancer society, died yesterday of heart disease at United Hos pital in St. Paul, where he was visiting. He was 81 years old and lived, at 11 Riverside Drive.

title: Warner's Attempt to Purchase Sterling Communications Fails
description: Warner Communications, Inc., and Sterling Communications, Inc., announced yesterday that they had been unable to reach a definitive agreement for the sale of Sterling Manhattan Cable Television and other Sterling subsidiaries to Warner.

title: Ali Is Already in Shape Vocally for Return Bout With Norton
description: The jaw may have been broken, but Muhammad Ali's mouth continues to work.

title: Chess: For 3 Interzonal Winners It's On to the Next Big Step
description: LENINGRAD, June 26 There is still one round to be played in the Interzonal Tournament, but the top three finishers, who qualify for the elimination matches to pick Bobby Fischer's challenger for the world title, are already decided.

title: DEATH OF OFFICER HEED.ACCIDENTAL
description: A Manhattan grand jury has refused to return criminal charges against the two police men who shot Police Of ficer Irving Wright March 5, the Manhattan District At torney's office disclosed yes terday.

title: Roundup: Clyde, With Eyes of Texas on Him, T ops Twins in Debut
description: David Clyde, the Houston schoolboy who had pitched nine nohitters for West chester High School, made his major league debut for the Texas Rangers last night in Arlington Stadium. The 18yearold lefthander allowed one hit in his fiveinning stint as the Rangers beat the Minnesota Twins, 43, before a sellout crowd of 35,698.

title: Bridgv:Chagas of Brazil Is Placed Among the Best in Tourney
description: At the end of the world championship in Brazil last month, Pietro Forquet of Italy was named the best player in the tournament. His teammate and former partner, Benito Garozzo, had turned in an equally fine performance, and was no doubt considered for the award.

title: U. S. Raids Go On, but Ground Fighting in Cambodia Is Reported Off
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 27  American combat planes were still attacking enemy positions in Cambodia today but the intensity of ground fighting seemed much less than usual during the last week.

title: Mets Defeat Phils, 76, Then Suffer 71 Loss
FASHION TALK
description: When the haggling was go ing on recently over the Coty Awards, some candidates for the designers honor were put down for being too European influenced.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Charles Leads Scottish Open

title: DR. FRANK DE FURIA, TAUGHT PEDIATRICS
description: Dr. Frank Guy de Furia, as sistant professor of pediatrics and medicine at Cornell Uni versity Medical College and as sistant attending physician at the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center, died at his home Monday after a brief ill ness. He was 34 years old and lived at 435 East 70th Street.

title: ARTHUR P. JACOBS, FRI PRODUCER, 51
description: HOLLYWOOD, June 27 (UPI)  Arthur P. Jacobs, the film producer, died today, appar ently of a heart attack. He was 51 years old.

title: Top Democrats Endorse Beame in a Show of Unity
description: Top Democrats, including Senator George McGovern and Howard J. Samuels, endorsed City Controller Abraham Beame for Mayor yesterday in a rare display of Democratic party unity. The endorsements for the victor in Tuesday's runoff primary heralded what the Beame forces hopes will be a bandwagon that will head off largescale defections to two other Democrats in the mayoral race, Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal and Representative Mario Biaggi, who are, respectively, the Liberal and Conservative can didates.

title: Film: 'Charley and Angel':The Cast
description: "Cinderella," the cartoon-revival half of a current Walt Disney package, is far and away the better part of yesterday's double-bill at the Guild and Quad I Theaters. Wise parents will time it so that the youngsters see this treat first. The new live-action comedy, "Charley and the Angel," can be taken as a tame, friendly caboose.The only real fun, judging by audience squeals at the Guild, is the finale, involving some wildly-flapping old flivver cars, as Fred MacMurray tries to rescue his two young sons from gangster-bootleggers. The kids loved this careening chaos. Otherwise, they had to settle for spurts of familiar trick photography, as a natty "angel" popped in to remind Mr. MacMurray, a stodgy business man, that he wasn't getting any fun out of life.Otherwise, nothing much happens. The picture, set in the Depression years, has a mildly diverting facade of nostalgia in costumes, tunes and those fine, tacky old cars. Mr. MacMurray, by now a Disney veteran, is front and center, unremittingly wide-eyed.Little sparkle or wit is accorded as appealing a family as any papa could wish. But Cloris Leachman as his wife, Kathleen Coty, Vincent Van Patten and little Scott Kolden do pleasantly by humdrum material. The same goes for Harry Morgan as the wry visitor from above, young Kurt Russell and, very minutely, Barbara Nichols.Master Kolden wedges in on bright, morning-after breakfast line after Mr. MacMurray is picked up, sipping lemonade, during a mild-looking roadhouse raid by police. "Hey, Pop," he chirps, "how was it in the clink?" The rest, until that chase, is pretty much milk and crackers.

title: ONLY 30% IN A POLL BACK 6YEAR TERM
description: Continued disapproval by the American public for changing the term of office of the Presi dent to one sixyear term with no reelection was indicated in a Gallup Poll survey released yesterday.

title: Pillsbury Profits Off in Quarter but Up for Year
Fire Fatal to 29 Persons Still Being Investigated
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 27 (AP)Investigators have com pleted checking the evidence taken from a French Quarter bar in which 29 persons died Sunday night, but a spokesman today termed the evidence in conclusive.

title: Suffolk Seeks 56Day Meet
description: BOSTON, June 27 (UPI) Suffolk Downs has applied to the State Racing Commission for a 56day thoroughbred meeting to run Sept. 3 to Dec. 9, officials announced today. The 56day request stems from a measure recently ap proved by the state legislature adding 50 days of thoroughbred racing.

title: TEST INTENSIFIES
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 27  President Nixon today vetoed a bill that would have cut off all funds for the bomb ing of Cambodia. He said a total halt in American air operations would undercut diplomatic ef forts for a ceasefire, jeopardize the Paris agreement for peace in all of Indochina and strike a blow at America's international credibility.

title: Doctor Charged With Murder In Long Island Mercy Killing
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 27  The chief surgical resident of the Nassau County Medical Center was indicted today on a charge of willful murder the Nassau County District At torney described as a Mercy killing.

title: Shift of U.N. Council's Debate On Mideast to Geneva Is Sought
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 27Kenya, India and some other Security Council members are trying to have the Middle East debate shifted next month from New York to Geneva. The proposal is run ning into strong opposition from the United States and Britain.

title: New Jersey Platforms
description: In New Jersey, both parties have prepared draft ver sions of campaign platforms in this gubernatorial elec tion year, which party members at state conventions are expected to debate and to adopt today.

title: Book Turns Those Recommendations Into Recipes
description: How can one criticize a lifesaving effort?

title: Text of 2 Memos on I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Following are two memoran dums on how the White House could use the Internal Revenue Service for political advantages, submitted to the Watergate committee today by John W. Dean 3d, former White House counsel. Mr. Dean told the committee that the memos are undated, it is the request of H. R. Halde man, former White House chief of staff, for the Secre tary of the Treasury. Since the memo is undated, it is unclear whether they were prepared for David Kennedy or John Connally, both for mer Treasury Secretaries. Mr. Dean said he prepared the first memo and that John Caulfield prepared the second memo.

title: DUN &
description: The Appellate Division of the United States Federal Court in New York has upheld a jury's finding against Dun & Brad street, Inc., which in June of 1969 awarded the plaintiff more than $6million, it was learned yesterday.

title: ExMental Patient Held in Coed Death
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 27  A 25yearold former mental patient from New Hyde Park was arrested by Nassau Coun ty detectives today and charged with the June 18 mur der of Patricia Ann Sullivan, 21, a student at the C.W. Post Center of Long Island Univer sity.

title: Blue Shield Seeks 36.9% Rise In Rates for Public Employes
description: The Blue Shield medical and surgical insurance plan has asked for a 36.9 per cent rate increase to renew its contract with the city administration for 140,000 public employes and their dependents. It said it was under a state Insurance Depart ment mandate that the con tract become selfsupporting.

title: Man Held for Robbery Indicted in Slaying of Priest
description: A 28yearold man arrested last month on a 1968 robbery charge was indicted yesterday in the murder of a Roman Catholic priest in St. Albans, Queens, last May 13.

title: ARTIFICIAL TURF GETS TIE IN STUDY
description: Charlie Caldwell, the out standing Princeton coach who died in 1957, made this com ment about football injuries 20 years ago. The body position man most often assumes when playing football is that of a squat. It's unnatural and so people get hurt. Gorillas would be great at this game.

title: Marchi Begins Campaign Insisting He Is Underdog
description: Cheerful and selfeffacing, State Senator John J. Marchi of Staten Island slipped into his second Republican cam paign for Mayor yesterday with a characteristically lowkey handshaking stop at Lexington Avenue and 86th Street.

title: Man Held for Robbery Indicted in Slaying of Priest
description: A 28yearold man arrested last month on a 1968 robbery charge was indicted yesterday in the murder of a Roman Catholic priest in St. Albans, Queens, last May 13.

title: Fiasconaro Runs 800 Meters In 1:43.71, Setting World Mark
description: MILAN, Italy, June 27 (UPI) The South Africanborn Ital ian, Marcello Fiasconaro, set world record of 1 minute 43.71 seconds for the 800meter run tonight during an ItaloCzecho slovak track meet.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Models Kick Off Special $3 Lottery Six girl models in jockey attire rode through midtown yesterday to symbolize the opening day of ticket sales in the New York State Lottery's $3 Summer Special. Tax Commissioner Norman Gallman said the new $3 Special would combine features of. the lottery's two previous specials and also add new features.

title: Ernest Truex, Actor in Films, Theater and TV, Is Dead at 83
description: Ernest Truex, the versatile actor who made hundreds of appearances here and abroad in the theater, films and tele vision, died on Tuesday at his home in Fallbrook, Calif. He was 83 years old.

title: Fiasconaro Runs 800 Meters In 1:43.71, Setting World Mark
description: MILAN, Italy, June 27 (UPI) The South Africanborn Ital ian, Marcello Fiasconaro, set world record of 1 minute 43.71 seconds for the 800meter run tonight during an ItaloCzecho slovak track meet.

title: Tunisian Chief Still Steadfast Moderate on Israel
description: TUNIS, June 27President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia came close to being stoned in Palestinian refugee camp in 1965 for suggesting that the Arab countries and Israel might find a way to live side by side and that continuous war against Israel was a vain enterprise.

title: Secret Service Director Says That Most of $1.9Million Spent on Nixon's Homes Was for Security
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 The director of the Secret Set vice told a House subcommitte today that most of the $1.9 million in public funds spen on President Nixon's privete homes in San Clemente, Calif., and Key Biscayne, Fla., had been requested by his agency to assure the President's security and safety.

title: COURT REVERSES BERRIGAN RULINGS
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 27A Federal Court of Appeals here has reversed the conviction on six of seven counts of smug gling letters into and out of a Federal prison levied against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and Sister Elizabeth McAlister who is now Mrs: Berrigan in 1972.

title: Ali Is Already in Shape Vocally for Return Bout With Norton
description: The jaw may have been broken, but Muhammad Ali's mouth continues to work.

title: G.E. and Exxon Jointly to Study Uranium Enrichment Program
description: The General Electric Com pany and the Exxon Nuclear Company, Inc., announced yes terday they would undertake a joint threephase study of the technology and economics of uranium enrichment by private industry. The study will focus on the gas centrifuge method.

title: Soybeans and Cottonseed Under Export Embargo
description: WASHINGTON, June 27In a move to prevent food short ages and hold down prices, the Government imposed export controls late today on soybeans and cottonseed and the meal and oil produced from them, with an embargo on export shipments at least until Mon day.

title: Justice Agency Sues G.E. For $21Million in Damages
description: WASHINGTON, Jun e 27 (UPI)The Justice Department filed today a civil suit against the General Electric Company seeking $21,322,759 in damages for alleged breach of a con tract with the atomic energy Commission. Attorney General Elliot. L. Richardson said the suit was filed at United States District Court in Spokane, Wash.

title: YANKEES SUBDUED BY ORIOLES, 4 TO 0
description: BALTIMORE, June 27Dave McNally of the Orioles, plagued this season by some bad breaks that had kept his wonlost rec ord looking anemic while his earnedrun average looked healthy, got some good breaks tonight as he scattered 10 hits to stop the New York Yankees, 40, before a crowd of 24,745 in Memorial Stadium.

title: TV: C.B.S. Views Social Security and News Story
description: The news department of the Columbia Broadcasting System is getting another of its occasional, very occasion al priinetime showcases this evening for two new C.B.S. Reports productions: at 9 o'clock, You'll get Yours When You're 65 and, at 10, Anatomy of a News Story. The executive producer for both is Burton Benjamin.

title: Earl Browder Dies
description: Earl Browder, who led the Communist party of the United States as general secretary from 1930 to 1946, its years of greatest influence, died yesterday at 82. Page 50.

title: YORKVILLE ZONING STIRS BIG DEBATE
description: Yorkville residents debated sharply yesterday with real estate owners and businessmen at a City Planning Commission hearing on a proposal to estab lish a special limited commer cial district on 86th Street be tween Lexington and Third Avenues.

title: POLICEMAN HELD AS A PAID SLAYER
description: A 29yearold patrolman, de scribed by law enforcement sources as a moonlighting hit man, was charged yesterday with the murder last August of a reputed drug dealer in Manhattan.

title: LOUIS COSTIN
description: Louis Costin, a compositor for The New York Times from 1936 until his retirement in 1963, died Monday at Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 82 years old and lived at 2802 Parsons Bou levard, Flushing.

title: Major League Baseball
description: National League YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: United Church of Christ Synod Leaders Optimistic About Easing of Faith Crisis
description: ST. LOUIS, June 27Lead ers of the United Church of Christ, a liberal Protestant de nomination that two years ago officially acknowledged it was deeply involved in the con temporary faith crisis, ex pressed optimism this week that the church now has the means to move creatively out of that crisis.

title: SCHOOL AID STIRS DEBATE IN HOUR
description: WASHINGTON, June 27A concept called, in Federal Gov ernment language, Hold Harm less that would take school aid funds from large urban states and give them to small er rural and Southern states has stirred a controversy in the House of Representatives.

title: ExMental Patient Held in Coed Death
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 27  A 25yearold former mental patient from New Hyde Park was arrested by Nassau Coun ty detectives today and charged with the June 18 mur der of Patricia Ann Sullivan, 21, a student at the C.W. Post, Center of Long Island Univer sity.

title: FIVE YOUTHS RIOT IN BROOKLYN RIOT
description: At least five youths were shot and five policemen in jured last night as rioting erupted along a tense thorough fare in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: MONTCLAIR CASE STILL A MYSTERY
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 27 Teams of investigators from the Essex County Prosecutor's office, the police and members of the detective division of the Montclair Police Department have been seeking an answer to a question that has doggedly disturbed this busy and affluent community for more than a month:

title: People and Business
description: Frederick D. Watkins, president of the Aetna In surance Company, believes that every company ought to do what it can to ease the nation's gasoline shortage. So this week he offeredan incentive to the 950 employ es of his Hartfordbased company to form car pools.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 27 (UPI)Bob Charles of New Zealand made a 40foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today for a oneshot firstround lead in the $37,500 Scottish open golf championship. He had a fiveunderpar 67. The British Ryder Cup captain, Bernard Hunt, was second.

title: INVESTORS GROUP SETS GOAL IN SUIT
description: Richard A. Gordon, president of the Independent Investor Protective League, said yester day his group hopes to find out the names of New York Stock Exchange member firms under intensive surveillance.

title: Ferraro Is Nominated for D.A. of Queens
description: State Senator Nicholas Fer raro was chosen yesterday to be the Democratic nominee for Queens District Attorney. He was selected at a meeting of district leaders at county Dem ocratic headquarters 7250 Aus tin Street, Forest Hills, by a vote of 51 to 3 with two ab stentions.

title: Agnew Not Upset by Report Of Inquiry About Him in '68
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) Vice President Agnew said today that he was not dis turbed by reports that Presi dent Johnson ordered the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation late in 1968 to investigate i whether Mr. Agnew had been the source of leaks about the Vietnam peace negotiations in Paris.

title: 4 Hanged in South Africa
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, June 27 (Reuters)  Four men were hanged on murder charges in the Central Prison here to day, bringing the total number of people hanged in South Africa this year to 23. Accord ing to records filed at the Su preme Court, three of the executed men were black Afri cans and one was of mixed race.

title: Family Service Elects
description: Louis Lowenstein, a lawyer here, was elected president of the board of directors of Jewish Family Service at its annual meeting. Mr. Lowenstein, who succeeds Robert A. Levinson as president, is a partner in the firm of Nickerson, Kramer, Lowenstein, Nessen & Kamin.

title: Pentagon Says Truce Permits Cut in Aid to Vietnam and Laos
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The Defense Department told Senate committee today that the Indochina ceasefire agree ments would permit a reduction of at least $500million in planned military aid to South Vietnam and Laos in the fiscal year beginning next Sunday, July 1.

title: Advertising: Money Is Talking
description: Money talks. So does its publisher. And yesterday he said that the new magazine is doing better than top management at Time, Inc. thought it would be doing after so short a time.

title: Welfare Cases in Times Square Called a Spur to Crime
description: The city's Human Resource Administration, through its wel fare arm, is placing hundred of drug addicts, mental case and other unstable people into some 20 seedy hotels in the Times Square area, creatin sanctuaries for thieves, pimps prostitutes and muggers who the police say, prey on pedes trians in the theater district.

title: Senate, 960, Approves Kelley As New Director of the F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Clarence M. Kelley, President Nixon's nominee as director of the Federal Bureau of Investi gation, was confirmed by the Senate today, 96 to 0.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, June 27 (UPI)RollsRoyce, Ltd., will pay off all its debts in full, Rupert Nicholson, the liquidator, said today.

title: Clarity and Confusion
description: The 1973 mayoral election is not over, despite the top heavy margin by which Controller Abraham D. Beame won the Democratic nomination in Tuesday's runoff primary. Unquestionably, that impressive victory gives Mr. Beame a substantial edge since Democrats outnum ber registered members of all other parties by nearly four to one in this city. However, Mr. Beame learned at first hand eight years ago that designation by the dom inant Democrats is no sure passport to the mayoralty.

title: Clinic Defends Sterilization of 2 Girls, 12 and 14
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 27 (UPI)The head of a fed erally funded familyplanning clinic accused of ordering the sterilization of two teenage black girls said today. that their mother had been briefed on the operation before she consented to it.

title: MIA, EXHORTED TO BACK REFORM
description: Dr. Charles C. Edwards, the Federal Government's highest ranikng health officer, warned organized medicine yesterday that the American people would not tolerate blind oppo sition by doctors to reformation of the national health care system.

title: COMMENT WITHHELD ON ATTICA CRITICISM
description: ALBANY, June 27 (AP)State officials withheld comment on a congressional committee's criti cism of the methods used to quiet the Attica prison rebellion in 1971.

title: Hearing in Sub Deaths
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., June 27 (UPI)Three Coast Guard offi cers will open hearings tomor row into the minisub accident off Key West June 17 that killed two of the four crewmen trapped nearly 32 hours some, 360 fet under the Gulf Stream.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Iowa Power and Light Company's offering of 500,000 shares of common stock was won by underwriters headed by Smith Barney & Co. The group bid $21.782 a share and will reoffer them to the public at $22.50 a share. Iowa Power and Light closed yesterday at 22, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: People in Sports: Drug Tests Are for Cows
description: No sooner did Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League, announce adoption of some new proce dures in the league's drug abuse program than the two most valuable players of last season stood up to object. Not that O. J. Simpson or Larry Brown are for drugs far from itbut both pro tested proposed urinalysis tests for N.F.L. players, which are not part of the new pro cedures, but are being con sidered.

title: Judge Orders Hospitals To Perform 2 Abortions
description: A New Jersey Superior Court judge yesterday ordered two Cumberland County hospitals to perform elective abortions on two women. The judge said he thought that his ruling was the first of its kind in the state.

title: Oil Spill Closes Beach
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., June 27 (AP)Burlington officials were forced to close the city's North Beach yesterday to the 1,500 people seeking relief from the heat. An oil spill in Lake Cham plain washed onto the beach and covered an area about 300 yards wide in the lake.

title: Plans for Girls School
description: BOSTON, June 27 (AP)The state will decide by July 4 if it will convert the Northampton School for Girls to a residential mental health center for chil dren, the administration secre tary, William I. Cowin said yes terday. Mr. Cowin said the hu man services secretary, Peter C. Goldmark, would make rec ommendations on the project.

title: Laird Says Nixon Will Reply To Watergate Accusers Soon
description: WASHINGTON, June 27In the next few weeks President Nixon will go before some pub lie forum to respond to the al legations being made against him in the Senate Watergate hearings.

title: SIRICA GETS PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Frederick C. LaRue, special as sistant to John N. Mitchell at the Committee for the Reelec tion of the President, pleaded guilty today to charges of con spiracy to obstruct justice.

title: Class Action Suit Is Filed Against Liggett &
description: A class action lawsuit filed yesterday in United States Dis trict Court alleged that during the first half of 1972 Liggett & Myers, lnc., issued optimistic statements about its future earnings, but failed to make available to the public mater ially adverse information.

title: SENATE PANEL ASKS CAMPAIGN REFORMS
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) The Senate Rules Committee approved today legislation to limit Federal campaign and contributions expenditures end WASHINGTON, provide new enforcement machinery. money influence, the bill would prohibit an individual from contributing more than $15,000 to a Presidential candidate or $5,000 to a Senate or House candidate. But separate con tributions totaling these amounts could be made for primary, runoff and general elections.

title: 3 Newspapers Here Reach. Agreement On Machinist Pact
description: The machinists union and the publishers of the city's three major dailies, The Daily News, The New York Post and The New York Times, reached agreement yesterday on a new twoyear contract.

title: 2 in J.D.L. Cleared in Bombing After Witnesses Balk
description: Bombing charges against two Jewish Defense League mem bers were dismissed in Federal Court here yesterday because two essential witnesses refused to testify degpite an angry judge's warning about criminal contempt.

title: Comparison of Nixon and Dean Positions
Fire at Essex House
description: Fire damaged a fourthfloor conference room at the Marri ott Essex House Hotel on Cen tral Park South last night There were no injuries.

title: SIRICA GETS PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Frederick C. LaRue, special as sistant to John N. Mitchell at the Committee for the Reelec tion of the President, pleaded guilty today to charges of con spiracy to obstruct justice.

title: Showdown on the Hill
description: President Nixon has now, as expected, vetoed a bill that would have cut off funds for the bombing of Cam bodia; and the House, as expected, has sustained the veto. But there is encouraging evidence that Congress may at last be determined to reassert its authority end a war with which a majority in both houses has lost all patience. Even before the Presidential veto, the House had attached a similar ban on United States mili tary actions in Cambodia and Laos to another money bill which will be more difficult to veto, a continuing reso lution to finance the entire Government from July 1 to Sept. 30 or until regular appropriations bills are enacted.

title: Doctor Charged With Murder In Mercy Killing in Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L. I.June 27 The chief surgical resident of the Nassau County Medical Center was indicted today on a charge of willful murder the Nassau County District At torney described as a mercy killing.

title: QuarterFinal Site Could Be a U.S. City If the Price Is Right
description: The American city that makes the right moves  to Check or cashcould be the site of the chess world cham pionship quarterfinal match between Robert Byrne and his foreign opponent.

title: MOW LINKED TOKOPECHNEDATA
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 A former F.B.I. official, Cartha D. Deloach, reportedly obeyed a White House request in the summer of 1969 for a report on Mary Jo Kopechne, who had drowned in the auto of Sena tor Edward M. Kennedy at Chappaquiddick Island, butt has denied that the F.B.I. wire tapped President Nixon in 1968.

title: Bankers Acceptance Up
description: The New York Federal Re serve Bank said yesterday total bankers acceptances outstand ing nationally rose $175million lin May to $6.88billion from $6.71billion in April.

title: U.S. WON'T ALTER TIES WITH GREECE
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  After a brief policy review, the Nixon Administration has de cided to maintain its cordial relations with Greece's mili tary led Government despite growing pressure from Con gress for cooler ties.

title: Beame Campaigns Again in All 5 Boroughs
description: Awakened by the sound of his own voice on a clock radioa replay of his victory statement in the Democratic mayoral runoff  Controller Abraham D. Beame hastened to his desk in the Municipal Building yesterday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An 18yearold youth, convicted of raping a 21yearold teacher at knifepoint in a Paterson school cloakroom, was sentenced to 18 to 20 years in prison. The charges you have been convicted of are horrible, Passaic County Court Judge Joseph M. Harrison told Harold Stancil, the defendant, prior to sentencing, Stancil, of Paterson, was convicted April 11 of the armed rape and assault, with intent to rob, of a fourthgrade teacher at School 12 here. He was also convicted of the armed robbery of a fifth grade teacher at the school the same day as the rape.

title: Four Nixon Justices Vote as Bloc on 70% of Cases
description: WASHINGTON, June 27in their first full term on the bench together, the four Supreme Court Justices appointed by President Nixon have formed a cohesive and effective power bloc that voted as a unit on 70 per cent of the cases that the Court heard and decided in the last nine months.

title: SCORES OF NAMES
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  John John W. Dean 3d told the Sen ate Watergate committee today that the White House lists of political enemies filled a file several inches thick.

title: Futures Traders Confused By U. S. Order on Ceilings
description: CHICAGO, June 27The confusion that has gripped the commodities industry since President Nixon's latest price freeze, imposed two weeks ago, was compounded today.

title: Big Board Seats Are Sold
description: The New York Stock Ex change reported yesterday the sale of a seat for $73,000, the lowest price in 15 years. This compares with the record of $515,000 reached several times during 1968 and early 1969. Two other membership trans fers took place yesterdaythe first at $80,000 and the second at $78,000, The $73,090 trans action was the last sale.

title: U.S. Reports Mines Cleared In Five Haiphong Channels
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (Reuters)  A United States Navy special force cleared mines from five main channels in the Haiphong area of the North Vietnamese coast and has begun minesweeping around Vinh, to the south, the Defense Department said today.

title: College Security Forces Unite Over Campus Crime
description: UNION, June 27  Reacting to mounting oncampus crime, security representatives from 20 colleges and universities met here today to form the Campus Security AssoCiation; the first organization of its kind in New Jersey.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York City's Human Resources Administration, through its welfare arm, is placing hundreds of drug ad dicts, mental cases and other unstable persons on welfare into 20 hotels in the Times Square area. This is happen ing while police, fire, health and hospital units have been welded into a special task force by Mayor Lindsay to crack down on crime, prosti tution, pornography and vile health and housing conditions in the theater district,

title: Army Warns Deserters Of Discharge in Absentia
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) The Army has sent letters to a third of its deserters living overseas saying it is prepared to discharge them, Pentagon records showed today.

title: Pennsylvania High Court Is Asked to Block Tower
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (UPI)The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, rebuffed four times in lower courts, asked the State Supreme Court today to block the construction of a tourist tower at Gettysburg be cause it would desecrate the, environment in violation of the public interest.

title: Skippers Hope to Renew Block Island Race Today
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I. June 27  The Storm Try sail Club was hoping to re sume racing tomorrow after a twoday layoff in Block Island Week.

title: Improper Calls to the S.E.C. Charged
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (Reu ters)William J. Casey, former head of the Securities and Ex change Commission, said today that he had received what he considered improper telephone contacts from John Ehrlichman, President Nixon's principal do mestic affairs adviser, and Sen ator Edward M. Kennedy, Dem ocrat of Massachusetts, during last year's investigation of major business merger.

title: Top Democrats Endorse Beame in a Show of Unity
description: Top Democrats, including Senator George McGovern and Howard J. Samuels, endorsed City Controller Abraham D. Beame for Mayor yesterday in a rare display of Democratic party unity. The endorsements for the victor in Tuesday's runoff primary heralded what the Beame forces hopes will be a bandwagon that will head off largescale defections to two other Democrats in the mayoral race, Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal and Representative Mario Biaggi, who are, respectively, the Liberal and Conservative can didates.

title: Blumenthal Attacks Opponents As Conservatives Tied to Past
description: Assemblyman Albert H. Blum enthal, the Liberal party can didate for Mayor, opened his campaign yesterday by attack ing his three opponents as con servatives, each is tied in his own way to the past and each either unable or unwilling to confront the problems of the future.

title: Radio
description: 8:0510 A.M., WNCN. Scara mouche, Milhaud; Louise; Depuis le Jour, Charpentier; Pelleas et Melisande, Faure; Symphony in C minor, Boccherini; Love For Three Oranges: Suite, Prokofiev; Taras Bulba, Janacek.

title: Hockey Transactions WORLD ASSOCIATION
description: MINNESOTASignad John Garrett, goalie, and Bob Boyd, defenseman.

title: Show No Mercy, Mayor Tells the Police In Pressing Midtown Parking Program
description: Mayor Lindsay, on a two hour walking tour of midtown traffic yesterday, chuckled when a policeman gave out a parking summons, told a meter maid to show no mercy and declared the city was going to have to tighten up on parking by diplomats, the press, the handicapped and physicians.

title: Pentagon Says Truce Permits Cut in Aid to Vietnam and Laos
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The Defense Department told a Senate committee today that the Indochina ceasefire agree ments would permit a reduction of at least $500million in planned military aid to South Vietnam and Laos in the fiscal year beginning next Sunday, July 1.

title: 210 Million in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) The Census Bureau has re ported the United States popu lation at about 210,157,000 on May 1, an increase of approxi mately 1,595,000 over the esti mate for May, 1972.

title: Guide
description: WORKSHOP For five years, MUSE has functioned as a doublebarreled museum at 1530 Bedford Avenue, near Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn (7742900). It is the interim facility for the Brooklyn Children's Museum and also the Bedford Lincoln Neighborhood Museum, and from 6 tonight through Sat urday both aspects will be represented in a special threeday workshops festival.

title: Heart Association Strengthens Its Advice: Cut Down on Fats
description: The American Heart Associ ation yesterday strengthened its recommendation that Americans curb their con sumption of some of their most beloved foodsprime ribs, ice cream, butter, bacon, sausages, cold cuts and the likeand switch to a leaner diet containing less saturated fat and cholesterol.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: The Stage: Coriolanus
description: MADISON, N.J., June 27 Coriolanus is not merely timely but pressingdealing with what we make of our heroes and what they do to themselves. Coriolanus is an upright man of action who considers himself far above the common people, and is tragically victimized by his own pride.

title: May Economic Indicators Surged After Lag in April
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) The Government's index of leading economic indicators re bounded with a strong increase in May after a sharp decline a month earlier, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Javits Demands Administration Release Fund for Summer Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Senator Jacob K. Javits, Re publican of New York, accused the Nixon Administration today of hoarding for some unknown future purpose $256.5million that was appropriated by Con gress for summer jobs for low income youths.

title: Totowa Concern and U.S. Agree on a Price Rollback
description: TOTOWA, June 27 (AP)  Agreement on a $400,000 price rollback was announced today between Filigree Foods, Inc., here and the Cost of Living Council.

title: Insurance Head Speaks
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The American Insurance Associa tion told a House securities panel today that much of the trouble within the brokerage community was traceable to Wall Street's unwillingness to make trading practices con form to dramatically changed market conditions.

title: ANACONDA AND AMAX IN MINING VENTURE
description: The Anaconda Company and American Metal Climax, Inc., completed negotiations yester day and signed agreements creating the Anamax Mining Company, a 5050 partenrship to operate and expand the Twin Buttes openpit copper mine in Pima County, Ariz.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Janovic/Plaza, the East Side paint and wallpaper store that has been In business for 85 years, recently opened a branch on the West Side, Customers will find here the usual wide selection of mate rials, plus an innovation for Janoviccarpeting.

title: Indicted in Passaic County Corruption
description: TRENTON, June 27A state grand jury investigating al leged corruption among law enforcement officials in Passaic County handed up five sealed indictments here this afternoon that were reported to name county lawenforcement official and another one from Pater son.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: JERSEY CIY, June 27John Benedict Wilson is one the youngest directors of athletics in the nation, but the 25yearold executive is not overawed with his new posi tion at St. Peter's College.

title: Books of The Times
description: Don't Bother MeI'm Working. This is the dominant note of the answers when editors Thomas B. Hess and Elizabeth C. Baker asked 10 contemporary women art ists, Why have there been no great women artists?

title: TEST INTENSIFIES
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 27  President Nixon today vetoed a bill that would have cut off all funds for the bomb ing of Cambodia. He said a total halt in American air operations would undercut diplomatic ef forts for a ceasefire, jeopardize the Paris agreement for peace in all of Indochina and strike a blow at America's credibility.

title: PENNSYLVANIA POLL SHOWS RIZZO IN LEAD
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 27  Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, the con servative former police chief here, is the strongest candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania next year, according to a pri vate statewide telephone poll taken in Auril and May.

title: ABBATIELLO WINS INTERCITY HONORS
description: Abbatiello triumphed in two of the five contests that paired four drivers from New York with four from Chicago's Sport man's Park and led the Yon kers quartet to a team victory, 556 to 444 points.

title: Not What They Had in Mind
description: CRANFIELD, England, June 27 (Reuters)  Researchers studying the effect of wind on findings today when they dis covered that a wind storm dur ing the night had blown the roof off their research station in this southern England Town.

title: TRUSTEE OF MUSEUM DISAPPROVED STUDY
description: Roland Redmond, a member of the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said yesterday that he had voted against approval of a re port issued Tuesday by a spe vial committee of the trustees, titled Report on Art Trans actions 19711973.

title: CHINA EXPLODES HYDROGEN BOMB
description: TOKYO, Thursday, June 28 (AP)  China announced today that she successfully conduct ed a hydrogen bomb test in the atmosphere yesterday for rea sons of defense and to break nuclear monopoly by the superpowers.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
5.6% PENSION RISE VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) The Senate approved today, 86 to 7, a 5.6 per cent across theboard increase in Social Se curity benefits to take effect next January.

title: Simon Leads Pocono Qualifiers With Average of 180 M.P. H.
description: Simon Leads Pocono Qualifiers With Average of 180 M.P.H.,

title: Baseball Transactions AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: CHICAGOSigned Ken Kravec, lefthanded pitcher, thirdround draft choice, and as. signed to Knoxville of the Southern League.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating Outlook
description: AREA AFishing is pretty thin, says John Falkiewicz at Surf City, N. J., who adds that a few striped bass and fluke, but no kingfish, are being caught in the surf. In Barnegat Bay, he said, there have been occasional good catches of striped bass that have lingered on later than usual. Fluke are being caught in or near the inlets. Meyers Yacht Basin at Barnegat reports excellent angling for bluefish off Barnegat Ridge, the fish running from 6 to 12 pounds. School tuna to 20 pounds are also plentiful in the same area, and fluke fishing is excellent offshore. Good numbers of stripers are being caught north and south of Barnegat Inlet about a mile offshore, although the fish are small, 4 to 8 pounds. Weakfishing has apparently ended, but crabbing in the bay is excellent. At Point Pleasant, boats are bringing in fair to good catches of fluke. Daytime blue fishing off Barnegat Ridge is excellent as is night fishing for the same species about 10 miles eastsoutheast of Manasquan Inlet. Stripers are scarce. Colvin's Bait and Tackle at Seaside Park, N. J., reports very poor surf fishing but fair to good angling in the bay for weakfish and small fluke. Many very small stripers are being taken in Barnegat inlet and, just offshore of the inletclose, but out of reach of surfcastersthere have been many small and medium sized bluefish caught.

title: Lawyer Says Mitchell Won't Implicate Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell definitely has no information implicatiing President Nixon in the Watergate bugging or the coverup, William G. Hundley, his lawyer, said tonight.

title: G.O.P. Senator Charges Effort to Intimidate Him
description: G.O.P. Senator Charges Effort to Intimidate Him

title: HEALTH OFFICIAL QUITS IN PROTEST
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 The director of the Federal program that provides health services for crippled children and lowincome pregnant mothers resigned today, charging that the Nixon Administration was not interested in the problems of children.

title: White House Defender
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Twentythree years ago, Joseph Fred Buzhardt Jr.'s career was advancing on course. In World War II he had served in the Army Air Corps for two years. He had graduated from West Point in 1946. In 1950, as a first lieutenant in the Air Force, he was piloting troop carriers from Japan and was determined to make his future with the military. But at 26 years of age he was forced to alter his course because his ears could no longer endure the pressure of flying. He went home to South Carolina and studied law.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: EDMONTONSigned Brian MacDonald, right wing, thirdround draft choice.

title: BLANCHE PERRIN, 79, NOVELIST, IS DEAD

But a widening circle of food processors and retailers are caught in a profit squeeze resulting from the price freeze, and this is beginning to curtail production of some foods.

title: Dean Navigates Watergate Shoals With Ease

Ervin Jr., the Democratic chairman, and Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the vaguely menacing Republican vice chairman. But John W. Dean 3d as crisply cool looking in a new brown suit as earlier in tans, blues and graysrnade it look easy.

description: The State Human Rights Appeal Board was ordered yesterday by the Appellate Division to hold a new hearing for discharged New York Post reporter, William Artis.

Approval would have increased the average tax rate $1.21 for each $100 of assessed evaluation, or from $7.40 to $8.61.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 29 (Reuters) Two Canadian truce observers are missing in an area of east of Saigon after making contact with Vietcong forces a Canadian delegation spokesman said today.

description: WASHINGTON, June 28The joint tax committee of Congress ordered today an investigation of allegations that the Nixon Administration has used tax audits to punish its enemies and help its friends.

title: Thai Restaurant Hidden in a Blimpie's
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stare asgood, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Red Smith
description: Back in the piping times when Knute Rockne coached football at Notre Dame, the 22 players on the first and second teams took their meals at two tables in the dining hall on the ground floor of the Administration Building. (That's the one with the golden dome always shown photographs). One undergraduate waiter worked both tables. He wheeled the vittles in on doubledecked carts from the kitchen, which was in another building across a courtyard. Because he invariably had to make another round trip for seconds, he was no better Sports than 7 to 2 to get his tables cleared and the dishes back to the kitchen in time to eat of with the other waiters, and if he wasn't on The Times time lie didn't eat, When the last mound tapioca vanished, so did 21 athletes. One stayed to help tidy up so the kid could make deadline. This was Elmer Layden, the allAmerica fullback and star sprinter on the track team. He wasn't asked to help and he didn't expect thanks, He just was, and is, that kind of gentleman.

title: 2 COMPANIES VOW MORE GASOLINE

description: To the Editor: Many people (and most governments) believe that they have the moral right, if not obligation, to control the thought and behavior of others. The rationale is that imposition of certain views upon others is essential for the society's existence or wellbeing.

Coxson, a flamboyant former convict who ran unsuccessfully for Mayor of Camden, N.J., last month.

The voice vote was 91 too.Dr. Schlesinger said that the only circumstance in which could foresee any possibility of renewing the bombing would be major aggressive actions by the North Vietnamese which would threaten South Vietnam; in obvious violation of the Paris agreements. He added he did not believe that such circumstances will arise.

description: Thirtyeight athletes, including Willie Mays, Muhammad Ali and Wilt Chamberlain, were named yesterday to the National Black Sports Hall of Fame.

title: Screen:Liv Ullmann Portrays Heroine in '40 Carats'
description: "40 Carats," which opened yesterday at Radio City Music Hall is Jay Allen's Broadway comedy recycled as a movie, the sort in which you could put the world's greatest actors and not even miss them. The blandness of the project renders everyone invisible.Liv Ullmann plays Ann Stanley, a Manhattan real-estate agent with a pool-playing daughter of 17 (Deborah Raffin), a madcap mother (Binnie Barnes) and a charming ex-husband (Gene Kelly) who acts in TV pilots and coffee commercials. Ann is successful and tranquil but unfulfilled.On a holiday in Greece, Ann meets personable, presentable Peter Latham (Edward Albert) when her car breaks down in front of a view of the Gulf of Saronikos. Peter, 22, offers her a lift on his motorcycle. Ann refuses, pointing out she is 36. Instead, he gives her some ouzo, which, strangely, she has never heard of, even though she has been junketing around Greece for weeks. One thing leads to another, and Ann and Peter spend an idyllic night together on the beach.Back in Manhattan, Peter wants to marry Ann. She refuses. She's lied to him, she admits. She's not 36 but 38, well, actually 40? The way Ann vacillates, you get the idea she sees herself as a female Humbert Humbert. Should she or should she not? Will love triumph? "Don't think of them as years," suggests her charming ex-husband, "but carats. You're a multi-careted, blue-white diamond!" As one drama critic said of the play with admiration, the movie doesn't cop out.It doesn't do much of anything. It just sits there, like a piece of expensively upholstered furniture.The women wear a lot of fancy gowns and trade wisecracks, only one of which, spoken by that fine comedienne, Nancy Walker, made me laugh. Gene Kelly gives the impression that he might still be as charming as we all remember him in "Singing in the Rain." Edward Albert, who made his debut in "Butterflies Are Free," has a very spruce appearance.Miss Ullmann, however, is utterly lost. This marvelous actress, the world's most beautiful woman in Bergman's "Cries and Whispers," looks like a 33-year-old frump, not a 40-year-old beauty. She is, I suspect, constitutionally incapable of dealing with this sort of nonsense in anything except the rather somber manner of a concerned night nurse in a charity ward. It seems she wants to help but she can't.Milton Katselas directed the movie and Leonard Gershe wrote the screenplay. They've succeeded in disguising the fact that it is basically a stage play, but not the fact that the material is hopelessly dumb.

description: DANSVILLE, N. Y., June 28 Bernard M. Hanafin, who retired this year as president of the W. A. Baum Company, Inc., maker of blood pressure equipment in Copiague, L. I., died here yesterday at his summer home. He was 76 years old and lived at 11911 89th Road, New Gardens, Queens.

title: Mrs. Francis Moore, 82, Director of Music School
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 28Mrs. Gertrude Ellis Moore, widow of the concert pianist and teacher Francis Moore, and herself a teacher and leader in musical affairs in southern Westchester, died last evening at a nursing home in New Rochelle. She was 82 years old and lived at 572 Manor Lane.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 28 (AP)The fiveyearold controversy surrounding the winner of the 1968 Kentucky Derby having died quietly this week, Bob Gorham, resident manager of Churchill Downs, said today the gold winner's trophy would be engraved and presented to Calumet Farm, owner of secondplace finisher Forward Pass, as soon as some paperwork was finished. The deadline passed this week for further court appeals by Peter Fuller, owner firstplace finisher Dancer's Image.

The stock of the world's largest Mat packer closed at 23, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

Turner, a Gloucester County Republican, was found guilty today on all three counts of conspiracy, bribery and giving false information to law enforcement officials in a plot to frame Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz, a Democrat, on narcotics charges.

If only because of the pressure from members who have made vacation plans, it is a recess that the leadership is not about to rescind.

H., June 28The American invesfor should be given the chance to buy inflationproof bonds that would be guaranteed by the Government against the loss of the dollar's purchasing power, a Yale University professor, who also acts as an adviser to the Treasury, suggested here today.

The measure states that cars must be equipped with seat safety belts or other suitable restraining device. It gives the State Motor Vehicle Director discretion determine if the safety devices meet proper standards.

title: Judge Rejects Nader Suit To Shut 20 Nuclear Plants
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) A Federal judge dismissed today a suit by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, that had sought to close 20 of the nation's nuclear power plants. Mr. Nader alleged that the installations posed a danger of radioactive contamination.

title: A.I. BEZYMENSKY, 75, SOVIET POET, IS DEAD
description: MOSCOW, June 28Aleksandr I. Bezymensky, an important poet of the early Soviet period, is dead, it was reported in the Soviet press today. He was 75 years old.

title: Cambodians Mood: Apathy, Resignation
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 28The windows of the big airconditioned car were rolled up, so an explosion three blocks down Monivong Boulevard sounded like muffled thunder.

title: Books of The Times
description: KISSINGER: Portrait of a Mind. By Stephen R. Graubard. 288 pages. Norton. $7.95.

title: Ruling on Schools
description: The Supreme Court has emphatically reaffirmed the vital principle of churchstate separation. In a 6to3 ruling, the Court has declared unconstitutional the New York statute which provided state subsidy for parochial schools repair and maintenance and offered tax relief for tuition reimbursement to parents whose children attend these schools.

title: A SpickandSpan Restaurant Out Front Can Shield Breach of Health Code in Back
description: The restaurant on Third Avenue smelled of freshly waxed floors and its low lights, checkered table cloths and mellow wood paneling gave a feeling of hospitality as two city health inspectors came through the door.

title: F.B.I. Seizes Suspect in Coxson Slaying
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 28A man wanted in an investigation into the slaying of seven people in Washington  five of them children  was arrested here today and identified later as a suspect in the murder of Major B. Coxson, a flamboyant former convict who ran unsuccessfully for Mayor of Camden, N.J., last month.

title: DOROTHY BOMBERGER
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 28 (AP) Dorothy Bomberger, former editor of a column for children in The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, died Tuesday. She was 75 years old.

title: Some Limits on Peddling Are Ruled Unconstitutional
description: The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that some of the city's regulations concerning where street peddlers may sell products were unconstitutional.

title: Strategy Aimed at Gaining Nixon Testimony Hinted by Ervin's and Baker's Queries
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 Strategy aimed at making increasingly difficult for President Nixon to refuse to testify on his own behalf before the Senate Watergate committee unfolded during the committee's hearings today.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 7:30 P.M.

title: A.M.A. Rejects Plan to Study Move in Direction of Unionism
description: The American Medical Association beat down yesterday an attempt to move itself in the direction of doctors unions whose creation and expansion in recent years has served to undermine the A.M.A.'s influence.

title: Football Transactions
description: KANSAS CITYSigned Bill Story, Southern Illinois offensive guard defensive tackle, ninth round draft choice; Torn Ramsey, Northern Arizona defensive tackle end, 12thround draft choice; Wilbur Grooms, Tampa defensive end, 16thround draft choice, and George Jackowenko, Syracuse placekicker, free agent.

title: Panel in Congress To Study Charges On TaxAudit Use
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The joint tax committee of Congress ordered today an investigation of allegations that the Nixon Administration has used tax audits to punish its enemies and help its friends.

title: Court Restrains Padres
description: SAN DIEGO, June 28, (UPI) 1A Superior Court judge put another restraint today on the San Diego Padres proposed move to Washington. Judge Eli 1Levinson ordered that a $900,000 claim filed by the concessionaire at San Diego Stadium be combined with a previous action under which the city of San Diego won a temporary restraining order blocking the club's move.

title: PATRICK L. CARTY
description: FREEPORT, L. I., June 28Patrick L. Carty, who retired in 1946 as president of Media Records, Inc., a newspaper advertising measurement and statistical organization, died here Tuesday at Doctors Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at 131 Bedell Street.

title: Smaller Stores Found Lagging On Posting of Price Freeze Data
description: Only chain stores and larger food and merchandise stores are obeying Federal regulations requiring them to post pricefreeze information, according to the heads of the Internal Revenue Service districts in. Manhattan, Brooklyn and Newark, which cover the metropolitan area.

title: Nuclear Fuel Order Cited
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it had received a $21 million nuclear fuel reload order. The company said the fuel would be fabricated for the San Onofre nuclear generating station that is jointly owned by the Southern California Edison Company and the San Diego Gas & Electric Company.

title: Feud Keeps Park Slope On Guard
description: The disorders and shootings on Wednesday night along a fiveblock stretch of Fifth Avenue in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn were the most violent in a longstanding hostility that has pitted the Puerto Rican community just to the north of Union Street against the predominantly Italian neighborhood just to the south.

title: $250,000 Left for Animals
description: WAYNESBORO, Pa., June 28 (AP)A childless widow who died June 10 has left a will providing $250,000 to establish an animal shelter. The will of Mrs. Florence Lyon, who was 83 years old when she died, was entered for probate yesterday at the Franklin County court.

title: Setback to Vote Reform
description: Although he had previously vetoed similar bills, Governor Rockefeller has this week inexplicably signed into law a measure that threatens totally to politicize New York City's electoral machinery and to make desperately needed reforms even more difficult to achieve. This bill, passed in the hectic, waning hours of the legislative session, reflects the narrow view of political leaders that control of the electoral process is best left to their handpicked subordinates.

title: SEC. LAYS FRAUD TO HOLIDAY MAGI
description: Holiday Magic, Inc., a multi  milliondollar, doortodoor cosmetics company that has come under sharp attack it recent months for its pyramid marketing plan, was chargec yesterday with fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Transport Aide Approved
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) The Senate today confirmed the nomination of John W. Barnum of New York to be Under Secretary of Transportation to succeed Egil Krogh Jr.

title: For G.M. Test Drivers, Deadline Season Is Hectic
description: MILFORD, Mich., June 28 If you are doing 100 miles an hour when you head into the banked, mathematically exact turn that sweeps up a hill and sharply to the right at the southern end of the northsouth straightaway, and if you hold the accelerator steady, you will automatically slow to 25 miles an hour at the top of the loop. Then you will start back down, and by the time you hit the bottom of the hill, only a few yards from the top, you will be hurtling back northward at 100 miles an hour again. Dick Mullany has driven the twoandahalfmile straightaway more times than he can count during the last 18 years, putting one car after another through its paces as part of his job as a test driver at the General Motors Corporation's Milford proving ground.

title: CITY LABOR PACTS EXPIRE TOMORROW
description: Contracts covering nearly 60,000 uniformed employes and 120,000 other city workers are scheduled to terminate at midnight tomorrow, but there is no threat of job action or expectancy of imminent crisis.

title: TEAMSTERS AGREE TO 7%AYEAR RISE IN 33MONTH PACT
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The nation's trucking industry and the teamsters union agreed today to a new 33month master freight contract providing wage and benefit increases averaging 7 per cent a year to 400,000 truck drivers.

title: Advice Is Offered
description: William E. Simon, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, yesterday urged oil exporting nations to make investments and handle their burgeoning wealth in a way that achieves the industrial development goals of producing countries and promotes international monetary cooperation.

title: Rites for Max Barsis
description: A memorial service for Max Barsis, author and artist, will be held at the Brandeis University chapel In Waltham, Mass., on Sunday at 1 P.M. Mr. Barsis, who died May 28 on the island of Ischia in Italy, most recently produced a comprehensive book of costume drawings. The Common Man Through the Centuries.

title: GRUTTOLA GUILTY IN ROBBERY CASE
description: A 50yearold Queens man, whose release in $500 cash bail last December on charges that included attempted murder touched off a heated controversy, was convicted in State Supreme Court yesterday of assault and robbery.

title: Sandman Stands by Nixon And Renews NoTax Vow,
description: TRENTON, June 28Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor, said today that Ms faith in President Nixon had not been shaken by the Watergate testimony of John W. Dean 3d.

title: Judge Rejects Nader Suit To Shut 20 Nuclear Plants
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) A Federal judge dismissed today a suit by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, that had sought to close 20 of the nation's nuclear power plants. Mr. Nader alleged that the installations posed a danger of radioactive contamination.

title: Sailor Killed by Electricity In an Accident at Sea
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 28 (AP) A Navy enlisted man from Groton, Conn., died at sea yesterday in an electrical accident on board the Garcia, a Newportbased destroyer.

title: Bridge: A Late Entry in the Bidding Can Be a Dangerous Move
description: A player who cannot bid at his first turn is almost always wrong to throw himself into the fray later without hearing from his partner, unless the opponents auction dies at a low level. Inexperienced players would be welladvised to treat this as a strict rule, thereby avoiding trouble. Even experts sometimes pick the wrong moment to break it, and South did so on the diagramed deal, played in Ireland.

title: Contempt Is Laid to C.B.S. Over Sketches in Court
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., June 28 (AP)A United States District Court judge, Winston Arnow, yesterday ordered CBS News to show cause why it should not be held in contempt of court for sketches that an artist made after the artist had been banned from Judge Arnow's courtroom last week.

title: Uganda Holds Up Plan To Recruit U.S. Blacks
description: LONDON, June 28 (Reuters)Uganda has reconsidered plans to recruit black Americans into her civil service, Radio Uganda reported today.

description: Listing of Prices for Contracts in Futures of Commodities

description: Winning numbers drawn on June 28 were:

title: U.S. Planes Strike Above Phnom Penh As Rebels Advance
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 28 (UPI)American planes struck repeatedly today at rebel forces advancing toward the Cambodian capital from the north on Routes 5 and 6.

title: Roman Stops Rival in Third In TuneUp for Foreman
description: PORTLAND, Me., June 27 (AP)Joe (King) Roman of Puerto Rico tuning up for his world heavyweight championship bout against George Foreman, knocked out littleknown Elmo Brown of Memphis, Tennin the third round here tonight.

title: DUTCH OFFER PLAN FOR REVISED NATO
description: BRUSSELS, June 26The Netherlands has formally begun the Atlantic alliance's process of selfanalysis in the light of the vast international changes of recent years by presenting a draft plan for the new Atlantic charter.

description: Today's Entries at Monmouth

title: BOOKIIIEN WEIGH OBSCENITY RULING
description: Bernhardt J. Hurwood's 45th book was published yesterday, with 250,000 paperback copies ready for his fans, but instead of sipping champagne in the posh offices of his publishers, Fawcett, Mr. Hurwood picketed City Hall to protest the Supreme Court's tough new antiobscenity rules. They're not going to inhibit me, he said.

title: Market Place: Yield Dims Glow Of SuperStocks
description: When the major banks talk about their investment portfoliosportfolios heavily laden with some 30 highgrowth companes like Avon Products, Xerox and International Business Machines they let you know that they have been smart in managing their billions.

description: Major League Box Scores

title: Senate Committee Votes For a U.S. Sports Board
description: An omnibus bill, which would create the United States Sports Board and bring about sweeping changes in amateur sports, passed its first hurdle in the Congress yesterday. The Senate Commerce Committee favorably approved the 35page bill, entitled the Amateur Athletic Act of 1973.

title: U.S. Jet Crash in Thailand Said to Injure Village Chief
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Junej 28 (Reuters)A United States Air Force F4 Phantom jet crashed into a house in northeastern Thailand, causing serious injuries to a village chief, the police reported today.

title: BLUE CHIPS SPUR RALLY IN MARKET
description: Selective buying among bluechip issues spurred the stock market to another strong gain yesterday in moderate trading.

title: KENNEDY A TARGET OF HUNT'S C.I.A AID
description: WASHINGTON, June 28E. Howard Hunt Jr., one of the convicted Watergate conspirators, was quoted today as saying that he had sought and received disguises and other equipment from the Central Intelligence Agency to investigate Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Personalities: Waive Goodby to Reichardt
description: After eight unspectacular years in the major leagues, Rick Reichardt is apparently through playing baseball. The Chicago White Sox yesterday requested waivers on the 30yearold outfielder for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.

title: N.F.L. IS HEALTHY, ROZELLE ASSERTS
description: Pete Rozelle, the National Football League commissioner, described the state of pro football yesterday as healthy but afflicted with problems. He made the remarks as the annual spring meeting of the club owners ended here.

title: East and West Agree on TroopCut Aims
description: VIENNA, June 28The nations of the Atlantic Alliance and the Warsaw Pact announced agreement today on the goals of negotiations for EastWest troop cuts in Central Europe, scheduled to begin here Oct. 30.

title: Loews Earnings in Third Quarter Reported 39.5% Below Year Ago
description: Net income of the Loews Corporation for the third fiscal quarter ended May 31 declined 39.5 per cent from a year ago, but increased 0.02 per cent for the nine months period, according to the report yesterday.

title: PALMER, WITH 66, SHARES GOLF LEAD
description: CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) Arnold Palmer found some new magic in an old putter and fashioned a fiveunderpar 66 for share of the firstround lead today in the $175,000 Western open golf tournament.

description: Western Golf Scores
