description: WASHINGTON, June 28E. Howard Hunt Jr., one of the convicted Watergate conspirators, was quoted today as saying that he had sought and received disguises and other equipment from the Central Intelligence Agency to investigate Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Foster to Defend Title
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 27 (AP) The world lightheavyweight champion, Bob Foster, will defend his crown against Pierre Fioure of South Africa, here Aug. 21, Paul, Chavez, a promoter, said today.

title: In the Glens of Ulster, Voting Offers a Fragment of Hope
description: GLENARIFF, Northern Ireland, June 28The Antrim glens are green and lush, cutting through the hills in nine parallel sweeps to the sea. Sunlight falls through the trees, salmon streams rush along the bottoms, yellow gorse and cottages climb the steep sides.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York

title: Chilean Army Announces Barracks Revolt Is Crushed
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 28 (UPI)The army announced the arrest today of several lowranking military men and the crushing of a barracks revolt against their commanding officers.

title: 1, 000 DETECTIVES TO GO ON PATROL
description: The Police Department, in a continuing effort by Commissioner Donald F. Cawley to augment precinct patrol forces, will assign more than 1,000 members of the Detective Bureau to precinct work in the next few months.

title: NEWSWEEK SIGNS PACT WITH UNION
description: A group of women editorial employes at Newsweek magazine announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the publication's management under which at least onethird of Newsweek's writers and reporters will be women by Dec. 31, 1974.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday upheld a lowercourt order directing 1,700 striking cemetery workers to return to their jobs. The decision the fivejudge bench thus opened the way for State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkawitz to press for criminal contempt action against the union and its officers. Sam Cimaglia, the president of the striking union, Local 365 of the Cemetery Workers and Greens Attendants, said that he planned to appeal the decision to the State Court Appeals.

title: Confessions of
description: QUESTION: Mr. Reston, do you swear to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you God?

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON A FUND CUTOFF FOR THE BOMBING
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 SenateHouse conferees reached agreement tonight on a bill containing a provision cutting off present and future funds for the bombing of Cambodia while efforts were made in other quarters to reach a compromise in the Congressional confrontation with President Nixon.

title: U.S. Money Supply Rises; Prime Rate Move Hinted
description: Monetary expansion has accelerated in recent weeks, data published yesterday by the Federal Reserve System showed.

title: AIRMAN IS SEIZED IN SLAYING OF 2
description: GOLDSBORO, N. C., June 28 (AP)An airman was arrested today in the slayings of a medical corpsman and a patient who were killed when a gunman burst into the emergency room at Seymour Johnson Air Force Base last Sunday, the police said.

title: BAKER SAYS PANEL WILL INVESTIGATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. charged today that supporters of President Nixon had tried to intimidate him since he became a member of the Senate Watergate committee. The Connecticut Republican said at the end of today's hearings that he had reported these attempts to the special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, so that Mr. Cox could determine whether someone had violated the law against trying to obstruct the proceedings of a Congressional committee.

title: Colonel Denies Aiding Foe While Prisoner in Vietnam
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 (AP)A former Vietnam war prisoner today denied charges of mutiny and aiding the enemy, saying he had repeatedly exposed himself to punishment from the North Vietnamese during five years captivity.

title: DR. LENDON SNEDEKER
description: BOSTON, June 28 (AP)Dr. Lendon Snedeker, former assistant director of the Children's Hospital Medical Center in Boston, died Tuesday in New London, N. H. He was 69 years old.

title: Turner Convicted In Drug Conspiracy
description: TRENTON, June 28State Senator James M. Turner, a Gloucester County Republican, was found guilty today all three counts of conspiracy, bribery and giving false information to law enforcement officials in a plot to frame Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz, a Democrat, on narcotics charges.

title: Judge Orders U.S. Funds Released for Youth Corps
description: A Federal judge in Newark ordered the United States Department of Labor yesterday to release $239million budgeted nationwide for the Neighborhood Youth Corps summer program.

title: AGREEMENT REACHED TO FREE I.0.S. FUNDS
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 28 (AP) Four regulatory agencies reached agreement here today on a plan to free some $145million in cash they had blocked to protect the assets of five mutual funds managed by Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., the once powerful mutual fund complex founded by Bernard Cornfeld.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES Baltimore 6, New York 3 (n.). Chicago 2, California 0.

title: I.B.M. Lawyer Offers Contempt Plan
description: Bruce D. Bromley, one of the nation's best known corporate lawyers, yesterday asked the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York to hold him in contempt for his failure to provide some 1,200 documents sought by the Justice Department in connection with its fouryearold antitrust action against the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Montoya Denies Hiding Origins of Campaign Funds
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 Senator Joseph M. Montoya, Democrat of New Mexico, a member of the Senate Watergate committee, denied today that he had concealed the origins of as much as $100,000 in contributions to his 1970 reelection campaign, in violation of New Mexico's election law.

title: Sinatra, 3 Others Accused of Assault In Coast Restaurant
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 28 (AP)A local insurance agent has signed assault and battery complaints against the singer Frank Sinatra and three other men in connection with an alleged beating at a restaurant in Palm Springs, Calif., an attorney, Bruce E. Coke, said today.

title: Running Tide Wins Class Honors Again In Block Island Sail
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., June 28Running Tide, owned and skippered by Albert Van Metre of Alexandria, Va., posted her second straight Division A victory today in Block Island Week. The 60  foot sloop finished approximately six minutes ahead of Norm Raben's La Forza Del Destino in a race counterclockwise around the island.

title: ISRAEL SAYS EGYPT FIRED ON AIRCRAFT
description: TEL AVIV, June 29 (AP)Israeli Air Force pllanes were fired on over the Israelioccupied Sinai Peninsula today, the military command here reported.

title: Doctor's Alleged Mercy Killing Stirs Debate
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., June 28Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano, the chief resident surgeon at the Nassau County Medical Center, who yesterday was indicted for willful murder in connection with an alleged mercy killing, has become the focus of a storm of protest and in the bate at the center and in the medical community.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES LAZARD SUIT HERE
description: A prolonged lawsuit by Edward M. Gilbert against Andre Meyer and Lazard Freres & Co. was dismissed yesterday by Judge Charles H. Tenney in Federal Court here.

title: City Council Is Indicted in Lackawanna
description: BUFFALO, June 28The fivemember City Council and the City Clerk of the suburban steel town of Lackawanna were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of conspiracy and extortion said to involve kickbacks in the construction of a $900,000 City Hall annex.

title: Texas Jury Suspends Inquiry On Watergate BreakIn Funds
description: HOUSTON, June 28A Federal grand jury tracing money used to pay the Watergate burglars has suspended its investigation without reporting. Federal prosecutors said that any action the grand jury might take would be announced in Washington.

title: Walter Snow, ExNewsman And Author, Is Dead at 68
description: COVENTRY, Conn., June 28 (AP)Walter Snow, a newspaperman and author, died yesterday at Windham Community Hospital in Williamantic, apparently of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

title: Screen:' Operation Leontine' Is French Caper Film
description: Michel Audiard's "Operation Leontine," which opened yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room, is a heavily artificial comic-caper movie about an aged French queen of crime (Franoise Rosay) who temporarily leaves her retirement to outwit, outmurder, and outsteal all the hottest talent in Parisincluding her own fast-thinking, two-timing young niece (Marlene Jobert). There is a story behind all this, but it is of no account, and since the film doesn't care about it, neither shall I.What the film does care about is some not terribly exalted notion of cinema styleor stylishnesswhich it does its endless, agonizing, suffocating, unfunny best to exploit. In the early nineteen-sixties it was fashionable among second- and third-rank French directors to make movies that were archly self-conscious of the medium, and it is to this tradition, 10 years out of date, that "Operation Leontine" belongs. It is the kind of film in which characters spend almost as much time talking to the camera as they do to each otherthus presuming on a bond of audience sympathy that has not been earned and therefore does not exist.Michel Audiard is well-known as a writer (not director) of popular film comedies, and Franois Rosay's career covers literally the entire history of the French sound filmso there is a degree of professionalism in "Operation Leontine" that seems to belie the absolute dullness of everything that shows on the screen. But the dullness is real and the professionalism, a waste. Movies at precisely this level make me long for fresh air and sunlight, and perhaps immersion in the 19th-century novel.Richard Sarafian's "The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing" is set in the post-Civil War West and is about a former Army officer-turned-train robber (Burt Reynolds) who was once married to an Indian girl named Cat Dancing. Hence the title. It's also about the high-born lady (Sarah Miles) whom he apparently liberates when he teaches her how to cook and make love.Most of the movie is a desultory chase: the officer-gentleman-train robber, the woman and some outlaws (including Jack Warden) in the lead, pursued by a sherif (Lee J. Cobb), the woman's husband (George Hamilton) and a posse. When one of the lesser outlaws gets fresh with Miss Miles, Jack Warden kicks him in the groin. When Mr. Warden rapes Miss Miles, Mr. Reynolds shoots him in the groin. When Miss Miles asks Mr. Reynolds why two people fall in love, he answers: "I dunno. I suppose it's like two drops of rain that fall together and become one."The film's poetry is as numbing as its violence."The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing" is, indeed, a kind of festival of incompetence. Each shot is held slightly too long or too short, and is somehow off-center. Each performance is uncertain, like something seen in an early rehearsal. Even the Indians look fake, including good old Jay Silverheels, who is real.The screenplay, based on Marilyn Durham's novel, is by Eleanor Perry ("David and Lisa," "Diary of a Mad Housewife"), who can do much, much better.

title: WILKINS IS VICTOR IN DISCUSS THROW
description: TORONTO, June 28 (Canadian Press)The United States picked up two medals in today's first two events of the Pacific Conference Games.

title: U. S. Heroin Addiction Reported On Decline After Peaking in 69
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 Heroin addiction in the United States doubled between 1965 and 1969 but is now on the decline, according to the White House Special Action Office for Drug Abuse et al drug treatment programs between June, 1969, and March, 1073, show a reversal in the siNyear trend toward more addicts that began in 1965.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Inge Estate Left to Sister
description: LOS ANGELES, June 28 (UPI)William Inge, the playwright, left his estate of over $50,000 to his sister, Helen Connell, it was disclosed today when his will was admitted to probate. The document, dated March 28, 1972, named Mrs. Connell as executor of the estate. Mr. Inge died June 10.

title: May Building Contracts Rose
description: May contracts for future construction work ran 4 per cent higher than the yearago level but this was interpreted as being a negative factor, according to George A. Christie, vice president and chief economist for the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company.

title: Food Shortages Termed Possible in Next Month
description: CHICAGO, June 28Housewives searching their supermarket shelves this coming week will find most of what they want still there. But widening circle of food processors and retailers are caught in a profit squeeze resulting from the price freeze, and this is beginning to curtail production of some foods.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Court Orders the E.P.A. To Hear Utility Objections
description: CINCINNATI, June 28 (UPI)  The Environmental Protection Agency may not enforce pollution abatement plans for Ohio and Kentucky until public utilities have a chance to file objections, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled today.

title: Ballet: Dream Sparkles
description: Lysander and Hermia and Demetrius and Helena were with us again, courtesy of the New York City Ballet, at the State Theater on Wednesday night. Lysander loves Hermia, and Hermia loves Lysander, but Demetrius also loves Hermia, and Helena loves Demetrius.

title: The Pop Life
description: Jazz, remarked the disk jockey Gerry Bledsoe last summer, is our greatest music, but it doesn't get played because it isn't popular enough and it's not popular because it doesn't get played.

title: TV Technicians Strike Enters Fourth Week at Four Stations
description: A technicians strike at four television stations owned by the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company went into its fourth week yesterday with no prospect for settlement in sight.

title: Brother Is Indicted in Slaying at Hospital
description: FREEHOLD, June 28A Monmouth County grand jury returned an indictment of murder today against Lester Zygmaniak in the apparent mercy killing of his paralyzed brother, George, at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune last week.

title: A DETECTIVE CHIEF AMONG 5 INDICTED
description: PATERSON, June 28The chief of Paterson detectives, a Passaic County detective and three others were charged by state grand jury today with bribery, misconduct in office and gambling.

title: Judge Weinstein Loses Bid for a New Primary.
description: ALBANY, June 28 (UPI)A State Supreme Court justice dismissed today an appeal by Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court for a new Democratic primary election to determine the party's nominee for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals.

title: Theater As You Like lt Papp Opens the Season at Delaconte in Park
description: What would summer in New York be like without Joseph Papp giving us Shakespeare at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park? Well, if the question is not entirely rhetorical, let me say that it certainly would not be any better. The summer festivities got off this year with Joseph Papp's own staging of As You Like It, and it is pretty, romantic, charming and lighthearted.

title: Notes on People
description: Howard Hughes has picked up London's option. The reclusive industrialist slipped out of The Inn on the Park hotel, made his way to Stansted Airport, boarded a chartered aircraft and flew to Ostend, Belgium. About an hour later, he returned to Britain, where he received a visitor's visa good for another six months. According to the Home Office, the whole todo was really quite unnecessary, as it is not necessary to leave and reenter the country for extension of permission to stay. Mr. Hughes has been in Britain since he left Nicaram& after last year's earthquakes.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE AS VOLUME SLIPS
description: Prices rose on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market yester day in sluggish trading.

title: Presidential Pilot
description: Through thirteen of the most fateful years in American history, Samuel I. Rosenman served as an influential White House adviser. He did more than coin the name for Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal and help draft scores of memorable speeches for both F.D.R. and Harry S. Truman. His sound counsel contributed significantly to shaping the policies that steered the United States through the Great Depression and led to victory in World War II.

title: Aqueduct Favorite Is Last As Zulu Tom, $15.60, Wins
description: The transfer of the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday to a mile on the dirt instead of the originally scheduled 11/6 miles on the turf proved quite beneficial to Zulu Tom of the Cragwood Stable. The 4yearold colt came along just in time to win, by a neck over Dundee Marmalade.

title: Enemies of the People
description: CHICAGOI have had a mixed reaction to being named on a long master list of enemies of Richard Nixon and his Administration, and on another list of less than twenty particular enemies that Mr. John Dean forwarded on Sept. 14, 1971, to an aide of Mr. H. R. Haldeman.

title: H.R.A. POSTPONING RENEWAL OF PACT
description: The renewal of a $2million contract from the Human Resources Administration to operate an antipoverty training program will be deferred pending an investigation by the agency of the Queens contractor running the program.
