description: Today's Entries at Monmouth

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: The arrival of the Newport Jazz Festival puts such a spotlight on jazz in New York that it's easy to forget that jazz is a hardy city perennial, one that seems to be getting stronger.

title: RATES ON CREDIT SHOW BROAD DIP
description: The bond market, which has been moving toward higher interest rates since early May, paused yesterday to decide if the trend had gone far enough.

title: P.O.W.'S WIFE SAYS U. S. KILLED HIM
description: DENVER, June 28The wife of a former prisoner of war who fatally shot himself yesterday charged today that his countrymen had killed him with harassment and torment.

title: World Group on Whaling Votes Curb on Hunt for One Species
description: LONDON, June 28The International Whaling Commission approved a moratorium today on the hunting of fin whales in the Antarctic.

title: MEIER TOPPLED BY BORG IN 5 SETS; TAYLOR ADVANCE
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 28Bjorn Borg, the 17yearOld Swedish wonder boy, advanced to the round of 16 in the Wimbledon tennis championship today, but it took all his startling speed of serve and the pinpoint accuracy of heavily spun forehand to subdire Karl Meiler of West Germany, 64, 6.4, 36, 26, 63.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Today's Entries at Aqueduct

title: Bill on Mail to President
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) Legislation has been introduced in the House that would authorize the sending of postagefree mail to the President, Vice President, members of Congress and Federal departments and agencies. Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of New York, introduced the bill Tuesday.

title: Wider Fish War?
description: The Cod War that recently has precipitated dangerous encounters between Icelandic patrol vessels and British frigates in disputed fishing areas off Iceland is threatening to move west and escalate into a far more serious confrontation between the United States and foreign fishing fleets operating off this country's East Coast.

title: AIDES DENY NIXON APPROVED CHARGE
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 28Spokesmen for President Nixon attempted today to dissociate the President from any personal involvement in or approval of the statement before the Watergate committee charging that John W. Dean 3d was the chief architect of the White House coverup.

title: Donald Weeden Is Elected President of the City Club
description: Donald E. Weeden has been elected president of the City Club of New York to succeed Robert Conrad, who will continue as a trustee.

title: CASEY SAYS DEAN MADE YESCO PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (Reuters)William J. Casey, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, charged today that John W. Dean 3d, the ousted White House counsel now testifying at the Senate Watergate hearings, had tried to delay an investigation of Robert L. Vesco, the international financier.

title: Users Abroad See Move as Threat To Supplies
description: LONDON, June 28 (Reuters)  The United States decision to ban exports of soybeans, a vital world source of protein, caused wide concern today.

title: FRANCE DECLARES TESTS HARMLESS
description: PARIS, June 28 (UPI)The Foreign Ministry released a white paper today on the French nuclear testing program, saying that tests in the South Pacific do not harm either people or environment.

title: Colson Denies Making List of Political Enemies
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Charles W. Colson, in a letter to the Senate Watergate committee, today denied that he was the author of the White House list of political enemies. I do not know who prepared that document, he said.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: CHICAGOWaived Rick Reichardt, outfielder, for purpose of giving him unconditional release.

title: Senate Names Specialist To Study State Problems
description: ALBANY, June 28 (UPI)The State Senate has hired a government administrative specialis to make fast but thorough studies of state problems and recommend solutions, Majority Leader Warren M. Anderson announced today.

title: Name Change Is Voted
description: Stockholders of the Family Finance Corporation voted yesterday at a special meeting in Atlanta to change the name of the company to Aristar, Inc. effective June 29. The company operates 447 consumer finance offices in 27 states and 101 retail furniture stores in the southeast.

title: 2d Missile Shot Succeeds
description: WHITE SANDS MISSILE RANGE, N. M., June 28 (AP)An Army Pershing artillery) missile launched yesterday from McGregor Range in southern New Mexico was terminated after a malfunction in flight, but a second firing was successful.

title: ALFREDO VALENTE
description: SEA CLIFF, L.I., June 28Alfredo Valente, curator of the New York Cultural Center until ilness forced his resignation several years ago, died yesterday at his home here. He was 74 years old.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON A FUND CUTOFF FOR THE BOMBING
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 A SenateHouse conference committee reached agreement tonight on a bill containing a provision cutting off present and future funds for the bombing of Cambodia while efforts were made in other quarters to reach a compromise in the Congressional confrontation with President Nixon.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MIDDLESEX, June 28For people who believe that horse shoes bring luck, the place to be Sunday is Mountain View Park. The New Jersey State Horse Shoe Pitchers Association is sponsoring the Middle Atlantic open championships, starting at 1 P.M.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.5 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 171.6 from 172.1 last week.

title: Orioles Defeat McDowell by 63
description: BALTIMORE, June 28No matter for whom he pitches, Sam McDowell can't seem to beat Baltimore. The Orioles got their seventh straight victory over the lefthander, 63, before an encouraging crowd of 26,012 in Memorial Stadium tonight to move.within one game of McDowell's new club, the firstplace New York Yankees.

title: 114 Loss to Phils Ends Mets Home Stay
description: A fivegame home stand this week gave the limping Mets a chance to take a breather, win a few and get some laundry done. They got some laundry done, but they gave up 32 runs and lost four of the five games.

title: $124,587 Spent by G.S.A. To Protect Agnew's Home
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP)  The General Services Administration reported to Conress today that it spent $124,587 on protective measures in April, May and June of this year at the residence of Vice President Agnew.

title: A Federal Program Will Assess 17YearOld Students Literacy
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 28 A Federal program to assess literacy among the nation's 17yearolds was announced here last night by Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: La Prevoyante Favored Today Over 15 Colts and Another Filly
description: La Prevoyante, a filly, is favored today in the $124,150 Queen's Plate at Woodbine in Toronto, A bulky field of 17, including 15 colts, has been entered for the 114th running of North America's oldest continuous stakes race. Distance for the event is 11/4 miles.

title: Bunker Is Expected to Get PanamaNegotiations Post
description: WASHINGTON, June 29Administration officials said today that President Nixon would probably name Ellsworth Bunker, former Ambassador to South. Vietnam, as the chief negotiator in the Panama Canal discussions.

title: Gay Skipper Is Rated 61 In Yonkers Pace Tonight
description: YONKERS, June 29While Valiant Bret continues to win and Ricci Reenie Time contimes to lose, Gay Skipper goes barely noticed through the 3yearold pacing picture. But the Meadow Skipper colt, who is rated 61 for tomorrow night's Cane Futurity Prep at Yonkers Raceway, has been taking his share of the stake all along.

title: ExNassau Zoning Official Cleared in TaxFixing Case
description: A Federal District Court jury of eight women and four men acquitted Frederick Costanzo, former chairman of the Nassau County Zoning Commission, of conspiring to fix Federal tax cases for fees.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The Indian shops that keep springing up all over town like seedlings after a good rain mostly stock mirror dresses, baggy embroidered tops and somewhat shapeless dresses made of the same coarse printed cotton that shows up in bedspreads, as well as gaudy jewelry and odds and ends in brass. In fact, the kind of thing that visitors to India might pick up cheaply at local bazaars.

title: Frazier Gets Football Post
description: JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., June 29 (AP)Roy Frazier was appointed Tennesse State University football coach today. He succeeds John Robert Bell, who resigned last week.

title: Newport Jazz Festival Blows In
description: Jazz men, accustomed to adversity, blew lilting choruses of joyous affirmations across the face of a sodden afternoon in Central Park yesterday to open the 20th annual Newport Jazz Festival.

title: Deadening Defense
description: What is it about the five walls of the Pentagon that seem to close in so relentlessly upon any fresh and innovative minds that presume to enter? President Nixon's new Secretary of Defense, James It. Schlesinger, is not the kind of man one would call a patsy. On the contrary, he seems to have the kind of bureaucratic and managerial toughness required to brake the momentum toward aggrandizement that has so divorced the defense establishment from the realities of America's needs.

title: Syrian Unit Reported in Hanoi Seeking Advisers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 29A Syrian military delegation arrived in Hanoi today to seek North Vietnamese military advisers for the Syrian armed forces, according to informed travelers from Damascus. They said that the leftist Syrian Government wanted experts in guerrilla warfare and in the use of surfacetoair missiles built by the Soviet.

title: June Prices Surged 6% for Farm Goods
description: WASHINGTON, June 29Prices farmers get for raw products soared 6 per cent in June and averaged 38 per cent more than a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP, June 29In future years Morris County residents won't have to worry about mild winters curtailing their ice skating and hockey. Last winter was disastrous for anyone waiting for Mother Nature to freeze the ponds and lakes solid enough for skating.

title: A Chain of Minor Accidents Snarls Traffic on Route
description: SECAUCUS, June 29A chain of minor accidents involving two buses, two trucks and three cars this afternoon snarled westbound traffic on Route 3 near the New Jersey Turnpike and Lincoln Tunnel.

title: Excerpts From Testimony by Dean Before Senate Panel Investigating Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, June 29Following are excerpts from a transcript the testimony of John W. Dean 3d on the 16th day of the hearings on the Watergate case today before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activity:

title: Jersey Officials Plan Smut Crackdown
description: TRENTON, Junne 29  The Attorney General of New Jersey and the state's county prosecutors met today to plan a crackdown on pornography under last week's ruling by the United States Supreme Court empowering local communities to establish their own definition of obscenity.

title: URUGUAY SEEKS END OF GENERAL STRIKE
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 29 (UPI)With gasoline and food running short, President Juan Marfa Bordaberry sought today to end a general strike called in protest against the end of constitutional government here.

title: People in Sports: Allen Lost to White Sox
description: Dick Allen of the Chicago White Sox, the American League's most valuable player last season and its leading vote collector in the current AllStar Game poll, will be out of the Chicago lineup for from one to four weeks.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: *Hanover Trail Steak House, 1401 Route 10, Whippany, N.J.

title: POLICY REVERSED ON HEALTH FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 29In a major policy reversal, the Nixon Administration indicated today its support of legislation that would provide $207.9million for health and medical research and training grants.

title: VICTOR I. HORN
description: LOS GATOS, Calif., June 29 (UPI)Victor I. Horn, a plastics engineer and World War II hero who was awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor for his exploits during the North African campaign, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his Sunnyvale home. He was 50 years old.

title: 3 OFFICERS INJURED IN ARREST ON BRIDGE
description: Three police officers were injured last night while arresting a 16yearold Brooklyn youth suspected of having held up several persons on the Brooklyn Bridge on previous Friday nights, the police reported.

title: A 22 Acre Industrial Park Planned at Navy Yard Site
description: The 22acre eastern section of the old Brooklyn Navy Yard site will be rebuilt into a $35million industrial park, the city's Economic Development Administration announced yesterday.

title: 4 AIRPORTS IN CHINA REPORTEDLY CLOSED
description: PARIS, June 29 (UPI)Four major airports in China, including the one in Peking, have been closed since yesterday with no reason given, French air officials said Friday.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NEW YORKSigned Mike Heath, shortstop, second round choice In freeagent draft, and assigned him to Johnson City, Tenn., Rookie League.

title: GAINS RESUMED BY CONIMODITIES
description: CHICAGO, June 29Prices of most commodities for future delivery resumed their advance today on the nation's leading exchanges as commercial tracters decided that the Government's price ceilings and export embargoes on certain oil seeds were unworkable.

title: EHRLICHMAN WORDS LAID TO KLEINDIENST
description: In yesterday's New York Times, the transcript of a telephone conversation of March 28 between Richard G. Kleindienst, the former Attorney General, and John D. Ehrlichman, the President's former adviser on domestic affairs, contained remarks attributed to Mr. Kleindienst that were actually made by Mr. Ehrlichman. The passage follows:

title: Shift of Mine Safety Authority To Labor Department Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. introduced today legislation that would transfer Federal mine safety responsibilities from the Interior Department to the Labor Department. He charged Ithat Interior had failed to abate what he called the unacceptable rate of death and injury in the mines.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 3080inmate jail for adolescents officially opened on Rikers Island with Mayor Lindsay, Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm and Robert McKay, chairman of the Board of Correction, all saying the city should probably never again build such an institution.

title: Roundup: Reds Top Padres, 40
description: Pete Rose is a throwback to the hungry ballplayers of a less affluent era. He plays baseball in the same determined fashion that Enos Slaughter once did for the St. Louis Cardinals in the forties and fifties.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: CROSSWORD PUZZLE Edited by WILL WENG

title: Bridge: Ruffin in Defense an Error If Partner Can Take Trick
description: To ruff in defense when partner is about to win the trick is nearly always an error, as almost all players realize. It is somewhat harder to apply the corollary, that it is usually an error to ruff partner's potential trick.

title: A 22  Acre Industrial Park Planned at Navy Yard Site
description: The 22acre eastern section of the old Brooklyn Navy Yard site will be rebuilt into a $35million industrial park, the city's Economic Development Administration announced yesterday.

title: PAYMENTS DEFICIT INCREASES IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, June 29 (AP)Japan posted her third consecutive record monthly balanceofpayments deficit in May, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: LIQUIDATION SET FOR 4 I.O.S. FUNDS
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 29 (Reuters)  Official investigating authorities from Luxembourg, the United States and Canada have decided to put four mutual funds of the collapsed Investors Overseas Services (I.O.S.) financial empire into liquidation, the head of the Luxembourg Banking Commission, Albert Dondelinger, said today.

title: STOCKS ARE MIXED ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices were mixed and trading was dull yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: GTE Sylvania Elects
description: Theodore R. Bunnell has been named vice president and general manager of the chemical and metallurgical division of GTE Sylvania, Inc., a subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation. He succeeds Dr. Richard W. Mooney who was recently chosen president of the Wilbur B. Driver subsidiary.

title: U.S. Steel Picks Officer
description: J. Bruce Johnston has been named vice presidentlabor relations for the United States Steel Corporation. He will take over his new post as one of the company's top labor executives on July 1. Mr. Johnston has been with U.S. Steel since 1957 when he joined the company as an arbitration representative. His most recent position was general managerlabor elations, divisions and subsidiaries which he assumed in 1966.

title: The David Eisenhowers Defend Nixon
description: David Eisenhower and his wife the former Julie Nixon, asserted last night that President Nixon, Mrs. Eisenhower's father, knew nothing of the Watergate burglary or later coverup attempts.

title: SAIL TROPHY WON BY HOOD'S ROBIN
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., June 29Ted Hood's 36foot sloop Robin, out of Marblehead, Mass., and Lone Ranger, a Ranger 26 sloop owned by two young Rhode Islanders, Dave Giuliano and Matt Chrostowski, carried off the major trophies today on the third day of racing in Block Island Week.

title: PREMIERES ARE SET FOR DANCE FESTIVAL
description: The 26th Connecticut College American Dance Festival, which opened last night with the Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater, will present the first premiere of its sixweek season in New London on July 6 with the Erick Hawkins Dance Company.

title: RALPH W. E. WHEATLEY
description: NASHVILLE, June 29 (AP)Ralph Waldo Emerson Wheatley, a former Associated Press political writer and bureau chief, died Wednesday. He wasl 180 years old. Mr. Wheatley joined the A.P. Washington staff in 1918 and covered the Senate as well as the Teapot Dome oil scandal.

title: PROSECUTORS QUIT WATERGATE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 The three original Watergate prosecutors withdrew from the case today, maintaining that their investigation had been conducted forthrightly, vigorously and professionally.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An Easthampton police sergeant was shot and seriously wounded inside the Municipal Building yesterday. A suspect, Jerome Jackson, a 21yearold Fort Dix soldier from Newark, was accused of assault with a deadly weapon on the policeman, Gerald D. Mingin, 24. Sergeant Mingin was reported in serious condition with a bullet wound in the abdomen.

title: S. I. AND MANHATTAN GET NEW BUS SERVICE
description: The Transit Authority is scheduled to begin a new express bus service between Staten Island and Manhattan next Monday.

title: Shipping/Mails
Monmouth Jockeys
description: Monmouth Jockeys

title: LIQUIDATION PLAN IS PENNSY THREAT
description: The trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company proposed yesterday to end all freight and passenger service over a 10week period beginning Oct. 31 unless the company receives assurances of aid from the Government or other outside sources prior to Oct. 1. The trustees are recommending $600million to $800million in aid for the railroad.

title: President Asks the Nation to Drive Smaller Cars
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 President Nixon asked the American people today to help cure the nation's energy shortage by driving smaller cars and by keeping their homes warmer in summer and cooler in winter.

title: U.S. Concerns and Soviet Sign Big NaturalGas Deal
description: MOSCOW, June 29  The Soviet Union announced today that it had signed the second multibilliondollar natural gas deal with American companies in a month.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Reporter Facing 30 Days in Jail Agrees to Testify About Attica
description: BUFFALO, June 29 (AP)A Buffalo television newsman who was to have begun serving a 30day sentence on Monday agreed today to tell a grand jury everything he knows about the 1971 Attica prison rebellion.

title: Winning Release of Job Fund Elates HighSchool Girl
description: NEPTUNE, June 29A 16yearold girl who was one of the winners in a major suit against the Federal Government said today that she felt great about a court order to release $239million in Federal funds for the Neighborhood Youth Corps summer program.

title: RESERVE MAKES 2 MOVES TO SLOW LENDING BY BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Federal Reserve Board took two dramatic actions today in its continuing effort to slow the explosive growth of bank lending, which has contributed to the inflationary boom in the economy.

title: GOVERNOR DELAYS TRACK NOMINEES
description: The expected announcement of Governor Rockefeller's appointees to the new State Racing and Wagering Board was postponed yesterday as members of existing racing and betting agencies that would be superseded met at the Governor's office on West 55th Street here.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Up there behind the glass facade on the 33d floor of 1350 Avenue of the Americas, up there where the framed pledge above the receptionist's desk proclaims the careers of our clients are our primary responsibility, up there where the William Morris Agency executives wheel and deal for Elvis Presley, Sophia Loren, Bill Cosby, Don Rickles, Pearl Bailey and The Jackson Five, a new client has been added to, if the old clients will pardon the expression, the stable. The new client is Secretariat, apparently sport's most commercial commodity since Mark Spitz splashed to the seven Olympic gold medals. The selling of the Triple Crown, like the selling of Spitz's gold medals, has been entrusted to the world's largest talent agency, with offices in New York, Beverly Hills, Chicago, London, Paris, Rome, Madrid, Munich and, presumably, the winner's circle at Arlington. Park today.

title: Books of The Times,
description: POINTS FOR A COMPASS ROSE. By Evart S. Connell Jr. 240 pages. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $6.95.

title: Venezuelan Flees to Cuba
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 29 (UPI)A Venezuelan Air Force pilot angered by charges of reckless flying broke away from a formation of jet bombers and flew to Cuba, Venezulan authorities reported yesterday.

title: BENEDEK CAPTURES U.S. SABRE CROWN
description: TUCSON, Ariz., June 29 (AP)  The MidAtlantic fencing champion, Mikles Benedek of New Jersey, won the underI9 sabre title today during the national fencing championships. He had seven victories and no losses.

title: DRUGS MAY BE KEY IN MOUTH DISEASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 29Dr. Paul Goldhaber, the dean of the Harvard University School of Dentistry, said here today that aspirin and a related drug may one day play a role in preventing tooth loss caused by periodontal disease.

title: Upstate Mayor Calls On Indicted Councilmen to Resign
description: LACKAWANNA, N. Y., June 29The Mayor of this industrial city called today for the resignation of all five members of the City Council, who were indicted yesterday on charges of demanding kickbacks in the construction of a $1.5million City Hall annex.

title: Study Assails Rate Rises by the P.S.C.
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 29A fouryear study of the State's Public Service Commission's decisions on utility rates shows that the utilities are continuing to enjoy phenomenal success in getting what they ask for to the detriment of the consumer, according to Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer, Democrat of Long Beach.

title: Crime Is Down Slightly in Cities But Up in Suburbs, F.B.I. Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) Reported serious crime declined 1 per cent in the nation during the first three months of 1973 but crime in the suburbs and rural areas continued to increase, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Uniform Crime Report, made public today.

title: Poverty Aide's Conviction For Loitering Is Reversed
description: A conviction against an antipoverty worker for loitering last July 29 has been unanimously reversed by the Appellate Term of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn and the complaint against her dismissed.

title: LINDSAY PROMISES COURT AID TO POOR
description: Mayor Lindsay promised yesterday that the city would discharge its obligations and maintain the evenhanded administration of justice whether or not the Legal Aid Society's lawyers carry out their threatened strike next week.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
BLUE CROSS PLANNING A BLOODBANK OFFER
description: TRENTON, June 29 (AP), Blue Cross of New Jersey proposed again today to pay the blood processing costs of subscribers who would be willing to participate in a blood donor program.

title: Dean Charge on Phone Tap Denied by ExNixon Aide
description: HONOLULU, June 29 (UPI)A former aide to President Nixon has denied allegations by John W. Dean 3d that he provided technical information to tap the telephone of Joseph Kraft, a syndicated columnist.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 2 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 2 P.M.)

title: As Queen Visits, Canadians Debate the Monarchy
description: TORONTO, June 29  As Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip paraded down one of Toronto's main streets the other day, sitting on velvet seats in a blue horsedrawn carriage, a young woman who had been, waiting on the sidewalk for, more than an hour hoisted a little boy high and said:

title: T. A. Zucker Weds Kathleen Morrison
description: Miss Kathleen M. Morrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Morrison Jr. of Northampton, Mass., was married here at noon yesterday to Theodore A. Zucker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Zucker of New York. State Supreme Court Justice Arnold L. Fein performed the civil ceremony in his chambers.

title: Col. George Goethals Dies; Father Built Panama Canal
description: BOSTON, June 29 (AP)Col. George R. Goethals of Watertown, son of Maj. Gen. George W. Goethals, who built the Panama Canal, died yesterdayi at the Veterans Administration) Hospital here.

title: Court Finds News Violates Trust Laws on Deliveries
description: The Daily News was declared yesterday to have violated the Federal antitrust laws in its homedelivery system for the newspaper.

title: Henry Gaylord Dillingham 2d Marries Miss Janet M. Brown
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 St. Luke's Episcopal Church was the setting here this morning for the marriage of Miss Janet Murray Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leland Scott Brown of Bedford, N. Y., and Chappaquiddick Island, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., to Henry Gaylord Dillingham 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Franklin Dillingham 2d of Sydney, Australia, and Honolulu. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur W. Hargate, assisted by the Rev. Spencer M. Rice.

title: Rift Remains After Strike by Writers
description: LOS ANGELES, June 29Although the Writers Guild of America strike against the Association of Motion Picture and Television Producers has ended, the guild remains bitterly divided with several factions whose interests do not always coincide.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: A Continuing Marvel: The Story of the Museum of Science and Industry, by Herman Kogan (Doubleday, $7.95).

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN DULL SESSION
description: The stock market drifted aimlessly yesterday in sluggish trading and closed with moderate losses.

title: Colson Goes to W eicker's Office But the Senator Orders Him Out
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, ordered a former White House aide, Charles W. Colson, out of his office today. Mr. Weicker accused Mr. Colson in an impassioned speech yesterday of trying to pressure Mr. Weicker into halting his inquiry on the Watergate scandal.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The United States Maritime Administration has approved a $51.06  million subsidy for three liquefied natural gas ships which are to be built by the Ogden Corporation's Avondale Shipyards. The three ships which will cost a total of $309.06million, are to be built for the El Paso Natural Gas Company. Ogden said the subsidy amounts to 16.5 per cent of the total cost.

title: Heavy Rains Hit Tristate Area; Some Counties Upstate Flooded
description: Recurrent rainstorms marched across New York, New Jersey and Connecticut yesterday, pounding and flooding some sections and passing over others with a grumble.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon relayed assurances to Congress that United States military activity in Indochina would end by Aug. 15 and that he would seek Congressional approval if additional military action was needed after that date. The House, when it got word that the President for the first time would accept a deadline for halting the bombing in Cambodia, accepted the compromise and voted to delay until Aug. 15 a cutoff of funds for United States military activities in all of Indochina. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Improved WireMaking Machine Is Devised
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 The world's largest manufacturer of wire and cable products received a patent this week for a wiremaking machine that promises many advantages over conventional equipment. The apparatus makes wire by, continuously forcing metal rod, which has been coated with beeswax or another thick, sticky substance, through an extrusion die under high pressure.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey, daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: CONTRACT AWARDS:,.,
description: The United States Maritime Administration has approved a $51.06  million subsidy for three liquefied natural gas ships which are to be built by the Ogden Corporation's Avohdale Shipyards. The three ships which will cost a total of $309.06million, are, to be built for the El Paso Natural Gas Company. Ogden said the subsidy amounts to 16.5 per cent of the total cost.

title: New Mexico Aidg Absolves Montojia On 70 Vote Gifts
description: SANTA FE, N.M., June 29 (AP)Senator Joseph M. Montoya, Democrat of New Mexico, violated no state laws by failing to report more than $100,000 in contributions to his 1970 campaign, Attorney General David Norvell said today. He described his statement as an informal opinion.

title: Ban on Restaurant Lifted
description: The Sandwich Club, a restaurant at 180 Montague Street, Brooklyn, which the Health Services Administration closed for health code violations on June 19, was permitted to reopen last Monday after the violations were corrected, spokesman for the city agency said yesterday.

title: 12 Police Officers Facing CoverUp Trial
description: Twelve police officers, including two captains and two lieutenants, will be tried by the department on charges that they attempted to cover up evidence in the killing of an alleged pimp by a policeman.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Concerts Dance

title: Great Hatred, Little Room
description: BELFAST, Northern IrelandThe campaign that preceded Ulster's Thursday elections was marked as much by emotionalism as by logic. Many a political gathering reminded one of William Butler. Yeats frightening line: I carry from my mother's womb a fanatic heart.

title: Kennedy to Wallace Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said yesterday he would attend an awards dinner next week for Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama because I think it's important to try and sort of bring this country together. Mr. Kennedy, a possible 1976 Presidential contender, was interviewed on the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: WINE TALK
description: Ned Calmer, a famous radio voice for many years, was prompted to send along some comments on a recent article about the wine cellar at Restaurant Lutce.

title: MARK REVALUED AS DOLLAR EASES
description: PARIS, June 29  West Germany increased the official value of the mark by 5.5 per cent against other European currencies today in an effort to save European monetary unity and to end new turbulence in the foreignexchange markets.

title: Ehrlichman Reports Nixon Audits Under Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, June 29New assertions of intervention by the White House staff in income tax cases were made today along with a counterclaim that the Kennedy Administration had harassed Richard M. Nixon himself with continuous audits.

title: Yankee Atomic Gets Permit
description: The Maine Yankee Atomic Power Company said yesterday that it had been granted a 100 per cent permanent operating permit by the Atomic Energy Commission. The license covers the 855,000kilowatt nucleir power plant at Wiscasset, Me., that is jointly owned by several New England utilities. The power plant had been operating at 75 per cent of capacity.

title: Impact of Mark Move Weighed
description: The revaluation of the mark may eventually make West German products more expensive in the United States, traders serving both countries said yesterday.

title: Experiment Set Back
description: WASHINGTON, June 29A brave European experiment aimed at maintaining an island of relatively fixed currency exchange rates in an otherwise floating world suffered a major setback with today's decision by West Germany to revalue the mark upward. The snake of eight European currencies that floated jointly against the United States dollar since March in effect fell apart today, though it was promptly reconstituted with a new set of currency values. The effort to preserve fixed rates for trade and other transactions among the eight countries in the experiment broke down, according to a widespread view here, for the same reason that the former global system of fixed rates broke down.

title: Linda's Chief Is Favored Over 6 Rivals in Saranac
description: Linda's Chief, one of the original prospects for the $125,000 Arlington Special featuring Secretariat, will race Instead at Aqueduct today. Neil Hellman's speedy performer, rigged at the top weight of 126 pounds, is the favorite to take the Saranac, a sevenfurlong test for 3yearolds, which heads the local program.

title: Soviet Commenas Talks
description: MOSCOW, June 29The Soviet leadership today gave routine endorsement to the results of Mr. Brezhnev's visit to the United States.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Major League Baseball

title: Marilyn Horne on WQXR
description: Marilyn Home, the Metropolitan Opera soprano, will be hostess of The Listening Room on WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, the week of July 9 while Robert Sherman, is on vacation. And she will be his guest on the program next Friday, from 10:05 A.M. to noon.

title: Minor Leagues
description: INTERNATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Hockey Transactions
description: BUFFALOSigned Joe Noris, center.

title: Letter of Prosecutors and Reply
description: WASHINGTON, June 29Following are the texts of letter from the three original Watergate prosecutors, withdrawing from the case, to Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor, and a response by Mr. Cox:

title: Playground Is Alive With Running Water And Soaked Children
description: Sprawling beneath a high, broad outcropping of rock in Central Park is a watery city.

title: Chris Evert Gets Revenge at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 29There were six American women in the last 16 at nightfall, and the match that everybody at Wimbledon was wondering about was settled when fourthseeded Chris Evert defeated Julie Heldman, 63, 61, to revenge her crushing loss last week at Queen's.

title: RETURN TO ITALY BARRED BY HECHT
description: GENEVA, June 29Robert E. Hecht. Jr., the American expatriate who sold an ancient Euphronios vase to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in. New York for about $1million last year, said last night that he would not return to Italy, where a warrant for his arrest has been issued.

title: HENRY F. MARCELLE
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 29Henry F. Marcelle, a former insurance executive of the Sinclair Refining Corporation, died today at his home here. He was 73 years old.

title: 2 Missing Canadian Observers Believed Safe in Vietcong Area
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 29 (UPI)Two Canadian truce observers who made a practice of visiting the remotest South Vietnamese hamlets in their territory disappeared last night, but a Canadian spokesmand said today that they were believed to be safe.

title: Reds Bench Leads National Leaguers In AllStar Voting
description: Johnny Bench of the Cincinnati Reds is virtually assured of the starting catcher's position on the National League AllStar team, according to fan vote totals released yesterday by the baseball commissioner's office.

title: JUNIOR CHESS TITLE GOES TO COAST BOY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 (AP)Larry Christiansen, 16 years old, of Riverside, Calif., has won the United States Junior Chess championship.

title: Voicing Regrets on Need, City Opens a Y outh Prison
description: A 1,080inmate jail for adolescents officially opened on Rikers Island yesterday with Mayor Lindsay, Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm and Robert F. McKay, chairman of the City Beard of Correction, all saying that the city should probably never build such an institution again.

title: Bridal Held Here For Penelope Orth
description: Miss Penelope Orth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Walter Orth of Dousman, Wis., was married here yesterday afternoon to Michael Bareau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Bareau of London. Judge Richard S. Lane of the Civil Court performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Nelson.

title: Nixon Accepts With Praise Resignation of 2 Officials
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 29 (UPI)The resignations of Philip J. Farley and John L. Hazard were accepted yesterday by President Nixon, who praised both men.

title: Israel Indicts Kahane in Abduction Plot
description: TEL AVIV, June 29Rabbi Meir Kahane, leader of the militant Jewish Defense League, was indicted in Jerusalem today for conspiracy to abduct and murder foreign officials in the United States. He said in an Israeli district court that the case was connected with plans to disrupt the recent visit of Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was
description: Tickets matching The number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers In sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third end fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Jet to Race Moon's Shadow to Study the Sun's Corona
description: ABOARD THE S.S. CANBERRA, in the Atlantic off MAURITANIA, Saturday, June 30The first prolonged observations of the sun's dynamic corona are expected today from a supersonic Concorde jet airliner racing the moon's shadow across Africa during a total solar eclipse.

title: Football Transactions
description: NEW YORK GIANTSSinned Rich Glover, Nebraska defensive tackle, thirdround draft choice.

title: 30th New Orleans Victim
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 29 (UPI)A 30th victim has died from the fire in the Upstairs bar in the French Quarter last Sunday. Jim Hambrick, 45 years old, of New Orleans, died yesterday in Charity Hospital.

title: Reds Bench Leads National Leaguers In AllStar Voting
description: Johnny Bench of the Cincinnati Reds is virtually assured of the stalling catcher's position on the National League AllStar team, according to fan vote totals released yesterday by the baseball commissioner's office.

title: I.D.A. to Give Burma Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) The International Development Association said today it would provide $33million in credits to help Burma improve its rail and barge transport systems.

title: Mitchell Expected to Say He Knew About Coverup
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell is prepared to testify before Congressional investigators that he was aware of efforts to cover upi the Watergate breakin but did not actively participate in the coverup, according to persons close to Mr. Mitchell.

title: DECISION RESERVED IN NIZER BOOK CASE
description: Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr. reserved decision in Federal Court here yesterday, on an attempt by the sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg to block further distribution of Louis Nizer's book The Implosion, Conspiracy about the couple executed 20 years ago for conspiracy to steal atomic secrets.

title: General Tire Sets Profit Mark For Quarter but Year Net Lags
description: The General Tire and Rubber Company in the quarter ended May 31 had the highest sales and earnings for any quarter in its 58year history but a large extraordinary gain last year put the net income for the 1973 period below a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Nonmedical employes at Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn went on strike yesterday in an attempt to force the payment of back wages owed them by the voluntary institution. The 377bed facility turned away all but emergency cases, sent some patients home and enlisted administrators, nurses, technicians, secretaries and volunteers to maintain its services.

title: RABBIS ATTACK MIXED MARRIAGES
description: The New York Board of Rabbis voted yesterday to bar from membership those rabbis who officiate at mixed marriages.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: CITY AVERTS LOSS OF $77.5MILLION
description: A city loss of $77.5million in Federal urbanrenewal aid was averted yesterday, at least temporarily, when the Nixon Administration agreed to a threemonth extension of a deadline under which the city must make controversial changes in its construction laws or lose the money.

title: Bolding Defeats AkiiBua. In Hurdles Race at Sweden
description: VASTERAS, Sweden, June 29 (AP) Jim Bolding of Oklahoma City, the Amateur Athletic Union champion, won the 400meter intermediate hurdles in 50 seconds during an internatonal track meet today. John AkiiBuat Uganda's world recordholder and Olympic champion, was second.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York

title: DollarandScent Sales
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP)  A sign in a delicatessen here says: If you can't smell it, we ain't got it.

title: Booming Singapore: A Clean, Green and Straitlaced Island State
description: SINGAPORE, June 26The other day the Minister of State for Education told the Boy Scouts on this tropical island just north of the Equator to give up their traditional jungle activities and convert themselves into good, useful city Scouts.

title: NATIONAL CITY BANK IN FRENCH VENTURE
description: The First National City Bank, in its first move into the French consumer credit market, said yesterday that it had acquired majority control of a home mortgage company, Societe de Credit pour L'Acquisition L'Amelioration des Immeubles.

title: 12 POLICE FACING COVERUP TRIAL
description: Twelve police officers, including two captains and two lieutenants, are facing departmental trials on charges that they tried to cover up evidence in the killing of an alleged pimp by a policeman.

title: CITY GRAFT STUDY BEGUN BY NADJARI
description: Special Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari is investigating allegations that city officials and other political figures received kickbacks to arrange placement of millions of dollars in city funds in interestfree acounts in favored banks, according to sources knowledgeable about the investigation.

title: Drug Agency Chief Quits and Charges White House Interference
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) John E. Ingersoll resigned today as director of the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs, the Government's chief drug lawenforcement agency, charging that interagency rivalry, confusion and intervention by the White House had blunted the efforts of the Nixon Administration in drug control.

title: RESERVE MAKES 2 MOVES TO SLOW LENDING BY BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Federal Reserve Board took two dramatic actions today in its continuing effort to slow the explosive growth of bank lending, which has contributed to the inflationary, boom in the economy.

title: Radio
description: Talks, Sports. Events News Broadcasts

title: China's 20thCentury Ascendancy
description: CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward IslandChina is just now making its debut on the world stage as the Third World Power. This involves a fundamental shift in the focus of world politics. This shift will affect us all. It is imperative that we understand its nature and consequences if we in the West are not to repeat our tragic recent history in Asia. But such an understanding will require a considerable reorientation in our thinking.

title: MRS. FRANCIS J. STOKES
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 29Mrs. Lelia Woodruff Stokes, the widow of Francis J. Stokes, founder of the F. J. Stokes Machine Company, a division of the Pennwalt Corporation, died yesterday in Chestnut Hill Hospital. She was 87 years old.

title: Prostitutes Form a Union
description: IZMIR, Turkey (AP)Prostitutes in this Aegean seaport have formed a trade union, the Priirate Service Workers Union, to protest what they say is oppression and insecure working conditions.

title: Atoms and Apollos Tie
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 29, (AP)The Philadelphia Atoms, unbeaten in 11 straight games, played to a 11 draw with the Atlanta Apollos in a North American Soccer League game tonight. The goals were scored in the first 2 minutes by Paul Child of Atlanta and Karl Minor.

title: MRS. JACK H. LOCKHART
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y June 29 Mrs. Nina Tall Lockhart, the Iwife of Jack H. Lockhart, as sistant general editorial manager of the ScrippsHoward Newspapers, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived at 30 Ridgedale Road.

title: Brandt and Ceausescu Vow Noninterference in Affairs
description: BONN, June 29 (Reuters)Chancellor Willy Brandt and Rumania's president, Nicolate Ceausescu, stated today that no country had the right to interfere in another country's affairs for any reason or under any pretext.

title: Election in Ulster Shows No Healing of Old Division
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, June 30Northern Ireland's voters kept to the old division in Thursday's election, with Protestants and Roman Catholics voting solidly for the parties most closely identified with their respective communities.

title: U.S. Aide Says Compromise on Bombing in Cambodia Will Allow Delicate Talks to Go
description: WASHINGTON, June 29A senior official of the Nixon Administration said today that Congressional acceptance of six more weeks of bombing in Cambodia would allow the United States to continue the extremely delicate negotiations now going on to end the fighting there.

title: Kodak Denies Allegations
description: In an answer filed in the United States District Court in New York yesterday, the Eastman Kodak Company denied, all allegations of unlawful activity and claims of damage made by Berkey Photo, Inc., in its $300million suit against Eastman filed on Jan. 29. Eastman asked for dismissal of the complaint which alleged monopolistic practices and domination of the market.

title: Chicago Executive Leads Police To Suspects in His Kidnapping
description: MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., June 29 (UPI)  A Chicago executive held for $1.5million ransom today eluded his kidnappers with a ruse, caught the attention of a passing policeman and led the police on chase that resulted in the capture of two suspects.

title: Peking Press Takes First Note Of Brezhnev's Visit to the U.S.
description: PEKING, June 29 (Reuters) The Chinese press today made its first reference to the recent summit meeting between Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, and President Nixon, but refrained from any comment on the outcome of the talks.

title: Text of President's Statement on Dealing With Nation's Energy Resource Problem
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 29Following is the text of the President's energy statement released here today:

title: PROSECUTORS QUIT WATERGATE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 The three original Watergate prosecutors withdrew from the case today, maintaining that their investigation had been conducted forthrightly, vigorously and professionally,

title: Soviet Trawler Saves American Boat
description: POINT JUDITH, R. I., June 29 The flagship of the Soviet fishing fleet rescued the captain and crewman of a small American fishing boat late yesterday after they had clung for more than 24 hours to the cabin roof of their foundering ship.

title: Good Old Country Boys Enliven the Scene
description: WASHINGTON, June 29Sometimes, when crackerbarrel time comes around at the Senate Watergate hearings, it's mind of hard on anyone who's not just a good old country boy.

title: Jaz: Mulligan's Big Age of Steam
description: Gerry Mulligan and his new big band, Age of Steam, got the Newport Jazz Festival started yesterday morning, seven minutes early and swinging hard. The festival's opening program was scheduled to begin at noon in the Wollman Amphitheater in Central Park, but with only a hardy handful of fans huddled under umbrellas and parkas in an intermittently drenching rain, Mr. Mulligan Hjumped the gun and gave the ardy ones something to be grateful for.

title: CUBS DOWN METS IN 10 INNINGS, 43
description: CHICAGO, June 29It's obvious why the Chicago Cubs look like a much more threatening baseball team under Whitey Lockman than they were under Leo Durocher. Lockman knows how to make the right moves.

title: Immigration Inquiry Reported Stalled
description: WASHINGTON, June 29An investigation of corruption and of management deficiencies in the Immigration and Naturalization Service in the Southwest has been hampered by difficulties in securing witnesses and records in Mexico, two Justice Department lawyers told Congress yesterday.

title: Qaddafi Concedes Differences With Egypt on Merger
description: CAIRO, June 29Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the leader of Libya, reported publicly for the first time here last night that basic differences existed between him and President Anwar elSadat of Egypt concerning the intended union of the two countries.

title: A 50c Fare on PATH Looming as Chance For Veto Is Refused
description: The only possible stumbling block is the Interstate Commerce Commission, which must determine whether the 20cent fare rise would violate President Nixon's current price freeze.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Very recently, a local paper reported that the United States was struggling to remain the world leader in the sale of arms to other nations.

title: Chilean Revolt Crushed As Army Backs Allende
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 29 Rebel troops seized control of the downtown area this morning and sprayed the Defense Ministry and the presidential palace with machinegun fire before being put down by armed forces loyal to President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: ALEXANDER'S NAMED IN DEFAMATION SUIT
description: A clothing manufacturer has filed a defamation suit against Alexander's Department Stores for $5.5million in Manhattan State Supreme Court.

title: People and Business
description: A national effort to translate the goals of American society into social action was urged yesterday by William F. May, chairman of the American Can Company.

title: Notes on People
description: Shortly before Aristotle Onassis and his wife, Jacqueline, sailed out of the Spanish resort of Estepona aboard his yacht, Christina, the shipping magnate delivered himself of an assessment of Generalissimo Francisco Franco to a local newspaper. Franco, he said, is the world's greatest genius, who has known how to organize a country like Spain and predict its future. Local sources said Mr. Onassis had been looking into the possibility of investment in Spain's popular southern coast.

title: United States Government and Agency Bonds
description: (Prices In 32d of a point, composite bill yields In basis points.)

title: A Coup Aborted
description: The prompt crushing by loyalist forces of an armored regiment's rebellion against President Allende in Chile is a cause for great relief. Chile has drifted into difficult and dangerous times under Dr. Allende's Marxistdominated Government; but a military takeover would only make things worse, raising prospects of civil war addition to destroying one of the few remaining democratic systems in Latin America.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DANCE Dance Films Association, as its name indicates, is dedicated to preserving visual records of dance and danceeducation interest, whether on film, videotape or stills.

title: HODESIA'S GRIEF ASSAILS BRITAIN
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 9  Prime Minister Ian D. mith of Rhodesia told Britain oday to get off our backs.

title: U.S. Six in World Tourney
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 29 (AP) The United States will send an entry to the first world junior hockey championships Dec. 27 through Jan. 7 in the Soviet Union, according to Robert Fleming of Rochester, Minn., the vice president of the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States.

title: 7 ARRESTS MADE IN AN I.B.M. CASE
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., June 29 (AP)  San Jose police announced the arrests today of seven suspects in a multimilliandollar industrial espionage case that the police said was perpetrated against the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Avco Corp. Plans 48Million Writeoff
description: The Avco Corporation announced late yesterday afternoon that it planned to write off about $48million of its firsthalf earnings due to the decision of Cartridge Television, Inc., to file a petition for arrangement with its creditors under Chapter Xl of the Bankruptcy Act.

title: William R. Brewster, 79, Educator Operated a Camp
description: EAST WATERFORD, Me., June 29William R. Brewster, an educator and summercamp operator, died today in the Bridgeton Hospital. He was 79 years old aml lived here in the summers and in Leesburg, Fla., in the winters.

title: Nuclear Test in Nevada
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 29 (AP)A nuclear device with a yield range of between 20,000 and 200,000 tons of TNT has been detonated underground at the Nevada Test Site near here. An Atomic Energy Commission spokesman said there was no radiation leakage and no reports the explosion had been felt outside the test site.

title: MARK REVALUED AS DOLLAR EASES
description: PARIS, June 29  West Germany increased the official value of the mark by 5.5 per cent against other European currencies today in an effort to save European monetary unity and to end new turbulence in the foreignexchange markets.

title: CORNELIUS R. VAN REES
description: Cornelius R. Van Rees, who retired in 1954 after 32 years as organist and choir director of the Baptist Temple in Brooklyn, died Thursday in Doctors Hospital. His age was 73, and he lived in Freeport, L. I.

title: Iceland Fires at Germans
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 29 (UPI)An Icelandic gunboat opened fire on a West German trawler that had intruded into Iceland's fishing waters yesterday and the trawler departed, the Coast Guard reported today. The incident was reported while talks started between the two countries to find a solution to the fishing dispute.

title: OBSCENITY RUNG WILL BE RESISTED
description: The outlines of a national campaign by booksellers, publishers and filmmakers to minimize the effects of the Supreme Court's tough new antiobscenity guidelines were agreed upon yesterday at a closed meeting in the offices of a Manhattan law firm.

title: Dean Ends Testimony, Story Unshaken; 3 Senators Hint They Want Nixon Reply
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 John W. Dean 3d completed his long appearance before the Senate Watergate committee today, unshaken on his central charge that President Nixon had been an active participant in the Watergate coverup.

title: Major League Leaders
description: Major League Leaders

title: Winning Release of Job Fund Elates High School Girl
description: NEPTUNE, N. J., June 29 A 16yearold girl who was one of the winners in a major suit against the Federal Government said today that she felt great about a court order to release $239million in Federal funds for the Neighborhood Youth Corps summer program.

title: Drought in the Southern Sahara Limits Drinking Water in Dakar
description: DAKAR, Senegal, June 25 Mbaye Diof put the family water pails on the hot yellow sand at the end of a long line of the pails of 20 other families at a public water tap.

title: LAURA BAUGH TIES FOR LEAD ON A 70
description: ATLANTA, June 29 (UPI)Laura Baugh made her professional golf debut today with a sparkling threeunderpar 70 and shared the firstround lead with Sandra Haynie in the Lady Tara golf tournament.

title: Minor Leagues
description: INTERNATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Equity Financing
description: Litton Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that Litton Industries International, NV, its Netherlands subsidiary, completed a subordinated loan agreement with Union Bank of Switzerland for the purpose of buying up to $25million of Litton Industries, Inc. common stock in Europe. The bank will make block purchases in Europe in amounts in excess of $250,000 per block, from time to time, for the account of Litton Industries International. Subject to the approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said, purchases may later be made in the open market in Europe. The stock of the electronics producer closed at 8, down , on the Big Board.

title: BUFORD SCOTT
description: RICHMOND, June 29 (AP)Buford Scott, a general partner in Scott & Stringfellow, one of the oldest investment houses in the South, died yesterday at the age of 77.

title: Irwin Gets A66 for 133, 2Shot Lead
description: CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) Arnold Palmer's redhot putter turned cold today and Hale Irwin swept into the secondround lead in the $175,000 Western open golf tournament.

title: Idaho Ranchers Declare a Shooting War on Rapidly Increasing Coyote Population
description: STANLEY, Idaho, June 21  Melting snow, icy creeks, ground squirrels dodging redtailed hawks and Basque shepherds tending ewes and lambs  it is an annual spring story in the Stanley Basin.

title: Dennis Banks Posts Bond
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., June 29 (UPI)Dennis Banks, a leader of the American Indian Movement, was released on $105,000 bond yesterday after surrendering earlier in the week to face 12 counts relating to the 71day occupation of Wounded Knee.

title: CITY GRAFT STUDY BEGUN BY NADJARI
description: Special Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari is investigating allegations that city officials and other political figures received kickbacks to arrange placement of millions of dollars in city funds in interestfree acounts in favored banks, according to sources knowledgeable about the investigation.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, JUNE 30, 1973
description: President Nixon relayed assurances to Congress that United States military activity in Indochina would end by Aug. 15 and that he would seek Congressional approval if additional military action was needed after that date. The House and the Senate, when they got word that the President for the first time would accept a deadline for halting the bombing in Cambodia, accepted the compromise and voted to delay until Aug. 15 a cutoff of funds for United States military activities in all of Indochina. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Secretariat Wears the Crown Easily Before Setting Chicago Afire
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., June 29It was nearly dark in Arlington Park's bleak, treeless stable area tonight when Baron reported for work at Barn 10.

title: LIQUIDATION PLAN IS PENNSY THREAT
description: The trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company proposed yesterday to end all freight and passenger service over a 10week period beginning Oct. 31 unless the company receives assurances of aid from the Government or other outside sources prior to Oct. 1. The trustees are recommending $600million of $800million in aid for the railroad.

title: G.E. Elects Vice President
description: Maurice H. Mayo has been elected vice president and controller of the General Electric Company, effective July 1. He had previously served as staff executive, financial resources.

title: A SAVING DRIVE URGEDBYNIXON IN ENERGY PLAN
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 29President Nixon announced today his plan to meet the nation's energy needs. It included a voluntary conservation drive in which the Federal Government would set the example, expansion of research to find new energy sources and Government reorganization to give higher priority to energy matters.

title: Nation's Energy Coordinator John Arthur Love
description: John Arthur Love was a littleknown Colorado Springs lawyer in 1962 when he first ran for Governor of Colorado. One of his opponents then pointed to a campaign poster with the word LOVE printed on it and said, how you going to get them to vote against that? Now he is well into his third term, and, if his tenure has not been particularly innovative, he has provided the people of Colorado with a comfortable, solid and quiet administration without a hint of scandal.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on bill requiring that appointments of director and deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget be confirmed by the Senate, which passed, 72 to 12, June 25.

title: ABORTIONS FOR 2 BLOCKED BY JUDGE
description: Demonstrations against abortion, including a prayer of thanksgiving, were held outside two South Jersey hospitals yesterday after an appeals judge stayed a lower court ruling allowing abortions for two women at the institutions.

title: Stallings Upsets Mac Foster
description: CHICAGO, June 29 (AP)Bob Stallings, Brooklyn heavyweight, scored an upset splitdecision victory over Mac Foster of Chicago tonight in the Aragon Ballroom. The defeat was only the third in 33 fights, for Foster, whose previous, losses were to Jerry Quarry and Muhammad Ali. There were no knockdowns.

title: A Prophet Retires
description: You may shoot me, but my men must be unmolested when surrendering; the 33yearold professor of Gaelic told his English captor after the gallant hist stand outside Dublin that ended Ireland's Easter Rising of 1916. And he would have been shot, along with fourteen other Irish revolutionary commanders and their romantic leader, Padraic Pearse, but for the accident of his birth in New York City. At that stage of World War I, the British decided not to risk such a major offense to American opinion.

title: Pulling the Plug
description: By impounding funds appropriated by Congress, by curtailing requests for new funds and now by administrative edict, the Administration is turning its back on the poor and on the cities in which so many'of them live. The latest example comes in health care, where newly promulgated rules of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare threaten to wipe out essential programs previously approved and funded by the Federal Government.

title: PARK SLOPE TALKS YIELD AGREEMENT
description: Feuding Italian and Puerto Rican neighbors in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, where twelve persons, including seven policemen, were injured earlier this week in disorders and shootings, met last night with city officials and agreed on a plan to ease racial tension in the area.

title: Kerwin Says Space Travel Is Healthful
description: HOUSTON, June 29A person living in space can develop a sense of glowing health and wellbeing, the first American doctor to go there said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MILAN, Italy, June 29 (AP)Adriano Panatta and Paolo Bertolucci, Italy's Davis Cup stars, were suspended for three months from the Italian Tennis Federation today for joining an international boycott of Wimbledon. The ban apparently dashed Italy's hopes of advancing in the Davis Cup competition, which resumes in Turin July 20 with a match against Spain.

title: Murcer Honer Defeats Perry
description: If Gaylord Perry was throwing a greaseball last night, it certainly lacked its usual stuff. The New York Yankees smacked three home runs off the Cleveland righthander to defeat the Indians, 72, before 9,958 in Yankee Stadium.

title: Peking Invites Taiwan To TableTennis Match
description: HONG KONG, June 29 The leader of Taiwan's tabletennis association has received a message from China inviting his organization to participate in a tournament in Peking beginning Aug. 25.

title: Court Decision Is Awaited In Little League Test Case
description: DETROIT, June 28 (UPI)Carolyn King, 12 years old, put aside her baseball glove yesterday to appear in court in her suit challenging the constitutionality of the Little League's no girls rule. Attorneys for Miss King, center fielder for the Ypsilanti Orioles, asked the United States District Court judge, Ralph Freeman, for an order declaring the rule to he unconstitutional. Arguments were presented, but no ruling was handed down by the court.

title: NIXON AGREES TO STOP BOMBING BY U. S. IN CAMBODIA BY A UG. 15, WITH NEW RAIDS UP TO CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 President Nixon relayed assurances to Congress today that United States military activity in Cambodia would end by Aug. 15 and that he would seek Congressional approval if American military action was needed after that date.

title: Congress Told by Kolton Market Should Advance
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The head of the American Stock Exchange told Congress today that there were good reasons to be optimistic about an early upturn in stock prices and market activity.

title: PENN STATE ASKS E.C.A.C. CHANGES
description: Pennsylvania State University threatened yesterday to withdraw from the Eastern College Athletic Conference on July 1, 1974 unless its financial assessment is lowered and it receives more benefits from its membership.

title: Colson Confirms Backing Kennedy Inquiry but Denies Knowing of Hunt's C.I.A. Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Charles W. Colson, a former White House aide, confirmed today that he had authorized E. Howard Hunt Jr. to investigate activities of Senator Edward M. Kennedy during the summer of 1971.

title: Antiques: The Sharp Rise in WeatherVane Prices
description: The recent rash of weathervane thefts is rooted, no doubt, in the current public frenzy to own vintage American weather indicators either to have them spin in the wind on a rooftop or remain static on a wall indoors.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: HelpWanted Ad Index Leveled Off in Month
description: The helpwanted advertising index, an indicator of employment potential, leveled off in May, The Conference Board reported yesterday. The index held at 122 per cent of the 1967 base period last month, the same as in April but 26 points higher than May, 1972, level.

title: A SAVING DRIVE URGEDBY NIXON INENERGY PLAN
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 29President Nixon announced today his plan to meet the nation's energy needs. It included a voluntary conservation drive in which the Federal Government would set the example, expansion of research to find new energy sources and Government reorganization to give higher priority to energy matters.

title: Rep. Bell, Nixon Friend, Warns on Impeachment
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 29Representative Alphonso Bell said today that if all the points about Watergate raised by dismissed White House counsel John W. Dean 3d were not satisfactorily answered by the Administration, he expected impeachment proceedings to begin in Congress.

title: Major League Leaders
description: BATTING

title: Baldwin Enunciates Ray Charles's Soul
description: James Baldwin, an only occasional visitor from France in the last couple of years, was explaining the other day how he had come to write the dramatic and narrative setting for the concert that Ray Charles will present tomorrow night in Carnegie Hall as part of the Newport Jazz Festival.

title: MESKILL BATTLING UTILITIES ON RATES
description: HARTFORD, June 29  Gov. Thomas J. Meskill suggested today that two powerful utility companies in Connecticut were seeking rate increases at a time when they might already be subsidizing companion utility companies in Massachusetts, where lower rates are charged the consumers.

title: Dr. Alphonso Castagno Led African Studies Center
description: BOSTON, June 29 (AP)Dr. Alphonso A. Castagno, director of the African Studies Center at Boston University, died yesterday of cancer at the Boston University Medical Center. He was 52 years old and lived in Brookline.

title: R. W. Pressprich Announces a Cut In Its Operations
description: R. W. Pressprich & Co., Inc., a New York Stock Exchange member firm founded in 1909, said yesterday it had cut back trading operations because of financial conditions in, the securities industry.

title: A Fall From Rome
description: When Lepidus, Antony and Octavian, later to'be Caesar Augustus, had won the civil war and taken povier in Rome, they compiled proscription lists of persons to be killed in order to secure serenity in a turbulent state. It was an occasion for settling old scores in blood. Each of the three new masters of Rome fattened the death lists with the names of his foes, and in the purge that followed many who had been the best of Rome perished.

title: Rossetti,With Reform Aid, Renamed Democratic Leader in Manhattan
description: In a rare display of unity, the Manhattan Democratic organization unanimously elected former Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti yesterday to another twoyear term as county leader.

title: United Brands Appoints
description: Harvey W. Johnson has been lected a vice president of United Brands Company, it was announced yesterday. Also named corporate vice presidents were Anthony G. DePalma, T. W. Klitsie, Ronald R. Berkey and. John Troost. All are officers of the Banana Group or of the Diversified Group. John A. Taylor, president of the Banana Group and a senior vice president of the company, has been elected a director.

title: COUNCIL STUDIES PRICE RISE CURB
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Cost of Living Council Is examining closely various ways to require businesses to absorb part of their cost Increases rather than pass them on ta customers by increasing prices.

title: OilExport Countries Ask Development of Industries
description: VIENNA, June 29The world's major oil exporting countries have agreed to use their leverage in the energy crisis to obtain heavy industrial investments from developed of the world market for industrial goods.

title: Bailey Clients Tell Of a Cache of GoldOn Missile Range
description: LAS CRUCES, N.M., June 29 (AP)A number of clients of F. Lee Bailey, the Boston lawyer, say that they have found a cache of gold bars worth millions of dollars in a cave on the White Sands Missile Range.

title: NIXON AGREES TO STOP BOMBING BY U. S. IN CAMBODIA BY AUG. 15, WITH NEW RAIDS UP TO CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 President Nixon relayed assurances to Congress today that United States military activity in Cambodia would end by Aug. 15 and that he would seek Congressional approval if American military action was needed after that date.

title: Chilean Revolt Crushed As Army Backs Allende
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 29 Rebel troops seized control of the downtown area this morning and sprayed the Defense Ministry and the presidential palace with machinegun fire before being put down by armed forces loyal to President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The House Foreign Affairs Committee has voted unanimously to repeal the longstanding Hickenlooper amendment to the basic foreign aid law that requires a cutoff in United States aid to any country that expropriates a United States company without compensation.

title: 50c FARE ON PATH IS NEARING REALITY
description: A 50cent fare on PATH, the Port Authority's commuter railroad connecting Newark and Jersey City with Manhattan, moved closer to being imposed yesterday when Governor Cahill and Governor Rockefeller approved the minutes of the authority's June 13 meeting, thus passing up a chance to veto the increase.

title: H.E.W. to Revise School Aid Code On Desegregation
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced plans today to revise eligibility standards for school desegregation so that five previously disqualified cities could qualify for Federal funds.

title: Peep Show Licensing Is Struck Down
description: A city law that required the licensing of peep shows was declared unconstitutional yesterday by Judge Morris E. Lasker in Federal District Court here.

title: Consumer Notes
description: July Fourth always seems to start in New York about June 25, to judge by the barrage of fireworks heard, even though all fireworks except those used by permit for display purposes are outlawed by many states, including New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and all of New England.

title: For Allende, 31 Months of Crisesand Survival
description: In his 31 tumultuous months in power in Chile, President Salvador Allende Gossens has survived crisis after crisis as the Western Hemisphere's only elected Marxist leader.

title: Little Rock Board Finally Approves School Settlement
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 29 (UPI)  The Little Rock desegregation case, the nation's first school integration crisis, has been settled.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: Major League Box Scores

title: JERSEY WILL TRY COXSON SUSPECT
description: CAMDEN, June 29Thomas J. Shusted, Camden County Prosecutor, said today Federal authorities had indicated New Jersey would be given priority in prosecuting Ronald Harvey, a suspect in the slaying of Major B. Coxson.

title: Nuclear Test in Nevada
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 29 (AP)A nuclear device with a yield range of between 20,000 and 200,000 tons of TNT has been detonated underground at the Nevada Test Site near here. An Atomic Energy Commission spokesman said there was no radiation leakage and no reports the explosion had been felt outside the test site.

title: Italian Communist Chief Has an Island Problem
description: ROME, June 29Piana, a windswept islet off the northwestern coast of Sardinia that is a third the size of Central Park in New York, has been causing trouble for the leader of the Italian Communist party, Enrico Berlinguer.

title: Football Transactions
description: NEW YORK GIANTSStoned Rich Glover, Nebraska defensive tackle, thirdround draft choice.

title: Chile at a Glance
description: GEOGRAPHYChile's 286,397 square miles are mainly deserts and pleasant valleys compressed between the Pacific Ocean and the Andes. The country has 2,485 miles of coast and an average width of 110 miles.
